The gentleman above shelters the host of yin, like a hut. Should the stripping reach its limit and consume the fruit, he would lose his own shelter. In the end, stripping yang is self-stripping. Thus the Great Sage transformed into a hut-like shrine to halt the stripping, then transformed into Erlang to merge with him, then entered Erlang’s shrine to show that the Great Sage’s shrine was Erlang’s shrine, and Erlang’s shrine was the Great Sage’s shrine—thereby making it clear. Hence the words: *“Sir, do not clamor—the shrine now bears the surname Sun.”* To strip Sun’s hut is to strip Yang’s hut; Yang’s hut is Sun’s hut. Thus the great fruit warns petty men not to consume it, and one should follow the times and halt.

Yet the tail was difficult to conceal, standing erect behind as a flagpole—another layer of subtlety. When gentlemen evade peril and withdraw from the world, it is better to act first than last. If all others go first and I alone lag behind, I miss the moment and court disaster. Thus to vanish without a trace is the ultimate withdrawal. To withdraw with the tail exposed leaves traces for prying eyes. Hence the *Hexagram Dun*’s first line: *“Withdrawal with the tail—danger.”* The Great Sage, at the *Hexagram Gou*, withdrew in accordance with heaven’s Dao of concealment, yet even so could not escape the peril of tail-withdrawal. Who recognizes the danger of tail-withdrawal?

The Immortal Master specifically uses the tail to illustrate the peril of tail-withdrawal. Yet withdrawal must not expose the tail, and stripping must not reach the tail. Now Erlang’s stripping has reached its peak above, even touching the tail—he should be warned to halt swiftly and turn back.

The Great Sage’s mouth became the shrine’s gate, fit for offerings but not for pursuit; his teeth became the door leaves, venerable and indestructible; his tongue became the bodhisattva, manifesting from compassion; his eyes became the window lattice, veiling brilliance with obscurity. Erlang sought first to smash the lattice, then to kick in the door leaves—envying its clarity and clamping its mouth shut.

The Great Sage was then in his tiger-transformation, yet the crowd instead raised the demon-revealing mirror, bowing humbly and spitting out slanderous words—an age-old pattern, nothing strange. The episode where he summons Li Hu and Zhang Long vividly portrays the postures of bribery and gluttony; such is the Immortal Master’s artistry in exposition.

Yet the crux lies solely in the Great Sage’s *observing and advancing*, and the Little Sage’s *stripping and coming*. What comes constitutes what goes; what is small constitutes what is great; observation is what constitutes stripping. Thus the sage looks up to observe the patterns of heaven, looks down to examine the principles of earth. Tracing origins and returning to endings, he knows the discourse of life and death. With spirit he knows the future; with knowledge he stores the past—thus he illuminates transformations and practices the workings of ghosts and spirits.

Those of old who skillfully managed petty men always followed the momentum of their expansion, remained still outside affairs, and gradually halted their advance. Thus the *Book of Changes* says: *“Follow and halt them—this is observing the image.”* In the time of stripping, follow and halt to observe heaven’s waxing and waning, the fullness of yin and the emptiness of yang. The gentleman follows heaven’s course and halts. He does not dare to be rigidly upright: following is how he halts, and halting is how he acts. Stripping does not advance; in *Fu*, advancing is favorable—there is no second way. The great fruit is not eaten—this is halting. Why is it not eaten? The fruit is yang. Yang cannot be stripped and advanced by yin; thus when stripping reaches its limit, it turns to *Fu*. Petty men lose their shelter and also follow the times to halt.

This is why Guanyin deploys Erlang: precisely to observe heaven’s course and follow its expanding momentum to gradually observe its halting—not to aid yin in dissolving yang. She does not use the pure vase to strike the Great Sage but has Laozi use the diamond chisel: precisely to remain still outside affairs, follow heaven’s course, and halt the stripping—to halt yin and rescue yang.

Yet stripping and halting are both heaven’s course. Following its stripping and halting it are both observing heaven’s course. In truth, the Great Sage’s observation is his own observation, merely borrowing Guanyin to expound the principle; his halting is his own halting, merely borrowing Laozi to reveal the meaning; his stripping is his own stripping, merely borrowing Erlang to follow its course. In truth, the stripping is not the Great Sage’s own stripping—he merely borrows the Great Sage to clarify heaven’s Dao of stripping.

To reproach others is to have each strip themselves as warning of their peril. Knowing the stripping and following its halt, knowing the following of its halt and its necessary return, knowing its necessary return—thus the Dao is made clear.

Guanyin pressed her palms together and said, “This humble monk requests that Your Majesty accompany the Dao Ancestor to the Southern Gate of Heaven to see for yourselves the truth of the matter.” This is precisely to observe the truth of heaven’s Dao in yin and yang. The Two Sages encircled the Great Sage but had yet to capture him—“the great fruit remains uneaten.” The pure vase was not used, preserving its immaculate clarity so that the body does not engage, a divine observation.

The Bodhisattva asked Laozi, “What weapons do you have?” Laozi replied, “I have, I have, I have.” From his left arm he took down a ring, called the *Diamond Chisel*, also named the *Diamond Noose*. This is the “golden hook” and “jade hook” of the *Ding* hexagram’s sixth line, fifth and top lines. The subtlety lies in the threefold “I have, I have, I have.” For the *Ding*’s fifth line, the hollow center is yellow, representing the ruler as solid. The fifth is empty, taking the second line’s solidity as its own solidity—thus Guanyin asks from her emptiness, and Laozi answers from his fullness.

All things move by their feet, but the *Ding* alone moves by its ears. The sixth line’s hollow center is virtue, forming the yellow ear-hook. Adding ears responds to the second line’s firm hardness. Like threading with a golden hook, it must remain consistent from beginning to end. In steadfastness, it is beneficial—thus solid yet hollow, hollow yet round, forming a ring. The top line’s jade hook, with yang on the left residing in yin, hard yet yielding, is tempered like jade, warm yet solemn. Thus, from the left arm comes the *Diamond Chisel*, gold conjoined with jade.

Why can it noose all things and be called a noose? The fifth line is hollow at its center, and emptiness can contain. The top is the elder, the fifth the ruler—thus it is Laozi. Only Laozi’s emptiness within and solidity without can subdue the upright and halt change. Erlang could not consume the Great Sage’s fruit, but the Great Sage could consume Laozi’s center, striking his heavenly crown and stumbling. Laozi’s following and halting is the Great Sage’s own following and halting. The hound’s bite sent him sprawling again—Erlang’s following and halting is the Great Sage’s own following and halting. The hound is *xu* (the dog), the eleventh earthly branch. The hexagram of the ninth month has *kun* within and *gen* without, following the season to halt. To act against the season is to halt in motion; to follow the season in halting is to move in stillness. The Great Sage’s entrapment and halt is precisely his own halting and movement.

The Seven Sages are the seven yin lines returning from *fu*. Piercing the *pipa* bones so he could no longer transform—this is the *Bo* hexagram. Halting the top line so the great fruit remains uneaten preserves the yang within the fruit to turn and restore *Kai Tai*. It halts where it cannot but halt. The halting without change is the Great Sage’s wondrous use of the primordial, not Erlang’s ability to pierce and restrain him.

Those who study the Dao and can observe its subtleties, who can establish themselves in the formless and wordless, embody Guanyin’s divine marvel—acting in yin without revealing it to others. In observation, the meaning is vast indeed!

The Immortal Master used the Great Sage and Lesser Sage to elucidate the Dao of the Golden Elixir, while I, with the Confucian Dao, elucidate the Lesser Sage and Great Sage, though I have not exhausted its wonders. I cannot but conclude: the Lesser Sage follows heaven and embodies *kun* yin. Viewed through the primordial Dao, in the later heaven it is the male. The Great Sage defies heaven and embodies *qian* yang. Viewed through the primordial Dao, in the later heaven it is the female. To follow heaven is to rebel against the Heavenly Palace; to punish rebellion is to embrace yin softness. Laozi, as the master of harmony, instead aids yin in restraining yang—the Golden Elixir operates in reversal. Thus, how can I speak of its wonders? I merely observe.

**Chapter Seven: The Great Sage Escapes the Eight-Trigrams Furnace; The Mind-Ape is Tamed Beneath the Five Elements Mountain**

Wu Yizi said: This concludes the preceding discussion of the primordial True Unity’s *qi*, which arises from Nonbeing into Being, from Being returns to Nonbeing, from Nonbeing once more emerges, and from this re-emergence attains Supreme Harmony. Supreme Harmony gives rise to *Qian*, *Qian* to *Gou*, *Gou* to *Pi*, *Pi* to *Kun*, and *Kun* to *Fu*—endlessly cycling, beginning anew, enduring through ten thousand kalpas.

The primordial is refined within the later heaven; the later heaven conceals the marvels of the primordial. The Immortal Master revealed these truths to the world through the later heaven’s Eight Trigrams and Five Phases, that people might observe, awaken, and cultivate this singular *qi* to transcend birth and death.

The Ancestor of Unity is Nonbeing; Nonbeing generates the One, and the One extends to Ten. The sequence of yin-yang circulation—One, Two, Three, Four, Five—is the true reckoning. Six, Seven, Eight, Nine, Ten are but their complements. The reckoning culminates at Five, yet Five resides within One, Two, Three, Four; Three and Four reside within Two; and Two resides within One. Grasp the One, and the hundred follow; perform ten thousand virtues, yet never depart from the One. The hundred, thousand, myriad, and billion never stray from One or Five.

Speaking of the numerical flow of the Five Phases: Heaven-One, Earth-Two; Heaven-Three, Earth-Four; Heaven-Five, Earth-Six; Heaven-Seven, Earth-Eight; Heaven-Nine, Earth-Ten. Speaking of the paired reckoning of yin and yang: *Qian*-One, *Dui*-Two, *Li*-Three, *Zhen*-Four, *Xun*-Five, *Kan*-Six, *Gen*-Seven, *Kun*-Eight—none depart from the Supreme Ultimate. Thus, doubling them yields the sixty-four hexagrams; applying them to affairs yields the three hundred eighty-four lines; accumulating them, all things arise. The number one thousand five hundred twenty remains bound to the Eight Trigrams; the Eight Trigrams to the Five Phases; the Five Phases to yin and yang; yin and yang to the Supreme Ultimate; and the Supreme Ultimate to Nonbeing. Thus, the Eight Trigrams and Five Phases are ultimately One. The Immortal Master speaks of both, each bearing profound meaning.

When he speaks of the Eight Trigrams, it is that cultivators may observe their roots within the paired trigrams—just as I, in the opening chapter, presented a diagram to verify the Dao. The Immortal Master long ago made this clear. Let us first clarify the purport of the Great Sage’s escape from the furnace.

In the elixir practice, there is the tripod and the furnace: the upper is the tripod, the lower the furnace. The meaning of the tripod was subtly indicated by the Immortal Master in the preceding chapter, lifting the word “observe” to prompt discernment—not through convoluted spirits and gods, nor can its marvels be fathomed. The meaning of the furnace likewise cannot be fathomed through such convolutions. For within the later heaven’s Eight Trigrams lies the primordial *qi*. The Great Sage, with divine insight, grasped its firing times.

Lord Lao, wielding the Central Yellow of the tripod, struck the Great Sage’s primordial spirit to subdue him, relying on Erlang’s true earth and the hound’s steadfastness—like an eagle seizing a hare. Yet without the refining fire’s work, he could not be fully subdued. Nor could ordinary fire or the fire and thunder deities’ flames forcibly tame him; only the true fire of the Eight-Trigrams Furnace could refine him into elixir. As the Perfected One of Purple Yang said: *“There is a natural true firing time—what need for kindling or bellows?”* Thus, the deities of the fire and thunder departments could not harm him; only Lord Lao could lead him away, cast him into the Eight-Trigrams Furnace, and refine the elixir with civil and martial fire.

The Great Sage, entering the furnace, burrowed beneath the *Xun* palace. *Xun* is the eldest daughter, the way of softness—manifesting the image of King Wen imprisoned in Youli. Only through yielding compliance could he unfold the primordial Eight Trigrams, ultimately unharmed. Wind stirred the smoke, scorching his eyes red—yet this revealed injury, while concealing brilliance nurtured obscurity, rightly employing clarity without harm. Hence it is said: *“Later called ‘fiery eyes and golden pupils.’”*

When the firing time was complete, the furnace was opened to retrieve the elixir. Suddenly, a sound arose from the furnace’s head, light blazed forth, and with a crash, the Eight-Trigrams Furnace was overturned. The Great Sage bolted outward like a white-browed tiger or a one-horned dragon—these two images of dragon and tiger now united as one. Lord Lao tumbled headfirst, barely escaping. Alas!

Marvelous, wondrous indeed! Earlier, Lord Lao struck the Great Sage’s Heavenly Crown with the crucible’s handle, causing him to stumble; now, Lord Lao tumbled headfirst while the Great Sage broke free. The former was the Golden Elixir’s compliance within the crucible to form the embryo; this is the Golden Elixir’s reversal from the furnace to cast off the embryo. The immortal master’s verse, *“The Primordial Body perfectly accords with the Prior Heaven,”* precisely depicts the marvel of elixir completion—each word a pearl of wisdom. The most crucial points of discernment lie in the phrases *“styled the First Mystery,”* *“not lead and mercury,”* and *“returning to transformation.”* For the mystery within the Mystery defies exhaustive speech. This is called *“styled the First Mystery,”* yet there remains something beyond; *“not lead and mercury,”* yet lead and mercury are still required. This is said to *“return to transformation,”* yet further transformation remains.

Laozi said: *“Mystery upon mystery—the gateway to all wonders.”* The first Mystery is already so intricate as to elude comprehension, and the second Mystery is even more so. Thus, the immortal master particularly emphasizes the phrase *“greatly disturbing the Heavenly Palace.”* Another verse contains two *“again”*s, precisely capturing the essence of *“Mystery upon Mystery.”* Why, then, did he once more wreak havoc in the Heavenly Palace? When the Prior Heaven’s true *yi*-essence enters the Eight Trigrams, it follows the timing of the Posterior Heaven; when it emerges beyond the Eight Trigrams, it precedes Heaven, and Heaven cannot oppose it. It contends with Heaven for its seat, unbound by Heaven’s dominion.

Earlier, the Great Sage’s disturbance of the Heavenly Palace led to his tempering within the furnace—first movement, then stillness, the initial phase of the work. This is the first Mystery. Now, the Great Sage’s renewed disturbance of the Heavenly Palace, followed by his confinement beneath the mountain, is stillness at its extreme giving rise to movement, and movement returning to stillness—the latter phase of the work. This is the Mystery upon Mystery. Yet while the first disturbance could be subdued by Lord Lao’s crucible, this one could only be quelled by Tathāgata’s palm. The former relied on the oppositional Eight Trigrams, the latter on the clustered Five Phases; though their methods of restraint differ, their wondrous function is one.

Most marvelous are the four lines of another verse. Readers must understand: the ape is paired with the heart, the heart is the ape—tightly bound and securely tethered, allowing no external pursuit. Thus, commentators on *Journey to the West* encapsulate the entire book with the four characters *“heart-ape, intent-horse,”* unaware that the ape is the Dao-body. The ape’s nature is slow, governing stillness; the monkey’s nature is restless, governing movement. This illustrates the Dao-body’s alternation between movement and stillness, corresponding to the human heart’s alternation between movement and stillness—not that the ape and monkey *are* the human heart. When the immortal master’s outline speaks of the *“heart-ape,”* saying the heart is the ape or monkey, the meaning is profound and demands the reader’s discernment.

If the heart is simply the ape or monkey, the expression is plain and shallow—why then the phrase *“profound meaning”*? For the Dao-body has stillness and movement, and the cultivator likewise has stillness and movement. Movement at its extreme must return to stillness, stillness at its extreme must give rise to movement, and movement at its extreme must return to stillness. The entire process of the Golden Elixir is contained herein—this is *“Mystery upon mystery, the gateway to all wonders.”* Hence, it is called *“profound meaning.”*

Why does the third line speak of uniting movement with stillness without mentioning the ape’s heart uniting with intent, but only the heart? Because in the Golden Elixir’s work, at the moment when stillness at its extreme gives rise to movement, one must subdue the monkey’s movement and pacify the ape’s stillness to accomplish the Great Dao. Thus, before the horse and ape unite, before heart and intent harmonize, one cannot be tightly bound and securely tethered but must be guided externally. Only when horse and ape unite, when heart and intent harmonize, can one be tightly bound and securely tethered, allowing no external pursuit.

The Great Sage’s transformation into three heads and six arms, dancing within the core, enduring through all ages, and eluding the grasp of divine generals—this precisely depicts the marvel of the Dao-body’s transformations. Those who interpret this as concerning the heart err greatly. Yet the Dao is no ordinary Dao; those who cultivate and subdue it become Tathāgatas. One must thoroughly investigate its origins before proceeding.

The Great Sage himself declared his spirit’s primordial root-source as the essence of the Prior Heaven, no mundane thing—this alone emboldened him to contend for precedence. In a single phrase, he revealed that while Heaven is of the Prior Heaven, so too is he. Thus, he dared to contend for precedence without yielding.

When the Great Sage was lured into submission, it was precisely the moment for the Golden Elixir’s inception. The five fleshy pillars and a wisp of azure *qi* corresponded to the time when heart and intent clustered the Five Phases. The inscription *“The Great Sage Equaling Heaven was here”* on the central pillar is what the Buddha referred to as: *“Within the cosmos, between heaven and earth, there lies a precious secret in the mountain of form—not in the heart or kidneys, but in the mysterious pass of the single aperture.”* Thus, he could not escape Tathāgata’s palm and remained within the Five Phases.

When the Buddha flipped his palm and thrust him beyond the Western Heaven’s gate, transforming the Five Phases Mountain to press him down, he clearly demonstrated that the path of the Golden Elixir must cluster the Five Phases to crystallize from emptiness. The human heart, attaining this alignment, gains a foundation and does not fall into oblivion. As *The Great Learning* states: *“Know where to rest, and you will be settled; settled, you will be tranquil; tranquil, you will be at peace; at peace, you may act without striving, gradually refining and transcending.”* The chapter’s subjugation of the demonic monkey and the grand assembly to pacify Heaven precisely embodies the principle of settled tranquility and peace.

*The Awakening to Reality* says:
*“Swallowing saliva and absorbing qi are human practices,
Only with substance can transformation arise.
If the crucible lacks the true seed,
It is like boiling water and fire in an empty cauldron.”*
The Great Sage is the true seed. For activity is the function of non-activity, and non-activity is the root of activity. One must first engage in activity and then return to non-activity to complete the wondrous path of the supreme, utterly real Dao. If one begins with non-activity and pursues stillness and stability, the foundation of life will not be firm, and one will ultimately fall into oblivion.

Should one engage in activity yet fail to transcend, the ground of inherent nature remains unemptied, still bound within the Three Realms. The Perfected Lord of Purple Yang states:

*“At first, with effort, few perceive its worth,
Only when effortless do all acknowledge its grace.
Though effortless seems the wondrous key,
Who knows that effort is the root’s embrace?”*

The one who acts is the Mind-Ape beneath Five Phases Mountain. The one who acts yet abides in non-action is the settled Mind-Ape beneath Five Phases Mountain. Throughout the text, from the monkey’s transformation into a spirit to the final passages where “monkey” recurs without mention of “ape,” it precisely reveals the principle that only after taming the monkey can the ape’s stillness be attained. As for Five Phases Mountain taking root and sealing seamlessly, responding to the breath of mortals—this is the Golden Elixir swallowed into the belly. Hunger met with iron pellets, thirst with molten bronze—both are of the metal class. The ape is metal within water, embodying the principle of like aiding like, is this not the work of nurturing unity and embracing the One?

Thus, observing the Tathāgata’s palm-turning subjugation of the ape, one may awaken to the truth that within the postnatal Five Phases lies the prenatal true essence of the One, requiring no distant quest—easily subdued as the turning of a palm.

**Chapter Eight: The Buddha Composes the Sūtra to Transmit Ultimate Bliss; Guanyin Receives the Edict to Journey to Chang’an**

Wu Yizi says: The first seven chapters elucidate the Great Way of the Golden Elixir, which is cultivated through refining the prenatal true qi of the One. Its alchemical method, origins, firing times, beginning and end, secret techniques for commencement—all are encompassed without omission. Those who study the Dao, through silent observation and careful reflection, with a master’s guidance, may together realize bodhi and ascend to immortality.

The Immortal Master feared that the world’s foolish might believe immortals and buddhas are born, not attainable by ordinary beings through cultivation; or that enlightenment lies solely in the mind, attainable by oneself alone. Thus, the following text presents Xuanzang as an exemplar, and Sun Wukong, Zhu Wuneng, Sha Wujing, and the Dragon Horse as agents of transformation—demonstrating that immortality and buddhahood are within everyone’s reach, not innate or fixed; that mutual aid, not solitary practice, is the path.

Yet the text’s trials and monsters, its perils and hardships—spanning one hundred and eight thousand miles, eighty-one ordeals, and fourteen years—may well evoke fear, doubt, and hesitation, leading one to believe such a journey impossible, such tribulations inescapable, such merit unattainable. If so, then *Journey to the West* would become an obstacle, deterring seekers.

The Immortal Master’s intent in writing is to reveal that without true transmission, one faces endless trials and extreme suffering; with true transmission, one attains eternal bliss. Hence the chapter’s theme: *“The Buddha composes the sūtra to transmit ultimate bliss.”* It aims to rescue those undergoing trials with what is most proximate and effortless. For with this sūtra’s existence, one may avoid the remoteness of one hundred and eight thousand miles, the perils of eighty-one ordeals, and the protraction of fourteen years.

The opening chapter’s bold declaration—*“Journey to the West to release from tribulation”*—makes clear that the journey’s purpose is liberation, not the imposition of hardship. Yet the trials and tribulations arise because Xuanzang has not yet received true transmission. One might assume enlightenment comes only after reaching Vulture Peak, meeting the Buddha, and receiving the sūtra. How then does he shed his mortal form and attain realization at Cloud-Soaring Crossing?

It is not known that the Bodhisattva, upon receiving the edict to seek a monk, had already bestowed five treasures, instructed him to subdue his three disciples, and prepared his mount. Xuanzang had secretly received the *Tight-Fillet* incantation. The transmission of the true sūtra had already occurred when the Bodhisattva set forth for Chang’an—there was no need to reach the Western Heaven to attain the Dao.

The text’s insistence on the journey to the West merely points to the source of the Great Way; the one hundred and eight thousand miles, eighty-one ordeals, and fourteen years illustrate the critical importance of vigilance against danger, the stages of progress, and the firing times. The distance is not inherently far—it arises from insufficient effort in bearing the load, from taking the easy path of haste. Recognizing that one hundred and eight thousand miles are not truly distant, one sees the Dao before one’s eyes; the sudden awakening arrives with a single somersault.

The difficulty is not inherent—it arises from delusion by worldly ties, from the unevenness of leaks and gaps. Understanding that eighty-one ordeals are easily resolved, one finds boundless joy; the greatly courageous need only a single strike of the golden cudgel to conclude them.

The duration is not inherently long—it arises from ignorance of the firing times of medicinal substances and the subtleties of weights and measures. Knowing that fourteen years are not truly long, one may swiftly attain the sūtra; the adept, with the golden fillet’s restraint, is already within my grasp.

Without experiencing the extremity of suffering, one cannot know the truth of ultimate bliss; without enduring the bitterness of extreme suffering, one cannot know the joy of ultimate bliss. Without traversing one hundred and eight thousand miles, eighty-one ordeals, and fourteen years of remoteness, peril, and duration, one cannot comprehend that nine nines reduce to one nine, two treasuries to one treasury, five thousand forty-eight days to a single firing time.

This sūtra originates from the *Yinfu Jing* and the *Daode Jing*, composed by the Yellow Emperor and Laozi. The Immortal Master merely entrusted the Buddha with expounding its teachings, the Tang era with disseminating its practice, Xuanzang with exemplifying its standard, and *Journey to the West* with unfolding its meaning—using allegory to reveal its essence.

If one were to insist that only by journeying to the West to fetch the sūtra, as Xuanzang did, can the Dao be attained, then the ancient past would lack buddhas and immortals, and future generations would be cut off from the seeds of buddhahood and immortality. Such a path would be excessively complex, difficult, and abstruse—unattainable by all—rather than the simplest, easiest, and most immediate Way, accessible to all. This would contravene the Buddha’s compassionate intent in transmitting the sūtra.

The Buddha’s transmission of the sūtra encompasses two wondrous meanings: for those who have yet to attain the Dao, it directs them to journey west like Xuanzang to fetch the sūtra; for those who have already attained the Dao, it guides them, like awakening, to reach the West and return to the Buddha. Though the methods differ, the transmission is one, and the transmission leads to one Ultimate Bliss. The subtlety of the sūtra’s essence lies in the discernment of the enlightened mind—thus, only the divine insight of Guanyin Bodhisattva can truly uphold its practice.

The opening verse speaks of those who meditate in dark contemplation, wasting effort in vain pursuits: like "grinding a brick to make a mirror," it cannot reflect form; like "piling snow for grain," it cannot sate hunger. They toil until old age without achievement, leading the young astray. Such sayings as "a hair swallowing the great sea" or "a mustard seed containing Mount Sumeru" are baseless claims—even the "Golden-Headed Ascetic" would but smile in quiet amusement. If one awakens to this truth, they "transcend the Ten Grounds and the Three Vehicles"; if one remains mired in delusion, they fall into the "Four Births and Six Paths," trapped in the wheel of rebirth for ten thousand kalpas, unable to escape.

Who can hear the spring message of the cuckoo’s call at "Cliff of No-Thought" beneath the "Shadeless Tree," suddenly shattering the dawn dream? Thus, the "path to Caoxi is perilous" and impassable; the "clouds of Vulture Peak are deep" and unreachable. Boundless and formless, it defies grasp. Here, the voices of old friends fade into silence—yet know this: amid the "thousand-foot ice cliffs," the "five-petaled lotus blooms," rising transcendent, its fragrance curling through ancient curtains and lingering upon timeworn silks.

If one can "discern the source and flow" herein, they will perceive the Dragon King’s three treasures and may then obtain the elixir, becoming immortal and buddha. How could mere meditation at the gate of Chan ever glimpse its depths? For Chan seeks only within the nature of the essence, neglecting the root of life—wasting endless effort until, in old age, one merges into the great transformation. How lamentable! How pitiful! They neither recognize the affair of the "Mind-Ape beneath the Five Phases Mountain" nor understand the matter of "taming the Mind-Ape beneath the Five Phases Mountain."

Thus, when the Tathāgata returned to the Thunderclap Jeweled Monastery, he addressed all buddhas and bodhisattvas: "With my profound, subtle, and wondrous compassion and prajñā, I survey the Three Realms. The fundamental nature of the root is ultimately quiescent, identical to the emptiness of space, utterly devoid of anything." By "fundamental nature of the root," he means the original face. Though it is difficult to directly enter quiescence, by focusing on the nature of the essence in cultivation, one may, upon attaining the Dao, perceive that the original nature is ultimately quiescent—"identical to the emptiness of space, utterly devoid of anything." "Identical to the emptiness of space" does not mean inert emptiness; "utterly devoid of anything" does not mean absolute nothingness.

The matter of subduing the rebellious monkey is known to none in the Three Realms. This matter is most true and most wondrous, neither quiescent nor inertly empty—it is merely that "names arise with the beginning of birth and death," and the dharma’s appearance accords with this. If one claims the original nature is inherently empty and fails to recognize this matter, then it is not my profound teaching but merely clinging to quiescence, which is quiescence alone.

Laozi said: "The nameless is the beginning of heaven and earth; the named is the mother of the myriad things." The nameless is death, the beginning of heaven and earth; the named is birth, entering into the Five Phases. The rebellious monkey is "named birth and death’s beginning," its dharma-appearance deviating from the root source of its original nature—thus it cannot escape the Tathāgata’s palm or transcend beyond the Five Phases.

In the Buddha’s Ullambana jeweled basin, a hundred rare flowers and a thousand wondrous fruits are arrayed—this is the "named, mother of the myriad things," the image of returning to the origin after purity. This inquiry is the meaning of the Buddha’s words: "I possess a treasure, hidden within the mountain of form—do any of you recognize it?" Thus, the assembly entreated the Tathāgata to "clearly reveal the root," and the Tathāgata "proclaimed the true fruit," unfolding the wondrous mysteries of the Three and Five. The Chan mind is the bright moon; the true nature embraces heaven—this is the true sūtra of the Three Treasuries of heaven, earth, and spirits.

In sum: the Three Treasuries are but the Three and Five; the Three and Five are but the One and Five; the One and Five are but the One. This One is the direct path of cultivating truth, the gate of true goodness. This sūtra, originating in the West, must await retrieval from the East—only one with the silent observation and secret discernment of a great being like Guanyin can obtain it.

The Tathāgata said: "On this journey, you must tread carefully, not traveling in the clouds but keeping to half-cloud, half-mist, meticulously noting the distance of the path." This means the cultivator must proceed with grounded steps, advancing gradually, not indulging in empty fantasies or skipping stages. Yet one must also be fluid and spiritually attuned, free from attachment, for within it lies the sequence of fire-times and stages of practice—these must be carefully remembered and not transgressed.

Among the five treasures is "a brocade kāṣāya robe." The kāṣāya is the garment of non-defilement. "Brocade" is woven from deep threads of five colors. In the five colors, it is blue, yellow, red, white, and black; in the five virtues, it is benevolence, righteousness, propriety, wisdom, and trust; in the Five Phases, it is metal, wood, water, fire, and earth; in the five relationships, it is ruler-minister, father-son, husband-wife, elder-younger brothers, and friends; in the five directions, it is east, west, south, north, and center; in the five tones, it is gong, shang, jue, zhi, and yu; in the five flavors, it is salty, bitter, sour, spicy, and sweet; in the five seasons, it is spring, summer, autumn, winter, and the four seasons—extending to the five officials, five grains, and more, all of which cannot be exhaustively described. Yet all are but the One and Five, all are the treasure of "a single brocade kāṣāya robe."

"A 'nine-ringed monastic staff,' the rings symbolizing the image of perfect completion without end. In the principles of numerology, it is cyclical recurrence; in yin and yang, it is the ebb and flow; in the firing times of alchemy, it is the nine rings; in substance and function, it is the interlocking chain; in the four corners, it is encirclement; in spirits and deities, it is contraction and extension; in Heaven and Earth, it is their efficacy; in life and death, it is beginning and end; in the four directions, it is unimpeded passage; in the unfathomable concealment and revelation, it is wisdom; in adapting to circumstances and responding to opportunities, it is expedient means—all residing within the One and Five, all the treasure of 'a nine-ringed monastic staff.'

These two treasures—one embodying completeness, the other efficacy—are why those who come here with steadfast resolve to seek the sutras may don the robe to escape the cycle of rebirth and wield the staff to avoid harm from poisons.

Then there are the three bands, 'called the *tightening bands*, though identical in form, each serves a different purpose.' There are also the three incantations: 'Gold,' 'Tight,' and 'Forbid.' Gold signifies restraint, the measure of advance and retreat. Through gold’s restraint, none may evade its control. One is used to subdue the Great Sage, employing restraint as the means; another to subdue the Black Bear, using non-greed as restraint; and another to subdue Sudhana, using virtuous relinquishment as restraint. Though their applications differ, the method of tight restraint remains the same. This is the esoteric essence of elixir refinement. When lesser practitioners hear of it, they cannot but laugh in derision, so the immortal master conceals rather than explicates it. Why? Those who cultivate the Dao must purge all worldly entanglements, remaining unstained by even a speck of dust. Gold is the first thing to be restrained—this accords with common understanding, and all would readily accept it as true. Yet few realize that if gold’s primary function were abandoned even for a moment, one would become unrestrained and uncontrollable, unable to guide others into one’s own gate. Thus, gold must be employed first, and restraint must be tight, to prevent the peril of transgression and recklessness. Why? Because gold is something all see and readily assent to, something that catches the eye and stirs the mind. Once the thought of gold arises, the eyes grow dim and the mind agitated, leaving no room for leniency—one cannot but submit to gold’s command. The Perfected One said: 'To seek the treasure of Heaven, one must use the wealth of the world.' This is the esoteric essence. Though gold is of a single nature, its uses differ, and the thoughts it evokes vary, yet the method of tight restraint remains constant. If the worldly abandon restraint and transgress bounds, the sage enacts golden statutes to restrain them—another method of establishing boundaries.

This revelation may strike some as far-fetched, prompting laughter, but observe the passage: 'If he will not submit to your command, give him this band. Once worn on the head, it will naturally take root in the flesh. Recite the appropriate incantation, and he will be brought into my fold.' The meaning is quite clear. Thus, even if one does not begrudge the use of gold, the 'Gold, Tight, Forbid' restraints do not contradict the earlier explanation of common principles. Those who grasp this—devotees at the foot of Vulture Peak, the Golden Summit Immortals, who seek the Dao with unwavering resolve—may attain this state within two or three years. This is the true teaching. Swift attainment of the Dao is indeed possible, though the fourteen-year period is not an immutable term.

Yet among these five items, three remain, still embodying the meaning of Three and Five—this must not be overlooked. From this point, Sha Wujing manifests.

This Sha Wujing is the most essential and wondrous aspect of the elixir path, though readers often misconstrue him. Liu Zongyuan wrote: 'In the mountains of the Western Sea, there is a water so weak and diffuse it cannot bear even a mustard seed, sinking only when it reaches the bottom. Thus it is called *Weak Water*.' Yang Xiong’s *Rhapsody on the Sweet Springs* speaks of 'the eastern glow illuminating the Eastern Sea, the western radiance shining upon the Flowing Sands.' Weak Water and Flowing Sands are actual place names in the Western Regions, but the immortal master employs them as metaphors: the passions are easily drowned, the foundation of inherent nature is hard to stabilize, and one must rely on true earth to solidify it. True earth is true intention; Flowing Sands are earth without constancy. True earth is formless yet pervades the nine palaces. Without it, water, metal, wood, and fire cannot harmonize—its efficacy is unparalleled, hence the name 'Sha Monk.'

As for the title 'Roll-Curtain General,' the 'shattering of the glass goblet at the Peach Banquet,' the 'once every seven days, a flying sword pierces my ribs,' and 'what choice was there but to seek sustenance from travelers'—these seem devoid of meaning, yet profound significance lies within. The curtain separates inner and outer, safeguarding integrity and modesty, yet he carelessly rolled it up without scruple. The 'Peach Banquet' is meant to foster joyous harmony. The 'glass goblet,' formed from a thousand years of distilled water, is the supreme treasure of the West, the sole means of fostering harmony. His lack of sincerity caused him to shatter it, forfeiting that harmony, profaning the treasure, and neglecting his duty—his offense was grave. The 'seven days' mark the return of Heaven’s will. In the quiet of night, reflecting on the hidden recesses of his own conduct, he felt remorse and pain as if pierced by a flying sword. Was he not merely consuming the flesh of the sutra-seekers, becoming a useless demon? His 'nine skulls' symbolize the true earth of the nine palaces, so water cannot sink them. 'The sutra-seeker will find use for them'—their wondrous application will be detailed when he is subdued.

Here, 'taking the sands as his surname,' he is named 'Sha Wujing,' 'enters the *sha* gate,' and 'purifies his mind and cleanses his thoughts, never again harming life.' From this, we know that to take refuge in the Pure Land, one must employ true intention and sincerity, avoiding carelessness that leads to harming life."

For the foundation of long life lies entirely in this earth’s harmonious union. Earth is the essential element in the refinement of the elixir—those who interpret Sha Wujing as pertaining to metal and water fail to grasp the true function of earth and merely speculate in vain.

From this point, Zhu Bajie manifests his form. The pig belongs to *hai*, and within *hai* resides *jia*-wood. Wood can generate fire, hence the term “speech-ability.” The character *hai* (亥) contains *yi* (乙), signifying gestation, and *er ren* (二人), representing male and female. With two heads and six bodies, it embodies the tenth month of pure yin, yet the principle of yang never wholly perishes, thus embodying the ceaseless cycle of generation. Without the harmonious forging and refinement of the golden elixir, it cannot be accomplished.

“Tianhe’s Marshal Tianpeng, having drunk, flirted with Chang’e.” *Peng* (蓬) signifies whirling without constancy, encountering the unpredictable—its nature is crooked yet upright, following righteousness while favoring metal. Wine is water-metal; upon meeting wood-metal, it spins without direction, and even Chang’e is toyed with. His true nature, akin to that of beasts, led him to “take the wrong path” and enter a pig’s womb. *Jia* is yang-wood, *mao* is yin-wood, so he was rightfully paired with the Second Sister of *mao*. “Before a year had passed, she died”—this reflects the principle of yang’s birth and yin’s demise. “All the cave’s possessions became mine to enjoy,” for within *hai*, *yi* gestates and receives emolument from *mao*. “Living by devouring others,” he indulged solely in wine and lust, “harming life” and taking lives, thus becoming a demon. Only when the Bodhisattva enlightened him did he “awaken as from a dream,” accept the precepts in earnest, and “sever the five pungent roots and three corpses,” hence the name “Zhu Bajie.”

From this point, the White Horse manifests his form.

From ancient times to the present, those who revere this tale as a guide take the ape as the heart and the horse as the mind. Yet if one claims the horse is the mind—since the heart is the essence of the mind, and the mind is the function of the heart—then all the wondrous and unfathomable feats, such as "Great Sage Equaling Heaven" wreaking havoc in the Heavenly Palace or the somersault cloud, should rightly be attributed to the White Horse. Why then are they solely ascribed to the ape? This reveals that the White Horse cannot be the mind.

The White Horse is a metal symbol, a dragon-horse. *Qian* represents the dragon and the horse. The horse is a creature of pure *Qian*, embodying the ceaseless vigor of *Qian*. Thus, those who cultivate the Dao must emulate the unrelenting diligence of *Qian*, possessing the great strength and burden-bearing capacity of the dragon-horse, only then can they journey to the West and obtain the scriptures. Ordinary horses, lacking such power, are inevitably hindered by Eagle Sorrow Gorge. If the horse were indeed the mind, would not those lesser horses also qualify? Yet why are they devoured by the dragon-horse, necessitating its presence?

However, another crucial principle must be clarified: for those who cultivate the Dao, taming the dragon is the foremost task. If one indulges in reckless abandon, they destroy their own luminous pearl, becoming a malevolent dragon. With unstable roots, how can one bear the Dao or travel far? Therefore, one must retreat into the deep abyss, conceal brilliance, and nurture obscurity, only then can their potential be properly harnessed. From this point, the Great Sage emerges from concealment.

The marvels of the innate true *yi* have been thoroughly expounded earlier, and need not be reiterated. To summarize clearly: wood, numbered three, resides in the East; fire, numbered two, resides in the South. Wood generates fire, and these two elements share the same palace, thus two and three combine to form five. *Wuneng* (*Hai*) unites water and fire as one family. Metal, numbered four, resides in the West; water, numbered one, resides in the North. Metal generates water, and these two elements share the same palace, thus four and one combine to form five. *Wukong* (*Shen*) unites metal and water as one family. *Wu* and *Ji*, inherently the generative number five, form the three fives. *Wujing* embodies the earth family, and the union of the three fives becomes the Supreme Ultimate.

*Tai* signifies the utmost greatness; *ji* denotes the utmost essential. Its principle lies within primordial chaos, and with a single movement, yin and yang are born. Yin and yang are *qi*. This is the principle that gives rise to *qi*, and *qi* in turn embodies the principle. Only with the *qi* of the innate true *yi* can the three families be generated; after the three families converge, they in turn generate the *qi* of the innate true *yi*, forming the spiritual infant. The infant relies entirely on the operation of this *qi* to shed its mortal form and become a true person.

*Xuanzang* is this infant, thus he cannot be separated from *Wukong*; indeed, neither *Wuneng* nor *Wujing* can be separated from *Wukong*. As the *Wuzhen Pian* states: “East three and South two together make five, North one and West four share the same. *Wu* and *Ji* inherently reside in the generative number five; the three families converge to form the spiritual infant.” This is the true essence. Alas!

Revealing the Dao to this point,世人 cannot fathom its meaning, inevitably resorting to wild conjecture and misguided speculation, their perverse doctrines and defiled practices reducing the most true and supreme wondrous Way to mere child’s play. Those with the aspiration to study the Dao must swiftly seek a true master, receiving step-by-step guidance to avoid falling into the cycle of rebirth.

In the closing of this chapter, the Great Sage’s four characters—“seeing nature and illuminating the mind”—the word “mind” here precisely strikes at the human heart, echoing the earlier teaching of Patriarch Subodhi: “After attaining the Dao, one must see nature and illuminate the mind.” At the very outset of Daoist practice, to be able to see nature and illuminate the mind is indeed the subtlety of the three vehicles of Chan. Yet if one knows only non-action and not action, this is no more than solitary cultivation of a single yin element—how can the elixir be formed and the sacred embryo achieved? In the end, one falls into emptiness. How lamentable! How pitiful!

Master Ziyang the Perfected says:
*“To see non-action as the essential subtlety is not as good as action as the foundation.”*

Ancestor Shangyang says:
*“To reach old age in non-action, how can one attain joy? Entering the chamber to gather lead—this is called action. In the marketplace of great virtue, who will awaken?”*

To forge the vast expanse, first establish the firm boundaries.
Only when the millet-grain pearl is obtained is one not in error.
Nine years of sitting in forgetfulness—non-action’s merit is vast.
When the three thousand deeds are fulfilled, joy is shared with all.
Yet if one clings to non-action alone, without first engaging in action,
This is but the folly of the deluded, self-bound in attachment!
These earnest words are spoken to enlighten later learners.

For seeing nature and illuminating the mind are the specialized practices *after* obtaining the elixir;
The gathering of the Five Phases is the very foundation of buddhahood and transcendence.
If one only sees nature and illuminates the mind but does not gather the Five Phases,
One will surely fail to escape the cycle of rebirth.

Like the Tang monk who had yet to form the sacred embryo,
Who required the three families to complete its coalescence;
Like Sun Wukong, whose Five Phases were already settled,
Yet still needed to see the Tathāgata to achieve liberation.
When one reads the exchange of gratitude between master and disciple aboard the bottomless boat,
All becomes clear.

**Chapter Nine: Chen Guangrui Meets Disaster on His Official Journey; The River-Flowing Monk Avenges His Origins**

Wu Yizi says: To read without a discerning eye is to bury the ancient masters’ painstaking intent—
Like savoring fine delicacies yet tasting no sweetness,
Or obtaining a piece of Bian jade yet mistaking it for common stone.

Yet how arduous it is! In leisure, I have perused the commentaries and exegeses of classics and histories, parsing their distinctions thread by thread—yet discrepancies abound, and clarity remains elusive. How much more so with this book, whose allusions branch in myriad directions, whose metaphors coil in hidden meanings? For centuries, it has been lumped together with trivial tales and absurd fables, casually dismissed or lightly mocked, serving only as fodder for idle wit.

Alas! To read the books of sages is difficult; to read the books of immortals is even more so! To read the books of immortals without recognizing them as such, yet still seek to grasp their sublime essence—is this not harder still? To read without recognizing their immortal nature, yet strive to reveal their profundities so that all may perceive their transcendent wisdom and, without exception, become immortals themselves—is this not the most arduous task of all?

Take this very chapter: readers may dismiss it as merely recounting the Tang monk’s past, devoid of deeper significance. Its events seem contradictory, at odds with worldly norms and common sentiment, scarcely worthy of belief. Consider the gaudy decorations, the bride-selecting ball toss—rites unrecorded in proper wedding customs.

How could the mother of a *zhuangyuan* be reduced to living alone in a foreign land? Would the daughter of a prime minister lack an escort when assuming office? A prefect’s wife could never secretly appear by the riverside. A single plank as a raft—hardly a sound plan to safeguard an infant. The beloved daughter won by the bride-selecting ball—why would she vanish without a trace? The doting mother of an official in office—how could she become a beggar after parting? Even if constrained by bureaucratic rank, how could there be no promotion for eighteen full years? Though kin and acquaintances may be few, could there truly be no word at all from even the most distant relation? Seeking one’s mother and recognizing her—how could one simply stride into the inner yamen? Pouring out one’s heart so freely—could it be that in a city of such size, with its cold officials and desolate offices, there were no gatekeepers to bar entry, no servants or maids in attendance? And once the scheme unraveled and capture was imminent, how could one muster an army of sixty thousand? Such manifold absurdities weary the reader’s ear. Earlier scholars have often excised this chapter, deeming it dispensable.

Alas! The immortal master’s learning spans past and present; his breast encompasses the workings of creation. He is intimately versed in the ways of the world and human sentiment, in the canons and measures of governance—would he ever wield such a careless brush? Nay, the immortal master’s profound intent and sublime expression lie precisely here, beyond the ken of ordinary minds. For he traces straight to the origins of Xuanzang’s parents’ birth, thereby illuminating the foundational workings of the Golden Elixir’s great Dao. The eighty-one trials of later chapters are rooted in this; the attainment of true fruition is rooted in this. All revolves around saving the golden carp—water giving rise to metal, the principle of inversion and reversal.

Metal can generate water, yet without water, it falls to the butcher’s block and cannot preserve its life. Water can generate metal, and with metal, it connects to the divine and can even revive the dead. Thus, preserving the life of metal is to preserve one’s own life; saving metal from death is to save oneself from death—this is the unifying principle, the very purpose for which Guanyin was sent to Chang’an. Hence, the mother can give birth to the child, and the child can in turn give birth to the mother. Mother and child mutually generate each other, and the alchemical method is complete.

Observe: *"In the Joyous Hall prefectural yamen, a son was born. By his ear, the Star Lord of the Southern Pole whispered, ‘By Guanyin’s dharma-decree, in days to come, husband and wife, mother and child shall reunite. Remember my words well. Awake! Awake!’"* This is meant to awaken the world—how could it be intended for Joyous Hall alone? *"Joyous Hall"* is metal, the product of the mountain’s opening. *"River Flow"* is water, born of metal’s nurturing—metal generates water. *"Secretly cast into the river’s edge"*—metal generates water. *"Flowing straight to Golden Mountain, where the raft came to rest"*—metal generates water. *"Seeking my mother within the Jiangzhou yamen"*—water generates metal. *"Rushing into the residence to rescue his mother"*—water generates metal. *"Xuanzang desperately tearing at the bonds"*—water generates metal.

Yet without discerning the myriad falsehoods of the world, one cannot know the singular truth within water. Only the bodhisattva’s divine insight can faithfully uphold this true decree. Guanyin was sent to Chang’an to enable Chang’an to perceive the great Dao. Alas, Chang’an *"changed its reign title to Zhenguan"*—able only to glimpse the Dao faintly, like a woman’s chastity. With a *Zhenguan* sovereign above, the great Dao could not be perceived; below, with Wei Zheng as minister, the grand vision could not be nurtured. *"Wei"* sounds like *"falsehood"*—falsehood; *"Zheng"* means *"outward verification."* If the vision is chaste but not great, then verification is false and not true. The transformation through reverent inaction is distant, and none in the world can perceive it. This meaning is not my own fabrication—observe how the immortal master prominently introduces the four characters *"Zhenguan Wei Zheng"* at the chapter’s outset, making it abundantly clear.

Now examine the falsehoods in the encounters of Xuanzang’s parents: The selection of the top scholar and appointment to office—Chen Guangrui’s case—yet the one who took office was the bandit Liu Hong. Here lies the falsehood in seeking talent and employing men, plain to see. The daughter of a prime minister resorting to a bride-selecting ball to arrange her own marriage—here lies the falsehood in the proper beginnings of husband and wife, the perversion of marriage rites. An official murdered by bandits, with the brigand’s faction usurping power—rulers and ministers unaware, colleagues indifferent. Here lies the falsehood in the laws of ruler and minister. An official left unpromoted for eighteen years, allowing bandits to tyrannize the people unchecked—here lies the falsehood in the selection and appointment system. Binding a false prefect and commanding sixty thousand troops—here lies the falsehood in military governance and temple calculations. Literature as a ladder to advancement, yet unknowingly becoming a path to destruction—here lies the falsehood in literature. Office as a place to honor oneself, yet unknowingly becoming a road to ruin—here lies the falsehood in fame and achievement. Leaving one’s mother to take office, yet losing all news of life or death; seeking to honor one’s parents yet reducing them to beggary—here lies the falsehood in honor and disgrace. Taking one’s wife along, yet parting in an instant—here lies the falsehood in love and affection. Over many years, parents unable to inquire after their children’s survival, children unable to send word to their parents; kin unable to assist, friends unable to help—here lies the falsehood in family and friendship.

Chen Guangrui gained office and a wife—falsehood. Liu Hong gained office and a wife—falsehood within falsehood. Chen Guangrui gained the favor of ruler and people—falsehood. Liu Hong gained the favor of ruler and people—falsehood within falsehood. Chen Guangrui faced death and life—falsehood. Liu Hong faced life and death—falsehood within falsehood. Lady Zhang had a son yet had no son—falsehood in mother and child. Miss Yin had a husband yet had no husband—falsehood in husband and wife. The Kaishan couple had a daughter yet had no daughter—falsehood in filial piety and compassion.

All this serves as proof that all is false—yet all is also a manifestation of *Zhenguan*. None of it compares to the salvation of the golden-scaled carp. That single act in the water alone could span beginning to end, reuniting flesh and blood in true and tangible fulfillment. The Way of salvation lies solely in the child born of water repaying his mother’s kindness.

Miss Yin, after all, calmly cut her own throat—was this not the *zhen* ("integrity") she beheld? It mirrors the "Zhenguan" ("True Vision") at the chapter’s outset, bringing the core theme full circle. "The monk Jiangliu resolved to settle into meditation"—was this not the *da* ("greatness") he beheld? It reflects back upon Guanyin’s commission to journey to Chang’an, inverting the falsity of *Zhenguan*.

The key lies in one’s spiritual vision and discernment, in seeking the original face before parents were born—that is all.

**Chapter Ten**
*The Old Dragon King’s Foolish Scheme Violates Heaven’s Decree*
*Minister Wei’s Letter Entrusted to an Underworld Official*

Wu Yizi says: Why do people read plain and ordinary words yet dismiss them as strange and unorthodox? It is because their vision is narrow, their steps confined. They see the Rabbit Garden but not the Lacquer Garden; they tread the azure clouds but not the Blue Ox. What they perceive is small, and where they rush is lowly.

In this chapter, the rulers and ministers of *Zhenguan* fail to attain great vision. All their deeds exist only within a dream. No one is without dreams, and none fail to recognize the illusory nature of dreams. None fail to see that worldly affairs are as illusory as dreams—so why, then, do they doubt the Tang emperor and his ministers dreaming of dragons seeking rescue, dreaming of slaying karmic dragons, dismissing it all as absurd and unorthodox?

It is not only the Tang emperor and his ministers who dream such dreams. From ancient times to the present, anyone might have such dreams. Why doubt the emperor’s decree or the minister’s intent at the time, as if they were not all willingly partaking in the same dream?

The emperor says, "I dreamed thus."
The minister says, "I dreamed likewise."
The generals say, "I dreamed likewise."
The officials and attendants—who among them does not say, "I dreamed likewise"?
The entire nation, from ministers to commoners—who dares not say, "I dreamed likewise"?

At such a time, no one of great vision stands forth, robed in solemnity, tablet in hand, and declares: "This is a dream, a wandering spirit’s delusion." One who can perceive the mind and see the nature, who grasps the supreme and truly wondrous Dao, knows that all worldly affairs are illusion—how much more so dreams!

Had the Tang emperor suddenly awakened and said, "Truly, it was a dream," then the dream would not recur. The Jing River would have no dragon without a head; the prime minister’s hall would lack the sword for slaying dragons; the cloud’s edge would not drop a severed head; the city gate would not display a decapitated skull. They would not die in dreams, live in dreams, and dream without end.

Alas, theirs was *Zhenguan*—their vision was small. They believed the dragon had defied Heaven and sought their aid, and so they agreed to save it. They believed Heaven’s punishment was entrusted to them, and so they wielded the blade to strike. Those adept at divining the emperor’s will would surely urge, "You can save it," and thus the hand would move the pieces on the board. Those skilled at aligning with the minister’s heart would surely seize the moment to offer, "You can slay it," and thus the head would hang in the marketplace.

If it is a dream within a dream, awakening is still possible. Within the false, there remains truth—Guanyin saving the dragon with a willow branch is such a case. But if it is not a dream yet treated as one, there is no moment of awakening or revival. Within the false, there is only further falsehood—Wei Zheng sending a letter to Cui Jue is such a case.

Wei Zheng sought to interfere with Heaven’s punishments, and it is clear he would interfere with human punishments as well. He would meddle in the affairs of the underworld, and it is no stretch to see he would meddle in the affairs of the living. Where there is one falsehood, all is false; where there is one sign, all is sign—all wrought by those who cling to "Zhenguan."

The Immortal Master does not mean to disparage Wei Zheng but uses him to expose the illusions of worldly affairs through the ages. There is no sign that is not false, no vision that is not *Zhenguan*. In the final analysis, it is better to be an unranked scholar, a woodsman like Zhang Yu or Li Qiao who can read and has a firm perspective. Their words say:

Those who contend for fame lose their bodies for its sake;
Those who seize profit die for its sake.
Thus, the pursuit of fame and profit by scholars and officials is false, and their striving is but a dream.

Those who receive titles sleep embracing tigers;
Those who enjoy favor run with snakes up their sleeves.
Thus, titles and favor are all false, and their acceptance is but a dream.

They also say:
"Take care on the road ahead, be vigilant—
Tomorrow at the street’s end, few will be familiar."
How sharp and urgent their warning!

Yuan Shoucheng knew the fish would swim into the net, knew fate would violate the year’s decree, knew rain would fall in due measure. Forewarned, he did not enter the dream. The Jing River dragon, deluded by the yaksha, by the broken divination, by the wager, by Marshal Shi, abandoned all caution to vie for victory, defied the law, and acted recklessly—dreaming within a dream, he plunged deeper into the dream.

The Tang emperor dreamed of a karmic dragon seeking rescue and convened his ministers to discuss the strange dream. Wei Zheng dreamed of slaying the karmic dragon and, in the emperor’s dream, left his body to wield the sword. The Tang emperor dreamed the karmic dragon demanded his life, saw ghosts and feared them—all one great dream. The civil and military officials kept night watch at the palace gates to suppress ghosts—all the court was dreaming. Even the Tang emperor’s death and Wei Zheng’s guarantee of his longevity seemed to place the Son of Heaven’s life and death in his grasp. Sending a letter to Cui Jue, he claimed, "In a dream, I once met you," as if the authority of the King of Hell could be swayed by him—was this not the greatest dream of all?

Thus, the Tang emperor tucked the letter into his sleeve and closed his eyes, never to return. This clumsy dragon’s case was a realm of their own making, conjured in the hearts of the Tang emperor and his ministers. Its hidden signs await revelation in later chapters, but its dreamlike nature is no different from the ant in the locust tree or the deer beneath the plantain—all waking illusions.

At first, what strangeness was there? Yet the old dragon’s clumsy scheme was never truly his own; his delayed rain-bringing invited heavenly punishment. Its profound meaning and subtle principles cannot be conveyed in mere words. A poem hints at the intent:

*"Clouds and rain bestow life upon the myriad things—
Take care to act with precision, never tardy.
The clumsy dragon wagered against the mysterious decree,
Drawing the divine blade to follow close behind."*

The *Yin Fu Jing* says: *"Fire is born of wood, and calamity inevitably strikes."* Does this not describe such a case? Today’s temporal masters delude the world with arts of "controlling women and waging battle," inviting ruin upon themselves—just as the *Shi* military advisor taught the old dragon to delay his rain, to wager and compete, defying heavenly judgment. Should we not take heed?

The Immortal Master calls him the *Shi* military advisor—its meaning is clear.
