**Chapter Eleven**
*The Tang Emperor Visits the Underworld and Returns to Life;
Liu Quan Presents Melons and Fruits to Reunite with His Wife*

Wu Yizi says: This chapter directly speaks of the Tang emperor’s entry into the dream to illustrate the Dao of yin-yang resonance—even the principle of exchange between man and woman. Where there is stimulus, there must be response; where there is cause, there must be effect, with not even a hair’s breadth of deviation.

Emperor Gaozu of Tang once dreamed of his own death, falling beneath his bed to be devoured by maggots. The Chan master Zhipu interpreted this as a sign of the multitudes rallying to him. The present dream of Taizong is unprecedented. Yet what one does by day, one dreams by night. His journey through the underworld—was this not the hidden truth of the "Zhenguan" era? The evil of hidden truths, conceived in the heart and taking form in dreams—here, one must take "the heart" as the master, for the peril of the human heart is the peril of hell itself. Like a shadow following the body, it cannot be erased.

In this chapter:
Taizong, lost and alone, trembles in terror, unable to find his way. In haste, he sends a private letter seeking refuge. At the Gate of Ghosts, he encounters the late Emperor Gaozu and his brothers demanding their due. He pleads the case of the clumsy dragon. The ledger of life and death is amended. He tours the underworld, heart pounding with dread. Passing through the eighteen layers of hell, his spirit quails. Gazing upon the Bridge of Helplessness, his heart again trembles. Arriving at the City of Wrongful Death, he is seized with terror. A horde of ghosts blocks his path, leaving him nowhere to hide; he begs Cui Pan for rescue and borrows Xiang Liang’s gold and silver to bribe his way free. Witnessing the Six Paths of Reincarnation, the judge urges Taizong to "illumine his heart and perceive his nature." Only when the underworld is free of cries of grievance will the mortal realm enjoy the blessings of peace. Every unwholesome deed may be amended one by one.

Thus, the chapter’s true purport is revealed: if one refrains from unwholesome acts in the mortal world, the underworld will naturally be free of hell’s perils. Every detail is painted from the heart, all drawn from Taizong’s past deeds and the unease they stir within him. Those who critique *Journey to the West* yet overlook this chapter’s focus on the heart are truly baffling.

The most striking moment comes when the wronged souls demand retribution, and the judge says, *"If Your Majesty offers them some money, I can save you."* Taizong replies, *"I came here empty-handed—where would I get money?"* This is what is meant by *"Ten thousand taels of gold cannot be taken, but a lifetime of karma follows you."* When the judge says money can save him, does he truly mean it? No—he means that here, money cannot reach, cannot be used—how then can it save you? Later, when he borrows Xiang Liang’s gold and silver, is this truly a loan? No—it means that in the mortal world, evil deeds bring evil retribution, and good deeds bring good retribution. In the underworld, the thirteen years of an emperor’s reign are no match for the thirteen treasuries of a commoner; the fifteen circuits of an emperor’s governance are no match for the single treasury entrusted to a commoner. The profound meaning lies in the reversal—readers must not cling to the surface!

In later chapters, when Xiang Liang and his wife’s accumulated wealth is revealed to be the fruit of alms-giving and virtuous deeds—not merely gold, silver, or paper money—the truth becomes clear.

Taizong enters the great dream because of the old dragon, and upon reaching the Gate of Ghosts, he should have encountered the ghostly dragon demanding his life. Why, instead, does he first meet the late Emperor Gaozu and his brothers, with no sign of the dragon? The Immortal Master embeds the intent of the *Spring and Autumn Annals* in hidden words. I reveal the unspoken meaning of *Journey to the West* to clarify what the Immortal Master left unsaid.

When the Sui dynasty’s governance faltered, the realm pursued the deer together. Raising the banner of righteousness to overthrow tyranny and rescue the people from fire and water—this was a cause both just and right.

How then could he employ Pei Ji’s cunning schemes, sending palace women of the Sui to attend the High Ancestor? By coercing him with an inescapable situation, he ensnared his father in unrighteousness, transgressing the bounds of filial duty and offending the august will of Heaven. The silent decree of retribution found its accomplices in his ministers and aides, who enabled the plot. The High Ancestor, like clouds moving and rain bestowing, failed in restraint—just as the old dragon was misled by the eel’s strategist. For defying the timely summons and delaying the clouds and rain, fearing celestial punishment and meeting the sword of wisdom, was this not fitting?

The dragon of the Jing River was none other than Li Yuan—hence called "old." The phrase *"rain and water together measured three feet three inches and forty-eight drops"* cryptically encodes the name "Li Yuan." Combining the two characters: three horizontal strokes form three feet, three vertical strokes form three inches, and the four water radicals with the eighteen strokes of *zi* make forty-eight drops. Further, when merged and arranged, they resemble the shape of the character "four," and when calculated separately, yield the number twenty-four (four times six); combined with the three water radicals and the character *ba*, they form another twenty-four (three times eight), totaling forty-eight drops. Removing the three vertical strokes subtracts three inches; removing the *ba* and *zi* from "Li" subtracts eight drops. The remaining strokes of "Li" (一) and "Yuan" (氵) combine to form "Jing." Thus, "Li Yuan" is veiled as "Jing." The dragon lurks in the depths, the old dwells in the turbid—Jing River was indeed his domain.

Yet when Taizong transformed the household into a state, he falsely claimed to rescue his father from peril while failing to avert the decree of Heaven’s justice. Concealing soldiers at Xuanwu Gate, he secretly accused his father of debauchery in the rear palace, then proclaimed his own unrecognized merits, forcing the events of the fourth day of the sixth month—seizing the throne by coercing his father and killing his brother, following the same path as Yang Guang. This was but a continuation of the Sui’s downfall. Guang perished in thirteen years, and Shimin died in thirteen years—was this not fitting?

Moreover, he took the consort of Prince Chaoli and fraudulently fabricated an heir, corrupting the bonds of husband and wife, father and son, brothers and sisters—so thoroughly that even the virtuous Lady Li, who cast herself into the noose to preserve wifely integrity, or Liu Quan, who risked death to present melons and uphold the husband’s authority, were not their equal. Thus, he was right to have the soul of Princess Wang seized, reuniting her in life and death with her kin, allowing husband and wife, father and child, brother and sister to reopen the lotus stem and gather in one chamber.

When Taizong wielded the blade, the bonds of fraternal loyalty were utterly extinguished, leaving no trace to extend to his sister. Such is the retribution of yin and yang, precise to the finest hair. Therefore, the Immortal Master, through Taizong’s own words, declared: *"When I return to the yang world, I shall repay only with melons and fruit."* The "southern melon" (*nan gua*): *nan* (south) is *li* (fire), belonging to the heart. It signifies that as long as the heart’s ground is luminous, the fruit will be the recompense. As the *Book of Songs* says: *"You cast me a quince, I return you a gemmed plum. Not as repayment, but to forever cherish the bond."* Lady Li’s noose and Liu Quan’s melon were the cast quince; Cuilian’s borrowed corpse and Yuying’s descent were the gemmed plum in return. Male and female embody the Dao of yin and yang; gift and reciprocity embody the principle of karmic retribution. To forever cherish the bond is to revive even after death. Compared to those who privately add two years of life or falsely borrow a treasury—though revived, they remain in a great dream—how vast is the difference!

Yet Taizong’s experience was but a dream, not true death. All the visions of hell were self-constructed within his mind. Thus, when his ministers spoke at the moment of returning to yang, they asked: *"What does Your Majesty still find unsettling?"* This is the true record. When the civil and military officials of the Eastern and Western Palaces all memorialized: *"How could Your Majesty’s dream of the former court last so long before awakening?"*—the words *"a dream"* were spoken with utter clarity.

**Note:**

Emperor Taizong ascended the throne at twenty-nine, changed the era name to *Zhenguan*, and lived to fifty-three. He reigned for twenty-four years in truth, not thirty-three. Now, when it is said that the thirteenth year of *Zhenguan* had two years added to it, the matter seems erroneous—yet therein lies a subtle meaning. For Gaozu Yuan reigned nine years, though in reality, it was Taizong’s scheming within the palace that coerced and usurped the throne. Thus, though *Wude* held the empty title, *Zhenguan* had already seized the divine regalia. If the nine years of *Wude* are shifted and added to the twenty-four of *Zhenguan*, does it not make thirty-three years? One and three make two and three; two and three make three and three—three threes precisely yield nine. Hence, the addition of two strokes already conveys the meaning of adding nine years, a stroke of the immortal master’s ingenuity.

Taking the thirteenth year as the time of his journey through the netherworld was to foreshadow the continuation of life after death. Adding two strokes revealed the hidden power of yin usurpation, exposing the concealed disloyalty to his father. Later, when Xuanzang returned after fourteen years, he did so beyond the falsely added years, so Taizong should not have lived to see it. Thus, the thirty-three years of his reign were merely a device to conclude the narrative of his westward journey and the transmission of scriptures for the salvation of the world.

Later generations, in discussing governance, extol the *Zhenguan* era of the Tang, nearly achieving a realm where punishments were laid aside. Yet the great root was already flawed, and all its branches and leaves were but falsehoods—what was there truly to admire? The immortal master used this to expound grandly, urging those who cultivate the Dao to refine their minds and selves in pursuit of the Great Way. If one resorts to deception and fraud, even the slightest unease in the heart is to forge one’s own hell. Thus, the Old Dragon, heeding the advice of his marshal, grew careless and unrestrained—yet could not escape a single sword. The Tang king, seeking Cui the Judge, could not set his heart at ease—and so had two strokes falsely added. Contrast this with Wukong, who set his heart down, stormed the halls of Fengdu, personally expunged his name from the ledger of the dead, and eradicated the ten classes of beings. Though all were dreams, their awakenings differed.

In sum, those who comprehend the Dao and set their hearts down will surely, like Wukong, clearly dissolve the records of death and ascend to heaven. Those who fail to comprehend the Dao and cannot set their hearts at ease will, like Taizong, secretly extend their lifespans—only to descend into the earth. Heaven and hell lie within the heart. Joy and terror both—how can one not be vigilant!

I once traveled to Daliang and visited the ancient Great Xiangguo Monastery. Its monastic halls stood towering and resplendent, with sandalwood relics spread across the fields—no less grand than the Bao Guo Monastery of Yandu. The last pavilion soared high into the azure, inscribed with the name "Sutra Repository." Ascending its layered stairs was like spiraling a conch; four tiers of flying eaves encircled it, crimson railings winding in curves. Gazing downward, all below appeared as ducks and ants, clouds and trees emerging and vanishing, their forms shifting with each step—truly a wondrous sight.

At its center stood a solemn altar, flanked by eight cabinets, their locks and bolts secure, housing the sutras within. In the right corner stood statues of a man and woman: the man with thick brows and a commoner’s topknot, the woman with a purple complexion and bared chest, both beaming with joy. I inquired of the guiding monk, who explained they were the "Water-Selling Lord and Lady." The tales of Taizong’s journey through the underworld, his borrowing of paper money, and his revival to rebuild the monastery aligned perfectly with *Journey to the West*. Examining the stele, I found records of the monastery’s founding, its origins unknown, flourishing in the sixth year of Tianbao during the Northern Qi, and restored under Emperor Ruizong of Tang. Though the annals detailed successive renovations in great depth, they made no mention of the deeds of Lord Xiang and his wife. Yet the couple had indeed contributed to the monastery’s merit. Their statues and the Sutra Repository endured through the ages, proving that the chronicler’s account was not entirely baseless mirages or illusions.

Alas! The two elders, toiling as water-sellers, amassed their wealth with great difficulty, yet delighted in benevolence and giving, never scheming for themselves. Their station was humble, but their vision was vast. Though they may not have fully comprehended the Dao, they glimpsed one facet of the great Way. As Laozi said: *"Putting oneself last, one finds oneself first; losing oneself, one preserves oneself."* Lord Xiang and his wife embodied this. Contrast them with those who hoard wealth and cling to stinginess, perishing in an instant—some even leaving descendants as beggars. What, then, was the purpose of their lives? How lamentable!

**Chapter Twelve: Xuanzang Holds Sincere Convocation—Guanyin Manifests to Transform the Golden Cicada**

Wu Yizi remarked: *"The vinegar fly calls the jar vast; the well-frog calls the sky small."* Yet the jar is not truly vast, nor the sky truly small—it is but the limitation of their view.

This chapter once more invokes the term *"Zhenguan"* to mark the inception of the convocation, revealing it as the *"Zhenguan"* of a woman, not the grand vision of a great sovereign. The governance of Taizong was *"Zhenguan"* indeed, yet Xuanzang surpassed it; the memorials of Fu Yi were *"Zhenguan"* as well, yet Xiao Yu surpassed them—both were, in essence, *"Zhenguan."* When Taizong bestowed upon Xuanzang a five-colored brocade kasaya, it was deemed the height of splendor and imperial favor. Little did he know of the Buddha’s gift of a brocade kasaya and a nine-ringed tin staff, the most resplendent and dazzling of treasures. After the Bodhisattva’s praise, Taizong’s offering paled into insignificance. When Taizong commanded Xuanzang to gather monks for meditation and sutra lectures, opening wide the gates of expedient means, it was called a grand convocation. Yet the Bodhisattva, striking the jeweled platform, cried aloud: *"Monk! You speak only of the Lesser Vehicle—can you expound the Great Vehicle?"* Once the Bodhisattva revealed the Mahāyāna Tripiṭaka, it could elevate the deceased to heaven, deliver the afflicted from suffering, cultivate a body of boundless life, and attain the state of neither coming nor going. Xuanzang’s usual teachings, by comparison, could only harmonize with the mundane. Why? For beholding the supremely beautiful, the merely beautiful loses its luster; gazing upon the boundlessly great, the merely great diminishes.

The Bodhisattva manifested her true form of salvation, adorned in majestic splendor. From midair descended a scroll, inscribed: *"In the West lies wondrous scripture,"* and *"Seek the true golden body."* This wondrous scripture of the West is the true Dao of the Golden Elixir. Xuanzang, vowing to journey to the two heavens, was styled *"Tripiṭaka,"* for he embodied the true scriptures of the Three Baskets in one. The name united the Five Phases of the three traditions.

What is *"Tripiṭaka"*? In terms of scripture count: 5,048 scrolls form one *piṭaka*, totaling 15,144 scrolls. In terms of the Five Phases: Metal and Water form one *piṭaka*, Wood and Fire another, and Earth the third. In terms of yin and yang: Heaven is one *piṭaka*, Earth another, and Ghosts the third. Ghosts are the innate efficacy of the two qi, pervading all between heaven and earth. At this point, Xuanzang bore the name of the Three Baskets but not yet their reality—hence, he was called the *"Golden Cicada."* The cicada does not sing with its mouth, drinks but does not eat, dwells in lowliness yet ascends to heights, the most refined of creatures, symbolizing purity, non-action, and a nature that embraces emptiness. Gold is a body tempered through a hundred refinings, radiant and indestructible, symbolizing the luminous emptiness of the nature. Yet though the nature is complete, the root of life remains unsecured—this is the *"towering Buddhist hall with no Buddha within."* Thus, Xuanzang’s grasp of the Lesser Vehicle was but the hollow shell of a golden cicada. Only after the meeting of the three traditions could the foundation of life be fulfilled, forging a body of true, indestructible gold and beholding the Tathāgata—this is the teaching of the Great Vehicle.

Guanyin, sent by the Buddha’s decree, revealed her intent through the five-colored brocade kasaya and the nine-ringed precious staff. Xuanzang, in receiving these, had grasped the Buddha’s decree without remainder. The kasaya symbolized the gathering of the Five Phases; the nine rings, the ninefold return of cyclical refinement—hence, *"manifesting to transform the golden cicada."* Not *"deliverance,"* but *"transformation,"* like timely rain that causes seeds to sprout and burst forth.

Readers of *Journey to the West* may find what follows strange and fantastical, doubting its authenticity. Yet the three disciples to come are the meeting of the three traditions, the medicinal ingredients; the eighty-one trials are the ninety-ninefold return, the firing process. The dispositions of the Five Phases and the numinous power of the nine transformations are inherently mutable and unfathomable. Wherever the brush touches, it reveals true and wondrous forms, the most profound and ordinary principles. Within lie courageous progress, vigilance against peril, and every subtle precept of the Dharma, all fully present. The line *"the Great Thunderclap Monastery of the Western Heaven, the realm of Tathāgata, our Buddha"* is a most revealing declaration. Those with innate immortal bones, if they study this book deeply and discern its mysteries, will receive its teachings as if from a true master, and the treasures of the brocade kasaya and nine-ringed staff may be worn and wielded in this very life.

Yet Xuanzang must first obtain his three disciples before he can pay homage to the Tathāgata—this is easily understood. The three disciples had already attained the Dao of longevity, their life-roots firm and indestructible through ten thousand kalpas. Why, then, did they take Xuanzang as their master? This is difficult to fathom. The reason lies in the shared path of immortals and Buddhas: the Buddha speaks of the *"seven-foot golden body,"* while immortals speak of *"cultivating two persons"*—both are the progression from action to non-action. To perfect life without perfecting nature is like a precious mirror left unpolished, lacking radiance—this is not the true emptiness of action. To perfect nature without perfecting life is like building a house without a foundation, erecting pillars in vain—this is the barren emptiness of non-action. Thus, those who act must first see nature and illuminate the mind before transcending the Five Phases—this is why the three disciples took refuge in the Buddha’s Dharma. Those who do not act must gather the Five Phases before transcending the mundane and entering sagehood—this is why Xuanzang subdued the three disciples.

The three disciples had not fully realized the subtlety of non-action, yet Xuanzang embodied it—thus they took him as their master. Xuanzang had not fully realized the subtlety of action, yet the three disciples embodied it—thus he taught them as his disciples. When master and disciples unite as one, this is the Great Dao of the Golden Elixir, the supreme and most authentic Mahayana Dharma. Only after ascending the bottomless boat and shedding the husk do they achieve the mutual aid of master and disciples, where neither owes gratitude to the other—this is the original intent.

The Patriarch said: *"Human life is like a bubble, an illusion. Without this bubble, this illusion, the great matter cannot be accomplished; but once the great matter is accomplished, what use is this bubble, this illusion?"* Ascending the bottomless boat and shedding the husk is precisely when the great matter is accomplished—it is the golden cicada shedding its shell and transforming.

Throughout the book, the master is styled as a "Buddha-child" and named *"Xuan"* (Mystery); the disciples are all "immortal-children" and named *"Wu"* (Awakening). Without awakening, there is no thorough mystery; without mystery, there is no thorough awakening. Immortals are Buddhas, Buddhas are immortals—there is no dual Dao, no dual function.

**Chapter Thirteen: Falling into the Tiger’s Den, the Metal Star Resolves the Crisis; At Twin-Fork Ridge, Boqin Shelters the Monk**

Wu Yizi said: Shun declared, *"The human heart is perilous."* Zhuangzi said, *"What is so impetuous and unbridled that it cannot be restrained? Is it not the human heart?"* Perilous, impetuous, and unbridled—these deeply reveal the treacherous nature of the human heart. The *"Five Sons’ Song"* in the *Book of Documents* says, *"Like driving six horses with rotten reins"*—the six horses are a metaphor for the human heart.

Yet controlling horses depends on reins and bridles, while controlling the heart depends on reverence. Reverence is how the sage begins and completes the Way. Thus, in cultivating the Dao and learning the Way, the very first step upon setting out is to fully restrain the perilous nature of the human heart, lest one fall into its traps.

This chapter marks Tripitaka’s first step on his western journey. The assembled monks debated the purpose, each describing the hardships ahead. Tripitaka said: *"When the heart arises, all manner of demons arise; when the heart is extinguished, all manner of demons are extinguished."* Some say these two lines succinctly capture the entire essence, leaving nothing more to be said.

Alas! To mistake the human heart for the Dao-mind is to mistake the heart for the Dao, to take the false as real—this is a grave error! One must recognize that all within this heart is demonic and must be severed and eradicated at the root. Only through unyielding strength and resolute decisiveness can this be achieved. If extinguishing the heart were the full extent of the purpose, why then journey to the West to obtain the Mahayana true sutras?

This is the blindness of the fleshly eye, failing to recognize the true form of the living Buddha—the wondrous seven-foot golden body. It is like setting out and reaching the border of mountains and rivers, only to take the wrong path and suddenly lose one’s footing, tumbling into a pit.

The chapter vividly illustrates this, for the phrases *"heart arises"* and *"demons arise"* merely point out the perilous nature of the human heart, teaching one to strike first—this is the starting point. Tripitaka mistook these two as the very trap, and his heart’s panic was the tiger’s appearance.

The human heart is like a tiger: the tiger’s trap and the heart’s trap ensnare a person in the same way. What difference is there between falling into the heart’s den and the tiger’s den? How can this be seen?

The concluding verse says: *"The white-browed king of South Mountain."* South is *li* (☲), corresponding to *bing* (丙), and the *bing* fire’s phase of growth begins in *yin* (寅)—the *yin* general. This clearly designates the *yin* general as the heart. Yet fearing that the world might not understand, the text introduces the two demons, the bear and the yaksha, as proof. The bear belongs to fire, born within *yin*; the yaksha belongs to earth, born within *bing*.

The demon king said: *"They delivered themselves to my door."* This entirely depicts the peril of the human heart ensnaring itself.

Yet the human heart is more perilous than the two demons, though not perilous when unified as one. Thus the Mountain Lord said: *"Devour the two, but spare the one—this may be done."* The Golden Star below signifies the original nature of the One. The two are the ordinary heart; the One is the Dao-heart. At this moment, Tripitaka sank into a stupor, lost and without mastery—unable to preserve his life. The way to preserve life rests solely upon the true One’s gold. *"Suddenly, an old man appeared, staff in hand"*—this is the original nature’s mastery, by which life may be preserved. Thus he thanked the old man for saving his life. The old man then asked: *"Have you lost anything?"* Tripitaka replied: *"Two attendants were devoured, and I know not where my luggage and horse have gone."* The old man pointed and said: *"Are not that a horse and two bundles?"* Tripitaka turned to look, and indeed, they were his belongings—only then did his heart settle. Though these seem idle words, they carry essential meaning. For the *"two attendants"* are the ordinary heart, fallen into the trap and devoured; Tripitaka, having beheld the master, retains only the Dao-heart. The *"one horse and two bundles"* symbolize the Dao-heart—his original possessions, unlost, forming the foundation for his westward journey. Only then could his heart be at ease.

The Golden Star led him out of the pit and pointed ahead to divine disciples, further clarifying that with the Dao-heart present, one must steel the heart and press onward. Though others may aid, the path cannot be walked alone to its end. The old man said: *"This is Twin-Fork Ridge, a den of tigers and wolves."* And again: *"Only because your original nature is fundamentally luminous were they unable to consume you."* Such insights are profoundly clear.

Threefold Basket, having encountered tigers and serpents, myriad demonic toxins—though knowing they arose from his own heart—found no means of deliverance. Alone and without recourse, he could only relinquish body and mind, surrendering to heaven’s decree. This was the moment when his original nature, fundamentally luminous, extinguished the human heart and temporarily preserved the celestial heart.

Yet this place was the crossroads where heavenly and mortal realms diverged, leaving him stranded amid towering ridges, neither able to advance nor retreat. The meaning of *"Twin-Fork"* echoed Mozi’s lament at the forked path, where one might turn southeast or northwest—where the White-Forehead King and Liu the Stalwart clashed in battle. Man and beast, vividly depicted, revealed the threshold between humanity and ferocity: only rectitude could dispel evil, only principle could overcome desire. If one could master reverence and self-restraint, cultivate courage and unyielding strength, then the heart’s demons would vanish, and one might feast on flesh and sleep upon hides.

*"Liu"* signified the power to overcome the Yin and halt the slaughter; *"Tai"* (Stalwart) denoted the capacity to contend for leadership and uphold household governance; *"Qin"* (Reverent) meant inner humility and outward dignity, mastering reverence to sustain the self. *"Wielding a rigid fork"* symbolized inflexible strength, while *"styled ‘Guardian of the Mountain’"* signified unshakable composure—reverence resided not beyond the heart but within it, as a fellow villager. The practice of reverence began within filial piety, thus making him a filial son. Only through reverence could he dwell unharmed in the tiger’s den; only through filial devotion could he guard the desolate mountain without peril. Tigers and wolves became his daily fare, for strength sufficed to quell desire; reciting sutras fulfilled his filial duty of deliverance, for sincerity could reach even the unseen. The single word *"reverence"* was the bridge spanning safety and danger, ease and hardship.

Yet he remained bound to the tigers and wolves, unable to transcend the snares of the world; he could only guard this mountain, not venture beyond its borders. Arriving at Two-Boundary Mountain, he escaped fear and obstruction, for here lay the parting of heavenly and mortal paths—he could not press forward as one. This was called *"able to detain the monk but unable to escort him."*

Alas! The mountain lord devoured monks yet detained them, consuming two; the mountain guardian devoured tigers yet detained the monk, preserving one. Yet it was not the tiger that consumed him, but the monk who consumed himself; not Qin who detained him, but the monk who detained himself. As for Twin-Fork Ridge and Two-Boundary Mountain, one must discern: *"Twin-Fork"* as the path where man and beast contend, *"Two-Boundary"* as the way where nature and destiny advance or halt—these distinctions could not be ignored.

**Chapter Fourteen: The Mind-Ape Returns to Rectitude, the Six Bandits Vanish Without Trace**
*Wu Yizi says:* The human heart is like weeds, the Dao-heart like fine grain. If one eradicates all mundane thoughts yet lacks sagely understanding, it is like clearing a field of chaff and barnyard grass—leaving it utterly barren. How then can one repay the debt of hunger? As the Patriarch said: *"If the cauldron lacks the true seed, one merely boils an empty pot with water and fire."*

The *"mind"* in *"mind-ape"* refers to the Dao-heart. The Dao-heart is not the spirit of deliberation within the heart, but the spirit of essence and oneness within the Five Phases. Only by attaining this heart does one possess the true seed, which is why the Lord of Yu specially emphasized the Dao-heart’s subtlety, refinement, and singularity, faithfully holding to the mean’s mystery.

Readers who mistake the human heart for the mind-ape, failing to recognize the Handsome Monkey King as the true seed of essence and oneness, are like those who take a parasitic wasp’s larva for their own child. Yet this heart remains bound to the Five Phases, still the root of birth and death’s cycle. Only by progressing from effort to effortlessness, forgetting both heart and Buddha, dissolving good and evil, does one attain the transcendent transformation of the supreme Mahayana, beyond the world.

The opening verse is the original text of the Perfected One of Purple Yang, each word a mani-jewel—it must be pondered deeply. The line *"To know it, one must master the mindless decision"* clearly points to the profound principle of not clinging to the heart. For the wonder of essence and oneness arises from emptiness, neither heart nor Buddha, but the formless true suchness, the bodiless true appearance—beginning in concentration, ending in utter oblivion; ever beginning, ever ending, indestructible through ten thousand kalpas.

Should one cultivate reverence and refine the heart with utmost devotion, even with the great power of Bo Qin, one may only escape the jaws of the tiger—how could one transcend beyond the boundaries of the realms? Yet this matter is difficult to comprehend, hence the verse twice employs the character "know" to instruct: only by truly knowing can one truly practice.

As when Bo Qin, standing at the Mountain of Two Realms, saw the monkey pleading for rescue and asked, *"How can I discern truth from falsehood?"* The monkey replied, *"It is true! I dare not deceive!"*—echoing the Tathāgata’s vow: *"I now pledge to ensure this matter for you, its fulfillment certain."* At the summit, six characters are boldly proclaimed, and the Monkey Spirit indeed emerges from the cave, bearing a profound principle beyond brush or ink. Only by knowing that the human heart must be extinguished and the Dao-heart must be born—extinguishing the human heart and birthing the Dao-heart—does the cultivation of the Way begin. Thus, rescuing the "heart-monkey" and renaming it *"Pilgrim"* marks the true knowing and the commencement of practice.

The first step in practice lies in subduing the tiger. *"Beyond the Mountain of Two Realms, a fierce tiger suddenly appeared."* This tiger is not the tiger that ensnares the heart within, but the tiger that sustains the body without—hence the words, *"Bring me clothes to wear."* At the sight of the Pilgrim, it prostrates in the dust, unmoving. The tiger’s nature is no longer wild, no different from the heart-monkey’s return to rectitude. Taking a garment becomes as one with the whole. The Pilgrim’s subduing of the tiger is the Tripitaka’s taming of the monkey—its significance is subtle indeed.

When the Venerable Sun boasts of his *"skills in subduing dragons and tigers,"* he foreshadows the subduing of the dragon as the second step. The verse contains the line: *"A hook of new moon pierces the dusk,"* a phrase of exquisite beauty. Readers may pass it by as mere embellishment of twilight’s leisure, unaware that after subduing the tiger, the crescent moon’s form has already taken shape—this must not be overlooked!

When Wukong debates the elder on their ages, he perceives the swift passage of time...

The Tang Monk and the elder trace their shared lineage, seeing self and other as one family. Master and disciples bathe, shedding grime in an instant to renew themselves; seeking needle and thread, they mend their faults even amid haste. All these depict the conduct of one returned to rectitude, yet hold no profound meaning.

But when suddenly six men burst from the roadside, roaring, *"Leave your baggage—or we’ll spare not your life!"*—here, the words *"life"* and *"spare"* carry a subtle truth. Earlier, at Twin-Fork Ridge, before the heart-monkey was subdued, one’s nature remained fundamentally luminous, yet life lacked a true master. Thus, one could only relinquish body and mind, entrusting them to Heaven’s decree. That life came from Heaven. Now, with the heart-monkey tamed, life bears a true seed—hence both *nature* and *life* are spoken of together. *"Spare you and let you pass"* means this life now depends on oneself. Though one may fall from the horse, the heart can rest easy in its affairs.

The heart is fundamentally empty, yet in truth, all things are complete within it. If the eye fixates on private gain, if thoughts arise from the bodily husk, this becomes a *private hoard*. But when one embodies the great and the public, gathering all beings into oneself, this becomes the *public treasury*. To neglect the public treasury while enriching the private hoard is to betray the lord and join the bandits—just as they say, *"You have nothing at all, yet you come back demanding things from us!"*

Thus, when the lord’s virtue is clear and bright, the six offices are harmonious; when the heart’s sovereign is at peace, the six officials fulfill their duties. The eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind—these are Heaven’s thieves. Men cannot see them, and the heart, lacking a master, is swayed: the eye sees and delights, the ear hears and rages, the nose smells and clings, the tongue tastes and craves, the mind conceives and desires, the body brims with cares. Thus, the bandits run rampant, plundering wantonly, and *nature* and *life* follow in their wake.

As the *Śūraṅgama Sūtra* says: *"The six entrances: the eye enters form, the ear enters sound, the nose enters scent, the tongue enters flavor, the body enters touch, the mind enters phenomena."* These six thieves are worldly bandits—all invited in when the master carelessly opens the door.

Wukong recognizes himself as the true master. *"Standing firm in the center"* means neither leaning nor drifting; *"feigning ignorance"* means unyielding strength. Wielding the weapon of wisdom, he extinguishes them all, strips them of their spoils, and repurposes them as clothing and provisions—this is using stillness to quell chaos, truth to vanquish falsehood. Unlike the human heart, which is disturbed by both mind and things, this is truly the thunderbolt’s might. If, in the moment, he had shown the slightest hesitation or mercy, it would have been like inviting thieves in—none escape unharmed. Hence he says, *"If I don’t kill them, they’ll kill you."* This is the thunderous shout of one who has experienced body and mind!

The Tang Monk, unaware of the bandits’ malice, remains ever compassionate, unable to act decisively—this is what it means to *"be unfit for monkhood, unworthy of the Western Heaven."* Thus, through Wukong’s words and deeds, the text portrays the endless harm wrought by a heart without a master.

The Tang Monk, his heart lacking resolve, yet claims *"I’ll decide for myself"*—this is throwing away his life in vain. He has already spoken his own doom; how can he fulfill his destiny? All stems from his inability to quietly observe and discern the unchanging unity of essence—hence Guanyin transforms into an old woman, bearing robes and hat, transmitting the spell, and pointing the way through delusion.

The old woman says, *"These were originally my son’s."* And again, *"My home is to the east; he must have gone there."*

She then says, *"I’ll call him back to follow you."*

Now, Wukong embodies the Dao-heart—he is the Metal Duke. The *Yi* speaks of what is easily let loose yet hard to subdue, easily lost yet hard to find. But since he was originally of my household, merely lodged in the West for a time, his return to the East already shows intent to return. One must recognize the call to *"summon him back!"* Thus, the *Awakening to Reality* says:

*"The Metal Duke was originally the Eastern House’s son,
Sent to the Western neighbor to lodge and take form."*

Recognizing the *"summons,"* he returns to his dwelling to nurture and unite, taking the Maiden as kin—here, the old woman’s guidance is most clear.

The *"gold-embedded flowered cap"* is the Golden Tight Restraint, as previously explained. Now, an embroidered robe is added, along with the *"True Spell of Settling the Heart"*—this depicts the character *"怀"* (to cherish). The robe bears the cap; Metal belongs to the Western Four. To establish the heart and don them—is this not *"怀"*? The meaning of *"怀"* inherently contains the sense of departure, yet returning is already implied. Just as *"cherishing the feudal lords"* makes the realm stand in awe, or *"cherishing the law"* keeps it ever in mind, the Dao-heart naturally abides. Thus she says: *"If he refuses to obey you, recite this spell—he will never dare leave again."* This is the one-word true spell, a truly wondrous formula.

The Dragon King urges Wukong to return to the Sangha, recounting the tale of Huang Shigong—showing that only with an empty heart can one attain the true fruit. The Bodhisattva teaches Wukong to turn back, entering the gate of tight restraint—showing that a single thought can take root. With no regret, one may press forward, and the Great Dao lies within sight.

Yet the Heart-Ape’s return to rectitude is a mutual awakening, not Wukong’s alone. For Wukong, it is the Heart-Ape of action, returning to rectitude by entering Xuanzang’s Buddhist gate. For Xuanzang, it is the Heart-Ape of non-action, returning to rectitude by gaining Wukong’s active Dao-heart.

The *"Six Bandits"* are everywhere beneficial, fully attesting to the Dao-heart. For Xuanzang, they nearly bring calamity—serving as whetstones for tempering. For Wukong, a single staff strike slays them—like gathering provisions for the Dao-path. It is said: *"The Trackless One"*—*"踪"* (track) lies within *"no return,"* while *"无"* (none) lies within *"return to rectitude."* When one returns, all returns; when one is rectified, all is rectified. The Heart-Ape is truly the seed of reality.

---

**Chapter Fifteen: Serpents Coil at the Mountain, Gods Secretly Protect;
The Eagle’s Sorrow Gorge, the Mind-Horse’s Reins Are Gathered**

Wu Yizi says: The Tai Bai Immortal’s song declares:
*"Dragons emerge from whore-fire,
Tigers are born in water."*

Regarding the Kan and Li of the body: it is clear that within yin there is yang, and within yang there is yin—the principle of yin-yang inversion. The heart is Li, yang, the dragon; the yin within Li is the tiger. The kidneys are Kan, yin, the tiger; the yang within Kan is the dragon. Only by subduing the tiger can the true water within Li descend and follow the dragon. Only by taming the dragon can the true fire within Kan rise and approach the tiger. This is called the *"water and fire intermingling, Kan and Li coupling"*—the first essential step in internal alchemy.

The previous chapter’s work of subduing the tiger was accomplished in the mountains; this chapter’s task of taming the dragon must be sought in the waters. *"Snake-Coiling Mountain"* depicts the body’s internal entanglements; *"Eagle’s Sorrow Gorge"* symbolizes the perilous ford where one is easily drowned.

The *"fiendish dragon suddenly emerges to swallow the horse, then vanishes without a trace"*—showing its elusive leaps and untamed ferocity. *"Old Sun cannot bear his impatience, scolds the master for being a pushover"*—showing that restraint has its methods, while fear and hesitation are of no use.

*"By Guanyin’s decree, the Metal Spirit secretly aids"*—clarifying that quiet observation and discernment reveal the priority of preservation. *"Lifting the tiger’s pelt, calling the loach to return the horse"*—demands vigilant self-mastery, ensuring governance is never lax.

The *"two locked in combat"* resemble the meeting of the Zi and Wu hours. *"Sanzang says: ‘The other day, when you struck the tiger, you claimed to have the skill to tame dragons and subdue tigers—why can’t you subdue this one today?’"* Here, the taming of the dragon is explicitly raised, tightly paired with the previous chapter’s subduing of the tiger.

*"The Traveler arrives at the gorge, churning the waters like the Nine Bends of the Yellow River in flood."* The fiendish dragon, deep in the gorge, sits and lies in unrest. To subdue and still it, one must first rouse and stir it—this is the Daoist formula: *"Flanks bent, waist curved, the Yellow River flows backward."* This is the method of striking and circulating, the key to taming the dragon. Otherwise, if left to its leaps and bounds, the dragon emerges from water, refusing to turn with the mind and heed our command—how then can it aid our Dao?

Only through ceaseless diligence, constant movement and stillness, can the true dragon be tamed. If it burrows into the grass, leaving no trace, it means the heels have rested, and progress halts. Thus, one must earnestly investigate, seeking its tracks and whereabouts, never allowing it to follow its own path and destroy the true mechanism. This is why the Monkey King, in his urgency, recites the spell, and the Earth Spirit reveals the dangers of the gorge.

*"Crows and sparrows dare not fly over, for the water is so clear they see their own reflections, mistaking them for their kin and often plunging in to drown."* This illustrates that those who do not recognize the true dragon in the water and seek to subdue it instead mistake the water for harmless and drown—just as crows and sparrows, ignorant, take their reflections for companions and plunge to their deaths.

Heaven has set this sheer gorge, where even wings cannot cross—yet within lies the Black Pearl, urgently awaiting exploration. How then to begin?

Direct the intent, tightly grasp the dragon’s horns, and bear the weight for distant conveyance. Swallow the white horse, and intent transforms into dragon; transform the white horse, and the dragon dissolves into intent. Follow intent in transformation, and the dragon’s nature becomes docile, obeying the heart’s every desire. Thus, upon seeing the *Bimawen*, control and release come effortlessly.

Yet to subdue the tiger, one must first subdue the ordinary tiger before the true tiger appears. The true tiger has no form—it takes the ape as its form. As when, in the previous episode, the tiger was slain and its skin flayed for clothing. To subdue the dragon, one must first subdue the dragon-like before the true dragon emerges. The true dragon has no appearance—it takes the horse as its appearance. As in this episode, when the horse was swallowed and its hide transformed into scales.

These dragon and tiger reside within the self—it is merely the foundation of inner cultivation. Should one seek to harmonize with the external Five Phases to achieve the Great Dao, then the *shen*-monkey must become the tiger, and the *hai*-pig must become the dragon. One must not cling to the text or fixate on images, mistaking false dragons and tigers and thus blundering blindly in practice.

Why then could the *Xingzhe* not subdue the dragon himself and had to enlist the *Jiedi* to summon the Bodhisattva? For the dragon is a creature of unyielding strength, and only the soft Way can approach it. The slightest impatience or coercion only rouses its nature further—only Guanyin’s effortless mastery can tame it. Just as before, when the tiger was subdued, it was through the effortless power of the floral crown that bound it. Thus, the moment the *Xingzhe* saw the Bodhisattva, he invoked the method of the floral crown to restrain his own demonic impulses. Even the sinful dragon labeled the *Xingzhe* a demon, yet neither could escape the bounds of effortless mastery.

Subduing the unruly arises from effortlessness, yet journeying toward the Spirit Mountain demands action. The Bodhisattva declared, *"Only when you obtain this dragon-horse can you proceed."* From this point forward, true vigorous progress begins. She summoned the young dragon and said, *"When have I ever uttered even half the word ‘Tang’ to you?"* How profound the intent! To remain ignorant of the origins of the scripture quest is to reach a dead end at this juncture. But to grasp its true purpose is to cross this shore and enter boundless prospects.

The Bodhisattva continued, *"That monkey-headed fool relies solely on his own strength and refuses to praise others."* Some say this means he cannot empty himself, making it a demonic obstacle on the path of cultivation. Others claim the *Xingzhe* trusts only his own hasty courage and scorns the wisdom of others’ effortlessness. Neither is correct. This passage reveals the immortal master’s secret essentials of the Great Dao—a subtle method of transmitting the golden needle.

The *Daoist Canon*’s ten thousand scrolls speak only of the Mysterious Pass and the Female Gate. Laozi said, *"The gate of the Mysterious Female is called the root of heaven and earth."* It clarifies the mechanism of yin and yang’s ebb and flow, their union and continuity, the root’s ingress and egress—what else could be the root of heaven and earth? Those who identify the Mysterious Female with mouth and nose, heart and kidneys, are mired in form and cannot speak of *"as if preserved."*

Dong Sijing said, *"Spirit is the convergence of qi."* Cao Daochong said, *"The Mysterious conceals spirit in profound obscurity; the Female harbors qi in harmonious emptiness."* Yu Yuwu stated, *"The two cavities of Kan and Li wondrously unite the two earths, blending spirit and qi without falling into names or appearances."* This comes closest to the truth.

Alas! The subtleties of internal refinement have been exhausted here, yet all speak only of the individual body. It is like crows and sparrows crossing a ravine, mistaking their reflections for companions—inevitably leading to fatal error. How lamentable!

Thus the Perfected One said, *"Do not cling to this body as the Dao,"* for this is the error of *"the monkey’s head stubbornly relying on its own strength."* Again he said, *"Recognize the elixir of immortality in that other realm,"* which is the truth of *"how could one refuse to praise another?"*

The following passage states: *"This time, as we proceed, there will be those who submit. First raise the words ‘fetching the scriptures,’ and without straining the mind, they will naturally yield in reverence."* This profoundly clarifies that straining the mind cannot be spoken of as the Dao, while submission is the means to fetch the scriptures. Straining the mind is solitary cultivation of a single element; submission is the gathering of the Five Phases. It is not attained through empty speculation but arises from the true accumulation of righteousness.

*"The Bodhisattva plucked the small dragon’s luminous pearl and instructed him earnestly, ‘Apply yourself diligently. Only after achieving merit will you transcend the mundane and restore your golden body of fruition.’"* This means that from now on, one must not rely on one’s own brilliance but must exert effort to succeed—take heed not to retreat or regret.

Most wondrous of all is when *"the Pilgrim seized the Bodhisattva and would not let go,"* saying four times, *"I will not go!"* Why? Taming dragons and subduing tigers pertains only to the Kan and Li of the individual body. Even if one has laid the foundation and refined the self, one remains an ordinary mortal—how can this fulfill destiny and transcend the world?

Thus he said, *"The Western Path is so treacherous. Guarding this mortal monk, when will we ever arrive? I will not go! I will not go!"*

Here the passage artfully presses forward to the marvel of the "three families meeting and proceeding together." Every line of the Bodhisattva’s exhortation is spoken in plain truth, without parable. *"Again, she bestowed a fundamental skill—plucking a willow leaf to transform into three life-saving hairs."* How profoundly subtle! The first three pertain to realizing nature, the inner lines of Qian; the latter three pertain to realizing destiny, the outer image of Qian. The first three and the latter three are ultimately the same, until all six lines become pure Qian, forging indestructible true gold—only then is the task complete. Yet the Pilgrim, taking the latter three as nature, truly embodies unfathomable transformation and boundless cyclicality. This is the very essence of great compassion and mercy, the fundamental intent of delivering the world and relieving suffering.

When the Pilgrim and Tang Monk reached the stream’s edge, they saw an old fisherman poling a raft to ferry travelers across. This raft, though substantial, carries the mortal monk to transcend the mundane and realize nature; later, the Cloud-Soaring Ferry, steered by the Guiding Buddha, is the bottomless vessel that ferries the sage monk to realize destiny as a Great Sage. Thus it is said: *"The vast true Suchness ascends the other shore; with sincere heart, nature is realized upon Vulture Peak."* This is the other shore of realizing nature, not the far bank of realizing destiny.

Upon arriving at the village gate to seek lodging, they received a saddle from the Dharma-protecting horse and a whip made of tiger sinew. What he rides is a dragon; what he wields is a tiger—just as they set forth on the path. Hence the words: *"The Bodhisattva bestowed saddle and bridle upon you. Strive diligently on the western journey; take care not to slacken or err."* Some say this signifies the mind-monkey returning to rectitude and the will-horse reined in, resolving seven or eight parts of the matter. Yet this merely glimpses the obstacles of mind and intent, without tracing the inner sanctum of nature and destiny! Such is the *"fleshly eyes and mortal frame, bowing in gratitude yet failing to comprehend—how many past achievements were squandered, provoking the Great Sage’s uproarious laughter!"* These half-hidden, half-revealed turns are most deceptive, hence the remark: *"He truly deserved a thrashing."*

Now, the meaning is clearly expounded: from the tangled heap, the treasure is plucked—pray, let all gather it, and spare yourselves the clout of old Sun’s golden cudgel.

**Chapter Sixteen: The Monks of Guanyin Monastery Scheme for the Treasure; The Monster of Black Wind Mountain Steals the Cassock**

Wu Yizi says: The Great Dao is profoundly subtle, its wonder lying in quiet observation and close scrutiny. With a pair of wisdom-eyes, one perceives that a thousand threads and ten thousand strands are but one affair—lest illusory shadows and empty flowers obscure the true essence and real meaning. These three chapters all prepare for the nineteenth, where Tian Peng is subdued, embodying the essentials of cultivating truth. Fearing that the world would not recognize this, the immortal master raises the banner of *"observation,"* threading it through the three chapters from beginning to end. One must observe both inception and conclusion; this must not be overlooked.

In this chapter, the folly of solitary cultivation of a single thing is made clear, and the perils of cunning and treachery leading to self-destruction must be known. The brocade cassock, a treasure of the heavens, is the color and form of the golden elixir. Only through accumulating virtue and amassing benevolence, radiating brightness and uprightness, honoring teachers and esteeming friends, and guiding through silent enlightenment may one hope for its reward. If one resorts to scheming and deceit, thinking only of oneself and not others, flaunting strength and cunning, and habitually straying into side paths—such are the ranks of wolfish schemers and rat-like thieves. They seek not longevity but hasten their own demise!

Thus, the root of cultivating truth most abhors a scheming mind. Of old, Master Duanmu encountered an old man by the Han River, who embraced a jar to irrigate his garden. Pitying his labor, Duanmu taught him to use a well-sweep. The old man said: *"I have heard that those who employ machinery must engage in mechanical affairs, and those who engage in mechanical affairs must harbor a mechanical mind. When a mechanical mind resides in the breast, purity and whiteness are no longer whole; when purity and whiteness are incomplete, the spirit is unsettled; when the spirit is unsettled, the Dao cannot bear it. I am not ignorant of this—I am ashamed to do it."* Duanmu hung his head in shame. The old man continued: *"You are about to forget your spirit and qi, cast off your bodily form, and only then may you approach it! If you cannot govern your own person, how can you govern the world? Begone, and do not hinder my work!"* For he detested excessive scheming.

The monk struck the bell and laughed, saying, *"You wouldn’t understand—this is ‘as long as I’m a monk for a day, I’ll strike the bell for a day.’"* He added, *"It was your grandfather Sun who taught me to strike it for fun."* This is what it means to follow conditions and accept one’s lot, to harbor no scheming mind, to play along with the occasion, and to embody the uncontrived delight of Heaven—true joy in forgetting all calculation. This stands in stark contrast to the old monk below, who stirred wicked intentions, with Broad Wisdom and Broad Scheming endlessly weighing gains and losses, each deploying their cunning.

The Dao is not beyond planning, yet there is oneself and others—when self and others are united as one, what one seeks is upright. Seeking uprightness is called *vital impulse*; where vital impulse abides, life endures. But if the old monk sought personal gain at others’ expense, he walked the path of perversion. Walking perversion is called *deadly impulse*; where deadly impulse reigns, destruction follows.

The Dao is not beyond stealing, yet to rob Heaven and Earth, to pilfer the workings of Creation without harm to either side or injury to the whole—this is called *knowing the mechanism*. Knowing the mechanism is *Heaven’s mechanism*; Heaven’s mechanism is spirit. But when the black bear seized the opportunity to stealthily carry things away, this was called *riding the mechanism*. Riding the mechanism is *human mechanism*; human mechanism is demonic. The absence of mechanism appears in spontaneity; human mechanism arises from contrivance.

Like the old monk who, once the cassock was in hand, wept bitterly by lamplight—Broad Wisdom and Broad Scheming’s schemes, fire attacks, and lethal force—this was human mechanism, riding the mechanism, walking perversion, and self-destruction. Yet with a numinous mind at work and seated awareness, hearing the crackle of firewood, he knew harm was afoot. Turning the tables, he ascended to the Southern Heavenly Lad to borrow the fire-repelling cloak, shielding Tang Monk while ignoring the rest. Where fire aids wind, this thing comes from illumination, harmonious yet not initiating—this was knowing the mechanism, Heaven’s mechanism, seeking uprightness to dispel perversion.

In this chapter, the two appearances of *"a honeybee"* devise a method, teaching one to observe closely and quietly, to recognize the error of harming others for personal gain, and the Dao’s counterstrike—how the Metal Duke cannot lack the Wood Mother. Tang Monk’s words, *"Do not compete in wealth with others,"* are the deep concealment of a wise merchant. The crowd’s words, *"You only harm yourself,"* are the self-invited consequences of fortune and misfortune. Though the admonitions are many, none hit the mark. Only by reading this closely can one grasp the art of narrative.

**Chapter Seventeen: Sun the Pilgrim Raises Havoc on Black Wind Mountain; Guanyin Subdues the Bear Spirit**

*Wu Yizi says:* The *Cantong Qi* states, *"Right and wrong pass through the viscera; inner observation yields reflection."* It speaks of the treasure of true yin and true yang, which cannot be obtained merely by scrutinizing the five viscera or scheming in thought. The old monk of the previous chapter, dwelling in Guanyin Monastery, schemed to seize the cassock—this was like inwardly observing the heart and employing the mind to plot. Little did he know that scheming with the mind stokes the heart-fire to a blaze, burning the heart-fire itself. Inevitably, it becomes a vast fire pit; not only does water fail to quell the flames, but the true treasure sinks into the lower field, just as the black bear stole away the cassock. This is the harm of misusing the mind’s mechanism. Thus, the opening laments: *"Cursed be that old skinflint who knew not men, scheming with his heart—today he has only harmed himself."* This is a sobering revelation.

Yet to abandon the method of observing the mind and forcefully direct effort toward the kidneys is to cling to the superficial talk of refining cinnabar and mercury—a mere side door, an external path! This black fellow is none other than the demon of the lower field. The Daoist is his qi, hence named *"Soaring Void"*; the scholar is his essence, hence clad in white. Calling it the *"Buddhist Robe Assembly"* shows they recognize only the name’s surface, not its inner reality. *"Black Wind Mountain, Black Wind Cave"* depicts the color of the Water Palace’s qi; *"iron helmet, black armor, dark robe, black boots"* shape the form of the Kan Palace. The Pilgrim’s entire account aligns with the essential aim of cultivating truth.

Only the line *"He said his body held elixir pills, but seeking them outside is futile toil"* directly condemns those who focus on the kidneys, refining mercury and extraction—an unlawful practice. It closely anticipates the later chapter where Tian Peng’s self-rescue represents the true, original, and natural union. *"The monster and the Pilgrim fought until the red sun stood at noon, then withdrew to eat."* This is the time when kidney qi wanes at noon and heart-blood flourishes, like closing the gate to draft a letter, inviting the venerable Gold Pond. *"Humble one"* denotes subordination; *"Venerable One"* denotes superiority. The meaning is clear.

The bear and black ape belong to fire yet appear as black men—these are the flames of desire within the kidneys; the Gold Pond belongs to wood yet is called the Cinnabar Chamber—this is the lustful fluid within the heart. Each has its season of encounter and can even offer mutual benefit, forming alliances. Drawn together by kindred qi, they say: *"Transmit to him some qi-absorption methods."*

The Immortal Master, fearing readers might misconstrue the previous monk as an impure mind, thus has the Pilgrim transform into a monk to clarify that the monk is none other than the Mind-Ape. *"Entering the cave, observing its couplets, a place of profound stillness and seclusion"*—this originally describes the realm of understanding destiny. Yet those who practice the demonic arts of extraction without comprehending the spiritual union of intercourse fail to know destiny.

After the deception is exposed and battle resumes, victory and defeat remain undecided. The Pilgrim says: *"I’m not much harder—let’s just call it an even match."* For the Pilgrim’s unyielding strength is like true gold, while the bear’s obstinate rigidity is like crude iron. Gold and iron do not merge, their banners and drums perfectly matched. Yet stubborn iron can be transmuted into gold—it simply lacks the alchemy of refinement to be gathered.

Thus, the journey to the Southern Sea to seek Guanyin is introduced, making clear that the method of subjugation must still be sought in the realm of contemplative freedom. Observe the marvel of subjugation: no longer forcing the scholar to slither like a snake, but simply snapping him in two, turning white into a face; no longer allowing the mess of filling earth, but cleaving the head into a cake, transforming black into cinnabar.

*"Seeing the words ‘Crafted by Lingxuzi’ at the bottom of the tray, the Pilgrim laughed: ‘Fortune! Fortune!’"*—for beneath these words lay the mechanism of destiny. Thus, the Bodhisattva seizes the opportunity, using the ploy to reclaim the kasaya. The immortal elixir cannot be formed apart from this, yet its function was misapplied, burying the treasure. Now, employing the very method of the other against himself, there is no need to rekindle the furnace and bell, sparing further toil. Why? True and false differ by but a single thought, yet fundamentally share the same principle. If one can master spiritual transformation, this can become that, and that can become this—this is the harmonizing elixir-head, the subtle workings of destiny in silent communion.

Thus, the Bodhisattva may transform into a demon, and the demon remains the Bodhisattva, revealing that self and other share a single source, never clashing. This sets the stage for the later self-mating of Metal Lord and Original Mother, who cannot bear even momentary separation. The Pilgrim eats the two immortal elixirs first—what is false can be transformed by the true; the Pilgrim then transforms anew—what is true shifts with the false. Transformation is boundless, concealment and revelation unfathomable, one becoming two, two becoming one—all is ultimately nothingness.

The moment the Pilgrim swallows the elixir, the demon is subjugated, demonstrating the principle of responsive spiritual communion. *"Already exited through the nostrils"*—showing the swiftness of transference. *"The Pilgrim, fearing delay, wished to strike him dead"*—this is *"no merit, yet merit lies within merit."* *"The Bodhisattva hastily stopped him, saying: ‘I have use for him elsewhere.’"*—this is *"having use, yet use is no use."*

*"The black man vowed to attain the true fruit; the Bodhisattva touched his crown and administered the precepts. Today, a wild heart is settled, and endless obstinacy is reined in"*—gaining the heart of freedom while restraining the desires of the senses, as circumstances dictate. The kasaya, lost and then recovered, the bear and ape return directly to the great sea, and the Black Wind Cave is transformed into a monastery for the beholder.

Chapter Eighteen: The Tang Monk Escapes Peril at Guanyin Monastery; The Great Sage Subdues the Demon at Gaolao Village

Wu Yizi observes: The *Book of Changes* states, *"Heaven and earth intermingle in misty vapor, and the myriad things transform into purity. Male and female unite in essence, and the myriad things come to life."* It clarifies that yin and yang employ union as their function. When heaven and earth unite, it is *Tai* (Peace); when mountains and marshes communicate, it is *Xian* (Mutual Joy); when water and fire merge, it is *Jiji* (Completion). Sometimes yin seeks yang, sometimes yang seeks yin; sometimes yang stirs and yin responds, sometimes yin moves and yang follows—only then can transformation and generation occur. From flying birds to hidden fish, from moving beasts to rooted plants, each possesses male and female, all following the Dao of one yin and one yang. If yin stands alone and yang is lacking, or yang stands alone and yin is lacking, then the qi of yin and yang becomes isolated and fails to unite—how can generation and transformation arise?

The *Cantong Qi* states, *"If a hen hatches an egg alone, her chick will not be whole."* It also says, *"If two women share a chamber, though their beauty be exquisite, even with Su Qin and Zhang Yi as matchmakers, their hair will rot and their teeth decay—ultimately, they will never know one another."* This principle is abundantly clear.

The Dao of Laozi and Zhuangzi fundamentally derives from the *Book of Changes*. Thus, Laozi says, *"The gate of the Mysterious Female is called the root of heaven and earth. Though it seems to endure ceaselessly, its use is inexhaustible."* And, *"All creatures emerge from it, and wriggling things none fail to follow."* Zhuangzi says, *"Supreme yin is solemn and still; supreme yang blazes and glows."* He also says, *"Though the corpse abides in stillness, the dragon appears; though the abyss is silent, thunder resounds. When the spirit moves, heaven follows."* For yin and yang, movement and stillness, each is the root of the other, and the Supreme Ultimate rides within them.

If one can embody the Supreme Ultimate, then the heavenly gate rests in the hand, and the earthly axis arises in the heart—this is the attainment of immortals, buddhas, and sages. But if a single thought errs, then movement and stillness alike depart from the heavenly principle; thus, the noble person values vigilance in solitude and introspection. If a single affair leans to one side, then movement and stillness alike lose their center; thus, the noble person values the investigation of things and the extension of knowledge. If one cannot investigate things and extend knowledge, but instead clings to one-sided yin or yang, cultivating only a single aspect—how can one become an immortal or buddha and transcend the mundane to enter sagehood?

Chen Niuwan says, *"There is something strange yet stranger still: the affinity of heart and kidney is not Kan and Li."* Yuanduzi says, *"The primordial qi of pre-heaven comes from the realm of emptiness. A single spark of yang essence is hidden within the mountain of form—not in the heart or kidney, but within the mysterious pass of the single aperture."* If scholars do not recognize yin and yang, do not know the proper timing, and cannot return to the source, but instead grope about within themselves, mistaking the flickering, luminous consciousness for the true reality, they will err again and again.

Alas! The Dao cannot be sought externally, nor can it be grasped by groping within oneself. It is profoundly mysterious and difficult to perceive. Those false masters who mislead their disciples, recklessly conjecturing that it is the art of bedroom alchemy or inner elixirs, stray ever further from the truth. The immortal master outlines the essentials, specifically revealing Laozi and Zhuangzi’s lofty and wondrous Dao—hence the name *"Gaolao Village."*

In the previous two chapters: one depicts the heart’s biased movement and the blazing of fire; the other, the kidney’s biased movement and the flaring of qi. Neither is the Dao, but rather calamity. If one mistakenly regards these two as the Dao, one falls into bias and encounters misfortune. Only by departing from this view can one escape this peril.

*"The Pilgrim turned the Black Wind Cave into a Cave of Crimson Wind"*—this is transforming a dark chamber into a realm of light, leaving a land of misfortune to ascend a mound of blessing. As master and disciples journey, spring’s warmth unfolds. The verses with *"mandarin ducks"* and *"butterflies"* depict the scene of paired flight in settled union—an exquisite depiction of yin and yang in harmonious union.

The most awakening moment lies in the passage where the place name is inquired. Wherever the Pilgrim goes, he never treats asking the name of a place as an urgent matter.

Here the repeated questioning is deliberate—if this place is indeed the true domain of Laozi and Zhuangzi, one cannot but investigate it with utmost care. To clarify this point is to *"grant convenience to others and to oneself."*

The subtlety lies in the two phrases: *"asking others brings no pleasure, but asking him yields commerce."* For to ask others is to stray from the Dao of Gao Laozhuang; to ask him, however, reveals the marvel of exchange and transaction. Later, when the Pilgrim sees the demon, he remarks, *"So this is the trade!"*—his heart already comprehends, echoing the earlier insight.

He says, *"This land on the border of the Ü-Tsang kingdom is called Gao Laozhuang."* The crow embodies the essence of the sun; the hare, the essence of the moon. In Ü-Tsang, the hare manifests, and through their mutual resonance, the boundary becomes distinct. The lofty origins of Laozi and Zhuangzi lie precisely here. The revelation that a daughter has *"taken in a demon as son-in-law"* is the very subtlety of their Dao.

To give a daughter in marriage is called *"marrying off,"* while to take a man into the family is called *"taking in."* The Dao of Laozi and Zhuangzi excels in managing yin and yang—not by following the natural course, but by reversing it. Proceeding in sequence, ordinary fathers and mothers produce mortal offspring; reversing the process, numinous father and mother give rise to immortals. A woman taking a man as her mate is like the moon receiving the sun’s light to shine. Thus, Daoists use the moon to symbolize the Dao’s essence—its meaning is abundantly clear.

When master and disciples are introduced, the elder states that his third daughter, Cuilan, has taken in a son-in-law from Mount Fuling. *"Third daughter"* signifies the marvel of the youngest; *"Fuling"* suggests blessings as vast as a mound—implicitly evoking the trigram *dui* (joyful maiden) and *gen* (resolute strength). Fearing the Pilgrim’s ugliness, the elder remarks, *"Ugly he may be, but he has skill."* He also notes that the son-in-law’s appearance and conduct are strange. The Pilgrim replies, *"When night falls, we shall see the truth."* All this depicts the worldly habit of judging by outward appearances, unaware that beneath coarse robes may lie jade, or within an old clam, a pearl—hidden within are the wondrous openings to immortality and Buddhahood.

The Pilgrim, weapon in hand, shatters the demon’s barrier and calls out, *"Summon your daughter—is she within?"* The old man calls his daughter forth, who weeps as she describes the demon’s erratic behavior: *"He vanishes like mist, leaving no trace."* One must seek the true form of one’s daughter in solitude and retrieve the whereabouts of one’s son-in-law from the depths of delusion—yet one must not cling to superficial traces and overlook the reversal of husband and wife.

*"The Pilgrim transformed himself to resemble the woman"*—this is not a change of form, but the revelation of his true form. Why? The primordial *yi* qi is metal within water, outwardly yin but inwardly yang. In essence, he is female; thus, in terms of external yin, the Pilgrim becomes the wife—this is principle. Readers, take note: the immortal master explicitly identifies the Pilgrim as female, not as a transformed guise. The subsequent dialogue—feigned illness, sighs, and entreaties—faithfully captures the intimate exchanges of a married couple.

Old Sun as the wife, Old Zhu as the husband—truly a pair heaven-made and earth-matched, a flawless and proper lady. All this is real meaning, though it may appear as playful illusion. When the Pilgrim reveals his identity as the Great Sage who wreaked havoc in Heaven five hundred years prior, Old Zhu immediately recognizes his origins and knows he can be subdued—he flees at once. The Pilgrim pursues relentlessly, like an eagle seizing a hare, like a cat pouncing on a mouse—such is the nature of their bond. *"The karmic tie forged five hundred years ago"*—their union was predestined, unbreakable. Let us proceed to the next chapter for a fuller account.

**Chapter Nineteen: Wukong Subdues Bajie in Cloud Ladder Cave; Tripitaka Receives the Heart Sutra at Floating Pagoda Mountain**

Wu Yizi observes: From the sixteenth chapter at Guanyin Monastery to this Cloud Ladder Cave, the interplay of metal and wood unfolds—the grand workings of true yin and true yang. Only thus does one open the gateways of the heart without falling into emptiness. This is *"true emptiness"*—empty yet not empty, precisely what the *Heart Sutra* means by *"form is emptiness, emptiness is form."*

Hence, the chapter’s outline pairs *"Wukong subdues Bajie"* with *"Tripitaka receives the Heart Sutra"* as a tight parallel. To *"subdue Bajie"* is to receive the *Heart Sutra*. *"Cloud Ladder"* is the chariot of Heaven; *"Floating Pagoda"* is the ladder transcending Earth. Ascending from lower learning to higher attainment, step by step, one moves from effortful action to effortless Dao—this is the ultimate aim.

The Monkey of *shen* belongs to Metal, and Metal engenders Water—west four and north one, together making one-five. The Pig of *hai* belongs to Wood, and Wood engenders Fire—east two and south three, together making one-five. Within these two fives, *wu* and *ji* naturally merge into one-five.

Within yang there is yin; within yin there is yang.
Within generation there is restraint; within restraint there is generation—
what is called "taking turns as guest and host, mutually serving as husband and wife."

In the ordinary sequence of the Five Phases:
Wood and Fire belong to yang and serve as husband;
Metal and Water belong to yin and serve as wife.
The Monkey is wife;
the Pig is husband.

In the inverted sequence of the Five Phases:
within yang lies true yin, which is wife;
within yin lies true yang, which is husband.
The Monkey is wife, yet in truth husband;
the Pig is husband, yet in truth wife.
True yin and true yang find their subtlety in *wu* and *ji*.

Thus it is said: the essence of the three and the five wondrously converges and coalesces.
The *Doctrine of the Mean* states: "The Way of the noble person begins with the relationship between husband and wife; at its utmost, it is discerned throughout Heaven and Earth."
If one grasps the word *"utmost"* as the utmost of exhausting one’s nature and fulfilling one’s destiny, enlightenment is already present in that very understanding.

Ordinary people do not follow the central Way, stubbornly clinging to partial yin or partial yang. Blindly cultivating and recklessly refining, they neither recognize the Dao nor attain it—
how pitiable, how lamentable!

At the chapter’s opening, "flames coalesce to manifest form"—the Pig embodies the vital essence of the Southern Dipper’s generative *qi*, the radiant hue of the Li Palace. The "nine-toothed iron rake" marks the yang number reaching its apex at nine, the very image of true yin; its operation turns with the rake, entrusted entirely to the *qi*-mechanism of bearing and movement.

Old Pig’s account of his self-rescue mirrors Monkey’s own self-narration, with phrases like "pairing yin and yang," "dividing sun and moon," "harmonizing dragon and tiger," and "drawing in the Golden Crow" all distilling the marrow of the Nine-Cycled Great Return Elixir. When Monkey engages him in fierce battle yet does not immediately subdue him, instead withdrawing their forces to their respective sides, he subtly highlights the three characters "Gao Family Village" to redirect attention to the original theme—why? Lest the world mistake victory in battle for true excellence, unaware that the highest good lies in subduing others without fighting! Here, the Dao of the Golden Elixir reveals itself as no mere art of seductive song.

Monkey recounts how "Tian Peng descended to the mortal realm, having mistakenly entered the wrong womb, yet his numinous nature remained intact." He adds, "For a celestial deity to take such a son-in-law hardly tarnishes the family’s reputation." This shows the upright *qi* of yin and yang, incomparable to mundane malevolent spirits, thus setting up the following line: "It’s only that there were no matchmakers or witnesses to mediate." Why so? The union of husband and wife depends entirely on go-betweens; without them, natures fail to harmonize. This is precisely what the *Cantong Qi* means by "those without shared speech are no kin." Thus Monkey resumes the challenge, declaring, "You don’t resemble one who forcibly seizes another’s daughter without matchmakers or witnesses"—his intent directly foreshadowing the water monster Sha Monk as the go-between ahead, while here planting the notion to elucidate how marital discord arises from such causes. Profound and intricately woven, this meaning is unparalleled. Yet readers dismiss it as mere banter, casually glancing past, burying its depth.

Monkey pressed further, inquiring whether the rake was truly from Squire Gao’s household. Pig boasted of it as iron personally forged by Lord Lao, bestowed by Laozi himself—both claims truthful. "Yet it could not so much as scratch my scalp," for wood cannot overcome metal. Upon hearing of the journey to the Western Heaven to seek the scriptures, Pig relinquished his rake. Why? Having received Avalokiteśvara’s clear decree, he knew that clinging solely to the rake was a one-sided attachment, incompatible with attaining true fruition—what is called "abandoning the self to follow others" rather than relying solely on one’s own strength. Thus he said, "Why not have spoken sooner of the scripture-seeking matter, instead of relying on brute force to batter at my door?" This precisely echoes the moment when Monkey subdued the young dragon, when the bodhisattva remarked, "That monkey-head relies entirely on his own strength and refuses to praise others."

With sincere resolve, Pig burned his den, surrendered his weapon, bound himself, and pledged allegiance—for wood, by nature compliant and righteous, yearns for metal, just as crooked wood submits to the carpenter’s line to be made straight. Within these eight verses, the principles of metal and wood generating and overcoming one another are expounded, as are the dynamics of guest and host in harmonious exchange. When husband and wife are not estranged, their natures and dispositions remain unopposed—this is the very inception of the Western Paradise’s bliss.

Upon their return after subduing Pig, Squire Gao recognized his son-in-law, and Tripitaka rejoiced in gaining a disciple, bestowing the name "Eight Precepts." With evil cast aside and rectitude embraced, a feast could now be prepared to celebrate their reunion.
