In what follows, "Eight Precepts seized Squire Gao, inviting my humble wife" reveals how hard it is to sever karmic ties; "Monkey and Eight Precepts drank the vegetarian wine" shows how easily one succumbs to fermented brews; "Accepting a single thread, ten thousand kalpas of cultivation are undone" illustrates the heavy burdens of material gain; "If the scripture quest fails, I’ll return to be a son-in-law" exposes the fragility of the resolve for the Way; and again, "Lest some mishap occur, the monk’s vows be broken, the wife’s marriage be lost" reveals the futility of blind, misguided practice. Every line is a child’s song of admonition—do not dismiss it as mere idle jest.

The three disciples took their leave and set forth toward the west. The verse within—"With harmony of disposition and settled nature, all conditions converge; when the moon fills the golden flower, the hair is shorn"—its first line alludes in passing to the recruitment of Eight Precepts, while the second heralds the reception of the *Heart Sutra*. For once Eight Precepts was subdued, the golden elixir took form, and so, having passed the border of Ü-Tsang, they encountered the Bird’s Nest Chan Master. Why? The sun west and moon east mark the division of the twin orbs’ illumination...

The crow hidden in darkness, the hare revealed in light—these are but the radiant interplay of a single qi. When conditions converge and the moon waxes full, this is the true essence. The luminous moon of Chan mind may thus be verified. This *Heart Sutra* scroll appears precisely here, like the crow concealed within the moon, bright and unstained. In its transmission of secret truths, it points the way through delusion—here lies the crux.

Tripitaka bowed and inquired about the road ahead. The Chan Master replied, "The path is long, and the journey’s end will come, but demonic miasmas are not so easily dispelled." Thus he bestowed the *Heart Sutra*, for it alone could dissolve such afflictions. Yet the sutra held no direct signpost to the Western Heaven, so he concluded, "This is the comprehensive scripture of true cultivation, the gateway to Buddhahood."

Tripitaka, still grasping for answers, pressed further about the way to the West. The Chan Master had already made it plain, saying, "Ask that acquaintance of yours—he knows the road west." Monkey, understanding, gave a cold laugh. "No need to ask him—ask me instead." Tripitaka failed to grasp his meaning.

The exchange that followed—Tripitaka seizing Monkey’s words—was the very question he sought to ask. Monkey said, "He insulted my brother and me." This was a veiled answer to the road west. Tripitaka replied, "He spoke of the western path—when did he insult you?" One took it as an insult pointing the way; the other heard only directions, not abuse. Master and disciple, question and response—all was Chan subtlety, every word a revelation. One must awaken swiftly.

Monkey said, "You wouldn’t understand: ‘A wild boar carrying a load’—that was an insult to Eight Precepts. ‘An old stone monkey of many years’—that was an insult to me. How could you possibly grasp his meaning?" To say *"You wouldn’t understand"* was to demand understanding; to say *"How could you grasp it?"* was to demand comprehension.

The Chan Master’s words—*"He knows the road west"*—were a charge to Monkey to relay the message. Monkey’s *"Ask me instead"* was his acceptance of that charge. All was already clear.

Eight Precepts said, "The divine master knows all past and future." He had spoken plainly enough. "But let’s see if his words—‘You’ll meet water monsters ahead’—prove true." Ah! How wondrous!

Oh, how profound! Though many demonic miasmas lie ahead on the journey, why single out only the phrase *"water monsters ahead"*? In the mouths of those two, the great road to the Western Heaven was already laid bare—why should Tripitaka ask further?

In Chapter Twenty, *"Tang Monk in Peril on Yellow Wind Ridge, Pig in the Vanguard at Mid-Mountain,"* Wu Yizi says: This passage makes clear that once one has received the *Heart Sutra*, one must act swiftly, lest one mistake the mind for the Dao and thus obstruct one’s own progress.

The opening verse speaks of the practitioner of the Dao having a method—one that arises from the mind and is extinguished by the mind. But who is it that gives rise to the method, and who extinguishes it? One must discern this clearly for oneself. If one claims that all is but one’s own mind, then why rely on the words of others? One need only apply effort to the mind itself—yet this is like trying to twist iron into blood, to knot the void into form, and to expect effortless attainment. Such a path is utterly impossible. This is to mistake the thief for one’s own child—how could one ever reach the state where both mind and dharma are forgotten?

One must recognize that there exists an immortal elixir beyond such delusions. Do not let it deceive you. First, see through the five phases, shatter all obstacles with a single blow, and strive until the mind becomes no-mind, whereupon the dharma will naturally cease. Only then is it like the autumn moon in a clear sky—undivided, with both nature and destiny fulfilled.

If one claims that the mind is already the Buddha yet fails to recognize that it is neither mind nor Buddha, misinterpreting the verse *"Since all is already the mind, why rely on the words of others?"* as a command to rely solely on oneself, has one not strayed from the true gate? Thus, the text begins: *"This verse is how Master Xuanzang awakened to the* Heart Sutra *and opened the gate."* If the mind were truly the Dao, and the Dao required nothing more, why speak of merely *"opening the gate"*? Why would he still journey westward to seek the true scriptures? Are the true scriptures of the Western Heaven not the teachings of others? This reasoning is clear and awakening!

The *Cantong Qi* says: *"Qian and Kun are the gates of the* Yi."* Wukong and Wuneng are the gates of the *Yi*, and thus the gates of the *Heart Sutra*. To attain Wukong and Wuneng is to open the gate. Only then can one proceed with cultivation and enter the inner sanctum.

Earlier, Chan Master Crow’s Nest, fearing that Tripitaka did not recognize the gate of the *Heart Sutra*, pointed to the *"wild boar"* and the *"old stone monkey,"* prompting Monkey to speak. The Elder understood the meaning, and so he recited and contemplated it constantly. A single spark of numinous light shone through—clearly the realm of *"the setting sun conceals the fire mirror, the rising moon reveals the ice wheel."* The Great Dao lies ahead; one must press onward swiftly.

If one merely gropes within one’s own mind, mistaking the luminous and ever-aware consciousness for the true reality, unaware of the great road to the Western Heaven, one is like a ghost clinging to home—what is this but a *"home-clinging ghost"*? How can one transcend the mundane? Thus, the ancients mocked those who preserved their youth and dwelled in the world yet could not shed their shells and ascend, calling them *"corpse-clinging ghosts."* Their folly is much the same.

When Monkey says *"your family’s ghost,"* he scorns all those who cling to the mind in their practice. Tripitaka says: *"Wuneng, if your heart were still so heavy with attachment to home, you would not have left it. You should return."* Though these words seem to reproach the fool without remorse, was Monkey truly slandering the idiot? No—he was using the fool to illustrate how clinging to the mind in cultivation is like leaving home yet still longing for it.

Observe how the fool *"comes with a dead heart, resolutely"*—to come with a dead heart is still a method of the mind, yet to apply effort, one must have skill. But if one has only a dead heart without skill, every step will be thorny, and the path forward will be blocked. Thus, the old man shakes his head and waves his hand, saying: *"You cannot go to the Western Heaven; you cannot obtain the scriptures."* Yet when Monkey reveals his true abilities, the old man says: *"You must have some skill."* And again: *"With such skill, you may yet reach the West."* This is the wondrous truth of Laozi and Zhuangzi.

Thus, the old man is made the master. The subsequent passage—*"south of the village, two young men with an old woman, three or four children"*—is but a shadow, the esoteric essence of Laozi’s *Daode* and Zhuangzi’s *Nanhua*, a tale that startles the foolish and shocks the vulgar, yet is the great skill for reaching the West.

When Pig mentions *"back in Gao Village, I often terrified mortals,"* he exposes the truth of those who are startled by ghosts and spirits. When Monkey laughs and says, *"Don’t speak nonsense—tidy up that ugliness,"* he speaks of transforming the coarse into the wondrous.

Later, the offering of tea, the inquiry into lineage and age—all foreshadow the perils of Yellow Wind Ridge, implying that only one with great skill like Sun Wukong can proceed. The hungry ghost who eats half a bowl of rice yet remains half-full illustrates the vast distance to the West, showing that only one with an unshakable resolve like Zhu Bajie can bear the burden.

For the mind is not the Dao. If one insists that the mind is the Dao and seeks it solely within the mind, one binds the mind with the mind and blocks the path—like the tiger demon of Yellow Wind Ridge, who tricked Golden Cicada and bound him to the wind-stilling stake. Why? The wind is *xun* wood, yellow is the center, and when they obstruct the heart and chest like a towering ridge, the tiger demon’s stubborn delusion is like the mind’s endless fixation.

See how the tiger demon *"clutches his own chest, flays his skin, and stands by the roadside"*—every detail vividly depicts the character *"heart."*

Thus he roared: “We are none other than the vanguard of the Yellow Wind Great King’s forces!” For to cling to the mind as the Dao is to be deluded mid-journey, blocking the path ahead. *"Pig chased the demon into the jagged rocks and drew his twin blades of red copper."* The "jagged rocks" signify the stubborn, tangled impurity; "twin blades," the discordant duality; "red," the mind’s true hue; "blades," the mind’s unyielding endurance. Thus the tiger demon, as the mind’s obstinate grip, serves as the mountain’s path-blocking vanguard—what need for further explanation? Pig, wielding the resolve of a dead heart, becomes the trailblazer halfway up the mountain, striking first with a single crushing blow.

Observe how *"Sanzang panicked and recited the *Heart Sutra*,"* while the demon, equally flustered, deployed the *"golden cicada shedding its shell"* ruse—now transforming into a tiger, now flaying its skin—all revealing how this mind, refusing to die, twists and turns, becoming its own demon. The moment true mindfulness arises, it is the very instant the wind carries him away. It is not the tiger demon using the golden cicada to seize the golden cicada, but the golden cicada itself using the golden cicada to seize the golden cicada. *"Clasping the Tang Monk in both hands to present him to the Great King"* and *"binding him in the rear garden"*—all are acts of the Tang Monk’s own doing, self-offering, self-binding, his mind ensnared in poisonous harm, beyond liberation.

Pig and Monkey saw through the tiger’s skin as the cicada’s discarded shell, recognizing the trap. One stood guard, the other fought, pressing straight to the demon’s cave. Monkey exerted himself and vanquished the tiger demon; Pig seized the moment and crushed it with a single strike of his rake. This is to first eliminate the mind’s obstinacy, shattering the barriers of true emptiness. Only then can one uproot the demon’s roots and rescue the golden cicada’s wholeness. Such skill is like a harmonious couple, one leading, one responding, inner and outer aiding each other in principle—what household difficulty could remain? Thus the verse concludes: *"When the Dharma Master meets demons in distress, / Temperament in harmony subdues the chaotic fiends."*

This passage begins with *"Dharma"* and ends with *"Dharma Master,"* while the next chapter’s outline immediately follows with *"Dharma Protection,"* clearly illustrating the method of cultivating truth, its subtle foreshadowing and hidden threads like a gray snake in the grass—those with keen eyes will surely see through it.

**Chapter Twenty-One: Dharma Protection Establishes a Manor to Detain the Great Sage; Mount Sumeru’s Lingji Subdues the Wind Demon**

*Wu Yizi says:* This continues the preceding discourse. Having extinguished the self-aggrandizing gaze of the tiger, one must still sweep away the rat’s head with its many forks. For when the mind possesses *shishen* (discerning spirit) yet clings to self-reliance, it is dazzled by brightness and loses clarity, dispatching illumination yet failing to illuminate—its harm lies in discernment that does not discern. To recognize that *shishen* is not true is to realize that the non-spiritual in spirit is true. Hence it is said: *"To refine spirit, refine the non-spiritual spirit."*

Scholars who fail to grasp the intent of *"non-spiritual spirit"* may scrutinize minutiae and spawn demons, or plunge into deep doubt and multiply delusions. Some drift into heterodox paths, others waver between two possibilities—all are blind cultivation and reckless refinement, called *"wild blindness."* Han Yu said: *"One who cannot discern the grounds of gain and loss is called wild."* When spirit does not guard its abode, the illness lies in the heart, like a violent wind shaking without stability. Confucius said: *"To speak without observing another’s countenance is called blindness."* When heart-fire attacks the liver and assaults the eyes, it is like the Yellow Wind blowing and wounding the injured.

Thus, long-held stagnation breeds vermin, and accumulated delusion multiplies hardships—all stem from lack of clarity, leading to endless entanglement. This is why the *Rites* warn against *"hesitation"* and the *Book of Documents* values *"decisiveness."* To transform hesitation into decisiveness lies in nothing but clarity. Yet clarity still does not depart from *shishen*—it is the eye-opening medicine, most urgent and precise.

In this passage, the ophthalmologist serves as the great eye, while Lingji Bodhisattva is the one who, after applying the eye-opening medicine, reveals radiant illumination. Dispelling the fleeting glimpses of confusion and awakening the unobscured wondrous vision, one stabilizes the wild, erratic wind and severs the rat’s two-pronged hesitation. The rat’s nature is thievish and suspicious; it emerges from its burrow indecisively, always wavering between two ends. Thus the old demon is an ancient rat spirit from the foothills of Vulture Peak.

Observe how *"the old demon lowered his head in silence, pondering a scheme,"* and upon hearing the words, *"grew even more vexed, saying, ‘This fool knows nothing!’*”*

“I never ate his master—yet he struck down my vanguard in turn.” Such are the words of one without steadfast vision, who instead faults others. “The old demon scrutinized carefully and saw that the Traveler’s frame was coarse and stunted, not even four feet tall”—this was belittlement born of blindness. “The Traveler said, ‘You whelp, you’ve no eye for true measure!’”—this was mockery to his face. “With a single blow to the head, he grew six feet, then stood a full ten feet tall.” For the four great elements compose a body, which inherently possesses the true form of ten feet—never to be judged by outward appearance or superficial likeness.

“The Traveler revealed himself and devised a plan, but the old demon mistook the feint for substance. The two fought outside the cave, the Traveler employing the art of ‘a body beyond the body.’” Thus, with many defenses confounding the senses, the eyes grew dazzled and disordered, and so harm befell them. “The old demon unleashed his yellow wind technique—using madness to counter delusion—how could heaven and earth not darken? Thus his assault targeted the eyes.” This passage expounds that chaos cannot be quelled by further chaos; only clarity suffices to end disorder.

“Hairs shrank to tiny things, like wheels spinning in frenzy.” “Fire-eyes and golden pupils could not be opened.” “Pig could not dare lift his eyes or raise his head, unaware of victory or defeat, life or death, lost in doubt and hesitation”—all depict the state of wild delusion without anchor, the moment when wondrous illumination is lost. From lack of illumination arises wild delusion; from wild delusion, the mind loses its illumination. To cure wild delusion, one must first restore illumination. Thus the Traveler said, “Saving Master can wait. I don’t know if there’s an eye-doctor around—let him treat my eyes first.”

“The two paused to look and saw a farmstead, its lamplight flickering dimly.” Already, within obscurity, a sliver of light had been borrowed. “The brothers sought lodging, paid respects to the old farmer, and sat with him. The Traveler asked, ‘Does anyone here sell eye medicine?’” “The elder said, ‘That’s called the *Samādhi Divine Wind*—if it blows on you, you might still live!’” Then he added, “I once met an extraordinary man who transmitted a formula called *Three Flowers, Nine Seeds Ointment*.” This is the wondrous method of *Three Flowers Gathering at the Crown* and *Ninefold Cyclic Elixir*.

Pig laughed, “Sir, where’s your bright staff?” The Traveler replied, “You’re treating me like a blind man.” “Pig chuckled silently, the Traveler snickered softly”—both were veiled mockery, implying that those who blindly cultivate in ignorance have never encountered a true eye-doctor. Zhuangzi said, “Healing the eyes can forestall aging.” So it is.

In the eye-medicine passage, “the guardian” is none other than *shishen*. The entire farmstead was arranged for the eye-medicine application, a provision to retain the Great Sage—indeed, the universal eye-medicine for all beings. Is the “farmstead” (*zhuang*) here any different from Zhuangzi’s “farmstead”?

“The Traveler suddenly awoke; Pig guessed idly”—do not dismiss these as mere jest. They reveal the folly of those without steadfast vision and the ignorance of vulgar eyes. The verse says, “Wondrous medicine cures eye pain; vanquish demons without hesitation.” Clear and decisive, this is the moment when illumination may be attained. Thus, in the following passage, the name of Lingji Bodhisattva appears, and the Golden Star points the way.

Pig said, “You secretly protected Master but could not manifest openly, so you transformed this immortal farmstead.” This shows that the eye-medicine was secretly transmitted by the old farmer—a profound truth not to be openly displayed. The Traveler said, “Let me go to the cave and scout around.” Pig replied, “Find out whether he’s dead or alive. If he’s dead… if he’s not dead…”—all indecisive, wavering words, lacking illumination.

“The Traveler reached the cave entrance, but it was still barred, the demons asleep.” “He transformed into a mosquito and entered; the lesser demons snored on.” All was murky confusion, a realm of dreamlike unawareness. The old demon said, “Guard the door carefully. I fear that gust of wind didn’t kill Sun Wukong.” Such was his fearful hesitation. Then, seeing “a tightly sealed inner door, he slipped inside”—already entering its *samādhi*.

He saw “Master Tang bound to the Wind-Stilling Stake”—a state of constraint and bondage, from which there was no self-liberation. The Master “could only fix his heart on Wukong and Wuneng,” showing how the mind cannot govern itself but seeks external aid. Reciting the *Heart Sutra* alone—what use was that? A lesser demon reported, “I saw a big-eared one, but not the one from yesterday.” Such was the smallness of his perception.

The old demon said, “Sun Wukong is nowhere to be seen—he must have been blown to death by the wind, or else fled to seek reinforcements elsewhere.” Such was the delusion of his perception. The lesser demons replied, “If he’s been blown to death, it would be our good fortune. But what if he wasn’t killed—what then?” Such was the timidity of their words. All was wild conjecture and idle talk, hesitant and wavering, torn between two fears.

Suddenly, the old demon confessed, “Only the Bodhisattva Lingji could still my wind’s power.” This was the hollow admission of a guilty mind, the *shen* revealing itself unbidden—a confession made without torture. As for the Star of Metal, that luminous and merciful constellation, “pointing south with his hand,” “transforming into a gentle breeze and vanishing,” with “Pig Eight Precepts bowing in gratitude”—such was the guidance of a benevolent master, akin to father and mother, for whom one vows to attain the Dao and repay the great debt.

Wukong ascended Mount Sumeru and peered within, seeing only “a hall adorned in brocade splendor, a chamber of solemn dignity. Golden flames and jade mist, wisdom’s sword and virtue’s assembly”—all describing Lingji’s boundless *dharma*-power, a marvel beyond words. The Wind-Stilling Pellet was perfectly round and true, the Flying Dragon Staff swift and wondrous in its divine efficacy. “Revealing his true form, he was but a yellow weasel—having stolen oil from a lamp, dimming its flame, he fled here and became a spirit.” This was the unvarnished truth of his blindness laid bare.

“Seized and brought to Vulture Peak to see the Tathāgata”—precisely the exercise of great *dharma*-power, shattering the web of doubt, attaining the radiant form, and once more beholding the Tathāgata. “The two of them slaughtered a den of cunning hares, fox-spirits, musk deer, and horned stags”—what cunning, what suspicion, what deer-like panic, what branching confusion remained? This was “summoning Lingji to rescue the true monk and rediscover the great western road.”

Alas!

Amidst the lotus thrones and Buddha-realms, blossoms innumerable—knitting his brows, he looked intently.

**Chapter Twenty-Two: Pig Battles the Flowing-Sands River; Mokṣa Enforces the Dharma to Subdue Wujing**

Wu Yizi says: “The Perfected One of Purple Yang said:
*Tiger leaps, dragon coils—wind and waves rage rough,
At the central true position, the Mystic Pearl is wrought.
Though fruit on branches ripens in due season’s span,
How could a child in the womb bear any pearl?*
This is the true purport of this chapter.”

The wondrous convergence of the Five Phases lies wholly in the two earths, wù and jǐ. Earth is the center of the Five Phases, presiding over the four seasons, each for eighteen days. Dispersed, it permeates the four times to engender and transform the myriad things; united in its twofold governance, it unifies the Nine Palaces and wondrously gathers the One Origin. Thus metal and water, meeting earth, congeal and gather; wood and fire, meeting earth, harmonize and blend. Wù is yang earth, jǐ is yin earth—metal, water, wood, and fire each possess their wù-jǐ position at the Central Palace, where the Five Phases converge and revert to the Supreme Polarity. The Supreme Polarity is but a forced designation. Though earth is one of the Five Phases, it is in truth their culmination. In the human body, it is the true; the true of intent is sincerity. With sincerity, movement and stillness are both true, and nature and feelings attain the mean—hence the noble person must make his intent sincere.

Sha Monk is true earth. The meanings of “flowing sands,” “weak waters,” “skulls,” and “rolled-up curtain” are all revealed in the eighth chapter. This chapter particularly clarifies that metal, water, wood, and fire cannot depart from earth; obtaining this earth, they assume their proper position at the Central Palace, whereupon the functions of the golden elixir are complete and the sagely embryo is formed.

The earlier gāthā of the Bird’s-Nest Chan Master says:
*“The wild boar shoulders his load and goes,”*
*“The ancient stone monkey of many years,”*
*“The water-monster met along the way.”*
“Met” is *gòu*, signifying the wondrousness of their encounter—thus they mutually rely on the great western road. Hence it first says: *“Having crossed Yellow Wind Ridge, one enters a stretch of level ground to the west.”* Yet why should great waters suddenly block the path, so difficult to ford? Not that it is truly hard to cross—precisely in the difficulty of crossing does one encounter and thereby attain passage, which is the great western road.

Yellow is the true color of the center, so from Yellow Wind Ridge the essentials of the Five Phases are drawn forth. In eight lines of verse, the embodiment of all five colors and the fullness of the Nine Palaces are depicted—each word is worthy of contemplation. When Bajie battles the monster, wood meets earth and they mutually overcome. The monster’s own account reveals the wondrousness of the three and five each as a five, within which it says: *“First I gathered the infant boy and the maiden girl, then I took up the wood-mother and metal-father as my staff.”* This is the true import. The two of them fought twice, yet through impatience could not subdue him—why?

When hearts and minds remain unaligned, there is need for patient mediation—this cannot be forced through coercion or haste. Thus when Wukong seeks stillness through impatience, his impatience only grows; when the water monster retreats to provoke action, his movement only makes stillness harder to attain. Hence Bajie’s plea for “ten thousand strategies,” and the Monkey King’s counsel to the master: *“Do not fret,”* followed by *“go beg alms and rest,”* showing that progress in cultivation should be gradual, not rushed. The remark on *“how hard it is to carry clouds”* reveals that ordinary beings can advance step by step but not all at once. The admonition that *“no methods should be applied, only thorough experience in foreign lands”* shows that dull natures value effort over ease. The observation that *“though they could protect, they could not go ahead to fetch the scriptures”* demonstrates that spiritual practice proceeds from difficulty, not ease.

When Bajie enters the water to challenge the monster, the origin of the treasure staff is recounted—phrases like *“length lies in the mind, thickness follows intent”* clearly reveal the operation of true intention and the mind’s radiant wisdom. *“This bout fought underwater then surfaced”* echoes the *Cantong Qi*’s *“where speech fails, they are no kin.”* The verse has already made this plain. For yin and yang to unite, true earth must mediate—just as a matchmaker is needed for a marriage. Where speech fails, hearts remain estranged, and harmony eludes. The line *“only because the wood-mother overcomes the elixir knife”* explicitly identifies Wuneng as wood and Wujing as earth.

*“The monster only clamors by the riverbank, refusing to come ashore”* depicts a nature still in flux, poised between two possibilities—most elusive to grasp. Once impatience takes hold, the creature vanishes without a trace, leaving no opening for action. Thus when Wukong’s temper flares and he leaps into a somersault, the monster conceals himself completely, nowhere to be seen. Only by turning inward in quiet reflection and summoning Guanyin Bodhisattva can the original face be revealed. Wukong then hastens to the Southern Sea to pay homage. The Bodhisattva says: *“You ape, ever relying on your own strength, unwilling to speak of protecting the Tang monk. Had you mentioned ‘the scripture-seeker,’ he would have submitted at once.”* For the protection of the scripture-seeker is the shared purpose of the three. To speak of *“the scripture-seeker”* is to establish common speech, align hearts, and dissolve suspicion through mutual sincerity.

The Bodhisattva calls Huian to fetch the red gourd, bids Wujing take refuge, and arranges the nine skulls in the pattern of the Nine Palaces, placing the gourd at the center—forming a dharma-boat. Excellent indeed! The Great Being’s compassionate vessel ferries the world, revealing the system of the golden elixir.

One who can harness and steer it finds their drifting nature settled, the tranquil waves passable, and thus avoids sinking to instead reach the far shore—all fundamentally rooted in this. The *"gourd"* symbolizes the two earths forming the jade tablet. *"At the center"* they wondrously merge and congeal. The *"arrangement of the Nine Palaces"* is all for my use; here, one establishes life and destiny—what peril or obstruction could remain?

A poem says:
*The Five Agents pair to match celestial truth,
Recognizing the old master from of old.
Refining the self and establishing the foundation—subtle use,
Discerning right and wrong to see the cause.
Metal returns to nature, reuniting with its kind,
Wood departs to seek affinity, yet remains of equal rank.
The two tablets complete the work in stillness,
Harmonizing water and fire without a trace of dust.*

For yin and yang must pair to match celestial truth. The old master was lost, but now may be recognized—this is the subtle use of establishing the foundation, the cause of dispelling the deviant and preserving the upright. Metal departs yet returns, restoring its original nature; self and other were ever of the same kind, metal and wood not of different ranks. Thus, the two tablets complete the work, forming the sacred embryo. From this stillness, nurturing and harmonizing, what trace of water or fire’s dust remains?

This single dharma-boat of the Great Being is like the dragon maiden’s single pearl—it is the original essence of human life. Thus, the Curtain-Lifting General is the true earth of true yin and true yang, the Yellow Dame of marital union, the essential subtlety of forming the embryo and establishing the foundation.

Mujaku then calls forth Wujing, who sincerely submits. The skulls are removed, the Nine Palaces arranged, the gourd placed at the center, and the master invited to sit upon it. Lightly and steadily they cross, waves calm and winds still; in no time, they reach the far shore. Truly, this is the great function of establishing life and destiny, of planting the feet firmly on solid ground.

Yet why is it also called *"pure and non-action"*? For though there is action, it does not adhere—like the Bodhisattva sending Mujaku to demonstrate the dharma without going herself. The operation lies with Wukong and Wuneng, the boat is formed by Wujing, while the Tang monk enjoys non-action. Though there is action, it is in truth non-action.

When Mujaku retrieves the gourd, it transforms into yin qi, the two earths become true, and the Nine Palaces merge completely. From this, the foundation is set, the golden elixir takes form, and the Way of non-action gradually manifests.

Ah! The method of the golden elixir’s function is clearly revealed here!

In Chapter Twenty-Three: "The Tang Monk Remembers His Origin; The Four Sages Test Meditative Resolve"

Wu Yizi says:
The Five Phases converge and cluster, forming the sacred embryo.
The original root is already attained, and life and destiny have their foundation.
From this point, one preserves and nurtures it, gradually shedding the embryo to approach spiritual transformation—thus may celestial immortality be realized.

Yet I fear that worldly people may misconstrue the wondrous Dao of convergence and clustering as the heterodox teaching of "absorbing yin to supplement yang," becoming infatuated at the sight of beauty, sinking into the sea of desire, forgetting their origin and drowning in mere words—how truly pitiable! Therefore, this passage urgently highlights how easily one may be deluded by feminine allure, and how crucial it is to maintain steadfast vigilance, never forgetting one’s original face.

Thus it is said: "This chapter of the tale reveals that the Way of seeking the scriptures does not depart from the Way of attending to the root within one’s own body." Ah! The immortal master’s words are most subtle—"attending to the root" runs through the entire work. Should one glance superficially, the profound principle would be buried and lost.

This "root" does not refer to what lies near or within, but rather to that which, in the opening chapter, precedes heaven and earth as the primordial spiritual root, and which, after the Five Villas’ episode, permeates the later heaven and earth, yet remains the primordial spiritual root. Every person possesses it in full, lacking nothing. Those who have lost it must attend to it to return; returning is but the restoration of what was originally present within. Those who have not lost it must attend to it to avoid forgetting; forgetting means forgetting what was never originally present within. Those who have lost and then regained it must attend to it to preserve it; preservation means securing what was originally present within, letting go of what was not, and fortunately returning to what was.

Hence it is said: "The Way of seeking the scriptures does not depart from the Way within one’s own body." In the verse, "the wayward monkey firmly bound" and "the inferior horse diligently reined" are acts of discipline upon the ground of inherent nature; "Wood Mother and Metal Duke" and "Yellow Dame with Crimson Child" are functions upon the root of life. Once the true message is recognized, this is the great wisdom. With a heavy burden and a long road ahead, all depends on diligent effort.

Should the slightest thought of slackness arise, it is a sign of failing to bear the burden fully—idleness and desire will then gradually sprout. If there is any impulse toward hasty progress, it is a sign of reckless haste and overstepping, inevitably leading to unruliness that cannot be reined in. Pigsy, resenting the weight of his load and urging the horse to speed, thus sows the seeds of trouble. This is like the Monkey King wielding his staff to tame the wayward ape, or spurring the inferior horse to gallop—both acts of discipline.

The episode "Testing the Chan Mind" is overt in its meaning, yet its subtlety lies beyond the words. For while testing the mind is the manifest intent, the alchemical method is still concealed within. Why? To test the mind is merely to test it—one or two beauties would suffice to captivate the soul; why wait for four? Yet the Dao is called the interplay of one yin and one yang. The master and his three disciples naturally form a fourfold harmony, the true number of yin and yang in balance, where none can be lacking. Only when one sees beauty as no beauty and faces temptation without attachment does one attain the unyielding, indestructible body. Scholars may find it easy to sever ties with the world and renounce all things, but when the body itself is subjected to restraint and confronted with temptation, the mind often shifts and resolve is lost.

To achieve true mastery, one must pass through the crucible of tribulation; to recognize pure gold in its full luster, it must be forged in searing flames. The trial by the Four Saints is like testing gold with a touchstone: when gold meets the touchstone, its true grade is revealed; when one encounters the trial of the Four Saints, the sacred and the profane are fully exposed. Nothing in the world stirs the heart more easily than beauty; if one remains unmoved by it, nothing can move the heart at all. This is why the transformed maiden tests them—like refining with fire, only true gold remains unaltered.

In the alchemical method, the female seeks the male, as in a marriage where the groom is brought into the bride’s home. This is no ordinary union, so the Four Saints take the form of women awaiting childbirth to summon a husband, with Pigsy as the groom and Friar Sand as the matchmaker. Yet the Four Saints are nothing other than the true qi of the One. From the One they become four, and from these four arise countless transformations—just as the Great Sage’s true gold can manifest boundless change. Only the Great Sage perceives this and recognizes the subtle work of enlightenment. The hidden meaning of the text is thus made clear.

The woman said, “I was born in the year *dinghai*, on the third day of the third month, at the *you* hour. Thus my husband is three years older than I.” “Three years older” means he belongs to the *shen* year. *Shen* is the Monkey—nothing other than the true *qi* of the One. This estate was left by one born in the Year of the Monkey, so are his wife and daughter not transformations of those not born in the Year of the Monkey? The mother and three daughters together total ninety-nine years in age, the extreme of yang numbers—this is the principle of old yang transforming into yin and producing the daughters.

The *Baihutong* states: “Fire is so called because it transforms.” Thus we know metal can transform into fire, and fire in turn can transform into metal. Here, the four women become the raging fire of four crucibles, and whatever encounters them is inevitably melted and refined. At first, one relies on this fire to congeal the elixir, and in the end, one relies on it to refine the elixir. This transformation is the most essential fire-work in the alchemy of the golden elixir, sufficient to forge and temper one into truth.

How do we know this is fire? The woman said, “I was born in the year *dinghai*.” Is not *ding* fire? Is not *hai* the wood that generates fire? And are they not in a pine and cypress grove, where the art thrives and fire blazes? If so, then her boasts of vast fields, livestock, silks, and embroideries are all the radiance of fire; her praises of Zhenzhen, Aiai, and Lianlian’s beauty are all the spirit of fire; her descriptions of the enjoyments of spring, summer, autumn, and winter are all the movement of fire. Her “sudden rage, turning to enter the screen, and bolting the waist-door” is the rising and falling of fire. Her disregard for Pigsy’s ugliness and eagerness to take him as a son-in-law, so long as he can manage the household, is fire’s indiscriminate melting of jade and stone alike.

Her “suddenly opening the door with a shout, raising a red lantern and a censer, fragrant clouds swirling, the clatter of jade pendants, leading the women in worship” is the fierce, swirling, searing, and refining power of fire. Her “leaving behind a pair of gauze lanterns, leading the fool step by step, the hall aglow with silver candles” is fire’s flickering brilliance, its thoroughness and precision, leaving no place to hide. Her words to the three daughters, giving them handkerchiefs to cover their heads and failing to find a match, are the unpredictable, lively, and elusive nature of fire. Her returning to the room, handing over a pearl-embroidered robe, and binding the fool are fire’s twisting restraint, its intricate and inescapable grasp.

“Those people vanished in an instant, leaving behind a grand hall with carved beams and painted rafters” is fire’s transformative concealment, its marvelous and swift changes, which cannot be grasped by form. When Pigsy “twisted left and right, unable to endure, repeatedly saying ‘let’s discuss this later’; letting go of the reins, calling his mother to arrange the marriage, boasting of his skills, declaring ‘no need to negotiate,’ his lust in disarray, insisting on bowing to them all, ‘all must cover their heads for me,’ and when he failed to catch them, you beckoned me; when he put on the pearl robe and fell to the ground”—all this is the state of being refined by fire, flying and leaping uncontrollably, bound and restrained, losing one’s original nature.

The most crucial point in this passage is Pigsy’s words, “In my youth, I once learned the method of *aozhan*.” Those who recklessly practice *caizhan* take female beauty as their crucible, believing the perverse doctrine of “absorbing yin to supplement yang,” thereby burning themselves to death—like moths flying into flame. How lamentable! Thus the poem concludes with its true meaning: *“The foolish do not know the root cause, / The sword of desire wounds the body in secret.”* This is the harm of seeking scriptures outside the body while neglecting the root.

The verse within states: *“From this, wash the heart and reform the faults.”* This is the essential point: after congealing the elixir, one must thoroughly wash the heart and guard against desire. Without guarding against desire, the original root, once obtained, will be lost again—how pitiful! If one can henceforth not forget the original root, only then is one truly virtuous. Thus it is also said: *“From the correct path, cultivate with care, / Sweep away love and desire to return to truth.”*

**Chapter Twenty-Four: The Immortal of Longevity Hill Keeps an Old Friend / The Handsome Monkey King Steals the Ginseng Fruit at Wuzhuang Temple**

*Wu Yizi* says: These five or six chapters together elucidate that consuming the golden elixir is the original root of the body. Within the chapter, the “ginseng fruit of Wuzhuang Temple” expounds the principle of the golden elixir. The “Pure Wind and Bright Moon” striking the fruit and the “elixir plate” receiving it reveal the name of the golden elixir. Its meaning is drawn from the *Doctrine of the Mean*: “Establishing the great root of the world, one can assist heaven and earth in their positions and nurture the myriad things,” transforming the intent of “stiff flesh” into a wondrous awakening, deeply sufficient to break through deafness and enlighten the vulgar. If readers remain ignorant and dismiss it as absurd and unorthodox, they are like the mice in the pine and cypress, unaware of the fine cedar within the hall.

*Can* means “three.” The *Book of Changes* says: “Three for heaven, two for earth, and thus the numbers are established.” One, three, and five are the numbers of heaven; two and four are the numbers of earth. Three threes make nine, the number of old yang; three twos make six, the number of old yin. Two threes and one two make eight, the number of young yin; two twos and one three make seven, the number of young yang. All are “three for heaven, two for earth.” Three multiplied by two is five, which ultimately returns to one. One paired becomes three; three and five transform into three. Three threes are three; five fives are five. Extending this to a hundred, a thousand, ten thousand, or a hundred million, and even to the infinite, there is nothing that is not “three and two,” nothing that is not one.

Thus the Dao of Heaven is without beginning or end, and through the reckoning of numbers one may infer its mechanism. The Dao of Heaven is most wondrous, and by means of numbers one may illuminate the true principle. Principle is made manifest through numbers, and numbers emerge from principle; they may rely upon each other but may not be violated—hence it is called “relying on numbers.”

What is the One? It is the primordial *qi* of True Unity. Master Zhu said: “Heaven, through yin and yang and the Five Phases, transforms and gives birth to the myriad things. *Qi* forms their shapes, and principle is also bestowed upon them. This principle does not depart from *qi*, nor does *qi* depart from principle.”

The Way of the Golden Elixir takes the cultivation of *qi* as its foundation. The essence of cultivating *qi* lies in accumulating righteousness. If one cannot accumulate righteousness but instead feels shame when looking up and remorse when looking down, then principle is lost and *qi* is obstructed—how can it then fill Heaven and Earth with its vastness? Thus the Way of the Immortals, when it reaches Mencius’ teaching on “cultivating *qi*,” is nearly fully revealed. And when it is said that this *qi* is born of “accumulating righteousness,” the methods of the Elixir are almost complete. Those who cling to emptiness and stillness without understanding the accumulation of righteousness and cultivation of *qi*—the work of the heart—will ultimately perish.

Human life is like a fleeting glimpse of a horse or a dream of a butterfly; Heaven’s mandate is without constancy. One must swiftly turn the light inward, sever desires, and follow principle, embracing impartial vastness. When principle is attained, one’s nature is restored; when nature is restored, life is consolidated. With the vastness of the eye attained, this is called accumulating righteousness and cultivating *qi*; this is called establishing oneself and securing one’s destiny. Its most crucial point lies in vigilance in solitude.

In a single thought of numinous clarity, preserve the genuine and eliminate the false, never departing from it for even a moment. What Heaven has bestowed upon me is only this; and what I use to practice virtue and attain the Dao is only this. Relying solely on this as the master, one is not swayed by emotions nor bound by names and conventions. Gain and loss, constant change—none of these are heeded. This is what it means to be steadfast.

Vigilance renders the heart’s ground empty and vast—this is the state before arousal, the establishment of the great root of the world, the original face of human life. Unfallen into being or non-being, unconfined by place, without sound or scent, it is the undifferentiated Great Ultimate. Confucius’ joy was in this; Yan Hui’s unchanging joy was in this. Li Yanping’s silent sitting and embodied realization were realizations of this; Lu Xiangshan’s “first establishing the great” was first establishing this. Chen Baisha’s emergence of signs in stillness—this was the very sign.

Those who have not yet recognized this must still it to perceive it; those who have recognized it must still it to nurture it. When stillness reaches its extreme and movement arises, one must move to embody this; when engaging with affairs and encountering things, one must face circumstances to verify this. This is what is meant by observing the mechanism of movement and stillness, being and non-being, and preserving the all-encompassing, unfathomable spirit.

Once the great root is established, the thousand branches and ten thousand leaves all flourish and grow unimpeded. Thus one can establish the heart for Heaven and Earth, secure the destiny of the people, and assist Heaven and Earth in nurturing the myriad things.

Yet even when one has fully attained this spirit—luminous and numinous, capable of responding to myriad changes, foreseeing past and future, equalizing life and death, transcending the mundane and entering sagehood—one may consider it the ultimate and complete, true and without further addition. But how is this spirit merely the yin spirit of the postnatal, not the yang spirit of the prenatal? When the Four Great Elements disperse, it remains solitary and is still bound by the regulations of Heaven and Earth, unable to regulate them. Heaven and Earth must settle this spirit in the place of utmost yang before it can fully attain its original root. The original root lies where I was born, inseparable from the primordial *qi* of True Unity.

Though principle is not mixed with *qi*, it is never apart from *qi*. Thus where *qi* transforms, there too is the abode of spirit and principle. *Qi* has no luminous, numinous spirit, but possesses a spirit of profound obscurity. The spirit that is not spirit is the ultimate spirit; the spirit of the ultimate spirit is the ultimate truth. When people speak of this spirit, they are utterly at a loss. Even those who claim to recognize it do not know where to begin, and some dismiss it entirely with the phrase “seeking the obscure and practicing the strange!”

Consider this: the *River Chart*, the *Luo Writing*, and the *Great Change* are the ancestral methods of the ancient divine sages, transmitted in the hearts of the Zhou and Confucius to enlighten later generations. What they expound—yin and yang in their proper and reversed sequences, the principles of the prenatal and postnatal—are these truly “seeking the obscure and practicing the strange”?

I do not say that fully attaining this luminous, numinous, and unwavering spirit is not the true Way, but rather that only when one reaches the utmost can one fully attain the luminous, numinous, and unwavering as the ultimate truth. Thus it is said: “If you wish for the Valley Spirit never to die, you must establish the root in the Mysterious Female.”

Let me clarify the meaning of this passage: At the beginning of the chapter, the Eight Precepts were bound by selfish desires, having lost their original root. The Traveler’s words in the *Xun* trigram faintly illuminated a hundred aspects, reminding and arousing their sense of shame and innate goodness. The *West River Moon* verse states: “There is only one original root, with no trifling profit to add to the bag. Safeguard this capital well, firmly guard it and do not let it dissipate.” This speaks of preserving what has not been lost, returning what has been lost, and, having lost and then returned, being vigilant—there is only one, with no possibility of addition.

From this, one knows that the depravity of those who practice sexual arts is like the Eight Precepts fainting in confusion, senseless. The Eight Precepts, ashamed, said: “From now on, I will never dare to act recklessly.” This is the moment of a scholar’s repentance and entry into the Way. Thus the author, in concluding the harm of lust, subtly reveals the root—this is the One.

The number One is contained within Five and reaches its utmost in the myriad. The outline speaks of “Mount Everlife,” and the inexhaustible myriad myriad is already encompassed within the myriad; it speaks of the “Abbey of Five Estates,” and the boundless permutations of five are already unified within Five.

The Five comprise three of Heaven and two of Earth, yet none depart from metal, wood, water, fire, and soil. Paired with the Five Teachings, they become benevolence, righteousness, propriety, wisdom, and trust; united in the One Origin, they form the Primal Chaos and the Supreme Ultimate. The text explicitly states: “When the Primal Chaos first divided and the Vast Mist began to separate, at the moment before Heaven and Earth unfolded, this Spiritual Root was produced.” This Spiritual Root is the same as the Spiritual Root in the opening chapter, yet it distinguishes between the prior-to-Heaven and the posterior-to-Heaven: the former, existing before Heaven and Earth, is the Spiritual Root that gives rise to Heaven and Earth—what is meant by “There is something prior to Heaven and Earth,” which is the prior-to-Heaven that Heaven does not transgress; the latter, arising after Heaven and Earth, is the Spiritual Root produced by Heaven and Earth—what is meant by “Within it lies a treasure, hidden in the mountain of form,” which is the posterior-to-Heaven that Heaven does not transgress. It emerges from the prior-to-Heaven and enters the posterior-to-Heaven. The Spiritual Roots of prior and posterior to Heaven are ultimately one qi, ultimately the Great Root, ultimately the progenitor of the Five Phases. Those who study the Dao, if they can obtain this prior-to-Heaven qi within the posterior-to-Heaven, can thereby master this qi to govern the myriad principles of the posterior-to-Heaven, without falling into isolation.

The outline speaks of the “Great Immortal”—between Heaven and Earth, only this Root is great; of the “Pilgrim”—between Heaven and Earth, only this is the movement of the Five Phases; of “retaining old friends”—retaining the old refers to traces already manifest; of “stealing the ginseng”—stealing the ginseng praises the power of Heaven and Earth. The text’s declaration to “offer incense and worship solely to the words ‘Heaven and Earth’” makes the fundamental intent clear. The boy says, “These two words—the one below cannot receive our incense,” meaning it belongs to yin and is insufficient to match the marvel of Heaven. The elder, having beheld the fine scenery of Mount Everlife, finds its secluded charm extraordinary and believes the Thunderclap Monastery is not far, but the Pilgrim laughs: “Too soon! Too soon!”

Here the Tang Priest has reached this stage—though he recognizes the original Root, he cannot examine it with true insight. To advance further, the original Root remains the original Root, yet still eludes his grasp. Only through reverent seeking, wholehearted devotion, and unwavering aspiration can it be fully preserved without loss. As the saying goes, “Recognizing the original Root is but the beginning of true work”—mere empty awakening does not bring one to Vulture Peak. Thus the Pilgrim speaks of such difficulty, urging him to sudden awakening: “If only your mind is sincere in seeing your nature, every moment of turning back is Vulture Peak itself.” This echoes the *Zhou Odes*: “Learning ever shines brighter toward radiance,” warning against needless doubts of distance or separation, lest the original Root be grasped and then lost again.

Only the Five-Zhuang Temple of Western Ox-Head Continent yields this “Herb of Returned Elixir,” also called “Ginseng Fruit.” The West is the direction of Lesser Yin, corresponding to autumn, the season when the myriad things bear fruit. Fruit embodies yang within yin—postnatal qi harboring the prenatal One. That ginseng grows between Heaven and Earth to become fruit follows the same principle. The character *草* (herb) is composed of *甘* (sweet), *日* (sun), and *十* (ten): two figures paired, encompassing the numbers of Heaven (one), Earth (ten), and the four directions with the center. Within lies the utmost yang, combining to form its image—hence *草* (herb), which also means “early,” urging swift return of the elixir. This is the true gold of the Golden Elixir, the rightful heir of returning to the origin—thus the name “Zhen Yuanzi” (Master of the Origin). If one can consume it, partaking of Heaven and Earth to become all things, how is this not to reign as lord of the world?

“It bears fruit once every three thousand years; to smell one grants three hundred and sixty years of life; to eat one, forty-seven thousand.” Among his scattered immortals, countless in number, forty-eight remain in sight. He takes forty-six to Heaven, leaving two to guard the temple: one aged one thousand three hundred and twenty, the other one thousand two hundred. Though the numbers of Three Heavens and Two Earths are interwoven to depict its marvel, this is no empty talk but solid truth—all ultimately deriving from the One and Five, extending to the myriad things.

Master Zhen Yuan instructs Pure Wind and Bright Moon to pluck ginseng fruit in welcome of old friends. The two lads, citing Confucius’ words, doubt they share the same path, revealing their deep understanding of how worldly scholars cling to Confucianism and doubt the Dao. The Great Immortal, recalling the Buddha’s assembly, clarifies their bond as old friends, pointing to the shared origin of Dao and Confucianism. When master and disciples arrive at the temple, they admire the scenery, read the couplets within, and inquire of Pure Wind and Bright Moon—yet these are not the “Heaven and Earth” incense offerings, for they speak of the Primordial Heavenly Worthy inviting one to taste the Dao Fruit of Chaos. All describe the reality of Two Earths and Three Heavens, the profound mystery of the prenatal True One, though people fail to recognize it.

The Pilgrim’s mischief is no mere temper—it exposes how worldly folk all claim sagely wisdom and heroic might. Even one as spiritually awakened as the Pilgrim struggles to yield and believe; how rare, then, are true kindred spirits! The Tang Priest, unaware of this rare treasure, trembles and retreats three feet—not from ignorance, but to show how worldly eyes, even in one with deep karmic roots like the Tang Priest, find it hard to receive such guidance. How many, then, abandon themselves to fate!

Pig, drooling with greed, schemes to taste the new; the Pilgrim turns invisible, climbs the tree, and steals the fruit. When one falls and vanishes, they summon the local earth god to investigate. This reveals how all covet the Golden Elixir, yet without true knowledge, none dare consume it hastily. The Pilgrim calls himself “the most notorious thief under Heaven”—no idle boast, for this path steals from Heaven and Earth, seizing the workings of creation, truly the ringleader of the treasury of principle.

The earth god says: “This fruit fears the Five Phases: it withers at wood, dissolves in water, burns in fire, and sinks into earth. Only when struck by metal does it fall; only when wrapped in silk can it be held.” For the Golden Elixir is the primordial qi of chaos, not leaning toward any single phase. To favor one is to fail in bearing true fruit—no margin for error, as the saying goes: “A hair’s breadth of deviation and the elixir will not form.”

The Great Sage steals three; the three share them, united in purpose. Pig, insatiable in greed, clamors and ruins the plan, unable to guard against danger. The two lads revile the Tang Priest, who says: “Virtue and righteousness matter most; have them apologize.” Yet the three disciples deny all—proof that the Tang Priest cannot partake of the Golden Elixir, foreshadowing the later uprooting of the tree. The Golden Elixir harmonizes the Five Phases and embodies the Five Virtues: the Tang Priest’s hesitation is lack of wisdom; the disciples’ denial, lack of faith. Without wisdom and faith, two of the Five Virtues are missing, three of the Five Phases unbalanced. With the root shaken, the fruit vanishes—is this not the inevitable workings of principle and fate?

Note: To the west of Persia lies a kingdom called Dashi. Its king often sends men by ship with provisions into the sea. After eight years, they still have not reached the western shore. In the sea, they see a square stone, upon which grows a tree with red branches and green leaves. On the tree, countless infants, six or seven inches long, neither speak nor cry but all can smile, moving their hands and feet, their heads fixed to the branches. When plucked, they wither and blacken in hand. The envoy brings back one branch, now kept by the king of Dashi. From this, we see such trees truly exist in the world—far from absurd. The immortal master merely borrows this to expound the Dao of the Golden Elixir, partaking of the creative workings of Heaven and Earth.

Those of limited knowledge like Jia Dao and Meng Jiao, unaware even of the infant tree, how could they ever grasp the wonders of the Golden Elixir!

**Chapter Twenty-Five: The Immortal Zhenyuan Gives Chase to Seize the Pilgrim Monks; Sun Wukong Raises Havoc at Wuzhuang Temple**

Wu Yizi observes: The earlier verse states, *"There is but one original root—no trifling profit to swell the purse."* Yet Zhu Bajie, in his greed, seeks to add where nothing is to be gained; Tang Sanzang, in his ignorance, resists and obstructs. Whether excessive or deficient, both fail to savor the true flavor—for the flavor lies in the original.

The root is first uprooted; whence then does the Dao arise? If one does not thoroughly investigate and firmly cultivate this fundamental root, it is to abandon the source for the branches, to remain ignorant of the hidden mechanism within one’s sleeve. One may attempt to steal across Chen Cang in darkness, yet know not that one’s footing is weak. No matter how cunning the schemes, no matter how extreme the transformations, all remain but illusory passions and false appearances—shifting and erring, turning back and forth, with no means of deliverance. Would this not delay the journey, preventing one from ever reaching the Western Heaven and beholding the Buddha’s face? As the saying goes: *"The halo behind the neck is still illusion; clouds beneath the feet do not make one an immortal."*

This is like the Great Sage toppling the tree’s fruit, whereupon the two youths bolt the layered gates, declaring: *"You’ve ruined the immortal root of our Wuzhuang Temple! If you wish to reach the Western Heaven and pay homage to the Buddha, you’ll have to turn back, re-enter the wheel of rebirth, and be born again!"* Stern in word and just in principle, their admonition is as thunderous as a hibernating dragon’s roar, as nurturing as a compassionate sail in the rain.

Yet Wukong laughs, revealing the truth; the two youths curse, branding him a thief; Bajie clamors to strike, taking sides—all mistaking the false for the true. How could they not forsake the real for the illusory? By uprooting the divine tree and severing the elixir’s lineage, their cry of *"Let’s all scatter!"* is as apt as *"When the tree falls, the monkeys disperse"*—precise and unerring. The verse *"Wukong has ruined the Herb of Returning Life; the bright moon and clear wind chill the heart and gall"* serves as the sharpest awakening.

For one must first act, then gradually attain effortless mastery. If one merely awakens to the emptiness within *"emptiness"* but fails to recognize the *"fruit of emptiness"* within that emptiness, what result can a single awakening yield? Is this not to lose the Returning Elixir in the very act of awakening? Though the clear wind and bright moon remain, how can they be enjoyed? In the end, one will still fall into the dust, unable to accomplish anything.

Locking the gates and lying are but mixed tactics—where then is the method to revive the dead? Adding greens and serving tea are but misapplied, rigid views; shutting the doors and hurling abuse only create a scene of verbal strife. Unlocking the gates to flee by night is but groping in the dark—though one may temporarily escape the cage, one cannot evade the net. Rushing forth while others sleep is but stumbling and falling—though one may strive forward, one will ultimately lag behind.

Thus, Immortal Zhenyuan awakens the two drowsy youths to investigate the root of the harm, and pursues them for nine hundred *li* to seize back the reckless ones who have obscured their origin. His mastery of the universe within his sleeve is like the strings that manipulate puppets—what is meant by *"The Heavenly Gate in hand, the Earth’s Axis born in the heart."*

*"Each tied to a single pillar"* shows that every person is inseparable from their fundamental root—how can one stand without relying on it? The hasty use of the Seven-Star Whip made from dragon skin to strike them reveals that each must be interrogated to uncover their origin—how can one not reflect deeply and gain insight! *"Striking the legs"* strikes at their unsteady footing—how can they wander recklessly? *"Substituting the blows"* substitutes repeated inquiry so that they may hasten forward.

If one relies on cleverness and deploys petty wit, seeking to use the fragile willow’s form for the plan of rebirth and transformation, this is to take the false as real—even the real becomes false. Like stealing away at midnight, it is nothing but a dream. When master and disciples transform the willow tree into an illusory body while obscuring the truth that the human and tree are the real body, how can the elder not nod off in the saddle, his foundation unsteady?

Once reproached, their guilt collapses; the Great Immortal catches up and seizes them again, binding them as before. He wraps the three in cloth, then lacquers them—those who obscure their origin do so because they cannot turn inward to illuminate themselves. The many-eyed cloth is wrapped tightly around them so that their entire bodies may grow eyes to seek clarity; the outer lacquering ensures that, though the exterior is dark, the interior may shine with self-awareness. If one cannot turn inward to awaken to the root, one is not far from death—even if revived from such a tight encasement and lacquered for burial, it is still a stroke of fortune. Who would say it is inappropriate?

Why is Wukong alone ordered into the oil cauldron? Oil is water; the cauldron is metal. Beneath it burns wood and fire; within it lies stone and earth. Though the five phases gather in their forms, they remain easily stained by grease and fat. Moreover, they are divided and disharmonious, unable to unite as one. If scholars do not fathom the deep source within but merely follow the external traces, their desiccation will come swiftly.

Toppling the immortal root serves to chastise the confusion of truth and falsehood; mistaking the false for the true serves to test one’s exhaustion. Uprooting the tree and overturning the hearth follow the same principle—both are but a great uproar. When the tree falls, the monkeys scatter; when the cauldron leaks, the oil dries—how can one not regret the tumult?

Alas! The difficulty of descending into the oil cauldron is like the difficulty of ascending to the Western Heaven! Only by enduring the oil cauldron can one ascend to the Western Heaven. Wukong may be able to descend but cannot; he may be able to ascend but cannot. If he cannot protect Tang Sanzang, neither descending nor ascending, neither ascending nor descending—what is to be done? To protect Tang Sanzang, descend into the cauldron, and ascend to Heaven, one must still turn inward, reflect, and invite Guanyin Bodhisattva.

Chapter Twenty-Six: Sun Wukong Seeks the Formula on Three Isles; Guanyin Bodhisattva Revives the Tree with Sweet Springs

Wu Yizi states: This precisely speaks of ingesting the golden elixir as the fundamental principle of cultivating the body.

Formerly, the Fifth Patriarch, Great Master Hongren, transmitted a verse to the Sixth Patriarch, Huineng:

*"When the sentient come to sow the seed,
By the ground the fruit will grow.
The insentient, lacking seed,
Lack nature and thus no birth."*

Having received it, Huineng added: *"The robe covers only your body—do not transmit it further."* When Huiming pursued him to inquire about the Dharma, the Sixth Patriarch said: *"Do not think of good, do not think of evil. At just this moment, return to me Venerable Ming’s original face."* Ming greatly awakened and asked: *"Beyond these secret words, is there yet meaning?"* The Sixth Patriarch replied: *"What I now tell you is not secret; if you turn inward in reflection, the secret remains with you."* The Sixth Patriarch then instructed him to go north to receive others.

Later, the Sixth Patriarch arrived at Caoxi, where he was pursued by wicked youths. Concealing his traces among the Huai and Ji districts, he at last accomplished the great matter.

How can fruit arise without seed? How can nature take form without sentiment? That nature cannot exist apart from sentiment is like fruit that cannot grow apart from the earth. When the Sixth Patriarch spoke of not thinking of good or evil, he had already returned the original face—yet he still said, *"Not secret; you must turn inward in reflection."* Instructing him to go north to receive others—whom was he to receive? This may be clearly understood.

Otherwise, like passing through the Wuzhuang Temple only to miss the ginseng fruit before one’s very eyes—is this not to be without sentiment and seed, and how then can there be nature and life? The Venerable Xue Daoguang, with his wondrous awakening beyond the dust, keen wisdom, and perfect comprehension, ultimately turned inward in reflection, yet deemed it not the supreme vehicle. Seeking out a true person and receiving guidance, he was drenched in sweat and suddenly repented his past errors. Thereupon, he cast off his monastic robes, returned to lay life, and concealed himself in a bustling metropolis, relying on the powerful to resolve his great matter before attaining the true fruit. This was Daoguang’s turning inward to seek the method, humbling himself to gain benefit.

Thus it may be known that mere awakening is not the true seed, and without sentiment, nature cannot be fulfilled. Mencius said, *"Whether one dies young or lives long, one does not waver; one cultivates the self and awaits destiny—this is how to establish one’s mandate."* Master Jing said, *"Though one stands unmoving at the hundred-foot pole’s tip, to have entered thus is not yet true. Take one more step at the hundred-foot pole’s tip, and the ten directions are your entire body."* The *Awakening to Reality* states, *"Only when medicine meets its kindred qi does it take form; the Dao resides in the subtle and imperceptible, harmonizing with nature. Once the golden elixir is swallowed into the belly, one knows at last that my destiny is not ruled by Heaven."* All speak of exhausting one’s nature to reach destiny, obtaining the primordial utmost essence as the supreme vehicle of the Great Dao.

Those who study the Dao in cultivating the self and dwelling in the world must not rely on self-strength; they must empty their minds, humble themselves before others, guard against deceit, and seek instruction—only after diminishing again and again can they gain true benefit.

Sun Wukong, with his divine transformations and extraordinary prowess, protected the Tang Monk, believing himself invincible in his strength—yet how much more invincible was the protection afforded by the ginseng fruit! How could Wukong escape the grasp of Zhenyuan? Why? Because empty awakening is not as real as the fruit.

The eight opening lines precisely diagnose the root malady, and the concluding line—*"For those stubborn in their rigidity, there are always others more rigid still"*—reveals that those mired in self-adherence remain utterly deluded. When the Immortal Zhenyuan took the pilgrim’s hand, it was the mechanism to guide the Tang Monk; when he demanded the tree be restored, it was to urge the cultivation of the Tang Monk’s root. He further said, *"If you can revive the tree, I will bow to you eight times and take you as my sworn brother."* For friendship is the mutual aid of having and lacking, and fraternal love is the support of hand and foot.

The immortals’ path begins with action and culminates in non-action—having is none other than non-being. If one cannot act as having, how can one act as non-having? The Buddha’s path begins with non-action and arises from action—non-being remains being. If one cannot be without non-being, how can one be with being? In silent accord and shared intent, they originally form a single principle, all seeking the same method of reviving the dead.

Though this passage speaks of the Monkey King’s quest across three isles for a remedy, it truly reveals the two schools’ unity in their original source. Could the Great Immortal not heal the tree himself? Yet he specifically invited Guanyin—this is to clarify that non-being precedes being, and to show that transformation has its wellspring. Though master and disciple each possessed their own spiritual root, they deferred to the Immortal Zhenyuan—this is to clarify that the self resides within others, and that their qi is not two.

From this discernment and pursuit, even the Three Stars of the Eastern Sea could not surpass its wonder. Naturally, they converged at Wuzhuang Temple, adding longevity, fortune, and prosperity. Even the Eastern Flower Patriarch could not surpass its divinity, and so extolled Wuzhuang Temple as a blessed land, a cave heaven, a spiritual root. Though the Nine Elders of Yingzhou could not advance further, they marveled at Wuzhuang Temple, hastening to welcome its master, offering him nectar to drink and jade lotus to eat.

Zhu Bajie tugging at the Star of Fortune to beg for fruit, rummaging about in chaos—this reveals his heavenly nature. Wukong laughing at Dongfang Shuo for stealing peaches without success, their mutual jesting—this too shows that it was not truly possessed. All these scenes, reflected through the ginseng fruit, in jest and play, truly convey that the ginseng fruit is not easily obtained.

Only upon reaching the rocky cliffs of Putuo and meeting Guanyin Bodhisattva did they recognize the subtle and imperceptible as the highest grade, the true flavor of Shaolin. Seeing that even the bear spirit had the affinity to attain the true fruit, how could the Tang Monk lack the means to save the spiritual root? Zhenyuan’s spiritual root was opened by Heaven; the sweet dew from the pure vase was wrought by the self.

The poem says:
*"To perfect the body of action, one must long practice the truly wondrous Dao.
This is indeed the true essence of the entire work."*

The *Diamond Sutra* states:
*"If one sees me in form, seeks me in sound, such a one walks the deviant path and cannot see the Tathāgata."* For the truly wondrous Dao is profound and difficult to perceive, lying entirely in the heart’s inward reflection and tranquil observation. To cling even slightly to sound or form is to depart from the formless, odorless original substance—such a one walks the deviant path and is cut off from the Tathāgata.

It further says:
*"All conditioned dharmas are like dreams, illusions, bubbles, shadows, like dew, like lightning—contemplate them thus."* Some interpreters say that all conditioned things are illusory, understanding only the fleetingness of a galloping horse’s shadow or a butterfly’s dream, the spark struck from stone or the flower in the mirror—what real benefit is there in this? Those skilled in discourse assign a meaning to every word, never repeating themselves—how much more so the World-Honored One! These four lines are the essential pointer of the entire sutra; how can one reduce them to a single "emptiness" and treat "dreams," "illusions," "bubbles," "shadows," "dew," and "lightning" as one and the same?

Thus, only by grasping the meaning of *"like dreams, illusions, bubbles, shadows"* can one grasp the mechanism of *"like dew, like lightning."*

The common folk fail to grasp the true essence of the *sweet dew* and the *dragged lightning* as the *lingering root’s* genuine virtue. They abandon the *suchness* of conditioned existence to enter the unconditioned, believing that through perception and insight they have attained awakening. Yet I do not know what they perceive, what they see, or what they awaken to. By the twenty-fourth night of the twelfth month, all will dissolve and vanish—deeply lamentable!

The *Avataṃsaka Sūtra* states:
*"If one follows the inclinations of all beings,
then one honors the Buddhas with supreme reverence.
With the water of great compassion nourishing all beings,
one cultivates the wisdom flowers and fruits of the Bodhisattvas."*

When Guanyin arrives in the rear garden, she dips a willow branch into the *sweet dew* and takes the gentle and weak as the ferry into the Dao. She draws a *resuscitation talisman* on the practitioner’s palm, seizing it as the reins to congeal the *true essence*. Observing the water’s flow as the measure, she forbids violating the *Five Phases’* vessels, relying on *non-dependence* as the standard for action. The *lingering root* transcends the Five Phases and exists alone; the *sweet dew* nourishes the original transformation to benefit all things. The withered roots revive upon receiving it; the fallen fruits restore themselves. "The fruit tree returns to life, gaining an extra one"—is this not the clear proof of returning to the origin, restoring the root, and fulfilling the mandate?

This is indeed *"nourishing with the water of great compassion to cultivate the wisdom flowers and fruits."*

*"The great immortal urgently commands taking gold to strike the child,
knocking down ten, arranging them on the elixir field,
each eating one—thus forming the gathering of the *rénshēng* fruit.*
It speaks of the *golden elixir* belonging to all; the great immortal merely hosts as an expression of fulfilling old debts. From this point, the *golden elixir* is complete—ingested, it revives the dead as one revived, like the dead returning to life. The treasure of the immortals is obtained; the foundation for the Western Heaven is laid. All are immortals of eternal youth—why fear not seeing the *jiao-liu* golden Buddha?"

They become brothers; the two families merge into one. The wondrous Dao of ripening causes and conditions is thus fulfilled.

If scholars rely only on their own rigidity, refusing to yield, ponder, or seek instruction, how can they recognize the extraordinary *rénshēng* fruit of the Five庄 Observatory in the *Mount Wànshòu*?

Thus the patriarch said:
*"I possess a treasure, hidden in the *xíng* mountain."*
Do the others recognize it?

**Chapter Twenty-Seventh: The Corpse Demon Plays Three Tricks on Tang Sanzang**

The Saintly Monk, having consumed the *rénshēng* ginseng fruit, now has the *golden elixir* within him. Henceforth, he has shed his mortal form and transformed his bones—his spirit refreshed, his body robust.

Yet after attaining the elixir, one must still clarify the mind and perceive true nature, discarding the common mortal form and exchanging it for the refined. If he fails to recognize truth, to see through illusions, if he appears merciful yet slips into indulgence, if he seems wise yet is blinded by cunning deceit, then his virtue may become excessive and invite *róngxié* perversity, his wisdom may falter and risk abandoning the right path!

Thus, the Corpse Demon’s three tricks are revealed, and the Saintly Monk’s resentment in driving him away is justified.

The Corpse Demon is none other than the *qì* shell of those who cultivate the Dao. Originally a malevolent spirit that deludes, it can mislead others unaware. It appears as a youthful beauty, yet is truly hollow white bone; it seems like a tender youth, yet is actually frail and aged; it masquerades as a living *bóshā* (菩萨), yet is in truth *jiūpánchútú* (鸠盘荼); it feigns pity, yet is merely a fool toying with others.

For the human body harbors three Corpse Demons, which resent one’s attainment of the Dao, and during moments of slumber, they accuse one of transgressions.

Those who seek the Dao, if they cling to form and appearance without first annihilating the three Corpse Demons, will never escape the mortal shell nor ascend to the *Yùjīng* (玉京) of immortality.

Thus, those who cling to the body are like guardians of the Corpse Demon, and the Demon’s accusations against them are countless. Those who preserve the body must only focus on eliminating the Demon, for its schemes against them are unfathomable.

How great is the Demon’s power to bewitch and mislead!

In this chapter, *"Sanzang was journeying to the Zōngyá place when hunger struck"*—just when the Corpse Demon sought to claim him as its meal. The Pilgrim declared, *"Master, you lack understanding!"*—meaning he failed to see through the deception.

Sanzang, drowning in his own partiality and displeased, took this as a harm wrought by hunger, yet his clouded wisdom was the root of his straying from the right path.

Since Sanzang subdued the Pilgrim at *Liángjiè Shān* (两界山), he has upheld the right and banished the false, combining both wisdom and courage—his deeds truly magnificent.

The monk also knew the Pilgrim could not be separated for an instant, so why did he suddenly grow angry at his lingering laziness, forgetting the favor of saving his life at *Liángjiè Shān*, yet acting as if he had done some great deed?

The author’s meaning is subtle!

*Liángjiè Shān* is the place where right and false stand opposed. Earlier, when the Pilgrim was confined between its towering peaks, it was a test of perceiving true nature and the beginning of his fate. Hence, Sanzang subdued him to establish this foundation.

Now, *"journeying to the Zōngyá place"* signifies the boundary of fate and the preservation of true nature—so Sanzang cast him aside as a warning.

To the Pilgrim, it showed that talent and cleverness are not to be relied upon, nor achievements to be boasted of.
To Sanzang, it revealed that *Mìluó*’s (汨罗) lone loyalty must be discerned, while *Huáiyīn*’s (淮阴) superficial merits are easily misjudged.
