**Forty-first Chapter: The Monkey-Heart Defeated by Fire, the Wooden-Mother Captured by the Demon**

A sage of old said:
*"To let emotion return to its nature,
first teach fire to retreat within the heart.
Two forces merge as one essence—
golden elixir everywhere."*

Again he said:
*"To preserve longevity, first restrain desire.
If desire-fire does not falter, the spirit steadies itself.
Wood returns to fire, yet does not turn to ash—
if one restrains desire, life extends."*

For emotion arises from nature,
and wanders beyond virtue or vice—
all driven by fire’s transformations.
Without fire, nothing is born;
without fire, nothing is extinguished.

Thus fire’s power is most wondrous—
for good, it is potent;
for evil, even more so.

Nature is its root;
the heart, its dwelling;
the will, its trigger;
*qi*, its manifestation.
*"Most vast, most rigid,"*
filling heaven and earth,
unassailable.

If one nurtures *qi* rightly,
the heart remains undisturbed,
and nature steadies itself—
harmonizing with the Dao.

Mencius spoke of *"direct nourishment, vast and unharming"*—
this is adjustment, rectitude, and stillness—
the true essence of *sanmei*.

To preserve the heart and nurture nature
is to serve Heaven.
Heaven’s lifespan is unchanging—
this is the foundation of one’s fate.
Gathering virtue brings forth the elixir;
following the natural order receives its rectitude.
The Dao of the Golden Elixir is now fully revealed.

Ah! This Dao was nearly exhausted by Mencius.

The immortal master’s treatise
exposes those who harm the heart by failing to nurture *qi*,
thus fully elucidating Mencius’ chapter on *"nurturing qi."*

Zhuangzi said: *"Calmness nurtures *qi*."
Mencius taught that *"not forgetting, not assisting"* is the proper way—
both emphasize cultivation before disturbance arises.
But once *qi* is aroused and forcibly suppressed,
this is already a step behind.

The opening verse holds the crucial secret of proper nurturing:
*"Forgive all wrongs in an instant,
ignore gain and loss alike.
Conceal or reveal—let fate decide,
eat when hungry, drink when thirsty.
The spirit, still and serene, remains ever quiet;
if deluded, demons will intrude.
The Five Phases invert in the Zen halls—
when wind stirs, cold seizes."*

The meaning is clear—
no need for further explanation.

This is *"clarifying the heart, seeing nature,"*
where all attachments dissolve,
leaving not a thread behind.
Serene and forgetful,
quiet and unassisted—
this is the true nurturing of *qi*.

The final two lines warn:
If one cannot remain serene,
cannot forget or assist,
even in the Zen halls,
encountering scenes will stir the heart—
and this is not true nurturing.

Fire uses smoke as its messenger;
*qi* takes anger as its form.
Thus Mencius used the examples of She and Yi’s *qi*-driven courage
to illustrate its harm;
the immortal master used the Red Boy’s demonic *qi*
to depict its malevolence.

Fire is *qi*;
smoke is anger—
their meaning is one.

*"Five swift chariots"*—
light and easily agitated.
*"Pressing Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, Earth"*—
fire governs the Five Phases,
just as the heart governs the Five Organs,
and anger governs the Seven Emotions.
As the verse says:
*"All generation and transformation stem from fire,
fire pervades the boundless sky, bringing life to all."*

*"The demon lost the battle,
then pounded his own nose in defeat,
spouting flames from his mouth,
thick smoke from his nostrils,
and fiery sparks from his eyes."*
All depict his *qi* erupting,
shaking his heart.

Seeing him strike his own nose, bleed,
and declare victory by sealing the door—
this reveals his unchecked arrogance,
his reliance on fearlessness as strength,
exposing his *qi*-driven fury.

Eight Rules exclaimed:
*"This wretch is shameless, unashamed!"*
Again: *"He unleashes such merciless fire!"*
Again: *"No hope!"*
Again: *"No justice—he sets the flames!"*
A true portrayal.

Eight Rules panicked,
abandoning the Pilgrim,
unwilling to engage further—
unable to align with righteousness and the Dao, he faltered.

Sand Monk sought victory through the theory of *"mutual generation and conquest,"*
using Water to subdue Fire—
but this failed in principle,
forcing suppression where harmony was needed—
a forced imposition like Zhi’s.

The Pilgrim sought rain from the Eastern Ocean,
and the Dragon King sprayed water on the flames—
like the Song scholar’s desperate attempt to coax the shoots—
*"Pouring oil on fire,
the more he doused, the fiercer it burned."*

Not only was it useless,
but it *"attacked the heart with fire-qi,
driving the Three Souls from their dwellings."*
Then came:
*"Qi choked his chest, his tongue grew cold,
his spirit scattered, his life abandoned."*
The shoots withered.

Eight Precepts and Sand Monk made the Pilgrim *"sit cross-legged in meditation, practicing the massage-Dhyāna technique."*

*"In a short while, his qi passed through the Three Passes,*
*turned at the Bright Hall,*
*burst open the orifices,*
*and he called out: ‘Master!’"*
Sand Monk replied: *"Brother, you were born my master—*
*even in death, you remain in my words."*

There must be purpose in this,
yet do not expect immediate results—
keep the heart undistracted.

*"Together they sat beneath the pine grove,*
*and in a short time,*
*his spirit settled, his qi harmonized."*
Thinking of *"invoking Guanyin Bodhisattva"*—
this was the gathering of virtue in action,
gradually entering the subtle realm of nurturing the self.

Yet gathering virtue is how one nurtures the qi,
and understanding speech is how one gathers virtue.
Unable to discern speech,
one fails to grasp the truth—
true and false become indistinguishable,
and actions in motion or stillness lose their proper measure,
leaving no path for virtue to gather.

The demon revealed the *Ruyi* skin-bag
and lured Eight Precepts,
*"transforming into a false Guanyin to await him."*

The *Ruyi*—
born from his own mind;
the *"false Guanyin"*—
emanating from his words;
the *"skin-bag"*—
a deceitful utterance.

Words may be deceitful, lustful, perverse, or evasive,
but we focus on deceit,
for it most clearly obscures the mind—
and one example suffices for the rest.

Eight Precepts, unable to distinguish true from false,
*"saw the image and took it for a Buddha,"*
believed the deceitful words,
and was stuffed into the bag—
unable to discern speech, he was deceived,
and though he grasped at virtue, it failed to gather.

The demon said: *"With your eyes wide open, you still don’t recognize me!"*
—revealing his own ignorance of his own deception.

Eight Precepts cursed from within the bag:
*"You’ve schemed every way to trick me into eating—*
*I’ll make sure you suffer the heavenly plague!"*
His words, born of malice, only harmed himself,
for he truly invited ruin upon his own nature.

The Pilgrim endured the pain and entered the demon’s cave,
daring not to confront him directly,
*"and transformed into a ‘melting-gold bundle’ to cast down."*
This transformation’s subtlety
nearly defies recognition.

For the mind is a fire-hiding place—
one must not let it flare upward.
The character *bao* (包) carries the radical of *bao* (包),
and though enclosure may seem profound,
it ultimately harbors two kinds of discomfort.
To cast down the bundle,
to abandon enclosure entirely—
what liberation!

Thus, he transformed into a bundle and cast it down,
to extinguish the flame.

*"Melting-gold"*—
the image of fire refining gold.
Ancient seal script for the character *xin* (心) was simply an inverted *"fire"* (火),
not enclosed but made to submit downward—
just as the Pilgrim *"cast down the bundle,"*
and as before, the meaning of *"letting go of the heart."*

Again, he transformed into a fly to scout ahead,
not first rescuing Eight Precepts
but following the Six Generals—
this was cautious, silent observation,
discerning the root without confrontation,
temporarily easing tensions to restrain its outbreak.

This action already subtly penetrated the *sanmei* [三昧].

**Chapter Forty-Two: The Great Sage Reverently Pays Homage to the Southern Sea, Guanyin Compassionately Binds Hong Hai**

The Sage said: *"Nature is the decree of Heaven.*
*Let its scope be as vast as Heaven’s, its duration as enduring as Heaven’s,*
*let it arise from me, not from Heaven—*
*yet it does not command one to indulge in fine food or sensual pleasures.*
*Thus, it is undivided Heavenly Principle, without vice.*

*When it manifests, it is also undivided Heavenly Principle, fully virtuous—*
*this is called *following Nature*.*

*If one follows Nature, it is *holding the Mean*, it is *True Suchness*,*
*it is *Inner Elixir*, Sagehood, Immortality, and Buddhahood.*

*But if there is even a hair’s breadth of partiality or perversity,*
*it is no longer undivided Heavenly Principle.*

*All partiality and perversity are evil, are demonic forces,*
*are the private desires of the human heart obscuring truth.*

*The undivided Heavenly Principle is nothing but *Ren*—*
*it is *compassionate virtue*."*

*To preserve the undivided Heavenly Principle, one must cultivate *qi*;
*to cultivate *qi*, one must still the heart;
*to still the heart, one must quiesce the mind;
*to quiesce the mind, one must gather righteousness;
*to gather righteousness, one must know speech;
*to know speech, one must remove obstructions;
*to remove obstructions, one must attain knowledge.*

*This is called *refinement*."*

*Within this chapter, the Pilgrim transforms into King Yumao,*
*turning the Dao into demonic forces—*
*this is not following Nature.*

*The father and son’s reverent meeting, courteous and proper,*
*is Nature, yet he acts within it.*

*The boy calls himself *“Ignorant Son,”*—*
*ignorance is obscuration, lacking clarity,*
*unable to attain knowledge—*
*this is Nature, yet truth cannot be seen through it.*

*Of all Heaven’s natures, none surpasses that of father and son.*
*The father deceives his son, mistaking a false son for the true one;*
*the son, in his ignorance, mistakes a false father for the true one.*

*The lesser demons all knelt and said:*
*“Great King, you cannot even recognize your own father!”*
*Words that lose the true for the false,*
*and obscure the Heaven-given nature of one’s birth.*

*To seek longevity while obscuring one’s Heavenly nature*
*is like asking a false father for one’s birth chart,*
*bothering Zhang Daoling to calculate the Five Stars of Ziwei*
*in hopes of matching Heaven’s immortal lifespan—*
*how could this succeed?*

*To defy Heaven’s decree and violate filial piety,*
*how is it different from striking one’s father and rebelling against one’s son?*
*When conscience awakens, how could one not blush with shame?*

*There are also those who falsely claim Daoist learning and misrecognize Heavenly nature,*
*just as the Pilgrim falsely impersonates the demon king,*
*pretending to hunt morality like a royal hunt.*

*“Sitting in the central seat of the south”—*
*occupying it without doubt.*

*What they calculate is the distant concern of securing one’s livelihood and old age;*
*what they boast of are their boundless transformations;*
*what they gather are the clever appearances of mimicking others;*
*what they uphold is the false austerity of thunder-fasts;*
*what they recognize are the celestial omens of the *Liuzhi* [六爻].*

This is a heartless, depraved act of evil, yet they know not they are devouring men, these demons of life’s corruption!
The Pilgrim’s transformation—from true to false, then back again—is but a display of his cunning, his laughter a mockery of the unknowing.

When he changes, let the unseeing open their blinded eyes;
when he laughs, let the ignorant shrink their probing heads—
for wisdom lies in exposing folly at its root,
not in clashing banners on the battlefield.
It is like the water-worker who strives against the current,
or the arsonist who seizes the wind.

*"No need to worry—I’ll fetch the Bodhisattva myself."*
*"Straight to the Southern Sea, to the cliffs of Lankā,*
*and prostrate myself in homage!"*

How clear the vision, how direct the path!

The Bodhisattva spoke in fury:
*"That wretch dares mimic my form!"*
With a sweep of his gem-studded alms-bowl,
he hurled it into the sea’s depths.

The Pilgrim scoffed:
*"This Bodhisattva’s fire has not yet cooled."*

Before he could finish, the waves churned—
a tortoise surfaced, bearing the bowl ashore,
and knelt in twenty-four obeisances.

*"Ah, the Keeper of the Bowl!"* said the Pilgrim.

The Bodhisattva commanded:
*"Pilgrim, take the bowl!"*
Not a drop could be moved.

*"You do not know,"* said the Bodhisattva,
*"that it was always empty—
but cast into the sea,
it now holds all its waters within.
What strength could you have to lift the ocean?
Thus, you cannot take it."*

Alas!

「Ah! How wondrous this is!

The commentator says: *"The tortoise bearing the bowl,*
*along with the later episodes of the lotus petals crossing the sea,*
*the Dragon Princess plucking hairs—*
*all these exchanges, leisurely unfolded,*
*seem unrelated to the main text,*
*merely serving as a foil to the Red Boy."*

*"Like the painter’s words:*
*'‘Fine grasses and fallen flowers make a brocade land,’*
*these fallen flowers are but embellishments*
*to adorn the fine grasses,*
*thus completing the brocade."*

*Yet this passage reveals the Immortal Master’s*
*application of profound truth,*
*crafting a marvelous form—*
*truly the core of the main text.*

*His imaginings and strokes*
*possess a divine, ghostly artistry,*
*beyond mortal reach.*
*Among a hundred chapters,*
*this stands as peerless masterwork!*

*Laozi teaches:*
*"Through kindness, one attains courage;
Through frugality, one attains breadth;
By not daring to lead the world,*
*one achieves enduring greatness."*

*In ancient times,*
*the Duke of Zhou and King Wu,*
*in their wrath, settled the land;*
*Confucius, in his wrath,*
*rectified the four cardinal directions—*
*great courage indeed.*

*Yet only through great kindness*
*could such great courage arise.*
*The demon’s guise as a false Bodhisattva,*
*deceptive yet plausible,*
*confuses truth with falsehood—*
*the foremost trick of evil spirits,*
*most destructive in its harm.*

*The Bodhisattva, in great kindness,*
*thus raged:*
*"That wretch dares mimic my form!"*
*"With a sweep of my gem-studded alms-bowl,*
*I cast it into the sea’s depths!"*
*Clear in vision, resolute in deed—*
*this is “Through kindness, one attains courage.”*

*The *Huainanzi* states:*
*"There is essence yet it is not used,*
*there is spirit yet it is not employed.*
*In harmony with the Great Primordial Purity,*
*one stands within the realm of utmost clarity."*
*This is the Way of frugality.*

*"‘Always an empty bowl,*
*cast into the sea,*
*now it holds all its waters within—*
*you cannot lift it.’"*
*The empty bowl is the epitome of frugality,*
*and only through such frugality*
*does one attain boundless breadth,*
*as in the saying:*
*"‘A sesame seed can contain Mount Sumeru,*
*a hair can swallow the great ocean.’"*
*This is “Through frugality, one attains breadth.”*

*The *Book of Documents* says:*
*"One must have capacity,*
*then virtue grows great;*
*one must endure,*
*then salvation is achieved."*
*This speaks of vast Qi/breath,*
*encompassing all with serene cultivation.*

*Among the myriad creatures,*
*the tortoise is the longest-lived,*
*taken as a symbol of guarding the female*
*and nurturing with wisdom.*
*The sage composed the *I Ching*’s *Yi Hexagram*,*
*its first line modeled on the tortoise,*
*to show how the virtuous one*
*cultivates themselves.*

*"‘Seeing the waves churn,*
*a tortoise emerges,*
*bearing the alms-bowl to the cliffs,’*
*it carries its burden with ease,*
*lifting what others cannot—*
*is this not*
*'By not daring to lead the world,*
*one achieves enduring greatness’?"*

*This contrasts sharply*
*with the Red Boy’s reckless triumph,*
*void of cultivation.*

*The Pilgrim bowed in reverence:*
*"This disciple does not know."*
*I too bowed in reverence:*
*"This disciple does not know."*
*Will those who read this book in ages to come,*
*and grasp my meaning,*
*also bow and say*
*"‘This disciple does not know’?"*

*"The Bodhisattva’s right hand lifts the bowl,*
*resting it on his left palm—*
*flowing effortlessly,*
*a display of mastery,*
*the third *Dhyāna* of perfect stillness."*

*Yet how does the water arise,*
*if the bowl holds the sea*
*and the tortoise dives beneath?*
*Unknown to the common eye,*
*the bowl’s contents are not mere water,*
*but the very Qi of the ocean—*
*formless, untouched by substance.*
*Thus the Bodhisattva declares:*
*"‘My bowl holds sweet dew,*
*not like the Dragon King’s spray,*
*which can extinguish that demon’s*
*threefold *Dhyāna* flame.’"*

*With the true water of *Dhyāna*,*
*he subdues the false fire of *Dhyāna*—*
*using spirit, not mere form,*
*exemplifying the art of perfect cultivation.*
*What need then for the mind’s wild flames?*

*When the mind is unrestrained,*
*it seeks dominance,*
*burning fiercely like wildfire;*
*when the mind is still and true,*
*it guards the female,*
*nurturing like sweet dew.*

*The wildfire*
*is the demon’s torment,*
*consuming the heart;*
*the sweet dew*
*is the elixir,*
*irrigating the soul.*
*The tortoise is indeed the Red Boy’s*
*tailored antidote.*

*As for the alms-bowl,*
*it cradles true Qi,*
*vast and tranquil,*
*not merely empty and detached—*
*this is the Dao of*
*"non-action yet transformation,*
*stillness yet creation."*

*Should one harbor*
*a hint of grasping or attachment,*
*they could never fathom its depths.*
*Thus the Bodhisattva again*
*illustrates the Dragon Princess’s*
*and the precious bowl’s reluctance to part,*
*showing that such treasures*
*are not easily obtained.*

*It is not the Bodhisattva who is hard to part from,*
*but the Pilgrim’s own*
*indulgence and stinginess*
*that make the Bodhisattva’s gifts difficult.*
*Hence, the tight-skin cauldron’s removal,*
*and the Bodhisattva’s words:*
*"‘You are at ease.’"*
*To let go is not to abandon,*
*but to transcend.*

*The Pilgrim plucking hairs,*
*fearing it might save his life,*
*the Bodhisattva says:*
*"‘Not a hair shall you pluck,*
*for even my treasure, Shàncái,*
*I cannot part with.’"*
*Stinginess thus makes parting hard.*

*Wealth and desire*
*are external temptations,*
*while Shàncái is the true nature’s*
*wondrous manifestation.*
*The Bodhisattva reveals:*
*Shàncái’s reluctance to part,*
*showing how one sees goodness*
*in wealth,*
*divines its use,*
*discerns the difficulty of letting go,*
*and awakens to the act of release itself.*

*This is where the Master*
*blends truth with metaphor,*
*logic with divine inspiration—*
*a realm akin to*
*"the Heavenly Maiden scattering flowers,"*
*not to be read lightly.*

*Emerging from filth yet pure,*
*the lotus stands alone,*
*thus its petals can serve as*
*the universal vessel of compassion,*
*blown by the breath of Dao,*
*dispelling all afflictions,*
*what fear of the boundless sea of suffering?*

*To even the emotions*
*and achieve harmony,*
*one must endure.*
*Thus the *Gāng* blade can form*
*the Bodhisattva’s seat of Dharma,*
*as he sits serene,*
*clouds gathering around,*
*unfazed by even the mightiest trials.*

*The Dragon Princess splits the lotus,*
*ascending to the other shore,*
*while Huì’àn leans on the cosmic *Gāng*’s power,*
*transforming into a lotus platform—*
*both reveal the clarity of true nature.*

*The Bodhisattva overturns the alms-bowl,*
*pours the water like thunder;*
*extends the willow branch,*
*turns the blade into a hook.*
*The reader may think:*
*"‘The water poured to quench the fire,*
*a preemptive strike;*
*the lotus seat to ensnare the blade,*
*a victory without battle—*
*the utmost of goodness.’"*

All have lost their subtlety.

They do not grasp
that overturning the alms-bowl like thunder’s roar
is itself *delusion*—
for it points to their delusion
and lets them awaken on their own.

To awaken with wisdom against delusion
only makes the deluded more so;
to delude with delusion
makes the deluded awaken themselves.
Thus the Dao of skillful guidance
is to let them awaken with goodness,
not to let them delude with goodness.

Sitting on the lotus platform to learn the Bodhisattva’s way,
that is awakening—
for they hear of the path to awakening
and know their own delusion.
To awaken the awakened,
yet the awakened seem deluded,
to delude the awakened
yet the awakened grow ever more awake.
Thus the law of skillful transformation
is to let them awaken fully,
not to let them delude fully.

The alms-bowl tilted writes the character *迷* (delusion),
*come, come, come*—
observe how distant the land is from the surging tides,
where does the little cart still gallop on its old tracks?

The blade’s tip becomes the platform of awakening,
*sit, sit, sit*—
who knows the glory of the hollow is but a trick of the edge?
How could one endure an empty blade swung to nothing?

The Wayfarer rages in anger,
the great compassion of skillful guidance;
the demon rages in anger,
the great awakening of being ensnared in delusion.

Wondrous indeed!
The Bodhisattva asks twice yet gives no answer,
quelling their reckless striving.

The demon strikes with one spear,
piercing the heart and exposing its core—
sitting there,
pointing to that very place—
how could it ever have been truly fixed?

One must know the mind of *non-abiding* (無住) and birth—
*strike, strike, go*—
only when the heart dies
is it truly born anew;
urgently seek to lay all down at once.

*"Three top supports"* (三个顶搭)
clearly mark the three stars of the mind,
supporting heaven and earth as the Three *Talents* (三才).
Do not thrust into the flames of fire.

*"Five binding straps"* (五个箍儿)
embody the five virtues within the body,
gathering the spirit and consolidating the *qi*,
restoring innate virtue—
rejoicing in the golden nest of ease.

*"Called the Child of Wealth"* (善财童子),
human nature is inherently good,
and all talents are good—
merely affirming their goodness.

This is the cultivation of the boundless *Hàorán* *qi* (浩然之氣),
revealing true nature and clarifying the mind,
the wondrous Dao of great compassion and great pity.

Its essence points to no other than *"rightness and stillness"* (正定),
hence the saying:
*"A single word can recognize the sands of the Ganges,*
*boundless and profound is the law’s power."*

**Forty-third Chapter**
*Black River Demon Captures the Monk*
*The Western Dragon Child Snatches the Turtle*
**Awakened One** says:
This passage follows the Black Boy’s ability to stabilize his true nature and perceive the great compassion—
when the true heart is clear, wild impulses dissolve.
The Black Turtle, unable to nurture its true nature, churns waves and follows currents—
when false desires stir, the true nature sways,
demonstrating the harm of letting nature be swayed by the heart’s movements.
The former preserves the heart,
this cultivates the nature.

The Bodhisattva takes away the sea’s waters,
the child returns to its right fruit,
the Wayfarer releases the Three Treasures and Eight Rules,
firmly vowing to journey west.
The fire-nature of self-arising is already subdued,
yet the water-nature of outward dispersion still lingers.
*"Suddenly hearing the sound of water"* stirs the heart again,
unable to keep the mind as still as water.

Thus the Wayfarer raises the *Heart Sutra* (多心經) again to clarify the Six *Thieves* (六贼).
Eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind—
the Six *Thieves* of Heaven;
color, sound, scent, taste, touch, and *dharma* (法)—
the Six *Thieves* of the World.
If the Six *Thieves* of Heaven are not understood,
the Six *Thieves* of the World will ride in separately;
if the Six *Thieves* of the World are not removed,
the Six *Thieves* of Heaven will steal together.
Mutually harming and robbing,
the vital *qi* is lost along with it—
all from failing to forget the artifices and kill the heart to invite this fate.
Hence the saying:
*"Summoning these six thieves in confusion,*
*how can one reach the Western Paradise to see the Buddha?"*

If one seeks success,
it must be through purifying the heart and nurturing the nature,
not letting the heart hold even a speck of love, desire, greed, anger, or delusion.

The harm of greed and delusion
is no greater than the Black Waters surging like tides,
the little turtle as a demonic force.
*"The Black Water River God’s domain in Hengyang Pass"* (衡阳峪黑水河神府)
refers to the Kidney Palace (肾宫),
where the true spirit resides.
The little turtle, relying on its strength,
seizes and plunders its domain—
that is the unruly *qi* of greed and delusion.
It calls itself *"the foolish nephew"* (愚甥),
clearly a confession of guilt.
The foolish one is he who confuses right and wrong—
compare it with the Black Boy’s *"foolish son"* (愚男),
both reveal their greedy ignorance,
not humility.

The turtle dwells in the Black Waters yet names itself *"pure"* (洁),
like a man harboring filthy thoughts yet unaware of his impurity.
The Dragon King tells the Great Sage:
*"This is my younger sister’s ninth son. Because his father-in-law delayed the rains,
he was sentenced by the Heavenly Tribunals to be beheaded by Wei Zheng,
leaving behind this nephew, who nurtures his nature and cultivates truth in the Black Water River,
unexpectantly committing such evil."*

The ninth son, the youngest son.
The turtle’s purity—its youngest son;
the turtle’s impurity—is it not the second son?
Seeing this, does my earlier note that the Old Dragon is Li Yuan hold true?

Its father was in the murky waters of Jingyang (泾阳),
and his rains came too late;
its son is also in the Black Waters of Hengyang (衡阳),
yet commits this evil.
Jing (泾) as Heng (衡),
perhaps the family custom.

It knows the Heavenly Tribunals sentenced Wei Zheng to behead its father,
yet does not know the Three Treasures journey west to retrieve scriptures,
to transcend and deliver its father;
nor does it know the Three Treasures retrieve scriptures
for whom’s sake—
with a muddled heart and perverse actions,
it even thinks of boiling the Tripitaka Master’s flesh for food,
a blazing lust of desire,
only caring to fulfill its cravings,
unknowing of its father’s nature,
unknowing of its own fate.

Alas!
Ignorance of nature and injury to filial duty—
what filth is worse than this?

「Its source already polluted, its current cannot but be unclean—
where then is purity to be found?

Within the chapter, the tale of the Heavenly Tribunals beheading the Black Waters Dragon is again raised,
to show that without cultivating the heart to nourish one’s nature,
one cannot serve the Heavenly Dao—
thus incurring the Heavenly Tribunals’ punishment.

Mao Kang gathered troops to avenge wrongs,
and in one battle, the dragon was captured—
the Tripitaka Master and Eight Rules were freed,
and the dragon was spared execution,
*"for the sake of my noble father’s face,"*
and sent westward.

Though the dragon’s accomplices were pardoned out of leniency,
this was truly inviting Heaven’s favor.

The heart governs the Six Desires,
and among them, the Black Waters Dragon’s desire is most difficult to restrain.

The immortal master composed another passage,
using veiled speech and allegory,
highlighting its core essence—
to awaken clarity of nature and purity of heart,
subtly contrasting with the Black Waters Dragon and its journey through the Underworld.
The passage merely points to its ambiguous heart,
and uses symbols to convey its meaning—
its intent is profound.

*"The River God summoned the art of obstructing the waters,
blocking the upper current.
Soon, the lower flow dried up,
and a great path opened."*

This is the method of uprooting and sealing the source,
forcing the waters against their nature
and preventing the lower flow—
truly the key to cultivating nature and attaining immortality.

The great path westward was revealed,
Red Boy was bound while the Black Crocodile returned,
and the Three Mysteries of pure cultivation were attained.

Yet why does the text say that whenever demons and monsters capture the Tripitaka Master,
they claim:
*"The Golden Cicada reincarnation,
a body of true yang refined over ten lifetimes—
if someone eats even a piece of his flesh,
it will extend their lifespan and grant eternal youth"*?

Because this text is written specifically for the Dao of Gold Elixir.
Those demons and monsters symbolize those who practice perverse, heretical methods,
hoping vainly for longevity—
they are likened to refining gold elixir into a tangible, substantial form,
hence the *"Golden Cicada reincarnation"*;
the *"true yang of the primordial body refined over ten lifetimes"*;
and the *"eating his flesh grants eternal youth"*.

They do not know that the Elixir of Rebirth is originally formless,
unlike the Tripitaka Master’s blood and flesh—
this is why they are considered heretical demons.

It boasts of its name, *"Mountain Until the Black River,"*
spanning tens of thousands of words,
a vast and profound discourse,
expounding the mysteries of the Dao,
all rooted in the benevolent cultivation of the heart
by Master Zhuang.

Some say this text belongs to the lineage of Zhong and Lü,
but they do not know it traces directly back to Mencius’ Dao.

The discerning may judge accordingly.

**Chapter Forty-Four: The Law Body and Primordial Fate Encounter the Ox-Cart’s Power**
**The Rectified Heart Overcomes the Heretical Demons at the Ridge Pass**

A scholar said: These three passages are specifically written to refute external Daoist sects.

External sects, like those seeking entry through side doors and alleys,
twisting and turning, devious and unorthodox,
are rarely able to attain true fruition—
why?

For those who advance at the proper time,
their foundation must align with the Heavenly Dao’s path.
External sects, however, are like galloping recklessly along walls and byways,
never finding their true path.

The multitude of heretical practices disrupts the scriptures,
their licentiousness only serves to destroy the body.

Within the chapter, the three Daoists—Peach Force, Deer Force, and Sheep Force—
embody the external sects in all their forms.

The external sects number three hundred and sixty,
but they are divided into three categories:
opening the Three Passes,
operating the Ox-Cart,
ascending the Ridge,
and the methods of mud pellets, chest supplementation, and returning essence—
all these are recorded in *The Yellow Court* and *The Spirit Pivot*,
along with the true scriptures of the immortals.
Later generations failed to receive the true transmission,
and passed on these methods in error—
they seem plausible but are fundamentally false,
the most likely to mislead and cause harm.

Guangchengzi said:
*"Cease your laborious efforts with the Ox-Cart and Elixir Furnace,
for the Blessed Embryo of the Crane and the Breath of the Tortoise
are naturally everlasting."*

Because the human body contains Heaven and Earth,
each inhalation and exhalation has its own roots and connections.
The Governing and Conception Vessels follow the movement of the qi,
forming the natural rotation of Heaven’s fate—
like the Ox-Cart.

Those who falsely practice opening the Three Passes,
turning the pulley,
and forcefully manipulate their essence,
disturbing their bones—
all these are unnatural,
contrary to Heaven and harmful to principle,
and sever the Great Dao.

They do not realize that the Ox-Cart is Heaven’s natural design,
its divine movement ceaseless—
once human interference begins,
it becomes choked and stagnant,
blood congeals and qi solidifies,
and strange poisons and chronic diseases arise—
this is truly the method of hastening death.

The border of Ox-Cart Country lies between the Black River and the Heaven-Piercing River,
embodying the meaning of the Ox-Cart’s stagnation.

The disciples heard the commotion
and assumed it was an earthquake, mountains collapsing,
thunderous claps of lightning,
and cries of people and neighing of horses—
all descriptions of unnatural, forced actions,
evoking dread and astonishment.

*"The Tripitaka Master saw many monks gathered in clusters,
pulling the cart with all their might,
and striking drums for power,"*
—this reveals their failure to harmonize the Five Phases,
to align with the natural unity of things,
and to follow the effortless Dao.

*"The cart was loaded with bricks, tiles, wood, and plants,"*
—this shows they were collecting dross, heavy and impure substances.

After recounting the high slopes, the narrow Ridge Pass, and the great pass,
*"How can the cart be pulled up such steep cliffs?"*
—all these directly point to their erroneous forcing of energy,
and their ignorance of the subtle marvels of the Ox-Cart’s natural rotation.

The Tripitaka Master transformed into the Cloud and Water Immortal,
and questioned the foreman Daoist about the reason—
then went straight to the riverbank,
passed the Twin Pass,
and descended the Ridge,
requiring no effort at all—
how effortlessly he moved with the circumstances!

The monks said:
*"He knows how to refine elixir and transmute mercury,
and turn stones into gold."*

If the external sects regard operating the Ox-Cart as internal alchemy,
and refining lead and mercury for consumption as external alchemy,
then this is their beginning and end—
leading the blind and believing in delusion,
like a madman or a wild horse,
and ultimately, never achieving success even unto old age.»

The lifespan may be slightly prolonged,
yet it is but a ghostly existence in a spectral abode.
Thus the venerable master said,
*"You cannot escape,"*
*"You cannot die."*
Neither death nor life—
not true longevity,
but merely prolonged suffering.

How could one attain the *arhat*’s journey to the Western Heaven for scriptures,
or the divine powers of the Heavenly Worthy of Equaling Heaven,
to redress this injustice among mortals?

The Tripitaka Master said:
*"Five hundred souls are kin to me."*
The Buddha spoke:
*"All sentient beings are my disciples."*
Originally boundless and impartial,
with neither inner nor outer distinctions—
yet now you cling so desperately—
what then is this vast compassion?

*"Unsheathing the Golden Hoop Staff,
a single strike to slay!"*
Just as Vajrapāṇi wields his demon-subduing scepter
to crush demons and deliver the monks.

The Tripitaka Master revealed his true form,
and the monks bowed in reverence,
begging him to subdue the demon and restore order.
*"Quickly drag the Ox-Cart past the Twin Pass,
through the Ridge,
lift it high and hurl it to shatter—
let the bricks, tiles, wood, and plants all tumble down the slope!"*

Truly excellent!
Truly excellent!

Restoring the original essence of the Law-body,
shattering the sluggishness of the demon’s strength,
upholding the loyal and virtuous single mind,
righting the crooked ridge of demonic deceit—
direct, swift, and resolute,
combining wisdom and courage.

Life and vitality—body, mind, essence, and breath—
everyone may preserve them whole.

Most wondrous is when the Great Sage plucks a hair,
each teaching twists it into the fingernail of the ring finger,
clenches it in a fist,
and calls—it answers instantly,
each summoning the Great Sage to appear and guard them,
so that no demonic intrusion may prevail.

The ring finger belongs to the heart,
speaking of how one’s thoughts may be as fine as hair—
firmly held in mind,
with every thought invoking the Sage,
how could there be any demonic obstruction?

Every person’s heart harbors Confucius,
every monk’s hand holds the Great Sage—
still and unmoving,
yet responsive when called—
the most profound and wondrous Dao.

The Master’s words are divine and wondrous;
readers must truly grasp their meaning.

This is the radiant wisdom,
like awakening from a dream—
when the old monk of Zhìyǔ Temple first saw the Tripitaka Master,
he bowed and called him "Grandfather"—
was it not Zhìbái Jinxīng saving human life in a dream?

The Three Monks secretly visited the Three Pure Ones’ Hall,
extinguishing the lamp’s light,
transforming into the Highest Venerable, Primordial Beginning, and Numinous Treasure,
demonstrating that Buddha is Taoist, Taoist is Buddha—
though teachings differ in schools,
their essence is one.

To neglect Zhìyǔ Temple
is to extinguish the Three Pure Ones’ Hall.

If both sides harbor deceit—
monks gluttonously stealing offerings,
Taoists hiding their ears and groping for the golden bell—
they invite the laughter of the discerning.

**Chapter Forty-Five: The Great Sage Leaves His Name at the Three Pure Ones’ Hall, the Monkey King Reveals His Law in the Country of Carrying the Chariot**

Wùyī Zǐ says:
This passage elucidates the elixir of the Saintly Water—
born of cultivation, not supplication;
true nature and emptiness are one,
relying entirely on divine efficacy,
not on sensory indulgence.

It shatters false paths,
pointing to ultimate truth.

Cool and detached in tone,
yet everywhere a warning.

The Three Daoists—Hǔlì, Lùlì, and Yánglì—
proclaimed themselves Great Immortals,
chanting sutras to avert calamities and seek longevity for the realm.
Yet ignorant of the Dao’s true essence,
how could they discern the Three Pure Ones’ authenticity?

They suspected the Celestial Vessel’s descent,
kneeling to beg for the Saintly Water elixir—
like common folk worshipping stars or invoking spirit-writing tablets,
praying for extended life.
Their delusion knows no bounds!

The Great Sage agreed to leave the elixir,
yet the "Three Immortals" carried it in a bucket,
a basin, or a bottle—
like mortals clinging to *Bāduànjǐn*, *Liùzìjué*, or *Shíliùzì hūxī*,
or refining autumn stone and red lead to swallow,
each sealing their own vessel—
far surpassing even the *Chénglù jīnjīng*,
yet still grasping at longevity and celestial favor.
How absurd!

The three monks each indulged in their own *niè*—
not jesting, but profound insight.
For swallowing saliva or inhaling qi
are both matters of *yin* substance;
autumn stone and red lead,
when refined, yield filth and impurities—
often stemming from *niè*.
Thus, the Sage spoke plainly:
*"You drink but the urine of your own niè!"*

Even the Three Teachings’ sages have referenced *niè* in speaking of the Dao:
The Buddhist scriptures say, *"The Dao lies in the dry excrement stake."*
The *Nánhuá* [Zhuangzi] declares, *"The Dao is in excrement and urine."*
The *Dàxué* [Great Learning] warns, *"Like hating foul odors."*
Yet even in the most putrid transformation lies divine marvel—
the receptive and pure restoring the original.
In the most turbid depths lies the purest essence.
*Niè* is not entirely unworthy of mention in the Dao—
yet how laughable that seekers of the Dao should fixate upon it!

Truly wise, the Great Sage said,
*"Just leave my name instead."*
For mortals, lost in wild speculation,
knowing not the Dao’s nature,
he must shout aloud:
**"Dao/Hao! Dao/Hao!**
**You fool, lost in such chaotic thought!"**

There are Three Pure Ones—
would they deign to descend to mortal form?
I shall reveal my true surname,
and make you understand.

The Wayfarer has no father or mother—
how then could he have a surname?
His surname was bestowed by the Ancestor of Bodhi,
the true transmission of life’s essence.

The surname is the very nature itself.
If you say, *"You take the Dao as your name,"*
do you truly know the Dao’s name?
Why such wild and groundless speculation?

Could the Three Pure Ones of highest sanctity
ever descend to this turbid world
and lightly cross over the common folk?
It is only because you do not know your true nature.

Now I shall reveal your true nature to you—
do you not know that all you consume
are but the urine of *niè*?
This is no forced interpretation—
observe *"Just leave my name instead"*—
why does it not leave a name,
but only speak of *"surname"*?
And why does it not leave a surname,
but only say *"true surname"*?

When you reach the closing line—*"fully realized in nature"*—
you will understand.

The Sage-Teachers used *"the Great Sage leaves a name"*
as a hook to draw attention,
to clarify the Dao’s true designation—
only the true nature itself.

In ancient times, the Divine Maiden conceived by Heaven’s grace,
and thus the character *"surname"* (姓) bears the radical *"woman"* (女).
For *"surname"* inherently contains the marvelous Dao
of nature’s generation and transformation.

Ah!
The surname is used to name,
the surname is used to represent nature,
the surname is used to name the Dao,
the surname is used to answer the call.

Spoken casually, yet each word is the Dao—
profound, unfathomable, divine!
Wondrous!

The Master and his disciples attended court, where the Old Daoist made a report, the Great Sage gave his account, and the Village Elder presented his petition—all recounting how the Carriage-Slow Kingdom sought rain through a contest of Buddhist and Daoist magical arts. The Sage-Teachers then explained the rain-invocation method to illustrate the vast difference between heterodox and orthodox Dao. It was not merely to showcase the Great Sage’s superior technique.

The Dao, fundamentally, is one nature permeating all things, revealing the true essence while harmonizing principle and practice. It transcends all oppositions in duality, merging with all things while operating alone. It is not a technique to be confined by techniques; it is not a display to be confined by displays. One cannot grasp the Dao by clinging to manifest techniques.

*"The Daoist ascends the platform, using the talisman as his signal."*
The talisman is but wood’s qi. One sound, two sounds, three sounds, four sounds—all commands arranged through tone and color. This is true technique, yet not the true nature.

The nature’s resonance has fixed responses, but techniques’ summons are unreliable. Thus, winds, clouds, thunder, and rain sometimes answer and sometimes do not.

The Great Sage used the staff as his signal.
The *Ruyi Staff* embodies the complete principle of the Five Phases.
One finger, two fingers, three fingers, four fingers, five fingers—all applied through divine transformation. This is true nature, encompassing true technique.

When technique empties, it becomes technique; when technique manifests, it reveals nature. Thus, winds, clouds, thunder, and rain always respond without fail.

This is what is meant by *"stabilizing nature and preserving spirit,"* practicing silently in meditation, with divine power operating alone—without loud incantations or displays of color.

If one speaks of technique apart from nature, it is like invoking rain through techniques alone—abandoning the root for the branches, not the true nature’s wondrous method.

Thus, the Wanderer says:
*"This is heterodox magic, not a true fruit of attainment—neither mine nor yours. If you can summon the Dragon King to appear in person,"*
then true nature is revealed, motion and stillness in harmony, hidden and manifest unfathomable—neither confined to display nor bound by technique.

The Wanderer’s call brought the Dragon King swiftly to manifest his true form:
*"Four dragons soared through mist and cloud, dancing toward the Golden Throne Hall."*
Breath and response in perfect communion—how vast and swift their operation!

How could those heterodox external arts ever steal such transformations or measure their extent?

The conclusion states:
*"The boundless, wondrous true method—
the utterly true nature shatters heterodoxy."*
This has already been made clear.

In the past, Master Lü heard Master Huanglongji’s Dharma talk. The master asked:
*"Who sits below?"*
Lü replied:
*"A wandering Daoist of clouds and water."*
The master said:
*"What if the clouds disperse and the water dries up?"*
Lü had no answer.

The master continued:
*"The Yellow Dragon appears."*
Lü suddenly awakened—realizing the Dragon’s manifestation was true nature, while refining water into gold was yet to grasp the true essence.

He left this verse:

It is clear: the **Spirit-Sensing King** is but a **Spirit-Sensing Bodhisattva**. The title remains, yet the **King** is transformed by a **Bodhisattva**. Then the **King’s** winds, his great snows, his manipulation of **Tang Seng**—were they not **Guanpo’s** manipulation of the **King** and **Tang Seng**, all of it the **Great Sage’s** manipulation of the **King** and **Tang Seng**, all in accordance with the Buddha’s will to guide the scripture-seeker?

**San Zang** said, *“This season is strange—I do not know if it is spring, summer, autumn, or winter.”* He saw that the **Dao** of heaven follows its natural course, and one must know its signs.

Again, he said, *“I did not know of the mountains and rivers’ dangers.”* He saw that the **Dao** of earth follows fixed principles, and one must know its changes.

Again, he said, *“In this world, nothing is heavier than name and profit. Others risk death for gain; my disciple serves the edict with loyalty—yet it is still for fame. How does this differ?”* He saw that greed for profit and fame are burdens, and one must know their harm.

If the restless mind is indulged, if one treads carelessly upon the layered ice, then one becomes a plaything of fate for eternity, unable to be a master of one’s own life. Thus, one must penetrate the **yin-yang**, deeply understand the times, know when to advance and retreat, guard against danger and foresee risk, abandon schemes and sever thoughts, still the form and rest the mind—only then can one remain true to the **Way**.

If one rushes forward in haste, it is as if one has passed the mark. The **Way** lies before you, yet you stumble past it. **Sha Wujing’s** words, *“In haste, one fears mistakes,”* are a sharp warning.

The **River of Heaven’s Passage** is the true path to retrieve the scriptures. The monsters within have not yet been subdued—how can one cross? The **gold in water** is the **Dao**’s marvel—true gold has not yet been obtained, and without it, there is no way to worship the Buddha.

The scriptures are the **gold in water**, not mere words. The Buddha is present in the world, not only in the Western Paradise. To seek the Buddha while recklessly risking danger—why not stay at Chen’s house to avoid error?

The **grass-shoe horse** was hasty; to walk on ice was reckless. To step into the abyss and sink to the depths—**Tang Seng** brought this upon himself. What blame is there for the monster?

**Guanpo** said, *“I dare not! I dare not!”*

For now, let him be. Better to endure two days, leisurely and at ease, enjoying oneself.

How reverent, cautious, and composed! Not only does this spare Tang Seng harm, but it also allows the monster to be contained, opens the door for the three disciples to rescue the drowning, and preserves the Great Sage’s ground for subduing demons. Who else but an embodiment of effortless transformation could do this?

The three disciples returned to Chen’s village and explained the spirit’s trickery. They headed straight to the water’s edge to seek their master and capture the monster—the moment of returning to origin and restoring essence lies here.

**Chapter Forty-Nine: The Monk Faces Calamity and Sinks into a Watery Abode—Guan Yin Appears in a Fish Basket to Save the Peril**

Wu Yi Zi said: *Gold elixir* is the convergence of true yin and true yang qi, following the natural cycles of Heaven and Earth through the four seasons and seventy-two solar terms, returning to the primal origin without artificial coercion. Only when one penetrates Lao Zi’s subtle and wondrous teachings does one realize the Dao’s simplicity and effortless ease—taking and consuming it grants fulfillment of nature and life, instantly ascending to sainthood.

This passage reveals the marvelous application of subduing the gold elixir, the secret essence of Guan Yin’s mission to Chang’an to relieve suffering and save from peril, marking the grand source and culmination of *The Scripture of Liberation from Calamity*. Its placement in the forty-ninth chapter underscores the *Great Correlation*’s number of fifty, with its full use manifesting in forty-nine—here lies its significance.

The immortal’s brush cannot fully convey its depth, so only Guan Yin’s miraculous fish-basket form is depicted to illuminate later generations. Its profound implications are boundless, encompassing all phenomena—only those who master yin-yang and comprehend the workings of creation can glimpse its essence. To say *Journey to the West* lacks ingenuity, relying solely on invoking the Southern Sea Bodhisattva in crises, is as blind as groping for a *zheng* (上“竹”下“龠”) in the dark.

The second disciple devised a plan to descend into the water to seek their master. When Zhu Bajie carried the real and false bodies of the disciple, it signified their shared resolve—urgent need to question a friend and seek their master. How could one not recognize another’s true form when there are forms beyond the body?

*"I’m right here, Old Monkey!"*
But calling to the deaf awakens no fool—*"You’re still carrying me!"*
At the sound of the song, your original form remains.

*Hurry, hurry—no delay!*
Lift your head—this is the Water Turtle’s domain.

Transformed into Shrimp Mother, question Shrimp Grandma—
The Great-Bellied One speaks of vitality;
Encounter Stone Lizi, listen to Stone Xiang—
The Living Tomb’s true master weeps over the path to death.

If the disciples could find their master together, what fear is there that the true scriptures won’t reach home?

The monk wept in grief, recounting the watery disaster—not out of hatred for water, but acknowledging that from birth to return to the source, water’s role is indispensable, never to be overlooked.

The disciple called out: *"Master, do not grieve over the watery calamity. The scriptures say: ‘Earth is the mother of the Five Phases; wood is the source of the Five Phases. Without earth, nothing grows; without water, nothing thrives.’"* This echoes the meaning: *"The Four Symbols and Five Phases rely entirely on earth; the Nine Palaces and Eight Trigrams cannot depart from it."* The point is clear—no need for further annotation.

Having clarified the situation, the disciple ordered Zhu Bajie and Sha Wujing to enter the water to fight separately—why? The monster is the *true gold in water*, a convergence of yin-yang and the Five Phases’ qi, already formed. Yet, obstructed by the talisman’s solar fire, its time has not come, so it cannot return to origin and attain its true fruition. Only Zhu Bajie’s wood-fire refinement and Sha Wujing’s true earth can subdue it.

*"Wielding a nine-pronged red copper mallet"*—a symbol of pure yang, standing alone and unyielding.

Zhu Bajie said: *"You fake being the Spirit King of Illusions, devouring children in Chen’s village! I’m Chen Qing’s one-catty gold—don’t you recognize me?"*
Not to make the king recognize him, but to let those refining the elixir do so.

At this moment, only a female form appears—no mention of boys. Beneath the water, a fierce battle unfolds among the three. Do not mistake this for the initial convergence of the Five Phases forming the embryo—this is the later stage of ten-month fire refinement after the embryo is formed.

The verse reads: *"With fate and affinity, the Dao is complete"*—yin-yang union.
*"Mutual generation and conquest, as countless as grains of sand"*—fire refinement.
*"Earth conquers water; water dries up to the bottom"*—water solidifies with earth.
*"Water generates wood; wood flourishes in blossom"*—wood thrives with water.

In Chan practice, this merges into unity;
In elixir refinement, the three families are distinctly subdued.
*"Earth is the mother, sprouting golden buds—
Golden water births the infant"*—earth generates gold and water.
*"Water is the root, nourishing wooden flowers—
Wood radiates fiery splendor"*—wood and fire refine the gold.
*"The Five Phases converge yet remain distinct—
Thus the faces change, each contending differently"*—
During refinement, though still converging, the fire’s intensity shifts constantly, each phase distinct—hence the monk’s battle with the monster involves ever-changing forms.

To read this verse merely as Five Phases generation-conquest rhetoric misses its profundity.

*"The two feigned defeat, luring it out to battle."*

The refining is yet incomplete—
Again it is quenched in water.
*"The fire’s power is insufficient; it cannot yet be subdued."*

*"The two return to challenge it"*—
The fire’s power advances once more.

The **Taoist** crone addressed the Great Sage:
*"The Great Sage of Heavenly Contention, born from the primordial unity of the Hunyuan Dao,
Refined in the Eight Trigram Furnace as the Golden Elixir Immortal,
Now submits to the Buddhist teaching.
Oh Great King, henceforth do not battle with him again!"*

She extolled the Great Sage’s origins,
Revealing that his elixir was forged from the **Hunyuan Dao**—
The **Hunyuan Dao** being the unity of **qi**,
Refined in the Eight Trigram Furnace.
When the fire’s power was perfected,
He must retreat and guard himself,
Waiting for the moment of **Dao**’s completion and transcendence.

This is as the **Cui Gong**’s *"Mirror of Entering the Medicine"* says:
*"Receive **qi** auspiciously, guard against perilous omens;
When the fire’s intensity is complete, do not harm the elixir;
Heaven and Earth’s essence refined—transformation is parsimonious."*

Thus the subsequent verses of the demon:
*"My noble sister’s vision is profound—
Tightly bar the gates!"*
*"Let any who call outside remain—
The gates shall never open!"*

The Pilgrim said:
*"You two must patrol the riverbank,
Lest he escape!"*
All were tactics of halting refinement and fortifying defenses,
Guarding against dangers and calamities,
Fearful of the *"midnight storm and thunder"* disaster.

**Danyang** Master spoke:
*"Fire in water rises, yet the mind must not be stirred;
Flowers bloom in snow—let the will extinguish the spring."*
This was when the monster had fortified its ramparts in layers,
Sealing the gates and refusing to emerge.
The **Dao**’s nature returns to its true essence—
A spontaneous, wondrous stillness.
The **Bodhisattva** of **Potalaka** moves with effortless grace—
Not awaiting the Pilgrim’s obeisance,
*"No one is permitted to attend—
She enters the bamboo grove to observe and play."*

Had the **Bodhisattva** known the demon would be subdued,
She would have prepared the instruments of capture beforehand,
To display their marvelous efficacy in **shen guan** [神观, divine observation].
This is not something to be shared with all.

The Great Sage then:
*"Let me sit for a moment,
Awaiting the Bodhisattva’s emergence."*
Since the time was not yet ripe,
He must patiently wait—
No need to agitate his restless mind.

When the **Red Boy** laughed:
*"In those days, your demonic passions clouded your heart,
But today you have attained the fruit of enlightenment—
Only now do you recognize my true goodness."*

This clearly marks the moment when the **Red Boy** revealed his true form.
Today’s demons, like the **Red Boy**,
Cannot achieve enlightenment without the **Bodhisattva**’s **Dao**-power and divine skill.
Though the principle of **Dao** is one—
To transcend the self and attain liberation—
The timing of their subjugation varies.

The Pilgrim’s heart burned with anxiety,
Fearful that delay would endanger his master’s life.
Yet time passed, and the elixir escaped its vessel—
His life was lost.

*"The Bodhisattva instructed,
‘Wait only for his own emergence.’"*
This refers to the elixir’s moment of **tui tai** [脱胎, transformation],
When it must be allowed to rise naturally.

Describing the **Bodhisattva**’s divine play in the bamboo grove—
All was effortless, unforced grace,
No artifice or pretense,
Revealing both male and female in one form,
Distinguishing purity from defilement.
Amidst the haste, she moved with perfect ease—
Within **zuo wang** [坐忘, seated oblivion], all was order.
The instruments of **shen guan** were truly profound,
As the **Ganlu** [甘露, sweet dew] of compassion fell upon the azure void.

Ah! How wondrous!

The River of Heaven’s demon’s root—
Only the Bodhisattva perceives its source;
In the bamboo grove, she strips the wicker—
What could the celestial hosts ever know?

To restore her household, few things she needs—
A single hand lifts a purple bamboo basket;
To rescue Tang Seng, time must not be lost—
No fetters bind the one who robes and sits.

Unadorned, the Bodhisattva appears,
Yet like a midwife pressed by urgent birth;
The basket tied at the stream’s head,
Plainly the fisherman against the current’s pull.

The Bodhisattva chants:
*"The dead depart, the living abide!
The dead depart, the living abide!"*
Divine! Divine!
The mechanism of life and death lies in her grasp—
Her secret technique, passed only by word of mouth,
Its wondrous inversion beyond speech.
Yet in shallow terms:
*"Abide"*—the essence of humanity,
Where heart-sprout and kidney-qi entwine,
Thus life is formed; entering my *"Gate"* is *"obstruction."*
*"Depart"*—the loss of unity,
Where the Seven Emotions and malevolent intent persist,
Thus death is sealed; when the *"ruin"* comes, it must *"perish."*

The living—this is *shen* [神, spirit],
Qi refined, ascending and abiding,
One’s attainment yields perfection,
Detached from humanity, self-sustaining—
Its abiding is its own, not the Bodhisattva’s.

The dead—this is *wu* [物, matter],
Substance impure, descending and departing,
Touch water, it breaks the law;
Meet the blade, it meets its fate—
Its departure is its own, not the Bodhisattva’s.

The *Sutra* says:
*"The Bodhisattva, in the Dharma, should dwell nowhere."*
Yet now it says *"abide"*—
Life arises from the living,
The living is without abiding, yet abiding arises from the living.
Departure stems from death,
Death is abiding itself—
Thus abiding leads to departure.
The chant’s manifest meaning is clear,
But its hidden marvels cannot be put to paper.

*"A radiant golden fish"*—
Suddenly enters the basket,
Only the Bodhisattva’s divine perception could mark its moment.

What intent does the Bodhisattva hold?
Tracing its origin, born from the lotus, unstained;
Examining her method, from the Nine Transformations, returning to One.

The *"tides surging from the sea"*—
Revealing the cause and conditions of its descent into the world as a spirit;

*"Counting the fingers, tracing the lines"*—
Calculating the time of its return to the origin.

*"Performing divine arts, weaving a bamboo basket, capturing the marvelous manifestation"*—
To show the common folk the vast compassion and great mercy—
For the divine response is such that the King is indeed the embodiment of a Great Sage.

As the *Sutra* states:
*"Guanyin Bodhisattva accomplishes such virtues,
Taking countless forms to traverse the lands,
Rescuing and liberating all beings."*

The Great Sage obtained the Dragon Girl and the Red Boy,
Revealing the true source of inherent nature;
The King obtained the boy and girl,
Manifesting the roots of life itself.

One and two are the same.

The people of Chenjiazhuang who hold faith—
Each household has its own divine-response Great Sage,
And the wondrous forms of the fish basket
Naturally possess the methods to subdue the divine-response King.
Yet why do they not revere and honor them with faith?

When the King is captured in the basket,
Tang Seng’s life is already saved,
The old turtle returns to its original abode and returns to the origin—
This is the completion of the Heavenly Passage and the Universal Salvation Boat.
Why bother with building ships or preparing oars?

*"Suddenly a loud cry from the river"*—
From *"knowing enlightenment is inherently divine,"*
*"It is truly real—*
*How dare it be false?"*

Crossing with a steady heart over ice thicker than layers—
*"A slight tilt, and the fruit of enlightenment is lost";*
Stepping on the lid, standing firm on either side—
Leading the horse upward, it is indeed the *River Diagram*.

Ah!

The turtle’s back emits a five-colored radiant light;
Within the Heavenly Passage, all mysteries of the formless are spoken.

Returning to the origin, it relies entirely on spontaneity;
Shedding its shell to become true, one must inquire of the Buddha and Ancestors.

Able to board the bottomless ship—
For here lies the root of divine essence planted.
Obtaining the scripture of written truth,
One must still traverse the *River Diagram*’s path.

Solemnly sworn to Heaven, not a word amiss—
I ask, I ask, do not forget.

**Fifty-First Chapter**
*Emotions Stirred by Lust, Nature Lost to Desire*
*The Godhead Dimmed, the Heart Bewildered by Demons*

Master Yu-yi of Enlightenment says: *The Journey to the West* expounds the Dao of the Golden Elixir, focusing solely on the two characters **"性" (nature/essence)** and **"命" (life/principle)**, which are in truth the original, true *qi* of the primal heavens.

Those who cultivate nature and life cultivate this single *qi*; when nature and life are both perfected, they return to unity.
Revolving endlessly, transforming in myriad ways, yet never departing from their source.

Various treatises establish doctrines:
Some first clarify nature, then life;
Others first clarify life, then nature.
Some say clarifying nature is the same as clarifying life,
Or that clarifying life is the same as clarifying nature.
Some emphasize nature alone, yet life holds no separate principle;
Others emphasize life alone, yet nature shares the same origin.
Some clarify nature but fail to grasp life’s subtlety,
Or clarify life but miss nature’s essence.
Some first grasp life, then later grasp nature,
Or first grasp nature, then later grasp life.
Some, failing to grasp nature, fall into emptiness and deceit,
Or, failing to grasp life, stray into demonic delusion.
Some, through false paths, fail to grasp life and lose their nature;
Others, through barren stillness, fail to grasp nature and cannot grasp life.
Some, led astray by material desires, fail to grasp nature;
Others, misled by illusions, fail to grasp life.
Some, not fully knowing nature’s beginning, cannot grasp it;
Others, not fully knowing life’s mysteries, cannot grasp it.

Some speak directly, some speak in reverse,
Some convey meaning through metaphor, some through symbols.
Some jest or indulge in idle musings to reveal inherent truth;
Others use cold, subtle words to demonstrate foundational practice.
Some hint at the essential keys,
Others openly reveal the true transmission.

Whether oblique or direct, indirect or allegorical.

The myriad demons may wield strange arts,
Yet all still revolve around refining **"性命"** (nature and life),
Or cultivating the **先天真乙之氣** (primal Daoist *qi* of the original Yang).

The first seven chapters follow a natural order.
Later ones, either ordered or without sequence,
Are inverted and rearranged—each chapter holds profound meaning.
Like the **造化** (Cosmic Transformation) carving all things,
No repetition exists; all ultimately stem from the **一元** (monarchal unity).

The *Paramartha Contract* says: *"孔窍其門"* (its gate is narrow and secret).
Ziyu Master says: *"引而不發"* (draw but do not release).
Only those who read well can **神觀默察** (divinely perceive and silently observe)
And thereby attain self-realization.

If a chapter’s teaching shifts with circumstance,
Unable to **安身立命** (settle oneself and establish one’s nature),
Then it is the *Yijing*’s *"思出其位"* (thinking beyond one’s station),
And the *Zhongyong*’s *"不能素位而願外"* (unable to abide in one’s inherent station yet craving the external).
All stems from **操守不固** (unstable moral discipline)
And **工夫未到** (unfulfilled practice).

The opening lines of *"Nán Kē Zǐ"* (The Southern Slope’s Child) reveal
A **心地工夫** (heart-mind cultivation) that is continuous and unbroken,
Every word piercing to the core.
Why single out *"南柯"* (Southern Slope)?
Because the world’s treacherous paths are **幻如南柯** (illusions like the Southern Slope).
If one’s heart clings to desires,
Unable to **隨遇而安** (adapt with equanimity),
Flitting from one place to another,
Then it is akin to being caught in a *Nán Kē* dream.

What is hardest for mortals to endure?
Nothing surpasses **饥欲** (hunger and craving),
And what most easily disturbs them?
**饥寒而思衣食** (hunger and cold, pondering food and garments).
In the text, the master and disciple share harmony of heart and unity of intent,
Pursuing truth and returning to the right path—
Thus refining nature and life.

Should hunger or cold arise,
One must **固穷** (embrace poverty with resolve),
Not recklessly act.
The Three Treasures (三藏) see the **楼台** (palatial halls) and desire to take alms,
The practitioner gazes at the **气色** (aura) and urges them not to enter,
Conveying the warning:
*"Do not knock at the gates of the mighty for gain,"*
*"Beware the ice-slick slopes and tread with caution."*
*"Dismount, sit level on the ground,
Do not stir your body.
Grant you a method to settle—
Draw a circle, charge you not to step beyond,
And steadfastly remain within.
This is **素位而行** (to move from one’s inherent station),
Not craving the external.
This is called **有坐性** (having settled nature),
Not merely tracing a circle like the *Yùzhàng Shù* (Jade Canopy Technique).

Having settled nature or lacking it—
Not in the sitting, but in the station.
To move from one’s inherent station is **有坐性** (having settled nature),
Not straying outside the circle.
Once one craves the external,
The settled station is lost—
Though one sits the whole day in stupor,
It is still **無坐性** (lacking settled nature),
Having stepped beyond the circle.

To dwell in wealth as though it were none—**有坐性**.
To endure poverty as though it were fixed—**有坐性**.
To face calamity as though it were trivial—**有坐性**.
To meet circumstances with ease,
Content and unperturbed,
Even without sitting, one sits.
Yet if the mind is restless,
Turned by external influences,
Then one has **性** (nature) and lacks **性** (nature).

To step outside this circle
Is to enter another—
As if trapped in the **罟獲陷阱** (nets and snares),
Yet unaware of how to avoid them.

Master and disciple both sit composed,
The practitioner does not shun a thousand *li* journey,
Serving the master with alms—
This is duty within the circle,
Not craving the external.
*"Until ancient trees rise to the heavens,
A village of dwellings is reached."*

The gate of brushwood creaked as an elder emerged, dragging a staff of *lú* (藜) and gazing upward to the heavens, proclaiming:
**"The northwest wind rises—tomorrow shall be clear!"**

A scruffy hound dashed forth from behind him.

Then he spoke again:
**"You’ve strayed from the path.
The Western Heaven’s way lies straight north ahead."**

But in his heart, fear struck him:
**"This monk is a ghost! A ghost!"**

Then he raised his staff to strike, and the Wayfarer replied:
**"Old one, no matter how you strike,
Just remember the tally of your blows—
One staff for one *shēng* (升) of rice,
Slowly measured out."**

Hearing this, the elder slammed the gate shut,
Shouting only: **"There’s a ghost! A ghost!"**

The Wayfarer said:
**"The Dao transforms the virtuous, and the virtuous release the foolish."**

With a hidden-body technique, he took a bowl of dry rice and returned.

Ah! How wondrous!
The Immortal Master’s parable is profound and veiled—
Unfathomable to the reader.
Common folk might think it merely depicts
A barking village dog and a miserly old man,
But who would know it’s a covert censure
Of those in high station who secretly hoard wealth,
Pretending to discern the *tian shi* (天时) and perceive human affairs,
Relying on their power to gauge the winds of fortune—
Truly, they are men of **shàng kuì fǔ zuò** (仰愧俯怍),
Who have stepped beyond the circle of **tian zuòxìng** (天坐性),
Likely akin to the *Mǎng Dàfū* (莽大夫) of the *Gāng Mù Shū* (纲目书).

How do we see this?
**"Ancient trees reaching to the heavens"**—
Is this not dwelling in the *Mù Tiān* (木天, the realm of wood)?
**"Dragging a staff of *lú* (藜)"**—
Is this not the *Tài Yǐ Zhàng* (太乙杖, the staff of the Supreme Unity), a *lú* staff?
**"Village dwellings and brushwood gates"**—
Is this not wandering in the wilds?
**"Gazing to the heavens and spotting a scruffy hound"**—
Is this not observing the winds while clinging to survival,
And feeling shame before the heavens?

**"You’ve strayed from the path—
The Western Heaven’s way lies straight north ahead."**
Not knowing his own error in facing south,
Yet instructing others of their westward deviation—
His heart is filled with shame,
Hence he cries: **"A ghost! A ghost!"**
If his mind clings to ghosts,
Is this not shame before humanity?

**"The elder raises his staff to strike.
The Wayfarer says: ‘Old one,
Just remember the tally of your blows—
One staff for one *shēng* (升) of rice.’"**
Indeed, he relies only on records to predict promotions,
Knowing nothing beyond his own stolen gains and self-satisfied sustenance—
His heart is filled with shame,
Hence he cries: **"A ghost! A ghost!"**
When he reflects on his deeds,
How could he not shame himself to death?

The Eight Precepts say:
**"I am not like that uncouth man,"**
And thus marks his own kind.

This man is neither virtuous nor foolish—
The Dao cannot transform him,
And the teachings cannot release him.

Such wretched souls—ashamed above, abashed below—
Though they hold office yet step beyond their station,
Their words betray their hearts, their deeds betray their speech,
Clear villains indeed! Better far were those who hide their faces,
Scratching for scraps to feed their parents, serve their masters,
Yet show the utmost reverence and respect.

The Sage’s words are not idle—
He stirs the spirit of loyal ministers,
Sets a warning for all who bear office,
Just as Mencius’ parable of the Qi man:
The wise man knows his own worth,
The fool knows his own folly—
Thus the noble refuse the taste of others’ fat and grain.

Tang Seng, bewildered by the fool’s tale of prison,
All left their circle together,
Sitting at the gates of princes and nobles,
Silent as a ghost’s lair, with no trace of man—
Not that there were none, but only beggars in the dead of night,
Living like ghosts in a tomb.

The fool entered and saw:
Silken curtains, ivory beds—
A heap of white bones, gaunt and shriveled.
To see one of noble rank yet neglect his nature and life—
The clear-eyed see only a pile of bones.

The fool wept and sighed:
*"Where now are the heroes and the bold?"*
A saying to stir the soul to wakefulness.

*"A flicker of lamplight in the tent"*—
The fleeting nature of life, like a spark soon gone.
*"Silken robes on the table"*—
The allure of purple and gold.
*"No matter right or wrong, he takes off his robe"*—
The shamelessness of office.
*"No one around—who could know?"*—
The fearlessness of the four watchful senses.
*"He stands unsteady, then crashes to the ground"*—
The fickleness of honor and disgrace.
*"He binds his own hands behind his back"*—
The ease with which one falls into the law’s snare.

Tang Seng, driven by hunger, left the circle and roused the demon.
The fool, clinging to warmth, fell into its trap—
All because desire clouded their nature, their passions unchecked,
Their ruin self-wrought. What blame to the demon?

Thus those who cultivate the Dao’s natural worth
Refuse the trappings of rank and finery.

The Pilgrim returned to the circle for food,
Found no one, no horses—
Looked back, and the towers had turned to jagged rocks.
The yellow millet still unripe, all changed in an instant—
The sea becomes land, land becomes sea—
Truly worthy of lament and song!

All because they could not steadfastly preserve their nature,
Dared to leave the circle, greedy for warmth and ease—
How could they not stray from the path,
Stumble into the jaws of demons?

The old man pointed to *"The Golden Cangshan Cave, where the One-Horned Rhinoceros King reigns."*
The *cang* is a helmet, armor for battle.
The rhinoceros with a single horn is *kàng*—
The king with a single horn is *zhǔ*—
One who steps beyond his station, restless and defiant,
A rebel lord, like the ancient *Huandou* of old.

Thus the tale begins with the master and disciples on their proper path,
Then suddenly a great mountain appears,
Its peaks towering, its ridges sharp—
San Zang holds the reins tight.

The lofty peaks contrast with the towering mountain,
The *cang* (helmet) echoes *Huandou*’s defiance.
Now the *"Cang"* character appears—
Hiding *Huandou* within the mountain’s grandeur.

*Huandou* aided *Gonggong* in rebellion,
Ravaging the age of sage rule—
The ultimate rebel, the most transgressive.
The Sage likens the demon to this ancient traitor.

The old man revealed himself as mountain god and earth spirit,
Accepted the alms bowl,
*"Wait until I rescue Tang Seng,
Then I will serve Tang Seng—
To show the Great Sage’s utmost reverence and filial piety."*
The mountain god does not overstep, does not accept improperly,
Proving the Great Sage’s respect is his due.

The Great Sage searched for the demon’s lair to battle,
The demon, hearing this, rejoiced:
*"Since leaving my palace,
I have not yet tested my skills."*

His joy was seized—
The *cang* (helmet) of defiance, restless and impulsive—
Not to be overcome by mere movement.

The Pilgrim, unable to win, grew frantic,
Lifted his *Jin’gu* Staff and split it into thousands of strands—
Thus, movement only fuels more movement,
And the more he stirs, the deeper he falls.

The demon’s trap was set by movement itself—
The old demon took the circle and bound the *Jin’gu* Staff,
All reduced to motion.

But motion cannot be contained—
All because the first impulse came from within.

Thus it is said:
*"Dao rises one foot, yet the measure stretches ten—
Nature disordered, passions clouded, home misjudged.
Alas, the Dharma-body has no seat—
At that moment, the moving thought was wrong."*

The Fifth Volume:
*The Monkey King’s Empty Schemes*
*Fire and Water Fail to Forge the Demon*

Master Wu Yi said: The rhinoceros is *chǒu*—
Earth of the ugly trigrams, in man it is *yì* (intent).
When intent runs wild with no restraint,
The heart follows, turning with no master—
Losing its grip, it forgets the principle,
And the *Jin’gu* Staff is bound away.

*"The Great Sage stood empty-handed, weeping:
‘Who would have thought my staff was lost?’"*
Meaning he had lost his resolve.

Man can master intent to overcome Heaven,
But Heaven cannot force intent upon man.
If intent is clouded by things and one falls into misfortune,
Yet knows not to reflect—
Only piously pleading to Heaven,
Like a guilty minister who has lost his way.

Without the staff to wield,
He only polishes his words and feigns respect,
Hoping the ruler will listen—
Though he trembles and grovels, bowing deeply,
Exhausting all artifice—
What good does it do?
It only deepens his delusion.

The Great Sage’s petition to Heaven—
A portrait of the deceitful minister—
How could the ruler take such a heart,
And make it sincere?

The Jade Emperor’s edict:
Let Han Xiang go with the Great Sage to investigate.
*The Zhou Ben Ji* names the Han clan as descendants of He.
*Han* is *He*—
Meaning *"how"*—
As in *"how shall we consult this?"*

Thus, upon close investigation, even the Five Emperors could not intervene, so the Monkey was ordered to select celestial generals. The Celestial Master, Xu Jingyang, merely said, *"Let him choose the generals according to his judgment."* Having selected the Li Heavenly King and his sons, as well as the Thunder Lord, the Jade Emperor granted his request—neither the Heavenly Belt nor the Celestial Master could oppose it.

When the Prince Nezha unleashed his magic, his transformations were boundless; when the Demon King hurled his ring into the sky, it ensnared the Six Divine Weapons. The Deng and Zhang lords dared not strike with thunder, and the Heavenly King exclaimed, *"How can this be resolved?"*—even the heavenly deities could not intervene.

They then summoned the Fire Deity of Vermilion Splendor to unleash flames, only to have the fire dragons themselves ensnared; next, they called upon the Water Deity of Wuhao Palace to flood the battlefield, but the waters surged outward uncontrollably. Even these lifeless yet tangible forces—fire and water—could not subdue him.

Finally, the Monkey transformed his own hairs into tiny monkeys, only to have them trapped as well. Resuming his true form, he realized that distant measures were futile and began to consider the principle of *"near-taking from within."* Yet how could he hope to restrain one so reckless when his efforts were confined to mere skin and hair?

The assembled gods deliberated:

The Demon King is easy to subdue—only the child’s nature is difficult to conquer.
Unless the treasure is obtained, the demon cannot be captured afterward.

For the strategy to subdue the demon, nothing surpasses first seizing what the demon relies upon;
To seize what the demon relies upon, nothing surpasses first mastering what one oneself employs.

Thus, Deng and Zhang the Two Masters said: *"If one must practice the art of stealth, none but the Great Sage can do it."*
Stealth means subtle transformation and silent operation.
To act with virtue is within oneself, not dependent on others;
Only by inwardly reflecting and rigorously self-examining,
Silently transforming within the heart,
Can one suddenly reclaim what was lost—
Not by mere theft of peaches or elixirs,
Nor by superficially grasping it as a skill.

Thus, the Pilgrim stole into the demon’s cave
And suddenly saw the Golden-Hooped Rod—
This was a fleeting enlightenment,
Yet the master of the staff returned to its rightful owner.
But it was not guaranteed he would not lose it again,
For seizing it through theft was but a glimmer in a crack,
Unable to perceive the whole,
And thus ultimately could not escape its bonds.

Earth resides in the central palace,
While Metal, Wood, Water, and Fire encircle it in function;
Distributed to the four corners,
Metal, Wood, Water, and Fire encircle it in form.
Departing from its proper office and achieving one-sided dominance—
If Earth accumulates and buries Metal,
Then the Golden-Hooped Rod is ensnared;
If Earth obstructs and Water is blocked,
Then Water’s force cannot break free from the bonds.

Earth, as the proper principle, is most divine;
Earth, as perverse, is also most divine.
This vile Earth steals its circle to ensnare all things.

Thus, when the spleen fails, danger is near;
When intent is corrupt, affairs fall into chaos.
Those skilled in distinguishing yellow (Earth) must regulate the spleen;
Those skilled in nurturing life must first subdue the intent.
For intent can harm the heart and disrupt the Five Virtues,
Just as Earth can harm nature and disrupt the Five Phases.

To tame the Earthly intent,
No amount of deliberation, strategy, coercion, or force can succeed—
This is why the heavenly deities, Thunder Lord, Fire Deity, and Water God were ineffective.

Thus, the precept states:
*"The mind-monkey, though plotting a thousand schemes,
Finds water and fire useless in refining the demon."*

**Chapter Fifty-Two**
*The Great Sage Raises Havoc in the Golden-Hooped Left "Mountain" Right "Pouch" Cave*
*The Buddha subtly instructs the protagonist:*

*The Venerable Huiyan Zen Master replied:*
