**Sixty-First Chapter**
*The Bull Demon King Ceases Battle and Attends the Banquet*
*The Sun Wukong Twice Persuades the Fan*

Thus the Sage said:
*"The Bull Demon King is the master of true yin.*
*To obtain true yin,*
*one must first seek the Bull of Great Strength."*

The Bull is yin-earth and great strength,
but as a Demon King, his might is even greater—
for he is easily unrestrained
and hard to capture.

*The Classic of Correlating Correspondences* says:
*"The Great Sun flows its pearl,*
*always desiring to leave man.*
*Yet when it meets the Golden Phoenix,*
*it turns and binds with it."*

This speaks of the yin-essence (阴精) in man’s body—
the pearl of the Great Sun,
like mercury in lead,
easily lost.

If one can obtain the *Golden Phoenix’s yin-qi* (金华铅气) to restrain it,
then it may turn to temper the fire’s heat,
binding and stabilizing it.

This is the Bull King’s attendance at the Banquet,
and his turn to meet the Demoness—
the shadowed borrowing of the Golden Phoenix’s yin-qi,
and thus the chance to unite with true enlightenment.

The heart belongs to fire,
the kidneys to water.
Fire is yang, water is yin.
The monkey symbolizes yang,
the bull symbolizes yin.

At first, they share the same origin,
then they repel each other,
and finally serve one another.
*"Five hundred years ago, we swore brotherhood,"*
tracing their beginnings.

The Earth Spirit said:
*"This fire was originally set by the Great Sage,"*
a truth confirmed.

The eight trigrams of the Primordial Dao were inverted
and entered into the Postnatal—
the fire of *Li* (離) grew dominant.
Men see the *Li* fire’s excess,
but do not know it comes from their own inversion,
thus saying: *"You no longer recognize me."*

*"Five hundred years ago, when I raided the Celestial Palace,"*
*"when Laozi refined me in his Eight-Trigram Furnace,"*
*"when the furnace was opened and I knocked over the remaining flames,"*
*"I was the Daoist who guarded the furnace."*
His words are clear and well-reasoned,
not a forced argument.

The *Li* fire cannot temper the flames of passion
without the *Kan* water (坎水),
and thus it must seek the Great Strength
to borrow true yin.

True yin is water,
governed by the *Xun* consort (巽女).
Without borrowing the Great Strength,
it cannot be fully obtained—
thus one must seek the Bull Demon King
through all means of wealth and treasure.

Yet those with great strength
must be tempted by external desires.

*"Now residing at Accumulated Thunder Mountain in Cloud-Drift Cave,"*
speaking of thunder stirring the clouds,
of rain falling at will—
of unrestrained lust.

*"The Jade-Faced Princess, with a hundred thousand treasures,"*
speaking of wealth and beauty together,
and desires easily indulged.

*"Abandoning the Demoness, never looking back,"*
speaking of neglecting true yin,
of never returning.

The flames grow fiercer,
with nothing to temper them.

*"Seeking the Bull King, bowing to beg his aid here,*
*only then can I borrow the true fan—*
for one must restrain desire,
control emotions,
guard true yin without losing it,
as husband and wife remain inseparable,
only then can true yin be obtained
to temper the flames."*

*"Accumulated Thunder Mountain lies to the south,"*
the position of *Li*—
the place of postnatal true yin,
a secondary consort in the outer chamber,
not like the Iron Fan’s original mate,
who holds the true fan of the Primordial Dao.

*"The Pilgrim searched for clues,*
*and suddenly saw beneath the pine shade*
*a woman of extraordinary beauty,*
*plucking a fragrant osmanthus branch,*
*gracefully swaying as she approached."*
A true sign of yin-essence manifesting.

When he feigned curiosity to inquire,
used pretexts to provoke anger,
and then frightened away her attendants,
when he embraced her and played coy,
when he wept, laughed, and spoke tenderly—
all her emotions were vividly depicted,
as if one could see her form,
hear her very words.

Thus it is made clear:
how alluring objects move the heart,
worthy of love and pity;
how the Bull’s attachment
melts the soul and steals the breath.

The Bull King met the Pilgrim,
exchanged old greetings and warm words,
and explained the reason for the son’s journey to Bliss—
now the son’s worthiness of renunciation was clear.

The Bull King spoke:
*"The grief of harming my child,
you have already spoken of;
yet you deceived me with my beloved consort,
stormed my gate—why so?"*

He plainly declared that the son could be renounced,
yet beauty must be seized—
thus revealing how the Bull’s devotion to color
led him to perish for its sake.

The Great Sage begged for aid and relief,
asked to borrow the fan to quell the flames,
and spoke of *"brother’s heart of opening heaven and earth,
leading little brother to visit the elder sister."*

He spoke of *Kan* and *Li* aiding and renouncing—
this was the heart of heaven and earth;
husband leading, wife following—
this was the Way of yin and yang.

If the elder brother did not visit the elder sister,
true yin would not be seen,
and true yang would not be aided.

The Bull King, enraged by deceit of wife and destruction of consort,
fiercely contested—
all to show his love of beauty and hatred of virtue.

When he heard the request to *"come quickly to the feast,"*
he abandoned battle for the banquet—
for once lost to color,
he would surely drown in wine,
one obsession replacing another.

His spirit and emotions were in chaos.
Lost in the watery abyss, rampaging wildly—
how could he not lose his own supporting strength?

Yet wine is water-gold.
Obtaining the Golden Flower,
he ceased his battle,
and there was room for change and transformation.

Thus the Pilgrim ultimately gained the Golden-Eyed Beast,
and transformed the Bull Demon King;
the Demon King ultimately gained the Scattered Flower Feast,
and came to meet the Rakshasa.

*"The Green Wave Pool among the chaotic rocks,"*
even in filth, there is purity;
*"The crab and shellfish know no decorum,"*
yet even in recklessness, there is order.

The Great Sage stole the beast and transformed its form,
then directly arrived at the Banana Grove.
The reader may think this was a trick—borrowing the true fan’s illusory technique—
but in truth, he seized the very principle of *yin* essence.

The Fire-Eyed Sage, with his Golden-Eyed Beast,
straddling the Water-Splitting Beast—
water and fire now share a meeting in form.

The Monkey-Heart takes it as heart,
the Bull-Demon as body—
heart and *yin* now intermingle in harmony.

When seeing his old wife again,
her affection only deepens;
when the wife sees her golden husband,
their bonds grow ever tighter.

Though their union is borrowed in form,
the principle holds true essence—
how could the treasure not naturally reveal itself?
There lies a natural marvel beyond artifice.

They mimic the joy of reunited spouses,
postures brimming with life—
sometimes laughter hides a trace of jealousy,
sometimes solemnity conceals coquettishness;
sometimes feigned anger betrays true affection,
sometimes playful pique draws out honest words.

Hand in hand, cheeks pressed warm,
they leap like twin fish playing in water;
clouds and rain in their glances—
almost too vivid to wash clean the Twelve Peaks of Wu.

The reader may say they’ve captured the intimate tenderness of married love,
yet they’ve overlooked the profound allegory.

She says: *“Your Majesty favors your new bride,
abandoning me—what wind today blew you here?”*
Speaking of loving an external wife while neglecting the inner one—
a fortunate turn when he finally looks back.

She says: *“I never meant to abandon you—
only that Princess Jade-Face was crowned queen,
household affairs grew burdensome,
and friends demanded my attention,
so I lingered outside—
yet I’ve even set up another household.”*
Speaking of being seduced by wealth and desire,
lingering in distraction,
unable to turn inward,
thus making the outer heavy and the inner light.

Then, feigning anger, she scolds: *“When did that damned monkey pass through?”*
And slaps her chest: *“Alas! Alas!
My lord was wrong—
how could you give this treasure to that monkey?”
“It kills me!”*
Speaking of the Way of the Pilgrimage—
without true *yin*, one cannot advance.
How could one pass without the true fan?
And how could one obtain the true fan without me?
If the wife had given the treasure,
that would be a true mistake.

「Then she says: *“My lord, you are newly married to the Great Sovereign—
do not forget your true bond of *yin* and *yang*,
and drink a cup of this native *yang* water.”*
Speaking of how the true *yin* and *yang* within one’s body are like the bond of marriage,
while the *yin* and *yang* outside are like foreign waters—
one must not indulge in fleeting desires
and forget the source of one’s true essence.

Then she says: *“I, due to my concern for external governance,
have been long separated from my lord,
yet night and day I guard and protect your ancestral domain.”*
Speaking of when *yin* and *yang* lose their proper alignment,
and one must bolster the *yang* essence—
this requires strengthening the *yin* foundation.

Then she says: *“‘Kang’ (康) is harmony (齐).
‘My lord is the *yang* parent that nurtures the body.’”*
Speaking of how *yin* and *yang* in perfect balance
bring forth the flourishing of all things;
true *yin* without *yang* cannot sustain and nourish the ten thousand beings.

When they stand side by side, leaning down to embrace,
and speak in unison to nourish the treasure,
clinging to each other in intimacy,
and reveal the *bao-bei* (宝贝),
the profound interplay of *yang* revering *yin*
and the mutual devouring of opposites
is beyond mere description or analogy.

The Great Sage gains the treasure,
lost in dark musings and divine contemplation,
while the Demon Queen, drunk on wine,
speaks of true sentiment and principle.

For the treasure is originally my family’s heirloom—
yet through reckless indulgence and dissipation,
I lost sight of its true nature,
and now cannot even recognize it.

Thus the Demon Queen says:
*“Great King, you must have been day and night lost in pleasure,
your mind clouded by that Princess Jade-Face,
so how could you forget even your own treasure?”*

For those in the world who live in dreams or drunkenness,
these few words can serve as a sharp awakening.

*“With the left thumb holding seven strands,
chanting ‘□ left “mouth” (口), right “four” (四),
hush, exhale, inhale, laugh, blow, breathe’—
it instantly grows two zhang and two chi in length.
This treasure transforms endlessly—
a fire of eight hundred *li*,
which can be extinguished with a single fan.”*
Speaking of restraining the seven emotions,
while channeling the singular *qi* (气) of the fingers—
true *yang* then flourishes,
and its boundless transformations unfold,
as the nine palaces and eight trigrams
are all but manifestations of this *yang* water’s wondrous effects.
Extinguishing flames and tempering heat—
what could be more difficult?

The Great Sage holds the true treasure in hand,
demonstrating its methods,
yet lacking the incantation,
he clutches it to his shoulder.
This cannot be swallowed whole,
nor transformed at will—
thus he cannot keep it without losing it again.

The Bull Demon King scatters the feast,
the Water-Beast having been stolen,
yet the lead is dispersed and true *mercury* (真汞) loses control.
The cause of the Crab’s reckless rampage is understood,
and the scheme of Monkey’s theft of the beast is revealed—
seeing remorse and regret, there remains a chance for return.

Riding the clouds straight back to the Green Cloud,
the Demon Queen shouts in rage: *“Heaven-damned!”*
Both husband and wife were careless,
thus the true treasure was lost,
and they are now in frantic haste.

The monkey steals the grandmother’s treasure,
the Bull King seizes the grandmother’s weapon—
true and false *yin* and *yang* are both disordered,
and Wood, Metal, Water, Fire all clash at once.

**Chapter 61: Zhu Bajie Lends His Strength to Break the Bull Demon King
Sun Wukong’s Three Attempts to Borrow the Banana Fan**

A scholar once remarked:
Readers compare *“Three Attempts to Borrow the Banana Fan”* (三调芭蕉扇)
with *“Three Visits to the Thatched Hut”* (三顾茅庐)
and *“Three Battles at Zhu’s Village”* (三打祝家庄),
as though these were all sacred *Daoist* talismans (宝箓),
mere set phrases in the novel.
It is like reading *The Strategy of the Rabbit Garden* (《兔园策》)
and *The Dragon-Tiger Scripture* (《龙虎经》)
without discerning their true distinctions.

The Fire-Flame Mountain descends from heaven,
meeting the earth—
this is the union of *Qian* (乾, Heaven) and *Kun* (坤, Earth),
giving rise to the three *yang* (阳) energies,
the Great Sage’s primordial *yang* *qi* (真动之气) transformed,
as explained by the adept who guards the Eight Trigram Elixir Furnace (八卦丹炉之道人).

**The First Attempt (一调):**
The Great Sage, dwelling in *Kun* (Earth),
seeks to borrow from *Qian* (Heaven).
In the first borrowing, *Xun* (巽, Gentle Wind) is born as the eldest daughter—
*Xun* is wind, hence the fan;
obtained from *Qian*’s Metal (金), hence the Iron Fan Princess (铁扇公主).
As the eldest daughter of Earth (土),
she is the first *yin* (阴) to appear.

**The Second Attempt (二调):**
The Great Sage, dwelling in *Kun* (Earth),
borrows again.
In the second borrowing, *Li* (离, Fire) is born as the middle daughter—
*Li* is fire, hence she sits in the south,
the symbol of a sovereign facing south,
thus the Jade-Face Princess (玉面公主) is obtained.
As the middle daughter of Earth,
she is the second *yin* to appear.

**The Third Attempt (三调):**
The Great Sage, dwelling in *Kun* (Earth),
borrows a third time.
In the third borrowing, *Dui* (兑, Joy) is born as the youngest daughter—
*Dui* is the marsh, the union of Water and Metal;
positioned in the west with a white hue,
hence the White Bull (白牛).
The bull belongs to Earth yet bears Metal,
traversing all nine palaces,
its power vast—
thus the Great Power King (大力王),
the *yang* parent that nurtures the Iron Fan Princess’s body,
the true *yin* sovereign—
thus the third *yin* appears,
and the true fan is offered.

Through *Kun*’s three borrowings,
three *yin* energies emerge,
to subdue the fire and nurture all things—
all rooted in the primordial *yin* *qi* (真乙之气).
This is the subtle essence of the Great Sage’s
first, second, and third attempts to borrow the fan.

*“If I were to demand it directly from his face,
he would certainly refuse.
But if he fans me once,
I would be sent eight hundred and forty thousand *li* away!”*
This reveals how *yin* and *yang* have cycles of mutual borrowing,
and how Earth can act as the guiding *qi* (用神).

Above, it can adapt and shift with the flow—
Earth subdues Water in reverse borrowing,
yet Water may also bring harm in its counterattack.
Earth borrows Wood in false alignment,
yet Water naturally brings growth and benefit.

Thus it is said:

「When [the fan] is obtained in the guise of the Eight Precepts,
the Eight Rules (*bājiè*) intercepts the Way and ambushes the Great Sage,
tricking him into surrendering the fan—
now knowing the roots of its acquisition and release,
he transforms as a peach kernel (*xìngpiàn*) and tosses it into his mouth.»

The Daoists regard the mouth as the Fire Flame Mountain,
and the true *yin* enters the mouth,
still invoking the *Lǐ* [hexagram] symbol.
The practitioner seeks the true *yin* within *Lǐ*
to achieve *Jìjí* [hexagram],
without relying on Earth and Wood’s functions,
they cannot acquire and succeed.

Thus the following passage focuses on
the assistance of Earth and the Eight Rules (*bājiè*)
as the backbone of action:
*"The Tang Monk sits upon the road,
and the fire *qi* scorches him—
his heart burns, his throat parched,"*
a lone *yang* rising to excess.

*"He questions the Earth Spirit and observes its powers,
summons the Eight Rules and commands them to exert effort,
rolling up the curtain to accompany him,"*
for Earth resides in the Central Palace and never departs.

*"He recognizes the path while traveling,"*
as Earth’s influence thrives in the south,
its vigor borrowed and sustained.

*"When walking straight ahead,
suddenly, they see fighting.
The Earth Spirit says: ‘Tianpeng, do not advance,
what else could be done?’
This means Earth can aid Wood,
and when the moment arises, it acts—
no waiting is required.*

*"The Eight Rules vanquish the Bull King,
while the Earth Spirit detains the Great Strength [Sun Wukong]."
Wood flourishes, Earth thrives—
the moment of their conjunction.*

The Bull King, the Great Sage, and the Eight Rules
strive with fierce resolve,
forging harmony between Metal and Wood,
thus manifesting the true *yin*—
hence, the Jade-Faced Princess of Accumulated Thunder Mountain
comes to lend her strength.

*"The Eight Rules, vexed by the difficulty of obtaining the fan,
contemplates taking an alternate path,"*
lest impatience and doubt arise.

The Earth Spirit says:
*"Great Sage, do not grow anxious,
Tianpeng, do not slacken.
To speak of an alternate path
is to enter a side door,
not the way of true cultivation.
Your master sits upon the straight path,
longingly awaiting your success."*
This means only the Great Sage’s Metal
and Tianpeng’s Wood,
when joined and united in purpose,
can exert bold action
to obtain the true *yin* Water
and fulfill the Great Dao.

If one abandons this and seeks an alternate path,
it is to forsake the true Dao for a side door—
Water and Fire cannot be *Jìjí*,
how then could one find the path to the West and retrieve the scriptures?

This is the Dao of *Jìjí* Water and Fire,
precisely to sit and watch
upon the straight path
for the success of Metal and Wood.

The Traveler (*Xíngzhě*) growls in agreement:
*"Indeed, indeed—
you speak with reason."*
He says: *"Well done, the Earthly Constraints transform!"*
He says: *"Shatter the obstinate void
and seek the Buddha’s face!"*
This means to act within the *Kun* [hexagram] Palace,
and through powers and transformations,
to meet the Buddha—
not like the Chan school,
which clings solely to the *xìngzōng* [nature school]
and falls into the void of obstinacy.

The Eight Rules exerts effort and says:
*"What care have I for the Bull King’s coming or not?"
This means to drive the Bull back to Earth,
the action is mine,
while the Bull knows nothing.*

He says: *"Wood in *hài* [the hour of the pig],
its nature paired with the pig,
dragging the Bull’s child back to Earth’s kind."*
This means Wood and Fire are paired,
*yin* within *yang*.
To drag Wood and Mercury (*gōng*) back,
preventing their wildness,
and make them return to Earth,
then the true *yin* is obtained to subdue Fire—
this is the Eight Rules’ exertion.

He says: *"From *shēn* [the hour of the monkey] comes Metal’s birth,
yet without punishment or suppression,
there is much harmony and *qi*."*
This means Metal and Water are paired,
clarifying the central *yang*.

*"With the banana leaf,
as Water’s intention,
the Fire Flame is extinguished—*Jìjí* achieved."*
The meaning is self-evident.

*"Two lead the Earth Spirit and the *yin* soldiers,
advancing together,"*
their actions never stray from Earth.

「Thus, in the moment when the three contend in battle, the Earth Spirit blocks the Way, saying: *"Great Strength King, where do you flee? We are here!"* The Old Bull and the Pilgrim engage in their own transformations and struggles, mirroring their prior contest in the Heavenly Palace with the Second Prince.

This one acts in accordance with the **Pristine Dao/Way**, following the **Heavenly Dao/Way** and the **Human Dao/Way**;
That one defies the **Heavenly Dao/Way**, embodying the **Dao/Way of the Immortal**.

Together, they display the marvel of one **following** and one **defying**.

The Old Bull ascends from Earth to Heaven,
first ascending to the **Heavenly Dao/Way**.
Transforming into a **celestial swan**—Heavenly Unity (*Tiānyī*) generates Water,
Water generates Wood, in **harmony**;
The Pilgrim transforms into a **sea-eastern green**—the **eastern green** is Wood,
Wood, though born of Water, **counteracts** Water—**defiance**.

The Bull King then shifts into a **yellow hawk**—Yellow belongs to Earth,
Water, though subdued by Wood, **reverses and nourishes** Earth—**defiance**;
Earth, though subdued by Wood, **reverses and restrains** Water—
Earth dries, Wood withers.

Thus, the **sea-eastern green** cannot subdue the **yellow hawk**,
but the **yellow hawk** subdues the **sea-eastern green**—**defiance**.

The Pilgrim then becomes a **black phoenix**—Black belongs to Water,
Wood, though restrained by Earth, **reverses and nourishes** Water—**defiance**;
Water, though restrained by Earth, **reverses and counteracts** Earth—
Water overflows, Earth collapses.

Thus, the **yellow hawk** cannot subdue the **black phoenix**,
but the **black phoenix** subdues the **yellow hawk**—**defiance**.

The Old Bull again becomes a **white crane**—White belongs to Metal,
Wood, though subdued by Water, **reverses and nourishes** Metal—**defiance**.

The Pilgrim transforms into a **crimson phoenix**—Crimson belongs to Fire,
Fire, though subdued by Water, **reverses and nourishes** Fire—**defiance**.

Heavenly Unity’s Water refines the Five Phases (*wǔxíng*) to generate all things,
never straying from the five colors—**eastern green, yellow, black, white, crimson**—
this is the Dao/Way’s **harmony of following and defiance**, manifesting in transformations above.

The Old Bull descends from Heaven to Earth,
later entering the **Earthly Dao/Way**.
Transforming into a **fragrant tahr**—Earthly Unity (*Dì’èr*) generates Fire.
The tahr shares kinship with the deer,
sharing the **Mare’s mansion** (*mǎgōng*)—Fire;
born from the **white crane’s** Metal, thus Metal **reverses and nourishes** Fire—**defiance**.

The Pilgrim becomes a **starving tiger**—the tiger’s domain is the West—Metal;
born from the **crimson phoenix’s** Fire, thus Fire **reverses and nourishes** Metal—**defiance**;
By principle, Metal cannot subdue Fire,
yet the tiger possesses the power to devour the tahr—
Fire **reverses and is subdued by** Metal—**defiance**.

The Old Bull again becomes a **golden-money leopard**—the leopard is of Metal,
transforming from the tahr—Fire **reverses and becomes** Metal—**defiance**;
The Pilgrim then becomes a **golden-eyed lion**—the lion is a Fire beast,
transforming from the tiger—Metal **reverses and becomes** Fire—**defiance**;
The Old Bull again becomes a **human bear**—the bear belongs to Fire,
the leopard transforms into the bear—Metal **reverses and becomes** Fire—**defiance**;
The Pilgrim then becomes a **reclining elephant**—the elephant’s power lies in its trunk—Earth,
the lion transforms into the elephant—Fire **reverses and becomes** Earth—**harmony**.

The *Sutra* of **Peeling** (*Bō*) says:
*"To follow and then restrain—this is observing the **symbols**."*
Earthly Unity’s Fire refines the Five Phases to generate all things,
never straying from the five **symbols**—Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, Earth.
This is the Dao/Way’s **harmony of defiance and following**, manifesting in transformations below.

Heavenly Unity generates Water,
Earthly Unity completes it—
Water and Fire **achieve mutual nourishment** (*Jìjí*),
all returning to Earth.
Thus, the Bull King retains his original form,
and the **white cow** appears.

Earth transforms into **white**—
then Wood is **balanced**, Water is **harmonized**, Fire is **quenched**, Metal is **clarified**,
and the **golden elixir** is nearly perfected.
Thus, the Pilgrim assumes his original form,
and the **ten-thousand-foot golden body** is fully manifest.

The verse says:
*"The clever monkey’s efforts descend the **Dao/Way**."*
Speaking of cultivation relying entirely on the mind’s concentration and exertion.

*"The precious fan must be used,"*
speaking of abandoning Metal and Water,
which do not aid Wood and Fire.

*"The Yellow Mother supports the origin,"*
*"The Wood Mother shares the same sentiment,"*
speaking of Earth and Wood’s application needing diligence.

*"In harmony, the Five Phases return to their proper unity—**the fruit of righteousness** is achieved."*
Speaking of the Five Phases converging into one,
not harming each other, and thus attaining **Western Paradise** (*Xīfāng*).

Here, the **Great Sage** and the Bull King vie in pursuit,
with the **Eight Rules** and Earth Spirit striving at every turn—
the **refining** of Metal and Fire,
relying solely on Earth and Wood’s application.

Their divine generals and the **Buddha’s power** in guarding and intercepting,
as well as the **Li Tianwang** and **Ne Zha**’s decapitation and **mirror-like** projection,
are none other than the **spirits of Fire, Water, and Earth** shining forth.

To the North stands **Bìlù** (*毘盧沙門*), the **Sage of Great Omniscience** (*Shéntōng Guǎngdà*), to the South, **Victory** (*Shèngzhì*), the **Sage of Boundless Virtue/Power** (*Fǎlì Wúliàng*);
To the East stands **Bìlú** (*毗卢*), the **Sage of Great Strength** (*Dàlì*), to the West stands **Unbreakable Venerable King** (*Bùhuài Zūnwáng*), **Forever Residing** (*Yǒngzhù*).
From all directions, divine soldiers and Heavenly Generals gather,
with **Li Tianwang**, bearing the **Tower**, and his son as heavenly guardians above.

*"The Old Bull returns, transforming into a great white cow,"*
a **symbol of returning to the origin and the unity of the elements**.

The **Prince** manifests **three heads and six arms**,
mounts the Bull’s back in flight,
and cuts off its head—
**_Qián_** transforms into **_Kūn_**, symbolizing **_yin_**.
The **Bull** loses its head, symbolizing **"Wǔ"** (*the hour of the horse*),
thus piercing forth a head,
spouting black **_qi_**, generating **_yin_**, ceaselessly—
**_yin_** fully revealed.

Ne Zha then blows **true fire**,
and **true _yin_** and **true _yang_** mutually nourish each other.
The refining complete,
the **mind-mirror** (*Xīnjìng*) is used to fix the original **symbol**,
preventing it from dispersing.
Great Strength subdued,
the **true treasure** shines forth—
this is the **orthodox path of taking refuge in the Buddha-Dharma**.

Ne Zha drags the **white cow** back,
the **Rakshasa** presents the **true fan**,
and the **Four Great Heavenly Kings** (*Sìdà Jīnjiāng*) declare:
*"Revered Sage, congratulations!
The **tenfold merit** is nearly complete!"*
This is the moment when the **golden elixir** is near perfection.

They further say:
*"You must now exert your utmost in cultivation,
never slackening for an instant!"*
This indicates that the **refining fire** for the **golden elixir** remains,
and one must not slacken for a moment.»

The **true fan** once waved, and the fire subsides;
twice waved, and the wind stirs;
thrice waved, and the rain descends.
Creation lies within my grasp,
demonstrating the natural sequence of **fire cultivation** (*huǒhòu*).

The verse says:
*"Ne Zha leads the white cow back to the Buddha’s realm,
no longer capricious—
water and fire unite, their nature naturally harmonized."*

For when **yin** and **yang** are joined, the cow’s strength is tamed;
when water and fire merge as one, the **Dao** returns to its true essence.

This is why the **Three Baskets** (*Sāṃzàng*) serve to
*"relieve dryness and dispel vexation,
purify the mind and settle the will."*

The Cow King directly returns to the **Buddha’s Pure Land** (*Fó jìngtǔ*), taking refuge in the **Pure Realm** (*jìngtǔ*);
The **Rakshasa** seeks its own **true fan** (*běnxuān*), departing to cultivate in seclusion.

At the moment of **elixir completion** (*dānchéng*), all furnace, cauldron, and refining implements
are cast aside.

*"Continuously waving the fan forty-nine times,
forever severing the root of fire."*

Forty-nine is seven times seven—
forty-nine cycles of **fire cultivation** (*yùnhuǒ*), all now fully revealed.

Yet this is not forced or contrived;
it is the natural unfolding.

The *Yì* says:
*"The great unfolding number is fifty,
but its application is forty-nine"*—
just so.

*"Where fire is, rain descends;
where fire is absent, skies clear."*
**Lǐ** below, **Kǎn** above—
**yin** and **yang** in perfect accord,
the image of serene heavens and tranquil earth.

Thus the conclusion:
*"When **Lǐ** and **Kǎn** are harmonized, the **true essence** unites;
water and fire balanced, the **Great Dao** is fulfilled."*

This chapter closely mirrors *Chapter 62: Seizing the Tower to Purify Filth, Binding Demons to Rectify the Self*—
where the **Second Brother** (*Èrláng*) subdues the **Great Sage** (*Dàshèng*), using **yin** to clip **yang** and thus forming *Pǐ*.
Here, **yin** nourishes **yang**, completing *Jìjí*—
thus both chapters employ **Li Tianwang** and Ne Zha father and son.

Its profound and wondrous phrasing,
and the inverted yet brilliant structure,
are such.

The *Yì*’s principle of correspondence holds true:
*"Jade veiled in stone makes mountains radiant,
pearls cradled in streams make rivers alluring—
the **Floating Pagoda** (*fútó*) stores treasures, its light illuminating the four quarters,
while a human body attains the **Dao**, its purity shining through face and back—
one principle alone."*

Readers say:
*"The **Pleiades** (*Qūyè*) shift their abode,
bound to the **virtue** of the sovereign;
**Mars** (*Yínghuò*) alters its course,
moved by the ruler’s heart.
The **Pearl River** (*Pǔzhū*) regards profit and loss as ebb and flow,
while **Jing Province’s** fields rise or fall with fortune’s division and union.
The waters of **Xīyáng Creek** are clear or turbid
as they reflect the governor’s greed or integrity;
the **stone mirror of Lin’an** (*Lín’ān shíjìng*) brightens or darkens
according to the official’s praise or censure.
The logic of **omens and responses** indeed has its truth."*

「The sixty-second chapter—*"Purifying the Heart by Sweeping the Pagoda"* and *"Binding the Demon to Return to the Dao by Cultivating the Body"*—

**Treasured in Understanding** said: *"When gold contains jade, the mountain shines; when water cradles pearls, the river enchants. The Floating Pagoda stores treasures, its light illuminating the four quarters, while a human body attains the Dao, its purity shining through face and back—one principle alone."*

Yet, when the **virtue** (*dé*) of the sovereign wanes, the **Pleiades** (*Qūyè*) shift their abode; when the ruler’s heart is misguided, **Mars** (*Yínghuò*) alters its course. The **Pearl River** (*Pǔzhū*) regards profit and loss as ebb and flow, while **Jing Province’s** fields rise or fall with fortune’s division and union. The waters of **Xīyáng Creek** are clear or turbid as they reflect the governor’s greed or integrity; the **stone mirror of Lin’an** (*Lín’ān shíjìng*) brightens or darkens according to the official’s praise or censure. The logic of **omens and responses** indeed has its truth.

This **Golden Pagoda** (*Jīnguāngtǎ*), though its treasures depart and its light recedes, is a metaphor for the human body stained by defilement and thus losing its **Dao/Way** (*dào*), where ruler and subject alike falter in their **virtue/power** (*dé*) and their transformations are obstructed—truly a profound and practical meaning. In the previous chapter, the master and disciple achieved balance through water and fire, having already attained the **mystic Dao** (*miàodào*); now, with **dissipation and idle thoughts** (*sǎnchǎn xiāoyáo*) dispelled, the Western Paradise lies in sight.

Yet one must **embrace the One and preserve the Primordial** (*bàoyī shǒuyuán*), nurturing it diligently at every moment, so that the heart’s clarity remains untainted. Only then can one await the **fulfillment of merit and the completion of practice** (*hòuzú gōngwán*). If even the slightest negligence or indulgence arises, then **supreme virtue** (*zhìdé*) cannot be cultivated, and the **refined Dao** (*zhìdào*) will not solidify. Hence, the opening verse of *"Temporary Residence by the River"* (*Línjiāngxiān*) is inscribed to emphasize this essential truth.

It says:
*"In every twelve-hour span, forget not to tend it,
a hundred moments of practice fully gathered.
Three years, ten times eight thousand cycles—
do not let the **Divine Water** (*Shénshuǐ*) run dry,
nor let the **Sacred Fire** (*Huǒguāng*) grow weary.
Balancing water and fire without loss,
the **Five Phases** (*Wǔxíng*) linked like a hook.
Harmony of **Yin and Yang** (*Yīnyáng*) ascending to the **Cloud Palace** (*Yúnlóu*),
riding the **Luan bird** (*Chéngluán*) to the **Purple Palace** (*Zǐfǔ*),
and crossing the **Hawk bird** (*Guàhè*) to the **Penglai Isles** (*Yíngzhōu*)."*
The meaning is clear: in a year of **thirty-six thousand moments** (*sānwànliùqiè*), three years yield **one hundred and eight thousand moments** (*shísānwànbāqiānqiè*). Each moment must be nurtured with unwavering devotion—no room for idle indulgence. For the **alchemical practice** (*dàn*) that follows, the **preservation of merit** (*bǎogù*) lies in **washing the heart and purifying the mind** (*xǐxīn dílǜ*), rectifying one’s nature. Otherwise, the nature will remain obscured, and the **alchemical elixir** (*dàn*) will not solidify.

As the master and disciple arrived in the **Sacrificial Realm** (*Jìsài guó*), they saw a monk bound in shackles, his **blue robes** (*lánlǚ*) in tatters, and inquired whether he was the wronged monk from **Golden Light Temple** (*Jīnguāngsì*). The **Three Treasures** (*Sānguì*)—**no-self** (*wúrén*), **no-other** (*wǒ*), and **no-phenomenon** (*wúzhòngshēng*)—are lost when a monk bears such wrongs. Thus, they sighed: *"A fox spared from death laments, creatures grieve their kind."* This **blood-stained Pagoda** (*xiěguì*) is but the **Three Treasures** (*Sānguì*) defiled by blood; its treasures lost, the **Three Treasures** (*Sānguì*) have themselves lost their essence—thus, it is a single calamity.

Together, they visited the temple gates to witness it. The **Three Treasures** (*Sānguì*) could not bear the sorrow, and after bowing to the Buddha, they turned away, unable to face the sight, yet still perceiving the **great unity of all beings as the heart’s truth** (*Dàtóng yītǐ wéi xīn*). The monks came to kneel and ask: *"Your forms are not alike."* The monk replied: *"It seems the celestial deities were disturbed; last night, all received a single dream. Today, they truly saw such strange appearances, hence recognizing them."* For though **no-self** (*wúrén*), **no-other** (*wǒ*), and **no-phenomenon** (*wúzhòngshēng*) may differ in name, the **Divine Mind** (*Shénmíng*) silently reveals itself, and through **subtle dreams** (*yōumèng*), all are made known.

With the monks’ recognition of forms through dreams, the **Three Treasures** (*Sānguì*) subtly imply the **Three Illusions** (*Sānxiàng*)—**no-self** (*wúrén*), **no-other** (*wǒ*), and **no-phenomenon** (*wúzhòngshēng*)—and draw the **Sweeping the Pagoda** (*Sǎotǎ*) lesson close to the **Tang Monk’s** (*Tángsēng*) own body and mind. When the text reaches:
*"The king said: ‘Holy monk, your noble bearing is so resplendent—how do your disciples appear thus?’
The **Great Sage** (*Dàsèng*) heard and said: ‘Your Majesty must not judge by appearances.’"*
only then does the meaning of **no-self** (*wúrén*), **no-other** (*wǒ*), and **no-phenomenon** (*wúzhòngshēng*) fully reveal itself. The **text’s profound intent** (*Wénxīn yōuzào*) holds **divine subtleties and hidden mysteries** (*shéncáng guǐnì*).

**"Relics"** (*Shèlì*) are the Buddha’s physical remains. In ancient times, **Emperor Yang of the Sui Dynasty** (*Suí Rénshào*) composed the *"Record of the Relics’ Omens and Responses"* (*Shèlì Gǎn yìng jì*): When a pagoda was raised in **Thinking Awakening Temple** (*Sījué sì*) in **Qin Province’s** (*Qín Huázhōu*) **Hua State** (*Huá*), the heavens sent a **divine snow** (*yīnxuě*). As the **relics** (*shèlì*) descended, the sun shone brightly, casting a **five-colored radiance** (*wǔsè guāngqì*), several zhang above the earth, resembling a **chariot wheel** (*chēlún*), directly covering the pagoda. From tens of miles away, those gazing saw the **relics** (*shèlì*) as a **pure red glow ascending to heaven** (*zhèngchì shàngshǔ tiān*). Once the **relics** (*shèlì*) had settled, clouds and mists rose again, and the **auspicious snow** (*ruìxuě*) scattered like **heavenly flowers** (*tiān huā*) upon people’s robes, lingering without wetting them. The **Golden Light Pagoda** (*Jīnguāngtǎ*)’s **relics** (*shèlì*) emitting light was an **already attested reality** (*yǐrán shíshì*).

Here, the **Golden Light Pagoda** (*Jīnguāngtǎ*) contains **relics** (*shèlì*), and its **auspicious clouds and rainbow hues** (*xiángruì yá cǎi*) are revered by all, near and far—this is no fabricated tale. The realm’s **literati are unvirtuous** (*wénbùxián*), its **martial prowess is weak** (*wǔbùliáng*), and the ruler lacks the **Dao/Way** (*dào*). This leads to **demonic calamities** (*yāoniè*), **blood-soaked theft** (*yǔxuě dào bǎo*), and the **four quarters’ despair** (*sìfāng shīwàng*). The **Tang Monk** (*Tángsēng*) was summoned, yet the blame was unfairly cast upon the monks. How different is this from one who fails to **cultivate the heart and refine virtue** (*xīnxīn dídé*), yet still **complains of heaven and blames others** (*yuán tiān yóu rén*)?

They said: *"The **tyrannical ruler** (*hūn jun*), the **corrupt official** (*zāng guān*), **a thousand tortures and myriad oppressive demands** (*qiān bān kǎodǎ, wàn xiáng zhuīqiú*), **the previous two generations were already beaten to death—now they seize us for punishment.**"* All spoke of **excessive punishments and heavy taxation** (*fánxíng chóuniàn*), **greed and cruelty** (*tānxīn nǔshēng*), **rooting out even the faintest traces of dissent** (*zhīmàn zhūmǎ*), and **deep-seated corruption** (*jīxí jiùrán*)—the very stains that defile.

The **Tang Monk** (*Tángsēng*) asked: *"What hour is it now?"*
They replied: *"This hour has arrived,"*
*"Give me a fresh broom of **new bamboo** (*xīn dǎo*), so I may bathe and sweep away their sufferings."*

This speaks of **self-purification through renewal** (*zìxīn xīn rén*), layer upon layer. If one resolutely begins anew from this very day, as **Pan Cheng** (*Pán Míng*) swore in his **ritual bath** (*mùyù*), then the **lower cultivation will ascend to the highest** (*xiàxué shàngdá*), and the **defilements of the eyes will be cleansed** (*wūguì mùchú*).

As the **Disciple** (*Xíngzhě*) swept, he heard voices from the pagoda’s summit. Stepping upon the clouds to look, he saw within the **thirteen-layered Pagoda** (*shísān céng tǎ*), two demons seated at its core—one **warming rice** (*pánfàn*), the other with **a bowl and a pot** (*yīwǎn yīhú*), **drinking and gambling** (*cāiquán chījiǔ*). This describes **seeking the body’s treasures** (*jiǎnshēn huòbǎo*), yet one must **steadfastly trust and resolve with clarity** (*wùdúxīn míngjué*), not indulging in **idle doubts or hesitation**.

If one does not **choose one path and hold fast** (*bùzé yī gùzhí*), yet **repeatedly wavers in uncertainty** (*fǎnfù chíchí*), **endlessly probing without resolution** (*tàntāo wú dìng*), then within the heart, the two demons sit like guests at the pagoda’s core, **endlessly gambling and drinking** (*yīwèi húcāi*)—nothing but **foolish conjecture** (*húcāi*).

The **Disciple** (*Xíngzhě*) pressed forward, and the two demons said: *"This has nothing to do with us! There is one who stole the treasures elsewhere!"*
For **doubt and conjecture** (*cāiyí*) are the true afflictions, arising from **confused understanding** (*zhīshì zhuóluàn*).

They named **chaotic demons** (*Luànshíshān Bìbōtǎn*), **Sage Kings** (*Wànshèng Lóngwáng*) and **Sage Queens** (*Wànshèng Gōngzhǔ*), the **Nine-Headed Prince** (*Jiǔtóu fùmǎ*), and the **Nine-Leaved Spirit Mushroom** (*Jiǔyè Língzhī*)—all revealing the **Sage’s self-assertion** (*Sèngzì xióng*), **endless deliberations** (*wànlǜ duōsī*), **searching the heavens and the earth** (*jí dì sōutiān*), and **comprehensive scrutiny** (*wúbù zhōudào*). Yet within their own minds, they **flounder in doubt** (*bēnbēn bōbō*), **add to the suffering of the kalpas** (*tiānzǎ jiéjié*), and remain **utterly without certainty** (*quánwú dìngzhǔn*).

The two lesser demons were named *"Bēnpōér Bō"* and *"Zhēibōér Bēn"*, mirroring their frenzied, chaotic, and frantic demeanor.

*"Confessing that Sun Wukong’s divine powers are vast, yet he persistently seeks only the fault of those who stray from the Dao—*"*
For Wukong’s steadfastness in this very matter, he could discern the faults of those who were not steadfast, embodying the principle of **"using one to overcome myriad"** (*dé yī yǐ yù wàn*).

*"The Pilgrim said, ‘This fiend specializes in malevolent deeds,’"*—rightly perceiving the fault of those who lack steadfastness—
*"‘Locking the demon at the temple,’"*—rightly seeking the fault of those who stray from the Dao.

*"When the Tripitaka Master bowed before the king, and the monks petitioned on behalf of the wronged, explaining the circumstances of the tower’s cleansing and the capture of the thief, the king was startled by the differing appearances of the master and his disciples,"*—
for the king saw only the distinctions between **humans** (*rén*), **demons** (*shén*), and **all beings** (*zhòngshēng*), unable to seize the thief.

The Great Sage declared:
*"‘One cannot judge by outward form—if one loves the appearance of wealth and splendor, how could one ever capture a demonic thief?’"*
His words spoke of purifying the mind and heart, of **unimpeded great impartiality** (*kuòrán dàgōng*), **neither within nor without**, **unattached to forms**.

Once one clings to forms, then one is bound to assess based on outward appearance, while **private desires** (*sīyù*) flood the mind and **demonic thieves** (*yāozéi*) run rampant—how could one ever hope to seize them?
This duty, then, falls beyond the capacity of the Great Sage **without form** (*wúxiàng*)—who else could be fit for the task?

The Pilgrim’s grand palanquin and yellow parasol, borne by eight attendants, were **simply arranged** (*suǒ yóu tè jiǎn*) for ease of travel.

The Foolish One laughed and said:
*"‘Brother, you’ve won this round for yourself.’"*

「Indeed, this kind of duty and merit is bestowed upon me by my own nature, yet not wielded by the Lord **Zhūnyán**—this is what is called *heavenly virtue* (*tiānjué*), not *human virtue* (*rényuè*).

The two demons confessed:
*"‘There is a **Universal Sage Dragon King** (*Wànshèng Lóngwáng*), whose daughter is exceedingly charming,’"*—speaking of **inner chaos** (*nèi*) and **outer confusion** (*shì*), **reckless calculation** (*fēnsù*), **concealing emotions** (*yǐnqíng*) while **favoring partiality** (*piānzhǔ*) and **self-aggrandizement** (*zìdà*).
*"‘The **Nine-Headed Son-in-Law** (*Jiǔtóu Fùmǎ*) was summoned as a **divine match** (*zhāozhuì*), with **unrivaled divine powers** (*shéntōng wúdì*),’"*—speaking of **external distractions** (*wài*) and **turbulent thoughts** (*rǎosī*), **clinging to desires** (*fùyì jiǔchán*) while **boasting in excess** (*zìduō*).

*"‘The Dragon King and the Son-in-Law meet as companions,’"*—**heart-intent** (*xīnyì*) and **material cravings** (*wùyù*) **intermingle** (*jiāochéng*), **"first unleashing blood rain"** (*xiān xià xuèyǔ*), **soiling oneself to soil others** (*zìwū yǐ wū rén*).
*"‘Then stealing the **Sacred Relics** (*shè lì*),’"**—**obstructing others for self-gain** (*fáng rén yǐ lì jī*).

*"‘Now he illuminates the Dragon Palace, making the night as bright as day,’"**—**vaunting in private wisdom** (*zìqīn sīzhì*), claiming he can **pierce the dark** (*zhé yōu*).
*"‘He also steals the **Queen Mother’s Lingzhi** (*Wángmǔ língzhī*), nurturing treasures in the pond,’"**—**coveting celestial merit** (*tān tiān gōng*), **hoping in vain to become a Buddha** (*ān xī zuò fó*).

This kind of **cultivation of the self** (*xiūshēn*) is **frantic and exhausting** (*cùyòng bēnpó*), **in vain wasting the eons** (*wǎng láo bājié*). Hence, the guiding principle is stated: *"‘Binding demons and returning to the true path is cultivation of the self’"* (*fǔ mó guī zhèng nǎi xiūshēn*), meaning **true cultivation must be grounded in concrete action** (*qìshí xiàshǒu*), not mere words.

To **seize the thief and capture the king** (*qín zéi qín wáng*), who but the Great Sage could **restore order** (*guī*)? The **Eight Precepts** (*Bājiè*) declared: *"‘I’ll assist Brother in seizing them with ease.’"* This is indeed **true resolve to act** (*nǎi zhēn néng xiàshǒu*).

**Chapter Sixty-Three: Two Monks Dispel Demons, the Dragon Palace in Chaos, the Holy Ones Subdue Evil, and Gain Treasures**

The **Awakened One** (*Wùyī Zǐ*) said: **Dao/Way** is not **empty enlightenment** (*xūwù*), **cultivation is true merit** (*xiū shì shígōng*). **Action must be decisive** (*xiàshǒu yào zhuó*), **first restraining the eyes** (*xiān wéi zhì yǎn*).

The *Yīnfǔ Jīng* states: *"‘The mechanism lies in the eyes’"* (*qí jī zài mù*).
The *Zhèngdào Bǎizì Jué* proclaims: *"‘The Eternal must dwell in the eyes; in the eyes, the *qi* follows the essence’"* (*zhēn cháng xū zài mù, zài mù qì suí jīng*).
The *Yì* speaks of *"‘looking upward and downward’"* (*yǎng guān fǔ chá*).
The **Ancient Sage** (*Lǎo*) says: *"‘Observe the boundless, observe the marvelous’"* (*guān jiāo guān miào*).
The **Buddha** teaches *"‘still observation and quiescent observation’"* (*jìng guān zhǐ guān*), while the **Four Sages** (*Sìshèng*) emphasize *"‘Four Abstentions’"* (*sì wù*), with **vision** (*shì*) as their priority.
The **Crumpled Sage** (*Bāxiān*) writes of *"‘Three Essentials’"* (*sān yào*), with the **eyes** (*mù*) as their pivot.

Even the saying *"‘The Dao/Way is right before you, yet you fail to see its command’"* (*dào zài qiánmiàn, gù zé míng mìng*)—from ancient sages, immortals, **Buddhas and Patriarchs** (*fó zǔ*), **scriptures and classics** (*jīng zhuàn*), **poetry and prose** (*shī cí*)—all affirm the **eyes** (*mù*) as the **critical mechanism** (*yào jī*).

Alas, how **mortals squander heaven’s gift** (*shì rén gūfù tiānfù*), **emptily possessing two eyes** (*kòng jù liǎng yǎn*), yet **they become obstructions** (*zuò zhàng*), **clouding vision** (*zuò yì*), **willing to glance or peer** (*gān piē gān kuī*), **yet unable to gaze deeply or discern clearly** (*mò néng dòngzhǔ shú dǔ*)!

This is what **the Sacrificial Kingdom** (*Jìsài Guó*) called *"‘the fleshly eyes of a common mortal’"* (*ròuyǎn fān tāi*), yet who knows that **immortals, ancient Buddhas, and Bodhisattvas** (*púsà*) **are present in the very gaze** (*xiànzài qiánmiàn*)?

The Great Sage’s **Flame Eyes and Golden Pupils** (*Huǒyǎn Jīnqīng*)—why rely on these two demons to **open his vision** (*zuò yǎn*)? *"‘Take these two small demons and bind them as eyes’"* (*bǎ liǎng gè xiǎo yāo dài qù zuò yǎn*)—this **clearly demonstrates the first step in cultivation is to restrain the eyes** (*zhèng míng xiānshǒu xiàshǒu gōngfū, zài zhì liǎng yǎn yě*).

The Great Sage could **pluck a hair to forge a blade** (*mó máo kě biàn dāo*), yet why **uniquely transform his Golden Hoop Staff into a Precept Knife** (*jīngú bàng biàn yī jiè dāo*)? *"‘With one slice, sever the demon’s ear; with another, sever the demon’s lips. Cast them into the water and say, *‘I am the Heavenly Equal Great Sage here!*’*"* (*yī gē yāo ěr, yī gē yāo chún, piē zài shuǐ lǐ, shuō wǒ qí tiān dà shèng zài cǐ yě*)—this **shows the resolve to act with fixed principle as a Precept** (*shì yòng dòng wù zhí yīdìng zhī lǐ wéi jiè*), ensuring the **ears do not listen to demonic sounds** (*ěr wù zuò yāo tīng*), the **mouth does not speak demonic lies** (*kǒu wù zhāng yāo yán*), and the **two eyes, plunged into the verdant waves, remain unobstructed** (*liǎng yǎn rù yú bì bō ér wú bì*).

**Precepts for movement, for ears, for mouth** (*jiè dòng, jiè ěr, jiè kǒu*)—all are **Precepts for the eyes** (*zǒng shì jiè mù*). Only when the **eyes are truly restrained** (*zhì mù*), does the **Heavenly Equal Great Sage** (*zhēn yī shàngxiān zhī qí tiān dà shèng*) **manifest here** (*xiànzài cǐ yě*).

The two demons reported: *"‘Disaster is upon us!’"* (*shuō huòshì liǎo*), a **warning of restraint** (*gào jiè yě*).
The Son-in-Law laughed: *"‘Mount Tai is at ease!’"* (*shuō Tàiyuè fàngxīn*), **yet he does not know of restraint** (*bù zhī jiè yě*).

He brandished a **Moon-Crescent Claw** (*yuèyá chǎn*), crying: *"‘What Heavenly Equal Great Sage? I stole treasures—what concern of yours? Yet without cause, you injured my head, and now you disturb my sacred mountain!’"* (*shì shén yī bǐng yuèyá chǎn, jiào shì shén qí tiān dà shèng, wǒ tōu bǎobèi, yǔ nǐ hé gān? què wú gù shāng wǒ tóumù, yòu shàng wǒ bǎoshān sī nào!* )

The **"Bright"** is the power of the sun and moon. The clarity of the eyes is like that of the sun and moon. Now, the Son-in-Law wields the Moon-Crescent Claw—this is the **partial light of the hooked moon**, unable to discern the Heavenly Equal Great Sage, yet he **plunders treasures and misperceives the sacred mountain**, wrongly taking the **restraint of the eyes** as an injury to his own.

The Wayfarer spoke: *"This fiend is utterly devoid of reason! Though I do not accept the king’s favor, you stole his treasures—monks are my kin by shared qi. How could I not aid in clarifying the truth for them?"* For **establishing virtue** does not arise from gratitude, and **acting in power** is not solely for oneself—**without self, others, or living beings**, this is true clarity.

*"The Great Sage struck first with a rod, and Eight Rules followed with a spade. That monster has nine heads—all eyes."* Yet he cannot **discern the past to know restraint**, nor **look ahead to understand warning**; though his eyes are many, what good are they?

*"Its true form was revealed—utterly ferocious."* Eight Rules asked: *"What blood and qi have spawned this beast?"* The Dao states: *"Birds are beasts."* Though birds have two wings and beasts four legs, how can they be said to be the same? *The Rites* say: *"The gibbon can speak, yet it is not separate from birds and beasts."* Thus, beasts include those that speak. This nine-headed creature—what beast is it? Birds that speak, beasts that speak—this describes something **far beyond human kind**, beyond what a single bird or beast could name.

*"The monster spread its wings and flew askew, then from its midsection stretched another head, biting off Eight Rules."* It mimics **glimpsing obliquely, listening wildly, and biting madly**—completely contrary to the **"Four Avoidances"**, yet unaware of restraint, arrogantly claiming might.

*"The Wayfarer transformed into a crab, biting through the rope to rescue Eight Rules; then using a hidden-body technique, he stole the spade and passed it to Eight Rules."* The crab—**dissolving, scattering difficulty**. Hidden—**concealing, the aperture of revelation**. This is **liberation from entanglement**, guiding the nature of restraint to **stealthy action**.

*"Eight Rules charged into the palace, smashing gates and vessels, startling the old and young."* This is the **vigorous effort to eliminate the old and birth the new**. *"The Wayfarer suddenly saw the pursuit of Eight Rules and, midair, trod upon clouds and mist, striking the old dragon’s head to smithereens."* This is **clear-eyed and swift-handed**, seizing the thief’s heart with the **unmatched method of one overcoming ten thousand**. Xue Wenqing said: *"Private desires have long disturbed my heart—now I must decisively sever them all to preserve my serene, pure essence."* Here, one strike slays the old dragon of myriad saints, and the **Emerald Pool is no longer muddied by chaotic stones**.

Yet the old dragon of myriad saints acted without wisdom, **drowned in greed**. Though it possessed countless principles yet failed to discern right from wrong, though named "myriad saints," it was truly **a thief many times over**. To kill the thief’s heart—**easy to destroy**. But the nine-headed demon, seeing much yet acting as a thief, **relying on its cunning**—though called "nine-headed," it is truly **ten evils**. With many thieves, its evil is hard to eradicate. Thus, **a great heavenly decree must be issued**, like the **autumn’s stern killing of all things**, to punish and renew.

*"The Wayfarer suddenly heard howling winds and grim mists—closer inspection revealed the Second Prince manifesting with the Seven Sacred Brothers."* Two—**a pair**; seven—**the number of minor yin**, the time of autumn. *The Daoist Canon Song* says: *"The White Emperor moves qi, the Dao is renewed."* This is the **great hour for eliminating evil**, a **mighty strategy**, hence: *"This is a grand opportunity."*

Autumn’s qi kills, yet **Heaven’s benevolent heart operates within it—life within death**. Grass and trees wither and dissolve, yet all treasures mature. This is **Heaven’s punishment**, exterminating the stubborn, purifying the people’s resolve, as the virtuous uphold righteousness, **cutting off desires and cultivating virtue**—all paths to **cleansing and renewal**. The Dao values **self-knowledge and repentance**, only then gaining salvation. The Great Sage, having *"once been subdued and disliking confrontation,"* knew repentance.

*"Eight Rules requested the True Lord to halt, and with the Great Sage, they reminiscenced in the Second Prince’s camp through the night, awaiting dawn to battle."* This holds the meaning of **Ji Gong’s triple kindness and quadruple virtue**, waiting until morning.

Why did Eight Rules slaughter the dragon’s offspring, why did the hound bite off one of the nine-headed beast’s heads, yet the monster escape unharmed? Because **the wicked seed was fully uprooted**, the **den of the great rebel pacified**; killing one to **warn a hundred**, leaving open the door for self-renewal. The leader’s head must be struck—**to set an example**; some thieves may be pardoned—**to show utmost mercy**. *"Even now, a nine-headed remnant drips blood,"*—**executing fully to satisfy the moment is not as effective as prolonged punishment to warn the ages**. The hound’s growl from its jaws **declares judgment to clear the guilty**.

Stele, the ninth month’s hexagram, **hides treasure in the fire storehouse**. The scholar must **sever desires and cultivate sincerity**, **severely reproach oneself**, establishing **virtue, deeds, and words**, preserving the **few and rare** to differ from beasts—**thus**.

*"The Wayfarer transformed into the Son-in-Law’s form, reclaiming the two treasure chests,"*—**turning evil into truth, gaining two from one**. *"Eight Rules pounced on the princess, producing the dragon widow, and left her in the tower,"*—**restraining the demon’s allure while revealing its maternal heart, abandoning abandonment to preserve benevolence**. *"The king uncovered the indestructible relics and obtained the heavenly life-granting grass,"*—**resolving grievances, cherishing virtue, illuminating the obscure and clarifying the mysterious**.

「**Tripitaka** placed the Buddha’s treasure atop the tower, enshrined the **Dragon Widow** within its heart, and the **Wayfarer** declared: *"With the life-granting grass, I swept the thirteen-layered tower layer by layer, placed it in the bottle, and nurtured the indestructible relics—thus, restoring the old as if it were new."* This is **self-discipline and earnest practice**, each step firmly grounded in reality, each step a treasure from Heaven—how could it compare to those who speak of **emptiness and truth** in vain, pontificating on the tower’s forms without substance?

The realm is called **"Sacrifice and Strife"** (*jìsài*), revealing treasure yet lacking **virtue’s** cultivation; the temple is named **"Golden Radiance"** (*jīnguāng*), flashing brilliance yet failing to embody **tranquility**. Now, the **"Sacrifice and Strife"** realm’s **"Golden Radiance"** temple is renamed **"Subdued Dragon"** (*fùlóng*), where **mystery and insight** dwell in quietude, its light returning and reflecting—this is truly **great and enduring**.

As for the **ten thousand sages** and **nine-headed demons** who flaunt their private interpretations, engaging in **stealthy plunder** and **self-aggrandizement**, bestowing **sainthood** and **wisdom** upon themselves—what **benefit** do they truly bring?

Thus, the conclusion is drawn:
*"The demonic thorns extinguish the Heavenly’s joy,
The golden tower’s light shines upon the Earth—**truly**."*

**The Sixty-Fourth Chapter**:
*"Upright at the Thorny Ridge, **Taoist** Treats with Earnest Effort—
In the **Wood Immortal’s** Hermitage, the **Tripitaka** Discusses Poetry."*

**Taoist** said:
"The **Dao** is vast and unobstructed, the world’s path smooth and open—**originally**, there are no thorns. Thorns arise from within the human breast."

In every breast, thorns abound;
In every heart, thorns are found—
Yet thorns stretch across Heaven and Earth—
Why single out **Thorny Ridge** alone?

This passage **specifically** borrows **Thorny Ridge** to encompass all ages, past and present—**thus it is**. It borrows the **Wood Immortal’s** Hermitage discussion of poetry to encompass **all** who speak of the **Way**, from ancient times to now—**all** are thorns, **none** escape like this **poetic discourse**.

The *Nanhua* (*Zhuangzi*) says:
*"Lost in the radiant, lost in the radiant—it does not harm my path;
Retreating from the crooked, retreating from the crooked—it does not harm my feet."*
**This is the pain of thorns** filling the way ahead.

I **do not avoid** the **thorny** reputation—
I **borrow** the **Heavenly Pound’s** strength (*Tiān Pēng*)—
And **unify** the discourse: **All** grand writings and splendid phrases, adorned with **eloquence** and **rich imagery**, profound yet stirring, **exquisitely refined** and **unparalleled**—
Some **deliberately** craft obscurity to boast of **depth** and **mystery**;
Some **recklessly** speak against taboos to display **talent** and **emotion**;
Some **eloquently** argue with **endless twists**, rolling forth ceaselessly to **enrich debate**.

Yet **truly**, those who **do not connect** their words to **self-cultivation, heart, nature, and life’s essence**—**all** are thorns!
Not only this—**all** who write books and speak of **mystery**, **emptiness**, yet **cannot embody the Way** with **personal practice**, merely **wielding pens** and **playing with words**, repeating **heard teachings** and **rumored sayings**—though they **utter all** the **marvels of the Way**, worthy of **emulation** and **transmission**, it is but **parroted cleverness**, **mocking reverence**, all like the **Wood Immortal’s** poetic discourse—**the most severe thorns**!

Heaven **born** the **three teachings’** sages, each **guiding the world** with **divided heads**—
Yet their **origins** all stem from the **Dao of the Yellow River, Luo River, the Supreme Ultimate, and Yin-Yang’s creative transformation**.
Later generations, **Daoist, Buddhist, and Chan schools**, split into **sects and factions**, **endless schemes** emerging—
They **compete** in **discourse**, **flaunting interpretations**, **mutually slandering**—**all** are thorns **within thorns**!

The **Confucian teaching** upholds **central harmony and singularity**, **unimpeded fairness**—
*"Citizens as one’s kin, all things as one’s companion"*—
**This is the most fitting and unchanging principle**,
**No different** from **preserving the Middle, attaining steadfast wisdom**—
**Desireless yet with desire, selfless yet with self**—
How **diverse** is this from **Mencius’** *"Cultivating the Qi"*?

Yet **Confucius** praised **the Yellow Dragon** (*Yóu Lóng*), saying:
*"In the West, a sage will arise!"*
Later generations **clung** to **textual details**, unable to **embody and practice**—
They **must reject** *"mysterious"* words,
**Betraying** the **Dao of the Yellow Emperor’s** *"mystery"* yet **unaware**;
They **must denounce** the *"emptiness"* character,
**Betraying** **Confucius’** *"emptiness"* yet **oblivious**;
They **must doubt** *"True Yin"* (*Zhēnyī*) **Qi**,
**Ignoring** **Mencius’** *"nurturing Qi"* yet **unrecognizing**;
They **must oppose** *"True Emptiness"* (*Zhēnkōng*),
**Excluding** **Zi Si’s** *"self-sincerity"* yet **remaining silent**.

**To debate principles**, why **quibble over words**?
They **must deliberately** reject and **denigrate**,
Claiming **defense of the Sage’s Way**,
Yet **what of** *"unimpeded fairness"*?
Is this not **severing thorns** while **thorns** **pierce** the breast **most severely**?

According to the *Yellow Emperor’s Inner Canon* (*Huángdì Nèi Zhuàn*):
The **Daoist teaching** began with **Emperor of Primordial Beginnings** (*Yuānshǐ Tiānwáng*),
**Opening** the **chaotic void**, **establishing** the **three powers** (*sān cái*),
**Transforming** to **generate** the **ten thousand things**—
Till the **Zhou Dynasty**, when **Laozi** transmitted the *Dao De Jing* (*Moral Teachings*) in **five thousand words**.

According to the *Book of Zhou* (*Zhōushū*):
The **Confucian teaching** began with the **Yellow Emperor**,
Who **commanded** **Cangxu** to **create script**, beginning **writing and contracts**—
Till the **twenty-eighth year of King Jing of Zhou**, when **Confucius** was born,
And **proclaimed** its **teachings**.

According to **Emperor Wu of Liang’s** *Buddhist Lineage* (*Fó Tǒng*):
The **Buddha** was born in **Eastern India**,
At the time of **King Zhuang of Zhou’s** ninth year,
On the **eighth day of the fourth month**—
From **Emperor Ming of Han’s** *Yongping* eighth year,
The **Dharma** began to **enter China** and **prosper**.

It has been **investigated** that the people of **Eastern India** are **naturally robust**, fond of **battle and slaughter**,
Considering **death in war** as **auspicious**, **peaceful passing** as **inauspicious**.
**Laozi**, upon leaving **Hangu Pass**,
**Transformed** the **Floating Image** (*Fútú*) **method**,
Ordering **internal and external purification**, **no harm to the body**,
And naming it **"Floating Image"** (*Fútú*).

In the **ninth year of King Zhuang of Zhou**, on the **eighth day of the fourth month**,
The **fixed stars** vanished, **falling like rain**—
That night, **Shakyamuni Buddha** was born,
Capable of **practicing** **Bo Yang’s** **Dao** (*i.e., Laozi’s teachings*),
And the people **followed** him, calling him **"Buddha"** (*Fó*).

**Buddha** is what China calls **"God"** (*Shén*),
The next rank is **"Bodhisattva"** (*Púsà*).
His realm **teemed with life**, **no widows, orphans, or lonely souls**—
Thus, people **wished to be reborn** there.

Then **Buddhist teaching** **originated from China**, spreading **westward**,
And **returned westward** to **re-enter China**—
**This is not a foreign teaching**!

**Laozi** **was truly the Buddha’s ancestor**,
The **Buddha truly performed Laozi’s teachings**—
**God is Buddha, Buddha is God**—
Only **different in pronunciation** between **East and West**!

**Confucianism** **originated from the Yellow Emperor’s** **script**,
**Revealing** the **marvelous Dao** of **three powers’** transformation and **generation**—
The **Yellow Emperor** was truly the **Confucian ancestor**,
**Confucius** merely **proclaimed** its **teachings**—
Yet **how** did later generations **consider Yellow Lao** as **contrary to Confucianism**?

The root of all confusion lies in ignorance of the **three teachings’** origins—
And those who bear **thorns in their breast** are the most extreme!

The **Buddha** is **God**; **immortals** are **God**.
**Perfect sincerity**—**ineffable and divine**—is what we call **God**.
Though all are called **God**, yet to claim **Confucianism** differs from the **two schools**,
Is this not to **plant thorns** within oneself?

The **Celestial Emperor** loved the **people** He created and transformed,
And specially begot the **sacred Son of Heaven** to govern and nurture them;
He specially begot the **three teachings’ great sages** to reveal the **principles of creation**,
To exhaust the **methods of teaching and transformation**,
And to refine the **qi and fate** of countless ages.
Born in the same era, yet guiding along separate paths—
The **Celestial Emperor** truly **oversaw them all**.

I have heard that **Zhuangzi** followed the **open lineage of the revealed tradition**,
That **Yashodhara**, wife of **Shakyamuni**, and **Rahula**, his son,
When ascending, wept and lamented bitterly—
How could this compare to today’s **widows and lonely souls**?

Later generations despised the **corruptions** of the **two schools**,
Yet failed to despise the **corruptions of Confucianism** as well.
Clinging rigidly, they scrutinized **single phrases or characters**,
And **slandered the sages**, defying **Heaven**—
Their own breasts bristled with **thorns**, yet they sought to **prune the world’s thorns**?

Now’s **Confucian scholar**, collecting **fleeting arts**,
Aspiring to **official rank and wealth**,
Their **initial thoughts and motives** are but **merchants’ schemes for profit and gain**—
They know not what **nature and life** are,
Nor what **benevolent governance** entails.
Their **knowledge and abilities** diverge utterly from the **scriptures’ teachings**—
The **heterodoxies of Confucianism** surpass those of the **two schools**,
Yet they fail to **prune the thorns**—
I do not know where this path will end.

Thus, I must speak of **thorns**,
To aid **Tianpeng** like a **myriad-legged insect** in battle.

If this book speaks of **demons and marvels**,
Men will see it as **thorns sprouting at every step of the Dao**—
Yet I see it as **orchids and osmanthus planted at every stride**.
The **discerning** will gather them.

At the **beginning**, the monks of **Fulong Temple** knew neither **advance nor retreat**,
And presumptuously hoped to join—
They do not grasp the **abundance of thorns** along the Dao.

The **traveler**, when the **tiger transforms**, must **halt and dwell**—
There is a **"Great Man’s tiger-transformation"**,
Unrecognized by the common crowd.

At **Jingjie Ridge**, one cannot proceed further—
As the poem says:
*"Everywhere brambles twine around ancient trees,
Layer upon layer, vines coil about the thick branches.
Who among men does not encounter thorns?
Yet who has seen the **Western Lands’ thorns** so vast?"*
This clearly states that the **West** too is thick with **thorns**—
It refers to **empty talk of poetry and prose**, like those at **Muxian An**.

The **Eight Precepts** say:
*"If you wish to cross, depend on me."*
The blame lies in one’s **own power to prune the thorns**.

The body stretches twenty *zhang* long,
The handle thirty *zhang*—
Both hands wield the hoe,
Left and right, clearing the way.

For the body holds the **Two Principles**,
The hands grasp the **Three Powers**,
Uniting the **Five Phases** to illuminate the **Precepts’ essence**—
Striving to prune the thorns with resolve.

Thus it is said:
*"From now on, the Eight Precepts break through,
Piercing the Western Path—smooth and clear."*

At an open stretch, suddenly met
By the **Eighteen Elders’** friends discussing poetry.
**Naive Master**, **Lofty Scholar**, and **Wisp-Clearing Hermit**
Recite verses all revealing their true nature—
Their meaning is self-evident.

Only they say:
*"We are not the ‘Four Sage Ministers,’
But the ‘Four Operatives’ of the deep mountains."*
To show that those who claim to cultivate the Dao
Yet flee the world’s clamor,
Feigning seclusion and lofty detachment,
Speaking grandly of **nature and life**
While utterly lacking substance—
All are **Confucian scholars’ Cao Cao**.

All deceitful pretenders
Must seek to associate with sincere gentlemen
To lend their names credibility,
Thus they contrive to ensnare **Tripitaka**
And engage him in **Chan** and Dao discourse.

**Tripitaka** responds with common teachings,
But when he says:
*"I’ve questioned **True Essence** at **Yuan Shi’s** anvil,
Realized **Muni’s** methods,"*
And again:
*"Who at the **Mystic Pass** can cross?
I’ve long cultivated **Great Awakening Chan**—
Only those with **root and resolve** may awaken,"*
This is the **Dao’s true truth**,
Not empty **Chan**—**Buddha is Immortal**.

The **Four Elders** say:
*"The **Venerable Monk** grasps the **Chan’s root essence,"*
A fitting observation.

**Wisp-Clearing Hermit** declares:
*"Though **Chan** is still, though **Law** is passed,
One must settle the **nature**, purify the **heart**—
All for the **Great Awakening’s true Immortal**,
Ultimately attaining the **Path of No-Birth."*
This strikes the mark.

When they say:
*"Our **Mystic** is far different,"*
They mean **nature’s original essence**—
Unbroken, unharmed,
Needing no cultivation,
Returning to verify the Dao.

This is **substance without cultivation**,
**Knowledge without practice**—
Externally boasting of lofty talk,
Internally lacking true benefit—
Thus they are **"Operatives."**

When they say:
*"We were born firm and solid,"*
Such words merely describe their **nature**,
With no profound meaning.

As for:
*"The Dao originates in China,
Yet they seek verification in the West—
Wasting grass-sandals for nothing,
Unclear what they’re searching for.
Stone lions’ hearts carved out,
Fox spirits’ saliva seeping to the bone.
Forgotten roots, they meditate in vain,
Chasing **Buddha’s fruit**—
All riddles of **Jingjie Ridge’s brambles**,
Empty **Luo-luo** jokes."*

They also say:
*"One must examine the face before them,
Within stillness, life unfolds.
Bottomless bamboo basket drawing water,
Rootless iron tree blooming.
Chained to **Lingbao Peak’s** foot,
Returning to the **Yahui Assembly** on dragon-clouds."*
Each word shatters the **Chan’s empty void**,
Drawing out the **mystic essence**.

The core of *Journey to the West* lies here—
**Jingjie Ridge’s** entire framework!

**Lofty Scholar** says:
*"Wisp-Clearing’s words reveal too much.
The **Venerable Monk** need not cling."*

This is how the **Master** uses their mouths
To reveal the **true Dao’s profound truth**.

Once the **true meaning** is reached,
One must know **false learning**.

The **Four Operatives** gather for **Moonlit Wandering**,
Not for **lectures on cultivation**;
The **Four Elders** dwell with **wood and stone**,
Only becoming **naked ghostly messengers**.

Polishing verses, crafting odd phrases,
Boasting of **literary skill**;
Taking pride in **reclusion’s leisure**,
Drifting in forests and valleys—**self-abandoned**.

Formless, useless,
Arrogant yet ordinary,
Pure in speech, corrupt in deed,
Unaware of death—
How pitiful!

Some mistakenly claim **True Cultivation**,
Hoarding **A-Jiao** to refine **yin essence**;
Jealous of the upright, they unleash **Red Lotus**,
Breaking **Precepts**—
This is how **Moon-Playing Poet** and **Peach Immortal** originate,
Exposing their deceit.

**Tripitaka** says:
*"You are all monstrous creatures,"*
All **Operatives**.

At first, they discussed **Dao** with **elegance**,
Now they lure with **beautiful women**—
Clearly exposed, no need for further explanation.

At dawn, the demons scatter in alarm,
The **Master and disciples** trace the roots—
They are **cypress, cedar, pine, and bamboo** turned monstrous,
Clearly the **Dao’s and Buddha’s thorns’ essence**,
Yet they feign **scholarly pretension**.

**Eight Rules** strives mightily,
Crushing them all—
How splendidly clear!

Students, beware—
Do not abandon **life-and-death’s true practice**
For empty **moral discourse**,
Nor compose **useless poetry**,
Content to be the **Four Operatives** of **Muxian An**.

**Lu Xiangshan** said:
*"Tell my fellow travelers—
Do not let words corrupt **Heaven’s order."*
**Zou Nan Gao** also said:
*"Tell the young at the window—
Do not waste your youth on **commentary and prose."*
One meaning.

**Chapter 65**
*The Demon’s Feigned Small Pure Land*
*The Four Disciples All Suffer Great Calamity*

「The **Master** said:
*"In the previous section, the demon assumed a lofty, boastful guise, relying on innate talent, yet neglecting **cultivation and practice**—only fostering idle **lectures and debates**, composing hollow **poetry and prose**, dwelling in secluded, leisurely places to appear as a **strange figure**. Here, the demon feigns the **Buddha’s** name, seizing **dharma and reason** to deceive, adorns its outward form with cunning artifice, and entices many of the **good** into confusion—none can distinguish it, though it appears **authentic**. The former harms itself and others in a minor way; this one harms others to the point of **destroying life and extinguishing nature**, even using **scholarship** to slaughter the **future generations of the world**—thus, it is the **great calamity**!

*"The **Tripitaka Master** has escaped the **thorny entanglements** of the **Ugly Peak**, now gazing upon lofty mountains that touch the **Heavenly realm**. Descending the pass to the west, he suddenly beholds a radiant **auspicious aura**, with swirling **colorful mists**, and **palaces and pavilions** faintly glimpsed through the **temple bells**. The **pilgrim** examines it closely—within the **auspicious signs**, there are also ominous **qi** and **portents**. Though it is **Léiyīn Temple**, the **path and way** are clearly **erroneous and misguided**.

*"The **Dao’s** true or false nature each bears its own **qi and portents**. The **true** flourishes from the **root of the heart**, while the **false** is mere outward adornment. The **qi** of the **rooted heart** is like flowers growing naturally from a tree—spirit vibrant, arising from **authentic virtue**. The **qi** of **adorned appearance** is like **clipped paper flowers**—colors dull and lifeless, born from **artifice and contrivance**. The distinction is clear: those with **clear insight** can discern it at once. Hence, the **pilgrim** observes carefully and knows this **path is flawed**.

*"Léiyīn Temple," though called such, is marked as **‘small’**—a **clear indication** of the **petty**. The **Tripitaka Master** cannot see its **smallness**, nor its **falsehood**, so he mistakes it for the **Buddha’s** pure **dharma-ground**, leading his **disciples** to bow in reverence. The **pilgrim**, however, sees its **smallness** and **falsehood**, and thus wields his staff, shouting:
*"How dare you falsely invoke the **Buddha’s** name and tarnish the **pure virtue** of the **Tathāgata**?"*
He **denounces the crime** and **demands justice**, with **rightful authority** and **proper words**. Yet the **Tripitaka Master** has already bowed and fallen into the **trap**—even the wisest cannot undo this now!

*"He was left behind with a **golden gong**, head and feet included. All was bound within it. The **Master and disciples** were seized together, their **bodies and minds** both ensnared. The **Buddha’s** form revealed itself as **demonic**, and the **Arahat** were all **minor demons**."*

This is precisely how the **petty’s Dao** is small yet its **demonic magic** vast—straying into false paths, how could one not waste their **heart of seeking the Way**? The **verse is plain**; no need for **explication**.

*"What is this **‘golden gong’**?"*

「“**Gong** (鐙) and “**Nao** (挠)” share the same meaning. Zhuangzi said, *“Heaven generates all things, none sufficient to **nao** (挠) the heart”*—meaning one must remain unyielding in their **Dao/Way** and never bend to falsehood.

The hearts of the **petty** are crooked, yielding to desires, steadfast yet unmovable, clinging to evil until the end, obstinate in their delusions, utterly dark with no glimmer of insight. This is what is called *“the lowest of the low cannot be swayed”*—like a **golden gong** (金鐙) sealed tight, unable to be pried open or emit a sound. Thus, the **pilgrims** were trapped inside it, in a black void from which they could not escape. Its **power** could even **spread and penetrate** like molten gold, rising to the high or sinking to the low, expertly sealing off all exits. So when I stood in the **high**, it used the **high** to constrain me, and I could not move; when I stood in the **low**, it used the **low** to constrain me, and I could not move. It was all because of its **obdurate, unyielding heart**—no crevice or opening to allow a person to turn or shift.

*"The **pilgrim** became **immovable like a drill**, the **minor demons**’ **power** too weak to **lift** it; the **Jade Emperor** dispatched the **Twenty-Eight Constellations** with spears, swords, knives, and axes—**bearing, lifting, prying, and levering**—yet the **golden gong** remained **coldly unmoved**."* This is precisely *“Heaven generates all things, none sufficient to **nao** (挠) the heart”*—its **shackles** were deep, its **fortress** unbreakable.

The **Golden-Headed Dragon** (亢金龙) said: *“Gazing upon this treasure, it must surely be a **wish-fulfilling** object.”* Its **black heart** mirrored its **wicked intentions**, yet its **authority and magical power** were enough to **ensnare** beings.

If a **gentleman** (君子) were unluckily trapped, he must **hold fast to the principle of moderation and rectitude**, **borrowing the strength of the Monkey and the Ox** (猿引犄角) to escape calamity, **concealing his light and entering its darkness** (韬其明而就其暗). Otherwise, none would avoid **disintegration of limbs** or **loss of life**.

Then the **Golden-Headed Dragon** transformed its horn into a **needle-sharp tip**, sliding it along the **seam of the gong** (钹口合缝), using a **force of a thousand pounds** before it could pierce through.

The *“seam”* (合缝) refers to the **central junction** of the two **gongs**, where their **mouths** open and close. The *“Golden-Headed”* (亢) is neither **flattery** nor **arrogance**, but rather **balanced strength**—neither lowly nor lofty—speaking of **upholding the principle of moderation**, yet its **power surpasses its form**, its **mind as fine as a hair**.

*"The **pilgrim** drilled the **seam** with its horn tip; its body shrank to the size of a **mustard seed**, crouching within the hole to emerge."* This is the **Dao/Way of subtle adaptability and emptiness**, **meticulous research**, **not boasting of its own abilities**, and **relying on the horn**—**discerning the openings within openings**, **treading beyond the heavens** (踏破天外天).

*"It drew out the **Golden Hoop Staff**, smashing the **golden gong**."* With one enlightenment, a thousand illusions dissolved; with one defeat, the **Four Great Elements** were shattered like **minced meat**. How could one rely on the **petty’s Dao/Way**? Even this **old demon** could not help but awaken in terror!

Yet its **ambiguous, black heart** could not be swayed or bent, though it could be **recognized and broken**. As for its **theft of the sayings *“All beings are my kin”** and *“All things are shared with me”***, this was the **ultimate truth of the Dao/Way**, beyond what even **humans and gods** could **ensnare or escape**. Hence, there was the **Post-Heaven Bag** (后天袋) as the **greatest calamity**.

The **demon** declared: *“This place is called **Little Western Heaven** (小西天), for I have attained the **true fruit** (正果), and Heaven bestows upon me this **treasure-hall and precious pavilion**.”* It **claimed to be the **Yellow-Browed Old Buddha** (黄眉老佛), **displaying its powers** to **wager a bet and challenge**, vowing to *“beat you all to death, then go to the **Tathāgata** to fetch scriptures—**the fruit is truly mine!**”* It sought to **make itself the ancestor**, **arrogantly inflating its own greatness**, yet it knew not that it was a **petty thief**, **usurping false titles**.

*"During the battle, the old demon untied its **old white cloth sack** (旧白布搭儿) and **bundled up all the holy ones** (圣众) within it."* Its **rageful heart** surged, and it **dragged many into its net**.

*"Each was bound tightly, no distinction between good and evil—all were cast to the ground."* It sought to **entrap them in its prisons**.

The **Buddha-Dharma** knows **no discrimination**, **no division between good and evil**—it is the **universal love**.
