Ah! The cunning **flower-shoe demon** slips free from the snare—truly dreadful!

In the **Eighty-Second Chapter**, *"The Maid Seeks Yang"* and *"The Primordial Spirit Guards the Dao"*, Master Wu Yi remarked: This passage cleverly uses the *"Errant Spirit Falls into the Bottomless Pit"* to stage a **sutra**-like performance, with hidden subtleties at every turn.

Those with innate **Daoist** essence can silently guide their **spirit** and **mind**—the **Penglai** and **Eluyuan** lie before them.

Alas! Though the **Soul Mountain** assembly gathers a thousand **Buddhas**, which one can escape this very place?

When **practitioners** reach this juncture, they must swiftly gather their **spirit** and **mind**, resolutely seeking a path beyond. They must devise every means to find an exit.

Here lies a **secret Vajra**—the *"river-crossing ferry, the ladder to heaven"*! The **Ancestral Master** dared not reveal it, so it remains concealed within these **nine-nine** cycles, returning to their beginning.

The **true mechanism** leaps forth, yet is held back—just as **Ziyu** said: *"The capable follow it,"* and here it is!

The *Cansong Contract* states:
*"The river maid, most refined and spirit-like,
Encountering fire, she takes flight, leaving no trace.
Ghosts and dragons hide, none know her whereabouts.
To subdue her, yellow sprouts must be the root."*

The annotation reads: *"Yellow sprouts—i.e., rabbit marrow, the gold within water."*

The **flower-shoe demon** embodies the **Kun** trigram. **Kun** obtains the **Qian** central line to form **Kan**; **Qian** transforms the **Kun** central line to become **Li**. The maid’s pursuit of **Yang** is the natural interplay of **yin** and **yang**.

Those who study the **Dao** must retrieve the **Yang** from within **Kan** and solidify the **Yin** in **Li**, achieving an indestructible **true-gold** body.

Yet once **Yang** is ensnared in **Kan**, it is as if one has fallen into the **Bottomless Pit**—how then can one emerge?

For centuries, those who profane this **sacred text** have failed to grasp what the **Bottomless Pit** truly is—**sin**! **Sin**!

The **Kan** hexagram is void above and void below—clearly, a mountain hollowed with no bottom.

The lecture begins with *"two female demons at the well drawing water."* The well is **Kan**; the demons are the **crawfish**. Two **yin** lines are plainly shown.

Then it says: *"On their heads, they wear a tall, one-foot-two-to-three-inch-high **‘mishu’** (髟狄) knot—quite unfashionable."* These two lines reveal the **secret essence** of refining the **gold elixir**—though the **Daoist Master** has exposed it, mortals fail to recognize.

In **Daoist** practice, one’s **qi** and **nature** must be gentle and yielding—no rigid boundaries. This aligns with **Laozi’s** *"teeth firm, tongue soft"* and the **Dao of War**: *"The virtuous prevail."*

The **practitioner** says: *"Gentleness conquers all; harshness falters even a step."* Again invoking **willow** and **sandalwood** as metaphors, deeply grasping **Laozi’s** meaning.

*"Two demons come here to draw this **yin-yang** copulating water, setting a pure feast"*—the emphasis on *"good"* reveals that without **yin-yang** union, male remains male, female remains female, and *"good"* cannot arise.

*"Male and female copulate, all things transform and generate."* The **Daoist** path is complete.

The **bewildered**, reading this, mistakenly assume it refers to **sexual alchemy**—the farther they stray, the harder it is to find salvation.

When the **practitioner** leaps in, he plunges into *"a fine place indeed—this is a **Tian** realm of bliss!"*

Yet within, one must grasp it firmly—never *"lose true Yang, fall into the wheel of rebirth, and never rise again."* Swiftly seek an exit; do not forget, for it plainly teaches that **birth** comes from **life**, urging **respect** and **truth-preservation**, and to urgently find the **transcendent** union—never abandoning the original path.

**Tripitaka** says: *"I’ve forgotten the way in."*

This reminds all to seek the **ultimate cause** of escape from the very path they entered.

The **practitioner** says: *"Do not speak of forgetting the way—this cave is strange, not meant for easy entry or exit. You came by diving headfirst and descending; now to save you, you must dive from below and ascend."*

Still, *"who knows if you have the skill to dig your way out?"*

Alas!

The **Daoist Master** speaks in subtle, cold tones, pointing to the **sutras** of transcending the world—seeming like a descent to ascend, yet truly not so.

The **discerning eye** understands this here: one may grasp the **Dao** of *"following the natural order to become a sage, or opposing it to forge the elixir."*

The **practitioner** devises a way out, requiring within the wine cup to *"pour forth the blossom of joy"*—transforming into a **worm** to enter the belly, within the **liquid gold** to employ **alchemical techniques**.

Who knows? The blossom has already scattered—nothing can be done.

When the female seeks but the male does not respond, only the female’s heart holds *"Brother, the marvelous one"*—like **Yang** above and **Yin** below, the **Hexagram of *Nòu*** (☱), yet an empty joy. It is the image of *"the eagle soaring, its talons wheeling—upsetting tables and overturning dishes, smashing bowls and plates."*

The **practitioner**, unable to escape, must turn and reenter, shifting to the **strategy of the red suit** (♥), teaching **Tang Seng** the **secret alchemical precepts** of false union.

Later, their words and intentions align, their bond like *"fish and water"*—the **demon** then reveals the **dharma** of *"fruit ripening on the branch, the interplay of Yin and Yang, Sun and Moon."* With tender emotions deepening, the **practitioner** acts in time—*"a single somersault, and he flips into the belly."*

Now the female leads, the male follows—truly *"Brother, the marvelous one"*—as **Yin** above and **Yang** below, the **Hexagram of *Tāi*** (☳), a real belly. The **demon** says: *"Sun Wukong, how did you contrive to burrow into my stomach?"* The **practitioner** replies: *"It’s nothing strange—just eating your six-leaf liver and lungs, the three-hair heart, and all your five **zàng** organs clean, turning you into a **hollowed-out gourd spirit**!"* Within the belly, he *"punches, kicks, braces his limbs, and aligns the four directions,"* nearly tearing apart the skin-sack.

The **demon**, unable to endure the pain, collapses in the dust. When lifted, she says: *"My belly already holds a man! Quickly send this monk out!"*

What meaning do the **scholars** find in this spectacle?

The *"Awakening to Truth"* (悟真篇) states:
*"Though fruit grows on the branch, it must ripen in time—
the child in the womb, how could it differ?"*

This clearly enacts the scene.

One may also perceive the **alchemical marvel** of *"condensing the Five Phases"* and their role in **elixir cultivation**.

When the lesser demons all came to carry him, the monk inside cried out: *"Who dares lift me? If you must, then you yourself must send my master out!"*—a display of innate, unassisted **Dao** power, beyond mortal strength.

The demoness said: *"So long as the bright moon lingers over the Five Lakes, what need is there to fear no place to cast the golden hook? Send this wretch out, and I’ll seek another head elsewhere."* With a leap, she vanished in a flash of light, straight to the cave’s mouth.

Just then, the clatter of weapons rang out—*clink-clank, clink-clank*—in chaotic battle. The monk said: *"That’s Eight Rules wielding his *pá*! Call him once."* The Master then called: *"Eight Rules!"*

Hearing this, Eight Rules replied: *"Master Sand! The Teacher has emerged!"*

To call Eight Rules was to gauge the **fire’s readiness**; to summon Master Sand was to attend to the **refinement’s intent**.

Ah! Just as the verse states:
*"The mind-monkey enters the cave to subdue the demon,
Earth and wood unite at the gate to welcome the holy monk."*

This scene reveals the **alchemical subtlety** of the **elixir emerging from the furnace**.

The three share a single purpose—calculating perils, guarding against danger, ensuring the **principal and auxiliary** roles are fulfilled without neglect.

The **"Maiden of Vermilion"** seeks **yang** as the **Great Dao**,
while the **"Original Spirit"** guards the **Way** with hidden teachings.

All mortals enter her cave—
those who preserve their **True Nature** without drowning,
who calculate their own escape—who can do so?

The lost do not probe the **yin-yang** from the heart,
nor seek a teacher’s guidance to attain the **Supreme Vehicle**.
Instead, they mistake **copulation and domination** as the path,
and thus sow the seeds of **Hell**, never to escape in ten thousand kalpas!

Beware! Tremble!

The preceding chapter laid the roots of those who fall into the cave;
this chapter reveals the **karma and consequences** of those who emerge.

**Chapter 83: The Mind-Monkey Recognizes the Elixir’s Core**
**The Vermilion Maiden Returns to Her True Nature**

The Master of Awakening said:
The **Dao of transcending the world** lies in subduing the **golden essence**.
If one knows the method of subjugation yet lacks cultivation,
and fails to grasp its truth,
then one cannot return to the origin and restore the fundamental.

When **principle and desire** wage war,
they remain separate from **True Nature**,
inevitably **soaring and unrestrained**—
wild and rampant—
leaving one ungrounded.
This is what is meant by:
*"Cultivation insufficient, no square nor round."*

The **Tang Monk’s** repeated fall after escape
arises from incomplete understanding
and untrue attainment.

Thus, the essence of seeking the **elixir**
demands meticulous inquiry into the roots,
to recognize the **core of the elixir**.

The **Celestial Master** feared the world would mistake falsehood for truth,
so he revealed this passage
to discern its subtle profundity.
If one views it merely as *"water’s end and clouds’ ascent,"*
a sudden turn after exhaustion—
merely a literary flourish—
then the author’s **benevolent intent** is buried.

The **Sutra** states:
*"Gold returns to its original nature—
only then may it be called the **Returning Elixir**."*

When the practitioner forces the **peach** into his belly,
compelling the **monkey** to carry the monk out,
it is not from **voluntary harmony** or **natural liberation**.
Thus, upon emerging, he **reassembles his forces**,
engages in chaotic battle,
leaving the **Tang Monk** alone and unsupported—
this violates the **principle of harmonious integration**.
Since the **gold** does not return to **True Nature**,
but **water, fire, earth, and wood** contend,
the **gold** is a false form—
first misplaced on the **left**,
now misplaced on the **right**.
Hence, the **flowered shoe** on the **right foot**
again shifts and cannot settle.

The **essence of the child** is the substance of the **Kan (Abyss)**.
When it emerges from the earth,
it is also called the **Earth-Surging Lady**.
Have you not heard of the **Earth-Surging Golden Lotus**?
The **Golden Lotus** is the **Lady’s delicate toes**,
adorned with **flowered shoes**.

The **shoes**, clinging to the **Kun (Receptive, earth)**, walk—
this is **returning to True Nature**.
When cast off and rising into emptiness,
it is **soaring and unrestrained**—
the **gold** does not return to **True Nature**.

The **left** belongs to **yang**, the **right** to **yin**.
Previously, **excessive yang** spun left—
yet the **left was false**.
Now, **excessive yin** spins right—
yet the **right is false**.

**"Shoes"**—a **play on words**.
How can **left and right** scatter?
Thus, one cannot **stand firmly on the earth**,
cannot remain steady.

「Yet the **Xīnniǔ (Maiden of Beauty)** is my true nature, so why call her a **démon (妖)**?

**Returning to True Nature** is the **True Essence (真精)**,
while **departing from True Nature** becomes the **Démonic Essence (妖精)**.
**Returning to True Nature** makes me **whole in truth**,
while **departing from True Nature** turns me into a **démon’s essence**,
and I fall into its snare.

*"The Tang Monk was seized and held in one embrace,
his reins severed—both man and horse were dragged away."*
All because he could not subdue the **True Gold (真金)**,
his roots were not firm, and his reins were broken.

The **Tang Monk’s steed’s** strength in its hooves
was never greater than the **Démonic Essence’s flowered shoes**,
so it must be tamed and made its foundation.

The **Great Sage** saw the half-severed reins,
and felt helpless sorrow welling up—
tears streamed from his eyes.
He turned swiftly, with fierce resolve,
seeking the origin’s root,
only then could he find true remedy.

Seeing the **Golden Character Tablet (金字牌)**,
he recognized his father’s and elder brother’s names,
and thus knew the **Dan (丹, cinnabar)**—
was he not filled with joy?

If his father **returned to True Nature**,
where could his son go?
He **clutched the Tablet** and ascended to the **Heavenly Palace (天堂)**,
to **report to the Jade Emperor (玉帝)**,
and thus his kin could be saved.

This is the **strategy of capturing the thief by seizing the king’s hand**,
the **key to tracing origins and uncovering roots**.

When the **Jade Emperor** commanded **Tai Bai (太白, the Great White Star)** to summon **Li Tianwang (李天王, the Heavenly King of the Li clan)** to the **court of judgment (对簿)**,
the Heavenly King failed to recognize her as a **female**,
and **Ne Zha (哪吒)** revealed her lineage—
*"The thief from the Sacred Mountain stole the Buddha’s fragrant flowers and lamps."*
Only then did he realize she was his **sworn sister (结拜)** by fate.

Yet how could she be a **sworn sister**,
if she was born of his clan?
The Heavenly King bears the **Li (李) surname**,
which belongs to **wood (木)**.
By the **wood’s children (木之子)**, **fire (火)** is meant,
so how could his daughter be of **gold (金)**,
with a **golden nose and white fur (金鼻白毛)**?

A **golden form throughout her body**?
He did not know that **gold in water (水中之金)** can subdue wood,
yet **gold** also **engenders water (生水)** to nourish wood;
that **fire in wood (木中之火)** can restrain gold,
yet **fire** also **engenders earth (生土)** to give rise to gold.

The grudge came first, then the bond—
thus she became his **sworn sister** by fate.

The *Awakening to Truth* says:
*"The Gold Prince was once the Eastern House’s son,
sent to the Western Neighbor to take root and be reborn.
Recognized and called back to his ancestral home to be nurtured,
paired with a radiant maiden as kin by fate."*
Within lies a hidden marvel of inversion—
words cannot fully capture its depth.

Why call her **"Half-Observed Guanyin"**?
Guanyin is **water and moon**—
without water, no moon’s fullness.
The radiant maiden is but **gold in water**—
is she not half?

Now, *"the essence lies in the southeast black horn with its hidden aperture,"*
and the gold returns to its original nature in the Eastern House—
just as the nuptial chamber’s candles glow,
**black qi swirling, faint fragrance perfuming the air**—
the moment of perfect union.

*"The Pilgrim found Tang Sanzang and his horses and baggage,"*
and the **foot-strength** was already prepared.
This old demon, with no path left,
knelt in submission—
the Heavenly King and Prince escorting the demon back to the palace.

From now on, Tang Sanzang and his four disciples
may ride horses, carry burdens, and march onward along the Great Path.

Thus, those refining the **elixir** must first subdue and temper the **golden essence**,
enduring unyielding, unbroken—
only then can the **foot-root** stand firm,
and only then may they advance westward.

Now, these sentient beings drown in the **sea of desire** without repentance,
burn in the **pit of wrath** without cleansing,
fall into the **trap of greed** without complaint,
plunge into the **abyss of fame** without awakening,
sleep drunk in the **moat of death** without waking,
stray on the **path of delusion** without returning,
entangled in the **net of glory** without escape—
all blinded to their true nature, sinking into emptiness,
with no end in sight.

Alas!

The previous chapter concealed the true gold in **Zhenhai Temple**,
this one reveals the **golden position** and **golden furnace** as recognizing the **elixir’s essence**.
What is transcended: the **golden lotuses** on either side;
what is subdued: the **white-furred golden nose**.
Speak of this inner true gold—
it is the **elixir’s supreme secret**, not to be overlooked.

---
**Eighty-fourth Chapter**
*"The Unquenchable Flame of Gajidhara’s Great Awakening"*
*"The Law-King’s Natural Perfection"*

A disciple of enlightenment says:
This passage speaks only of **all dharmas being empty**,
with no attachment—
thus the great meaning is fulfilled.

Humanity’s nature is **originally round and awakened**,
with no division between self and others.
When **self and dharma** arise, division appears.
If **self has no dharma**, others extinguish my nothingness;
if **others possess dharma**, I extinguish their dharma with my own.
Only when **self and others both lack dharma**,
and the **heavenly body** is perfectly round,
does **Great Awakening** emerge.

In the **Dao**,
**insight** is the **gateway to marvel**,
**stillness** the **true essence**,
**wise thought** the **armor and shield**,
**discriminating wisdom** the **sword and spear**.
Breaking the **inner demon’s high ramparts**,
crushing the **outer foe’s fortified ranks**,
pacifying the chaotic and explaining the ensnared.

Deeply knowing that **form and substance** cannot long endure,
yet the **true spirit** persists through countless eons.
Understanding **transformation’s impermanence**,
the **abiding** lies only within myself.

Not originally **dharma**, it cannot be spoken of as dharma;
not originally **teaching**, it cannot be transmitted as teaching.
As it is said:
*"Round and red, not a thread nor a hair."*

Yet within it lies a **foundation of firm footing**—
if one drifts like a rudderless boat,
lost in empty vagueness,
the Buddha calls it **"vague and empty"**—
still, it is the plight of falling into the **bottomless abyss of emptiness**.

Confucius said:
*"One may stand with him, but not yet be entrusted with authority."*
Only when one can **stand firm** may one speak of **authority**.

The immortal master opened his mouth to say:

*"The Three Treasures clings to the Original Yang,
escaping the bottomless demonic pit—
followers must advance westward!"*

This is when one’s **foundation is firmly established**,
the moment one may **stand firm**.

Yet still, it is not yet sufficient.
Thus, the text suddenly presents an aged mother’s loud cry:
*"Monk, do not proceed!
Westward lies only the path of death!"*

This great sage, with his **compassionate vessel**,
splits the path with a single strike—
blocking the way, he makes clear:
*"Not to blend with the mundane,
nor to follow the round and square—
one step is unworkable!"*

Now, observe the **Destruction of the Dharma-realm** at hand,
uttering the **wish of ten thousand monks**,
slaying the **nameless**,
awaiting only the **named**—
until the ten thousand are gathered,
plainly pointing out that **all dharma is but an empty shadow**.

The Three Treasures then sought a **skillful path** to pass through,
but the aged mother laughed:
*"You cannot pass!
You cannot pass!"*

In that laughter, she rejoiced at his **not taking a direct route**,
and mocked his **twisting and turning in vain**.
One must walk the **middle path**—
there lies a **skillful gate**,
to traverse through;
do not stray into **devious side paths**,
lest you lose your way entirely.

Thus again he hurriedly called out to stop them.

For **skillful means** are not contrary to the **Way** itself,
but rather, to weigh the **light and heavy** along the **true path**,
to bend one’s heart without abruptness—
thus must one **seek the Dao** until the journey’s end.

Since the **Han dynasty** onward, none have truly understood its meaning,
and so they abandon the **middle path** to take **devious side paths**—
how could they align with **reason**?

Those who cannot uphold the **Way** invariably enter **erroneous paths**,
and cloak their **skillful means** in pretense to justify their **deviance**;
while those who practice **skillful means** in truth
must follow the **right path**, transforming the **Way** to serve the **orthodox**.

This is the **true skillful gate** of the **middle path**—
the **skillful means** of **sages, immortals, and Buddhas**.

Past readers of *Journey to the West* have seen the **Great Sage’s** appearance
as mere literary exhaustion, unable to grasp these **cool, idle words**—
all profound in meaning.

**Dao** is that which **does nothing yet nothing remains undone**.
Its **substance** is **emptiness and non-being**,
its **function** is **following and adapting**.
Without fixed form, without enduring shape,
it thus explores the **emotions of all things**;
neither preceding nor following things,
it thus becomes the **master of all things**.

With **dharma** or without **dharma**, it acts according to the **time**;
with **precepts** or without **precepts**, it harmonizes with **sentient beings**.
Thus it is said:
*"The sage is imperishable, for he guards with the times."*
And again:
*"Change and move without abiding, shifting with the flow of the age."*
This is the **true intent** of the **Great Sage’s** westward journey to guide the world.

The instruction having been made clear,
he turned straight back to the **Southern Seas**.

The **Pilgrim** then concealed his name to avoid danger,
transforming into a **moth-lantern** to advance by the **light**,
observing carefully and acting in accordance with the **opportunity**;
when the **Way** was clear, he changed his attire,
imitating the **disguise of a humble servant** in the **Song dynasty**—
truly blending with the mundane, not clinging to his own form.

He surveyed every detail of the inn’s guests,
attentive to the **hardships of the world**,
the **innkeeper’s wife** with child
adopting the **common guise** of the age;

seizing the moment to **steal**,
exploiting the situation to **play tricks**,
stirring the **true essence of Heaven’s machinations**,
revealing a **lively and spirited** manifestation of **qi**.

*"Disguised as a commoner near the city,
altering my name to suit the official’s register;
a **horse merchant**, with ten brothers;
a **Han man** leading horses into the shop,
a **woman** inviting guests upstairs;
asking for the **lamps** to examine the **wares**,
boasting of my **horse numbers**,
praising my **room’s breadth**;
negotiating the **room fee**,
discussing the **price of meals**;
calling for the **slaughter of livestock**,
stumbling on the **threshold**;
setting the **taboo day** for **abstinence**,
opening the **shop on the next day**;
**young mistress**, you’ll come tomorrow;
where shall I sleep? Leaning against the **counter**;
**daughter** holding a **child**, speaking close by;
no **buying or selling**, just a **horse merchant**;
wanting to **sleep in darkness**, there’s a **large counter**;
covering it with a **blanket**, come early."*

This is all the art of conforming to human nature and worldly affairs, revealing how the Wayfarer transcends self-attachment and adapts with boundless flexibility—*"able to wield an unimpeded mind, entering all things universally. Seeing without defilement, knowing without grasping. This is called true seeing, also called liberated knowing. The Buddha perceives beyond birth and death, all dharmas thus equal."*

Ah! Without worldly law, there is no Buddhist law—realizing that no-mind is the Dao-mind. The most subtle part is the *"Entering the Counter to Stir Ghosts"* passage.

Laozi says: *"A skilled merchant hides his goods as if empty."* If one has no worldly possessions, why not feign emptiness while revealing substance? Boldly brandishing the law like a torch, one knows the peril of being caught in darkness by light; robbing the horse merchant reveals the danger of arrogance inviting theft.

The law’s net is dense—everywhere, one must beware. All are the Wayfarer’s embodied teachings.

At this stage, the Great Sage displays boundless, transcendent transformations—left arm, right arm, left as right, nothing unsuited. Manipulated on the palm, left and right flow effortlessly. Thus, a single shake of the Golden Hoop scatters across the six directions; gathering into truth, it retreats into the hidden.

*"Form and spirit both perfect, harmonizing with the Dao’s truth—thus able to multiply the body into countless transformations, pluck a hair to forge countless weapons."* From the highest palaces and ministries to the lowest officials and commoners, noble or lowly, great or small—spontaneous divine power shifts forms and moves emotions.

This is the Wayfarer’s body transforming into a blade, shaving every hair clean, making self and others one, all rounded into perfection, unrestricted movement, natural as heaven—is this not like one suddenly awakening from a dream?

Ah! Destroying law through law, revering law to attain law—law has no fixed form. Such is its nature.

The Eighty-Fifth Chapter: The Heart-Monkey Envious of the Wood Mother, the Demon King’s Scheme to Devour Zen

The Sage said: This chapter—readers may say that the earlier demons were beyond comparison, but this one is merely ordinary, as if hastily written. Yet what seems unremarkable is truly wondrous: what can be thought of is not what should be thought at all.

The previous section exposed the emptiness of human nature and worldly affairs, revealing all dharmas as void. One must blend with the world, adapting to circumstances—whether square or round—though outwardly responding to events, yet rooted in the boundless luminosity of the heart’s essence. Fearful that others might not perceive this from the heart, the Immortal Master forcefully turns outward to inward, emphasizing the profound intent of *"The Heart Sutra is not to be sought far away,"* urging one to recognize this heart and never harbor the slightest obstruction, lest one fall into demonic snares.

For the Holy Heart is like a mirror-still pool—ever luminous, ever tranquil, ever responsive yet ever still. All uses arise from its singular essence, and its essence never strays from all uses. Thus it is said: *"The body of wisdom is silent and still, its function radiant and suchness."*

Yet if even a speck of obstruction arises, the heart’s essence grows murky and clogged, and its outer functions become deceitful—like mist veiling the soul’s faculties, where Zen is swallowed whole, as though dense fog concealed within the transparent layers of the *Lianhuan Cave*, shattering the sky-piercing pillars!

Thus the next section is titled: *"Hidden Mist Mountain, the Broken Peak, the Linked-Ring Cave."* The Five Peaks are the celestial pillars; the One Heart is the master of the body. When the peaks collapse, the sky lacks support; when the heart is obscured, the body loses its root. Actions unrooted in the heart become nothing but afflictions—what Zen remains?

Zen seeks to dissolve demons; the staff is wielded to subdue them. Yet how does the demon wield the staff and devour Zen? Zen stills but one mind, while the demon traverses the Six Realms. To bind Zen and extinguish dharma is for the demon to govern demons—how can it avoid becoming a gluttonous maw, greedily consuming living Zen?

Why? Because following desire is not Zen-mind. It splits into precepts, concentration, and wisdom—expanding into the Six Perfections, dispersing into myriad practices. Zen is but one of the Six Perfections—how can it encompass all dharmas? Few escape becoming demonic.

Moreover, Zen-mind is hard to purify, and the golden and wooden essences remain unmelted. How could one then reject all existence and eliminate all dharmas without falling into calculation? If all dharmas are void, it is not that there are no dharmas. The heart gives rise to all dharmas yet does not belong to them. Those who attain it find dharma at their command, verified from the heart, arising as desired—neither identical nor different, neither different nor identical; neither dharma nor non-dharma, neither non-dharma nor non-non-dharma. How could one seek it by clinging to traces?

Dharma is like a tuft of hair. External dharmas are like the body’s bearing—without dharma, it is a loss of decorum. The opening lines, spoken by the ministers, plainly state *"loss of decorum."* Yet the subtlety of dharma’s empty nature is beyond those who cling to worldly dharmas. The minister says, *"I do not know,"* the king replies, *"Indeed, you do not know,"*—each weeping profusely, truly pitiful.

When the king repents of killing and the entire kingdom takes refuge, changing *"destroying dharma"* to *"revering dharma,"* it embodies the principle *"The Buddha has no fixed form; no abiding birth-mind."* For clinging to dharma is to destroy dharma; not clinging to dharma is to revere dharma. Thus sitting in Zen is sitting as Buddha; sitting as Buddha is killing Buddha. Clinging to dharma is fixing the mind; a fixed mind is demonic mind.

The Elder on horseback joyfully declared, *"Wukong, this principle is excellent, of great merit."* Already, all dharmas return to One—every aspect radiates the Dao’s essence. Sha Wujing immediately continued, *"Brother..."*

「Where could one find so many artisans of such craft?」
In the secular world, this is called *"losing decorum"* (失仪); in the Buddhist law, it is called *"crafting appearances"* (整容).
Though seemingly opposed, they mutually complement each other—such is the law’s refusal to be rigidly fixed.
This is the principle that *dharma has no fixed form*, its transformations boundless, its wondrous play unfolding through roots and mind.

The Pilgrim recited this once, then swiftly chanted the four lines of the *Heart Sutra’s Preface* (《多心经》四句《颂子》):
*"The Buddha is not sought afar on Spirit Mountain—
Spirit Mountain stands within your own mind.
Each person has a Spirit Mountain stupa—
Practice beneath it, and you shall find."*

The Tang Monk said, *"All scriptures and teachings boil down to cultivating the mind."*
*"When the mind is pure, clarity shines alone;
When the mind harbors dharma, all worlds grow clear.
A moment’s negligence breeds slackness—
No success in ten thousand years, no matter how long.
But with a single thread of true sincerity,
The Voice of Thunder resounds right before your eyes."*

This *"mind"* is the very focus of the two preceding passages.

The Monkey was of the *Jin-Water Hour* (金水), the Pig of the *Hai-Wood-Fire Hour* (亥木火)—
Though they clash, they also complete each other.
The Monkey, laboring yet weary, harbors resentment from exhaustion;
The Pig, slack from idleness, deceives through comparison.
Below, it was precisely this negligence and lack of sincerity that caused the error—
Thus the sudden rise of wind and mist.

*"Eight Rules [of Conduct] shirks duty,
The Pilgrim deceives him, calling demons ‘good’ and mist ‘qi.’
Steamed rice, flatbread, vegetables—
Little eaten, but the mouth complains.
The horse must be fed first—
Fresh grass sought before its meal.
Fine food for the handsome, coarse for the ugly;
Mumbling ‘Great Sage!’ from his lips."*

Their words ring hollow, deceit between them—
Greedy, lazy, mouth and heart misaligned—
Is this not falling into the *Circle of Demonic Illusions*?

Had the Pilgrim not turned his mind inward and secretly intervened,
Their hidden deceit and broken precepts would have sealed their fate.
Thus, when the heart’s sincerity is absolute, demons retreat;
When the mind wanders, demons manifest.
Demons are not external—they are shadows summoned by one’s own heart.

Observe how the Pilgrim and Eight Rules were deceived by the clear wind and mist—
The demon, to deceive them, gathered the wind and dispersed the mist.
When the Pilgrim and Eight Rules sought to eat the offering,
The demon demanded the monk instead;
When the Pilgrim spoke of steamer’s vapor,
The demon scraped the pot to steam the monk.
Eight Rules and the Pilgrim disguised themselves as a short monk and false Pilgrim—
The demon became a false demon in return.
The Pilgrim employed the *Divided Body Technique*—
The demon countered with the *Sliced Plum Blossom Scheme*.
When the Pilgrim saw the demon defeated and turned back,
The demon retreated to its cave, silent and still.
The Pilgrim called Eight Rules *"Vanguard General"*—
The demon anointed a minor demon as *"Scout."*

Sincerity makes *Chan* the master, swallowing demons;
Negligence makes demons the master, devouring *Chan*.
Like the pole’s shadow or echo in the valley—
Blurred, indistinguishable.
*Chan* or *demon*?
One or two?

The demon bound the Tang Monk to a tree,
And the woodcutter likewise bound to the tree,
Each speaking of loyalty to lord and filial piety—
Their deepest, most sincere words.

The tree, with roots and branches,
Is the foundation of all things.
A just ruler and filial parent are the great Dao of heaven and earth,
While loyalty and filial virtue are the roots of human nature—
Both spring from the true nature of the heart,
Adorned with no false pretense or artifice.

To bow in devotion, serving with utmost loyalty,
And to nurture life while honoring death—
Not betraying the lord’s grace—
This is the true attainment of the sacred scripture.

To exhaust one’s strength in filial duty,
Nurturing life and honoring death—
Repaying the debt of parental kindness—
This is the true reverence for the living Buddha.

If one does not act from the root of true nature,
But instead feigns loyalty and filial piety in outward show,
Then it is like the hidden leopard of Aiyue Mountain,
Wielding the staff of demon-subduing in reverse—
Devouring *Chan* while disguised as virtue.

Lost in the root, cloaked in false filiality as demon—
How easily one may be lamented and defeated!

Oh, Three Treasures and woodcutter—
How could they not be moved to sorrow and grief?

The profound meaning leaps beyond the text,
Beyond the strokes of the brush.

Is it plain?
Or wondrous?
Can it be contemplated and imitated?
Or is it beyond contemplation and imitation?

The Eighty-Sixth Episode: *Mu* Mother Aids in Subduing the Fiend
*Jin* Father Applies the Dao to Exterminate the Demon

*Wu Yi Zi* said: This continues from the previous section, speaking of the Dao/Way being obscured by *Chan* (meditation).

Due to negligence and deceit, one must diligently awaken and discipline oneself—never allowing the slightest falsehood or pretense—then can one penetrate the inner and outer, and comprehend the interconnected cycles of cause and effect.

*"Hidden Mist Mountain, the Aiyue Leopard’s Linked and Pierced Illusion"*—its meaning was clarified earlier.

The one who calls himself *"Nan Shan Da Wang"* (Southern Mountain King), *Nan* (south) being the *Li* (trigram of wood) and belonging to the heart—
*"For hundreds of years, I have roamed here"*—speaks of his demonic form arising from long indulgence of the heart, hence he is singled out to refute his arrogance by invoking Laozi, the Buddha, and Confucius, the three great sages of the teachings.

The Fifth Patriarch said:
*"The body is the Bodhi tree, the mind the mirror platform.
Ever diligently wipe and polish it,
Lest dust gather upon it."*

Further still:
*"Bodhi has no tree, the mirror no platform.
Originally, there is no single thing—
Where could dust gather upon it?"*

Though their exhortations differ in tone,
both illuminate the mind’s proper clarity and purity.

The boar belongs to *Hai* (the eleventh earthly branch), *Hai* being wood;
the monkey belongs to *Shen* (the ninth earthly branch), *Shen* being metal.
When out of harmony, metal subdues wood, creating jealousy;
when in harmony, metal generates water to nourish wood,
and the fire within wood generates earth to foster metal—
thus it aids.

Metal and wood have both restraining and fostering relationships.
Metal becomes true gold when refined by water and fire;
wood thrives when nourished by metal and water.
The original pairing of husband and wife
never truly departs.

When husband and wife live in harmony, the household prospers;
when metal and water are balanced, the body and life align—
this is the Dao/Way of water’s inherent tranquility,
which calms inner and outer, repelling chaos.
Thus, the demon is subdued from this very source.

Yet though the demon comes from without,
its true origin lies within the mind.
So whatever the mind creates,
the demon knows;
whatever the demon creates,
the mind knows.

The practitioner recognizes this as *"the Plum Blossom’s Divided Petal Strategy"*,
and also knows *"the demon’s dwelling is here—my master must be in this very place"*,
both insights arising from the mind’s own discernment.

Yet the most perilous deception is when the false resembles the true—
like the demon crafting a human head from a willow tree,
which is easily discerned as false;
but far more treacherous is when it mimics the true,
such as the demon fashioning a fresh human head as the master,
seemingly real yet not—
most difficult to recognize.
Thus the practitioner brothers failed to perceive and wept together in lament.

The distinction between true and false is subtle,
yet the root of right and wrong is easily confused.

But why did they weep as one?
Was it because the practitioner truly believed in the illusion
and led the crowd in grief?

Sorrow can turn black silk to green or yellow,
and diverging paths can lead east or west.
Their unified weeping holds profound meaning!

Only through great lamentation
can one either mistake the false for the true,
or seek the true while abandoning the false.
How so?

Weeping is the mind’s pain—
with sound and tears, both arise from genuine sincerity,
able to awaken true awareness.
The demon confuses me with falsehood,
but I master it with truth—
then evil cannot overcome righteousness,
and the demon vanishes.

Thus, *"Strive forward, shatter the Stone Gate!"*
and the fortress collapses.

Those who once sought ease and slacked in discipline,
now suddenly rouse courage and sharpen their resolve—
the Southern Mountain King’s reckless form
can no longer be fully comprehended!

Before, the practitioner raised a false doppelgänger to summon the demon;
now, he employs a true doppelgänger to dispel it—
*"Strike from without, slay from within the ranks,"*
united force and will, inner and outer assault—
overthrowing the scheming *Cang Lang* (blue wolf),
blocking the long-indulgent old fiend,
then calming the *qi* and preserving the mind,
examining its gateways,
penetrating its origins and currents,
slipping unseen into its lair—
true and false now fully revealed,
great demons and small, all trembling in confusion.
What fear could there be of its plots and harm?

Recognizing it as demonic,
refining its essence to true insight,
all fiends fall, instantly silenced—
its original form exposed,
and the false paths shattered.

Only then does the true manifest,
the false perish,
its roots severed, its form laid bare.
The Aiyue Leopard’s superficial illusions are removed,
and my true mind remains unharmed.
This is how the woodcutter’s filial devotion,
moving heaven and earth,
escaped death and glimpsed his mother’s true nature.

The woodcutter said:
*"Now the mountain is at peace,
and I may travel through the night."*
And again:
*"This path leads west for less than a thousand *li*."*

Ah!

The inner and outer as one,
penetrating through surface and depth—
how near we stand to the Land of Ultimate Bliss!
This is the Dao’s true measure.

**Chapter Eighty-Seventh: The Phoenix Immortal County—Defying Heaven’s Drought, the Great Sage Sun Wukong Urges Benevolence to Bring Rain**

The Awakened One said:
*"This passage reveals that those who cultivate the True Way must first amass hidden virtue.
Before hidden virtue is complete,
even a beautiful name is useless,
and a half-finished deed collapses.
Ghosts and spirits cannot silently aid,
and all deeds remain hollow pretense.
One must urgently turn inward and reflect,
awaken boundless compassion,
observe strict discipline with diligent progress,
and widely cultivate hidden virtue.*

*What is hidden virtue?*
Cultivating one’s own *heaven* to honor others’ *heaven*—this is hidden virtue;
acting secretly with skillful means—this is hidden virtue;
giving without expecting repayment—this is hidden virtue;
accumulating goodness unknown to others—this is hidden virtue;
not forcing others into peril—this is hidden virtue;
concealing others’ flaws—this is hidden virtue.

The *sutra* says:
*'When they bring calamity, I bring fortune;
When they bring enmity, I bring virtue.'*
All these are deeds of hidden virtue,
boundless in dispelling disasters and karmic retribution.

*The Awakening of the True* says:
*'Great joy lies in what is easy to know,'*
for knowledge comes from both self and *heaven*.

If one does not accumulate deeds and hidden virtue,
demons and fiends will obstruct at every turn.
For though one’s fate is not entirely by *heaven*,
it lies in the marvel of creation within oneself;
and though it is also by *heaven*,
the silent power of reflection rests with *heaven*.

The practitioner says:
*'Only by amassing merit and virtue can I grant you this great rain,'*
—this is the essence of this passage.

The name *'Phoenix Immortal County'* signifies a land of transcendent virtue,
yet now it fails to accumulate hidden merit while boasting hollow fame.
Though it claims to love the people outwardly,
it secretly harms them.
With the people’s lives hanging in peril,
how can the true ruler appease *heaven’s* wrath?

Yet the county magistrate, *Shangguan*,
is *'tenfold in his uprightness'* and *'deep in his love for the people.'*
His plea for rain to save the people is a deed of boundless goodness—
how then does he fail to move *heaven*?

It is said:
*'This is outward virtue, not hidden virtue.'*

For though he is *'tenfold in his uprightness,'*
he is too bright, too rigid in righteousness—
like the fierce *yang* force,
and thus *'unbenevolent.'*
The *Hongfan Transmission* says:
*'If bright, then drought.'*
Brightness is *yang* force unbalanced by *yin* to harmonize it.
Without *yin*’s nourishing flow,
the land’s vitality cannot penetrate deep,
human efforts falter below,
and *heaven’s* response manifests above—
drought is its sign.

Thus, rulers must embody benevolence and relief,
widely practice hidden virtue,
and not prize mere clarity as wisdom.

The sages have said:
*'Brightness without compassion is worse than ignorance.'*
Yao’s three pardons,
Yu’s descent from his chariot,
Tang’s release of the fishnets—
all were brightness tempered by compassion.

Officials who receive *heaven’s* bounty,
holding their posts by imperial command,
must cherish the land and its people—
this is their duty.
What virtue do they possess?

True virtue is known only to *heaven*,
not to mortals.
Yet when *'three years ago, on the twenty-fifth day of the twelfth month,
Shangguan’s household overturned the vegetarian offerings for the gods to feed dogs,
and spoke blasphemous words, defying *heaven,’*
this was hidden evil—
known only to *heaven*, not to men.

The people are *heaven’s* creation;
*heaven* loves all it creates.
If a ruler embodies *heaven’s* heart in loving the people,
he will surely receive *heaven’s* hidden reward—
this is an unchanging principle.

To love the people must begin with revering *heaven*,
hence the saying: *'Revere *heaven* and diligently tend the people.'*
Now Shangguan cannot revere *heaven* but instead profanes it—
no greater crime exists!

For the people, food is *heaven*.
The offerings are what the people rely on for sustenance,
the foundation *heaven* uses to nourish them.
To overturn them for dogs is to deceive and extinguish both *heaven* and the people—
what greater lack of benevolence could there be?

Thus, a thousand outward good deeds
cannot outweigh one hidden evil act.

Hence the Sage is cautious in public and vigilant in solitude,
while the virtuous man guards his private conduct.

For *yin* is the realm of solitary knowledge,
and *virtue* is what one attains in the heart.
It is neither name-seeking nor reputation-chasing.

When the roof leaks, the streets become thoroughfares;
in dreams, night merges with day.
Spirit and breath silently commune with the imperial throne—
the speed of response surpasses even drumbeats!

Yet the one who has incurred *heaven’s* wrath is the magistrate—
how then does disaster descend upon the common folk?

The magistrate is the wind, the people the grass:
if the magistrate is unbenevolent, the people become unrighteous.
Above and below follow in kind—
*qi* and kindred natures resonate.
Day and night, his guilt festers into the people’s hidden anxieties;
a single moment of irreverence spreads as fate’s blessing or ruin for all.

If the magistrate creates it, the people will love him—
this is the natural order of cause and effect.

Thus, extraordinary local calamities
must stem from those in power losing virtue—
and this drought, defying *heaven*, is entirely deserved.

Yet *heaven’s* heart is supremely benevolent,
slow to punish evil to allow repentance,
and swift to reward goodness to encourage virtue.

There are also the appropriate urgencies of *yin* and *yang*:
hidden virtue is delayed to await accumulation and magnify its reward,
while hidden evil is swiftly met to demonstrate *heaven’s* response and confirm its retribution.

For *yang* is known to all,
while *yin* is known only to *heaven*.
Though there are differences in urgency,
there is not the slightest error.

When intent is absolute and aligned,
it is not *heaven* that calls—
but the person who summons their own fate."*

Thus, when one defends their position, the mountains of rice and flour collapse in an instant, towering twenty zans high—
their crimes are as vast as mountains and valleys, beyond reckoning!

When feeding dogs, the roosters are already clenched-mouthed, slow-mouthed,
long-tongued or short-tongued, behaving like beasts and accumulating sins too deep to purge!

When offending others, the golden chains remain unbroken, yet a single lamp’s flame
cannot be extinguished—its punishment knows no end!

Yet still, one evil deed can corrupt a hundred virtues,
while one act of goodness can redeem a hundred evils.

The Four Heavenly Masters addressed the Great Sage with a smile and said:
*"This matter can only be resolved through goodness.
If you but turn your heart from evil to good,
shaking the heavens above,
then the mountains of rice and flour will topple at once,
the chains and rods will break without delay—
go and persuade him to repent, and blessings will follow naturally."*

For evil and virtue both originate from oneself—
to abandon evil and embrace virtue lies solely in one’s own hands.
If only one sincerely reflects and turns toward goodness,
then evil can be transformed into virtue,
calamity into fortune.

The Dragon King cannot act out of favor,
the Great Sage cannot act out of strength,
nor can the heavens force a man—
only the three signs of warning are shown to admonish.

If he truly repents with earnest heart,
broadly cultivating hidden virtue,
then the fierce flames shall turn to sweet dew,
the star-mountains shall crumble into drifting clouds;
the rooster’s tongue of retribution shall be silenced,
the dog’s tongue of blame shall be cut short;
fire shall cease to blaze,
the cords of punishment shall dissolve into nothingness.

In an instant, the heavens descended sweet rain,
each drop falling without fail—how swift its arrival!
The spirits and deities also parted the clouds and mists,
each revealing their true form.

It moves the heavens and earth,
stirs the ghosts and gods—
is this not wrought by a single change of the virtuous heart?
Thus, the temple is named **"Sweet Rain Universal Salvation Monastery."**

In the pursuit of the Elixir,
those who do not repent and cultivate hidden virtue
are like cooking sand for rice or using bamboo to point at the moon—
their efforts shall never bear fruit!
How then does it earn the name **"Universal Salvation"?**

Yet the Sage Master holds a profound secret,
concealed within the transitions of this chapter.
The previous chapter expounded the emptiness of all phenomena;
enlightenment of the heart and true nature—
inner and outer as one, subtly perfect and harmonious—
is already the Buddha’s presence in this land.
Where else might one labor to attain?

The woodcutter said, *"That great path lies not far to the west."*
Why then is this not a resting place,
but rather a waypoint still traversed?
For accumulating virtue and refining power
is merely the work of those in the early stages of cultivation—
why speak of it when enlightenment and clarity are already attained?
Yet few know of the wondrous Dao residing between.

Observe the opening verse:
*"The Great Dao is profound and subtle—
how can it be fathomed?
It embraces the cosmos,
splits the hidden gateways—
its joy surpasses all in the world.
The spirit soars before the sacred peak,
a gem plucked from its treasure,
radiant with fivefold brilliance.
Piercing through heaven and earth,
all beings above and below—
the wise live as long as mountains and seas."*

These words encapsulate the essence of the Elixir’s purpose;
even the ghosts and gods are startled by its revelation.
How much more so for mortals?
Thus, it is not spoken aloud.
Only when the nature-body is firm
can one refine the Elixir;
only when hidden virtue is deep
can one perfect the Elixir.
The Dao of the Elixir is wondrous yet unfathomable in this way.

The ancient Master Maopu (鸠摩罗什) often sighed,
*"If only the fragrance of the scriptures could be written with ink to make the Great Vehicle,
the Abhidharma would not be inferior to the teachings of Kāśyapa!"*
Now that those who deeply understand are few,
what remains to be expounded?

The ancients did not wish to reveal it,
lest the ghosts and gods be startled—
this is the same principle.
In the **Eighty-Eighth Chapter**, *"The Zen Reaches Jade Fluid and the Law Assembly"*
*"The Monkey-Spirit and Wooden Demons Instruct the Disciples,"*
Master Wùyī (悟一子) said:
*"This reveals the Great Dao—
it must be transmitted by a teacher.
To hoard the Dao is to obstruct the heavenly Way;
to reveal it lightly is to profane the heavenly treasure—
one must truly understand this."*

**"Jade Fluid"** refers to the Elixir of returning Jade Nectar.
At this stage, the nature-body is perfected;
to withhold transmission, leaving none to follow,
is the selfishness of obstructing the path.
If transmitted to the unworthy,
and the secrets are carelessly divulged,
disaster shall surely befall the one who does so.
The chapter’s teachings are most awakening and urgent.

When the Three Treasures (三藏) reached Jade Fluid,
he instructed his disciples:
*"Be cautious—
do not be reckless!"*
This clearly shows the meaning of not revealing lightly.

**"Eight Precepts bowed his head,
Sand Monk covered his face,
Pilgrim supported the Master."**
Even so, they still could not help but exclaim in unison:
*"We have only seen high monks who subdue dragons and tame tigers—
never one who subdues pigs and tames monkeys!"*

For the world knows only of dragons and tigers
as the effects of cultivation,
yet never understands what dragons and tigers truly are,
nor the merit of subduing them.
They do not know that pigs and monkeys
are but other names for dragons and tigers—
and when suddenly revealed,
how could they not be startled in doubt?

The **Monkey** (申猿) is the Elixir of Metal-Water,
the **Pig** (亥猪) is the Elixir of Wood-Fire,
and the **Sand** (沙) and **Precepts** (戒) represent the central Earth—
this is the principle of the Five Phases converging.
Readers unaware of its subtlety
mistake it for the restless monkey-spirits of the heart,
and dismiss the Sand and Precepts families as insignificant—
their understanding is no different from those who have never seen a monk subduing pigs and taming monkeys.

The world flees at sight,
stumbling and crawling,
ever fearful of avoiding it too little—
yet who knows that through fourteen cycles of cold and heat,
countless evils and demons,
they have endured untold suffering
before attaining the precious formula?

This treasure is not easily won—
worthy of being learned by kings and nobles—
yet if its brilliance is too shallow,
and one boasts of selling it,
one shall be deemed frivolous.
The scriptures say:
*"Clad in coarse robes yet holding jade within."*
*"If empty, if foolish."*
The Ancestors taught with great care—
not from selfishness or vanity.
For a lone string plays no harmony,
startling the crowd and shocking the wise;
few are the connoisseurs who respond,
and fewer still are those who benefit—
most only lose themselves.
How could one not be cautious?

Within the chapter, **"暴纱亭"** is revealed—
a sign of shallow, boastful display.
**"标窃神兵"** warns of the danger of flaunting and deceiving others.
**"暴"** means to proclaim;
**"纱"** means light and frivolous;
**"亭"** means a temporary stop.
If one carelessly reveals the secrets,
the curious shall seize the opportunity,
pretending to follow while exploiting the openings.

See how the Prince and the palace officials
were alarmed by the monk’s grotesque appearance,
begging him to go to **暴纱亭** to eat alms.
This is but a monk of outward form—
one who does not recognize his inner treasure’s worth,
and thus is not sincerely invited to dwell as a revered teacher,
but rather treated as a transient guest at an inn.

When the Prince boasted of his own prowess,
and the Three Disciples excelled in their arts,
the rooster’s cackle grew ashamed of its small cage,
the frog in the well felt the limits of its vision.
*"The father and son prostrated themselves in worship,
while Pilgrim coldly observed from the side."*
This was the assembly where the Law could be applied—
why not then enact a grand salvation
right at **暴纱亭**?

For there are teachings that must be kept secret,
and those that may be revealed without concealment.
Zen is the **Sramana’s** (沙门) method—
the **Sramana’s** (沙) teachings can be openly shared,
yet to guide beings toward liberation,
for those who chase after fame and profit,
or are weary from the labors of the world,
it must serve as a resting place and refuge.

The **elixir of jade nectar and return-to-origin** is the marvelous Dao/Way of awakening the mind and seeing true nature.

The **jade brilliance** of its splendor outshines the **fuxia** (甫华) and **gong** (衮) robes,
the **jade hue** of its luster surpasses the **qiang** (嫱) and **shi** (施) beauties;
the **jade essence** of its enduring nature is sturdier than the tripod or bell.

All possess it, each household holds it—
thus, no need for eager exhortation to entice,
nor for frantic efforts to rescue.

Those who return are not hindered by waiting for an invitation,
and seekers are not delayed by anger before guidance begins;
children are not burdened by my brevity,
and the reckless are not burdened by my indulgence.

It can be the **unsummoned** true friend of all beings,
and the **owner** of the Four Dependencies and Ten Stages.

Unlike the **golden elixir of return-to-origin**, passed down only once in ten thousand aeons,
which must be kept secret and never revealed.

These three monks, within the **violent-silk pavilion’s** quiet chamber,
on the same day accepted disciples,
received the **divine transmission** of the **Sramana’s** (沙门) teachings,
and **circulated the cosmos** through their **mystic energy**—
this is called the **open transmission** of the **Sramana’s** (沙) Law,
no more than external tools like weapons and martial prowess.
Their **subduing-pig, taming-monkey** (降猪伏猴) hidden marvels
were never uttered aloud or exposed in plain sight.

The **eight precepts’** stake and mallet weigh **5,048 jin** (斤) in total,
a single **treasure’s** measure.
The **Sramana’s** (沙) staff also weighs **5,048 jin**,
also a single **treasure**—
no difference in principle.

The **lonely wanderer’s** (独行者) rod weighs **13,500 jin**,
for it has already encompassed the **three treasures’** total,
yet it lacks the **three-five** (三五) harmonious perfection.

This tool can be replicated in form,
but must never be abandoned day or night—
in the **Buddhist** tradition, it is called the **"subduing-demon staff"** (降魔杵),
in the **Daoist** tradition, the **"wise sword"** (慧剑),
and in the **Confucian** tradition, the **"righteous cleaver"** (刚断).
It is an innate **intelligence**, a **treasure** for safeguarding truth and banishing evil—
never to be parted from for an instant.
Thus, **"a million rays of crimson light pierce the heavens,
a thousand streams of auspicious qi illuminate the earth."**

If one does not **return the spirit** and **abandon the body**,
but instead **departs for a moment**,
one will fall prey to **external demons**.

Hence, **"when left in the straw shed for three days,"
it was swept away by the **devouring jaws of the tiger and leopard** (豹头虎口).

The Prince, having received his teacher’s transmission,
his **original spirit** (元神) returned to its source,
his **shedding of the old self and rebirth** (脱胎换骨) complete—
like the dead revived—
now wields the **divine weapon**.

Thus, it is evident that the **Zen school’s** teachings,
once reaching the **jade brilliance** stage,
are sufficient to **enlighten ordinary beings**,
and **broadly manifest compassion**.

Those who have not yet glimpsed its **gate**,
yet **borrow the guise of a head monk** (头陀),
and **spread long-winded doctrines** (长舌),
are indeed the **later tiger and leopard jaws** (豹头虎口).

The **eighty-ninth installment**:
*"The Yellow Lion Spirit falsely convenes the stake and mallet assembly,
the gold, wood, and earth demons stir up chaos at Tiger’s Mouth Mountain."*
**Wùyī Zǐ** (悟一子) said:
This describes the **yellow-crowned** (黄冠) sect,
who **usurp the Daoist name**,
and bring upon themselves **misfortune from presuming without a teacher**.

Before the **jade brilliance** (玉华) assembly was held,
it was **ancestral transmission**—
true knowledge and genuine power—
hence called the **"authentic Law assembly"** (施法会).
This **stake and mallet** (钉钯) assembly,
however, is **false and teacherless**—
self-asserted, arbitrary—
thus called the **"empty assembly"** (虚设会).

The phrase **"Tiger’s Mouth Mountain, Leopard’s Head Cave"** (豹头山虎口洞)
clearly reveals those who **devour and indulge** in such teachings,
pretending to be **divine immortals**,
yet unaware of their own **wicked nature**.

Their **headgear** is the **Daoist cap** (道冠),
yet in truth, it is the **leopard’s head** (豹头);
their **utterances** are **Daoist speech** (道言),
yet in truth, it is the **tiger’s jaws** (虎口).

To generalize:
**Long sashes and short staffs** (长绦短麈) mimic the **master’s trimmed tail** (师剪尾) arrogance;
**Patched robes and straw sandals** (衲服芒鞋) imitate the **spotted and tattered** appearance.
They **entrap the fox** (绥狐) with **sharp claws** (利爪),
storing **nightly seduction** (夜夜之娇) in their **gourd** (葫芦);
they **seize the green serpent** (青蛇) with **bared fangs** (张牙吻),
concealing **clinking daggers** (铮铮之匕) in their **pouch**.
They **follow the traces of Master Zhang** (杖远公),
yet **do not hear the Three Mysteries** (三藐不闻);
they **wear the coarse robes of Master Damo** (着达摩之农),
yet **have not yet understood the One** (一归未解);
they **recite the sutras of Master Bolu** (诵波罗之经),
yet **deceit proliferates** (诡谲丛生).

Their **cushion** (蒲团) serves as the **den of a cunning hare** (狡兔之窟),
their **alms bowl** (钵盂) seeks the **land of drunken ease** (酣蘖之乡).
They **linger in the Jeta Grove by day** (祗园),
and **haunt the Flower Market at night** (花市),
**bodily a monk** (身比丘),
yet **in heart, a thief like Jié** (心盗跖).
How different can this be?

In the chapter, the Prince remarked:
*"People say there are immortals in the cave."*
Pilgrim replied:
*"It must be this region’s wicked fiend."*
A single word **pierced the deceitful’s vitals** (湛奸人肺腑),
proving that those who **deceive the world**,
can be **exposed by the vulgar**,
yet cannot **fool the wise**.

*"Seeing two wolf-headed demons,
they spoke clearly: ‘Our great king has been fortunate these days—
last month, he obtained a beautiful woman,
who lingers in the cave, bringing him great joy;
last night, he also acquired three kinds of weapons,
truly priceless treasures;
tomorrow, he will host a feast
to celebrate the **stake and mallet assembly** (钉钯会)!’"*

The mind’s pure contemplation, where *samādhi* and *prajñā* are inseparable,
is the Buddha’s void and luminous form—
the *dharma*’s subtle radiance.
The void of the Buddha is also the void of the *dharma*,
the void of the *saṅgha*—the mind itself abides.
Abiding in the three voids’ treasure,
this is also called the **Three Refuges**.

Thus it is said: the **Three Jewels**—Buddha, *Dharma*, *Saṅgha*—
are verified by the mind itself,
not borrowed from without.
How could they be seized and obtained?

The Yellow Lion stole the Three Jewels in secret,
rejoicing in his private heart.
Yet he rejoiced only in the **stake and mallet**,
not in the golden cudgel or jewel-staff—
not only did he fail to grasp the Three Jewels’ subtlety,
he did not even recognize what the **stake and mallet** were!
Perhaps he saw the mallet’s teeth resemble claws,
thinking them useful for sharpening his ferocity—
worthy of celebration, indeed!

To call it the **"Stake and Mallet Assembly"**
was but to gather his claws and fangs,
a hollow display of might.

To take pleasure in a beautiful woman
is to wield an axe against one’s nature;
to feast over the stake and mallet
is to plant the roots of self-destruction.
Given to lust and drunkenness,
forming factions and boasting of fame—
neither monk nor Daoist,
he flaunts grand deeds.
Even the **Maitreya** and **Laozi** would surely
manifest as **Vaiśravaṇa** in wrath,
wielding a flying demon-slaying blade,
to annihilate him instantly.

*"Only two small demons went east to buy swine and sheep."*
The **Qian** hexagram is where all yang originates,
yet to send small demons to buy swine and sheep—
how absurd their mistake!
This stems from their arrogance by nature,
seeking no true teacher,
only skilled in plunder and deceit.
They presume their cleverness surpasses all,
their wisdom piercing the four directions—
yet they reveal only cunning and eccentricity,
eccentricity and cunning.

Eight Rules transformed into cunning and eccentricity,
Pilgrim into eccentricity and cunning,
Sandy the Monk disguised as a swine-and-sheep merchant—
though called a scheme,
it is truly **speaking the Dao**.

**"Calculation"** (*jì*)—
the union of **"speech"** (*yán*) and **"ten"** (*shí*).
The principle of east three, south two,
north one, west four, and the center’s ten.

Pilgrim, as **Metal-Water**,
holds yang within yin—
thus his transformation into **eccentricity and cunning**,
where cunning lurks within eccentricity.
Eight Rules, as **Wood-Fire**,
holds yin within yang—
thus his shift into **cunning and eccentricity**,
where eccentricity hides in cunning.
Sandy the Monk, as **Central Earth**,
borrows from the four directions and thrives—
a guest of all yang,
in accordance with the **Luo River Diagram’s** logic.

They feigned pretense; we acted with true calculation.
To strike falsehood with truth—
how could it fail to be exposed?

When traced to his origin,
he was the **Golden-Haired Lion**,
a disciple of the **Nine Spirits’ Patriarch**.
Ah!
Having shattered their hollow guesses,
they now awaken to wisdom.

The two cunning ones
have already settled into their dual forms—
both body and mind.

A single invitation—
plainly a confession of guilt.

The Nine Spirits’ Patriarch wasted his divine thought,
yet it was the Three Monks’ staff-shouts that broke the spell.
Four-Ming’s blade could not sever the root of delusion—
how then escape the endless wheel of rebirth?

Gold, Wood, Earth—
the Five Radiant Yang Deities—
their Dao/Way,
yet they speak of *"playing with empty tricks to deceive my treasure"*?

The Golden-Haired Lion’s countless deceits,
his fake Fox-Dharma tricks—
no escape from sweeping the cave and burning the nest,
no fleeing to beg his master’s rescue.

Bamboo-Node Mountain—
node by node, hollowly transparent—
yet only secretly piercing emptiness;
Nine-Twist Cave—
twist by twist, intricately deceptive—
yet merely winding and groping in circles.

Lion’s head, lion’s tail, tangled and wild—
not a thread of truth remains;
Lion Patriarch, lion descendant—
chaos and clamor—
all half-hearted schemes.

Ah!
Futile scheming—
what use is it?

The Nine Spirits may command all lions,
worthy of being called *Lion Patriarch*,
yet not *Patriarch Master*.

Though thoughts multiply,
what good are they?

The *Analects* say:
*"To ponder without benefit is not as good as learning."*
The *Sutra* declares:
*"Without a teacher’s guidance,
even deep contemplation leads to the void of heaven’s gods."*

Self-made delusions blind the innate wisdom—
pitiable, indeed!

Here, the Three Monks are clearly marked as Gold, Wood, Earth—
their "monkey-mind, horse-will" theory
originates from self-made delusions!
