**Ninety-First Chapter: The Lion-Teacher’s Transmission—Same Root, Different Branches**
**The Thief of Dao/Way Entangles Zen, Calming the Nine Spirits**

A sage once said:
*"This passage’s Dao/Way is profound and unfathomable—
even the Immortal Sage’s brush cannot exhaust its meaning,
leaving no choice but to end here."*

As for those who scrutinize and analyze,
exhausting thought and insight,
yet grasp only its surface—
such cases need not be discussed.

Even Li Zhi of Zhuo-Wu, upon reading the closing lines,
*"Sudden escape from all thoughts, quieting the mind for true fruit,"*
knew the Nine Heads as Nine Thoughts,
dividing until thoughtlessness—
seemingly grasping the marrow,
yet still only the surface?

The outline states:
*"The Lion-Teacher’s transmission—same root, different branches;
The Thief of Dao/Way entangles Zen, calming the Nine Spirits."*

Those who truly awaken interpret the first half:
*"Lion"* is *"thought"*—
*"Lion-Teacher"* is *"self-made delusion."*
*"Transmission"* is *"passing on"*—
*"transmission and reception"* is *"passing and receiving."*

Self-made delusion in enlightenment,
and receiving the Dao/Way through transmission—
though differing in effort,
they ultimately converge.

Interpreting the latter half:
*"Thief of Dao/Way,"*
*"entangling Zen,"*
*"calming the Nine Spirits"*—
terms for gradual and sudden methods,
further illustrating their convergence—
already surpassing Li’s understanding,
yet still only the surface?

Even the insightful say:
*"Lion-Teacher"* is merely *"self-made delusion"*—
the Dao/Way cannot be obtained through it;
*"transmission and reception"* is *"teaching"*—
the Dao/Way cannot be gained without enlightenment.

The error of self-made delusion
and the flaw in mere teaching
are the same.

The latter half:
The Dao/Way cannot be stolen,
Zen cannot be entangled,
nor can the Nine Spirits be stilled.

To seek enlightenment without awakening
is *"stealing the Dao/Way"*;
to grasp the Dao/Way through self-made delusion
is *"entangling Zen."*

The failure of *"Lion-Teacher’s transmission"*
is like *"stealing the Dao/Way, entangling Zen,"*
yet still hoping to calm the Nine Spirits into unity—
how could this succeed?

This has advanced beyond the surface,
yet still fails to reach the marrow.

The true path is:
*"Lion-Teacher"* is merely *"self-made delusion"*—
lions cannot be imitated;
only through a true teacher’s transmission
can one’s thoughts align in unity.

Why cannot thoughts be imitated?
Only through a true teacher’s transmission
can thoughts avoid error and converge.

Yet what law is transmitted?
What meaning is received?
This remains unsolved—
words cannot exhaust it.

In the past, the Tathagata Shakyamuni
dwelled in the world for eighty years,
teaching countless heavenly and human beings,
voice-hearers, and bodhisattvas.

He expounded the Five Precepts, Eight Precepts,
major and minor Vinaya,
the Four Noble Truths,
Twelve Links of Dependent Origination,
perfection of wisdom,
four immeasurables,
three knowledges and six powers,
thirty-seven factors of enlightenment,
the ten directions,
four fearlessnesses,
eighteen unique laws,
conventional truth,
ultimate truth,
countless liberations,
samadhi and dhāraṇī gates,
bodhisattva nirvana,
eternal dharma-nature,
ornamenting Buddha-lands,
saving sentient beings,
guiding bodhisattvas,
all wondrous methods—
truly vast and exhaustive,
encompassing the dharma-realm without bounds,
penetrating the nature-ocean without limit,
gradual and sudden methods left nothing omitted.

Yet in the end, he privately transmitted the *True Dharma-Eye* to Mahākāśyapa,
ordering ancestral succession,
a separate path in the world—
the *"special transmission outside scriptures,"*
beyond what the world could see or hear.

This was not to favor Kāśyapa over voice-hearers and bodhisattvas,
but because this law is the root of all sentient beings,
what all Buddhas realize,
transcending all reason,
free from all phenomena,
incapable of being grasped by speech, intellect, or analysis—
hidden from all speculation, visible or subtle.
Only heart-to-heart transmission,
seal-to-seal resonance,
can one self-attest to its luminous fruition.

Ancestor to ancestor, secretly revealing profound truths—
originally not something to be imitated through self-made delusion,
seized by force, or stolen.

Yet the Dao/Way is inherently within nature—
it cannot be stolen,
though the mystery of *"stealing the Dao/Way"*
lies precisely in the *True Dharma-Eye’s* singular transmission,
beyond thought or imitation.

The *Yin-Shu Jing* says:
*"Its thieving mechanism—
no one in the world can see,
no one can know."*

Master Lu said:
*"To pilfer the mechanism of Heaven and Earth,
to steal the vital qi of the Middle Void."*

Thus, the Dao is indeed obtained through this very act of theft.

The true teacher’s transmission
transmits not only the Dao
but also the Dao of *stealing the Dao*.
This *stealing of the Dao* is no ordinary Dao.
Hence it is said:
*"The Dao that can be spoken is not the eternal Dao."*
It cannot be named or symbolized,
cannot be conveyed through words.

Yet if the Dao can be stolen,
then can Zen not also be entangled?

Having already *"stolen the Dao,"*
why then speak of *"entangling Zen"*?

Zen is true emptiness—
if one is entangled within it,
it is like two cords twisted together,
impossible to unbind.
What purpose does *"entangling Zen"* serve?

The subtlety of *"stealing the Dao"*
lies precisely in the profound constraint of the Dharma-limit,
the essence of still contemplation and unity.

For solitary contemplation alone cannot *"steal the Dao,"*
nor can exclusive Zen practice achieve still contemplation.

The art of *"stealing the Dao"*
resides in the authenticity of *transmission and reception*,
not in the delusion of *"teacher-lion"* posturing.

The art of *"entangling Zen"*
lies in what follows *"stealing the Dao,"*
not in mere still contemplation.

If one takes still contemplation as Zen,
they disturb Zen with stillness,
falling into void and emptiness—
not true Zen.

If one uses Zen to probe the Dao,
they chase the Dao with thought,
lacking the true seed within—
a false Dao.

The Nine Spirits have no way to stillness,
and the *"teacher-lion"* is but empty fabrication,
not the true transmission of the master.

Thus, *"stealing the Dao"*
is the foundation for stilling the Nine Spirits,
while *"entangling Zen"*
is the culmination of *"stealing the Dao"*—
beyond what pen and ink can fully explain.

This is the Dharma of the True Dharma-Eye,
fixed and unheard by most.

Its essence lies in first knowing
the Nine Spirits as one’s own self,
the six desires harming the body as the six lions encircling front and back,
with the green-faced trickster leading them,
and the nine-headed one as their commander,
arrayed in the *Kan* palace—
then the primordial yang sinks and cannot rise again.

What relies on the three monks’ true Five Phases
clashing fiercely is but a draw of equal strength.
Only the灵心’s transformation,
with intent following the heart’s turn,
can avoid being bound.

Yet the Nine Spirits’ roots come from Heaven—
once thought and desire stir,
the entire host is ensnared.
What is precious is preserving the heart to restrain desire,
calming the spirit,
boldly penetrating the tiger’s den,
until the Nine Spirits’ bamboo-jointed mountain’s nine winding caves—
only then does one grasp its depths.

The six senses are hard to sever,
most reluctant to abandon,
so the old demon weeps unseen—
one must forcefully subdue the mind-monkey,
from the start, like a great hammer striking
after a deep sleep in the brocade-cloud nest,
until the true heart suddenly breaks through.

Once the true heart emerges,
it naturally extinguishes the three corpses,
freely attaining liberation.

If one is agitated and startles themselves,
and the desire-root secretly flares,
then they can still be controlled by it—
for they lack the sovereign to command it.

Only with utmost sincerity and discernment
can one uncover its true master
and thus subdue it.

*"The Eastern Extreme’s Wondrous Rock Palace"*
is the realm of true nature.
*"Where the Lord of the Great Unity resides"*
is the Heavenly model to emulate.

The six lions cannot lurk within,
the nine lions cannot disturb.

The Lord of Heaven summons the **Qi-lion Disciple**—
his crime revealed: stealing the **Supreme Daoist’s** *Wheel of Rebirth* elixir,
three days lost in slumber, and thus straying from the **Nine Spirits’** source.
Now he glimpses the subtlety of *"Dao-Theft"*—
yet, before attaining stillness of thought.

The Lord of Heaven arrives at **Bamboo-Knot Mountain**,
declaring: *"The **Primordial Sage** is a spirit long refined by Dao,
penetrating the Three Realms above,
descending to the Nine Abysses below."*
Thought, when perfected, becomes a Sage—
translucent and boundless, past and future known,
radiant and luminous, and thus is true.

To fail in recognizing the **One True** as sovereign,
is to wander in false conjecture,
disturbed by chaotic delusions—
though luminous, it remains obscured.

Only when the **owner** is truly acknowledged,
ceasing all restless agitation,
and returning to **primordial forgetfulness**—
then the marvel of *"Ensnaring Zen"* is realized,
and the **Nine Spirits** are stilled.

For the **Master-Lion** cannot still the **Qi-Lion**,
but *"transmission"* may yet reveal *"Dao-Theft"*;
*"Dao-Theft"* cannot be without *"Ensnaring Zen"*,
but *"Ensnaring Zen"* can still the **Qi-Lion** and lead to unity.

*The **Awakening to Truth*** says:
*"At first, there is action—no one perceives,"*
that is *"Dao-Theft"*;
and again:
*"When true non-action dawns, all begin to know,"*
that is *"Ensnaring Zen"*.

Theft means **stealing**, ensnaring means **reveling**—
*"Dao-Theft and Ensnaring Zen"*
and the **Nine Spirits** merge as One!

Let the Daoist student not be deceived
by **false teachers** who **steal** their **alchemical tools**,
nor burdened by the **Six Desires** that disrupt the Way—
then they may yet succeed!

The **Immortal Master** uniquely employs the **Violent Silk Pavilion**
to subtly demonstrate his meaning—
thus the lines: *"Again to the Violent Silk Pavilion"*,
*"—one transmission of instruction."*

At the start: *"The **Blue-Faced Fiend** clings close to the **Nine-Headed Lion**,"*
showing the **illusion of chaotic conjecture**,
proclaiming: *"The mind must be transmitted, never forced to guess!"*
The **Blue Beast** is the **conjecture** itself.

The **True Person** declares:
*"Though your wisdom surpasses **Yan** and **Min**,
without the True Master, do not force your guesses!"*
Thus, the practitioner strikes down **doubt** with one blow—
and **false subtleties** and **perverse insights** become mere **meat-pies***.

**Yuhua** and **Jinping** are outer domains of **India**—
**Yuhua** is the **elixir of jade**, where **Zen** reaches its peak,
and **transmission of law** and **instruction to disciples** are both **royal****.

*"The **seventy-two kinds of solutions**"*—
the meaning of **seventy-two critical moments**.

The **transmitted tools**:
*"A **staff of one thousand jin**,
**pestle and rod each of eight hundred jin**"*—
this is the **primordial qi of the First Heaven**,
the **Eight-Eights of the Azure Dragon’s** essence.

Here lies the **"Tiger-Maw Cavern"**, mirroring below
the **"Azure Dragon Mountain of Jinping Prefecture"**—
parallel imagery.

**"Jinping Prefecture"** is the **elixir of gold**,
directly opposed to **"Yuhua"**—
on the **fifteenth day of the first month**, when the moon is full,
the **qi of gold** is perfectly balanced.

With the **"Azure Dragon Mountain"** mirrored to this tale’s **"Tiger-Maw Cavern"**, again parallel.

**Chapter 91: Jinping Prefecture’s Midwinter Lantern Festival**
**Xuan Ying Cavern’s Tang Monk’s Deposition**

The **Awakened-to-One** says:
These next two chapters—**"Jinping Prefecture"**—
stand in direct contrast to the previous three—**"Yuhua Prefecture"**—
**"Yuhua"** represents the **inner Five Phases’** *law-symbols*,
**"Jinping"** the **outer Five Phases’** *law-symbols*.

This uniquely clarifies the **fire-moments** of external alchemy—
they must not be missed!
Thus the **lantern festival** is used as an analogy.

**Zi Yang True Person** says:
*"Lead meets **Geng**—quickly harvest the **mustache**,
Gold meets the **waning**—do not dare to taste!"*
And again:
*"Before the **first half of the month** and after the **second half**,
The **first half** of the **first half**—
When the **drug’s flavor** is balanced, the **qi-symbol** is complete."*

*"Lead meets **Geng**"*—the hour is **zi**.
*"Gold meets the **waning**"*—the moon is **waning**.

The **first half** belongs to **yang**, the **second half** to **yin**—
within **yin**, **yang** is balanced,
yielding **eight liang of gold** from water’s depths,
its flavor **balanced**, its **qi-symbol** **complete**.

From the **third day** to the **fifteenth**, the **Three Yangs** are full—
the *law-symbol* is **《Kǎn》**—
at this time, the **yin-essence water** is exhausted,
the **yang-essence gold** swells in its cycle,
thus the **full moon**, pure **yang** without **yin**,
hence the term **"waning moon"** is reversed.

Speaking of: **urgently** seizing the moment to work,
never delaying a **jǐ** or **kè**—
lest the **Heavenly Opportunity** be lost!

*"The fifteenth day of the first month, Upper Element’s Festival—
the **Golden Lantern Bridge** with three **golden lanterns**,"*
when the **gold within water** is fully balanced—
one must **see clearly** and **act swiftly**.

*"Not before the third watch,
or the wind will come,"*
meaning the **yin-qi** has already surged,
the **fire-moment** has passed—
now it is **untastable**.

*"Four people herding three sheep,
descending from the **Western Slope**,"*
proclaiming the meaning of **"Three Yangs’ Prosperity"**—
the **West** is the **White Tiger’s** direction,
where **yang** is born—
when the time arrives, it comes,
urgently demanding harvest.

*"Only because the **Master** relaxed his **Zen-nature**,
resting at **Ci Yun Temple** to enjoy pleasure,
did the **prosperity peak** fail to arrive,
and **joy’s extreme** give way to **sorrow**."*
Revealing: beyond this **moment**, **yang** gradually yields to **yin**,
and the **fire-moment** is **slightly missed**.

The **four** represent **year, month, day, and hour**—
the **eyes of the fire-moment**—
without the **fire-eyes of golden clarity**, who can recognize?

*"**Ming Tian County**"*—
the **meaning of weeping and wailing**.

*"Fragrant oil fills the nostrils,
its worth is **precious and rare**,
yet it is only lit for **three nights**"*—
when the moon rises in **yín**, it is **most precious and rare**,
like **people’s vital essence**—difficult to accumulate,
easy to exhaust—
not to be **wasted** in ordinary pursuits.

If one fails to grasp its **rare and fleeting** signs,
and mistakes a **false Buddha** for **true nature**—
great **pity** indeed!

See how they fail to recognize the **Western Slope’s** joy,
yet say: *"Here, the virtuous folk,
reading scriptures and chanting **Buddha**,
all hope to cultivate and be reborn in **China**."*

*"It is further said, ‘Westward to the Soul Mountain, we have not yet gone.’*
This speaks of direction as if it were mere place—west or east—
yet fails to grasp that west and east transcend mere locality.
It is as if one mistook the path’s beginning,
and thus strayed from the true way.

Like Tang Seng, who failed to discern the false,
and bowed before a Buddha—
his error was his own alone,
no blame upon others—
just as his own confession attests.

The opening line—
*‘Departing from Jade Flower City’*—
reveals its bordering with Golden Plateau.

Observe how idle wanderers,
entering Ci Yun Temple to rest their horses,
call the abbot one who ‘leisurely nurtures ease,’
and invite Tang Seng to ‘stay at leisure, to play awhile’—
all describing the blind, careless squandering of time,
hence their startled cry:
*‘We’ve wasted the very light of days!’*

The text subtly embeds the lesson of *viewing lanterns on Yuan Night*
to signify discerning the *fire-moment’s* urgency—
a meaning made plain.

As for *Averting Cold, Averting Heat, Averting Dust*,
and the pretense of ‘oil offerings to the Buddha,’
it lays bare a band of dissolute loafers,
who steal idle days in sham devotion—
mistaking falsehood for truth,
while life’s swift hours slip away.

The Pilgrim raged:
*‘You thieving oil-mouthed demon!’*
—truth recorded as fact.

For *‘oil’* is *‘wandering’*—
as *‘sheep’* is *‘yang’*—
a cipher in this book’s hidden speech.

Yet *‘thieving oil’* reveals
the failure to grasp the fire-moment’s critical hour,
and to seize what is past its time.

Oil belongs to water—*yin*.
The three tusks are *yin*-earth, things of water—also *yin*.
To steal by moonlight, when the time has passed,
is to plunder *yin* with *yin*—
how could such ever be true?
Thus, a false Buddha.

For those who deeply know the fire-moment’s essence,
yet seize it out of season, are thieves of the Dao.
Those who fail to grasp its truth,
and misuse it against its time—
are thieves of oil.

The same act of theft,
yet one true, one false—
so vast the difference.

Sha Monk said, *“Lest we lose the chance.”*
Eight Rules said, *“Seize this moonlit hour to subdue demons.”*
Both speak to this same truth.

Let the reader’s eye follow to the next chapter—
where the Green Dragon Mountain looms,
and deeper meaning awaits.

**Chapter Ninety-Two**
*The Three Monks Battle Green Dragon Mountain*
*The Four Stars Seize the Rhinoceros Demon*

A Disciple of Awakening says:
This clearly marks the theft of *yin* by *yin* as the false Buddha—
one must swiftly discern and destroy it,
to root out deceit and restore truth.

Oil is pure *yin*-water, dregs unfit for use,
symbolizing the distant, useless *yin* within man.
The Three Rogues, under false names and sacred guise,
bewitch the ignorant, claiming the Buddha’s heart requires oil,
that oil may nourish the Buddha—
yet they waste only fat and feed delusion.

Like those who seek the elixir but confuse *yin* and *yang*,
and refine in error—
how far they stray!

The chapter begins with *“Green Dragon Mountain’s Mystic Cavern”*—
pointing to the black, murky *qi* of the earth.

Green Dragon is the east’s *yin* within *yang*—
bright without, dark within—
as when a man’s four great limbs are all *yin*,
yet he knows not what is *yang* essence.

One must borrow a spark of *yang* light,
turn it inward to illuminate,
and drive back the host of *yin*—
only then does one abandon falsehood for truth,
know time and grasp the moment.

Hasten with keen discernment and fierce resolve,
lest you mistake the path,
and waste the chance!

Thus, the text explicitly begins with the words *“Great Battle”* to awaken the mind.

The practitioner transforms the Fire-Flame Insect to illuminate the cave,
beholding the demons with their doors shut, fast asleep—
like an endless night,
is it not a block of sheer *yin*,
akin to the black, dark abyss of hell,
without distinction of day or night?

The Master Tang was in the dark, marveling at *“the different scene in the West”*,
saying, *“Now it is the first month,
lantern bugs stir from their dormancy—
why are there lantern bugs flying?”*

The commentator notes that though the Master Tang recognized the climate,
he did not realize that the Master Tang himself sat in ignorance of the climate.

For *yin* and *yang* have the principle of inversion,
and advance and retreat know no fixed moment.
The scripture says:
*“The Winter Solstice does not fall on the hour of Zi,
the morning and evening are but empty comparisons of Mao and You.”*

If one judges the flying of lantern bugs by the lunar calendar,
it is as if taking midnight for the hour of Zi,
and morning and evening for Mao and You—
a great error! A great error!
Hence, the practitioner urgently replies:
*“Master! Because of your failure to discern truth from falsehood,
you have wasted so much time and expended so much effort!”*

Alas! Such idle, cold words
are enough to make those who mistake *yin* essence and lag in seizing the moment
break out in a cold sweat.

The lantern’s glow appears only in darkness—
a *yang* within *yin*—
if one could always turn the light inward,
it would suffice to guide the lost.

The Master Tang’s astonishment at its untimely flight,
and the False Buddha’s door-shut slumber,
share the same confusion—
how could they not confess their crimes?

Locking them away in darkness,
yet eager to escape—
it is like covering one’s ears to steal a bell,
how could they hope to gain anything?

Sha Monk said:
*“Could it be that they are harming my master in secret?”*
The foolish one said:
*“Thieves stealing oil!”*

Everywhere, their true nature is revealed—
truly awakening the mind.
*“At this time, about the third watch,
the moon’s light in the sky is like daytime,”*
yet why were the Eight Rules and Sha Monk bound?

The moon is a *yang* within *yin*,
when *yin* qi moves with the moment,
abandoning darkness for brightness,
it gains the upper hand—
a subtle confirmation of the timing’s truth.

But the hour of Chou is the domain of earth,
wood can subdue earth,
so they should ascend to the East—
yet why did the practitioner ascend to the West?

Upon seeing the Great White Star of Metal,
he inquired into its origins,
revealing the strategy of tracing to the root—
in the True Gold, he discerned its falsehood.

In the earlier capture at Jade Flower State,
the lion should have ascended to the West to meet the Tathāgata—
yet why did it ascend to the East to meet the Lord of East Peak, the Marvelous Rock of the Supreme One?

In the True One, he settled the chaos.
The same principle applies:
the Jade Flower’s Tiger’s Maw Cave,
the Green Dragon Mountain of the Golden Plateau—
both display the marvel of inverted *yin* and *yang*,
and reciprocal illumination.

*“The half-rhino demon, barely formed,
can be subdued only by the four Wood-Beast stars.”*
The reader says that wood subdues earth
is the common principle of the Five Phases,
with no deeper meaning.

Yet here we see the true distinction between reality and illusion.

For the Dao of true immortals,
inverts the primordial *yang* of Heavenly Antiquity,
and through fire refining gold, the true gold emerges—
the marvel of seeing lanterns on the New Year’s Eve.

The False Buddha’s demonic essence,
follows the *yin* of the later Heaven,
and through wood subduing earth, the false earth collapses—
the error of lantern bugs flying at the third watch.

Thus, within the cave,
he rescued the Master Tang and his disciples,
gathering many pearls, jade, gold, and treasures—
wood aiding fire to purify the true gold,
as pearls and jewels enhance their luster.

Earth, injured by fire,
strips away the false earth clinging to the gold—
like the rhino’s retreat from its tracks.

Hence, the three rhinos fled for their lives,
daring not to enter the southern lands where fire thrives,
but instead plunging into the western seas where waters run deep—
they sought survival in the place where they were subdued,
yet did not know that in fleeing life,
they sought death.

Such is the folly of ignorance and misapplication—
contrary, perverse, and erroneous.

The scripture says:
*“Fire arises from wood,
disaster strikes when it is subdued.”*
Harvesting *yin* to cultivate wood,
the disaster of fire burning oneself—
the Four Wood-Beast stars align with Tianpeng,
thus their condemnation of the three rhinos is just,
truly knowing the clear principles of dharma and law—
how could they fail to punish according to the law?

It says:
*“Oafish rhino demons,
cloaked in hair and horn,
unaware of the meaning of ‘Three Yangs Open Tai,’
foolishly boasting of the three rhinos’ ability to flee.
Lazy and thieving,
they deceive the masses to amass wealth.
With the False Buddha’s face,
they devour living souls,
acting with cunning and deceit.
Riding the demonic wind,
they drain vital essence,
spreading their rampant chaos far and wide.
They grasp not the mechanism of growth and decay,
nor the wisdom of retreat and approach.
Burning their own nests,
they expose the law’s clarity—
beheading and dismembering,
they fulfill the people’s vengeance.”*

Hahaha!

The practitioner, having circled the **Golden Level Prefecture** ([金平府 *Jīnpíng Fǔ*]), issued a command midair—
the **True Law** ([真法 *Zhēnfǎ*]) thundered like rain, a spectacle all, wise or foolish, revered.

Master and disciple rose at the fifth watch,
stealthily crossing **Chen Cang** ([陈仓 *Chéncāng*]—lit. "Dark passage through Chen Cang"),
lest they be punished for their **reckless complacency** ([偷安错认 *tōu’ān cuòrèn*]) and stray from the path.

From now on,
they must **hasten their cultivation** ([修行 *xiūxíng*])—
no more delays!

**Chapter 93**
*At the **Giving Alone Garden** ([给孤园 *Gěigū Yuán*]), ancient tales are pondered, causes discussed,*
*The **Chao King** ([朝王 *Cháowáng*]) of **India** ([天竺 *Tiānjú*]) meets with chance.*

The **Awakened One** ([悟一子 *Wùyī Zǐ*]) said:
*"This passage, from beginning to end, repeats itself time and again.
After closing the scroll and deep reflection,
I still cannot grasp its meaning."*

**Suzi** ([苏子 *Sūzǐ*]) replied:
*"Reading books, one should not seek excessive understanding."*

Yet—
may one not understand it through not understanding?
If one insists on forcing an understanding, it would say:
*"Cultivators refine only the mind ([修道者修心 *xiūdào zhě xiūxīn*])—
the mind is inherently empty ([空洞无物 *kōngdòng wúwù*]), devoid of speech or script.
What need for words or letters?"*

The passage states:
*"‘No words or letters’ ([无言语文字 *wú yányǔ wénzì*]) is the true understanding ([真解 *zhēnjiě*]),*
*and this is the ‘**discussion of causes** ([谈因 *tán yīn*])’ ([因 *yīn*]).*

When **Tang Seng** ([唐僧 *Tángsēng*]) and **Xingzhe** ([行者 *Xíngzhě*]) say:
*"‘We understand it’ ([解得 *jiědé*])"*—
they mean this.

When they say:
*"‘At **Golden Level Monastery** ([布金禅寺 *Bùjīn Chántí*]), the **World-Honored One** ([世尊 *Shìzūn*]) was invited to deliver the **dharma** ([说法 *shuōfǎ*])’"*—
they speak of this.

When they say:
*"‘How many scholars are there in the world,
yet their bellies are hollow’ ([肚子里空空 *dùzǐ lǐ kōngkōng*])"*—
they refer to this emptiness ([空 *kōng*]).

When they say:
*"‘The old **Arhat** ([老和尚 *lǎo héshàng*]), **Tang Seng**, and **Xingzhe** in the **Giving Alone Garden** ([给孤园 *Gěigū Yuán*]) enjoy the moon,*
*listening to the **painful cries** ([痛苦之声 *tòngkǔ zhī shēng*]) and feeling their hearts ache’"*—
they mean this **emotional resonance** ([感触 *gǎnchù*]).

When they say:
*"‘In matters of sorrow and lament,
none but this **master** ([师家 *shījiā*]) can discern them clearly’ ([明辨 *míngbiàn*])"*—
they speak of this **discernment** ([明辨 *míngbiàn*]).

When they say:
*"‘**San Zang** ([三藏 *Sānzàng*]) and **Xingzhe** ([行者 *Xíngzhě*]), having heard this,
held it deeply in their hearts’ ([切切在心 *qièqiè zàixīn*])"*—
they mean this **deep reflection** ([切切 *qièqiè*]).

When they say:
*"‘Hoping to return to the country and widely apply the **dharma’s power** ([法力 *fǎlì*])’"*—
they speak of this **broad practice** ([广施 *guǎngshī*]).

The saying of **"discussion of causes"** ([谈因 *tán yīn*]),
is it so?
Or is it not?

If one were to force an interpretation and say:
*"Those who cultivate the Dao merely gather the primordial yang true-qi*—
then the true understanding is that body and mind must be harmonized, and yin-yang paired in union—
this is called **"encountering the pair"** ([遇偶 *yù'ǒu*]).*

When they say:
*"‘All rush off to watch the tossing of the embroidered ball’"*—
they mean this **gathering** ([采取 *cǎiqǔ*]).

When they say:
*"‘The Pilgrim does not forget the old monk’s words,
and together they go to the painted pavilion to discern truth from falsehood’"*—
they speak of this **discernment** ([辨明 *biànmíng*]).

When they say:
*"‘The false Princess, knowing that San Zang would arrive today at this very hour,
borrowed the moment to gather’"*—
they mean this **gathering** ([采取 *cǎiqǔ*]).

When they say:
*"‘From the pavilion, they cried in unison:
“A monk has been struck!”’"*—
they speak of this **striking** ([打着 *dǎzhe*]).

When they say:
*"‘The three of us will enter the court—
within ourselves, we shall know how to discern’"*—
they mean this **discrimination** ([辨别 *biànbié*]).

When they say:
*"‘The Pilgrim said:
“Fool, do not speak recklessly!
First pack our belongings—
then we shall proceed to court to offer protection”’"*—
they speak of this **protection** ([保护 *bǎohù*]).

The saying of **"encountering the pair"** ([遇偶 *yù'ǒu*]),
is it so?
Or is it not?

「If one insists on forcing a literal interpretation,
then let one listen to it as such—
yet in truth, the answer is a resounding *no*.
But to abandon this and seek another true interpretation,
one would leave the reader utterly perplexed.

This is the **limit of the True Dharma** ([正法限 *zhèngfǎ xiàn*]),
a **separate transmission outside the teachings** ([教外别传 *jiào wài bié chuán*]),
which cannot be expressed in words.

In the verse, *“The Dao is in the sacred transmission, its practice lies within oneself”* ([道在圣传修在已 *Dào zài shèngchuán xiū zài yǐ*]),
the seven characters have been **explained** ([解 *jiě*]),
yet it is said that the meaning can be **transmitted** ([传 *chuán*]),
but not **explicated** ([解 *jiě*]).

The **Pilgrim** ([唐僧 *Táng Sēng*]) received the *Heart Sutra* ([《心经》 *Xīn Jīng*]) from **Master Wu Chao** ([乌巢禅师 *Wū Cháo Chánshī*]).
When **Master Wu Chao** said, *“You are reciting it in a muddled way,”*
**the Pilgrim** ([行者 *Xíngzhě*]) replied:
*“Master, you only recited it—
you never sought to explain it to me.”*

Since **San Zang** ([三藏 *Sān Zàng*]) had never **explained** ([解 *jiě*]),
upon being prompted, he declared:
*“You damned monkey! How dare you say I never **explained** ([解 *jiě*]) it?
Do *you* understand it?”*
The **Pilgrim** ([行者 *Xíngzhě*]) answered:
*“I understand it.”*
From then on, he made no further sound.

Readers may take this as **Master Zhū** ([夫子 *Fūzǐ*]) calling upon **Pán** ([参 *Shēn*]),
but they do not realize that here,
the **Master** ([师 *shī*]) **transmits** ([授 *shòu*]) to the **disciple** ([徒 *tú*]),
while in the original,
the **disciple** ([徒 *tú*]) **transmits** ([授 *shòu*]) to the **Master** ([师 *shī*]).
This is the **reverse method of the Daoist path** ([仙道逆法 *Xiāndào nìfǎ*]),
with its own profound significance.

When **Eight Rules** ([八戒 *Bā Jiè*]) pressed him to **explicate** ([解 *jiě*]),
**Sha Monk** ([沙僧 *Shā Sēng*]) said:
*“Big brother is spouting nonsense,
tricking Master to move on.”*
Both were **unaware of the explanation** ([不知解者 *bù zhī jiě zhě*]).

Thus, **San Zang** ([三藏 *Sān Zàng*]) declared:
*“Sun Wukong’s **explication** ([解 *jiě*]) is beyond words and letters—
it is the **true explication** ([真解 *zhēnjiě*]).
What is this **true explication** ([真解 *zhēnjiě*])?”*

The ancient Master of Nanquan instructed the assembly, saying:
*"The heart is not the Buddha, wisdom is not the Dao."*

Chen Nihuan remarked:
*"There is another layer of strangeness beyond strangeness—
the heart and kidneys are not the *Kàn-Lí* [坎离] of yin and yang.
Spirit, soul, heart, mind, and qi—
when observed, they seem real yet are ultimately not."*

Master Lü said:
*"The Four Great Elements [四大] of the body are all yin—
where then does the yang essence reside?"*
And again:
*"Do not cling to this body as the Dao,
for solitary cultivation of a single thing is but solitary yin."*

When Master Tí Lǎng asked Stonehead [石头], *"What is the Buddha?"*
Stonehead replied: *"You have no Buddha-nature."*

Master Wúyè, of noble bearing, met Master Mazu, who said:
*"This grand Buddha Hall stands empty—
within it, no Buddha dwells."*

A monk asked Master Shànjué:
*"Does this dog still possess Buddha-nature?"*
*"I am not a sentient being,"* he replied.
*"If you are not a sentient being,"* the monk pressed, *"are you then the Buddha?"*
*"No,"* the master said.
*"Then what in truth are you?"*
*"Nor am I a thing."*
*"Can it be grasped or perceived?"*
*"Thought cannot reach it, analogy cannot grasp it—
thus it is said to be beyond thought and comparison."*

Though the nature of the *Xìngtán* [杏坛] is without limits,
yet Master Zǐyú’s cultivation of qi is said to be difficult,
for he spoke of the sages of the Three Teachings
never taking the heart as the Dao,
but striving instead for the utmost in *géwù zhìzhī* [格物致知].

If one reads the *Heart Sutra* and claims *"mind is Buddha,"*
then one has failed to grasp the subtlety of *color-emptiness, emptiness-color*.
Its profundity cannot be conveyed through words or letters—
thus the Master *"never spoke again."*

Yet neither is it *"non-heart, non-Buddha,"*
for it cannot be awakened by the mind alone—
one must await transmission from the Master before understanding.

Hence, when Jìgū’s nobleman paved the garden with gold
to purchase the Jeta Grove,
only then could he invite the World-Honored One to teach—
how lightly such truths can be passed on!

How many scholars pore over these texts,
yet their minds remain hollow—
who among them truly knows?
Deeply lamentable!

If one takes these hollow, cold words
and claims they are but the idle verse of poets Jia Dao or Bai Juyi,
then one’s understanding is shallow indeed!

He speaks of *"Bǎijiǎo Mountain"*—
a hidden warning that pure yin’s domain is no place for action.
He mentions *"Jīmíng Pass"*—
one must await the return of yang’s first stir.

*"At this moment, the crescent moon shines bright,"*
revealing where the Dao/Way resides.
*"Suddenly, a Daoist arrives with news: ‘The Master has come.’"*

Led to the Jeta Grove where the World-Honored One taught,
walking beneath the moon’s glow, the heart still—
when a voice, tragic and sharp, pierces the silence.
*"Tragic"*—that is *"non-heart"*;
*"sharp"*—the soil of *"knife-and-pill"*,
not of the heart, yet truly piercing.

Ah, the wonder of it!
*"The matter of this tragic cry
is beyond even this Master’s clear discernment."*
Unless one meets a monk like Tang Seng,
no further words may be spoken.
*"It is beyond speech or letters—
only true understanding remains."*

*"Last year’s same day,"*
when the crescent moon shone bright—
*"at the very moment of clear nature’s illumination,
a gust of wind suddenly rose,
and a voice, tragic and sharp, broke through."*
Upon the Jeta platform stood
a maiden of exquisite beauty and grace.

Within this moonlit scene,
the World-Honored One’s teaching place
suddenly scattered heavenly flowers,
summoning celestial maidens—
not to be mistaken for demons or ill omens.

Here, the Buddha had already bestowed
the True Dharma Eye upon Xuánzàng.
Thus, when the Three Pilgrims heard,
they grasped its profundity—
to be held close in the heart.

*"Close"*—that is *"knife-and-pill"* soil.
As the Master and disciples prepared to depart,
the old monk again urged the tragic matter,
and the Pilgrim laughed in reply:
*"I understand! I understand!"*
The transmission now clear,
just as the flower was plucked and a smile exchanged.

Like the crowing of the golden rooster,
they awoke suddenly—
free to take the great road,
passing the pass unobstructed by Bǎijiǎo Mountain.

From there, they pressed straight to the Golden City’s celestial treasury,
together ascending the painted pavilion to watch the ball of embroidered silk.
*"Painted"*—the five hues, the radiant colors of the Five Phases;
*"ball"*—the Supreme Ultimate, the perfect union of yin and yang.

Tang Seng suddenly recalled:
*"My mother also cast the embroidered ball—
a fateful encounter that bound us in marriage."*
Ah, the wonder!
From the very source of birth,
one awakens to this thread of destiny—
the original face itself.

The opening poem declares:
*"Whether becoming immortal or Buddha,
one must arrange it from here."*
Alas! Who could fail to arrange it
from the very place of one’s parents’ birth?

The false princess sought the monk’s true *qi*
to become a celestial being;
the true monk could not be deceived by her,
lest he fall into hell.

The Pilgrim’s ability to discern truth from falsehood
is precisely his grasp of the *Heart Sutra*.

The Pilgrim devises the *"leaning on marriage to summon demons"* stratagem—
Tang Seng nods in silent understanding,
while the King of India and the false princess remain unaware.
Eight Rules and Sha Wujing exchange playful banter,
the stationmaster’s words are upside-down—
just as the *Lotus Sutra* warns:
*"If such matters are spoken of,
all heavens and all people
will be filled with astonishment and doubt."*

I have drawn out this lengthy tale,
yet have not truly fathomed a single character of the *Heart Sutra*—
no different from the Master’s *"never speaking again."*

On that day, Tang Seng walked beneath the moon in the Jeta Grove,
met an old monk,
and upon hearing the tragic cry, awakened.

Oh, reader—do not cling to the text in vain imaginings!
Could you not also meet the old monk,
stroll beneath the crescent moon’s light,
and listen for the tragic cry?

**Ninety-fourth Chapter**
*The Four Monks Feast in the Palace Garden*
*A Monster Harbors Lustful Desire*

**A Disciple’s Awakening:**
These next two chapters I did not wish to explain,
for fear that explanation would only deepen confusion.

The Buddha said:
*"If such matters are spoken of,
all heavens and all people
will be filled with astonishment and doubt."*
That mortals should be astonished is due to their narrow vision—
let that pass.
But why should even the heavens be astonished?
Then there must be matters truly astonishing and doubtful.

Thus, I refrain from explanation,
lest I add to the confusion of others.
Some may say this is but the fiction of *Meng Liang’s Plum Garden*,
or the allegory of *Zhi Yuan’s Ink Garden*—
yet they cannot fathom what is performed or what is concealed.

Truly, to mock the book’s clear references—
like taking the jade hare and teasing it with the south wind—
is a grave sin!

Let us take the book’s most evident passages and explain them,
so that astonishment and doubt may be set aside.

All have read *Journey to the West*—
should the *"factor"* in *"discussing the factor"* not be emphasized?
*"Factor"*—that which gives rise.

This chapter discusses the *factor* before one’s parents’ birth,
and the *factor* that follows birth.

All have read the *I Ching*—
should the *"encounter"* in *"encountering偶"* not be emphasized?
*"Encounter"*—the yin line.

This chapter reveals:
*Kàn* moving and falling into *Kūn*, forming *Kǎn*;
*Kūn* moving and falling into *Kàn*, forming *Lí*—
the paired configurations.

On that day, the World-Honored One, with compassion for all beings,
spoke of the *factor* in his teaching,
for those who would escape birth and death
must first know the *factor* of their birth,
and only then may they learn to die.

As when treating illness—
one must first know the root of the disease
before the proper remedy can be applied.

Thus, before entering the Jeta Grove, the *factor* was discussed,
and before entering the Palace Garden, the *factor* was questioned.
Only through the subtlety of questioning the *factor* in the Palace Garden
can one truly grasp the principle of discussing the *factor* in the Grove.

Hence, I pause here to speak of the *factor* before birth.

When Tang Seng reached the Golden Hall,
the king asked:
*"From where have you come, monk?"*

---

The king inquired: *"Where did the three of you originate? What are their surnames and given names? Why did they take ordination? Which scriptures do they seek?"*

Was this not asking about the *factor* of their coming?

The monk replied: *"Your Majesty asks of my coming *factor*—I shall now declare it."*

Was this not asking about the *factor* of their coming?

The Pilgrim responded: *"My father is Heaven, my mother Earth; once I paid homage to the Supreme Sage and mastered the Great Dao. It was only due to the chaos of the Peach Blossom Festival, where I rebelled against the Celestial Palace, that I was pressed beneath the Five-Phase Mountain."*

Was this not the *factor* of their coming?

Eight Rules spoke: *"All my life I was in confusion, until I met a true Sage. I diligently cultivated the twenty-four practices and reverently refined the sixty-six precepts. It was only because, drunk from the Peach Blossom Festival wine, I teased Chang'e, that I was banished to the mortal realm."*

Was this not the *factor* of their coming?

Sand Rules said: *"Fearful of rebirth, I encountered a celestial companion. I nurtured a child and completed the marriage of a maiden. It was at the Peach Blossom Festival gathering that I dropped a cup, shattering it, and was thus exiled to the Flowing Sands."*

Was this not the *factor* of their coming?

If one does not recognize the *factor* of their coming, then the biographies of the Three Disciples are fully recorded in the earlier chapters—this repetition seems redundant and meaningless. Yet it reveals the root of the Great Dao, which must be unveiled in the World-Honored One’s teaching at the Golden Hall and clarified in the Palace Garden’s display of the Dao.

Though the monk’s *factor* of coming has already been spoken of, the Pilgrim said: *"Fortunate is my Master, who departed from the Eastern Lands to pay homage in the Western Realm."*
Eight Rules said: *"I protect Tang Seng on his direct journey to the Western Heaven."*
Sand Rules said: *"I follow the Buddhist disciple of the Tang Dynasty to the Western Heaven."*

This seems to restate the *factor* of their coming anew, yet it also reveals their original unity as Master and disciples.

The Three Disciples all originated from the Peach Blossom Festival, showing that their brothers were born from the same *qi*.

Originally, they were of the *Qián* (乾) nature—only when one moved did it become *one* (一), and when one *odd* (奇) changed into *pair* (偶), the true yang was submerged, giving rise to *Kūn* (坤), which then formed *Kàn* (坎), while *Qián* (乾) formed *Lí* (離). In this moment of confusion, the matching of yin and yang was achieved, and this is the true principle of the *factor* of their coming—they encountered the *pair*.

If earlier, the True Princess fell into the Golden Hall, a pure *Qián* (乾) place that became the *Lí* (離) configuration;
then the Three Tripitaka Master and disciples all arrived in the Palace Garden, within the *Kūn* (坤) realm, forming the *Kàn* (坎) symbol—this is the differing *factor* of their coming, yet still an encounter with the *pair*.

The profound meaning of this chapter cannot be fully exhausted.

As the Pilgrim said: *"We ordained beings progress step by step."*
Now, *"discussing the factor"* and *"encountering the pair"* may indeed be called *"a step forward."*

Let me further advance a step for all—do not be startled or doubtful at what the World-Honored One has said.

The True Princess is the transformed body of Tang Seng’s Three Disciples;
Tang Seng’s Three Disciples are the divided forms of the True Princess.

Why so?

The True Princess is *yang* within and *yin* without—though appearing as a female form, she is truly male.
The Three Disciples are *yang* without and *yin* within—though appearing as male forms, they are truly female bodies.

The *Awakening to Reality Chapter* states:
*"The sun residing in the *Lí* (離) position yet becomes female,
the moon paired in the *Kàn* (坎) yet is truly male.
Those who do not grasp this inverted meaning
should not presume to speak loftily of worldly matters."*

This is the *factor* that can be endlessly discussed.

Let the assembly advance yet another step: The False Princess is but the borrowed form of Tang Seng’s Three Disciples and the True Princess;
Tang Seng’s Three Disciples and the True Princess are likewise the borrowed forms of the False Princess.

Why so?

A stir in the Heavenly Palace gives rise to wrath and desire,
a stir in the Moon Palace gives rise to wrath and desire—
all from one movement, all one monstrous essence.

Because of the Moon Hare’s monstrous theft into the Yin Palace,
it thus mingled into the Palace, thus overturned the Heavenly Palace,
thus made it impossible to settle the outcome.

Yet the False Princess was not wrought by Jade Hare—
it was all wrought by Tang Seng’s Three Disciples and the True Princess.

Tang Seng’s present fall into the *Kūn* (坤) Palace
was not wrought by the False Princess—
it was all wrought by the Pilgrim’s rebellion against Heaven,
self-inflicted.

Tang Seng’s present marriage to the False Princess
was not wrought by the False Princess—
it was all wrought by Eight Rules’ drunken sport with Chang’e,
self-invited.

Tang Seng’s present striking of the embroidered ball
was not wrought by the False Princess—
it was all wrought by Sha Monk shattering the glass cup,
self-struck.

The True Princess’s entrapment at the Cloth-of-Gold Temple
was not wrought by the False Princess—
it was all wrought by Suo E’s single palm of worldly longing,
self-trapped.

The Five Phases coalesce into one *qi*,
the Three Monks coalesce into one Monk—
divide their forms, and four may arise;
a myriad truths are but one truth,
one monstrosity becomes a hundred monstrosities—
yet in essence, none but one.

Thus, the True Princess is again Tang Seng’s Three Disciples,
Tang Seng’s Three Disciples are again the True Princess.
Tang Seng’s Three Disciples and the True Princess
are again the False Princess.

Today’s ball-throwing and marriage invitations
were not wrought by the False Princess—
they were all wrought by Suo E’s single palm.

This is the *factor* that cannot be endlessly discussed.

Advance yet further: For men to seek women is the norm of propriety.
Why does the False Princess, as a woman, seek men as if marrying a bride?
This inversion has its cause.

Let the assembly advance yet another step: All the thousand demons and hundred fiends across the hundred chapters
are but one monstrosity—
all wrought by the False Princess’s single monstrosity.

All the myriad trials and difficulties across the hundred chapters
are but one movement—
all wrought by the True Princess’s single palm.

The causes of true and false are indeed beyond clear distinction!

This comes from the "meeting of pairs" within the *factor*.

The assembly may wish to advance yet another step, yet fear touches upon matters that are startling and dubious—
thus, one cannot but halt here.

Within the chapter:
*"The traveler, pondering the elder’s words, proceeds to investigate true and false."*

He declares:
*"If she is a true woman, then you shall become a son-in-law."*
Again he says:
*"At the wedding ceremony, let us all cause a commotion and take her away."*
*"Master and disciple shall follow one another without a moment’s separation."*
All are but expressions of the intent to clarify cause and effect,
and to seek liberation through self-understanding.

The *"Hall of Pacifying Flowers"* must clarify the true nature of gold,
while the *"Pavilion of Retaining Spring"* must clarify the falsity of lingering.
Man lingers in Spring, ascending to Pacify Flowers—
one must discern the true through the false;
each partakes in feasting, compelled to rejoice—
again, the false responds to the false.

In spring, summer, autumn, and winter,
one should forget emotions by aligning with the scene—
within the false, there lies the true;
at joyous gatherings of auspicious times,
though one may lead and the other follow,
within the true, there lies the false.

Cupping wine and sleeping deeply—
true, yet not truly true;
playing and shouting—
false, yet not falsely false.

The twelve auspicious days hold genuine marvels,
yet the cluster of flowers is but hollow blossoms.

The *Zhao Yang Palace* performs grotesque music,
fearing that the true may shatter the false;
in the *Imperial Flower Garden*, counting on fingers—
fearing that the false may shatter the true.

To restrain the heart, to evade the body—
the true may become false;
to depart the *Soul Mountain*, to transform the form—
the false may become true.

Manifesting the true body, transforming into a bee,
the false union, the *Crow and Magpie Palace*—
false within false, true within true—
indescribable in rigid terms.

Yet its origins, though still discernible,
are such that only the *Buddhist monk of the Golden Pagoda*
can clarify the true and false causes and effects—
none but Tang Sanzang and his three disciples can do so.

Let one carefully ponder the next chapter,
where *"Meeting Pairs"* again reveals the marvel of origins.

---
**Ninety-fifth Chapter: False Form Captures the Jade Hare, True Yin Returns to Meet the Soul Element**

A disciple awoke and said:
*"The Golden Crow and Jade Hare are the essence of sun and moon;
the waning, new, full, and crescent phases are the union of yin and yang.
Heaven and man share no separate principles—
divine motion follows its own natural laws.
The moon borrows the sun’s light to illuminate,
yin relies on yang’s function to manifest its use.
Those who willingly enter the cycle of rebirth
let their minds follow *qi* in transformation,
thus true and false alternately divide and multiply;
those who escape death and life
preserve their nature while reversing *qi*,
thus true and false ultimately merge as one.

Urgent is the need to clarify and seize with resolve;
do not delay, lest they slip away.
This chapter precisely clarifies the origins of true and false—
it is the true exposition of the *Heart Sutra*.
It is the monk of the Golden Pagoda’s earnest, sorrowful admonition.

Clarity lies within clarity itself,
yet one cannot distinguish beyond it.
When moonlight is brightest, golden *qi* fills the wheel—
pointing to the moon and verifying its imprint,
the marvel of paired union becomes true.

The essential technique lies in seeing without seeing color,
remaining entirely free of thought.
Thus, at the chapter’s opening, the traveler sees his master
completely unmoved, and exclaims in awe:
*"What a monk!"*
The foundation of not moving the mind
must be seen through and the true and false discerned.

The traveler, seeing through it, cries:
*"Master, the princess is false!"*
The elder replies:
*"She is false—yet how shall we make her reveal her true form?"*
Ah! How wondrous!

Recognizing the true within the false—
this is the Buddha who came from the West.

For the false is the false princess;
yet what is the "false of the false"?
Within the false there remains the true—
only when the true form is revealed
does one attain clear discernment.

*"How shall we make her reveal her form?"*
Then there must be a method indeed.

The traveler says:
*"Summon the *dharma-body*, and seize her here."*
Thus it is clear the traveler too is a false form.

If she does not reveal her true nature,
then false is joined with false—
the true becomes indistinguishable.

Hence, *"Once the true form is revealed,
he steps forward and seizes her,
shouting: ‘You here fabricate falsehood as truth,
deceiving my master’s true *yang*!’*
The monk clutches the king, crying:
*"Your Majesty, fear not!
This is my wayward disciple using *fa-li* to discern true from false."*
He also consoles the queen:
*"Fear not!
Your princess is but a false form made to seem true."*

Throughout, the words *"true"* and *"false"* are the key.

*"The false princess shed her garments,
cast aside her ornaments,
and in haste discarded her falsehood—
her true essence now manifest,
she fought with the monk."*

Here lies the divine subtlety, utterly free of falsehood—
this is the true within the union of falseness.

When the battle raged long,
and they neared the Western Paradise,
it was revealed as a golden being of the West—
turning back to the gate of the Western Land,
suddenly *"with a wave of his body,
golden light radiated in ten thousand rays,
hurling straight toward the south."*

Reaching a great mountain,
he pressed upon the golden light,
plunged into the cave—
and vanished without trace.

Thus the West is his native land,
while the South is but his borrowed abode.

As the *Yijing* says:
*"In the southwest, companions appear—
one may walk with them in harmony."*

The traveler gathered his forces and returned.
At this point, the immortal master pointed to the profound Dao, saying:
*"This is the hour of *shen*."*

Why this sudden mention of *"shen"*?
*"Shen"* is metal—
*ren* water thrives in *shen*.
Is it time?
Is it *shen* itself?
Or *"shen hour"*?
The hidden meaning leaps forth.

Those with innate immortal essence,
reading this passage,
should reverently set up an incense altar,
bow a hundred times in devotion, and say:
*"Homage to the Great Compassionate, Great Merciful,
Savior of Suffering, Most Benevolent, Most Holy,
Most Wondrous Great Bodhisattva."*

The king asks:
*"If the false princess is a demon,
where then is my true princess?"*

The traveler replies:
*"Seize the false princess,
and the true one will naturally appear."*
The true lies within the false—
when the false is captured,
the true emerges effortlessly.
This is the authentic method of saving truth through falsehood.

At this juncture, vigilance is paramount.
*"Dividing inner and outer,
keeping the heart ever watchful."*
This passage speaks to the critical work of guarding against peril—
most urgent of all!

Only thus may one clearly discern true from false,
lest one waste effort in vain.

The traveler ascends to the southern peak, where the demon retreats into its lair, feigning cowardice and hiding. The mountain spirit declares:
*"This mountain, from ancient times to now, has never harbored a demon—it is a land of fivefold auspicious *yáng* energy. If the Great Sage seeks a demon, he should look toward the Western Heavenly Path."*

This reveals the limited wisdom of one unable to discern true from false. Little do they know that the five radiant *yáng* lands are precisely where the essence of *jīn* (metal) lies concealed. Then:

*"When the traveler reaches the southern peak’s cavern, two massive stones block the entrance. With an iron rod, he pries them apart—the demon, startled, leaps out with a ‘whoosh!’ Terrifying the mountain spirit and earth god into frantic retreat."*

This is what is meant by *"speaking the truth sends demons into panic."*

A true practitioner recognizes that where five-colored lotuses bloom atop a mountain, the earth’s rivers and mountains are but a single jewel hidden within. True and false intertwine—who can truly distinguish them?

Suddenly, the Star of Lesser Yin reveals how the Jade Rabbit stole the elixir, exposing the case of Chang’e’s descent to the mortal realm. With the truth laid bare, the demon’s original form is exposed—*"rolling about to reveal its true nature."*

Thus, the luminosity of Lesser Yin illuminates the true and false of Lesser Yin itself; beyond this illumination, there is no other light.

*"A radiant patch of clouds appears in the south, bright as day"*—this marks the moment when the Jade Rabbit returns to its true form. The traveler’s loud cry awakens the deluded. Eight Rules’ lustful impulse is a warning against carnal desire. The king inquires further, realizing the false princess was the true Jade Rabbit, while the true princess was the false one. By removing the false and seeking the true, the old monk’s urgent words at the Golden Temple become clear.

When the Jade Rabbit is returned to the Moon Palace, the true *yīn* returns to India. Retracing the illusions of moon-viewing and ball-playing, recounting the tragic separation of mother and child, and reforming the subjugation system of the Precious Flower Monastery—these lingering details all touch upon profound truths. Yet to truly discern true from false, one must awaken the heart.

Further clarification: The false princess is indeed false—false in her assumed form, yet before assuming it, she was true. Before capture, she was the false princess; once exposed, she became true. False yet truly real—who can distinguish this?

The true *yīn* is the true princess. Only after returning to purity is she truly true; before that, she cannot be called true. Only when she returns to purity can she reunite with the *língyuán*—can she be said to reunite with it before purity? Even this is false. True yet truly false—who can distinguish this?

Deeper still: The Jade Rabbit is a celestial beast; Chang’e is a celestial maiden. Within the Moon Palace, only the Jade Rabbit’s spirit is vital—all the immortals’ elixirs depend on its mortar and pestle. The Moon Palace can do without Chang’e, but not the Jade Rabbit. The Rabbit is the false consort of the king’s realm yet the true one of the Moon Palace; Chang’e is the true consort of the *Kūn* (receptive) realm yet the false one of the *Qián* (creative) realm. This too must be discerned.

Earlier, the traveler remarked:
*"A woman’s husband is her noble one—how could he not be seated?"*
The character *"seated"* (坐) combines two *"people"* (人) into *"earth"* (土). Earth contains *wù-jǐ* (the five earthly branches), and without this earth, a person cannot pair—*"seated"* is the subtle essence of *"deeply in mind."*

The Buddha said:
*"Within the *qián-kūn*, between heaven and earth, there is a treasure hidden in the form-mountain, not in the heart or kidneys, but in the *xiānguān* orifice."*
The term *"noble"* (貴) symbolizes *"a treasure within"* and is the essence of *"urgent matters."*

As for *"India"* (天竺) and *"Precious Flower"* (寶華), *"heaven"* (天) is *"two people"* (二人), *"India"* (竺) is *"two"* (二个)—within lies the birth of the Precious Treasure, the essence of *"encountering a match."*

The final four words—*"realized nature"* (了性) and *"true emptiness"* (真空)—are not to be confused with the annihilation of nature or empty stillness. These must be clearly distinguished.

**Ninety-sixth Chapter: Leak the Official Welcomes a High Monk, Tang the Elder Rejects Wealth and Nobility**

A disciple asked: In the following two chapters, the calamities of protecting the *dharma* and destroying the *dharma* are shown as one. One uses the slaughter of ten thousand monks as an analogy; the other feigns inviting ten thousand monks. Practitioners must scrutinize their intentions—relying on those with great virtue and strength to protect the *dharma*, not flaunting wealth to invite disaster.

At the chapter’s start:
*"The Pilgrim asks his disciples, ‘What place is this?’ The traveler replies, ‘I do not know, I do not know.’"*
These two *"I do not know"* are the key insight.

Human hearts are unfathomable, and circumstances ever-changing. A tiger may sit guard at the gate, yet the host invites monks to a feast—how can one say one cannot eat at a tiger’s mouth? The surname *Kòu* (寇) suggests banditry, yet the host shows no plundering intent—why suspect the *Kòu* clan and harbor doubts? An old woman fears no ugliness, recognizing the celestial and human realms—why then the shift from respect to rudeness? The heart is unfathomable.

The son, though seemingly aligned, bows in submission—yet why does a good beginning turn to ruin? Circumstances are ever-changing. At the close of spring and dawn of summer, when the *dào* flows freely, listening to two discuss rise and fall demands vigilant reflection.

The **Copper Terrace Hall** is a place where one may share in the golden splendor; the **Earthly Spirits County**, a land fortunate to host men of outstanding talent.
*"It stirs the townsfolk to such alarm—startled and fearful, speculating and suspicious, crowding around to争看 [peer at the spectacle]!"*
This depicts those who fail to **韬晦 [conceal their brilliance]** and expose their **圭角 [sharp talents]**, inspiring awe and dread among the ignorant and common.

Seeing the phrase *"万僧不阻 [ten thousand monks unobstructed]"*, one has already gained the **护法 [dharma-protectors’]** favor, and the **灵山 [Spiritual Vulture Peak]** is not far off.

What should be feared are the **妇人小子 [women and children]**, who, when slighted, harbor resentment and stir up strife—like the *"穿针儿 [Needle Girl]"* or *"小秀才 [petty scholar]"*, truly **绵里裹针 [silk-wrapped needles]** or **根莠败秀 [tares spoiling fine grain]**.

What should be guarded against is the **主人 [host]**, who craves fame, proudly displays his **奖善之额 [award for virtue]**, fills his doors with guests, and drowns out the clamor of drums and music.
With **结彩 [decorated banners]** and **张筵 [spread feasts]**, flaunting wealth and boasting of victory—he claims to honor teachers and seek friends, yet fails to see it as **开门揖盗 [inviting thieves by bowing at the door]**. Calling him a **寇员外 [bandit host]**, he brings ruin upon himself.

For indeed, **好客 [hospitality]** may attract unwanted attention, while **觊觎 [covetous schemers]** will seize the opportunity; **不贪 [not being greedy]** yet defying others’ wishes will invite **嫉妒 [envy]**, and the envious will bear grudges.
As the saying goes:
*"无贪犹取恕 [Refusing greed is akin to granting pardon]，
剧喜必生优 [Excessive joy breeds sorrow]，
众女兢闺中 [All women tremble within their chambers]，
独退反成怒 [Yet the one who withdraws alone provokes wrath]."*

When **Tang Seng [the monk Xuanzang]** arrived at the **华光行院 [Hua Guang Monastery]**, he saw its opulence and brilliance yet found its conduct contrary to the **良贾深藏 [virtuous merchant’s principle of concealing his wares]**.

Suddenly, a dark cloud and heavy rain descended in an instant—just as the saying goes:
*"天有不测风云 [Heaven has unpredictable winds and clouds]，
人有旦夕祸福 [Man has fortunes that shift like morning and evening]."*
One must ever be on guard.

Thus concludes:
*"泰极还有否 [Prosperity at its peak still harbors decline]，
乐处又逢悲 [Joy’s abode meets sorrow once more]."*
Truly so.

**Chapter Ninety-Seventh: The Golden Reward for External Protection Meets Demon Poison, The Sacred Manifests the Hidden Soul to Save Its Origin**

A disciple of enlightenment remarked: This follows from the preceding passage, illustrating the unfathomable nature of human hearts and the ever-shifting course of events—how prosperity harbors decline, and joy meets sorrow. There is nothing strange in this.

One must penetrate the subtle principles of yin-yang correspondence and preempt the perils of unpredictable transformations.

By leveraging mighty strength to subdue the ignorant masses and deploying divine powers to safeguard the original essence, this tale stands in stark contrast to the *Monkey King’s Rebellion*.

They, through the destruction of the Dharma, slaughtered ten thousand monks—yet never a monk of renown—and required the collusion of the Four Assemblies to complete the deed. Wickedness, yet not yet the height of wickedness!

Here, through the protection of the Dharma, ten thousand monks were fed—yet none were truly virtuous—and the Four Assemblies conspired to fulfill the ritual. Auspicious, yet not yet the full measure of auspiciousness!

Seeing that fortune and misfortune have no ultimate end, yet human desires remain insatiable.

They avoided execution in the chest only to fall prey to thieves,
while here, avoiding the alms only to be robbed and imprisoned.

They, as officials, pursued thieves and captured the Four Assemblies,
while here, the Four Assemblies seized thieves only to be apprehended by the officials.

They stole garments and headgear in secret from the second-storey inn,
while here, they openly presented a *kashaya* before the jailer.

They killed monks and yet shaved their own heads in repentance,
while here, they fed monks and yet met with sudden, violent retribution.

They awoke to enlightenment after a night of evil,
while here, they fell into eternal slumber after an instant of virtue.

They used a thousand hands to shave monks across the land,
while here, a single kick sent them sprawling through the entire county hall.

They, mother and son, plotted against the guest in secret,
while here, mother and child conspired to ensnare the monk.

They, the Pilgrim, revealed past lives to a widow in plain speech,
while here, the old man and his mother mimicked idle gossip behind his back.

They displayed their prowess in the mortal realm,
while here, they secretly wielded divine powers in the underworld.

They, the shaven monk, was the Pilgrim—yet remained utterly unaware,
while here, the thief was no member of the Four Assemblies—yet insisted on the pretense.

They, facing the destruction of the Dharma, revered the Law,
while here, encountering its protection, they violated it.

They, the Pilgrim, disguised as a merchant among the vulgar,
while here, the Pilgrim feigned as a ghost and invoked spirits.

They saw that evil could not be relied upon,
while here, they saw that virtue could not be boasted of.

As for this very tale:
The household head bore the surname *Kou* and was robbed by *Kou* [bandits],
while Tang Seng sought the Dao and instead encountered thieves.

The deceased household head spoke though dead,
while the living bandit remained mute.

The monk acted as the examining magistrate and freed the true thief,
while the prefect, holding false accusations, exonerated the monk.

The master and disciples returned the stolen goods only to be accused of receiving them,
while the thieves, though robbing and plundering, lost their spoils.

The false accuser spoke recklessly with fabricated tongues,
yet the evidence of the stolen goods stood undeniable.

The innocent, though cleared at the trial’s end,
only saw their lifespan extended in vain.

In life, they refused to harbor the monk,
yet in death, the monk returned unexpectedly.

Flower-bedecked, they sent the monk out with drums and music resounding,
while bright and clear, they invited thieves in—only to weep in sorrow upon the floor.

Events twist and turn, reversing and inverting,
defying all description, utterly beyond naming.

The overall description portrays those with wealth as bound to secretly suffer misfortune,
while those of the Dao/Way are prone to trials and tribulations.
It is not through possessing the might to trample the entire county with a single kick,
that one can subdue the ignorant masses and dispel the venom of demons—
thus, those who follow the Dao/Way must diligently uphold their foundation,
secretly fortify themselves, lest they falter even once.

What is this "great kicking power"?
Wealth without hoarding is great kicking power;
Fame without clinging is great kicking power;
Power without misuse is great kicking power;
Law without display is great kicking power.
Softness and weakness as strength, in harmony with the world without contention—
even the finest armor of all ages cannot harm them, this is great kicking power;
Discerning omens and timing one’s actions, advancing and retreating with rectitude—
neither water nor fire, nor tigers or rhinoceroses can harm them, this is great kicking power.
Ah! Such virtues can indeed be practiced!

Thus, it concludes:
*"The earth vast can shelter malevolent deeds,
the heavens high never fail those of pure virtue.
Steady and unhurried along the Path of the Tathāgata,
Only reaching the Lotus Sutra’s blissful gate."*

The commentator says this chapter marks the end of the hells,
and the next begins the heavens—
a view not without insight.

Yet heavens and hells, the realms of principle and desire,
are ever interchanging—
no true end or beginning exists.
The Tang monk’s Dao/Way not yet perfected,
his mind not yet pure, cannot escape the hells’ burdens.

At the **Lingyun Crossing** and the **Bridge of a Single Plank**,
it still resembles the hells’ grim scenes.
Only when he boards the **Bottomless Ship** and reaches the other shore,
does he truly escape the sea of suffering.

The notion of beginning and end is but a vague perception.
