**Chapter Ninety-Eight**
*"When the Monkey is Tamed and the Horse Subdued, Only Then Does He Escape the Shell"*
*"When Merit is Fulfilled and the Path Complete, He Sees the True Suchness"*

The master said:
*"The venerable patriarch, in his compassion for the dull and confused nature of sentient beings,
feared they might not grasp the meaning—
thus, this passage leads them from the very ground of reality,
so that they may tread firmly and dispel all doubt, fear, and hesitation.
Ah! The **Lingyun Crossing**, the **Bridge of a Single Plank**, and the **Bottomless Ship**—
these are truly the most perilous and the most insubstantial.
How then does it say 'treading firm ground'?
If the intent were not made clear in this division,
the patriarch’s original purpose in crafting the **Golden Elixir** would not be passed on,
and the immortal master’s intention in composing the *Journey to the West* to guide the world
would ultimately fail.
Thus, the common folk, lost in the vast sea of suffering,
would have no footing to stand;
the ordinary and vulgar, swept along in the endless cycle of rebirth,
would find no way to rise above."*

Those who study Buddhism and sit in meditation are like grinding bricks to make a mirror—
a hundred attempts yield not a single success.
Those who study Dao and attain the Way are like drawing cakes to stave off hunger—
utterly without real benefit.
Those who study the sages and perfect their nature are like threading a needle in lightning—
they pass it by in plain sight.

Better to take the straight path of the **Lingyun Crossing**, the **Bridge of a Single Plank**, and the **Bottomless Ship**—
for these are the ways of firm footing.

Laozi says:
*"Man’s greatest affliction lies in his having a body.
If I had no body, what affliction could there be?"*
For so long as one has a body, there will be affliction.
To escape the greatest affliction, one must embody the ultimate Dao.
To embody the ultimate Dao, one must clarify the original heart.

The heart is the substance of the Dao;
the Dao is the function of the heart.
When one examines the heart and observes nature,
the round and luminous self-illumination arises naturally,
and the function of non-action is spontaneously fulfilled.
Without contrivance, one suddenly transcends the other shore;
all phenomena are suddenly abandoned, not a speck of dust adheres.
The body cannot burden the nature, the world cannot disturb the true self—
what affliction could possibly remain?

This is the realm of the supreme sage, whose true essence is unblemished.
The heart, like a bright mirror, receives without accepting;
responding to circumstances, harmonious yet not leading,
thus able to overcome all things without harm—
the wondrous Dao of supreme truth!

Alas, the common folk are dull and deluded, lost in their original nature,
clinging to their bodies, fearing death and craving life—
thus they ultimately fail to awaken and verify the truth.

The Yellow Emperor and Laozi pitied their greed and attachment,
so they taught methods of nurturing life to guide them according to their desires,
gradually leading them onward.
This is the art of the Golden Elixir—
a method for the average person, a firm-footed practice,
enabling them to gain purchase and gradually cross to the other shore.
The Master of Purple Yang expounded this thoroughly in the *Awakening to Reality* and detailed it extensively in the *Postscript*.

This *Journey to the West* is the immortal master’s use of Tang Sanzang—
one who awakens gradually as a model of firm footing.
Through the intent of seeking scriptures, amid countless trials,
he is led to the **Lingyun Crossing**, the **Bridge of a Single Plank**, and the **Bottomless Ship**,
so that he may transcend the mundane and need not fear or doubt.
The summit of the Soul Mountain is none other than the self, naturally attained.

Now let us clarify the true meaning of **"Lingyun," "Single Plank," and "Bottomless."**
The Great Dao is broad and straight, like a whetstone or an arrow—
what are these images of "Lingyun," "Single Plank," and "Bottomless"?

Because people’s understanding is shallow and dimmed by desires,
the other shore seems distant as the clouds—
yet if one views all things with detachment, standing beyond the world,
nurturing the vast and boundless *qi*,
it will fill the **Lingyun Crossing**.

Because people act recklessly without restraint, deceiving themselves in secret,
yet when they reflect, they tremble with dread—
like a **Bridge of a Single Plank**—
if one is diligent and cautious, treading carefully as though on thin ice,
then the spirit of solitary vigilance will traverse the **Bridge of a Single Plank**.

Is this not the true realm of genuine practice?
Yet it must be done with sincerity, not achieved through imitation;
it lies in examining things, not in clinging to one-sidedness.

Now the **"Bottomless Boat"** is devised precisely for those who find the **Lingyun Crossing** difficult to traverse and the **Bridge of a Single Plank** difficult to walk. Those who find it difficult to cross and walk are simply those who love their bodies.

Thus, if one loves their body while desiring to cross, they must use a boat—and if they use a boat, they must have a bottom. Without a bottom, it is drowning the body; if drowning the body, it is better not to cross or walk at all—then how can it be called love? Not knowing that a boat has a bottom means loving the body while actually drowning it; without a bottom, it is not loving the body yet not drowning it.

Why? People do not know that a boat *with* a bottom is hollow, while a boat *without* a bottom is solid. A boat with a bottom is the kind people use daily—it saves the body from drowning, yet some fear drowning and refuse to use it; a boat without a bottom is the kind people use once—it saves the body yet *must* drown it, and there will never be those who fear drowning and refuse to use it.

Now, let us test those who have traveled the road for a long time and ask them: *"If there were a bottomless boat, would you board it?"* People will surely be angry, calling it either foolishness or madness, unaware that they are already boarding a bottomless boat and drowning themselves.

Again, let us test those who have traveled the road for a long time and ask them: *"If there were a bottomless boat that would never drown you, would you board it?"* People will again be angry, calling it either falsehood or deceit, unaware that there are those who board boats with bottoms and yet still drown.

Thus, the bottomless boat is one that all must board yet cannot treat lightly. If one has *vast qi* yet cannot nurture it well, or has a spirit of solitary vigilance yet cannot examine things thoroughly, they have not yet reached the **Lingyun Crossing** or the **Bridge of a Single Plank**—they are like an ape that is strong yet a horse that is unbroken, unable to board the boat and cross.

If one can nurture their *vast qi* well, maintain solitary vigilance, and reach the **Lingyun Crossing** and the **Bridge of a Single Plank**, yet still wishes to board a boat with a bottom to cross, they are like an ape that is not yet mature and a horse that is not yet trained—unable to board the boat and ask to cross.

An ape must be fully integrated and unobstructed before it is called mature; a horse must have its strength fully transformed before it is called trained. Confucius said: *"Hear the Dao in the morning, die in the evening—what more can one ask?"* Meaning, without hearing the Dao, death is impossible; but if one hears the Dao, even death is acceptable.

This is called *"the ape is mature, the horse is trained, only then can one shed the shell."* Without the ape being mature and the horse trained, one cannot board the bottomless boat. People all know that a bottomless boat can drown the body, yet they do not know it cannot drown the mature ape and trained horse. People all know that a bottomless boat can drown the body and never rise again, yet they do not know that a bottomless boat cannot drown the trained and mature ape and horse, and they will rise without drowning.

When people board a bottomless boat yet still believe it has a bottom, it truly has a bottom, yet they do not know they will drown and never rise. Again, when they see others board a bottomless boat and believe it has no bottom, that they will drown and never rise, it truly is rising without drowning, yet they do not know.

Though it is the same bottomless boat, one assumes it has a bottom and will not drown; though it is the same bottomless boat, there is a vast difference between drowning and not drowning, yet they assume it is the same drowning with no distinction.

Thus, what they call a boat *with* a bottom is actually bottomless; what we call a boat *without* a bottom is actually bottomed. Does the boat with a bottom truly float? Is the boat without a bottom truly stable? Is the boat with a bottom truly stable? Is the boat without a bottom truly stable?

Therefore, to board a bottomless boat and truly be stable is something only the mature ape and trained horse can do. To make the ape mature and the horse trained requires the alchemical work of *jin dan*.

The maturity of the ape is not the maturity of the mind, but the seamless integration of the Dao itself; the training of the horse is not the training of the will, but the complete transformation of one’s cultivation. Mistaking the mind for the ape and the will for the horse is not the grounded practice of reality.

In the text, those who *"fake the realm and forcefully bow"* are not the mature ape and trained horse; those who *"reach the true realm and dismount"* are the mature ape and trained horse.

*"Dao-children guiding"* is the alchemical essence; *"being tricked by Guanyin"* is not trickery, but seeing that Tang Seng can progress gradually yet not suddenly.

*"Bathing"* is the verification of the mature ape and trained horse; *"yesterday in rags, today resplendent"* is the completion of *jin dan* and shedding the mundane.

*"Not yet on the Cloud Path, must walk the original path"*—this clarifies that abandoning the path of cultivating immortality cannot reach the sacred mountain, seeing Tang Seng’s necessity of gradual progress.

*"Clouds come, clouds go, never truly stepping on this ground"*—this reveals the traveler’s ability to attain sudden enlightenment without gradual progression.

*"Just walk out from the Hall of the Celestial Realm, the back door is right there"*—after action, there is non-action.

*"Tang Seng sees the living water flowing, startled and mistakenly points; the traveler laughs, saying, ‘No mistake.’ Pointing to the great bridge, one must cross over it to attain the Way"*—this shows that this body has not yet left the mundane, danger still remains, and one must nurture *qi* until it cannot be nurtured further, maintain solitary vigilance until it cannot be maintained further, and only then can the Way be attained. This is the true time of genuine practice, finding no other path, hence it is said: *"This is the path, this is the path!"*

*"The traveler steps onto the bridge, running back and forth"*—this is the sudden enlightenment of the superior sage, the ape being naturally mature.

Tang Seng says: *"Difficult! Difficult!"*

Eight Steppings says: *"Slippery! Slippery! Slippery!"*—this is the doubt and fear of the mediocre, as if they would ride the clouds and cross swiftly, yet this is the path of delusion taken by those who stray. Hence, the Traveler urgently stops them, forbidding deviation and guiding them back to the true, solid Dao.

After shedding the mortal shell, master and disciple owe no thanks to each other—this embodies the principle of *er shi ju de* (both benefactors and beneficiaries), the essence of giving both *fa* (law/teaching) and wealth. Yet in this world, superior sages are few while mediocre minds prevail. None dare avoid death, though they must die; none dare board the bottomless ship, though they must board it. Only the Dao of *jin dan* (Golden Elixir) offers broad observation with true stability and solidity.

Before attaining *jin dan*, the body is not without peril; after attaining it, the body remains a hindrance to the Dao. Though one may choose not to ascend, it is not as superior as ascending to transcendence. As in the *Chuan Deng Lu* (Record of the Lamp): Lü Zu wandered the Lougu Platform, listening to Huanglong Jian’s Zen teachings. The master, knowing Lü was a transcendent, asked: *"Who sits below—the river folk?"* Lü replied: *"A wandering monk of clouds and water."* The master said: *"What if the clouds disperse and the water dries?"* Lü had no answer. The master spoke again: *"Huanglong appears."* Lü departed, leaving a poem:

*"Abandoning the gourd-bag, smashing the lute,
Now I no longer covet mercury’s gold.
Since first meeting Huanglong’s truth,
I regret my past misguided heart."*

This is not regret for the error of mercury and gold, but regret for not realizing their noble transformation. Hence another poem says:

*"The Bag Monk ascends to Mingzhou,
Staff in hand, sandals on feet, wandering freely.
Though you may manifest in myriad forms,
Each body still bears its own sorrow."*

This speaks further of transcendence within transformation. Thus, great Buddhas and immortals—some depart like cicadas shedding their shells, some perish in flames, some return westward by foot, some climb trees to demonstrate cultivation, some suffer harm to repay debts—though their traces differ, all await the moment when the ape is mature and the horse is tamed.

For they deeply understand that the physical form cannot endure, while the true spirit eternally persists. This is why the guiding masters emphasize *"wan dong anran ziran"* (ten thousand movements in tranquil ease).

*"Stepping on the ship, unable to stand"*—this is the mind sinking into fear of death at the moment of ascent.
*"One pull and you’re raised"*—this is the daily practice of *jin dan* pulling you along; not you alone, but all of us.
*"Downstream, floating corpses—all say, ‘It’s you, it’s you’"*—not you alone, but all of you.

At this stage, how could one not rejoice? This is the boundless wisdom, the birth into the other shore, the supreme truth beyond limits—what need is there for *"lingyun"* (soaring clouds), *"du mu"* (single plank), or *"wudi"* (bottomless ship)?

Liberated from the mortal coil, the work is complete, the path fulfilled.
Adrift atop the Soul-Mountain’s peak, bowing beneath the Tathagata’s feet,
Only then does one recognize Avalokiteshvara’s compassion—
A single mind entrusted to the *One Hundred Fifty-Four Thousand Fourteen* volumes,
Yet ultimately contained within the *True Scripture of No-Writing*.

This Scripture is most exalted and precious—guard against transmitting it with empty hands, lest customs grow vulgar and ignorant, leading to disrespect and arrogance. Use the *No-Writing Scripture* for the superior sage, the *Written Scripture* for the masses. The Buddha’s differentiation in transmission mirrors Confucius’ teaching tailored to the student—how different can they be?

Ananda first transmitted the *No-Writing True Scripture*—not out of deceit, but fear of disrespect. Later, he exchanged it for the *Five Thousand Forty-Eight Volume Written Scripture*—transmitting the Golden Elixir with the Golden Bowl. For the *No-Writing* is the sudden method, the *Written* the gradual. Sudden is non-action, gradual is action. From gradual to sudden, from action to non-action—all are True Scriptures. The True Scripture never departs from the *No-Writing River Diagram* and the *Written I Ching*, hence it is said:

*"The source of the Three Teachings—treasure it! Cherish it!
Within lie the secrets of immortality and Dao attainment,
Unveiling the marvelous prescriptions for ten thousand transformations."*

The text proposes: *"A total of fourteen years—five thousand forty-eight days, yet eight days short—does not align with the hidden numbers."* Ah! Truly a marvelous prescription!

Readers may claim this book shows Daoist and Buddhist origins as one, with Dao as the gateway and Zen as the ultimate attainment—this seems plausible! Yet unknown is that this book solely expounds the Great Dao of the alchemical Golden Elixir. The phrase *"attaining immortality and completing the Way"* serves as its entire footnote.

Buddha and Immortal cannot be realized without the Golden Elixir—only through transforming action into non-action. There is no superiority or inferiority. Immortal is Buddha; Buddha is Immortal. The Buddha is called *"Great Awakened Golden Immortal,"* while the Immortal is named *"Great Luo True Immortal."* One and two, two and one.

Thus it concludes:
*"Seeing nature, clarifying mind, and communing with the Buddha-patriarchs—
When virtue is complete and practice fulfilled, one ascends to the skies."*

**Ninety-ninth Chapter**
*"Ninety-nine times complete, demons eradicated—
Three threes fulfilled, the Way returns to its root."*

The disciple of enlightenment says: This passage elucidates the meaning of *"even a hair’s breadth difference prevents elixir completion."*

To let mortals penetrate yin-yang, deeply grasp transformation, measure time like an incense clock, and precisely calculate the fire’s moment—neither excess nor deficiency—only then may one obtain the Golden Elixir, shed the mortal frame, and renew the bones. Should even a hair’s breadth differ, it is like walking ninety paces in a hundred-mile journey.

The poem concludes with *"Anciently, its mysteries align with *The Concordance of the Three*"*—this is the book’s entire essence.

The *River of Heavenly Passage* marks the halfway point of the ten thousand eight thousand [stages], yet here it proposes returning to origin to complete the nine nines. It reveals that lacking one in nine nines is like abandoning the halfway mark in vain.

The term *"Heavenly Passage"* is chosen because the heavens span fifty-four thousand *li*—the measure of one *藏* (treasure-house). This is when the Great Sage rescues the primordial essence with a fish basket.

Though called half the labor, the latter half achieves only the former half. Laozi said: *"The Mysterious, yet more mysterious."* The first *"Mysterious"* refers to the first half; the *"yet more"* to the second.

How could one recognize this without the patriarchs’ direct transmission of the profound intent? Ah! The meaning of *Heavenly Passage* and return to origin is profound. Studying the poem *"Nine Nines Return to Truth"* may grant some enlightenment.

The traveler lifts his head and gazes back: *"Here! Here!"*

The reader may dismiss the traveler’s words as idle chatter, yet they hold profound significance. Though one recognizes the *Heavenly Passage*’s location, why does he repeat it so emphatically? His words imply that even the slightest error in practice occurs here—thus, one must be vigilant and remember it well.

*"Eight Rules [Precepts] said to Sand Monk: ‘Surely this is your ancestral home!’
The traveler replied: ‘No! No! This is the *Heavenly Passage*!’*
To call it ancestral home yet insistently correct it—what a warning!

The traveler declared: *“Cannot depart! Cannot depart!”*
This speaks of the *Nine Nines*’ inherent Dao-work, beyond human effort—*"There is naturally true fire, why need fuel or fanning?"*

The old tortoise cried: *“Holy Sage! Here! Here!”*
Meaning: *From here one goes, and to here one returns.*

*"The four disciples and five horses, all borne upon his back"*—this mirrors the *River Diagram*’s symbolism.
The Five Phases return to the One *Taiqi*, with no distinction of self or other, as one attains their original form—thus, the Dao returns to its root and fulfills its mandate.

When the old tortoise suddenly questions and Master Tang remains silent, then shakes his body, all fall into the water—readers must not misinterpret this. At this juncture, Master Tang’s Dao-fruit is already complete; why would he still lack a trial? It must be supplemented?

Indeed, *refining the elixir* and *returning to origin* occur here—even the slightest misstep cannot yield true attainment. The tortoise’s tale of forgotten trust serves as a critical warning at the *Heavenly Passage*’s most vital moment, emphasizing that true faith must be held here, lest any error arise.

This is the true *cloak and bowl* of the *Eight Vajra Protectors*, whispering, *“Thus and thus—follow the Bodhisattva’s precepts, not to be violated.”*
It cannot be explained through words alone.

If one interprets the Dao-body as pure *Qian* [Creative], admitting no trace of *yin* [Receptive], or that the *disaster star* remains unfulfilled and still relies on this place to complete it—then one fails to grasp the subtlety of *returning to origin*.

*"The Three Treasures pressed the sutra, Sand Monk pressed the sutra, the traveler guarded left and right to prevent *yin* demons from wasting [the qi]."*
This reveals that the sutra and this place are prone to error, requiring urgent protection until the *yin* dissipates.

The traveler said: *“This sutra steals the creative power of Heaven and Earth, enduring as long as the cosmos, as bright as sun and moon, with eternal spring and an unbroken *dharma-body.”*
These are the true meanings of *golden elixir*, not mere praise.

At the brink of completion, one must fear external demons sapping or stealing the work—vigilance must be absolute, never lax.

When the sutra’s tail is stained, *“This is the mystery of Heaven and Earth’s incompleteness, beyond human power to remedy.”*
Laozi said: *“Great completion seems deficient—its use is inexhaustible.”*

Readers claim that Heaven and Earth’s deficiency is, in fact, the grandest truth—mere idle speculation.

Some say the old tortoise’s words exposed it, but I say they ruined it. If *“Heaven and Earth’s incompleteness”* is already a mystery, why must it be explained? Only a true master’s transmission can reveal its *“incompleteness”*—how could one guess its meaning?

Ah! Only those who grasp the ebb and flow of the *tidal source* will know the body’s own fullness and emptiness.

The Chen Family Village’s **Deng** and **Qing** welcomed him with gratitude, repaying the old debt of saving their children—summoning **Chen Guanbao** to present a **yīncín** of gold in thanks, and founding the **Jiùshēng Temple**. All this was the beginning and end of **Huan Yuán’s** [Returning to the Origin] affairs.

Fame cannot be dwelled upon for long;
The dusty world is no place for a guest to linger.
*"A true person does not reveal their form—
Revealing it, they are no true person."*
*"Fragrant breezes drift and rise from emptiness"—
The deeds of a true man are complete.

Thus it is said:
*"When the elixir is perfected, one recognizes the original face,
Healthy as ever, bowing to the master."*

**Chapter 100: Directly Returning to the Eastern Land**
**The Five Saints Achieve Perfection**

**Wu Yīzǐ** said: This entire section concludes the **Jīndān** [Golden Elixir] teachings, encapsulating its essence in the poem’s two lines:
*"The five phases’ wondrous hues return to void and stillness,
A hundred false names are all empty."*

For **Jīndān** arises from the convergence of the five phases, though initially it seems deliberate, in the end it is effortless—hence the saying:
*"When the Dao’s fruit is complete, tranquility is natural."*

All its dangers and strangenesses are but emptiness.

The *Yì* says:
*"The interplay of yin and yang is called the Dao."*
Yin and yang are originally one **qi**, which encompasses the five phases.

When the five phases converge and yin and yang harmonize,
Heaven and Earth take their places, and all things flourish—
This is the ultimate, supreme Dao of beginning and end.
If yin is excessive or yang is solitary,
Lacking balance and harmony, how could perfection be achieved?
This contradicts the natural order of **tianming** [Heaven’s mandate] and **suìxìng** [following one’s nature],
And fails to grasp their shared origin—
Where the divine transformations reside.

**Note:** In Buddhist scriptures, the opening *"Yēyǒutúo, Móxūluó"* refers to when the Buddha, before his renunciation, married **Yēyǒutúo** and fathered **Móxūluó**. After twelve years of asceticism, he returned and reunited with them. His words at his parents’ funeral were filled with profound sorrow.

When speaking to the archer Shì about the teachings of the celestial deities,
He often spoke of filial piety, fraternal duty, loyalty, and sincerity—
These were never teachings that strayed from my own **yǐlún** [inherent moral principles].

**Note:** Laozi’s son was named Zōng, who became a general of Wei.
Zōng’s son, Zhù, inscribed the **yǔ** [womb/palace] of his mother;
The **xuánsūn** [mysterious grandson], Jiǎ, served under Emperor Wen of Han;
Jiǎ’s son, Xiè, became the tutor of the Prince of Jiaoxi.
His descendants flourished in the world, all transmitting the virtues of loyalty and filial piety.
Later generations, neglecting to cultivate their inner essence and exert their efforts,
Instead coerced their emotions and attachments,
Claiming it to be a shortcut to transcendence—
Thus, his disciples all lived as widows and widowers, without wives or children.
How could this be the teaching of **Buddha** or **Laozi**?

To disregard the distinctions between male and female,
To abandon the proper order of clothing and ritual,
And merely speak of the study of mind and nature—
This may work within the confines of a secluded meditation chamber,
But applied to the governance of the world, how few could avoid great chaos!
No wonder the Confucian scholars took the opportunity to disparage it!

Between the Jin, Liang, Tang, and Song dynasties,
Many rulers, ministers, and great officials studied under them,
Listened to their teachings, and only **Chánglí** [Khan Li, i.e., Han Yu] did not follow.
Later, he even befriended a leading monk,
And in his old age, he was deceived by alchemy, never reaching its true depths.

From *Zhūzǐ’s Collected Sayings*:
*"Someone asked, ‘How does Laozi’s ‘wu’ [無, non-being] differ from Buddhism’s ‘wu’?’
He replied: ‘Laozi’s non-being is based on the presence of the old [order],
As in his saying: *“Wu [無, non-being], to observe its mystery; yǒu [有, being], to observe its limits.”*
But Buddhism’s non-being treats Heaven and Earth as illusions,
And the four **dà** [great elements] as false combinations—
This is absolute non-being.’"*

Foolishly, I observe:
Zhūzǐ ultimately conceded to **Huángdān** [Yellow Court, i.e., Daoist alchemy] a single point,
Deeming it absolute non-being,
Yet failing to recognize its absolute presence.
If one knew it as absolute presence,
Then one would see it aligns with Laozi’s *yǒu* [有, being] and cannot differ;
If one knew the unity of **Laozi** and **Buddhism**,
Then one would see it shares the same origin with **Confucianism** and cannot differ.

Reading the line *“The sutra’s origin is paired with the five phases,”*
Do the teachings of the five phases in all these scriptures truly differ from
Our Confucian sayings of **rén** [benevolence], **yì** [righteousness], **lǐ** [ritual propriety], **zhì** [wisdom], and **xìn** [trustworthiness]?
No!

*"The branches face east but return to the west"*—
This refers to **Xuánzàng** [Tripitaka Master Xuanzang, i.e., Xuanzang]’s actual journey to fetch the sutras,
And even this single passage reveals his sincerity could move all things,
While Heaven’s will silently responded with its own **líng** [numinous resonance].

The **bādà jīnjiāng** [Eight Great Vajra Protectors] called from the sky:
*"Holy monk, go now and deliver the sutra,
Then return immediately!"*
The **Sānjiāng** [Three Treasures] recounted the deeds and travels of his three disciples,
Exactly embodying the essence of delivering the sutra.
*"Coming and going in eight days’ span—*
This means only within the three-five **miàodào** [mysterious transformations] does it unfold.
The passage states: *“Five days eastward, three days westward upon return,”*
Coming five, returning three—
It clearly indicates the truth,
Yet people fail to awaken to it.

Readers say such passages are beyond thought or imitation,
Yet how can one reconcile *“Three-five as one: three characters—*
How few in ancient and modern times truly understand this!”?

**Jīn** [gold], **jǐn** [restraint], **jìn** [prohibition]—
No need to stir the mind; naturally, they fall away.
Before the Dao is perfected,
One must rely on methods and restraints;
Gold is first employed,
Like the roots generated by thought—
Once stirred, they cannot be moved.
After the Dao is perfected,
One attains serene stillness, free from thought,
Breaking beyond all boundaries—
Gold becomes useless;
One does not seek to cast it off, yet it casts itself off.
As said: *“The ferry-boat left on the river, the ladder discarded in the sky—*
All is abandoned upon arrival.”

The **Zhāngchūn** [Long Spring] Master **Qiū Zhēnrén** [Hill True Person] left this book,
Originally intending to reveal the supreme **jīndān** [gold elixir] Dao to future generations,
Yet he borrowed the story of Xuanzang’s quest for the sutras
To expound and clarify,
Illustrating how the **Sānjiāng** [Three Treasures] shed their mortal shells to attain truth—
By fulfilling nature to reach **mìng** [fate];
And how the three disciples’ illusory bodies became true—
By cultivating **mìng** [fate] to fulfill nature.
Though their paths differed in gradual and sudden stages,
Their ultimate success was one:
All became **dàjué** [greatly awakened] golden immortals.
Divided into five, each became a holy one;
United as one, they all became the **zhēnyǐ** [true unity] of the gold elixir.
Later people failed to recognize this as the **great Dao of the immortals**,
Instead calling it **Buddhist fiction**,
And clinging to empty talk of **xīnyuán yǐmǎ** [mind-monkey, heart-horse],
Or **xīnmiè mómiè** [mind-extinction, demon-extinction],
Their understanding as narrow as viewing through a tube or measuring with a ladle—
How far they have strayed!

The **Zǐyáng** [Purple Yang] True Person said:
*"Jīn Gōng was originally a son of the eastern household,
Sent westward to a neighboring clan to take a mortal form and be born.
When he recognized the call and returned to his dwelling to nurture [the Dao],
He paired with the **xī** [radiant] maiden as a bond of affection.
Again, he said: *“To learn the Dao of immortality, one must learn the Dao of celestial immortality,
And only the gold elixir is the most direct path.
When the two essences unite, nature and fate align,
And the five phases gather like the coiled dragons and phoenixes of the **húlóng pán** [Peak of the Tiger and Dragon].
Originally paired by the **wùjǐ** [Earthly Branch, i.e., the fifth and sixth phases],
Thus the husband and wife settle in eternal harmony.
Wait only until the work is complete at the northern gate,
Where nine clouds’ radiance reveals the soaring cranes.”*
This is the mystery of *“directly returning to the eastern lands, the five saints attaining truth.”*

Every person inherently possesses the **numina** [灵根] of immortality, saints, or Buddhas.
From **post-heaven** [后天] to **pre-heaven** [先天],
Those who perfect it are not bound to the east or the west—
The principle is simple, the attainment effortless.
Why should cultivators wait for another life or another world?
All teachings ultimately boil down to *“abandoning illusion to attain truth.”*
This is why I composed *Zhēn yì* [True Explication].

**My exhortation, your exhortation, the exhortation of all under Heaven and future generations—**
All must strive!

chunks.original_text: 西游真诠 第一回　灵根孕育源流出　心性修持大道生 悟一子曰：此明大道之根源乃阴阳之祖气，即混元太乙之先天，无中生有之真乙。 能尽心知性而修持之，便成金身不坏，与天地齐寿也。 此回提纲二语最着意在上一句，为作者全部之统要。 解者只提心字为主，妄揣混注，反昧却大道之根源，是不知道也。 并不知心，竟将仙师度世真谛全然遗弃，可惜可叹。 首言灵根也者，先天真乙之气也。 经曰："无名天地之始，有名万物之母"。 又云："两者同出而异名"。 方其气也，真乙之气不可见，故为天地之始； 及其有也，真乙之珠现于空虚中，故为万物之母。 一气生阴阳，阴阳生四象，四象生五行，五行生万物，俱真乙之气变也。 其为气也，立于天地之先，入于天地之内。 始自无中生有，复自有中生无。 人能得此一气，可以包罗万象。 故曰："得其一，则万事毕矣"。 《悟真篇》曰："道自虚无生一气，便从一气产阴阳，阴阳再合成三体，三体重生万物昌"。 《易》曰："天地氤氲，万物化醇"。 元始以一粒宝珠证道，三教圣人无不从此道直探根源，洞明造化。 盖道生一气，一气生形，形中又含始气。 故天一生水，水为壬水。 壬即真一生物之祖气。 壬水长生在申，申者猴也，故为猴。 申金生于土，石者土之精气之核，故为石猴。 按周天三百六十五度、二十四气、九宫八卦，即《悟真篇》所云："五行四象全藉土，九宫八卦岂离壬"者是也。 乙为花果之木，生于震东，阳气始生之地，纳音为海中之金，故在东胜神洲傲来国花果山。 此水中之金即父母未生前先天真乙之真金，故无父母而父天母地产于石卵。 目运两道金光也，因服食后天之水而金光潜息，将渐失其初禀之性矣。 以其为水中之金，故居于水帘洞。 内有铁板桥，分明是天造地设的家当，非人力所能为。 此种家当，得之者我命不由天，不受老天之气者矣。

**The True Interpretation of the Journey to the West, Chapter One**

**The Spiritual Root Takes Form and Flows Forth; Cultivation of Mind and Nature Gives Birth to the Great Dao**

Wu Yizi said: This clarifies that the root-source of the Great Dao is the primordial qi of yin and yang, the precelestial origin of the Hunyuan Taiyi, the True Yi born from nonbeing. By fully realizing the mind and knowing one’s nature through cultivation, one may attain an indestructible golden body and live as long as heaven and earth.

The two guiding lines of this chapter place greatest emphasis on the first, which encapsulates the author’s overarching principle. Those who interpret it by focusing solely on the word "mind," recklessly imposing misguided annotations, obscure the root-source of the Great Dao and thus fail to comprehend it. Not only do they misunderstand the mind, but they entirely abandon the true essence of the immortal masters’ teachings on liberating the world—how lamentable, how pitiful!

The "spiritual root" spoken of first is the precelestial True Yi qi. As the *Classic* says: *"Nameless, it is the beginning of heaven and earth; named, it is the mother of the myriad things."* It also states: *"These two emerge together but bear different names."* When it is in its qi-state, the True Yi qi is invisible, hence it is the beginning of heaven and earth. When it takes form, the True Yi pearl appears within the void, hence it is the mother of the myriad things. From the One qi arise yin and yang; from yin and yang arise the Four Images; from the Four Images arise the Five Phases; from the Five Phases arise the myriad things—all transformations of the True Yi qi.

As qi, it stands before heaven and earth and enters within them. It begins as being born from nonbeing, then reverts to being born from being. One who attains this One qi can encompass all phenomena. Thus it is said: *"Obtain the One, and all matters are complete."*

*The Awakening to Reality* states:
*"The Dao from emptiness gives birth to the One qi,
From the One qi arise yin and yang,
Yin and yang unite to form the Three Bodies,
From the Three Bodies flourish the myriad things."*

The *Book of Changes* says: *"Heaven and earth intermingle, and the myriad things transform into purity."*

From the beginning, the Primordial One attained the Dao through a single precious pearl. The sages of the Three Teachings all directly explored this root-source, penetrating the workings of creation.

For the Dao gives birth to the One qi, the One qi gives birth to form, and within form is contained the original qi. Thus, *"Heaven One gives birth to water,"* and water is Ren-water. Ren is the ancestral qi of the True One that generates all things. Ren-water’s phase of long life is in *shen* (the ninth earthly branch), and *shen* is the monkey. *Shen*-metal is born from earth, and stone is the essence and core of earth’s qi—hence the Stone Monkey.

According to the celestial cycle of 365 degrees, the twenty-four qi, the Nine Palaces, and the Eight Trigrams, this aligns with what *The Awakening to Reality* states: *"The Five Phases and Four Images all rely on earth; how could the Nine Palaces and Eight Trigrams depart from Ren?"*

Yi is the wood of flowers and fruit, born in *zhen* (the east), the place where yang qi first arises. Its natal tone is metal within the sea, hence its location in the Flower-Fruit Mountain of the Eastern Continent of Superior Body. This metal within water is the true gold of the precelestial True Yi before the birth of one’s parents—thus, without father or mother, it is born from a stone egg by Heaven as father and Earth as mother.

Its eyes emitted two beams of golden light, but after consuming postnatal water, the golden light receded and gradually faded, losing its originally endowed nature. Because it is metal within water, it dwells in the Water-Curtain Cave. Within it lies an iron-plank bridge, clearly a celestial and terrestrial creation, not something fashioned by human effort. Such an endowment, once obtained, means *"my fate is not determined by Heaven"*—one is no longer subject to the qi of old Heaven.

Indeed, it is the supreme sovereign of joy between Heaven and Earth, hence the title Handsome Monkey King. From what I have heard of the reckoning of Heaven and Earth, this fully clarifies the profound subtleties of the spiritual root’s origin and flow—yet nowhere is the word "heart" to be found. The immortal master employs a poetic turn, subtly shifting the focus onto the human body, making it abundantly clear: he borrows the name of the monkey merely to complete the perfection of the Golden Elixir’s great Dao. Were all people through the ages to achieve such perfection, they too would be called outer kings and inner sages, free to act as they please—not because the heart is difficult to master.

The following passage then explains that one must personally examine its wonders, fully comprehend the heart and know one’s nature, and diligently cultivate and uphold what is most precious. The human body is hard to obtain, a century passes in an instant; one should urgently awaken the heart of the Dao and strive for oneself. Know that the Way of immortals, Buddhas, and sages, the method of longevity and agelessness, is within everyone’s reach—yet how pitiful that all people in the world are mere pursuers of fame and profit, with not a single one attending to their own life and destiny. Thus, the immortal master points out a path: journey westward to inquire, reaching the Western Continent of Cattle-Gift, to seek out the whereabouts of a divine immortal.

Alas! Do immortals choose where they are born? Could it truly be that the Southern Jambu Continent has none, while the Western Continent of Cattle-Gift does? The immortal master’s intent is merely to indicate that the south is a land where fire flourishes, not a place where metal is born—only in the west is true gold produced. This aligns with the overarching theme of the entire book: the scriptures must be sought in the west.

He speaks of a filial gentleman, for filial piety is the foundation of practicing benevolence and is akin to the Way of immortals. Thus, they are neighbors, and within this lies a profound meaning. The Way of immortals is water giving birth to metal, not metal giving birth to water—an image of the mother nurturing the child in the womb, the child repaying the mother’s kindness, both mirroring the path of filial piety.

The woodcutter said, “Not far, not far. This mountain is called the Mountain of the Numinous Terrace and Square Inch; upon it lies the Cave of the Slanting Moon and Three Stars. Here, the text explicitly mentions the Numinous Terrace and Square Inch—a hook and three dots—readers will surely say this refers to the character for "heart," and how could I deny it points to the heart?

Alas! They are mistaken.

chunks.original_text: 若云是心，以心问心，参禅打坐，祛欲循理便可长生，又何又用求仙访道，南奔西驰耶？ 以此心为天地之心则可，以此心为人心之心则失之远矣！ 《易》曰："不远复，复见其天地之心乎"？ 天地之心不可见，因有地雷复卦为见天地之心。 盖静极而动，动而生阳，生生续续，皆因于坤。 故《参同》曰："因母立兆基"。 即坤生复也。 又曰："六五坤承，结括始终。 温养众子，世为类母"。 所谓万物之母也。 故樵夫云："那祖师出去的徒弟也不计其数"，言万物皆从此出也。 又云："见今还有三四十人从他修行"。 其从者为东三西四中十，其祖师则为北一南二，坎离既济，五行攒簇明矣。 又云："你顺那条小路儿向南行，不远即是他家了"。 由西而西南不远，非坤位乎？ 《易》曰："西南得朋，乃以类行"。 《悟真》曰："只在西南，而本乡是也"。 小路者西兑之位也。 兑为少阴，故曰小路。 他家者，即《悟真》所谓"认取他家不死方"也。 始曰："不远不远"，继曰："不远"，明言不远复之义。 终曰"约有七八里远"，七八者十五也。 金逢望月之位，其义微矣。 仙师篇首取邵尧夫之诗："冬至子之半，天心无改移。 一阳初动处，万物未生时"。 明天始有根，到此明天心之所在也。 静悄悄杳无人迹，阴静之极也。 然静极未见天地之心，静极初动方见天地之心，故又说美猴王跳上松梢摘子一象，明震木初动而时在子之义。 其阐理微奥如是。 童子道："我家师父讲道，未说出原由，教我来接，想必是你"。 猴王道："是我，是我"，此中又有妙义。 盖真乙之精其家在东，寄体在西，此阴阳颠倒之义。 有生以来，走在他家，今番认得，说出原因，分明原是我家物也。 故曰："是我是我"，与上"他家"二字相照。 见菩提祖师端坐台上，两边有三十个小仙侍立，即《参同》"六五坤承，结括始终"之义---五六三十也。 历代仙师又以坤方为月生之地，以偃月为象。 一勾为偃月，三点为三星。 月受真阳之气而生明，中有精气神三星之象。 复卦为阳之首，朔旦为月之首。 故《参同》曰："五六三十日，度竟复更始"。 魏公以月三十日配坤卦，同一义也。 大觉金仙一诗，空寂真如，语语透露识得天心方是大法师也。 然欲尽其心，则必知其性。 知其性则知天心之微妙而完成大道矣。 猴王志心明礼，自东而西，凡以求知其性也。 曰："我无性"，曰："我无父母"，曰"想是树上生"，曰："恰是石里长"，盖因既生之后为尘欲所染，而渐失其先天之性，遂不知为东方震木之物，亦即为西位兑金之体，岂有不弃其天造地设的家当耶？ 故须菩提大发慈悲，曰："我与你就身上取个姓氏，古月老阴不能化育儿男，婴细正合本论。 仙师已实发性中之妙，无庸复言。 猴王曰："好！

If one claims this refers to the heart, then by inquiring into the heart, engaging in meditation, sitting in dhyāna, dispelling desires, and following principle, one could attain longevity—why then seek immortality, quest for the Dao, or rush about east and west? To regard this heart as the heart of Heaven and Earth may be acceptable, but to take it as the heart of the human heart is far from the mark!

The *Book of Changes* states: *"Not far off is the return; in the return is seen the heart of Heaven and Earth."* Yet the heart of Heaven and Earth cannot be seen—only through the hexagram *Fù* (Return), Earth and Thunder, is the heart of Heaven and Earth revealed. For when stillness reaches its extreme, movement arises, and from movement, yang is born. Generation upon generation continues, all rooted in *Kūn* (Earth). Thus, the *Cantong Qi* says: *"By the mother is the foundation laid"*—that is, *Kūn* gives birth to *Fù*. It further states: *"The sixth line of *Kūn* upholds, binding beginning and end. It nurtures all children, ever the mother of kinds."* This is the mother of the ten thousand things. Hence the woodcutter says: *"That patriarch’s disciples are beyond count"*—meaning all things emerge from this. He adds: *"Now there are still thirty or forty following him in cultivation."* Those who follow are three in the east, four in the west, and ten in the center, while the patriarch himself is one in the north and two in the south—*Kǎn* and *Lí* in harmonious union, the five phases gathered in clarity.

He further instructs: *"Follow that small path southward; his home is not far."* From the west to the southwest is not far—is this not the position of *Kūn*? The *Book of Changes* says: *"In the southwest, one gains companions and proceeds with one’s kind."* The *Wuzhen Pian* states: *"Only in the southwest lies one’s native place."* The small path is the position of *Duì* in the west, *Duì* being lesser yin, hence called a "small path." "His home" is precisely what the *Wuzhen Pian* refers to as *"recognizing the deathless method of that other household."*

First, he says, *"Not far, not far,"* then simply *"not far,"* clearly alluding to the meaning of *"not far off is the return."* Finally, he says, *"about seven or eight *li* distant"*—seven and eight make fifteen, the phase of gold meeting the full moon, its meaning subtle indeed.

At the outset of the immortal master’s chapter, he cites Shao Yaofu’s poem:
*"At the winter solstice, half of *zǐ*,
The heart of Heaven remains unchanged.
Where the first yang stirs,
Before the ten thousand things arise."*
This clarifies the root of Heaven and reveals the locus of the heart of Heaven. *"Silent and still, with no trace of man"*—this is the extreme of yin stillness. Yet before stillness reaches its extreme, the heart of Heaven and Earth is not seen; only when stillness first stirs is the heart of Heaven and Earth revealed. Thus, the image of the Handsome Monkey King leaping onto a pine branch to pluck fruit elucidates the meaning of *Zhèn* (Thunder) wood’s initial stirring at the *zǐ* hour.

Such are the profound principles expounded. The boy says: *"My master was lecturing on the Dao but did not explain the reason. He sent me to fetch you—I suppose it must be you."* The Monkey King replies: *"It is I, it is I!"*—here lies another subtle meaning. For the essence of true yi resides in the east but dwells in the west—this is the principle of yin and yang inverted. Since birth, it has wandered in that other household; now, recognizing it and stating the cause, it is clearly one’s own original possession. Hence he says, *"It is I, it is I!"*—echoing the earlier phrase *"that other household."*

Seeing the Venerable Patriarch Subhūti seated upon the dais, with thirty young immortals standing to either side, this embodies the meaning of the *Cantong Qi*: *"The sixth line of *Kūn* upholds, binding beginning and end"*—five times six is thirty. Later immortals also take the *Kūn* direction as the place of the moon’s birth, symbolized by the crescent moon. The hook is the crescent, the three dots the three stars. The moon receives the true yang qi and generates brightness, within which lies the image of the three stars—essence, qi, and spirit. *Fù* is the first of yang, the new moon the first of the month. Thus, the *Cantong Qi* says: *"Five times six, thirty days, the cycle completes and begins anew."* Master Wei equates the thirty days of the moon with the *Kūn* hexagram—both express the same idea.

The poem of the Greatly Awakened Golden Immortal, in its emptiness and true suchness, reveals in every line that only by recognizing the heart of Heaven can one be a great master of the Dharma. Yet to fully realize this heart, one must know one’s nature. Knowing one’s nature, one knows the subtlety of the heart of Heaven and completes the great Dao.

The Monkey King, with sincere heart and clear ritual, journeys from east to west—all to seek knowledge of his nature. He says: *"I have no nature,"* *"I have no parents,"* *"I suppose I was born from a tree,"* *"No, I grew from stone."* For after birth, he was stained by worldly desires and gradually lost his primordial nature, no longer knowing himself as a thing of *Zhèn* wood from the east, nor as the body of *Duì* metal from the west. How could he not abandon the endowment bestowed by Heaven and Earth?

Thus, the greatly compassionate Subhūti says: *"I shall take a surname for you from your own body. Ancient moon, old yin, cannot transform to bear male offspring—yet ‘infant’ fits perfectly with this discourse."* The immortal master has already revealed the wondrousness within nature; no further words are needed. The Monkey King exclaims: *"Good!"*

"Excellent! Excellent! Only today do I know my surname." He then exclaimed, "Wonderful! Wonderful! Wonderful! From this day forth, I shall be called Sun Wukong!" Should one grasp the meaning of the characters *hao* (excellent), *xing* (surname), and *kong* (emptiness), one would be a being of vast wisdom, a true suchness of the ocean of original nature, awakened and perfectly enlightened. Thus it is said: *"When chaos first parted, no surnames existed—shatter the stubborn void, and you must awaken to emptiness."* Yet to perceive the true nature of the primordial, one must delve deeply into the acquired.

**Chapter Two: Penetrating the Wondrous Truth of the Dao—Severing Demons to Return and Merge with the Original Spirit**

Wu Yizi states: This reveals the true and wondrous transmission of the great alchemical Dao, subtly illustrating the method of *"taking from Kan to fill Li,"* thereby returning to the root and merging with the original spirit. The key lies in the two characters *"penetrating awakening"*—one must focus the mind here. The principles of the true and wondrous Dao require profound awakening and thorough penetration, and only with the transmission of a true master can one properly begin. It is not that this mind is the Dao, nor that awakening alone suffices. If self-cultivation through the mind alone could attain the Dao, then what is awakened? What is attained? This is but the practice of silent sitting in the gate of stillness—ultimately grasping at the moon’s reflection in water, all in vain. Thus, the chapter subtly hints at the meaning of *"severing demons"* to return and merge with the original spirit. When he retrieves the golden cudgel from his own cave, it fully embodies the principle of returning to the root and merging with the original spirit.

The immortal master’s poem reads:
*"The three families unite as they naturally are,
Pointing to the unborn, revealing the mystery of nature."*

People know the *"three families"* as three surnames, yet they do not know the three families are one surname. Knowing the wonder of the earlier poem—*"originally no surname"*—one then understands the wonder of this poem: *"the three families unite as they naturally are."* Though called three surnames, they are ultimately one surname; though called one surname, they are ultimately no surname.

When Wukong hears the master expound the Dao and recognizes its wondrous resonance, it is the moment when he can be spoken to of the Dao. On Rotten Peach Mountain, he ate his fill of peaches seven times. Rotten peaches symbolize the stripping away of the outer husk, revealing the kernel within. The *Cantong Qi* says: *"Stripping away the limbs, dissolving the form—when the Dao is exhausted, it returns, reverting to the primal Kun."* This is the time of *"stripping down to rise again."* The seven times signify the principle of *"the seventh day’s return."* At the moment when the Dao-heart manifests, the ancestral master declares that all four methods—movement, stillness, flow, and quietude—are side doors. Through question and answer, distinctions are made with clarity.

What is particularly startling is that within the *"flow"* category, the Confucian, Buddhist, and Daoist traditions are deemed side doors, and within the *"stillness"* category, practices like *"pure quietude and non-action"* and *"guarding the spirit to enter samadhi"* are likewise labeled as such. This is bound to arouse astonishment. Why? The Confucian seeks to rectify the heart, the Buddhist to illuminate the mind, and the Daoist to contemplate the mind. *"Pure quietude and non-action"* is the heart-method of Laozi; *"meditating and entering samadhi"* is the mind-seal of the Buddha. All cultivate the mind, perfectly aligning with the interpretation of *"monkey-mind and horse-intent"* in *Journey to the West*, the understanding of *"gathering the scattered mind."* Yet now, it is said to be like *"setting a pillar in a wall"* or *"a brick in a kiln"*—abandoning this to seek the true mind elsewhere leaves one bewildered: where is it to be found?

Alas! This reveals the long-standing error in reading and interpreting *Journey to the West* as *"monkey-mind and horse-intent,"* the superficiality of *"gathering the scattered mind."* The immortal master has already made this plainly evident, and it is not my private opinion. The great sages of the three teachings devoted themselves to cultivating the Dao, not to equating the cultivation of the mind with the Dao. It is acceptable to say the Dao harmonizes with the monkey-mind; it is unacceptable to say the monkey-mind is the Dao. The common interpretations of Confucianism, Buddhism, and Daoism as *"monkey-mind and horse-intent,"* as *"gathering the scattered mind,"* are why the master explicitly calls them side doors, not the supreme and true great Dao of the golden elixir.

This Dao, even the naturally most intelligent Wukong could not comprehend—thus he had to seek the transmission from Subhuti. As the Perfected One of Purple Yang said: *"Even if one’s wisdom surpasses Yan and Min, without a true teacher, do not force guesses."* Had Wukong not been of the most naturally intelligent and wished to force guesses from within himself, could he have heard of it? There are also those vulgar and foolish men who, with their *"yin-cultivation and yang-supplementation"* heresies, deceive and distort the sacred scriptures. Thus, the master first refutes their delusions in the *"movement"* category, urging those with aspirations to learn the Dao to pay close attention.

This Dao is transmitted but once in ten thousand kalpas—it is not imparted to those unworthy. The Patriarch Subhuti set it as a riddle within a tray, transmitting it in secret. Wukong was able to shatter the tray, kneel in faith, and receive it—truly a seed of Buddhahood. The Patriarch then chanted from his mouth: *"Difficult! Difficult! Difficult!"*

chunks.original_text: 道最玄。 莫把金丹作等闲。 不遇至人传妙诀，空言口困舌头干！ "可知金丹之道，必师传而得，非可求之于人中也。 然悟空虽打破盘迷，知打三下为三更时存心，关中门为后门进步，秘处传道。 定息存神，约到子时前后，偷开后门直至寝榻，跪求长生之道。 菩提云："显密圆通真妙诀，惜修性命无他说。 都来总是精气神，谨固牢藏休漏泄。 休漏泄，体中藏，汝受吾传道自昌。 口诀记来多有益，屏除邪欲得清凉。 得清凉，光皎洁，好向丹台赏明月。 月藏玉兔日藏乌，自有龟蛇相盘结。 相盘结，性命坚，却能火里种金莲。 攒簇五行颠倒用，功完随作佛和仙。 "此金丹作用之始终，字字包括。 若遇口诀指点，即可闻道。 内有最重要精、气、神三字，恐人错认，予特为指出：此精不是交感精，此气不是呼吸气，此神不是思虑神。 幸弗从自己心中摸索而落于心猿意马，收其放心之谬解也。 祖师说破根源，悟空记了口诀，暗暗维持。 金丹之作用，子前午后温养之工夫，三年之后，法性颇通。 难容五百年后，天降雷灾，须要见性明心。 可知见性明心乃丹成以后之事。 若不见性明心，则理欲混杂，不能纯一，则落于邪辟。 故天神不容，雷灾难免。 此外来之灾，犹属易避。 若不能见性明心，则本身之阴火未除，迟久又积而成害，火灾自生。 若不能见性明心，则本身之阴气未净，迟之又久积而为殃，风灾自生。 此三灾之发明道成之后，须归到无为原真之极处也。 祖师传口诀，行者学成变化，始而爬云，继而筋斗云，总见得见性明心自能超脱尘凡，与天地同其变化，由强勉而抵于神化也。 读《西游记》者见七十二变化，十万八千筋斗，又解是心。 若是心，则是悬空妄想，正是放心，有何真际实落？ 不知此乃金丹之灵妙，真才实用，变化何止万万，而以七十二候之气运概之； 筋斗何止万万，而以十万八千之藏数概之。 此道只宜自知，不宜在大众面前卖弄，故从来古佛上仙了道之后即超然远举，不露圭角，正见明心也。 行者变拟树耍子，未免惊动大众，成何世界？ 故祖师曰："这个工夫敢在人前卖弄？ 假如有人求你，你若畏祸，只得传他； 若不传他，必然加害。 "观此则知此身未离凡世，切不可在人前卖弄也。 故祖师又传他一法，曰："你去罢，你从哪里来，从哪里去。 "盖教他归本还原以避祸也。 虽然，七十二般变化者，一年之候也； 爬云者，法来精也； 只怕有心人者，密密留心也； 十万八千者，两藏之数也； 变松者，金木并而铅汞就也； 舌动是非生者，谨言秘炼也； 不可在人前卖弄者，防不测之祸也； 哪里来，哪里去者，从东而来，还从东而归也，此便是保全性命也； 只说自家会者，必待师传也； 哪消一个时辰，早看见花果山水帘洞，美猴王自知快乐者，金丹得手也。 此又有盘中之盘，迷中之迷，非凡人所能打破。 俱是附耳低言，口诀中之妙法也。 金丹口诀，祖师不能笔之于书，又虑世人终难测识，故于悟空归洞之后微示其意，演出一段断魔故事。 明归洞之后，须断去此魔，为第一工夫也。 猴王为水中之金，离东而去西。 自一去之日而正北之水即混入于水帘洞中，洞中之猴亦混入于正北水脏，故曰："混世魔王。
chunks.translated_text:
The Dao is most profound.
Do not treat the Golden Elixir as commonplace.
Without meeting a perfected master to transmit the wondrous formula,
One’s words will but parley the tongue dry!

Know then that the Way of the Golden Elixir must be received through a master’s transmission—it cannot be sought among men. Yet though Wukong shattered the tray’s riddle, discerning that three taps meant the third watch, that the closed gate was the back door for entry, and that the Dao was transmitted in secret, he still regulated his breath, gathered his spirit, and waited until the hour before or after midnight to stealthily open the back door, approach the sleeping couch, and kneel to beseech the Way of long life. The Patriarch intoned:

*"The wondrous formula of perfect esoteric and exoteric teachings—
Nothing else avails in cultivating nature and destiny.
All comes down to essence, qi, and spirit:
Guard them firmly, seal them well, let no leakage occur.
Let no leakage occur—conceal them within the body,
And the Dao you receive shall flourish of itself.
Remember this oral formula, for it brings great benefit:
Banish perverse desires to attain cool clarity.
Attain cool clarity, and radiance will shine pure.
Then ascend the cinnabar terrace to admire the bright moon.
The moon conceals the Jade Hare, the sun conceals the Golden Crow,
While the Tortoise and Serpent coil in mutual embrace.
Coiled in embrace, nature and destiny grow firm,
Enabling one to plant golden lotuses in fire.
Gathering and reversing the Five Agents,
When the work is complete, one becomes Buddha or immortal."*

This is the beginning and end of the Golden Elixir’s workings, every word encompassing all. If one receives the oral formula’s guidance, one may then hear the Dao. Within it, the three crucial words—essence, qi, and spirit—lest they be misconstrued, I shall explicitly point out: this essence is not the essence of intercourse, this qi is not the qi of breathing, and this spirit is not the spirit of thought. Take care not to grope within your own mind and fall into the delusion of the "monkey-mind and horse-intent," mistaking the "scattered mind" for the true.

The Patriarch revealed the root source, and Wukong memorized the oral formula, secretly upholding it. The workings of the Golden Elixir—warming and nurturing before midnight and after noon—after three years, his dharma-nature became quite penetrating. Yet after five hundred years, Heaven would send a thunder calamity, requiring him to see his nature and clarify his mind. Know that seeing one’s nature and clarifying the mind are matters *after* the Elixir’s completion. Without seeing nature and clarifying the mind, principle and desire remain mixed, unable to achieve purity, and one falls into heterodoxy. Thus, the heavenly spirits cannot tolerate it, and the thunder calamity is unavoidable. Such external disasters are still relatively easy to evade. But if one cannot see nature and clarify the mind, the body’s yin fire remains unremoved, and over time, it accumulates into harm, spontaneously generating fire calamities. If one cannot see nature and clarify the mind, the body’s yin qi remains uncleansed, and over time, it accumulates into misfortune, spontaneously generating wind calamities. These three calamities arise after the Dao’s completion, necessitating a return to the ultimate state of non-action and original truth.

After transmitting the oral formula, the Patriarch saw the practitioner master transformations: first climbing clouds, then the somersault cloud, all demonstrating that by seeing nature and clarifying the mind, one can transcend the mundane and share in Heaven and Earth’s transformations, progressing from strenuous effort to spiritual transformation. Readers of *Journey to the West* see the seventy-two transformations and the thirty-six-thousand-mile somersault and interpret them as the mind. But if it were merely the mind, it would be empty delusion—precisely the "scattered mind"—what true reality or solid foundation would there be? They do not know that this is the wondrous efficacy of the Golden Elixir, a true and practical skill. Transformations are not limited to ten thousand times ten thousand, but are summarized by the seventy-two seasonal qi movements; somersaults are not limited to ten thousand times ten thousand, but are summarized by the number of the two *zang* organs. This Dao is only for self-knowledge and should not be flaunted before crowds. Thus, since ancient times, Buddhas and immortals who attained the Dao would transcend and depart, concealing their brilliance, for they had truly seen their nature and clarified their minds.

When the practitioner transformed into a tree to play tricks, he inevitably startled the crowd—what kind of world would that be? Thus, the Patriarch said: *"Dare you flaunt this skill before others? If someone seeks it from you, should you fear misfortune, you may only transmit it to them; if you do not, they will surely harm you."* From this, know that as long as one has not left the mortal world, one must never flaunt one’s skills before others. Therefore, the Patriarch transmitted another method to him, saying: *"Go now. Return whence you came."* This was to teach him to return to his origin to avoid calamity.

Nevertheless, the seventy-two transformations correspond to the year’s seasonal nodes; climbing clouds represents the arrival of dharma-essence; "beware the intentional man" means to guard one’s mind closely; the thirty-six thousand miles correspond to the number of the two *zang* organs; transforming into a pine tree signifies the union of metal and wood, lead and mercury; the moving tongue that stirs up right and wrong signifies the need for discreet refinement; not flaunting before others is to guard against unforeseen calamities; "whence you came, thither return" means coming from the East and returning to the East—this is how one preserves life and nature. Only those who have received a master’s transmission may claim to have mastered it. In less than an hour, he saw Flower-Fruit Mountain and the Water-Curtain Cave, and the Handsome Monkey King knew bliss—for the Golden Elixir had succeeded. Here again is a riddle within a riddle, a mystery within a mystery, which no ordinary person could shatter. All are whispered secrets, wondrous methods within the oral formula.

The oral formula of the Golden Elixir could not be written down by the Patriarch, and fearing that worldly people would forever struggle to comprehend it, he subtly revealed its meaning to Wukong after his return to the cave, enacting a tale of demon-quelling. It was made clear that upon returning to the cave, one must first sever this demon. The Monkey King was metal within water, departing the East for the West. From the day of his departure, the water of due North mingled with the Water-Curtain Cave, and the monkeys of the cave mingled with the water *zang* of due North—hence, the "Demon King of the Turbid World."

hus, the master first refutes their delusions in the *"movement"* category, urging those with aspirations to learn the Dao to pay close attention.

This Dao is transmitted but once in ten thousand kalpas—it is not imparted to those unworthy. The Patriarch Subhuti set it as a riddle within a tray, transmitting it in secret. Wukong was able to shatter the tray, kneel in faith, and receive it—truly a seed of Buddhahood. The Patriarch then chanted from his mouth: *"Difficult! Difficult! Difficult!"*

chunks.original_text: "正北属坎，故执有刀； 其色黑，故头戴乌巾，身挂皂袍，下穿黑甲，足踏黑靴。 坎中有金，惟因混而成魔也。 悟空曰："我乃正南方。 "正南者，离宫也。 没器械，光着头，红色衣，勒黄绦，踏马靴，俱形容离宫之义。 中火而鲜金，非没器械乎？ 形圆而似日，非光着头乎？ 日色之光焕，非红色衣乎？ 日行之黄道，非勒黄绦乎？ 日中之金乌，非踏乌靴乎？ 最妙在两手勾着天边月也。 月为真阴，交日而阳魂生。 上弦为左手勾着，下弦为右手勾着。 月圆则阳魂盈轮而两手勾着矣。 夫能两手勾着天边月而大道完成，而脏魔自断，故能取魔金而即为我用。 顶门一下，砍为两段，妙矣哉！ 正北坎中之水，一刀两段，变奇为偶。 坎水已固而复归为坤，岂非烧得枯干，尽归一体之乾耶？ 混去之孩儿自倏忽还乡，而水脏洞收不上身之被众猴已脚踏实地，认得家乡，不陷于坎而填乾尽离矣。 悟空又结出南方无道之言，以指出西方之路。 仙师书中如此笔墨，非洞察阴阳，深明造化，何从测识乎？ 此所谓"断魔归本合元神也，"非与天同寿的真功果，不死长生的大法门乎？ 纯阳一得而孙孙不绝，变化无穷，又何天地幽冥之得以拘束之哉？ 第三回　四海千山皆拱服　九幽十类尽除名 悟一子曰，此发明金丹大道乃水中金之一物，能得其真者，则凡地下之自近而远，自显而幽，无所障碍而一如我意之展施也。 猴王自得混世魔王一口之金，旋取傲来国武库之金，复收七十二洞献贡之金，花果山成铁桶金城，根本已固，靡远勿届，但未及通神也。 故猴王曰："我这口刀着实狼犺，不遂我意。 "盖此道贵于中正纯粹，方能所向无前。 则入海博求之举不可已矣。
chunks.translated_text:
"Due North belongs to *Kan*, hence he wields a blade; its color is black, so he wears a black headscarf, dons a dark robe, black armor below, and black boots. Within *Kan* lies metal, yet through turbidity it becomes a demon.

Wukong said, 'I hail from due South.'
Due South is the *Li* Palace.
No weapon, bare head, red garments, a yellow sash, and riding boots—all embody the essence of *Li*.
Within fire yet metal gleams—is this not the absence of weapons?
Round in form, like the sun—is this not a bare head?
The sun’s radiance—is this not red clothing?
The sun’s yellow path—is this not a yellow sash?
The golden crow within the sun—is this not black boots?
Most wondrous are the two hands hooking the moon at the edge of the sky.
The moon is true *yin*, coupling with the sun to birth yang’s soul.
The waxing moon is hooked by the left hand, the waning moon by the right.
When the moon is full, yang’s soul fills its wheel, and both hands hook it.
Thus, one who can hook the moon at the sky’s edge completes the great Dao, and the visceral demon severs itself—hence, the demonic metal is seized and turned to one’s use.
A single strike to the crown splits it in two—how marvelous!
The water of due North’s *Kan*, cleaved in two by one blade, transforms the odd into the even.
*Kan*’s water, now steadfast, reverts to *Kun*—is this not scorched dry, wholly returning to the unity of *Qian*?
The lost child vanishes and instantly returns home, while the *Water-Visceral Cave*’s monkeys, no longer adrift, tread solid ground, recognize their homeland, and escape *Kan* to fill *Qian* and exhaust *Li*.

Wukong then utters the words of the Dao’s absence in the South, pointing the way to the West.
Such brushstrokes in the Immortal Master’s book—without penetrating *yin-yang* or fathoming creation’s workings, how could one grasp their meaning?
This is what is called 'severing the demon to return to the root and unite with the primordial spirit'—is this not the true merit of sharing heaven’s lifespan, the great gateway to undying longevity?
With the attainment of pure yang, descendants endure unbroken, transformations boundless—how could heaven, earth, or the netherworld restrain them?

**Chapter Three: The Four Seas and Thousand Mountains All Bow in Submission, The Nine Netherworlds and Ten Kinds All Lose Their Names**

Wu Yizi said: This elucidates the great Dao of the Golden Elixir as the metal within water. One who attains its truth can, from the near to the distant, from the manifest to the hidden, extend their will without hindrance across the earth.
Since obtaining the metal from the *Demon King of the Turbid World*, Wukong swiftly seized the metal from the armory of Aolai Country, then gathered the tribute metal from the seventy-two caves. Flower Fruit Mountain became an ironclad golden fortress, its foundation unshakable, its reach boundless—yet it had not yet attained spiritual communion.
Thus, the Monkey King said, 'This blade of mine is truly fierce, but it does not fulfill my intent.'
For this Dao prizes centrality and purity, only then can it advance unimpeded.
Thus, the quest to seek broadly from the sea cannot cease."

chunks.original_text: 从铁板桥下而入求铁板，一定之理也。 自称天生圣人，无生无灭，自命非凡，必须得至一者以操之也。 龙王取出一把大杆刀，乃乾之初九，勿用也； 又抬出一杆九股叉，乃乾之九四，未可意也； 三千六百斤者，四九三十六也。 统初九、九二、九三也。 又抬出画杆方天戟，乃乾之九三、九四、上九也，统三爻为八九七千二百斤也，亦未可意也。 及说出天河定底神针铁，是大禹定江海浅深的一个定子。 噫！ 可悟矣。 此乃尧授之舜，舜授之禹，圣圣相传，用中之精微，其乾之九五，龙德之正中者也。 非天生之圣人，从容之大勇，不能胜任哉！ 龙王道："扛不动，抬不动！ "金光万道者，万理万物皆从此生也。 二丈长者，二五又十也； 东三、南二、北一、西四、中十也； 两头两个金箍，中间一段乌铁者，执两用中也。 唤作如意金箍棒，重一万三千五百斤，如意者，一如我心之运用而咸宜也。 一万三千五百斤者，得九又五九四十五也，九五也。 又隐寓三四一十二，为东西南北中之象。 得一万二千，又加十五，为三五之义。 此器已统乾卦之全象。 一边心思口念，只有丈二长短，碗口粗细，可见此物随意转变，有定之中而无定。 丈二者，亦三四一十二也； 碗口者，圆极也。 又可见无定之中而有定。 盖刚健中正，纯粹精也。 此明慧器入手之妙也。 数百年来，读《西游》、批《西游》者，亦俱说是心，以着如意二字也。 不知《中庸》程序所云"正道宝圣"者，果是心乎？ 抑非心乎？ 何不将其书"始言一理，终散为万事，末复合为一理，放之则弥六合，卷之则退藏于密"一细味之乎？ 此金箍棒为历圣相传，执中之要旨明矣。 仙家谓之水中金者，正大道内之至真至妙，而不可以言传者也。 悟空执在手中者，执中也； 一客不犯二主，没有定不出门者，不二法门也； 走三家不如坐一家，千万告求一件者，三家总属一家，万件总归一件，所谓"得其一，万事毕"也。 不去不去，随高就低者，不执理以逐物，俟物来而应之也。 擂鼓撞钟，须臾到齐者，声施宏远，感应神速也。 东为青龙之木，必得三人之奉而始完全其棒。 有谘诹四岳，和合四象之义焉。 仙师下字之妙如此。 藉丝履出于水，玄武也，北也； 锁子甲成于金，白虎也，西也； 凤翅冠明于火，朱雀也，南也。 乃自东自西自南自北，无思不服也。 此提纲所谓"四海千山皆拱服"也。 悟空跳出波外，身上更无一点水湿。 金光灿灿，走上桥来。 盖属纯乾之象而道体完备矣。 将宝贝揩在手中，叫大就大，叫小就小，使出一个法天象地的神通，那棒上抵三十三天，下至十八层地狱。 收了法象，还变做绣花针儿，藏在耳内一段，读《西游》者又以为奇异变化，必无此事，不过形容心之妙耳。 不知是极庸常之定理，即"散之则弥六合，卷之则退藏于密"也。 岂曰心猿意马之谓哉？ 此道也，非止魔物人神之拱服，亦幽冥异类之所钦仰也。 四猴六王亦为十类。 举蛟鹏狮猕之大而一切飞走之小与蠢动含灵者，莫不于焉统之矣。 老君曰："玄牝之门，是谓造化根。 众夫蹈以出，蠕动莫不由。 "盖能尽其性，则能尽人物之性。 一尽无不尽，而可以放下心矣。 不曰"放心"而曰"放下心"，不曰"心放下"而曰"放下心"，其中妙义非世人所知。
chunks.translated_text:
Seeking the iron plate beneath the Iron-Plate Bridge is a principle of certainty. One who styles himself a Heaven-Born Sage, beyond birth and extinction, and claims extraordinary destiny must obtain the Ultimate Oneness to wield it.

The Dragon King produced a great halberd—this was Qian’s first yang, yet it was not to be used. He then brought forth a nine-pronged fork—this was Qian’s fourth yang, but it did not suit his intent. The weight of three thousand six hundred catties corresponded to four nines, thirty-six, encompassing the first, second, and third yang lines. Next appeared a painted-shaft square halberd—this was Qian’s third, fourth, and top yang lines, uniting three lines into eight nines, seven thousand two hundred catties—still not to his liking.

Only when the Heaven-River Bottom-Stabilizing Divine Iron was mentioned—Yu the Great’s gauge for measuring the depths of rivers and seas—did enlightenment dawn. This treasure had been passed from Yao to Shun, and Shun to Yu, transmitted through the sages as the essence of centrality, the very core of Qian’s fifth yang, the true mean of the Dragon’s virtue. None but a Heaven-Born Sage, possessed of effortless great courage, could bear such a burden! The Dragon King declared, "It cannot be lifted, nor carried!"

The iron radiated ten thousand beams of golden light—for from it arise all principles and all things. Its length of two *zhang* signified two fives making ten; the directions—east three, south two, north one, west four, center ten—were all embodied. The two golden bands at either end and the black iron in the center represented the principle of "grasping the two extremes and employing the mean." Named the Compliant Golden-Hooped Rod, it weighed thirteen thousand five hundred catties—for compliance meant adapting perfectly to the mind’s every movement. Thirteen thousand five hundred catties corresponded to nine and five nines, forty-five—this was the nine-five. It also concealed the numbers three and four, twelve, symbolizing the directions of east, west, south, north, and center. Twelve thousand, plus fifteen, embodied the meaning of three and five. This instrument thus encompassed the entire hexagram of Qian.

As the Monkey King pondered and murmured, the rod shrank to a length of one *zhang* and two *chi*, as thick as a rice bowl—revealing its ability to transform at will, possessing constancy within inconstancy. The length of one *zhang* and two *chi* also signified three and four, twelve; the bowl’s mouth represented perfect roundness, showing inconstancy within constancy. For it was firm, strong, central, and pure—utterly refined. Such was the marvel of this enlightened instrument when grasped.

For centuries, readers and commentators of *Journey to the West* have all claimed this rod symbolizes the mind, fixating on the word "compliant." Yet do they not know the *Doctrine of the Mean*’s preface speaks of "the treasure of the sage, the correct Dao"? Is this truly the mind, or not? Why not ponder deeply the passage: "It begins with one principle, unfolds into ten thousand affairs, and in the end returns to one principle—when extended, it fills the six directions; when retracted, it withdraws into secrecy"?

The Golden-Hooped Rod, passed down through the sages, clearly embodies the essential principle of centrality. Daoist adepts call it "the metal within water"—the utmost truth and wonder within the great Dao, beyond words. When Wukong held it in his hand, he grasped the mean. "One guest does not offend two hosts," and "without a fixed destination, he does not leave"—this is the non-dual Dharma gate. "Walking three houses is not as good as sitting in one," and "seeking ten thousand things is still seeking one thing"—for three houses are ultimately one house, ten thousand things ultimately one thing, as the saying goes: "Obtain the One, and all affairs are complete." "Not going, not going, adapting to high and low"—this is not clinging to principle to chase after things, but awaiting their arrival to respond. "Beating the drum and striking the bell, all assemble in an instant"—its influence is vast, its spiritual resonance swift.

East is the Wood of the Azure Dragon, and only with the tribute of three beings was the rod made complete. Herein lies the meaning of consulting the Four Peaks and harmonizing the Four Symbols. Such was the subtlety of the immortal master’s naming.

The silk slippers emerged from water—this was the Dark Warrior, the north. The chainmail armor was forged from metal—this was the White Tiger, the west. The phoenix-winged crown blazed with fire—this was the Vermilion Bird, the south. Thus, from east, west, south, and north, all submitted without resistance. This was the guiding principle: "The thousand mountains and four seas all bow in submission."

Wukong leapt from the waves, his body not a drop wet. Golden light gleamed as he walked onto the bridge—for he now embodied the pure Qian hexagram, and the Dao’s essence was complete. Holding the treasure in his hand, he could make it large or small at will, displaying a divine power that modeled heaven and earth. The rod reached up to the thirty-third heaven and down to the eighteenth layer of hell. When he withdrew the cosmic form, it shrank back into an embroidery needle, which he tucked into his ear. Readers of *Journey to the West* marvel at such wondrous transformations, dismissing them as impossible—mere metaphors for the mind’s subtlety. Yet this is the most ordinary of principles: "When extended, it fills the six directions; when retracted, it withdraws into secrecy." How can this be called the "monkey mind" or "horse intent"?

This Dao commands not only the submission of demons, humans, and spirits but also the reverence of the hidden and the strange. The four monkeys and six kings make ten kinds. From the great—dragons, roc, lions, and macaques—to all creatures that fly, walk, or crawl, and all beings with consciousness, none are not encompassed by it.

Lord Laozi said: "The Gate of the Mysterious Female is called the Root of Creation. All men tread upon it to emerge, and all creeping things without exception proceed from it." For one who fully realizes their nature can fully realize the nature of all things. When one is fully realized, all are fully realized—and one can then "lay down the heart." Not "lay down the heart" but "lay the heart down," not "the heart laid down" but "lay down the heart"—the profound meaning therein is beyond the understanding of ordinary people.

chunks.original_text: 未免又有一番私解窃见。 批评者于此着眼，谓是放心之害正，生死关头，因放下心，致魔致睡而入于幽冥界。 看得悟空竟未曾了道而全靠操存者，失之远矣。 提纲云"九幽十类尽除名"，盖明其已经了道而无之不可也。 学问之道，固求其放心而已。 若道果成就，则从心所欲而已。 悟空已得金箍棒，全副披挂，执两用中，神化莫测。 故着"放下心"三字，以明其入地登天而无碍也。 又何死之一字足以动其心？ 故下文先从能入幽冥而见其伎俩也。 批《西游》者总因错认心字为道而以放下心为心害，种种看错，未免失真。 不知心者，正人生生死死之缘因，轮回之根蒂。 圣人言存心者，名教治世之方； 释仙言无心者，无为出世之法。 不洞晓根蒂，但执心浮论，万劫轮回，其能免乎？ 不得道者，死固死，生亦死也； 得其道，生固生，死亦生也。 统生死为一致，则长生矣。 怯死则有死之心而不得生； 不怯死则无生之心而不得死。 若以怕死而存心，则其死也立至； 若不知其心掇存何处，其必存于所生之处，而死中有生，生中又有死。 死死生生，何时了歇？ 未审是人是物，千磨万难，无有出头。 此长死之苦而非长生之乐也。 悟空睡着，见两个人拿一张批文，上有孙悟空三字。 其所差之名，各必一系活无常，一系死有分耳。 不容分说，人所无可如何者也。 悟空独顿然醒悟，掣出宝贝，把两个勾死人打为肉酱。 自解其索，反打入城中，是死者反生而勾死者反死矣。 慌得十殿阎君不能作主，令其自检生死簿，到魂字一千三百五十号，正与宝贝之数相合，亦系三五之数。 至三百四十二岁，百者，一百也，亦系东三南二西四北一中十之数。 取笔过来，一概勾之。 一勾之义妙矣哉！ 心者，死之根也。 其精微姑俟别回畅明。 且明心字之义。 心字之勾向上，不放心，则心字之勾向上而死藉注矣； 勾账之勾向下，放心，则心字之勾向下而死藉消矣。 一概勾之，"了账！ 了账！ 今番不服你管了也"，此等作为，已动地惊天矣。 悟空只如绊了一个草纥[纟*达]之易。 一跌而醒，乃是一要。 凡人以生前为作梦者，悟空以死去为作梦； 凡人以生时而作死事者，悟空以死中而消生名。 下海不妨身往，入幽不妨神往。 其出幽入冥之神通已极其妙。 于草纥[纟*达]一绊，何也？ 草纥[纟*达]者，草昧初开之意。 即屯卦初开草昧，如梦方觉也。 然未经登天，不足以见其开泰之力量也。 试观二表直达上苍，而恰如代为路引。 一角天使来迎，而适待正思天上。 金丹之为用大矣哉！ 故紫阳真君曰："一粒金丹吞入腹，始知我命不由天。 " 第四回　官封弼马心何足　名注齐天意未宁 悟一子曰：此发明能了金液还丹大道，寿与天齐，冲举九天之上，由其出入，天帝亦不得而拘束之也。 天帝为乾坤主宰，黜陟幽冥，包含古今，原无等伦。 惟圣人为能观天之道，执天之行。 运化阴阳，神明合德，万化生身而与天为伍。 何也？

Here yet arises a tangle of private interpretations and stolen insights. Critics who fix their gaze upon this point declare that the very harm of "laying down the heart" lies in its truth—at the threshold of life and death, to "lay down the heart" is to invite demonic delusions and drowsy torpor, plunging one into the netherworld. They regard Sun Wukong as never having attained the Dao, relying solely on forced preservation, missing the mark by a vast margin. The guiding principle states, *"The Nine Netherworlds and Ten Kinds are all erased from the register,"* for it is made clear that he has already attained the Dao, and thus nothing can bind him. The path of learning, indeed, seeks only to "lay down the heart." Yet if the Dao is truly perfected, one may follow the heart’s desires without restraint. Wukong has already obtained the Golden Cudgel, donned his full armor, and wields the mean with divine transformation—his powers unfathomable. Thus, the phrase *"lay down the heart"* is employed to reveal his unobstructed ascent to heaven and descent into earth. How could the mere word "death" stir his heart? Hence, the following passage first demonstrates his prowess by entering the netherworld and displaying his artifice.

Those who critique *Journey to the West* consistently mistake the heart for the Dao and "laying down the heart" for the heart’s harm, leading to myriad misinterpretations and a loss of truth. They fail to recognize that the heart is precisely the cause of life and death, the root of samsara. The sages speak of preserving the heart as the method for governing the world through moral teachings; the Buddhas and immortals speak of the heart’s absence as the way to transcend the world through non-action. Without penetrating the root, merely clinging to superficial theories of the heart, how can one escape the endless cycle of rebirth? For those who have not attained the Dao, death is death, and life is also death; for those who have attained it, life is life, and death is also life. Unifying life and death as one, one achieves longevity. Fear of death gives rise to the heart of death and thus fails to attain life; fearlessness of death dissolves the heart of life and thus fails to attain death. If one preserves the heart out of fear of death, death arrives swiftly; if one does not know where the heart is stored, it must reside where life arises—within death lies life, and within life lies death. Death after death, life after life—when will it end? Unaware of whether one is human or thing, enduring countless trials without liberation, this is the suffering of eternal death, not the joy of eternal life.

Wukong, asleep, saw two figures holding a writ bearing the name "Sun Wukong." The names they bore were inevitably one "Living Uncertain" and the other "Death’s Allotment"—inescapable, beyond human control. Wukong alone awoke in sudden realization, drew his treasure, and pounded the two death-summoners into mincemeat. He untied his bonds, stormed back into the city, turning the dead to life and the death-summoners to death. The Ten Yama Kings, thrown into chaos, could not command him and ordered him to inspect the Register of Life and Death himself. Upon reaching the *hun* section, entry 1,350, it matched the number of his treasure—also a combination of three and five. At 342 years, the "hundred" signified one hundred, also corresponding to the numbers of the five directions: east three, south two, west four, north one, and center ten. He took up the brush and struck through them all. The meaning of this single stroke is profound! The heart is the root of death. Its subtleties shall be expounded in another passage; for now, let us clarify the meaning of the character for "heart."

When the hook of the character *xin* (心, "heart") points upward, it signifies "not laying down the heart," and thus the ledger of death is recorded; when the hook points downward, it signifies "laying down the heart," and thus the ledger of death is erased. Striking through them all, he declared, *"Settled! Settled! From now on, you have no authority over me!"* Such actions shook heaven and earth. Yet for Wukong, it was as effortless as tripping over a blade of grass. A single stumble awakened him—this was the key. Ordinary people take their lives to be a dream; Wukong took death to be a dream. Ordinary people act as if dead while alive; Wukong erased his living name from within death. Venturing into the sea posed no obstacle to his body; entering the netherworld posed no obstacle to his spirit. His divine transformations in exiting and entering the netherworld reached their utmost subtlety. Why, then, did he trip over a blade of grass? The "blade of grass" (*caoda*) signifies the dawn of primordial chaos, like the initial hexagram *Zhun*, where chaos first parts, as if awakening from a dream. Yet without ascending to heaven, one cannot witness the power of its unfolding.

Observe how the two memorials reached directly to the heavens, as if serving as his passport. A celestial envoy arrived to welcome him, precisely as he was contemplating the heavens. How vast is the function of the Golden Elixir! Thus, the Perfected Lord of Purple Yang said: *"Swallow a grain of the Golden Elixir, and you will know your fate is not ruled by heaven."*

**Chapter Four: Appointed as Protector of the Horses—Heart Still Unsatisfied; Named Equal of Heaven—Intent Yet Unsettled**

Master Wu Yi Zi said: This reveals the great Dao of the Golden Fluid and Returning Elixir, where one’s lifespan equals that of heaven, soaring above the Nine Heavens, transcending all bounds—even the Heavenly Emperor cannot restrain him. The Heavenly Emperor, sovereign of heaven and earth, governs the netherworld, encompasses past and present, and has no equal. Only the sage can observe the Dao of heaven and grasp its workings, harmonizing yin and yang, uniting with the divine in virtue, and transforming all things to stand alongside heaven. Why is this so?
