chunks.original_text: 金者，历劫而不坏； 丹者，日月之精神，浑是一团阳气。 天地之所循环者，气也； 金丹之所变化者，亦气也。 天地之气，无所不包； 金丹之气无所不有。 故《参同契》曰："含精养神，通德三光。 众邪辟陈，正气常存。 "又曰："幽潜沦匿，变化于中。 包囊万物，为道纪纲。 "皆言圣人与天齐体而等量也。 《易》所谓与天地合德，日月合明，鬼神合吉凶者，何异《中庸》所谓"天地位，万物育，又皆童而习之"者？ 大圣之与天齐名，夫何疑哉？ 读《西游》者错看提纲"心何足"、"意未宁"，又解作心猿意马放心妄想，钩取篇内半句一言，牵合其说。 总因未识金丹之道之大也。 金丹之道会五皇而还于太极，御劫运于无穷，出乾坤于不约者也，岂代天御马之足以称其职？ 亦齐天虚位之未可尽其量也。 金星与猴王一齐驾云而起，何以把金星撇在脑后？ 金星者，五行之一； 悟空者，五行之全也。 然何以挡住天门，不肯放进？ 见天神亦所不能识也。 金星说到素不相识，见了天尊，向后随你出入。 悟空何以说"也罢，我不进去了。 "总由我而不肯为天所限也。 金星奏曰"妖仙已到。 "玉帝问曰："那个是妖仙？ "以悟空而称为妖，妖名违其实矣。 悟空即应到："老孙便是。 "直受而不辞，已见其包含之量。 一切仙卿反大惊失色，则地位不及可知。 帝又曰："下界妖仙初得人身，不明朝礼。 "若天帝之包含矣，实未察其为先天真乙之妙也。 正是下文不能收伏之根。 悟空却朝上唱个大喏，亦直受而不辞。 非悟空之包含天帝哉？ 天宫御马监缺个正堂，玉帝传旨，授为弼马温。 到任之后，弼马昼夜不睡。 盖体"天行健，君子终日乾乾，夕惕若，自强不息"之义。 读《西游》者批为子午抽添之火候，真傍门谬说也。 然在天上视之谓之马者，在地下视之必谓之龙矣。 在天上名之谓御马监者，在地下名之必谓之御龙监矣。 悟空曰："没品，想是极大？ "大众道："唤做未入流。 "在天宫为未入流者，在地宫仰之即极品矣。 悟空何以曰："不做他，不做他？ "昔者，陶唐氏欲以天下让巢由，而且有洗耳污口之故事。 岂道大如悟空而犹肯终其职于御马监耶？ 忽喇一声推倒此席，取出宝贝打出御马监，径至南天门。 何等斩然超脱也。 不觉心中火起，心中大恼，只是发明以御劫之大圣而欲以御马之一职收伏之，已大违其本来，必不可得。 心中火，心中恼，乃由金光自然之发越也。 批者又以为放心妄意，试问上帝明威之所，可容放心妄意者恣其出入而又无可如何耶？ 紫阳真君曰："一粒金丹吞入腹，始知我命不由天。 "魏伯阳祖师曰："天地神明，不可测度。 利用安身，隐形而藏。 "夫天地之形体象数，人皆知之。 至于神藏鬼匿之机，人固莫得而测也。 唯圣人知精气为物，游魂为变。 是故知鬼神之情状，乃擅其利用，安乎其身。 宇宙在乎手，造化生于心。 出有入无，隐显莫测。 知此则知大圣之入地登天，皆系真心实用而非天之所能规域。 故有独角鬼王为之推戴。 王而独角者，主也。 特献赭黄袍，乃黄中通理之象。 劝晋齐天大圣，立竿张挂，明主张由我而不由天也。 特黄而加赭，过赤也，有阳极之义。 王而自主，亢也。

Gold is indestructible through kalpas; the Elixir is the essence of sun and moon, a mass of pure Yang qi. What heaven and earth circulate is qi; what the Golden Elixir transforms is also qi. The qi of heaven and earth encompasses all; the qi of the Golden Elixir contains all. Thus the *Cantong Qi* states: *"Nurture essence and cultivate spirit, commune with the virtue of the Three Lights. All evil disperses, and the true qi abides."* It also says: *"Hidden and submerged, it transforms within, enfolding the myriad things as the warp and woof of the Dao."* Both speak of the sage’s body and measure equaling that of heaven. What the *Book of Changes* calls *"harmonizing virtue with heaven and earth, brightness with sun and moon, fortune and misfortune with ghosts and spirits"*—how does this differ from the *Doctrine of the Mean*’s *"Heaven and earth take their places, the myriad things are nurtured, all learned and practiced from childhood"*? That the great sage equals heaven in name—what doubt can there be?

Those who read *Journey to the West* misread its key themes, taking *"heart still unsatisfied"* and *"intent yet unsettled"* as mere "monkey-mind and horse-will," seizing half a phrase or a single word to force their interpretations. All because they fail to grasp the vastness of the Golden Elixir’s Dao. The Dao of the Golden Elixir unites the Five Emperors and returns to the Supreme Ultimate, steers kalpas through the boundless, and transcends the constraints of heaven and earth—how could the post of Heavenly Stablemaster suffice to match its office? Even the empty title of "Equal of Heaven" cannot exhaust its measure.

When the Star of Metal and the Monkey King ascend together on clouds, why is the Star of Metal left behind? The Star of Metal is but one of the Five Phases; Sun Wukong embodies all Five Phases. Yet why does he block the gates of heaven, refusing entry? Even the heavenly deities cannot recognize him. The Star of Metal says they have never met, and that upon seeing the Heavenly Honored One, he may come and go as he pleases. Why then does Wukong say, *"Very well, I shall not enter"*? It is simply that he refuses to be bound by heaven.

The Star of Metal reports: *"The demonic immortal has arrived."* The Jade Emperor asks: *"Which one is the demonic immortal?"* To call Wukong a demon is a misnomer. Wukong responds at once: *"This old monkey is."* Accepting the title without refusal reveals his capacity for inclusion. All the immortal ministers recoil in shock—his stature is clearly beyond theirs. The Emperor then says: *"This demonic immortal from the lower realm, newly attained human form, does not understand court etiquette."* Though the Heavenly Emperor displays magnanimity, he has not yet discerned Wukong’s wondrous nature as the primordial True One. This is the root of his later inability to subdue him.

Wukong bows deeply toward the throne, accepting without refusal. Is this not Wukong encompassing the Heavenly Emperor? The Heavenly Stables lack a director, and the Jade Emperor issues a decree appointing him *Bima Wen*. Upon taking office, *Bima* works day and night without rest, embodying the meaning of *"Heaven’s movement is ceaseless; the noble person exerts unrelenting effort, vigilant even at dusk, ever striving."* Those who annotate *Journey to the West* misinterpret this as the fire-timing of midnight and noon—truly a heretical and absurd reading.

Yet what is called a "horse" in heaven would surely be called a "dragon" on earth. What is named the "Heavenly Stables" in heaven would surely be named the "Dragon Taming Bureau" on earth. Wukong asks: *"No rank—does that mean it’s extremely high?"* The crowd replies: *"It’s called ‘Unranked.’"* What is "unranked" in heaven becomes the highest rank when viewed from the earthly realm. Why then does Wukong say: *"I won’t do it, I won’t do it"*? In ancient times, Emperor Yao sought to yield the world to Xu You and Chao Fu, who washed their ears to cleanse the taint of such an offer. How could one as great as Wukong willingly remain in the post of Heavenly Stablemaster?

With a sudden crash, he overturns his seat, draws out his treasure, and smashes his way out of the stables, heading straight for the Southern Gate of Heaven. What resolute transcendence! Unaware, his heart ignites with fury, his mind seething with indignation—this reveals that to assign the office of stablemaster to one who steers kalpas is a fundamental contradiction, utterly impossible. The fire in his heart, the rage in his mind, arise from the natural effulgence of his golden light. Annotators again mistake this for "scattered thoughts and wild intentions." But in the radiant presence of the Heavenly Emperor, could one with scattered thoughts and wild intentions roam freely, unchecked and unchallenged?

Purple Yang the Perfected says: *"Swallow a grain of the Golden Elixir, and you will know your fate is not ruled by heaven."* The ancestral master Wei Boyang says: *"Heaven and earth, gods and spirits, cannot be fathomed. Use them to secure your body, conceal your form, and hide."* The forms, images, and numbers of heaven and earth are known to all. But the mechanisms of divine concealment and ghostly stealth remain beyond human comprehension. Only the sage knows that essence becomes things and wandering souls transform. Thus, understanding the conditions of ghosts and spirits, he masters their utility and secures his body. The cosmos rests in his hand; creation arises from his heart. He emerges from being and enters non-being, his presence and absence unfathomable. Knowing this, one understands that the great sage’s descent to earth and ascent to heaven are matters of true intent and real application, not subject to heaven’s constraints.

Thus, the Single-Horned Demon King pledges allegiance to him. A king with a single horn is a sovereign. The offering of the cinnabar-yellow robe symbolizes the principle of *"yellow at the center, penetrating all patterns."* Urging him to proclaim himself the Great Sage Equal of Heaven and raise his banner is to declare that authority rests with him, not heaven. The robe is yellow with a cinnabar hue—surpassing red, it embodies the meaning of *"Yang at its apex."* A king who rules himself is lofty indeed.

Only the sage can observe the Dao of heaven and grasp its workings, harmonizing yin and yang, uniting with the divine in virtue, and transforming all things to stand alongside heaven. chunks.original_text: 有亢龙之象。 已伏后回乱反之根。 及玉帝封李天王为降魔大元帅，欲收伏大圣。 不察其孕育之根源，修持之奥妙，而反以大圣为魔，不能收伏也宜矣。 故巨灵神一棒而逃，哪咤又一棒而逃。 以全体之圣而取胜于诸天之末，又何怪焉？ 然巨灵之非敌而逃，宜矣。 哪咤一变而为三头为六臂为万万千千，乃乾之三横，为万变从化之象。 大圣亦一变为三头为六臂为万万千千，乃乾之三横，为万变从化之象。 体相等，力相敌也。 何以大圣拔下一毛，现出本象，从后打哪咤左膊一下而遂逃？ 盖哪咤在先，为乾之下三爻； 大圣在后，为乾之上三爻。 纯阳之极，则必变而反于初爻，以破其坚，岂非拔一毛出本象，从背后伤其左膊耶？ 惟天以大圣为魔，是认真为假，因而有六魔称圣，反以假为真。 不但不能伏圣，而并不能伏魔矣。 天以圣为魔，而不能收伏一魔； 圣以魔为圣，而且能收伏群圣。 并后此之收伏千魔万怪，皆基于此。 其度量固早已包乎天之外而非齐天之虚号足以羁縻之也。 迨天王太子回奏请兵，玉帝闻言惊讶，犹谓狂妄而欲诛之。 即佛祖所谓"一切诸天，皆当惊疑"者，此也。 太白奏道："恐一时不能收伏，请就做齐天大圣，收他的邪心。 "玉帝依奏降诏，若似乎天能纵之圣之。 纵之圣而终不能收伏者，在收其邪心之见。 盖悟空而非圣，则不能纵。 既纵其圣，又何可去邪？ 云邪而纵，是纵邪也，又何能收伏？ 此后日之乱蟠桃，非悟空也，玉帝与金星纵之使乱也。 悟空何心焉？ 悟空见蟠桃则食之，亦惟有听其圣之邪之而已矣。 玉帝曰："悟空过来，今宣你做齐天大圣。 "官品极矣。 玉帝以为极品者，悟空亦止朝上唱个大喏，与前弼马温时无异。 初不以齐天大圣为极品，盖大圣乃其自大，齐天乃其自齐，初非帝之大之齐之也。 夫既自大自齐，不能使其不大不齐，又何能使之安之宁之哉？ 虚设二司，何益之有？ 适以司其不安，司其不尽而已。
chunks.translated_text:
Herein lies the image of the Ascendant Dragon. Though it has subdued the root of future chaos and rebellion, when the Jade Emperor appointed Li Tianwang as the Great Marshal to Subdue Demons, seeking to capture and tame the Great Sage, he failed to examine the origins of his nurturance or the subtleties of his cultivation. Instead, he mistook the Great Sage for a demon—no wonder he could not subdue him.

Thus, when the Giant Spirit Deity struck once and fled, and Nezha struck once and fled, how could it be strange that one whose sageliness was whole triumphed over the lesser denizens of heaven? That the Giant Spirit fled without a fight was only fitting. Yet when Nezha transformed—sprouting three heads, six arms, and ten thousand thousand forms—this was the three horizontal lines of *Qian*, the image of myriad transformations following nature. The Great Sage likewise transformed—three heads, six arms, ten thousand thousand forms—also the three horizontal lines of *Qian*, the image of myriad transformations following nature. Their forms were equal, their strength matched.

Why, then, did the Great Sage pluck a single hair, reveal his original form, and strike Nezha’s left shoulder from behind, sending him fleeing? For Nezha stood first, as the lower three lines of *Qian*, while the Great Sage stood after, as the upper three lines of *Qian*. At the apex of pure Yang, it must transform and return to the first line, breaking its rigidity—was this not the plucking of a single hair to reveal his original form, striking from behind to wound the left shoulder?

Heaven mistook the Great Sage for a demon, taking truth for falsehood, and thus the Six Demons proclaimed themselves sages, inverting falsehood as truth. Not only could it not subdue the sage, but it could not even subdue demons. Heaven, seeing the sage as a demon, could not subdue a single demon; the sage, seeing demons as sages, could subdue a host of sages. All later subduals of a thousand demons and ten thousand monsters stemmed from this. His capacity had long since encompassed what lay beyond heaven—how could the empty title of "Equal of Heaven" bind him?

When the Heavenly King’s son returned to report and request troops, the Jade Emperor, astonished by his words, still deemed them mad and sought to execute him. This was precisely what the Buddha had foretold: *"All the hosts of heaven shall be struck with doubt."* The Star of Venus then memorialized, "Fearing we cannot subdue him at once, I beg to appoint him as the Great Sage Equal of Heaven, to curb his wayward heart." The Jade Emperor assented and issued the decree, as if heaven could thus indulge the sage.

Yet indulging the sage while failing to subdue him arose from the misguided attempt to "curb his wayward heart." For if Wukong were not a sage, he could not be indulged; once indulged as a sage, how could his "waywardness" be removed? To call it waywardness while indulging it was to indulge the waywardness itself—how could this lead to subjugation? The later chaos in the Peach Orchard was not Wukong’s doing, but the result of the Jade Emperor and the Golden Star indulging him to create disorder. What intent did Wukong have? When he saw the peaches, he ate them—what else could he do but follow the sage’s or the demon’s nature as it arose?

The Jade Emperor said, "Wukong, come forth. I now proclaim you the Great Sage Equal of Heaven." The rank was supreme. Yet what the Jade Emperor deemed the highest office, Wukong merely acknowledged with a bow, no different from his time as Keeper of the Heavenly Stables. He did not regard the title of Great Sage Equal of Heaven as the ultimate rank, for his greatness was self-proclaimed, his equality with heaven self-declared—it was not the emperor who made him great or equal. Since he had already made himself great and equal, how could one prevent him from being so? And how could one make him content or at peace?

The establishment of two empty offices was of no benefit—it only served to oversee his discontent and his incompleteness.
chunks.overlap_context: Single-Horned Demon King pledges allegiance to him. A king with a single horn is a sovereign. The offering of the cinnabar-yellow robe symbolizes the principle of *"yellow at the center, penetrating all patterns."* Urging him to proclaim himself the Great Sage Equal of Heaven and raise his banner is to declare that authority rests with him, not heaven. The robe is yellow with a cinnabar hue—surpassing red, it embodies the meaning of *"Yang at its apex."* A king who rules himself is lofty indeed.

chunks.original_text: 第五回　乱蟠桃大圣偷丹　反天宫诸神捉怪 悟一子曰：此发明天道物极必反，乃鬼神莫测之机，正先天真乙之气自然之运用，并非大圣自得主张。 仙师特假名托象，以形容其妙耳。 错认心猿者以为极力描写，不识道理者以为文字变化，岂不毫厘千里之谬哉？ 大圣自立而正，与天齐名，乃乾之上九，亢龙之象也。 阳极必反，自然之理，岂大圣果能反耶？ 岂天宫果可反之所耶？ 天宫乾为天也，上九之宫也，岂真天宫而大圣能反之耶？ 然反则必先于乱，乱则必有其由其所。 云心猿纵放，无故设此幻想，结撰簇簇笔花徒眩人心目耶？ 齐天府起在蟠桃右，右则桃园在左明矣。 天道左旋者也。 大圣居纯阳之上，阳中之阳，其气变温为热，万物茂盛之时，其阳极而成亢。 夏至一阴生而势不能反阴，而左旋于蟠桃园矣。 左首为青龙，属木，故为桃，此真人闲中生事之请。 玉帝权管蟠桃之命，气运之所必至，而并非大圣之所自主也。 世人之疑者以为大圣既得先天之道，乃能统御阴阳而不为阴阳所规弄，何以不能自主而反耶？ 不知先天之道一顺一逆者，先天之道逆而体之，而反阴而阳，成圣成仙成佛。 而人物顺之，魔怪顺之，地只顺之，幽冥顺之，天神亦顺之。 以逆为体，以顺为用，逆生顺也。 所谓先天而天弗违也，用九而不为九所用也。 先天之道顺而用之，则反阳而阴，为人为物为鬼为魔怪。 而诸神逆之，诸天逆之，诸仙佛亦逆之。 以顺为体，以逆为用，顺生逆也，所谓后天而奉天时也，用六而不为六所用也。 程子曰："心通天地之先而用必后天，事配天地之后而知必先天。 "《文言》曰："知进退存亡而不失其正者，其唯圣人乎？ "此反天宫也，正明大圣之顺用先天之妙也。 蟠桃园者，坤宫之帝出乎震也。 三千六百株者，坤宫之六六三十六也。 前一千二百株者，坤初二爻之二六一十二也。 三千年一熟者，得下乘也。 中一千二百株者，坤中二爻之二六一十二也。 得中乘也。 后一千二百株者，坤五六爻之二六一十二也，得上乘也。 桃熟者，阴中之阳也。 自此以后三五日一次赏玩者，五日为一候，十五日为一气，三五十五，阴气为之一降也。 所以候桃之熟，而顺天之行也。 忽设一计者，阳体将变之时也。 脱下冠服者，剥至之象也。 熟的大桃吃了一饱者，阳受坤之阴气而阳渐变阴也。 二三日又去偷桃者，三二日为五，又一候也。 王母差七仙女摘桃者，后之女为姤，六阳遇七而来姤也，复至七日为姤，故为七女。 大圣变二寸小人在大树梢浓叶底睡着，妙矣哉！ 绿叶成阴，二为阴爻，小为阴象。 乃大变为小，奇成偶，阳化阴。 乾初得阴而为巽也。 睡着者，阳息阴盛之时。 顺天而潜，即用九"见群龙无首"，本刚而用之以柔，居亢而潜之于初也。 篇中"只有衣寇不知何往，四下里都没寻处"等语，俱是妙义。 仙女入树下摘桃，阴之渐进而剥阳也。 前三篮后三篮，非先甲三日后甲三日，即前三与后三耶？ 由前而中，由中而后，只见花果稀疏，隐言花果山之时逢剥落也。 仙女东张西望，只见向南枝上只有个半红半白的桃子，青衣女子扯下枝条，红衣女子摘了等语，妙义不可言尽。 言向南则系北枝所结之桃； 半红半白，将熟之候；

Wukuyi said: This reveals the Dao of heaven where things reach their extreme and must reverse—a mechanism beyond the ken of ghosts and spirits, the natural operation of the primordial True Unity’s qi, not something the Great Sage could claim as his own design. The immortal master merely borrows names and images to depict its wonder. Those who mistake this for a mere "monkey of the mind" take it as a display of literary skill, while those who fail to grasp the principle see it as mere stylistic variation—how far they stray from the truth by a hair’s breadth!

The Great Sage established himself in rectitude, matching heaven in name—this is the ninth line of Qian, the image of the ascendant dragon. When yang reaches its extreme, it must reverse: such is the natural principle. How could the Great Sage truly reverse it? How could the Heavenly Palace truly be overturned? The Heavenly Palace is Qian as heaven, the palace of the ninth line—could the Great Sage truly reverse it? Yet reversal must begin with disorder, and disorder must have its cause and occasion.

Why does the text speak of the "monkey of the mind" running wild, conjuring these illusions, weaving clusters of literary flowers merely to dazzle the eyes and mind? The Palace of Equality with Heaven stands to the right of the Peach Orchard, so the orchard must lie to the left. The Dao of heaven turns leftward. The Great Sage dwells at the pinnacle of pure yang, yang within yang—his qi shifts from warmth to heat, the time when the myriad things flourish, when yang reaches its extreme and becomes ascendant.

At the summer solstice, a single yin is born, yet its force cannot reverse into yin; instead, it turns leftward toward the Peach Orchard. The left side is the Green Dragon, belonging to wood, hence the peach—this is the idle provocation of a true person. The Jade Emperor’s authority over the peaches is the inevitable course of qi’s movement, not something the Great Sage could control.

Those who doubt may ask: If the Great Sage has attained the primordial Dao, mastering yin and yang without being manipulated by them, why can he not control himself from reversing? They do not understand that the primordial Dao moves both in accord and in opposition. The primordial Dao is opposed in its embodiment, reversing yin into yang, becoming sage, immortal, or buddha. Yet humans, creatures, demons, and ghosts follow its accord, as do the earth, the netherworld, and even the heavenly gods. To embody opposition while employing accord—this is how opposition gives rise to accord. This is what is meant by "the primordial Dao, which heaven does not defy," and "using the nine without being used by it."

When the primordial Dao is employed in accord, it reverses yang into yin, becoming human, creature, ghost, or demon. Then the gods oppose it, the heavens oppose it, and even the buddhas and immortals oppose it. To embody accord while employing opposition—this is how accord gives rise to opposition. This is what is meant by "the later heaven following heaven’s timing," and "using the six without being used by it." Master Cheng said: "The mind connects with what precedes heaven, yet its application must follow the later heaven; affairs align with what follows heaven, yet their understanding must precede heaven."

The *Wenyan* states: "Who but the sage knows advance and retreat, life and death, without losing correctness?" This rebellion in the Heavenly Palace precisely illustrates the Great Sage’s masterful employment of the primordial Dao in accord. The Peach Orchard is the emergence of the emperor from Zhen within the Kun palace. The three thousand six hundred trees correspond to the six sixes of thirty-six in the Kun palace. The first twelve hundred trees are the two sixes of twelve in Kun’s initial two lines—this is the lower vehicle. The three thousand years for their ripening signify the lesser attainment.

The middle twelve hundred trees are the two sixes of twelve in Kun’s middle two lines—this is the middle vehicle. The last twelve hundred trees are the two sixes of twelve in Kun’s fifth and sixth lines—this is the higher vehicle. The ripened peaches are yang within yin. After this, visiting every three to five days: five days make a *hou*, fifteen days make a *qi*, and three times five is fifteen—this marks the descent of yin qi. Thus, the ripening of the peaches follows heaven’s movement.

The sudden scheme arises at the time when the yang body is about to transform. Removing his cap and robes is the image of *Bo* (Splitting) reaching its extreme. Eating his fill of ripe peaches: yang receives Kun’s yin qi, and yang gradually turns to yin. Returning to steal peaches after two or three days: two and three make five, another *hou*. The Queen Mother sends seven immortal maidens to pick peaches: the later hexagram *Gu* (Meeting) is when six yang lines encounter seven, bringing *Gu*—seven days complete *Gu*, hence the seven maidens.

The Great Sage transforms into a two-inch man, sleeping in the dense leaves atop a great tree—how wondrous! Green leaves form shade; two is a yin line, small is a yin image. Thus, the great becomes small, the odd becomes even, yang transforms into yin. Qian’s first line gains yin and becomes Xun. Sleeping marks the time when yang wanes and yin waxes. Following heaven in concealment is "using the nine" to "see a flock of dragons without a head"—employing hardness with softness, dwelling in ascendance yet concealing it in the beginning.

The lines "Only the clothes and hat were missing, nowhere to be found" and the like all carry profound meaning. The immortal maidens enter beneath the trees to pick peaches: yin gradually advances to strip yang. The first three baskets and the last three baskets—are these not "three days before *jia* and three days after *jia*," simply the first three and the last three? From first to middle, from middle to last, only sparse flowers and fruit are seen, subtly alluding to the time of decline on Flower-Fruit Mountain.

The immortal maidens look east and west, seeing only on the southern branch a peach half-red, half-white. The green-clad maiden pulls down the branch, the red-clad maiden plucks it—such wondrous meanings cannot be fully expressed. The southern direction refers to the peach borne on the northern branch; half-red, half-white marks the moment of near-ripening.

chunks.original_text: 只有者，仅见之物也； 青衣女子扯下，青者，真阴之色，内阴而外阳也； 红衣女子摘了，红者，真阳之色，外阴而内阳也。 将枝子往上一放，大圣惊醒，即现本相，此正不期而遇，谓之姤。 纯阳忽遇一阴小人，女子始进之象。 姤天心以巽得坤初为地。 王元美曰："剥乱成姤，姤乱不忧，剥而忧姤。 "盖一阴有敌五阳之志，壮甚可畏。 此正乱蟠桃之祸所由始也。 大圣知为祸始而大怒，说出"偷摘我桃"。 偷桃之义即窃天地之玄机，盗阴阳之造化也。 及仙女说出蟠桃胜会、王母懿旨，东西南北中央诸圣，分明是攒簇五行之象。 而大圣先天之气乃其帝尊也。 大圣知姤始之消息，回嗔作喜，用定身法曰："住住住"，即姤之初六"系于金柅"是也。 如止车之柅而系以金之坚强，止之固而使不进，恐为柔道所牵也。 仙师慈悲之至，已明泄金丹下手之妙于此。 自此大圣跳出桃园，正撞赤脚大仙，即姤之初六"羸豕蹢躅"是也。 豕喜木而蹢躅，虽羸弱之豕，亦必跳踯，固当深为之备而势不何止也。 故定计一变，即改赤脚大仙模样，正剥之初六"剥床以足"之义。 赤足而成剥，阴将侵阳道，自下而上也。 前奔瑶池欲还，未有仙来，忽闻一阵酒香，就弄神通，就缸挨瓮，放量痛饮，即姤之九二"包有鱼，不及宾"是也。 如取渔先至者，一举网而得； 后至者虽善渔利，不及彼矣。 此巽为白茅，包中鱼为阴物之美。 而制之以早，不使其及于众宾也。 在酕醄醉中自道"不好！ 不好！

Only this—what meets the eye alone. The green-clad maiden pulls down the branch: green, the true color of yin, inwardly yin yet outwardly yang. The red-clad maiden plucks it: red, the true color of yang, outwardly yin yet inwardly yang. As the branch is lifted upward, the Great Sage awakens abruptly, revealing his true form—this is an unlooked-for encounter, called *Gou*. Pure yang suddenly meets a single yin, the first advance of the feminine. *Gou* arises when heaven’s heart, through *Xun*, receives the first of *Kun* as earth.

Wang Yuanmei said: “When *Bo* descends into chaos, *Gou* arises; when *Gou* descends into chaos, there is no sorrow—only in *Bo* does one fear *Gou*.” For one yin harbors the ambition to contend with five yangs, its vigor truly formidable. Here lies the very origin of the calamity that would disrupt the Peach Banquet. The Great Sage, recognizing the onset of disaster, flies into a rage, exclaiming, “You’ve stolen my peaches!” To steal peaches is to pilfer the profound mechanism of heaven and earth, to rob the creative workings of yin and yang.

Yet when the immortal maidens speak of the Peach Banquet and the Queen Mother’s august decree, of the sages of east, west, south, north, and center—this is clearly the convergence of the Five Phases. And the Great Sage’s primordial qi is its sovereign lord. Perceiving the portent of *Gou*’s beginning, he turns wrath to joy, employing the art of immobilization: “Stay, stay, stay!”—this is *Gou*’s first six, “bound to the metal *ni*.” Like the *ni* that halts a chariot, fastened with metal’s unyielding strength, it arrests firmly to prevent further advance, lest the yielding way entangle him. Here the immortal master, in utmost compassion, has already revealed the wondrous subtlety of commencing the Golden Elixir.

From this, the Great Sage leaps out of the peach garden and directly encounters the Barefoot Great Immortal—this is *Gou*’s first six, “the emaciated pig hesitates.” The pig delights in wood and hesitates, and though emaciated, it must leap and bound; one must prepare deeply, for its force cannot be easily stopped. Thus he devises a plan and transforms at once, assuming the guise of the Barefoot Great Immortal—this is *Bo*’s first six, “stripping the bed at the feet.” Bare feet signify *Bo*: yin is about to encroach upon the yang path, ascending from below.

Rushing toward Jasper Pool to return, no immortals appear, when suddenly a waft of wine fragrance reaches him. Exerting his divine power, he presses against the vats and jars, drinking to his heart’s content—this is *Gou*’s nine-two, “wrapping the fish, not reaching the guests.” Like a fisherman who arrives first, casting a net to catch all; those who come later, though skilled in fishing, cannot match him. Here *Xun* is the white cogon grass, the wrapped fish the beauty of yin things. Yet it is controlled early, lest it reach the assembled guests. In his drunken stupor, he mutters to himself, “Not good! Not good!”

Wishing to return to his palace to sleep, he takes a wrong step and loses his way—this is *Gou*’s nine-three, “the buttocks stripped of skin, his gait halting and hesitant.” *Xun* is the thigh; three, occupying the upper position, is the buttocks. The first is resented by the second; three, isolated and without support, seeks an encounter in its ambition, thus finding no peace in its place and faltering in its steps. This is the image of being trapped between advance and retreat.

Proceeding to the Tushita Palace, he suddenly awakens to realization: all this time, he had come to seek this elder, yet upon entering, not a soul is to be seen—this is *Gou*’s nine-four, “the wrapped sack holds no fish; misfortune arises.” Four and the first should correspond and meet, but the first has already encountered the second, leaving four unfulfilled. Having lost its destined meeting, it is like a sack without fish—popular favor has departed. The separation is about to begin.

Entering the Elixir Chamber, he sees five gourds, which contain refined golden elixir. Pouring it out, he drinks—this is *Gou*’s nine-five, “wrapping the melon with willow, containing inner radiance; there is a fall from heaven.” Willow grows in fertile soil, yet the wrapped melon remains uneaten. The willow’s binding of the melon is like the five yang forces restraining the initial yin—an effort doomed to collapse. Yet Heaven’s intent is still unfolding; one cannot contend by force. Only by concealing one’s brilliance, keeping inner power hidden, can the Mandate of Heaven be retrieved. The five gourds are the refined golden elixir—nine-five’s veiled radiance lies within, capable of reclaiming the Mandate. This is like a fall from heaven: what was not there suddenly appears. As I seek to consume the golden elixir to forge my destiny, Heaven bestows it freely. Here the immortal master reveals the principle of inner and outer golden elixirs, saving and delivering the world. The meaning of *Gou*’s time is vast indeed!

In an instant, Wukong sobers from his drunkenness, reflecting with unease, “Not good! If I alarm the Jade Emperor, my life will be forfeit. Flee! Flee!”

Without retracing his steps, he took the Western Gate of Heaven, using the art of invisibility to escape, returning to the Mountain of Flowers and Fruit. Ah! How wondrous! The world does not recognize the subtlety within these writings, mistaking Wukong’s violation of Heaven’s decrees as mere worldly flight—unaware that this is the Great Sage’s compliance with Heaven’s will in retreat. Ascending to Heaven and descending to the mountain is called the "Heaven-Mountain Retreat." The Great Sage, knowing the excess of yang and turning toward *xun*, five yang suddenly encountering one yin becomes *gou*—*gou*’s perilous momentum cannot be curbed. It is the root of *xun*; the mechanism of retreat; the gradual onset of *pi*; the foundation of *bo*; the inception of *kun*. To fail to retreat at this juncture is to lack awareness of the moment. This retreat is to depart from excess and conceal oneself in the beginning. Thus, the Great Sage’s disruption of the Peach Banquet was not his doing—it was the work of the qi’s course; the immortal maidens’ plucking of the peaches was not the Queen Mother’s dispatch—it was the qi’s course that sent them. All is the doing of *gou*. Thus, the chapter most thoroughly embeds the meaning of *gou*. Knowing the fierce calamity of feminine yin, only by the Great Sage’s compliance in discerning it and opposition in restraining it can the great Dao of primordial Heaven be made clear. Those who critique *Journey to the West*, reducing the Great Sage’s disruption of the Peach Banquet and rebellion in Heaven’s Palace to mere depictions of deluded desires, do grievous wrong! How lamentable! The Great Sage, returning to the mountain to feast, somersaulted back in an instant using the art of invisibility, arriving at the Jasper Pool—where the guests remained unaware—seizing the four great jars and returning to his cave to hold a drinking assembly. Such is the way of stealth and vigilance, soaring in excess yet following the heart’s desire: meeting it, one sees not its head; following it, one sees not its tail. Left or right, all is fitting.

Though the fermented brew had sown the seeds of chaos far and wide, it could still be silently shifted and subtly redirected. The two instances of "art of invisibility" in this passage precisely capture the unfathomable marvel of vanishing without a trace. When the Jade Emperor was informed and dispatched the Four Heavenly Kings with a hundred thousand celestial troops and eighteen layers of heavenly nets and earthly snares, the Great Sage paid them no heed—this is what is meant by "cares and woes cannot burden him, arrows and snares cannot reach him." He flees in name yet does not flee in truth. Who but the Great Sage could abide in such ease and self-possession?

The Great Sage repelled the Nine Luminaries and laughed, saying, "These deeds are indeed real—what do you intend to do now?" For the Four Heavenly Kings and the Nine Luminaries are none other than the *nine in the fourth place* of the hexagram, all yang and unyielding. The Great Sage, embodying *"fellowship with hidden weapons in the wilds,"* dared not rise openly to advance, and thus could oppose the five yang lines without fear—this is the *nine in the third place* of *Fellowship*. When the *nine in the fourth place* clashed with the Great Sage, they fought from dawn till dusk; all the horned demons were captured, save for the Four Vigorous Ones who escaped. The horned demon corresponds to the *top yang of Coupling*—unyielding in the highest position. At that moment, its rigidity had no place to manifest, no position to encounter, and unlike the *nine in the fifth place* of *Fellowship*, which *"contains brilliance and guards it,"* it was seized. Yet the *nine in the fourth place* could not claim full victory, for it bore the image of *"mounting the wall but failing to attack"* in *Fellowship*. The Four Vigorous Ones and the Great Sage correspond to the *nine in the fifth place* of *Fellowship*. Amidst the five yang lines, the central and correct position finds resonance with the *two in the second place*, and thus they could cover the retreat. *"First wailing, then laughing"*—why first wail? The *two in the second place*, separated by the *three* and *four*, could not aid the *five*, hence the wailing, born of private attachment. Later, meeting the *five* unharmed, they laughed—this too was private sentiment.

The Great Sage said, "Why fret? Just guard tightly, eat your fill, sleep soundly, and nurture your spirit." This is the *top yang of Fellowship*, *"fellowship in the wilds,"* where one’s aspirations remain unfulfilled. For the Great Sage harbored a will that spanned Heaven and Earth, yet the times were adverse, cutting him off from humanity and forcing him into reclusion—how pitiable! Reading the words *"nurture your spirit,"* my tears flow like rivers.

**Chapter Six: Guanyin Attends the Banquet to Inquire of the Cause; The Little Sage Displays Might to Subdue the Great Sage**

Wu Yizi says: This elucidates the principle of the waxing and waning of yin and yang, the alternation of prosperity and decline, the great going and the small coming, shifting with the times. It reveals how the Great Sage’s unfathomable transformations, though compliant in their application, never stray from the primordial Dao of Heaven. The passage brims with boundless meaning, encompassing all without a single superfluous word. I know not how the immortal master, when setting brush to paper, could so effortlessly weave such a tapestry, every thread a truth. It is because his Dao had reached its apex, his mind like the vast emptiness, where the transformations of Heaven and humanity are mirrored in his writing. The shallow grasp its shallows, the profound its depths—all depends on the learner’s own attainment. Yet how lamentable that the world has never truly understood!

Guanyin Bodhisattva appears throughout the text, and this passage serves as its guiding thread, revealing the marvel of divine insight. To *observe*—how profound its meaning! To observe is to manifest correctness to others, guiding them toward purity without self-assertion. As the *Book of Changes* says: *"Great observation is above; compliant and yielding, it is central. Correctness is observed throughout the world."* And again: *"Observe the Dao of Heaven, and the four seasons do not err. The sage establishes teaching through the divine Dao, and the world submits."* Below, there is the wish to observe oneself and the people; above, there is no ruler who establishes teaching through the divine Dao. Above, there is the virtue of observing oneself and the people; below, there is the crudeness of childish observation and admonition—this is not divine observation. Divine observation employs yin without revealing it to others, and thus it stands above compliance, worthy of the name *Great Observation*. Why? The Dao of observation is the Dao of Heaven. To observe Heaven’s divine Dao is to silently and subtly operate, teaching through the manifest to reveal the divine—not revealing the divine through teaching. This is the unmanifest power of the divine.

Thus, Guanyin Bodhisattva arrives at the moment when yang wanes and yin waxes, establishing teaching through the divine Dao so that the world submits. Guanyin Bodhisattva is *Great Observation*; attending the banquet is *temporal observation*; inquiring of the cause is *divine observation*. Seeing the banquet in disarray, though celestial immortals were present, none took their seats—this was the gathering of yang’s waning and yin’s waxing. Commanding Hui’an to scout the military situation was the pivotal moment of divine observation. Here, the immortal master first sets forth the image of the *Ding* hexagram, laying the groundwork for the Great Sage’s eventual submission.

The *Ding* cauldron has fire above and wood below, used for cooking and offering to the Supreme Emperor and the sages. The Peach Banquet was such an offering. Yet the Great Sage, though a sage, was not present—this was a failure to partake in the offering, leading to chaos. Was this not a loss of the proper balance and transformation in cooking? This Peach Banquet was a gathering of yin’s ascendancy and yang’s decline. Who but the divine observer, Guanyin Bodhisattva, could discern the cause of this ebb and flow? The trend was inevitable: yin would advance further, and yang would wane further. It was a gathering of *Adversity*, where yang would soon be stripped away. The times compelled it, yet not entirely—ah! The immortal master’s subtle admonition to the world is profound indeed!

For the *Ding* cauldron embodies the secret essence of the Golden Elixir, and thus the immortal master dared not speak of it plainly, instead setting forth this symbol to await the discernment of later generations. He specifically invoked Guanyin’s joined palms in a single offering to reveal the marvelous function of divine observation—knowing that yin was growing while yang was waning, just as petty men advance while noble men retreat, as at the mouth of the Guan River in Guanzhou.

The *Book of Songs* says: *“The old man pours and pours,”* and the following line reads: *“The young lad prances and prances.”* The “young lad” is yin, and he dwells at the mouth of the Guan River. The Manifestly Sage Erlang, True Lord, is the second line of *Kun*’s hexagram. *Kun*’s yin, moving in accord with Heaven, follows a path of radiant display, its power compliant and unfailingly advantageous. At this moment, for the Great Sage, what came before was *Gou* and *Dun*; what followed would be *Pi* and *Bo*.

The six brothers are the six yin lines; the twelve hundred grass-headed spirits are the two sixes that make twelve. The first and second lines show petty men joining ranks to advance, like *“pulling the creeping grass, each after its kind.”* The grass-soldiers form a *Cui* hexagram, an image of thronging and surging abundance. That they *“heed commands but not proclamations”* reveals their insubordinate nature. The divine troops, leading hawks and hounds, appear as nothing but hawks and hounds. The True Lord laughed and said, *“This little sage has come,”* clearly declaring his smallness.

Yet one must contend with him in transformations—how subtle is the meaning of *transformation*! The *Book of Changes* says: *“In *Bo*, the yielding transforms into the firm.”* If yin strips away yang, why speak of *transformation*? Generally, when noble men expel petty men, they denounce their crimes before the royal court and cast them out without hesitation. Thus in the *Guai* hexagram, five yang lines expel one yin, and it is called *Guai*. When petty men expel noble men, their reasoning is unjust and their words unrighteous. They cause yang to dwindle day by day without realizing it is changing, revealing the cunning of their schemes. The subsequent *“one transformation, two transformations, three transformations, four transformations”* are all part of their art.

The Little Sage then said: *“Gentlemen, with your heavenly nets and earthly snares, do not cover the space above.”* Generally, when petty men harm noble men, they first allow them freedom to roam, then secretly exploit their vulnerabilities, leaving no trace. Such is the venom of their plots. The passage where the six brothers are ordered to restrain the hawks and hounds, with their laughter and gestures, vividly portrays the demeanor of petty men. The Great Sage, seeing this, asked with a grin about their origins. Once their roots were revealed, he knew their yin-like adaptability and mutability.

Erlang shook himself and transformed, towering ten thousand *zhang* tall, brandishing the Three-Pointed, Two-Edged Divine Blade in both hands. The second transformation completes the *Kun* hexagram. *Kun*’s yin moves in accord with Heaven, its power and flame filling the sky—this is the natural course of events. Why raise the Three-Pointed, Two-Edged Divine Blade? The word *“point”* clearly signifies a petty man, while the *“two edges”* resemble two lips. It shows a heart without mercy but wielding a weapon of slaughter. With green face and fanged teeth, crimson hair—is this not a ravenous demon? Though the Great Sage’s upright *qi* fills Heaven and Earth, capable of resistance, how could he contend with the grass-headed hawks and hounds rising in pursuit, startling his wings into retreat!

The Great Sage, sensing the great calamity had begun, concealed his golden-hooped staff in his ear and transformed into a sparrow, alighting and perching on a treetop. This mirrors the first line of *Ming Yi*: *“In *Ming Yi*, it flies, its wings drooping.”*

For it coiled its brilliance, feigning no lofty flight; it concealed its tracks, lest its flight be seen. The six brothers raised a clamor together—how fearful it is when petty men, having gained power, bark in unison! Erlang’s phoenix eyes widened into circles—why such widening? For in ordinary times, he feigned restraint, but in haste, his ferocity was fully exposed. Transforming into a starving hawk, he spread his wings to strike—was this not reliance on the sharpness of talons and beak? The Great Sage became a great *ci* vulture, soaring into the sky, which is the line of *Ming Yi*’s six in the fourth place: *“Entering the left belly, one obtains the heart of *Ming Yi* upon exiting the gate.”* For when concealment among the near is no longer possible, one may yet enter the hidden recesses of the left belly. By upholding the virtue of humility and compliance, one attains the heart of *Ming Yi*, exiting the gate to flee far away. The *ci* vulture demonstrates humility and righteousness. Erlang swiftly transformed into a great crane, darting into the clouds to peck—still employing his beak.

The Great Sage plunged into the stream and became a fish, reaching the utmost in concealment. Erlang transformed into an osprey, resembling yet not resembling a green kite—this was a disguise; resembling yet not resembling a heron—this was a private bribe; resembling yet not resembling an old stork—this was feigning age. The Great Sage flicked his tail and fled, resembling yet not resembling a carp—this was following principle; resembling yet not resembling a mandarin fish—this was noble integrity; resembling yet not resembling a black fish—this was true purity; resembling yet not resembling a bream—this was inner rectitude. Erlang lunged forward to peck once more—still using his beak. The Great Sage became a water snake, slithering into the grass, neither viper nor serpent—concealed in the wild thickets. Erlang transformed into a gray crane, stretching forth a long beak like a pair of sharp-tipped iron pincers. Alas!

chunks.original_text: 二郎始终用喙而最后最可畏。 仙师描写至此，不觉令人通身汗下。 大圣又变作花鸨，能群居，自有行列，乃群而不党之物。 二郎鹰鸦之侣宜可用群而免患，乃反恶其与鸾凤相交为耻，即挟弹击打，见邪正之不两立也。 然何以不变而用弹？ 大凡小人恶君子，每不自发难端，嗾人弹击以害之。 不变之中而有甚变也。 大圣趋机滚下山崖，又变一座土地庙。 此一变之妙，微言奥义，非世人所识。 或批为文字之化境，或批为猴头庙以谑之，经数百年无能一窥。 盖大圣变庙之妙，宜乎识者之寡俦也。 大圣何以不可变而必变显然不可掩之庙，又何处不可遁而必变二郎而反入必不可入之二郎庙？ 其义已明白显着。 欲知其义者，须读剥之上九“硕果不食，君子载与，小人剥庐”也。 是时也，大圣登天无路，入地无门，蒙难坚贞，诸阳消尽，独上仅存。 君子在上为众阴之庇，如庐舍然。 倘剥极而食其果，是自失其所庇也。 究极于终，剥阳即所以自剥。 故大圣变为庙如庐舍以止之，复变为二郎以同之，复入二郎之庙以示大圣之庙即二郎之庙，二郎之庙即大圣之庙以晓之。 故曰：“郎君不要嚷，庙宇已姓孙了。 ”言剥孙之庐即剥杨之庐，杨庐即孙庐也。 所以硕大之果，戒小人之不食，宜顺时而止也。 至尾巴不好收拾，竖在后面变为旗杆，其中又有妙义。 君子避难遁世，贵先不贵后。 如众皆先而我独后，是失时而贾祸。 故无首而潜，遁之至也。 遁而在尾，有形迹可窥矣。 故遁之初六曰：“遁尾，厉。 ”大圣当姤而遁，天道之潜也，犹难掩于尾遁之危，识乎尾遁者乎！ 仙师特借其尾以发明尾遁之危如此。 然遁不可尾而剥尤不可及尾。 今二郎之剥极于上，亦已及于尾，戒宜速止而返也。 至大圣口似庙门，宜享而不宜逐也； 齿做门扇，齿尊而不可毁也； 舌做菩萨，从慈而标现也； 眼变窗棂，韬晦而糊明也。 二郎乃欲先捣窗棂，后蹋门扇，妒其明而钳其口也。 大圣方当虎变之时，众人反举照妖之镜，谦躬下士，吐哺流言，今古同辙，无足异也。 其点查李虎张龙等一段，曲肖苞苴食黩态状，仙师立言之妙如此。 但至要之旨惟在大圣之观而往，小圣之剥而来。 来者所成往，小者所成大，观者所以成剥也。 是故圣人仰以观于天文，俯以察于地理。 原始反终，故知死生之说，神以知来，知以藏往，所以明变化而行鬼神也。 古之善御小人，必顺方张之势，静处事外，徐止其进。 故《易》曰：“顺而止之，观象也。 ”剥时顺止以观天之消息盈虚，阴盈阳虚之时，君子顺乎天行而止也。 不敢刚正者，顺所以止，而止所以行。 剥不往，与复利往，无二道也。 硕果不食，止也。 何以不食？ 果者，阳也。 阳非阴所能剥而进，故剥极则复，小人自失其所庇，亦顺时而止。 此观音之举二郎者，正观天之行而顺其方张之势以徐观其止，非助阴以消阳也。 不用净瓶打大圣，而令老君用金刚琢者，正静处事外，顺天之行而止其剥，乃止阴以救阳也。 然剥也止也，皆天之行也。 顺其剥而止之，皆观天之行也。 观实大圣之自观，特借观音以阐其理； 止实大圣自止，特借老君以发其义； 剥实大圣自剥，特假二郎以顺其行； 剥实非大圣之自剥，特假大圣以明天道之剥。
chunks.translated_text:
Erlang ever wielded his beak—yet it was in the end most fearsome. The Immortal Master’s brush, arriving here, unwittingly sets one’s whole body dripping with sweat.

The Great Sage next transformed into a bustard, a creature that thrives in flocks, keeps its ranks, and lives in company without cliques. Erlang, companion to hawks and crows, ought to have welcomed the flock and averted danger—yet he loathed the bustard’s association with phoenixes as a disgrace, and at once nocked his pellet-bow to strike, revealing how the upright and the crooked cannot coexist. But why did he not transform, instead resorting to the bow? In general, when petty men despise gentlemen, they seldom provoke trouble themselves but incite others to strike with pellets and bring harm. In seeming non-transformation lies the most extreme transformation.

The Great Sage seized the moment, rolled down the cliff, and transformed into a village shrine. This transformation’s subtlety, its hidden meaning, eludes the world’s understanding. Some critics praise it as the alchemy of prose; others mock it as a “monkey-headed shrine,” and for centuries none have glimpsed its depths. Truly, the Great Sage’s shrine-transformation is such that few can fathom its rarity.

Why did the Great Sage not transform into something else but chose instead a shrine so manifestly impossible to conceal? And why, of all places to flee, did he transform into Erlang and enter the very shrine he could not enter? The meaning is already plain and evident. To grasp it, one must read the *Hexagram Bo*’s top line: *“The great fruit is not eaten; the gentleman carries it away, while the petty man strips the hut.”*

At that moment, the Great Sage had no path to heaven, no gate to earth; steadfast in tribulation, all yang had dissolved, only the topmost line remained. The gentleman above shelters the host of yin, like a hut. Should the stripping reach its limit and consume the fruit, he would lose his own shelter. In the end, stripping yang is self-stripping. Thus the Great Sage transformed into a hut-like shrine to halt the stripping, then transformed into Erlang to merge with him, then entered Erlang’s shrine to show that the Great Sage’s shrine was Erlang’s shrine, and Erlang’s shrine was the Great Sage’s shrine—thereby making it clear. Hence the words: *“Sir, do not clamor—the shrine now bears the surname Sun.”* To strip Sun’s hut is to strip Yang’s hut; Yang’s hut is Sun’s hut. Thus the great fruit warns petty men not to consume it, and one should follow the times and halt.

Yet the tail was difficult to conceal, standing erect behind as a flagpole—another layer of subtlety. When gentlemen evade peril and withdraw from the world, it is better to act first than last. If all others go first and I alone lag behind, I miss the moment and court disaster. Thus to vanish without a trace is the ultimate withdrawal. To withdraw with the tail exposed leaves traces for prying eyes. Hence the *Hexagram Dun*’s first line: *“Withdrawal with the tail—danger.”* The Great Sage, at the *Hexagram Gou*, withdrew in accordance with heaven’s Dao of concealment, yet even so could not escape the peril of tail-withdrawal. Who recognizes the danger of tail-withdrawal?

The Immortal Master specifically uses the tail to illustrate the peril of tail-withdrawal. Yet withdrawal must not expose the tail, and stripping must not reach the tail. Now Erlang’s stripping has reached its peak above, even touching the tail—he should be warned to halt swiftly and turn back.

The Great Sage’s mouth became the shrine’s gate, fit for offerings but not for pursuit; his teeth became the door leaves, venerable and indestructible; his tongue became the bodhisattva, manifesting from compassion; his eyes became the window lattice, veiling brilliance with obscurity. Erlang sought first to smash the lattice, then to kick in the door leaves—envying its clarity and clamping its mouth shut.

The Great Sage was then in his tiger-transformation, yet the crowd instead raised the demon-revealing mirror, bowing humbly and spitting out slanderous words—an age-old pattern, nothing strange. The episode where he summons Li Hu and Zhang Long vividly portrays the postures of bribery and gluttony; such is the Immortal Master’s artistry in exposition.

Yet the crux lies solely in the Great Sage’s *observing and advancing*, and the Little Sage’s *stripping and coming*. What comes constitutes what goes; what is small constitutes what is great; observation is what constitutes stripping. Thus the sage looks up to observe the patterns of heaven, looks down to examine the principles of earth. Tracing origins and returning to endings, he knows the discourse of life and death. With spirit he knows the future; with knowledge he stores the past—thus he illuminates transformations and practices the workings of ghosts and spirits.

Those of old who skillfully managed petty men always followed the momentum of their expansion, remained still outside affairs, and gradually halted their advance. Thus the *Book of Changes* says: *“Follow and halt them—this is observing the image.”* In the time of stripping, follow and halt to observe heaven’s waxing and waning, the fullness of yin and the emptiness of yang. The gentleman follows heaven’s course and halts. He does not dare to be rigidly upright: following is how he halts, and halting is how he acts. Stripping does not advance; in *Fu*, advancing is favorable—there is no second way. The great fruit is not eaten—this is halting. Why is it not eaten? The fruit is yang. Yang cannot be stripped and advanced by yin; thus when stripping reaches its limit, it turns to *Fu*. Petty men lose their shelter and also follow the times to halt.

This is why Guanyin deploys Erlang: precisely to observe heaven’s course and follow its expanding momentum to gradually observe its halting—not to aid yin in dissolving yang. She does not use the pure vase to strike the Great Sage but has Laozi use the diamond chisel: precisely to remain still outside affairs, follow heaven’s course, and halt the stripping—to halt yin and rescue yang.

Yet stripping and halting are both heaven’s course. Following its stripping and halting it are both observing heaven’s course. In truth, the Great Sage’s observation is his own observation, merely borrowing Guanyin to expound the principle; his halting is his own halting, merely borrowing Laozi to reveal the meaning; his stripping is his own stripping, merely borrowing Erlang to follow its course. In truth, the stripping is not the Great Sage’s own stripping—he merely borrows the Great Sage to clarify heaven’s Dao of stripping.

chunks.original_text: 责人人自剥以儆其危。 知其剥而顺止，知其顺止而必复，知其必复而道明矣。 观音合掌道：“贫僧请陛下同道祖出南天门亲去看看虚实。 ”即观天道阴阳之虚实也。 二圣把大圣围困，只是未得擒拿，“硕果不食”也。 净瓶不用者，致其洁清而身不与，神观也。 菩萨问老君“有甚么兵器？ ”老君道：“有，有，有。 ”左膊上取下一圈，一名金刚琢，又名金刚套。 即前文鼎之六五、上九“金铉”、“玉铉”是也。 妙在“有有有”三字。 盖鼎之五虚中为黄，在君为实。 五无实，以二之鼎有实为实，故观音以其无问，老君以其有答也。 凡物之行在足，独鼎之行在耳。 六五虚中德也，为黄耳铉。 加耳者，应二坚刚。 如贯以金铉，当始终如一。 而贞固则利，故实而虚，虚而圆为圈。 上九玉铉，而左上为阳居阴，刚以柔，节之如玉，温润而栗然。 故左膊上取金刚琢，金并玉也。 何以能套诸物而又名套？ 五虚中，虚故能容。 上者老也，五者君也，故为老君。 惟老君之虚中而实，故能伏正而止变。 二郎不能食大圣之果，大圣则能食老君之中，打中天灵跌了一跤，老君之顺而止之，即大圣之顺而止之也。 细犬一口又扯了一跌，二郎神之顺而止之也，即大圣之顺而止之也。 犬者戌也。 九月之卦内坤而外艮，顺时止也。 不顺时而行，行即止也； 顺时而止，止亦行也。 大圣之被困而止，正大圣之自止而行也。 七圣者，自复而反之七阴也。 穿了琵琶骨，再也不能变化者，剥卦是也。 止住上爻而硕果不食，留果中之阳以转复开泰，止乎其所不得不止也。 止住而不变，大圣先天之妙用，而非二郎之能穿而住止之也。 学道者能观其微妙，而能于无画无文处安身立命，是即观音之神妙，阴用而不与人者也。 观之时，义大矣哉！ 仙师以大圣小圣发明金丹之道，予以儒者之道发明小圣大圣而未尽其妙者。 不得不结言之：小圣者，承天而行坤阴也。 以先天之道观之，在后天为男子也； 大圣者，逆天而行乾阳也。 以先天之道观之，在后天为女子也。 以顺天为反天宫，以讨逆为阴柔。 老君为调和之主而反助阴制阳，金丹以逆用也。 如此，予亦何能言其妙？ 亦观之而已矣。
chunks.translated_text:
To reproach others is to have each strip themselves as warning of their peril. Knowing the stripping and following its halt, knowing the following of its halt and its necessary return, knowing its necessary return—thus the Dao is made clear.

Guanyin pressed her palms together and said, “This humble monk requests that Your Majesty accompany the Dao Ancestor to the Southern Gate of Heaven to see for yourselves the truth of the matter.” This is precisely to observe the truth of heaven’s Dao in yin and yang. The Two Sages encircled the Great Sage but had yet to capture him—“the great fruit remains uneaten.” The pure vase was not used, preserving its immaculate clarity so that the body does not engage, a divine observation.

The Bodhisattva asked Laozi, “What weapons do you have?” Laozi replied, “I have, I have, I have.” From his left arm he took down a ring, called the *Diamond Chisel*, also named the *Diamond Noose*. This is the “golden hook” and “jade hook” of the *Ding* hexagram’s sixth line, fifth and top lines. The subtlety lies in the threefold “I have, I have, I have.” For the *Ding*’s fifth line, the hollow center is yellow, representing the ruler as solid. The fifth is empty, taking the second line’s solidity as its own solidity—thus Guanyin asks from her emptiness, and Laozi answers from his fullness.

All things move by their feet, but the *Ding* alone moves by its ears. The sixth line’s hollow center is virtue, forming the yellow ear-hook. Adding ears responds to the second line’s firm hardness. Like threading with a golden hook, it must remain consistent from beginning to end. In steadfastness, it is beneficial—thus solid yet hollow, hollow yet round, forming a ring. The top line’s jade hook, with yang on the left residing in yin, hard yet yielding, is tempered like jade, warm yet solemn. Thus, from the left arm comes the *Diamond Chisel*, gold conjoined with jade.

Why can it noose all things and be called a noose? The fifth line is hollow at its center, and emptiness can contain. The top is the elder, the fifth the ruler—thus it is Laozi. Only Laozi’s emptiness within and solidity without can subdue the upright and halt change. Erlang could not consume the Great Sage’s fruit, but the Great Sage could consume Laozi’s center, striking his heavenly crown and stumbling. Laozi’s following and halting is the Great Sage’s own following and halting. The hound’s bite sent him sprawling again—Erlang’s following and halting is the Great Sage’s own following and halting. The hound is *xu* (the dog), the eleventh earthly branch. The hexagram of the ninth month has *kun* within and *gen* without, following the season to halt. To act against the season is to halt in motion; to follow the season in halting is to move in stillness. The Great Sage’s entrapment and halt is precisely his own halting and movement.

The Seven Sages are the seven yin lines returning from *fu*. Piercing the *pipa* bones so he could no longer transform—this is the *Bo* hexagram. Halting the top line so the great fruit remains uneaten preserves the yang within the fruit to turn and restore *Kai Tai*. It halts where it cannot but halt. The halting without change is the Great Sage’s wondrous use of the primordial, not Erlang’s ability to pierce and restrain him.

Those who study the Dao and can observe its subtleties, who can establish themselves in the formless and wordless, embody Guanyin’s divine marvel—acting in yin without revealing it to others. In observation, the meaning is vast indeed!

The Immortal Master used the Great Sage and Lesser Sage to elucidate the Dao of the Golden Elixir, while I, with the Confucian Dao, elucidate the Lesser Sage and Great Sage, though I have not exhausted its wonders. I cannot but conclude: the Lesser Sage follows heaven and embodies *kun* yin. Viewed through the primordial Dao, in the later heaven it is the male. The Great Sage defies heaven and embodies *qian* yang. Viewed through the primordial Dao, in the later heaven it is the female. To follow heaven is to rebel against the Heavenly Palace; to punish rebellion is to embrace yin softness. Laozi, as the master of harmony, instead aids yin in restraining yang—the Golden Elixir operates in reversal. Thus, how can I speak of its wonders? I merely observe.

chunks.original_text: 第七回　八卦炉中逃大圣　五行山下定心猿 悟一子曰：此结上文先天真乙之气自无而有，自有而无，自无而复，有复而泰，泰而乾，乾而姤，姤而否，否而坤，坤而复，终终始始，万劫长存。 先天炼于后天之中，后天秘有先天之妙。 仙师所由以后天之八卦五行揭示世人，欲人观察晓悟，修此一气以脱生死也。 一之祖曰无，无生一，一至十。 阴阳流行之序一二三四五，正数也。 六七八九十乃其配耳。 数止于五，究竟五只在一二三四中，三四只在二中，二又只在一中。 得其一而百，行万善不离一中。 百千万亿不离一五。 以五行流行之数言，则天一、地二，天三、地四，天五、地六，天七、地八，天九、地十； 以阴阳对待之数言，则乾一、兑二、离三、震四、巽五、坎六、艮七、坤八，总不离乎太极。 因而重之则变为六十四卦； 因而事之则为三百八十四爻； 积而终于万有。 一千五百二十之数总不外乎八卦； 八卦不外乎五行； 五行不外乎阴阳； 阴阳不外乎太极； 太极不外乎无。 然则八卦五行总属一也，仙师并言之，各有深意。 所言八卦者，欲修道者在八卦对待之中观察其根源，即予首篇请示一图以证道之意。 仙师早已明着于此。 请先明炉中逃大圣之旨。 修丹者有鼎有炉，上为鼎，下为炉。 鼎之义，仙师上篇隐示之，提一观字以令人察识，非有鬼神之曲折，未可以测其妙。 此炉之义亦非有鬼神之曲折未可以测其妙。 盖后天之八卦伏有先天之气。 大士神观得其火候。 老君既执鼎之中黄以击大圣先天之灵而收伏之，仗二郎细犬之真土而不动，已如鹰之搏兔矣。 非加火功煅炼，仍未得而收伏也。 又非一切凡火及火雷二部之火所得勉强制服，必藉八卦炉中之真火方可煅炼成丹。 紫阳真人曰：“自有天然真火候，何须柴炭及吹嘘”是也。 故篇首火雷部诸神俱不能损伤，须老君领去，推入八卦炉中，以文武火煅炼出丹来也。 大圣入炉钻在巽宫位下。 巽为长女，柔道也。 乃明入地中，文王囚于羑里之象。 惟柔顺逊克以演先天八卦，而终无伤损也。 风搅烟来，双眼煼红，乃明而见伤，韬明养晦，正所以善用其明而无伤也。 故曰：“后来唤作火眼金睛”。 适火候俱全，忽一日开炉取丹，只听得炉头声响，看见光明，忽喇一声，蹬倒八卦炉，往外就走，好似白额虎、独角龙，此龙虎二象合而为一矣。 老君摔了个倒栽葱，脱身而走。 噫！

**Chapter Seven: The Great Sage Escapes the Eight-Trigrams Furnace; The Mind-Ape is Tamed Beneath the Five Elements Mountain**

Wu Yizi said: This concludes the preceding discussion of the primordial True Unity’s *qi*, which arises from Nonbeing into Being, from Being returns to Nonbeing, from Nonbeing once more emerges, and from this re-emergence attains Supreme Harmony. Supreme Harmony gives rise to *Qian*, *Qian* to *Gou*, *Gou* to *Pi*, *Pi* to *Kun*, and *Kun* to *Fu*—endlessly cycling, beginning anew, enduring through ten thousand kalpas.

The primordial is refined within the later heaven; the later heaven conceals the marvels of the primordial. The Immortal Master revealed these truths to the world through the later heaven’s Eight Trigrams and Five Phases, that people might observe, awaken, and cultivate this singular *qi* to transcend birth and death.

The Ancestor of Unity is Nonbeing; Nonbeing generates the One, and the One extends to Ten. The sequence of yin-yang circulation—One, Two, Three, Four, Five—is the true reckoning. Six, Seven, Eight, Nine, Ten are but their complements. The reckoning culminates at Five, yet Five resides within One, Two, Three, Four; Three and Four reside within Two; and Two resides within One. Grasp the One, and the hundred follow; perform ten thousand virtues, yet never depart from the One. The hundred, thousand, myriad, and billion never stray from One or Five.

Speaking of the numerical flow of the Five Phases: Heaven-One, Earth-Two; Heaven-Three, Earth-Four; Heaven-Five, Earth-Six; Heaven-Seven, Earth-Eight; Heaven-Nine, Earth-Ten. Speaking of the paired reckoning of yin and yang: *Qian*-One, *Dui*-Two, *Li*-Three, *Zhen*-Four, *Xun*-Five, *Kan*-Six, *Gen*-Seven, *Kun*-Eight—none depart from the Supreme Ultimate. Thus, doubling them yields the sixty-four hexagrams; applying them to affairs yields the three hundred eighty-four lines; accumulating them, all things arise. The number one thousand five hundred twenty remains bound to the Eight Trigrams; the Eight Trigrams to the Five Phases; the Five Phases to yin and yang; yin and yang to the Supreme Ultimate; and the Supreme Ultimate to Nonbeing. Thus, the Eight Trigrams and Five Phases are ultimately One. The Immortal Master speaks of both, each bearing profound meaning.

When he speaks of the Eight Trigrams, it is that cultivators may observe their roots within the paired trigrams—just as I, in the opening chapter, presented a diagram to verify the Dao. The Immortal Master long ago made this clear. Let us first clarify the purport of the Great Sage’s escape from the furnace.

In the elixir practice, there is the tripod and the furnace: the upper is the tripod, the lower the furnace. The meaning of the tripod was subtly indicated by the Immortal Master in the preceding chapter, lifting the word “observe” to prompt discernment—not through convoluted spirits and gods, nor can its marvels be fathomed. The meaning of the furnace likewise cannot be fathomed through such convolutions. For within the later heaven’s Eight Trigrams lies the primordial *qi*. The Great Sage, with divine insight, grasped its firing times.

Lord Lao, wielding the Central Yellow of the tripod, struck the Great Sage’s primordial spirit to subdue him, relying on Erlang’s true earth and the hound’s steadfastness—like an eagle seizing a hare. Yet without the refining fire’s work, he could not be fully subdued. Nor could ordinary fire or the fire and thunder deities’ flames forcibly tame him; only the true fire of the Eight-Trigrams Furnace could refine him into elixir. As the Perfected One of Purple Yang said: *“There is a natural true firing time—what need for kindling or bellows?”* Thus, the deities of the fire and thunder departments could not harm him; only Lord Lao could lead him away, cast him into the Eight-Trigrams Furnace, and refine the elixir with civil and martial fire.

The Great Sage, entering the furnace, burrowed beneath the *Xun* palace. *Xun* is the eldest daughter, the way of softness—manifesting the image of King Wen imprisoned in Youli. Only through yielding compliance could he unfold the primordial Eight Trigrams, ultimately unharmed. Wind stirred the smoke, scorching his eyes red—yet this revealed injury, while concealing brilliance nurtured obscurity, rightly employing clarity without harm. Hence it is said: *“Later called ‘fiery eyes and golden pupils.’”*

When the firing time was complete, the furnace was opened to retrieve the elixir. Suddenly, a sound arose from the furnace’s head, light blazed forth, and with a crash, the Eight-Trigrams Furnace was overturned. The Great Sage bolted outward like a white-browed tiger or a one-horned dragon—these two images of dragon and tiger now united as one. Lord Lao tumbled headfirst, barely escaping. Alas!

chunks.original_text: 妙哉，神哉！ 前老君执鼎耳打中天灵而大圣一跌； 此老君倒栽葱而大圣脱身。 前是金丹之顺于鼎而结胎； 此是金丹之逆出于炉而脱胎也。 仙师：“混元体正合先天”一诗，正形容丹成之妙，字字牟尼珠。 最须察识处在“号初玄”，“非铅汞”，“还变化”等字。 盖玄中之妙，难以言尽。 此谓号初玄，尚有在此； 非铅汞，尚须铅汞。 此为能变化，还有变化。 老子曰：“玄之又玄，众妙之门”。 玄之已曲折不可测识，又玄则更曲折而不可测识。 故仙师于此特着大闹天宫一句。 又诗曰，一诗两个又字，正又玄又字之精髓也。 何以又大乱天宫？ 盖先天真乙之精入于八卦之中，则后天而奉天时； 出于八卦之外，则先天而天弗违。 自与天争席而非天所御也。 前大圣闹天宫而入于炉中煅炼，是先动而后静，前半下手之功也。 所谓玄之也； 此大圣又闹天宫而入于山下压定，是静极而动，动而又静也，后半下手之功也。 所谓又玄也。 然前大闹则有老君之鼎可伏，此大闹则惟如来之掌可伏。 彼以对待之八卦，此以攒簇之五行，制伏虽殊而妙用则一也。 最妙在又诗曰四句，读者必解曰猿猴配心，心即猿猴，紧缚牢拴莫得外寻。 故批《西游》者将心猿意马四字罩住全书，不知猿猴乃道体耳。 猿性缓，主静； 猴性躁，主动。 喻道体之有动静，与人心之有动静相配，非谓猿猴即人心也。 仙师提纲谓心猿，言心即猿猴者，意思有甚深而贵乎人之察识也。 心即猿猴，明白浅显，何以着“意思深”三字？ 盖道体有静有动，修道者亦有静有动。 动极则必静，静极则又动，动极则必静。 金丹始终作用已尽在其中，即“玄之又玄，众妙之门”也。 故曰“意思深”。 第三句何以合动于静而未言猿心合于意，而专言心？ 盖金丹作用，当静极又动之际，必须收伏猴之动而平定猿之静方成大道。 故马猿未合，心意未合，不可紧缚牢拴，而须外导者，适马猿合作，心和意和而紧缚牢拴莫外寻矣。 大圣变三头六臂，在核心里飞舞。 亘古常存，神将难捉等语，正形容道体变化之妙。 解者又说关心，大误矣。 然道非常道，能修炼降伏者即是如来。 切须根究来历，方好下手。 大圣自道灵混根源乃先天之精，非凡间之物，只此敢来争先。 一语道明天固先天，我亦先天。 故敢与争先而无多让也。 迨诱大圣入手，正金丹入手之候。 而五根肉柱，一股青气，正合心意攒簇五行之时。 中间柱子写“齐天大圣到此一游”，即佛祖所云：“乾坤之内，宇宙之间，有一宝秘在形山，不在心肾，而在乎玄关一窍”者是也。 故离不得如来掌中而未超于五行之外也。 佛祖翻掌一扑，推出西天门外，化五行山压住，明示金丹之道，必五行攒簇而从虚空中结就。 人心得此配合而有所依据，不落空亡，如《大学》“知止而后有定，定而后能静，静而后能安，可以不事作为，渐摩超脱矣。 ” 篇中殄灭妖猴安天大会，正定静安之的旨。 《悟真》曰：“咽津纳气是人行，有物方能造化生。 鼎内若无真种子，如将水火煮空铛。 ”大圣者，真种子也。 盖有为者，无为之用； 无为者，有为之本。 必先有为而后归于无为，方了无上至真之妙道。 若先无所为而从事静定，则命基不固，终落空亡。

Marvelous, wondrous indeed! Earlier, Lord Lao struck the Great Sage’s Heavenly Crown with the crucible’s handle, causing him to stumble; now, Lord Lao tumbled headfirst while the Great Sage broke free. The former was the Golden Elixir’s compliance within the crucible to form the embryo; this is the Golden Elixir’s reversal from the furnace to cast off the embryo. The immortal master’s verse, *“The Primordial Body perfectly accords with the Prior Heaven,”* precisely depicts the marvel of elixir completion—each word a pearl of wisdom. The most crucial points of discernment lie in the phrases *“styled the First Mystery,”* *“not lead and mercury,”* and *“returning to transformation.”* For the mystery within the Mystery defies exhaustive speech. This is called *“styled the First Mystery,”* yet there remains something beyond; *“not lead and mercury,”* yet lead and mercury are still required. This is said to *“return to transformation,”* yet further transformation remains.

Laozi said: *“Mystery upon mystery—the gateway to all wonders.”* The first Mystery is already so intricate as to elude comprehension, and the second Mystery is even more so. Thus, the immortal master particularly emphasizes the phrase *“greatly disturbing the Heavenly Palace.”* Another verse contains two *“again”*s, precisely capturing the essence of *“Mystery upon Mystery.”* Why, then, did he once more wreak havoc in the Heavenly Palace? When the Prior Heaven’s true *yi*-essence enters the Eight Trigrams, it follows the timing of the Posterior Heaven; when it emerges beyond the Eight Trigrams, it precedes Heaven, and Heaven cannot oppose it. It contends with Heaven for its seat, unbound by Heaven’s dominion.

Earlier, the Great Sage’s disturbance of the Heavenly Palace led to his tempering within the furnace—first movement, then stillness, the initial phase of the work. This is the first Mystery. Now, the Great Sage’s renewed disturbance of the Heavenly Palace, followed by his confinement beneath the mountain, is stillness at its extreme giving rise to movement, and movement returning to stillness—the latter phase of the work. This is the Mystery upon Mystery. Yet while the first disturbance could be subdued by Lord Lao’s crucible, this one could only be quelled by Tathāgata’s palm. The former relied on the oppositional Eight Trigrams, the latter on the clustered Five Phases; though their methods of restraint differ, their wondrous function is one.

Most marvelous are the four lines of another verse. Readers must understand: the ape is paired with the heart, the heart is the ape—tightly bound and securely tethered, allowing no external pursuit. Thus, commentators on *Journey to the West* encapsulate the entire book with the four characters *“heart-ape, intent-horse,”* unaware that the ape is the Dao-body. The ape’s nature is slow, governing stillness; the monkey’s nature is restless, governing movement. This illustrates the Dao-body’s alternation between movement and stillness, corresponding to the human heart’s alternation between movement and stillness—not that the ape and monkey *are* the human heart. When the immortal master’s outline speaks of the *“heart-ape,”* saying the heart is the ape or monkey, the meaning is profound and demands the reader’s discernment.

If the heart is simply the ape or monkey, the expression is plain and shallow—why then the phrase *“profound meaning”*? For the Dao-body has stillness and movement, and the cultivator likewise has stillness and movement. Movement at its extreme must return to stillness, stillness at its extreme must give rise to movement, and movement at its extreme must return to stillness. The entire process of the Golden Elixir is contained herein—this is *“Mystery upon mystery, the gateway to all wonders.”* Hence, it is called *“profound meaning.”*

Why does the third line speak of uniting movement with stillness without mentioning the ape’s heart uniting with intent, but only the heart? Because in the Golden Elixir’s work, at the moment when stillness at its extreme gives rise to movement, one must subdue the monkey’s movement and pacify the ape’s stillness to accomplish the Great Dao. Thus, before the horse and ape unite, before heart and intent harmonize, one cannot be tightly bound and securely tethered but must be guided externally. Only when horse and ape unite, when heart and intent harmonize, can one be tightly bound and securely tethered, allowing no external pursuit.

The Great Sage’s transformation into three heads and six arms, dancing within the core, enduring through all ages, and eluding the grasp of divine generals—this precisely depicts the marvel of the Dao-body’s transformations. Those who interpret this as concerning the heart err greatly. Yet the Dao is no ordinary Dao; those who cultivate and subdue it become Tathāgatas. One must thoroughly investigate its origins before proceeding.

The Great Sage himself declared his spirit’s primordial root-source as the essence of the Prior Heaven, no mundane thing—this alone emboldened him to contend for precedence. In a single phrase, he revealed that while Heaven is of the Prior Heaven, so too is he. Thus, he dared to contend for precedence without yielding.

When the Great Sage was lured into submission, it was precisely the moment for the Golden Elixir’s inception. The five fleshy pillars and a wisp of azure *qi* corresponded to the time when heart and intent clustered the Five Phases. The inscription *“The Great Sage Equaling Heaven was here”* on the central pillar is what the Buddha referred to as: *“Within the cosmos, between heaven and earth, there lies a precious secret in the mountain of form—not in the heart or kidneys, but in the mysterious pass of the single aperture.”* Thus, he could not escape Tathāgata’s palm and remained within the Five Phases.

When the Buddha flipped his palm and thrust him beyond the Western Heaven’s gate, transforming the Five Phases Mountain to press him down, he clearly demonstrated that the path of the Golden Elixir must cluster the Five Phases to crystallize from emptiness. The human heart, attaining this alignment, gains a foundation and does not fall into oblivion. As *The Great Learning* states: *“Know where to rest, and you will be settled; settled, you will be tranquil; tranquil, you will be at peace; at peace, you may act without striving, gradually refining and transcending.”* The chapter’s subjugation of the demonic monkey and the grand assembly to pacify Heaven precisely embodies the principle of settled tranquility and peace.

*The Awakening to Reality* says:
*“Swallowing saliva and absorbing qi are human practices,
Only with substance can transformation arise.
If the crucible lacks the true seed,
It is like boiling water and fire in an empty cauldron.”*
The Great Sage is the true seed. For activity is the function of non-activity, and non-activity is the root of activity. One must first engage in activity and then return to non-activity to complete the wondrous path of the supreme, utterly real Dao. If one begins with non-activity and pursues stillness and stability, the foundation of life will not be firm, and one will ultimately fall into oblivion.

chunks.original_text: 倘先有所为而未能超脱，则性地不空，尚域三界。 紫阳真君曰：“始于有作人难见，及至无为众始知。 但见无为为要妙，岂知有作是根基。 ”有作者，五行山下之心猿是也。 有作而又无为者，五行山下之定心猿是也。 篇中自猴子成精及末幅屡提猴字，并不及猿字，正发明伏猴之功而后能定猿之静之义。 至于五行山生根合缝，随人呼吸者，乃金丹吞入腹也。 饥与铁丸，渴与铜汁，皆金类也。 猿为水中之金，乃同类相济之义，其温养抱一之功乎？ 然则观如来之翻掌定猿，可悟后天五行之中，有先天真乙之精而无事远求，如翻掌之易伏也。 第八回　我佛造经传极乐　观音奉旨上长安 悟一子曰：前七篇，明金丹大道是修炼先天真一之气而成，其丹法、根源、火候、始终、下手秘诀、包括无遗。 学道者静观密察，得师指示，即可共证菩提，立跻仙位。 仙师恐世人愚昧，或谓仙佛乃系天生，非凡人可学而至。 或谓参悟惟在一心，止自已可求而得。 故下文提出玄奘一人，做个榜样； 提出悟空、悟净、悟能、龙马，做个作用； 见得仙佛人人有分，非天生性成； 彼我共济，非一己孤修也。 但书中设险设怪，作魔作难，至十万八千之远，八十一难之多，一十四年之久，又未免起人骇疑畏阻之心； 以为必不可至之地，必不可脱之厄，必不可成之功。 若然，则是以《西游》阻绝世人也。 仙师立言之意，发明未得真传，而有千魔万难之极苦； 己得真传，而有一永得之极乐也。 故提纲云：“我佛造经传极乐。 ”正欲以至近至易者，救试验从生。 若曰：自有此经，而可免十万八千之遥赊，八十一难之险阻，一十四年之淹久也。 现首篇劈头提出“西游释厄”四字，便晓西游原以释厄，非有作难也。 然则为魔为难，因玄奘未得真传而设，似宜到大雷音见佛祖传经之后而得道，何以至凌云渡，即已脱壳成真？ 不知大士奉旨寻僧，己传与五般宝贝。 令其收伏三徒，准备脚力，玄奘己密受《紧箍》口诀。 真经之传，己在大士上长安之日，固不必到西天而即可得道也。 特借必往西天，以指明大道根源之处； 借十万八千之远，八十一难之苦，一十四年之久，以指明防危虑险，功程火候之至要。 原不远也，远生于担荷之不力，浅迫之便途； 知十万八千之匪遥，而道在目前； 顿悟者，一觔斗而己至矣。 原无难也，难生于尘缘之迷惑，僻漏之参差； 识八十一难之易解，而乐自无极； 大勇者，一金箍棒而己了矣。 原非久也，久生于不识药物之火候，锱两之奥妙； 知一十四年之非久，而经可立致； 善知识者，金禁紧而即已入我彀中矣。 第不能历极苦之假，不知极乐之真； 不历极苦之苦，不知极乐之乐； 不历十万八千、八十一难、一十四年之远险而且久，不知九九之止一九，两藏之止一藏，五千四十八日之止一候也。 此经本于《阴符》、《道德》，造自黄、老，仙师特托我佛以阐其教，唐世以广其为，玄奘以示其标，西游以演其义，取缔以发其旨己耳。 倘谓必如玄奘之西游取经而始可成道，则是上世应鲜古佛真仙，后世断绝佛胎仙种； 为甚繁甚难甚幽远，人人必不可得之道，非至简至易至切近，必可共得之道，则天违我佛传经之婆心矣。

Should one engage in activity yet fail to transcend, the ground of inherent nature remains unemptied, still bound within the Three Realms. The Perfected Lord of Purple Yang states:

*“At first, with effort, few perceive its worth,
Only when effortless do all acknowledge its grace.
Though effortless seems the wondrous key,
Who knows that effort is the root’s embrace?”*

The one who acts is the Mind-Ape beneath Five Phases Mountain. The one who acts yet abides in non-action is the settled Mind-Ape beneath Five Phases Mountain. Throughout the text, from the monkey’s transformation into a spirit to the final passages where “monkey” recurs without mention of “ape,” it precisely reveals the principle that only after taming the monkey can the ape’s stillness be attained. As for Five Phases Mountain taking root and sealing seamlessly, responding to the breath of mortals—this is the Golden Elixir swallowed into the belly. Hunger met with iron pellets, thirst with molten bronze—both are of the metal class. The ape is metal within water, embodying the principle of like aiding like, is this not the work of nurturing unity and embracing the One?

Thus, observing the Tathāgata’s palm-turning subjugation of the ape, one may awaken to the truth that within the postnatal Five Phases lies the prenatal true essence of the One, requiring no distant quest—easily subdued as the turning of a palm.

**Chapter Eight: The Buddha Composes the Sūtra to Transmit Ultimate Bliss; Guanyin Receives the Edict to Journey to Chang’an**

Wu Yizi says: The first seven chapters elucidate the Great Way of the Golden Elixir, which is cultivated through refining the prenatal true qi of the One. Its alchemical method, origins, firing times, beginning and end, secret techniques for commencement—all are encompassed without omission. Those who study the Dao, through silent observation and careful reflection, with a master’s guidance, may together realize bodhi and ascend to immortality.

The Immortal Master feared that the world’s foolish might believe immortals and buddhas are born, not attainable by ordinary beings through cultivation; or that enlightenment lies solely in the mind, attainable by oneself alone. Thus, the following text presents Xuanzang as an exemplar, and Sun Wukong, Zhu Wuneng, Sha Wujing, and the Dragon Horse as agents of transformation—demonstrating that immortality and buddhahood are within everyone’s reach, not innate or fixed; that mutual aid, not solitary practice, is the path.

Yet the text’s trials and monsters, its perils and hardships—spanning one hundred and eight thousand miles, eighty-one ordeals, and fourteen years—may well evoke fear, doubt, and hesitation, leading one to believe such a journey impossible, such tribulations inescapable, such merit unattainable. If so, then *Journey to the West* would become an obstacle, deterring seekers.

The Immortal Master’s intent in writing is to reveal that without true transmission, one faces endless trials and extreme suffering; with true transmission, one attains eternal bliss. Hence the chapter’s theme: *“The Buddha composes the sūtra to transmit ultimate bliss.”* It aims to rescue those undergoing trials with what is most proximate and effortless. For with this sūtra’s existence, one may avoid the remoteness of one hundred and eight thousand miles, the perils of eighty-one ordeals, and the protraction of fourteen years.

The opening chapter’s bold declaration—*“Journey to the West to release from tribulation”*—makes clear that the journey’s purpose is liberation, not the imposition of hardship. Yet the trials and tribulations arise because Xuanzang has not yet received true transmission. One might assume enlightenment comes only after reaching Vulture Peak, meeting the Buddha, and receiving the sūtra. How then does he shed his mortal form and attain realization at Cloud-Soaring Crossing?

It is not known that the Bodhisattva, upon receiving the edict to seek a monk, had already bestowed five treasures, instructed him to subdue his three disciples, and prepared his mount. Xuanzang had secretly received the *Tight-Fillet* incantation. The transmission of the true sūtra had already occurred when the Bodhisattva set forth for Chang’an—there was no need to reach the Western Heaven to attain the Dao.

The text’s insistence on the journey to the West merely points to the source of the Great Way; the one hundred and eight thousand miles, eighty-one ordeals, and fourteen years illustrate the critical importance of vigilance against danger, the stages of progress, and the firing times. The distance is not inherently far—it arises from insufficient effort in bearing the load, from taking the easy path of haste. Recognizing that one hundred and eight thousand miles are not truly distant, one sees the Dao before one’s eyes; the sudden awakening arrives with a single somersault.

The difficulty is not inherent—it arises from delusion by worldly ties, from the unevenness of leaks and gaps. Understanding that eighty-one ordeals are easily resolved, one finds boundless joy; the greatly courageous need only a single strike of the golden cudgel to conclude them.

The duration is not inherently long—it arises from ignorance of the firing times of medicinal substances and the subtleties of weights and measures. Knowing that fourteen years are not truly long, one may swiftly attain the sūtra; the adept, with the golden fillet’s restraint, is already within my grasp.

Without experiencing the extremity of suffering, one cannot know the truth of ultimate bliss; without enduring the bitterness of extreme suffering, one cannot know the joy of ultimate bliss. Without traversing one hundred and eight thousand miles, eighty-one ordeals, and fourteen years of remoteness, peril, and duration, one cannot comprehend that nine nines reduce to one nine, two treasuries to one treasury, five thousand forty-eight days to a single firing time.

This sūtra originates from the *Yinfu Jing* and the *Daode Jing*, composed by the Yellow Emperor and Laozi. The Immortal Master merely entrusted the Buddha with expounding its teachings, the Tang era with disseminating its practice, Xuanzang with exemplifying its standard, and *Journey to the West* with unfolding its meaning—using allegory to reveal its essence.

If one were to insist that only by journeying to the West to fetch the sūtra, as Xuanzang did, can the Dao be attained, then the ancient past would lack buddhas and immortals, and future generations would be cut off from the seeds of buddhahood and immortality. Such a path would be excessively complex, difficult, and abstruse—unattainable by all—rather than the simplest, easiest, and most immediate Way, accessible to all. This would contravene the Buddha’s compassionate intent in transmitting the sūtra.

chunks.original_text: 我佛传经，妙有二义：未得道者，令如玄奘之往西而取经； 己得道者，令如悟之到西而皈佛。 总一传也，总传一极乐也。 其经旨之微妙，在人神明而察识之，故必观音大士之神观为能奉行也。 篇首一诗，言参禅冥悟之众，虚费工夫，如“磨砖作镜”而不可鉴形； “积雪为粮”，而不可充饥，到老无成，迷误年少。 其言“毛吞大海，芥纳须弥”，总属无据之说，而“金色头陀”，未免傍观微笑矣。 人能悟此，则“超十地三乘”； 滞此而不能悟，则入于“四生六道”，而轮回万劫，不可脱也。 谁人能听得“绝想崖前，无阴树下”，恍惚杳冥之中，有杜宇一声之春信，忽然惊破晓梦耶？ 因致“曹溪路险”，而不可行； “鹫岭云深”，而不可到，茫茫无畔，莫可捉摸。 此处故人之音信，杳绝无闻耳，须知“千丈冰崖”之间，有“五叶莲开”，超然而出，有馨香袅袅，透垂帘而绕古段也。 人能于此中“识破源流”，便见龙王三般之至宝，始可得丹而成仙作佛也。 岂彼禅关参觅所得窥其涯涘哉！ 盖禅关止在性体上参求，而不从命根上着脚，徒费工夫万万，直至老死茫茫，终归大化。 可悲，可惜！ 是皆不识五行山下心猿之事，并不识五行山下走心猿之事也。 故如来回至雷音宝刹，对诸佛、菩萨道：“我以甚深微妙慈悲般若之心，遍观三界。 根本性原，毕竟寂灭。 同虚空相，一无所有”。 言“根本性原”，即本来面目也。 虽难以径入寂灭，而专从性体参求，至得道之后而观性原，毕竟寂灭。 “同虚空相，一无所有”。 言“同虚空相”，则非顽空； 言“一无所有”，则非绝无。 我所殄灭乖猴之事，三界莫有识是事者。 是事乃至真至妙，而非寂灭、顽空者，特以“名生死始”，而法相应如是耳。 倘谓性原本空，而莫识是事，则非我之甚深，而徒事寂灭，则亦寂灭而己矣。 老子曰：“无名，天地之始； 有名，万物之母。 ”无名则死，而为天地之始； 有名则生，而入于五行之中。 如乖猴，是名生而死始，法相有乖本性根源，故出不得如来之掌，而超脱五行之外也。 佛祖盂兰宝盆中，具百样奇花，千般异果，是“有名，万物之母”，贞下还元之象。 此一问也，即佛祖所谓“我有一宝，秘在形山，诸人还识得么”之义。 故大众“请如来明示根本”，如来“宣扬正果”，发三五之妙蕴，禅心朗月，真性涵天，此谓天、地、鬼三藏之真经也。 总而言之：三藏止三五，三五止一五，一五止一而己。 一也者，乃修真之径，正善之门。 此经出于西方，必待东土求取，非有静观密察如大士者，不可得也。 如来道：“这一去，要踏看路道，不许在云霄中行，须是要半云半雾，谨记路程远近之数。 ”言修行者务脚踏实地，循序渐进，不得悬空虚想，躐等妄作。 又须机活神圆，毫无执滞，其中有火候功程次第，切须谨记，不可违错。 五件宝贝之内，有“锦襕袈裟一领”。 袈裟，离染之服。 锦者，五色深丝织成。 在五色为青、黄、赤、白、黑，在五德为仁、义、礼、智、信，在五行为金、木、水、土，在五伦为君臣、父子、夫妇、兄弟、朋友，在五方为东、西、南、北、中央，在五音为宫、商、角、征、羽，在五味为咸、苦、酸、辛、甘，在五季为春、夏、秋、冬四季，至于五官、五谷之类，不可罄述，总一五也，总“锦襕袈裟一领”之宝贝也。
