**Chapter Fifteen: Serpents Coil at the Mountain, Gods Secretly Protect;
The Eagle’s Sorrow Gorge, the Mind-Horse’s Reins Are Gathered**

Wu Yizi says: The Tai Bai Immortal’s song declares:
*"Dragons emerge from whore-fire,
Tigers are born in water."*

Regarding the Kan and Li of the body: it is clear that within yin there is yang, and within yang there is yin—the principle of yin-yang inversion. The heart is Li, yang, the dragon; the yin within Li is the tiger. The kidneys are Kan, yin, the tiger; the yang within Kan is the dragon. Only by subduing the tiger can the true water within Li descend and follow the dragon. Only by taming the dragon can the true fire within Kan rise and approach the tiger. This is called the *"water and fire intermingling, Kan and Li coupling"*—the first essential step in internal alchemy.

The previous chapter’s work of subduing the tiger was accomplished in the mountains; this chapter’s task of taming the dragon must be sought in the waters. *"Snake-Coiling Mountain"* depicts the body’s internal entanglements; *"Eagle’s Sorrow Gorge"* symbolizes the perilous ford where one is easily drowned.

The *"fiendish dragon suddenly emerges to swallow the horse, then vanishes without a trace"*—showing its elusive leaps and untamed ferocity. *"Old Sun cannot bear his impatience, scolds the master for being a pushover"*—showing that restraint has its methods, while fear and hesitation are of no use.

*"By Guanyin’s decree, the Metal Spirit secretly aids"*—clarifying that quiet observation and discernment reveal the priority of preservation. *"Lifting the tiger’s pelt, calling the loach to return the horse"*—demands vigilant self-mastery, ensuring governance is never lax.

The *"two locked in combat"* resemble the meeting of the Zi and Wu hours. *"Sanzang says: ‘The other day, when you struck the tiger, you claimed to have the skill to tame dragons and subdue tigers—why can’t you subdue this one today?’"* Here, the taming of the dragon is explicitly raised, tightly paired with the previous chapter’s subduing of the tiger.

*"The Traveler arrives at the gorge, churning the waters like the Nine Bends of the Yellow River in flood."* The fiendish dragon, deep in the gorge, sits and lies in unrest. To subdue and still it, one must first rouse and stir it—this is the Daoist formula: *"Flanks bent, waist curved, the Yellow River flows backward."* This is the method of striking and circulating, the key to taming the dragon. Otherwise, if left to its leaps and bounds, the dragon emerges from water, refusing to turn with the mind and heed our command—how then can it aid our Dao?

Only through ceaseless diligence, constant movement and stillness, can the true dragon be tamed. If it burrows into the grass, leaving no trace, it means the heels have rested, and progress halts. Thus, one must earnestly investigate, seeking its tracks and whereabouts, never allowing it to follow its own path and destroy the true mechanism. This is why the Monkey King, in his urgency, recites the spell, and the Earth Spirit reveals the dangers of the gorge.

*"Crows and sparrows dare not fly over, for the water is so clear they see their own reflections, mistaking them for their kin and often plunging in to drown."* This illustrates that those who do not recognize the true dragon in the water and seek to subdue it instead mistake the water for harmless and drown—just as crows and sparrows, ignorant, take their reflections for companions and plunge to their deaths.

Heaven has set this sheer gorge, where even wings cannot cross—yet within lies the Black Pearl, urgently awaiting exploration. How then to begin?

Direct the intent, tightly grasp the dragon’s horns, and bear the weight for distant conveyance. Swallow the white horse, and intent transforms into dragon; transform the white horse, and the dragon dissolves into intent. Follow intent in transformation, and the dragon’s nature becomes docile, obeying the heart’s every desire. Thus, upon seeing the *Bimawen*, control and release come effortlessly.

Yet to subdue the tiger, one must first subdue the ordinary tiger before the true tiger appears. The true tiger has no form—it takes the ape as its form. As when, in the previous episode, the tiger was slain and its skin flayed for clothing. To subdue the dragon, one must first subdue the dragon-like before the true dragon emerges. The true dragon has no appearance—it takes the horse as its appearance. As in this episode, when the horse was swallowed and its hide transformed into scales.

These dragon and tiger reside within the self—it is merely the foundation of inner cultivation. Should one seek to harmonize with the external Five Phases to achieve the Great Dao, then the *shen*-monkey must become the tiger, and the *hai*-pig must become the dragon. One must not cling to the text or fixate on images, mistaking false dragons and tigers and thus blundering blindly in practice.

Why then could the *Xingzhe* not subdue the dragon himself and had to enlist the *Jiedi* to summon the Bodhisattva? For the dragon is a creature of unyielding strength, and only the soft Way can approach it. The slightest impatience or coercion only rouses its nature further—only Guanyin’s effortless mastery can tame it. Just as before, when the tiger was subdued, it was through the effortless power of the floral crown that bound it. Thus, the moment the *Xingzhe* saw the Bodhisattva, he invoked the method of the floral crown to restrain his own demonic impulses. Even the sinful dragon labeled the *Xingzhe* a demon, yet neither could escape the bounds of effortless mastery.

Subduing the unruly arises from effortlessness, yet journeying toward the Spirit Mountain demands action. The Bodhisattva declared, *"Only when you obtain this dragon-horse can you proceed."* From this point forward, true vigorous progress begins. She summoned the young dragon and said, *"When have I ever uttered even half the word ‘Tang’ to you?"* How profound the intent! To remain ignorant of the origins of the scripture quest is to reach a dead end at this juncture. But to grasp its true purpose is to cross this shore and enter boundless prospects.

The Bodhisattva continued, *"That monkey-headed fool relies solely on his own strength and refuses to praise others."* Some say this means he cannot empty himself, making it a demonic obstacle on the path of cultivation. Others claim the *Xingzhe* trusts only his own hasty courage and scorns the wisdom of others’ effortlessness. Neither is correct. This passage reveals the immortal master’s secret essentials of the Great Dao—a subtle method of transmitting the golden needle.

The *Daoist Canon*’s ten thousand scrolls speak only of the Mysterious Pass and the Female Gate. Laozi said, *"The gate of the Mysterious Female is called the root of heaven and earth."* It clarifies the mechanism of yin and yang’s ebb and flow, their union and continuity, the root’s ingress and egress—what else could be the root of heaven and earth? Those who identify the Mysterious Female with mouth and nose, heart and kidneys, are mired in form and cannot speak of *"as if preserved."*

Dong Sijing said, *"Spirit is the convergence of qi."* Cao Daochong said, *"The Mysterious conceals spirit in profound obscurity; the Female harbors qi in harmonious emptiness."* Yu Yuwu stated, *"The two cavities of Kan and Li wondrously unite the two earths, blending spirit and qi without falling into names or appearances."* This comes closest to the truth.

Thus the Perfected One said, *"Do not cling to this body as the Dao,"* for this is the error of *"the monkey’s head stubbornly relying on its own strength."* Again he said, *"Recognize the elixir of immortality in that other realm,"* which is the truth of *"how could one refuse to praise another?"*

Straining the mind is solitary cultivation of a single element; submission is the gathering of the Five Phases. It is not attained through empty speculation but arises from the true accumulation of righteousness.

*"The Bodhisattva plucked the small dragon’s luminous pearl and instructed him earnestly, ‘Apply yourself diligently. Only after achieving merit will you transcend the mundane and restore your golden body of fruition.’"* This means that from now on, one must not rely on one’s own brilliance but must exert effort to succeed—take heed not to retreat or regret.

Most wondrous of all is when *"the Pilgrim seized the Bodhisattva and would not let go,"* saying four times, *"I will not go!"* Why? Taming dragons and subduing tigers pertains only to the Kan and Li of the individual body. Even if one has laid the foundation and refined the self, one remains an ordinary mortal—how can this fulfill destiny and transcend the world?

Thus he said, *"The Western Path is so treacherous. Guarding this mortal monk, when will we ever arrive? I will not go! I will not go!"*

Here the passage artfully presses forward to the marvel of the "three families meeting and proceeding together." Every line of the Bodhisattva’s exhortation is spoken in plain truth, without parable. *"Again, she bestowed a fundamental skill—plucking a willow leaf to transform into three life-saving hairs."* How profoundly subtle! The first three pertain to realizing nature, the inner lines of Qian; the latter three pertain to realizing destiny, the outer image of Qian. The first three and the latter three are ultimately the same, until all six lines become pure Qian, forging indestructible true gold—only then is the task complete. Yet the Pilgrim, taking the latter three as nature, truly embodies unfathomable transformation and boundless cyclicality. This is the very essence of great compassion and mercy, the fundamental intent of delivering the world and relieving suffering.

When the Pilgrim and Tang Monk reached the stream’s edge, they saw an old fisherman poling a raft to ferry travelers across. This raft, though substantial, carries the mortal monk to transcend the mundane and realize nature; later, the Cloud-Soaring Ferry, steered by the Guiding Buddha, is the bottomless vessel that ferries the sage monk to realize destiny as a Great Sage. Thus it is said: *"The vast true Suchness ascends the other shore; with sincere heart, nature is realized upon Vulture Peak."* This is the other shore of realizing nature, not the far bank of realizing destiny.

Upon arriving at the village gate to seek lodging, they received a saddle from the Dharma-protecting horse and a whip made of tiger sinew. What he rides is a dragon; what he wields is a tiger—just as they set forth on the path. Hence the words: *"The Bodhisattva bestowed saddle and bridle upon you. Strive diligently on the western journey; take care not to slacken or err."* Some say this signifies the mind-monkey returning to rectitude and the will-horse reined in, resolving seven or eight parts of the matter. Yet this merely glimpses the obstacles of mind and intent, without tracing the inner sanctum of nature and destiny! Such is the *"fleshly eyes and mortal frame, bowing in gratitude yet failing to comprehend—how many past achievements were squandered, provoking the Great Sage’s uproarious laughter!"* These half-hidden, half-revealed turns are most deceptive, hence the remark: *"He truly deserved a thrashing."*

Now, the meaning is clearly expounded: from the tangled heap, the treasure is plucked—pray, let all gather it, and spare yourselves the clout of old Sun’s golden cudgel.

**Chapter Sixteen: The Monks of Guanyin Monastery Scheme for the Treasure; The Monster of Black Wind Mountain Steals the Cassock**

Wu Yizi says: The Great Dao is profoundly subtle, its wonder lying in quiet observation and close scrutiny. With a pair of wisdom-eyes, one perceives that a thousand threads and ten thousand strands are but one affair—lest illusory shadows and empty flowers obscure the true essence and real meaning. These three chapters all prepare for the nineteenth, where Tian Peng is subdued, embodying the essentials of cultivating truth. Fearing that the world would not recognize this, the immortal master raises the banner of *"observation,"* threading it through the three chapters from beginning to end. One must observe both inception and conclusion; this must not be overlooked.

In this chapter, the folly of solitary cultivation of a single thing is made clear, and the perils of cunning and treachery leading to self-destruction must be known. The brocade cassock, a treasure of the heavens, is the color and form of the golden elixir. Only through accumulating virtue and amassing benevolence, radiating brightness and uprightness, honoring teachers and esteeming friends, and guiding through silent enlightenment may one hope for its reward. If one resorts to scheming and deceit, thinking only of oneself and not others, flaunting strength and cunning, and habitually straying into side paths—such are the ranks of wolfish schemers and rat-like thieves. They seek not longevity but hasten their own demise!

Thus, the root of cultivating truth most abhors a scheming mind. Of old, Master Duanmu encountered an old man by the Han River, who embraced a jar to irrigate his garden. Pitying his labor, Duanmu taught him to use a well-sweep. The old man said: *"I have heard that those who employ machinery must engage in mechanical affairs, and those who engage in mechanical affairs must harbor a mechanical mind. When a mechanical mind resides in the breast, purity and whiteness are no longer whole; when purity and whiteness are incomplete, the spirit is unsettled; when the spirit is unsettled, the Dao cannot bear it. I am not ignorant of this—I am ashamed to do it."* Duanmu hung his head in shame. The old man continued: *"You are about to forget your spirit and qi, cast off your bodily form, and only then may you approach it! If you cannot govern your own person, how can you govern the world? Begone, and do not hinder my work!"* For he detested excessive scheming.

The monk struck the bell and laughed, saying, *"You wouldn’t understand—this is ‘as long as I’m a monk for a day, I’ll strike the bell for a day.’"* He added, *"It was your grandfather Sun who taught me to strike it for fun."* This is what it means to follow conditions and accept one’s lot, to harbor no scheming mind, to play along with the occasion, and to embody the uncontrived delight of Heaven—true joy in forgetting all calculation. This stands in stark contrast to the old monk below, who stirred wicked intentions, with Broad Wisdom and Broad Scheming endlessly weighing gains and losses, each deploying their cunning.

The Dao is not beyond planning, yet there is oneself and others—when self and others are united as one, what one seeks is upright. Seeking uprightness is called *vital impulse*; where vital impulse abides, life endures. But if the old monk sought personal gain at others’ expense, he walked the path of perversion. Walking perversion is called *deadly impulse*; where deadly impulse reigns, destruction follows.

The Dao is not beyond stealing, yet to rob Heaven and Earth, to pilfer the workings of Creation without harm to either side or injury to the whole—this is called *knowing the mechanism*. Knowing the mechanism is *Heaven’s mechanism*; Heaven’s mechanism is spirit. But when the black bear seized the opportunity to stealthily carry things away, this was called *riding the mechanism*. Riding the mechanism is *human mechanism*; human mechanism is demonic. The absence of mechanism appears in spontaneity; human mechanism arises from contrivance.

Like the old monk who, once the cassock was in hand, wept bitterly by lamplight—Broad Wisdom and Broad Scheming’s schemes, fire attacks, and lethal force—this was human mechanism, riding the mechanism, walking perversion, and self-destruction. Yet with a numinous mind at work and seated awareness, hearing the crackle of firewood, he knew harm was afoot. Turning the tables, he ascended to the Southern Heavenly Lad to borrow the fire-repelling cloak, shielding Tang Monk while ignoring the rest. Where fire aids wind, this thing comes from illumination, harmonious yet not initiating—this was knowing the mechanism, Heaven’s mechanism, seeking uprightness to dispel perversion.

In this chapter, the two appearances of *"a honeybee"* devise a method, teaching one to observe closely and quietly, to recognize the error of harming others for personal gain, and the Dao’s counterstrike—how the Metal Duke cannot lack the Wood Mother. Tang Monk’s words, *"Do not compete in wealth with others,"* are the deep concealment of a wise merchant. The crowd’s words, *"You only harm yourself,"* are the self-invited consequences of fortune and misfortune. Though the admonitions are many, none hit the mark. Only by reading this closely can one grasp the art of narrative.

**Chapter Seventeen: Sun the Pilgrim Raises Havoc on Black Wind Mountain; Guanyin Subdues the Bear Spirit**

*Wu Yizi says:* The *Cantong Qi* states, *"Right and wrong pass through the viscera; inner observation yields reflection."* It speaks of the treasure of true yin and true yang, which cannot be obtained merely by scrutinizing the five viscera or scheming in thought. The old monk of the previous chapter, dwelling in Guanyin Monastery, schemed to seize the cassock—this was like inwardly observing the heart and employing the mind to plot. Little did he know that scheming with the mind stokes the heart-fire to a blaze, burning the heart-fire itself. Inevitably, it becomes a vast fire pit; not only does water fail to quell the flames, but the true treasure sinks into the lower field, just as the black bear stole away the cassock. This is the harm of misusing the mind’s mechanism. Thus, the opening laments: *"Cursed be that old skinflint who knew not men, scheming with his heart—today he has only harmed himself."* This is a sobering revelation.

Yet to abandon the method of observing the mind and forcefully direct effort toward the kidneys is to cling to the superficial talk of refining cinnabar and mercury—a mere side door, an external path! This black fellow is none other than the demon of the lower field. The Daoist is his qi, hence named *"Soaring Void"*; the scholar is his essence, hence clad in white. Calling it the *"Buddhist Robe Assembly"* shows they recognize only the name’s surface, not its inner reality. *"Black Wind Mountain, Black Wind Cave"* depicts the color of the Water Palace’s qi; *"iron helmet, black armor, dark robe, black boots"* shape the form of the Kan Palace. The Pilgrim’s entire account aligns with the essential aim of cultivating truth.

Only the line *"He said his body held elixir pills, but seeking them outside is futile toil"* directly condemns those who focus on the kidneys, refining mercury and extraction—an unlawful practice. It closely anticipates the later chapter where Tian Peng’s self-rescue represents the true, original, and natural union. *"The monster and the Pilgrim fought until the red sun stood at noon, then withdrew to eat."* This is the time when kidney qi wanes at noon and heart-blood flourishes, like closing the gate to draft a letter, inviting the venerable Gold Pond. *"Humble one"* denotes subordination; *"Venerable One"* denotes superiority. The meaning is clear.

The bear and black ape belong to fire yet appear as black men—these are the flames of desire within the kidneys; the Gold Pond belongs to wood yet is called the Cinnabar Chamber—this is the lustful fluid within the heart. Each has its season of encounter and can even offer mutual benefit, forming alliances. Drawn together by kindred qi, they say: *"Transmit to him some qi-absorption methods."*

The Immortal Master, fearing readers might misconstrue the previous monk as an impure mind, thus has the Pilgrim transform into a monk to clarify that the monk is none other than the Mind-Ape. *"Entering the cave, observing its couplets, a place of profound stillness and seclusion"*—this originally describes the realm of understanding destiny. Yet those who practice the demonic arts of extraction without comprehending the spiritual union of intercourse fail to know destiny.

After the deception is exposed and battle resumes, victory and defeat remain undecided. The Pilgrim says: *"I’m not much harder—let’s just call it an even match."* For the Pilgrim’s unyielding strength is like true gold, while the bear’s obstinate rigidity is like crude iron. Gold and iron do not merge, their banners and drums perfectly matched. Yet stubborn iron can be transmuted into gold—it simply lacks the alchemy of refinement to be gathered.

Thus, the journey to the Southern Sea to seek Guanyin is introduced, making clear that the method of subjugation must still be sought in the realm of contemplative freedom. Observe the marvel of subjugation: no longer forcing the scholar to slither like a snake, but simply snapping him in two, turning white into a face; no longer allowing the mess of filling earth, but cleaving the head into a cake, transforming black into cinnabar.

*"Seeing the words ‘Crafted by Lingxuzi’ at the bottom of the tray, the Pilgrim laughed: ‘Fortune! Fortune!’"*—for beneath these words lay the mechanism of destiny. Thus, the Bodhisattva seizes the opportunity, using the ploy to reclaim the kasaya. The immortal elixir cannot be formed apart from this, yet its function was misapplied, burying the treasure. Now, employing the very method of the other against himself, there is no need to rekindle the furnace and bell, sparing further toil. Why? True and false differ by but a single thought, yet fundamentally share the same principle. If one can master spiritual transformation, this can become that, and that can become this—this is the harmonizing elixir-head, the subtle workings of destiny in silent communion.

Thus, the Bodhisattva may transform into a demon, and the demon remains the Bodhisattva, revealing that self and other share a single source, never clashing. This sets the stage for the later self-mating of Metal Lord and Original Mother, who cannot bear even momentary separation. The Pilgrim eats the two immortal elixirs first—what is false can be transformed by the true; the Pilgrim then transforms anew—what is true shifts with the false. Transformation is boundless, concealment and revelation unfathomable, one becoming two, two becoming one—all is ultimately nothingness.

The moment the Pilgrim swallows the elixir, the demon is subjugated, demonstrating the principle of responsive spiritual communion. *"Already exited through the nostrils"*—showing the swiftness of transference. *"The Pilgrim, fearing delay, wished to strike him dead"*—this is *"no merit, yet merit lies within merit."* *"The Bodhisattva hastily stopped him, saying: ‘I have use for him elsewhere.’"*—this is *"having use, yet use is no use."*

*"The black man vowed to attain the true fruit; the Bodhisattva touched his crown and administered the precepts. Today, a wild heart is settled, and endless obstinacy is reined in"*—gaining the heart of freedom while restraining the desires of the senses, as circumstances dictate. The kasaya, lost and then recovered, the bear and ape return directly to the great sea, and the Black Wind Cave is transformed into a monastery for the beholder.

chunks.original_text: 第十八回　观音院唐僧脱难　高老庄大圣降魔 悟一子曰：《易》曰：“天地氤氲，万物化醇，男女媾精，万物化生。 ”明阴阳以交为用，天地交而为泰，山泽通而为咸，水火合而为既济。 或以阴求阳，或以阳求阴； 或阳感而阴应，或阴动而阳从，方能化生。 飞潜动植，各有男女，总一阴一阳之道也。 倘孤阴而寡阳，孤阳而寡阴，则阴阳之气专而不交，何能生化哉！ 《参同契》曰：“牝鸡自卵，其雏不全。 ”又曰：“使二女共室，颜色甚姝，虽有苏、张结媒，毙发腐齿，终不相知。 ”其理甚明。 老庄之道，一本于《易》。 故老子曰：“玄牝之门，是谓天地根。 ”“众夫蹈以出，蠕动莫不由。 ”庄子曰：“至阴肃肃，至阳赫赫。 ”又曰：“尸居而龙见，渊默而雷声，神动而天随。 ”盖一阴一阳，一动一静，互为其根，而太极乘乎其中。 人能体夫太极，则天关在手，地轴生心，即是仙佛圣人了也。 设有一念之差，则动静皆非天理，故君子贵慎独省察； 设有一事之偏，则动静皆失其中，故君子贵格物致知。 不能格物致知，而偏阴偏阳，独修一物，又何能成仙作佛而超凡入圣乎！ 陈泥丸曰：“别有些儿奇又奇，心肾缘来非坎离。 ”缘督子曰：“先天一气，自虚无中来。 一点阳精，秘在形山，不在心肾，而在乎玄关一窍。 ”学者不识阴阳，不知时候，不能还返，止于自身摸索，而认取照照灵灵之识神以为真实，辗转差池。 噫！ 道既非可外求，又非可自身摸索，真玄之又玄，难以察识。 彼邪师迷徒，妄揣为御女闺丹之术，失之愈远。 仙师提纲，特揭老、庄高妙之道示人，故曰：“高老庄”。 前二回：一是心之偏动而火炽，一是肾之偏动而气焰，固非道，而是难。 若错观二者为道，变是一偏而遭难。 能离此观，则脱此难矣。 “行者将黑风洞烧做红风洞”，是转暗室而为光天，去祸地而就福陵也。 师徒行路，时值春融，诗内“鸳鸯”“蛱蝶”之句，俱形容定偶双飞之景象，乃阴阳交泰之妙文也。 最提醒人处，在问地名一段。 行者到处，未尝以问地名为急务。

Chapter Eighteen: The Tang Monk Escapes Peril at Guanyin Monastery; The Great Sage Subdues the Demon at Gaolao Village

Wu Yizi observes: The *Book of Changes* states, *"Heaven and earth intermingle in misty vapor, and the myriad things transform into purity. Male and female unite in essence, and the myriad things come to life."* It clarifies that yin and yang employ union as their function. When heaven and earth unite, it is *Tai* (Peace); when mountains and marshes communicate, it is *Xian* (Mutual Joy); when water and fire merge, it is *Jiji* (Completion). Sometimes yin seeks yang, sometimes yang seeks yin; sometimes yang stirs and yin responds, sometimes yin moves and yang follows—only then can transformation and generation occur. From flying birds to hidden fish, from moving beasts to rooted plants, each possesses male and female, all following the Dao of one yin and one yang. If yin stands alone and yang is lacking, or yang stands alone and yin is lacking, then the qi of yin and yang becomes isolated and fails to unite—how can generation and transformation arise?

The *Cantong Qi* states, *"If a hen hatches an egg alone, her chick will not be whole."* It also says, *"If two women share a chamber, though their beauty be exquisite, even with Su Qin and Zhang Yi as matchmakers, their hair will rot and their teeth decay—ultimately, they will never know one another."* This principle is abundantly clear.

The Dao of Laozi and Zhuangzi fundamentally derives from the *Book of Changes*. Thus, Laozi says, *"The gate of the Mysterious Female is called the root of heaven and earth. Though it seems to endure ceaselessly, its use is inexhaustible."* And, *"All creatures emerge from it, and wriggling things none fail to follow."* Zhuangzi says, *"Supreme yin is solemn and still; supreme yang blazes and glows."* He also says, *"Though the corpse abides in stillness, the dragon appears; though the abyss is silent, thunder resounds. When the spirit moves, heaven follows."* For yin and yang, movement and stillness, each is the root of the other, and the Supreme Ultimate rides within them.

If one can embody the Supreme Ultimate, then the heavenly gate rests in the hand, and the earthly axis arises in the heart—this is the attainment of immortals, buddhas, and sages. But if a single thought errs, then movement and stillness alike depart from the heavenly principle; thus, the noble person values vigilance in solitude and introspection. If a single affair leans to one side, then movement and stillness alike lose their center; thus, the noble person values the investigation of things and the extension of knowledge. If one cannot investigate things and extend knowledge, but instead clings to one-sided yin or yang, cultivating only a single aspect—how can one become an immortal or buddha and transcend the mundane to enter sagehood?

Chen Niuwan says, *"There is something strange yet stranger still: the affinity of heart and kidney is not Kan and Li."* Yuanduzi says, *"The primordial qi of pre-heaven comes from the realm of emptiness. A single spark of yang essence is hidden within the mountain of form—not in the heart or kidney, but within the mysterious pass of the single aperture."* If scholars do not recognize yin and yang, do not know the proper timing, and cannot return to the source, but instead grope about within themselves, mistaking the flickering, luminous consciousness for the true reality, they will err again and again.

Alas! The Dao cannot be sought externally, nor can it be grasped by groping within oneself. It is profoundly mysterious and difficult to perceive. Those false masters who mislead their disciples, recklessly conjecturing that it is the art of bedroom alchemy or inner elixirs, stray ever further from the truth. The immortal master outlines the essentials, specifically revealing Laozi and Zhuangzi’s lofty and wondrous Dao—hence the name *"Gaolao Village."*

In the previous two chapters: one depicts the heart’s biased movement and the blazing of fire; the other, the kidney’s biased movement and the flaring of qi. Neither is the Dao, but rather calamity. If one mistakenly regards these two as the Dao, one falls into bias and encounters misfortune. Only by departing from this view can one escape this peril.

*"The Pilgrim turned the Black Wind Cave into a Cave of Crimson Wind"*—this is transforming a dark chamber into a realm of light, leaving a land of misfortune to ascend a mound of blessing. As master and disciples journey, spring’s warmth unfolds. The verses with *"mandarin ducks"* and *"butterflies"* depict the scene of paired flight in settled union—an exquisite depiction of yin and yang in harmonious union.

The most awakening moment lies in the passage where the place name is inquired. Wherever the Pilgrim goes, he never treats asking the name of a place as an urgent matter.

chunks.original_text: 此处特再三致诘者，若云此处乃老、庄真区处，不可不着意穷究也。 若将此处说个明白，便是“与人方便，与已方便”。 又妙在“问了别人没趣，须是问他才有卖买”二语。 盖问别人，则非高老庄之道； 而问他，则有卖买交易之妙也。 末后行者见了妖精道：“原来是这个卖买。 ”心知默会，与此处相照应。 曰：“乌斯藏国界之地，叫做高老庄”。 乌者，日之精； 兔者，月之精。 乌斯藏，则兔斯现，彼此交感，其界甚清，老庄之高端，在于斯。 说出个女儿招了妖精，正是老庄之妙。 以女嫁人，谓之娶，以男入赘，谓之招。 老、庄之道，善事阴阳，不以顺行，而以逆用。 颁行，则凡父、凡母而成人道； 逆用，则灵父、灵母而成仙道。 女之招男而配，如月之得日而明也。 故道家以月喻道体，其旨甚显。 师徒引见，太公说出第三女翠兰招福陵山人女婿。 “三女”为少女之妙，“福陵”做为多福如陵之高也，隐寓兑女艮勇名象。 太公怕行者相貌之丑，老孙道：“丑自丑，却有本事。 ”又言女婿嘴脸行迹亦怪。 行者道：“入夜之时，就见好歹。 ”这都是描写世人皮相之俗见，不知披褐怀玉，老蚌含珠，其中实有成仙作佛之窍妙也。 行者手捻兵器，打破魔关，道：“你叫声女儿，可在里面么？ ”老儿叫出女儿，哭诉怪态道：“他云去雾来，不知踪迹。 ”要须从幽独里寻获亲女形容，迷途内讨取嫡婿下落，却勿泥常执迹，昧却夫妻颠倒之故也。 “行者变得就如那女子一般，”非变相也，现本相也。 何也？ 真乙之气，乃水中之金，外阴而内阳，本为女子，故就外阴而言，则行者为妻，理也。 读者着眼此处，仙师明指行者为女子，弗拟为变相。 其下文推病措词，叹气陈情，曲肖两口情态。 老孙做老婆，老猪做老公，真天造地设一对，绝色正头好夫人也。 这都是实义，如目为游戏幻境。 迨说出五百年前大闹天宫的老孙，老猪即知其来历，足以相制，往外就走。 行者紧紧追随，如鹰搏免，如猫捕鼠，情性使然，所谓“五百年前结下的因缘”，匹配已定，不可拆离者也。 请进后篇而详其说。 第十九回　云栈洞悟空收八戒　浮屠山玄奘受心经 悟一子曰：自十六回观音院至此云栈洞，绪出金木交并，真阴真阳之大作用，方是打开心中之门户，而不落于空亡。 名为真空，空而不空。 即《心经》所谓“色即是空，空即是色”也。 故提纲以“悟空收八戒”，“玄奘受《心经》”紧对项联，明收得八戒，乃受得《心经》“云栈”者，上天之车； “浮屠”者，超地之级。 下学上达，层次而进，自有为而至于无为之的旨也。

Here the repeated questioning is deliberate—if this place is indeed the true domain of Laozi and Zhuangzi, one cannot but investigate it with utmost care. To clarify this point is to *"grant convenience to others and to oneself."*

The subtlety lies in the two phrases: *"asking others brings no pleasure, but asking him yields commerce."* For to ask others is to stray from the Dao of Gao Laozhuang; to ask him, however, reveals the marvel of exchange and transaction. Later, when the Pilgrim sees the demon, he remarks, *"So this is the trade!"*—his heart already comprehends, echoing the earlier insight.

He says, *"This land on the border of the Ü-Tsang kingdom is called Gao Laozhuang."* The crow embodies the essence of the sun; the hare, the essence of the moon. In Ü-Tsang, the hare manifests, and through their mutual resonance, the boundary becomes distinct. The lofty origins of Laozi and Zhuangzi lie precisely here. The revelation that a daughter has *"taken in a demon as son-in-law"* is the very subtlety of their Dao.

To give a daughter in marriage is called *"marrying off,"* while to take a man into the family is called *"taking in."* The Dao of Laozi and Zhuangzi excels in managing yin and yang—not by following the natural course, but by reversing it. Proceeding in sequence, ordinary fathers and mothers produce mortal offspring; reversing the process, numinous father and mother give rise to immortals. A woman taking a man as her mate is like the moon receiving the sun’s light to shine. Thus, Daoists use the moon to symbolize the Dao’s essence—its meaning is abundantly clear.

When master and disciples are introduced, the elder states that his third daughter, Cuilan, has taken in a son-in-law from Mount Fuling. *"Third daughter"* signifies the marvel of the youngest; *"Fuling"* suggests blessings as vast as a mound—implicitly evoking the trigram *dui* (joyful maiden) and *gen* (resolute strength). Fearing the Pilgrim’s ugliness, the elder remarks, *"Ugly he may be, but he has skill."* He also notes that the son-in-law’s appearance and conduct are strange. The Pilgrim replies, *"When night falls, we shall see the truth."* All this depicts the worldly habit of judging by outward appearances, unaware that beneath coarse robes may lie jade, or within an old clam, a pearl—hidden within are the wondrous openings to immortality and Buddhahood.

The Pilgrim, weapon in hand, shatters the demon’s barrier and calls out, *"Summon your daughter—is she within?"* The old man calls his daughter forth, who weeps as she describes the demon’s erratic behavior: *"He vanishes like mist, leaving no trace."* One must seek the true form of one’s daughter in solitude and retrieve the whereabouts of one’s son-in-law from the depths of delusion—yet one must not cling to superficial traces and overlook the reversal of husband and wife.

*"The Pilgrim transformed himself to resemble the woman"*—this is not a change of form, but the revelation of his true form. Why? The primordial *yi* qi is metal within water, outwardly yin but inwardly yang. In essence, he is female; thus, in terms of external yin, the Pilgrim becomes the wife—this is principle. Readers, take note: the immortal master explicitly identifies the Pilgrim as female, not as a transformed guise. The subsequent dialogue—feigned illness, sighs, and entreaties—faithfully captures the intimate exchanges of a married couple.

Old Sun as the wife, Old Zhu as the husband—truly a pair heaven-made and earth-matched, a flawless and proper lady. All this is real meaning, though it may appear as playful illusion. When the Pilgrim reveals his identity as the Great Sage who wreaked havoc in Heaven five hundred years prior, Old Zhu immediately recognizes his origins and knows he can be subdued—he flees at once. The Pilgrim pursues relentlessly, like an eagle seizing a hare, like a cat pouncing on a mouse—such is the nature of their bond. *"The karmic tie forged five hundred years ago"*—their union was predestined, unbreakable. Let us proceed to the next chapter for a fuller account.

**Chapter Nineteen: Wukong Subdues Bajie in Cloud Ladder Cave; Tripitaka Receives the Heart Sutra at Floating Pagoda Mountain**

Wu Yizi observes: From the sixteenth chapter at Guanyin Monastery to this Cloud Ladder Cave, the interplay of metal and wood unfolds—the grand workings of true yin and true yang. Only thus does one open the gateways of the heart without falling into emptiness. This is *"true emptiness"*—empty yet not empty, precisely what the *Heart Sutra* means by *"form is emptiness, emptiness is form."*

Hence, the chapter’s outline pairs *"Wukong subdues Bajie"* with *"Tripitaka receives the Heart Sutra"* as a tight parallel. To *"subdue Bajie"* is to receive the *Heart Sutra*. *"Cloud Ladder"* is the chariot of Heaven; *"Floating Pagoda"* is the ladder transcending Earth. Ascending from lower learning to higher attainment, step by step, one moves from effortful action to effortless Dao—this is the ultimate aim.

The Monkey of *shen* belongs to Metal, and Metal engenders Water—west four and north one, together making one-five. The Pig of *hai* belongs to Wood, and Wood engenders Fire—east two and south three, together making one-five. Within these two fives, *wu* and *ji* naturally merge into one-five.

Within yang there is yin; within yin there is yang.
Within generation there is restraint; within restraint there is generation—
what is called "taking turns as guest and host, mutually serving as husband and wife."

In the ordinary sequence of the Five Phases:
Wood and Fire belong to yang and serve as husband;
Metal and Water belong to yin and serve as wife.
The Monkey is wife;
the Pig is husband.

In the inverted sequence of the Five Phases:
within yang lies true yin, which is wife;
within yin lies true yang, which is husband.
The Monkey is wife, yet in truth husband;
the Pig is husband, yet in truth wife.
True yin and true yang find their subtlety in *wu* and *ji*.

Thus it is said: the essence of the three and the five wondrously converges and coalesces.
The *Doctrine of the Mean* states: "The Way of the noble person begins with the relationship between husband and wife; at its utmost, it is discerned throughout Heaven and Earth."
If one grasps the word *"utmost"* as the utmost of exhausting one’s nature and fulfilling one’s destiny, enlightenment is already present in that very understanding.

Ordinary people do not follow the central Way, stubbornly clinging to partial yin or partial yang. Blindly cultivating and recklessly refining, they neither recognize the Dao nor attain it—
how pitiable, how lamentable!

At the chapter’s opening, "flames coalesce to manifest form"—the Pig embodies the vital essence of the Southern Dipper’s generative *qi*, the radiant hue of the Li Palace. The "nine-toothed iron rake" marks the yang number reaching its apex at nine, the very image of true yin; its operation turns with the rake, entrusted entirely to the *qi*-mechanism of bearing and movement.

Old Pig’s account of his self-rescue mirrors Monkey’s own self-narration, with phrases like "pairing yin and yang," "dividing sun and moon," "harmonizing dragon and tiger," and "drawing in the Golden Crow" all distilling the marrow of the Nine-Cycled Great Return Elixir. When Monkey engages him in fierce battle yet does not immediately subdue him, instead withdrawing their forces to their respective sides, he subtly highlights the three characters "Gao Family Village" to redirect attention to the original theme—why? Lest the world mistake victory in battle for true excellence, unaware that the highest good lies in subduing others without fighting! Here, the Dao of the Golden Elixir reveals itself as no mere art of seductive song.

Monkey recounts how "Tian Peng descended to the mortal realm, having mistakenly entered the wrong womb, yet his numinous nature remained intact." He adds, "For a celestial deity to take such a son-in-law hardly tarnishes the family’s reputation." This shows the upright *qi* of yin and yang, incomparable to mundane malevolent spirits, thus setting up the following line: "It’s only that there were no matchmakers or witnesses to mediate." Why so? The union of husband and wife depends entirely on go-betweens; without them, natures fail to harmonize. This is precisely what the *Cantong Qi* means by "those without shared speech are no kin." Thus Monkey resumes the challenge, declaring, "You don’t resemble one who forcibly seizes another’s daughter without matchmakers or witnesses"—his intent directly foreshadowing the water monster Sha Monk as the go-between ahead, while here planting the notion to elucidate how marital discord arises from such causes. Profound and intricately woven, this meaning is unparalleled. Yet readers dismiss it as mere banter, casually glancing past, burying its depth.

chunks.original_text: 行者究问是高老家筑地之钯，老猪夸美为老君亲炼之铁，授自老子，都是真言。 “不能筑动老孙一些头皮”，木不能克金也。 老猪一闻西天求经之言，去了钉钯，何也！ 盖亲受观音之的旨，知独倚钉钯，乃是偏执，不可以得正果，所谓舍已从人，不专倚自强也。 故曰“何不早说取经之事，只倚凶强上门打我”，正与行者收伏小龙时，菩萨道“那猴头专倚自强，那肯称赞别人”相应。 老猪真心发愿，焚巢纳械，自缚投诚，盖木性顺义而恋金，曲木从绳而受直也。 八句诗中，阐明金木相生相克之理，宾主相交合之情。 夫妻不隔，情性无乖，为西方极乐之造端也。 迨收服归来，高老认得女婿，三藏喜得吾徒徒，起名“八戒”，去邪归正，已可安排筵宴，欢庆团圆矣。 下文“八戒扯住高老，请我拙荆”，见情缘之难断； “行者、八戒也吃素酒”，见曲蘖之易耽； “受了一丝，千劫难修”，见货利之多累； “取经不成，还来做婿”，见道心之易退； 又道“恐一时有些差池，却不和尚误了做，老婆误了娶”，见盲修瞎炼之无功。 处处都是孺子之歌，切勿看作闲情打诨也。 三众辞别，投西而去。 诗内“情和性定诸缘合，月满金华是伐毛”，上句偶过收八戒，下句起受《心经》，盖已收八戒，金丹有象，故行过了乌斯藏界，即遇鸟巢禅师。 何也？ 日西月东，为双丸之分照；
chunks.translated_text:
Monkey pressed further, inquiring whether the rake was truly from Squire Gao’s household. Pig boasted of it as iron personally forged by Lord Lao, bestowed by Laozi himself—both claims truthful. "Yet it could not so much as scratch my scalp," for wood cannot overcome metal. Upon hearing of the journey to the Western Heaven to seek the scriptures, Pig relinquished his rake. Why? Having received Avalokiteśvara’s clear decree, he knew that clinging solely to the rake was a one-sided attachment, incompatible with attaining true fruition—what is called "abandoning the self to follow others" rather than relying solely on one’s own strength. Thus he said, "Why not have spoken sooner of the scripture-seeking matter, instead of relying on brute force to batter at my door?" This precisely echoes the moment when Monkey subdued the young dragon, when the bodhisattva remarked, "That monkey-head relies entirely on his own strength and refuses to praise others."

With sincere resolve, Pig burned his den, surrendered his weapon, bound himself, and pledged allegiance—for wood, by nature compliant and righteous, yearns for metal, just as crooked wood submits to the carpenter’s line to be made straight. Within these eight verses, the principles of metal and wood generating and overcoming one another are expounded, as are the dynamics of guest and host in harmonious exchange. When husband and wife are not estranged, their natures and dispositions remain unopposed—this is the very inception of the Western Paradise’s bliss.

Upon their return after subduing Pig, Squire Gao recognized his son-in-law, and Tripitaka rejoiced in gaining a disciple, bestowing the name "Eight Precepts." With evil cast aside and rectitude embraced, a feast could now be prepared to celebrate their reunion. In what follows, "Eight Precepts seized Squire Gao, inviting my humble wife" reveals how hard it is to sever karmic ties; "Monkey and Eight Precepts drank the vegetarian wine" shows how easily one succumbs to fermented brews; "Accepting a single thread, ten thousand kalpas of cultivation are undone" illustrates the heavy burdens of material gain; "If the scripture quest fails, I’ll return to be a son-in-law" exposes the fragility of the resolve for the Way; and again, "Lest some mishap occur, the monk’s vows be broken, the wife’s marriage be lost" reveals the futility of blind, misguided practice. Every line is a child’s song of admonition—do not dismiss it as mere idle jest.

The three disciples took their leave and set forth toward the west. The verse within—"With harmony of disposition and settled nature, all conditions converge; when the moon fills the golden flower, the hair is shorn"—its first line alludes in passing to the recruitment of Eight Precepts, while the second heralds the reception of the *Heart Sutra*. For once Eight Precepts was subdued, the golden elixir took form, and so, having passed the border of Ü-Tsang, they encountered the Bird’s Nest Chan Master. Why? The sun west and moon east mark the division of the twin orbs’ illumination...

chunks.original_text: 乌藏兔显，实一气之交辉。 缘合月满，乃是真诠。 皓月禅心，从可印证。 此《心经》一卷，所以即于此处出现，如月中藏乌，明朗无垢； 传授密谛，指示迷津，端在斯矣。 三藏拜问路途，禅师道：“路远终到，魔瘴难消。 ”故授以《心经》，止可消除魔瘴而已。 其中原未有西天端的，故结曰：“此乃修真之总经，作佛之会门也。 ”三藏扯住，再问西天端的，而禅师已历历指明，曰：“你问那相识，他知西去路。 ”行者知而冷笑道：“不必问他，问我便了。 ”三藏还不解其意。 下面扯住行者的话，正是问我。 行者道：“他骂我兄弟两个一场。 ”乃暗答西天大路，故三藏道：“他讲的西天路径，何尝骂你？ ”一以为骂我是指路，一以为讲路而非骂。 一师一徒，一向一答，全是禅机，语语显露，急须省晓。 行者道：“你那里晓得：他说：‘野猪挑担子’，是骂的八戒； ‘多年老石猴’，是骂的老孙。 你怎么解得其意？ ”曰“那里晓得”，乃是要人晓得； 曰“怎么解得”，乃是要人解得。 禅师曰“他知西去路”，是交与行者传言； 行者曰“问我便了”，是替那禅师代说。 已是了了。 八戒道：“神师晓得过去未来之事。 ”已知他分明说了。 “但看他‘水怪前头遇’这句话，不知验否？ ”噫！ 妙哉！
chunks.translated_text:
The crow hidden in darkness, the hare revealed in light—these are but the radiant interplay of a single qi. When conditions converge and the moon waxes full, this is the true essence. The luminous moon of Chan mind may thus be verified. This *Heart Sutra* scroll appears precisely here, like the crow concealed within the moon, bright and unstained. In its transmission of secret truths, it points the way through delusion—here lies the crux.

Tripitaka bowed and inquired about the road ahead. The Chan Master replied, "The path is long, and the journey’s end will come, but demonic miasmas are not so easily dispelled." Thus he bestowed the *Heart Sutra*, for it alone could dissolve such afflictions. Yet the sutra held no direct signpost to the Western Heaven, so he concluded, "This is the comprehensive scripture of true cultivation, the gateway to Buddhahood."

Tripitaka, still grasping for answers, pressed further about the way to the West. The Chan Master had already made it plain, saying, "Ask that acquaintance of yours—he knows the road west." Monkey, understanding, gave a cold laugh. "No need to ask him—ask me instead." Tripitaka failed to grasp his meaning.

The exchange that followed—Tripitaka seizing Monkey’s words—was the very question he sought to ask. Monkey said, "He insulted my brother and me." This was a veiled answer to the road west. Tripitaka replied, "He spoke of the western path—when did he insult you?" One took it as an insult pointing the way; the other heard only directions, not abuse. Master and disciple, question and response—all was Chan subtlety, every word a revelation. One must awaken swiftly.

Monkey said, "You wouldn’t understand: ‘A wild boar carrying a load’—that was an insult to Eight Precepts. ‘An old stone monkey of many years’—that was an insult to me. How could you possibly grasp his meaning?" To say *"You wouldn’t understand"* was to demand understanding; to say *"How could you grasp it?"* was to demand comprehension.

The Chan Master’s words—*"He knows the road west"*—were a charge to Monkey to relay the message. Monkey’s *"Ask me instead"* was his acceptance of that charge. All was already clear.

Eight Precepts said, "The divine master knows all past and future." He had spoken plainly enough. "But let’s see if his words—‘You’ll meet water monsters ahead’—prove true." Ah! How wondrous!

chunks.original_text: 神哉！ 前途魔瘴甚多，何以止提“水怪前头遇”一句？ 他两个口中，分明将西天大路说出来了，三藏何须再问。 第二十回　黄风岭唐僧有难　半山中八戒争先 悟一子曰：此明既受《心经》，急须下手，弗误认心即道，而自阻前程也。 篇首一偈，言修道者有法，法从心生，还从心灭。 所以生法、灭法者为谁？ 须自己辨别明白。 若云既然皆是自己心，又何用别人说？ 只须就心下功，是欲扭铁出血，挽空作结，而期无为，万无是理。 此是认贼为子，何能到心、法两忘地位？ 不知其间有他家不死之方。 休教他瞒我，先须识透五行，一拳打彻障碍，期心可无心，而法自可辍矣。 这才是碧天秋月，彼此无分，性命俱了也。 若云即心即佛，而不识非心非佛，谬解诗中“既然皆已心，何用别人说”之句，系责成自己之要诀，岂不错了门户？ 故起语云：“这一篇偈子，乃是玄奘师悟彻了《多心经》，打开了门户。 ”若言心即是道，道无不了，何以云止“打开了门户？ ”其必仆仆再往西天，取何真经？ 岂西天之真经，非别人之说乎？ 此其说可晓然而悟矣！ 《参同契》曰：“乾坤其《易》之门户。 ”悟空、悟能，乃《易》之门户，即《心经》之门户也。 得了悟空、悟能，便是打开了门户。 从此下手修为，方可造其堂奥矣。 前乌巢禅师恐唐僧不识《心经》门户，故指示“野猪”、“石猴”，令行者说出。 长老已解其义，故长老常念常存，一点灵光自透，分明是“日落西山藏火镜，月升东海现冰轮”境界。 大道在望，急须前进。 倘止从自家心上摸索，而认取灵灵昭昭之识神，以为真实，不知有西天之大路，如恋家的一般，谓之“恋家鬼”，何能超脱尘俗？ 故前人有讥驻颜住世，而不能脱壳飞升者，谓之“守尸鬼”，其说相似。 行者说个“您家鬼”，骂尽自来执心用功者。 三藏道：“悟能，你若在家心重时，不是出家的了。 你还回去里。 ”呆于原无退悔言语，而设此一段话头，岂真行者赃埋呆子哉？ 特借呆子以发明修心而恋心，犹出家而恋也。 你看呆子“死心踏地前来”，死心前来，复是心法，而下手用功，却须手段。 但能死心而无手段，则在在棘手，去路不通，故老者摆手摇头道：“去不得西天，难取经。 ”及行者说出本事，而老者道：“你想必有些手段。 ”又曰：“你既有这样手段，西方也还去得。 ”此真老、庄指示之妙谛也。 故提老者为主，下文“庄南两个少年人，带着一个老妈妈，三四个小男女”一段影子，正老、庄《道德》、《南华》玄妙中之秘要，惊愚骇俗的故事，去得西方的大手段也。 八戒又提“在高老庄时，常吓杀凡人”，即说破鬼神惊骇者是。 行者笑道：“不要乱说，把那丑也收拾些”，即说着丑行着妙者是。 下文献茶、问姓嗣、叙年庚，俱引起黄风岭难行，须有大手段如老孙者，方才去得之意； 饿鬼添饭半饱，俱形容西方路远，须志愿难满如老猪者，方才担得之义。 盖心本非道，倘谓心即是道，而期必于心，乃以心缚心而横截去路，便是黄风岭虎怪计脱金蝉，而捆缚定风桩上也。 何以故？ 风为巽木，黄为中央，横于心胸如岭矗然。 虎怪之转辗执迷，即已心之辗转期必也。 你看虎怪“抠住自家胸膛，把皮剥下，站立道傍”，形容模样，句句宛肖“心”字。
chunks.translated_text:
Oh, how profound! Though many demonic miasmas lie ahead on the journey, why single out only the phrase *"water monsters ahead"*? In the mouths of those two, the great road to the Western Heaven was already laid bare—why should Tripitaka ask further?

In Chapter Twenty, *"Tang Monk in Peril on Yellow Wind Ridge, Pig in the Vanguard at Mid-Mountain,"* Wu Yizi says: This passage makes clear that once one has received the *Heart Sutra*, one must act swiftly, lest one mistake the mind for the Dao and thus obstruct one’s own progress.

The opening verse speaks of the practitioner of the Dao having a method—one that arises from the mind and is extinguished by the mind. But who is it that gives rise to the method, and who extinguishes it? One must discern this clearly for oneself. If one claims that all is but one’s own mind, then why rely on the words of others? One need only apply effort to the mind itself—yet this is like trying to twist iron into blood, to knot the void into form, and to expect effortless attainment. Such a path is utterly impossible. This is to mistake the thief for one’s own child—how could one ever reach the state where both mind and dharma are forgotten?

One must recognize that there exists an immortal elixir beyond such delusions. Do not let it deceive you. First, see through the five phases, shatter all obstacles with a single blow, and strive until the mind becomes no-mind, whereupon the dharma will naturally cease. Only then is it like the autumn moon in a clear sky—undivided, with both nature and destiny fulfilled.

If one claims that the mind is already the Buddha yet fails to recognize that it is neither mind nor Buddha, misinterpreting the verse *"Since all is already the mind, why rely on the words of others?"* as a command to rely solely on oneself, has one not strayed from the true gate? Thus, the text begins: *"This verse is how Master Xuanzang awakened to the* Heart Sutra *and opened the gate."* If the mind were truly the Dao, and the Dao required nothing more, why speak of merely *"opening the gate"*? Why would he still journey westward to seek the true scriptures? Are the true scriptures of the Western Heaven not the teachings of others? This reasoning is clear and awakening!

The *Cantong Qi* says: *"Qian and Kun are the gates of the* Yi."* Wukong and Wuneng are the gates of the *Yi*, and thus the gates of the *Heart Sutra*. To attain Wukong and Wuneng is to open the gate. Only then can one proceed with cultivation and enter the inner sanctum.

Earlier, Chan Master Crow’s Nest, fearing that Tripitaka did not recognize the gate of the *Heart Sutra*, pointed to the *"wild boar"* and the *"old stone monkey,"* prompting Monkey to speak. The Elder understood the meaning, and so he recited and contemplated it constantly. A single spark of numinous light shone through—clearly the realm of *"the setting sun conceals the fire mirror, the rising moon reveals the ice wheel."* The Great Dao lies ahead; one must press onward swiftly.

If one merely gropes within one’s own mind, mistaking the luminous and ever-aware consciousness for the true reality, unaware of the great road to the Western Heaven, one is like a ghost clinging to home—what is this but a *"home-clinging ghost"*? How can one transcend the mundane? Thus, the ancients mocked those who preserved their youth and dwelled in the world yet could not shed their shells and ascend, calling them *"corpse-clinging ghosts."* Their folly is much the same.

When Monkey says *"your family’s ghost,"* he scorns all those who cling to the mind in their practice. Tripitaka says: *"Wuneng, if your heart were still so heavy with attachment to home, you would not have left it. You should return."* Though these words seem to reproach the fool without remorse, was Monkey truly slandering the idiot? No—he was using the fool to illustrate how clinging to the mind in cultivation is like leaving home yet still longing for it.

Observe how the fool *"comes with a dead heart, resolutely"*—to come with a dead heart is still a method of the mind, yet to apply effort, one must have skill. But if one has only a dead heart without skill, every step will be thorny, and the path forward will be blocked. Thus, the old man shakes his head and waves his hand, saying: *"You cannot go to the Western Heaven; you cannot obtain the scriptures."* Yet when Monkey reveals his true abilities, the old man says: *"You must have some skill."* And again: *"With such skill, you may yet reach the West."* This is the wondrous truth of Laozi and Zhuangzi.

Thus, the old man is made the master. The subsequent passage—*"south of the village, two young men with an old woman, three or four children"*—is but a shadow, the esoteric essence of Laozi’s *Daode* and Zhuangzi’s *Nanhua*, a tale that startles the foolish and shocks the vulgar, yet is the great skill for reaching the West.

When Pig mentions *"back in Gao Village, I often terrified mortals,"* he exposes the truth of those who are startled by ghosts and spirits. When Monkey laughs and says, *"Don’t speak nonsense—tidy up that ugliness,"* he speaks of transforming the coarse into the wondrous.

Later, the offering of tea, the inquiry into lineage and age—all foreshadow the perils of Yellow Wind Ridge, implying that only one with great skill like Sun Wukong can proceed. The hungry ghost who eats half a bowl of rice yet remains half-full illustrates the vast distance to the West, showing that only one with an unshakable resolve like Zhu Bajie can bear the burden.

For the mind is not the Dao. If one insists that the mind is the Dao and seeks it solely within the mind, one binds the mind with the mind and blocks the path—like the tiger demon of Yellow Wind Ridge, who tricked Golden Cicada and bound him to the wind-stilling stake. Why? The wind is *xun* wood, yellow is the center, and when they obstruct the heart and chest like a towering ridge, the tiger demon’s stubborn delusion is like the mind’s endless fixation.

See how the tiger demon *"clutches his own chest, flays his skin, and stands by the roadside"*—every detail vividly depicts the character *"heart."*

Thus he roared: “We are none other than the vanguard of the Yellow Wind Great King’s forces!” For to cling to the mind as the Dao is to be deluded mid-journey, blocking the path ahead. *"Pig chased the demon into the jagged rocks and drew his twin blades of red copper."* The "jagged rocks" signify the stubborn, tangled impurity; "twin blades," the discordant duality; "red," the mind’s true hue; "blades," the mind’s unyielding endurance. Thus the tiger demon, as the mind’s obstinate grip, serves as the mountain’s path-blocking vanguard—what need for further explanation? Pig, wielding the resolve of a dead heart, becomes the trailblazer halfway up the mountain, striking first with a single crushing blow.

Observe how *"Sanzang panicked and recited the *Heart Sutra*,"* while the demon, equally flustered, deployed the *"golden cicada shedding its shell"* ruse—now transforming into a tiger, now flaying its skin—all revealing how this mind, refusing to die, twists and turns, becoming its own demon. The moment true mindfulness arises, it is the very instant the wind carries him away. It is not the tiger demon using the golden cicada to seize the golden cicada, but the golden cicada itself using the golden cicada to seize the golden cicada. *"Clasping the Tang Monk in both hands to present him to the Great King"* and *"binding him in the rear garden"*—all are acts of the Tang Monk’s own doing, self-offering, self-binding, his mind ensnared in poisonous harm, beyond liberation.

Pig and Monkey saw through the tiger’s skin as the cicada’s discarded shell, recognizing the trap. One stood guard, the other fought, pressing straight to the demon’s cave. Monkey exerted himself and vanquished the tiger demon; Pig seized the moment and crushed it with a single strike of his rake. This is to first eliminate the mind’s obstinacy, shattering the barriers of true emptiness. Only then can one uproot the demon’s roots and rescue the golden cicada’s wholeness. Such skill is like a harmonious couple, one leading, one responding, inner and outer aiding each other in principle—what household difficulty could remain? Thus the verse concludes: *"When the Dharma Master meets demons in distress, / Temperament in harmony subdues the chaotic fiends."*

This passage begins with *"Dharma"* and ends with *"Dharma Master,"* while the next chapter’s outline immediately follows with *"Dharma Protection,"* clearly illustrating the method of cultivating truth, its subtle foreshadowing and hidden threads like a gray snake in the grass—those with keen eyes will surely see through it.

**Chapter Twenty-One: Dharma Protection Establishes a Manor to Detain the Great Sage; Mount Sumeru’s Lingji Subdues the Wind Demon**

*Wu Yizi says:* This continues the preceding discourse. Having extinguished the self-aggrandizing gaze of the tiger, one must still sweep away the rat’s head with its many forks. For when the mind possesses *shishen* (discerning spirit) yet clings to self-reliance, it is dazzled by brightness and loses clarity, dispatching illumination yet failing to illuminate—its harm lies in discernment that does not discern. To recognize that *shishen* is not true is to realize that the non-spiritual in spirit is true. Hence it is said: *"To refine spirit, refine the non-spiritual spirit."*

Scholars who fail to grasp the intent of *"non-spiritual spirit"* may scrutinize minutiae and spawn demons, or plunge into deep doubt and multiply delusions. Some drift into heterodox paths, others waver between two possibilities—all are blind cultivation and reckless refinement, called *"wild blindness."* Han Yu said: *"One who cannot discern the grounds of gain and loss is called wild."* When spirit does not guard its abode, the illness lies in the heart, like a violent wind shaking without stability. Confucius said: *"To speak without observing another’s countenance is called blindness."* When heart-fire attacks the liver and assaults the eyes, it is like the Yellow Wind blowing and wounding the injured.

Thus, long-held stagnation breeds vermin, and accumulated delusion multiplies hardships—all stem from lack of clarity, leading to endless entanglement. This is why the *Rites* warn against *"hesitation"* and the *Book of Documents* values *"decisiveness."* To transform hesitation into decisiveness lies in nothing but clarity. Yet clarity still does not depart from *shishen*—it is the eye-opening medicine, most urgent and precise.

In this passage, the ophthalmologist serves as the great eye, while Lingji Bodhisattva is the one who, after applying the eye-opening medicine, reveals radiant illumination. Dispelling the fleeting glimpses of confusion and awakening the unobscured wondrous vision, one stabilizes the wild, erratic wind and severs the rat’s two-pronged hesitation. The rat’s nature is thievish and suspicious; it emerges from its burrow indecisively, always wavering between two ends. Thus the old demon is an ancient rat spirit from the foothills of Vulture Peak.

Observe how *"the old demon lowered his head in silence, pondering a scheme,"* and upon hearing the words, *"grew even more vexed, saying, ‘This fool knows nothing!’*”*

“I never ate his master—yet he struck down my vanguard in turn.” Such are the words of one without steadfast vision, who instead faults others. “The old demon scrutinized carefully and saw that the Traveler’s frame was coarse and stunted, not even four feet tall”—this was belittlement born of blindness. “The Traveler said, ‘You whelp, you’ve no eye for true measure!’”—this was mockery to his face. “With a single blow to the head, he grew six feet, then stood a full ten feet tall.” For the four great elements compose a body, which inherently possesses the true form of ten feet—never to be judged by outward appearance or superficial likeness.

“The Traveler revealed himself and devised a plan, but the old demon mistook the feint for substance. The two fought outside the cave, the Traveler employing the art of ‘a body beyond the body.’” Thus, with many defenses confounding the senses, the eyes grew dazzled and disordered, and so harm befell them. “The old demon unleashed his yellow wind technique—using madness to counter delusion—how could heaven and earth not darken? Thus his assault targeted the eyes.” This passage expounds that chaos cannot be quelled by further chaos; only clarity suffices to end disorder.

“Hairs shrank to tiny things, like wheels spinning in frenzy.” “Fire-eyes and golden pupils could not be opened.” “Pig could not dare lift his eyes or raise his head, unaware of victory or defeat, life or death, lost in doubt and hesitation”—all depict the state of wild delusion without anchor, the moment when wondrous illumination is lost. From lack of illumination arises wild delusion; from wild delusion, the mind loses its illumination. To cure wild delusion, one must first restore illumination. Thus the Traveler said, “Saving Master can wait. I don’t know if there’s an eye-doctor around—let him treat my eyes first.”

“The two paused to look and saw a farmstead, its lamplight flickering dimly.” Already, within obscurity, a sliver of light had been borrowed. “The brothers sought lodging, paid respects to the old farmer, and sat with him. The Traveler asked, ‘Does anyone here sell eye medicine?’” “The elder said, ‘That’s called the *Samādhi Divine Wind*—if it blows on you, you might still live!’” Then he added, “I once met an extraordinary man who transmitted a formula called *Three Flowers, Nine Seeds Ointment*.” This is the wondrous method of *Three Flowers Gathering at the Crown* and *Ninefold Cyclic Elixir*.

Pig laughed, “Sir, where’s your bright staff?” The Traveler replied, “You’re treating me like a blind man.” “Pig chuckled silently, the Traveler snickered softly”—both were veiled mockery, implying that those who blindly cultivate in ignorance have never encountered a true eye-doctor. Zhuangzi said, “Healing the eyes can forestall aging.” So it is.

In the eye-medicine passage, “the guardian” is none other than *shishen*. The entire farmstead was arranged for the eye-medicine application, a provision to retain the Great Sage—indeed, the universal eye-medicine for all beings. Is the “farmstead” (*zhuang*) here any different from Zhuangzi’s “farmstead”?

“The Traveler suddenly awoke; Pig guessed idly”—do not dismiss these as mere jest. They reveal the folly of those without steadfast vision and the ignorance of vulgar eyes. The verse says, “Wondrous medicine cures eye pain; vanquish demons without hesitation.” Clear and decisive, this is the moment when illumination may be attained. Thus, in the following passage, the name of Lingji Bodhisattva appears, and the Golden Star points the way.

Pig said, “You secretly protected Master but could not manifest openly, so you transformed this immortal farmstead.” This shows that the eye-medicine was secretly transmitted by the old farmer—a profound truth not to be openly displayed. The Traveler said, “Let me go to the cave and scout around.” Pig replied, “Find out whether he’s dead or alive. If he’s dead… if he’s not dead…”—all indecisive, wavering words, lacking illumination.

“The Traveler reached the cave entrance, but it was still barred, the demons asleep.” “He transformed into a mosquito and entered; the lesser demons snored on.” All was murky confusion, a realm of dreamlike unawareness. The old demon said, “Guard the door carefully. I fear that gust of wind didn’t kill Sun Wukong.” Such was his fearful hesitation. Then, seeing “a tightly sealed inner door, he slipped inside”—already entering its *samādhi*.

He saw “Master Tang bound to the Wind-Stilling Stake”—a state of constraint and bondage, from which there was no self-liberation. The Master “could only fix his heart on Wukong and Wuneng,” showing how the mind cannot govern itself but seeks external aid. Reciting the *Heart Sutra* alone—what use was that? A lesser demon reported, “I saw a big-eared one, but not the one from yesterday.” Such was the smallness of his perception.

The old demon said, “Sun Wukong is nowhere to be seen—he must have been blown to death by the wind, or else fled to seek reinforcements elsewhere.” Such was the delusion of his perception. The lesser demons replied, “If he’s been blown to death, it would be our good fortune. But what if he wasn’t killed—what then?” Such was the timidity of their words. All was wild conjecture and idle talk, hesitant and wavering, torn between two fears.

Suddenly, the old demon confessed, “Only the Bodhisattva Lingji could still my wind’s power.” This was the hollow admission of a guilty mind, the *shen* revealing itself unbidden—a confession made without torture. As for the Star of Metal, that luminous and merciful constellation, “pointing south with his hand,” “transforming into a gentle breeze and vanishing,” with “Pig Eight Precepts bowing in gratitude”—such was the guidance of a benevolent master, akin to father and mother, for whom one vows to attain the Dao and repay the great debt.

Wukong ascended Mount Sumeru and peered within, seeing only “a hall adorned in brocade splendor, a chamber of solemn dignity. Golden flames and jade mist, wisdom’s sword and virtue’s assembly”—all describing Lingji’s boundless *dharma*-power, a marvel beyond words. The Wind-Stilling Pellet was perfectly round and true, the Flying Dragon Staff swift and wondrous in its divine efficacy. “Revealing his true form, he was but a yellow weasel—having stolen oil from a lamp, dimming its flame, he fled here and became a spirit.” This was the unvarnished truth of his blindness laid bare.

“Seized and brought to Vulture Peak to see the Tathāgata”—precisely the exercise of great *dharma*-power, shattering the web of doubt, attaining the radiant form, and once more beholding the Tathāgata. “The two of them slaughtered a den of cunning hares, fox-spirits, musk deer, and horned stags”—what cunning, what suspicion, what deer-like panic, what branching confusion remained? This was “summoning Lingji to rescue the true monk and rediscover the great western road.”

**Chapter Twenty-Two: Pig Battles the Flowing-Sands River; Mokṣa Enforces the Dharma to Subdue Wujing**

Wu Yizi says: “The Perfected One of Purple Yang said:
*Tiger leaps, dragon coils—wind and waves rage rough,
At the central true position, the Mystic Pearl is wrought.
Though fruit on branches ripens in due season’s span,
How could a child in the womb bear any pearl?*
This is the true purport of this chapter.”

The wondrous convergence of the Five Phases lies wholly in the two earths, wù and jǐ. Earth is the center of the Five Phases, presiding over the four seasons, each for eighteen days. Dispersed, it permeates the four times to engender and transform the myriad things; united in its twofold governance, it unifies the Nine Palaces and wondrously gathers the One Origin. Thus metal and water, meeting earth, congeal and gather; wood and fire, meeting earth, harmonize and blend. Wù is yang earth, jǐ is yin earth—metal, water, wood, and fire each possess their wù-jǐ position at the Central Palace, where the Five Phases converge and revert to the Supreme Polarity. The Supreme Polarity is but a forced designation. Though earth is one of the Five Phases, it is in truth their culmination. In the human body, it is the true; the true of intent is sincerity. With sincerity, movement and stillness are both true, and nature and feelings attain the mean—hence the noble person must make his intent sincere.

Sha Monk is true earth. The meanings of “flowing sands,” “weak waters,” “skulls,” and “rolled-up curtain” are all revealed in the eighth chapter. This chapter particularly clarifies that metal, water, wood, and fire cannot depart from earth; obtaining this earth, they assume their proper position at the Central Palace, whereupon the functions of the golden elixir are complete and the sagely embryo is formed.

The earlier gāthā of the Bird’s-Nest Chan Master says:
*“The wild boar shoulders his load and goes,”*
*“The ancient stone monkey of many years,”*
*“The water-monster met along the way.”*
“Met” is *gòu*, signifying the wondrousness of their encounter—thus they mutually rely on the great western road. Hence it first says: *“Having crossed Yellow Wind Ridge, one enters a stretch of level ground to the west.”* Yet why should great waters suddenly block the path, so difficult to ford? Not that it is truly hard to cross—precisely in the difficulty of crossing does one encounter and thereby attain passage, which is the great western road.

Yellow is the true color of the center, so from Yellow Wind Ridge the essentials of the Five Phases are drawn forth. In eight lines of verse, the embodiment of all five colors and the fullness of the Nine Palaces are depicted—each word is worthy of contemplation. When Bajie battles the monster, wood meets earth and they mutually overcome. The monster’s own account reveals the wondrousness of the three and five each as a five, within which it says: *“First I gathered the infant boy and the maiden girl, then I took up the wood-mother and metal-father as my staff.”* This is the true import. The two of them fought twice, yet through impatience could not subdue him—why?

When hearts and minds remain unaligned, there is need for patient mediation—this cannot be forced through coercion or haste. Thus when Wukong seeks stillness through impatience, his impatience only grows; when the water monster retreats to provoke action, his movement only makes stillness harder to attain. Hence Bajie’s plea for “ten thousand strategies,” and the Monkey King’s counsel to the master: *“Do not fret,”* followed by *“go beg alms and rest,”* showing that progress in cultivation should be gradual, not rushed. The remark on *“how hard it is to carry clouds”* reveals that ordinary beings can advance step by step but not all at once. The admonition that *“no methods should be applied, only thorough experience in foreign lands”* shows that dull natures value effort over ease. The observation that *“though they could protect, they could not go ahead to fetch the scriptures”* demonstrates that spiritual practice proceeds from difficulty, not ease.

When Bajie enters the water to challenge the monster, the origin of the treasure staff is recounted—phrases like *“length lies in the mind, thickness follows intent”* clearly reveal the operation of true intention and the mind’s radiant wisdom. *“This bout fought underwater then surfaced”* echoes the *Cantong Qi*’s *“where speech fails, they are no kin.”* The verse has already made this plain. For yin and yang to unite, true earth must mediate—just as a matchmaker is needed for a marriage. Where speech fails, hearts remain estranged, and harmony eludes. The line *“only because the wood-mother overcomes the elixir knife”* explicitly identifies Wuneng as wood and Wujing as earth.

*“The monster only clamors by the riverbank, refusing to come ashore”* depicts a nature still in flux, poised between two possibilities—most elusive to grasp. Once impatience takes hold, the creature vanishes without a trace, leaving no opening for action. Thus when Wukong’s temper flares and he leaps into a somersault, the monster conceals himself completely, nowhere to be seen. Only by turning inward in quiet reflection and summoning Guanyin Bodhisattva can the original face be revealed. Wukong then hastens to the Southern Sea to pay homage. The Bodhisattva says: *“You ape, ever relying on your own strength, unwilling to speak of protecting the Tang monk. Had you mentioned ‘the scripture-seeker,’ he would have submitted at once.”* For the protection of the scripture-seeker is the shared purpose of the three. To speak of *“the scripture-seeker”* is to establish common speech, align hearts, and dissolve suspicion through mutual sincerity.

The Bodhisattva calls Huian to fetch the red gourd, bids Wujing take refuge, and arranges the nine skulls in the pattern of the Nine Palaces, placing the gourd at the center—forming a dharma-boat. Excellent indeed! The Great Being’s compassionate vessel ferries the world, revealing the system of the golden elixir.

One who can harness and steer it finds their drifting nature settled, the tranquil waves passable, and thus avoids sinking to instead reach the far shore—all fundamentally rooted in this. The *"gourd"* symbolizes the two earths forming the jade tablet. *"At the center"* they wondrously merge and congeal. The *"arrangement of the Nine Palaces"* is all for my use; here, one establishes life and destiny—what peril or obstruction could remain?

A poem says:
*The Five Agents pair to match celestial truth,
Recognizing the old master from of old.
Refining the self and establishing the foundation—subtle use,
Discerning right and wrong to see the cause.
Metal returns to nature, reuniting with its kind,
Wood departs to seek affinity, yet remains of equal rank.
The two tablets complete the work in stillness,
Harmonizing water and fire without a trace of dust.*

For yin and yang must pair to match celestial truth. The old master was lost, but now may be recognized—this is the subtle use of establishing the foundation, the cause of dispelling the deviant and preserving the upright. Metal departs yet returns, restoring its original nature; self and other were ever of the same kind, metal and wood not of different ranks. Thus, the two tablets complete the work, forming the sacred embryo. From this stillness, nurturing and harmonizing, what trace of water or fire’s dust remains?

This single dharma-boat of the Great Being is like the dragon maiden’s single pearl—it is the original essence of human life. Thus, the Curtain-Lifting General is the true earth of true yin and true yang, the Yellow Dame of marital union, the essential subtlety of forming the embryo and establishing the foundation.

Mujaku then calls forth Wujing, who sincerely submits. The skulls are removed, the Nine Palaces arranged, the gourd placed at the center, and the master invited to sit upon it. Lightly and steadily they cross, waves calm and winds still; in no time, they reach the far shore. Truly, this is the great function of establishing life and destiny, of planting the feet firmly on solid ground.

Yet why is it also called *"pure and non-action"*? For though there is action, it does not adhere—like the Bodhisattva sending Mujaku to demonstrate the dharma without going herself. The operation lies with Wukong and Wuneng, the boat is formed by Wujing, while the Tang monk enjoys non-action. Though there is action, it is in truth non-action.

When Mujaku retrieves the gourd, it transforms into yin qi, the two earths become true, and the Nine Palaces merge completely. From this, the foundation is set, the golden elixir takes form, and the Way of non-action gradually manifests.

Ah! The method of the golden elixir’s function is clearly revealed here!

In Chapter Twenty-Three: "The Tang Monk Remembers His Origin; The Four Sages Test Meditative Resolve"

Wu Yizi says:
The Five Phases converge and cluster, forming the sacred embryo.
The original root is already attained, and life and destiny have their foundation.
From this point, one preserves and nurtures it, gradually shedding the embryo to approach spiritual transformation—thus may celestial immortality be realized.

Yet I fear that worldly people may misconstrue the wondrous Dao of convergence and clustering as the heterodox teaching of "absorbing yin to supplement yang," becoming infatuated at the sight of beauty, sinking into the sea of desire, forgetting their origin and drowning in mere words—how truly pitiable! Therefore, this passage urgently highlights how easily one may be deluded by feminine allure, and how crucial it is to maintain steadfast vigilance, never forgetting one’s original face.

Thus it is said: "This chapter of the tale reveals that the Way of seeking the scriptures does not depart from the Way of attending to the root within one’s own body." Ah! The immortal master’s words are most subtle—"attending to the root" runs through the entire work. Should one glance superficially, the profound principle would be buried and lost.

This "root" does not refer to what lies near or within, but rather to that which, in the opening chapter, precedes heaven and earth as the primordial spiritual root, and which, after the Five Villas’ episode, permeates the later heaven and earth, yet remains the primordial spiritual root. Every person possesses it in full, lacking nothing. Those who have lost it must attend to it to return; returning is but the restoration of what was originally present within. Those who have not lost it must attend to it to avoid forgetting; forgetting means forgetting what was never originally present within. Those who have lost and then regained it must attend to it to preserve it; preservation means securing what was originally present within, letting go of what was not, and fortunately returning to what was.

Hence it is said: "The Way of seeking the scriptures does not depart from the Way within one’s own body." In the verse, "the wayward monkey firmly bound" and "the inferior horse diligently reined" are acts of discipline upon the ground of inherent nature; "Wood Mother and Metal Duke" and "Yellow Dame with Crimson Child" are functions upon the root of life. Once the true message is recognized, this is the great wisdom. With a heavy burden and a long road ahead, all depends on diligent effort.

Should the slightest thought of slackness arise, it is a sign of failing to bear the burden fully—idleness and desire will then gradually sprout. If there is any impulse toward hasty progress, it is a sign of reckless haste and overstepping, inevitably leading to unruliness that cannot be reined in. Pigsy, resenting the weight of his load and urging the horse to speed, thus sows the seeds of trouble. This is like the Monkey King wielding his staff to tame the wayward ape, or spurring the inferior horse to gallop—both acts of discipline.

The episode "Testing the Chan Mind" is overt in its meaning, yet its subtlety lies beyond the words. For while testing the mind is the manifest intent, the alchemical method is still concealed within. Why? To test the mind is merely to test it—one or two beauties would suffice to captivate the soul; why wait for four? Yet the Dao is called the interplay of one yin and one yang. The master and his three disciples naturally form a fourfold harmony, the true number of yin and yang in balance, where none can be lacking. Only when one sees beauty as no beauty and faces temptation without attachment does one attain the unyielding, indestructible body. Scholars may find it easy to sever ties with the world and renounce all things, but when the body itself is subjected to restraint and confronted with temptation, the mind often shifts and resolve is lost.

To achieve true mastery, one must pass through the crucible of tribulation; to recognize pure gold in its full luster, it must be forged in searing flames. The trial by the Four Saints is like testing gold with a touchstone: when gold meets the touchstone, its true grade is revealed; when one encounters the trial of the Four Saints, the sacred and the profane are fully exposed. Nothing in the world stirs the heart more easily than beauty; if one remains unmoved by it, nothing can move the heart at all. This is why the transformed maiden tests them—like refining with fire, only true gold remains unaltered.

In the alchemical method, the female seeks the male, as in a marriage where the groom is brought into the bride’s home. This is no ordinary union, so the Four Saints take the form of women awaiting childbirth to summon a husband, with Pigsy as the groom and Friar Sand as the matchmaker. Yet the Four Saints are nothing other than the true qi of the One. From the One they become four, and from these four arise countless transformations—just as the Great Sage’s true gold can manifest boundless change. Only the Great Sage perceives this and recognizes the subtle work of enlightenment. The hidden meaning of the text is thus made clear.
