「The myriad things have no fixed essence, yet their principles align in harmony.
The refinement of *two* is not as precise as that of *one*,
the ornate is not as concise as the plain,
the noble is not as secure as the humble.

The new will inevitably lean toward obscurity,
while the enduring cannot safeguard its transformations.

The eyes cannot be trusted,
wisdom cannot peer into the unseen,
and calculations cannot bind the true.

The remembrance of past reversals brings manifold omissions and illuminations,
while stillness in waiting reveals no form can escape observation.

Divine clarity and insight reside within the person—
thus, the Dao of supreme sincerity
is true knowing and genuine seeing,
not reliant on conjecture,
yet capable of foresight.

Why does the *lùlù* [鹿鹿] act thus?
Its strength is deficient, yet this is its inherent nature.

And what of guessing the *immortal peach*?
Why does it become a pit?

For limbs are easily stripped away,
while great fruits are never eaten—
falling like bubbles, only *virtue* endures.

Those who glimpse with skill
hold a complete bamboo in their chest;
those who strike with precision
see no whole ox in their gaze.

The adept do not cling to mere traces,
perceiving the boundless *generative transformations* within;
the shallow only observe the surface,
missing the wondrous *mutual transformations* beyond.

Divine luminosity moves in silence,
changing yet ever in flux—
coming and going without fixed form,
even spirits and deities cannot fathom it.
Hence, the sage values mastery of the *Yì* [《易》].

Why does the *divine ram* [神羊] have intelligence?
Its strength is deficient—
is this not fitting?

And what of guessing the *Daoist soil* [道土],
only to see it turn into a *monk* [和尚]?
Marvelous, this transformation!
The mortal is effaced in the *void*,
while the immortal and the Buddha merge as one.

The *Old Monkey* [老孙] becomes a *Daoist adept*,
and the *Buddhist teacher* [佛师] is the *Daoist master* [道师];
the *Daoist novice* [道童] turns into a *Buddhist disciple*,
for *Daoists* are originally *Buddhist followers* [佛徒].

*"Shaving the head bare"*—
what law ever had hair?
The *law beyond law* surpasses all laws;
*"donning the yellow robe"*—
emptiness far outweighs mere hue,
the *true color* of color reaches its ultimate.

The wooden fish is struck—
within, the *Yellow Court* [《黄庭》] is secretly chanted;
the voice *"Āmítuó"* [阿弥陀] is uttered—
splitting the spine to emerge from the world.

*"Bursting forth in unison, all chanting in harmony"*
is the moment of celestial blossoms descending.

*"The Dao that can be spoken is not the eternal Dao;
The name that can be named is not the eternal Name."*」

"Those who cling to names and fixed forms,
with eyes like a tiger’s, glaring and menacing—
how vulgar they are!

The tiger’s strength is but a feeble show,
for it is its own delusion that blinds it.

The Three Powers* [三力] fail to reflect upon their learning,
instead wallowing in side paths;
hard to deceive by the true *dharma* [正法],
yet they conjure many illusory arts,
foolishly hoping to achieve their ends.

The *practitioners* [行者] of such ways
then use their very own techniques
to slay themselves—
what purpose could they have?

In ancient times, there were those who fought
and lost their heads yet still spoke,
‘*Even without a head, it is fine*’ [无头亦佳],
who joyfully endured flaying of flesh and heart,
or plunged into boiling caldrons like honeyed rice,
all forged through the tempering of their original *true nature* [本真性],
treating the body as illusion,
not letting illusion ensnare the body.

*Qi* [教气] may gather or disperse,
*principle* [理] transcends gathering and dispersing;
grasp the *principle*, and vast *qi* [浩气] abides with it.

The form may die or live,
*nature* [性] knows no death nor life;
know the *nature*, and the spirit remains unobscured.

A ruler may be without *virtue* [圣] or without *non-virtue* [不圣],
yet loyalty must never waver;
a father may be without kindness or without unkindness,
yet filial devotion must never falter.

There are those with the spirit to master blades and fire,
yet blades and fire do not bend nor oppress them—
as if blades and fire were but illusions.

This is like the *practitioner*’s *Great Unity Golden Essence* [太乙金精],
which has been refined through the *Eight Trigrams Furnace* [八卦炉],
a single moment of *true nature* [真性] manifesting in this way.

Thus, those who cultivate their *true nature*
face great calamities or critical junctures,
like *Bo Qi* [伯奇] and *Xiao Si* [孝巳],
*Bo Yi* [伯邑考] and *Shen Sheng* [申生],
who died for filial *virtue* [孝];
*Guan Longfeng* [关龙逢] and *Wen Tianxiang* [文天祥],
whose bodies were separated yet spirits unbroken,
akin to those who joyfully endure heart-splitting;
*Sun Jue* [孙揆] severed by the saw,
and *Fang Xiaoru* [方孝孺], *Tie Xuan* [铁铉],
*Jing Qing* [景清], *Huang Zicheng* [黄子澄],
*Lian Zining* [练子宁], who died in pieces for loyalty—
all were wise and preserved their bodies,
yet perfected their *true nature* [真了命],
unharmed in any way.

But those like *Kong Guang* [孔光],
*Hu Du* [胡度], *Su Weidao* [苏味道],
*Chu Yuan* [褚渊], and *Feng Dao* [冯道],
who fled calamities to save their lives,
though they lived long—
had already lost their *true nature*,
and thus marred their limbs in vain.

The *practitioners*’ entire *true nature* [本真性之全体]
is not an illusion;
it merely manifests through the body and sets forth *dharma*,
to distinguish the true from the false.

Thus the summary states:
‘*Manifest the sacred, extinguish the demonic*’ [显圣灭邪].

The head may be cut off,
but the *true nature*’s head cannot be severed—
‘*still grows anew*’ [长出一个],
yet chopping does not truly chop.

The belly may be split open,
but the *true nature*’s belly cannot be rent—
‘*remains whole as before*’ [依然长合],
yet splitting does not truly split.

The oil calamity cannot be endured,
yet the *true nature* may be immersed—
‘*playing in waves, defying the flames*’ [翻波顽耍],
for the oil calamity cannot harm the *true nature*.

The marvel lies in the passage:
‘*The practitioner feigns death within the oil pot*’ [油锅内行者假死],
a reminder to the world:
know only the *true nature*’s operation—
piercing metal, passing through stone,
entering water yet not drowning,
plunging into fire yet not burning;
weapons cannot harm the body,
tigers and rhinos cannot wound the form;
emerging alive, vanishing unharmed—
life and death in perfect accord,
not bound by knowledge of life and death,
nor by thoughts of gain or loss.

chunks.original_text: 一落死生知识心意，便带尘缘性念，不能到此地位。 三藏祭文道：“生前只为求经意，死后还存念佛心。 ”是着死生知识心意而论，失其真矣。 故八戒道：“师父，不是这祷祝。 ”曰“无知的弼马温”，不落知识也； 曰“该死的泼猴头”，不拘死生也。 曰“猴头了帐”，何心之有？ 曰“马温断根”，何意之有！ “行者忍不住，现了本相”，分明形容出一团真性来也。 盖性无死生，死了显魂之说，非系真谛。 行者闻言，掣摔打杀，道：“我显甚么魂！ ”言性为生前之灵，而非死后之显魂也。 学道者早向生前修炼真性而可矣。 三力不知真性，误踹傍门。 生前习茅山开剥之幻术，炼身外冷龙之左道，唤雨呼风，点金炼汞，妄希长生保国，昧本逐末，自欺欺人。 知伪学可以詟愚，不知伪久则败； 知勾法可以警俗，不知勾久必亡。 故虎头不免于犬口，鹿脏竟喂诸鹰肠，羊骨终糜烂于釜爨，而冷龙莫之救，此国王所由放声大哭道“不遇真传莫炼丹”，“徒用心机命不安”。 又曰：“点金炼汞成何济，唤雨呼风总是空。 ”何其深切着明哉！ 第四十七回　圣僧夜阻通天河　金木垂慈救小童 悟一子曰：车迟国王误信河车之力，几致丧命。 赖行者打碎车辆，早除妖道，救全真性，保固山河。 一经省悟，便属智渊，方知禅门有道，不可偏心也。 “也敬僧，也敬道，也养育人才”，真是三教同归一性，广大智慧之正法门也。 性者，天也。 知性知，原是一贯。 固通天之实学也。 仙师虑世人知性为性，而不知性为人找一体，有偏全纯驳之辨，乃执一已而修，鄙滞不通，如夜行失路，阻截难前，故此特着通天河三篇精义，设大士竹篮收鱼之妙相，以指引万世迷津，即佛祖教外别传之正法眼，太上得一还元之秘密旨。 学者能知此一事，则性体归元，金丹之道备矣。 但通天之路，坦荡无陂，不能行者少，即能知者亦少，故不得不标榜立石，傍注十字，曰：“径过八百里，亘古少人行。 ”然此道人人咸具，家家自有。 唐僧道：“今宵何处安身？ ”行者道：“到人家之所再住。 ”篇中曰“做斋的人家。 ”曰“望见一簇人家住处。 ”曰“有四五百家。 ”曰“径来人家门首。 ”下文逐节点醒“人家”二字为眼，自将陈家庄作骨，寓笔之妙，不即不离，如灰蛇草线，令人寻绎难穷。 读至后回结穴处，方见其神。 所谓“此般至宝家家有，目是愚人识不全”是也。

The moment one clings to knowledge of life and death, heart and intention,
one carries along the defilements of dust and fate—
unable to reach this state.

San Zang’s funeral prayer reads:
*“In life, I sought only the Dharma’s intent;
in death, I still cherish the Buddha’s mind.”*
This clings to knowledge of life and death, heart and intention—
losing the true Way.

Thus, the Eight Precepts say:
*“Master, this is not the right invocation.”*
*“The ignorant Primal Horse Attendant”*—
not bound by knowledge;
*“The damned Monkey King”*—
not constrained by life and death.

*“The Monkey King settled the account”*—
what heart remains?
*“The Horse Attendant severed the root”*—
what intention lingers?
*“The Practitioner could not endure—
revealing his true form”*—
clearly depicting a mass of true nature.

For nature knows no life and death—
the claim that death reveals the spirit
is not the ultimate truth.

Hearing this, the Practitioner lunged, struck, and shouted:
*“What spirit do I reveal?”*
Speaking of nature as the vitality of life,
not the spirit displayed after death.

Those who study the Dao should cultivate the true nature
while yet alive—
that is sufficient.

San Zang knew not the true nature,
erring toward false paths.
In life, he practiced the illusory arts of Mao Shan—
flaying the body, forging external cold dragons,
summoning rain, calling wind,
turning gold, refining mercury,
vainly hoping for longevity and national salvation,
pursuing the superficial while neglecting the root—
self-deceived and deceiving others.

He knew that false learning could fool the ignorant,
but did not know that falsehood, prolonged, leads to ruin.
He knew that snares could warn the vulgar,
but did not know that snares, prolonged, bring destruction.

Thus, the Tiger’s head did not escape the dog’s jaws,
the deer’s entrails fed the eagles’ bellies,
the sheep’s bones boiled to ruin in the pot—
the cold dragon could not save them.
This is why the King wailed:
*“Without the true transmission, do not forge the elixir—
your scheming mind brings no security.”*
And again:
*“What good are gold-turning and mercury refining?
Summoning rain and calling wind—all in vain.”*
How profoundly he saw the truth!

**Chapter Forty-Seventh**
*The Holy Monk Blocks the Heavenly River*
*The Golden Wood Extends Mercy to Save the Child*

Yu Yi Zi said:
The King of Car Wheel mistakenly trusted the power of the Heavenly Chariot,
nearly losing his life.
Thanks to the Practitioner shattering the vehicle,
the demonic Daoist was swiftly removed,
the true nature preserved,
and the land secured.
Once enlightened, he became a wise sage,
knowing that the Zen gate holds the Dao—
one must not be partial.

*“Honor the monk, honor the Daoist,
nurture talent”*—
truly, the Three Teachings converge in one nature,
the boundless wisdom of the true path.

Nature is Heaven.
Knowing nature is knowing—
originally, it is one and unbroken.
It is the genuine study of Heavenly Communication.

The Immortal Master feared that people would know *nature as nature*,
yet fail to know *nature as the very essence of being*—
distinguishing between partial and complete, pure and mixed,
grasping one aspect while neglecting the whole,
stagnant and unenlightened,
like one lost in darkness, blocked from progress.
Thus, he specially inscribed the three essentials of the Heavenly River,
depicting the Great Sage’s bamboo basket catching fish—
a marvelous metaphor to guide all ages through the mist,
the true Dharma-eye beyond scripture,
the secret essence of *Oneness Restoring to the Primordial*.

If scholars grasp this truth,
the nature-body returns to its source,
and the Golden Elixir’s path is complete.

Yet the Heavenly Communication path is vast and unobstructed—
few can walk it, though all possess it inherently.
San Zang asked:
*“Where shall we lodge tonight?”*
The Practitioner replied:
*“At the home of a man.”*
The text says:
*“A household offering alms.”*
*“A cluster of homes appeared.”*
*“Four or five hundred households.”*
*“Straight to the door of a home.”*
Later, each phrase subtly awakens the eye to *“home”*—
using the Chen Family Village as the skeleton,
hinting with brushstrokes that are neither direct nor detached,
like ash-snake grass-thread,
making readers trace and ponder endlessly.
Only at the closing of later chapters does its genius reveal itself—
as in *“This supreme treasure every home possesses,
yet fools fail to recognize it fully.”*

chunks.original_text: 三藏向老者借宿，老者道：“东土到我这里，有五万四千里路，你这等单身，如何来得？ ”三藏道：“我还有三个徒弟，保护贫僧，方得到此。 ”盖通天适当十万八千之中，乃修道者至中不偏之路，不容稍有移易差殊，非执己孤修者所能至。 世人说到这里，无不骇疑惊怪，莫肯承当。 故三藏叫：“徒弟，这里来。 ”而老者看见，唬得跌倒在地，说怪说丑所由来也。 岂知其中实有降龙伏虎之能，非可以信不信。 迨师徒斋罢，二老欠身道：“你等取经，怎么不走正路，却跄回到我这里来？ ”行者道：“走的是正路，只见一股水挡住，不能得渡。 ”一问一答，均明通天河为修道正路，到陈家庄，乃见得渡通天河之要道。 迹非正路，而实正路也。 说出“灵感大王”。 “灵”为生育之灵，“感”为云雨之感，虽甘雨庆云，足以长养万物； 而恣情纵欲，还能斫伤真元。 恩中带杀，慈里伤人，每每消耗真阴真阳，就如好吃童男童女一般。 此喻言其隐微，岂真吃童男童女哉！ 故曰：“只因好吃童男女，不是昭彰正直神。 ”乃是潜通造化，混一阴阳之至精，而未可以形迹浅窥。 老者道：“我们这里属车迟国元会县所管，唤做陈家庄。 ”“元”为真元，“会”为运会，有转轮不息之机，本家家具足之物。 可知陈玄奘住在陈家庄，家庄即有玄奘，玄奘不出家庄，同宗一气，非有二姓，非可求之玄渺而失之家内也。 “一秤金”，名虽童女，止八岁，实二八之真阳； “陈关保”，名虽童男，止七岁，实两七之真阴。 “轮次祭赛”，分明令人各家示宝； “预修亡斋”，乃是叫人早修善死，“一秤”者，气味和平之准则； “关保”者，关睢天保之始终。 此般至宝，纵弃破家财，万两黄金何处买？ “极为灵感，知大小美恶，生时年月，莫那移。 ”噫！ 妙哉！

When the Master of the Three Treasures (San Zang) sought lodging from the old man,
the old man said:
*“From the Eastern Land to my place,
there are fifty-four thousand *li* of road—
how could you, alone and solitary,
traverse such a distance?”*

The Master of the Three Treasures replied:
*“I still have three disciples,
who protect this poor monk,
and thus I have arrived here.”*

Indeed, the Heavenly Communication (Tong Tian) path lies at the center of the ten-eight thousand (ten thousand eight thousand) *li*,
a Daoist path of perfect balance,
admitting no deviation or slightest error—
one who clings rigidly to solitary practice alone
could never reach it.

At this point, all hearers are astonished and perplexed,
none daring to accept its truth.

Thus, the Master of the Three Treasures called out:
*“Disciples, come here!”*
The old man, seeing them, was so terrified he collapsed to the ground—
the source of his cries of alarm and revulsion.

Yet who could know that within them lay the power to subdue dragons and tame tigers?
It is not a matter of belief or disbelief.

When the Master and his disciples finished their alms-keeping (zhai),
the old man bowed and said:
*“You seek the Sutras (taking dharma) —
why not walk the proper Dao?
Instead, you’ve stumbled back here?”*

The Practitioner replied:
*“We walked the proper Dao,
but a current of water blocked our way,
and we could not cross.”*

Each question and answer
clearly reveals that the Heavenly Communication River (Tong Tian He)
is the very path of Daoist cultivation,
and arriving at Chen Family Village (Chen Jia Zhuang)
marks the discovery of the essential means to cross it.

Though it seems not the proper path,
in truth, it is the proper path.

He then spoke of *“Lord of the Mystic Response”* (Ling Gan Da Wang).
*“Ling”* refers to the vital force of generation,
*“Gan”* to the interplay of clouds and rains—
though sweet dew and auspicious clouds
are sufficient to nourish all things,
yet unrestrained indulgence
can still harm the true vital essence (zhenyuan).

Within grace lies destruction,
beneath kindness lies injury—
ever consuming true yin and true yang,
like one who devours young boys and girls.

This metaphor speaks to its hidden subtleties—
not that he truly consumes young boys and girls!

Hence it is said:
*“Only because you love to devour young boys and girls,
are you not the radiant and upright deity.”*
Rather, it is the profound essence of transformation,
the merging of yin and yang at their utmost refinement,
which cannot be superficially discerned by mere appearances.

The old man said:
*“Our place belongs to the jurisdiction of the County of Original Assembly (Yuan Hui Xian),
within the realm of the Carriage-Delay Country (Che Chi Guo),
and is called Chen Family Village.”*
*“Yuan”* means true vital essence (真元),
*“Hui”* means the cyclical convergence of fate (运会) —
a ceaseless turning wheel,
a substance inherent in every home.

Thus, it is known that Chen Xuanzang dwells in Chen Family Village,
and Chen Family Village contains Xuanzang—
Xuanzang does not depart from Chen Family Village,
for they share the same vital breath (tizong yiqi),
not two distinct lineages,
nor something sought beyond the home
while lost within it.

*“One *Catty* of Gold”* (Yi Chèng Jīn) —
though its name is *young girl*,
she is but eight years old,
yet holds the true yang of sixteen *catty*;
*“Chen’s Gatekeeper”* (Chen Guan Bǎo) —
though its name is *young boy*,
he is but seven years old,
yet embodies the true yin of fourteen *catty*.

*“The rotating rites of sacrifice”* (Lúncì Jìsài) —
plainly, it instructs each household to display its treasures;
*“Preparing alms for the departed”* (Yù Xiū Wáng Zhāi) —
a call to cultivate the art of a virtuous death (shan si) early.

*“One *Catty* of Gold”* is the standard of balanced qi and flavor;
*“Gatekeeper”* is the beginning and end of the *Gate of the Phoenix* (Guan) and the *Heavenly Protector* (Chi).

This supreme treasure,
even if abandoned for broken wealth,
where could one purchase ten thousand *liang* of gold?

*“Mysterious and responsive in essence,
knowing greatness and smallness, beauty and ugliness,
the years and months of life—
nothing can alter it.”*

Ah! Marvelous indeed!

chunks.original_text: 关保是行者化身，行者变关保，何曾有二？ 一化二，奇变偶，请认识阴里阳精是水金。 秤金是八戒变体，八戒变秤金，真个就像一是八，阳生阴，须认得阳里阴精是木火。 两般至宝像丹头，原要两个丹盘。 金木交欢去耍子，不过为金鱼—味。 先吃男，后吃女，喻两段工夫，不着于形质，何有伤损？ 金丹始终真妙法，说不出玄之又玄。 刚道得“造化”，发其机，打开门，抬男女，已和盘托出。 不由于造作，原无矫强。 药物阴阳尽在兹，莫胡猜傍门邪行，少不得哭哭啼啼嘱付伊。 第四十八回　魔弄寒风飘大雪　僧思拜佛履层冰 悟一子曰：《南华经》云：“北溟有鱼，化而为鹏。 ”鱼者，阴中之阳； 北溟属水，寓言水中有真金也。 化为鹏者，朱雀也。 南方，属火； 图南九万，阳数已极； 火中又能化木。 总此一味水中金之循环无端，转运不穷也。 学道者能收得水中金一味，何患不圣、不仙、不佛！ 世多下士，非但不肯深信，莫不为□（左“斥”右“鸟”）鴳之笑。 不知此道至切、至真、至近、至简，绝非荒唐幻渺也。 昧此者，犹如有家而不知家在何处，俱在醉生梦死之乡而已。

「*"Guanbao"* is the practitioner’s transformed body,
the practitioner becomes *Guanbao*—
how could there ever be two?
One transformation yields two,
a marvelous shift from odd to even—
please recognize that the *yin within yang* is **Water and Gold**.

*"Chengjin"* is the manifestation of the Eight Precepts (Bājiè),
the Eight Precepts transform into *Chengjin*—
truly, it is as if one is eight,
*yang generates yin*—
one must discern that the *yin within yang* is **Wood and Fire**.

These two supreme treasures resemble the **elixir essence** (dāntóu),
originally requiring two **elixir cauldrons** (dānwǎn).
When **Gold and Wood** harmonize and dispel the *fetus* (yàozi),
it is but the **essence of the Golden Fish**—
a single flavor.

First consume the male, then the female—
a metaphor for two stages of practice,
not bound to physical form or substance,
how could there be harm or injury?
The **Golden Elixir’s** beginning and end hold true marvelous methods,
too profound to utter, let alone fathom.

Once *"造化"* (Zàohuà) is grasped,
its principle revealed,
the door is opened,
and the male and female lifted—
already, the entire truth is laid bare.
Not contrived, nor forced—
originally, it has no artifice.
All medicinal substances of *yin* and *yang* are contained here;
do not recklessly conjecture or stray into false paths,
lest you weep and wail, entreating your fate in vain.

**Chapter Forty-Eight**
*Magic Whips the Cold Wind, Snow Falls in Sheets*
*The Monk Ponders Worshipping the Buddha on Layered Ice*

Master **Wu Yi** said: *"The Zhuangzi* states:
‘The northern sea has a fish,
which transforms into a *Peng* (peng).’
The fish is the *yang within yin*;
the northern sea belongs to **Water**—
a parable hinting at **true gold within water**.

Its transformation into the *Peng* is the **Vermilion Bird** (Zhūquè).
The south belongs to **Fire**;
**Nine Ten Thousand** (jiǔ wàn) of southward flight—
the *yang* essence has reached its peak;
**Fire can again generate Wood**.

In summary, this endless cycle of the **Golden Fish essence** within water,
an unceasing transformation—
the adept who can gather this **essence of Water and Gold**,
what fear is there of not attaining **sainthood, immortality, or Buddhahood**?

Many are the **lowly scholars** (xiàshì),
not only unwilling to deeply believe,
but all mocking it as **empty delusion** (□鴳).
They do not know this **Dao** is most urgent, most true, most near, most simple—
absolutely not frivolous or fantastical.

Those who fail to grasp this
are like those who have a home yet do not know where it lies,
still wandering in the realm of **drunken life and dreamlike death**.»

The account of the Chen Family Village gathering’s rites and sacrifices unfolds thus:
Those who could truly believe and act upon the **Eight Precepts’** transformations
would proceed to Linggan Temple,
where they would recognize the **golden-character spirit tablet**,
kneel and follow its dictates—
this is called **clarity and purity of the master’s intent**,
daring not to muddle through the customary observances,
only then returning to their own homes.

Ah, the **Great Sage** and **Tianpeng** spoke:
*"Let us return to our own home."*
*"Where is your home?"*
*"To sleep at Old Chen’s place."*
*"Fool! You’re babbling again."*
*"You call me a fool! Just teasing him—why take it seriously?"*
*"To be fully human is to begin and end with sincerity."*
Each knock met its response,
mutual revelation stirring even the wanderer abroad
to yearn for his homeland,
the exile in distant lands
to tighten the reins of return.

Every home has its own home—
do not lodge in another’s.
Every home still has its own—
do not dream of another’s as your own.
To cease being a fool,
to jest and pass through—
that is true.
To speak nonsense yet begin and end with sincerity—
that is enlightenment.

The striking of the gong
resonates clear and piercing—
how much more than the evening drum and morning bell
to awaken the lost from slumber!

The **Pilgrim’s** exchange with the monster
merely reveals an old household custom.

When the **Eight Rules** manifested as a monster,
it had already found two **heaven-piercing giant scales**.
Having traced its path,
there was a method to capture it.

Returning to Chen’s home,
all were unharmed—
hosts and guests, masters and disciples—
united in joyful conversation, their delight evident.

The **Water’s gold** harbors **true yin and true yang**,
the **qi of the Five Phases and Four Seasons**.
It was originally Chen’s own possession,
yet not yet subdued.

The fish leaps in the deep—
the **Dao** reveals itself naturally.

The **Dao** is the **Dao**; I return to myself—
no entanglement with it.
I am confined within the **Dao**,
yet the **Dao** plays with me.

Birth, old age, sickness, death—
arising, dwelling, subsiding, emptiness—
all stem from the **Dao**.

The child of **creation** acts without intent;
**Tang Seng** seeks the **Sutra** with desperate urgency.
To strive against **creation’s flow**,
to contend and oppose—
this is the **Water’s gold**, not yet tamed,
and so it harbors the impulse to torment **Tang Seng**,
for **Tang Seng’s** own urgent, self-driven pursuit is its cause.

Ah, the **compassionate heart** of the **Carp Grandmother**,
saving **Tang Seng** from the monster,
demonstrating the **good method** of refining the **restless mind**.

If one sees this as aiding demons in cruelty,
it is to cling to literal forms,
not to grasp the author’s intent—
how can one fathom the **Heart Sutra’s** profundity?

The **Heart Sutra’s** marvel lies in **non-attachment**.
A mind fixed on objects is not the **wonderful mind**.
Once, a **wild fox** disguised as a woman
could discern where a man’s mind dwelled—
for the mind was fixed upon something.

**Master Daan** placed his mind in the **Four Fruitions of Arhat**,
yet the fox could not find it.
I say: the fox was merely a fox—
the mind that sought was its own fixation;
how could it search everywhere and fail?

I knew it through the very mind that sought.
What mind of mine knew it?

The **Tang Seng**’s mind to retrieve the scriptures was most urgent—urgent in his progress, unaware of retreat or survival, each with its own signs. How could he know that opposing the **Dao**’s natural unfolding only brings harm to himself?

The **Guanpo** said, *“I have long known that Your Majesty has the **Dao**-transcending power to summon winds and call rains, to churn the seas and overturn rivers.”*

When **Tang Seng** reached the riverbank, seeing the winds stilled and waves calm, he sought a flat-bottomed boat and crossed in an instant. Yet once in midstream, the **Dao**’s power and **qi** manifested—unexpected, swift, and decisive. Why resort to crude tactics of whipping winds, summoning snow, or freezing ice to ensnare him?

To stir winds and summon snow, to freeze the river—was it not to deliberately obstruct him, preventing swift passage and thus thwarting his **Dao**-transcending power? To make the crossing treacherous, forcing caution and thus dampening his **qi** and power? Was this not the **good method** of saving the monk and subduing the demon?

When the great snow fell and the ice grew bitterly cold, the cold penetrated to the core, and the plum blossoms bloomed in response. When faced with the extraordinary, strategy revived—thus, the extreme of cold births harmony, and the most blocked paths open. Without enduring severe cold, one cannot refine the true nature.

Eight hundred layers of ice—this was the most perilous path. To brave danger was to fall into traps; to recognize peril was to walk with caution. Thus, one who treads on a tiger’s tail receives its bite, and one who steps on frost knows its threat. Without plunging into the deepest abyss, one cannot still the restless mind.

**Guanpo** had long understood **Tang Seng**’s impulsive, restless nature. Precisely because this was the **Dao**-aligned path to heaven, she devised this trial—to temper his nature with cold and still his mind with the abyss. Was she not perhaps the very embodiment of the Great Earth?

How do we know this? Observe how the **Great Sage Equaling Heaven** did not wait for the **Journeyer’s** report but rushed to the bamboo grove to forge weapons. **Guanpo** was the **Great Sage**—when the **Great Sage** captured the fish, **Guanpo** was not present. The **Great Sage** was **Guanpo**. Every word and deed of **Guanpo** served only to protect **Tang Seng** and aid the **King of the River**.

It is clear: the **Spirit-Sensing King** is but a **Spirit-Sensing Bodhisattva**. The title remains, yet the **King** is transformed by a **Bodhisattva**. Then the **King’s** winds, his great snows, his manipulation of **Tang Seng**—were they not **Guanpo’s** manipulation of the **King** and **Tang Seng**, all of it the **Great Sage’s** manipulation of the **King** and **Tang Seng**, all in accordance with the Buddha’s will to guide the scripture-seeker?

**San Zang** said, *“This season is strange—I do not know if it is spring, summer, autumn, or winter.”* He saw that the **Dao** of heaven follows its natural course, and one must know its signs.

Again, he said, *“I did not know of the mountains and rivers’ dangers.”* He saw that the **Dao** of earth follows fixed principles, and one must know its changes.

Again, he said, *“In this world, nothing is heavier than name and profit. Others risk death for gain; my disciple serves the edict with loyalty—yet it is still for fame. How does this differ?”* He saw that greed for profit and fame are burdens, and one must know their harm.

If the restless mind is indulged, if one treads carelessly upon the layered ice, then one becomes a plaything of fate for eternity, unable to be a master of one’s own life. Thus, one must penetrate the **yin-yang**, deeply understand the times, know when to advance and retreat, guard against danger and foresee risk, abandon schemes and sever thoughts, still the form and rest the mind—only then can one remain true to the **Way**.

If one rushes forward in haste, it is as if one has passed the mark. The **Way** lies before you, yet you stumble past it. **Sha Wujing’s** words, *“In haste, one fears mistakes,”* are a sharp warning.

The **River of Heaven’s Passage** is the true path to retrieve the scriptures. The monsters within have not yet been subdued—how can one cross? The **gold in water** is the **Dao**’s marvel—true gold has not yet been obtained, and without it, there is no way to worship the Buddha.

The scriptures are the **gold in water**, not mere words. The Buddha is present in the world, not only in the Western Paradise. To seek the Buddha while recklessly risking danger—why not stay at Chen’s house to avoid error?

The **grass-shoe horse** was hasty; to walk on ice was reckless. To step into the abyss and sink to the depths—**Tang Seng** brought this upon himself. What blame is there for the monster?

**Guanpo** said, *“I dare not! I dare not!”*

For now, let him be. Better to endure two days, leisurely and at ease, enjoying oneself.

How reverent, cautious, and composed! Not only does this spare Tang Seng harm, but it also allows the monster to be contained, opens the door for the three disciples to rescue the drowning, and preserves the Great Sage’s ground for subduing demons. Who else but an embodiment of effortless transformation could do this?

The three disciples returned to Chen’s village and explained the spirit’s trickery. They headed straight to the water’s edge to seek their master and capture the monster—the moment of returning to origin and restoring essence lies here.

**Chapter Forty-Nine: The Monk Faces Calamity and Sinks into a Watery Abode—Guan Yin Appears in a Fish Basket to Save the Peril**

Wu Yi Zi said: *Gold elixir* is the convergence of true yin and true yang qi, following the natural cycles of Heaven and Earth through the four seasons and seventy-two solar terms, returning to the primal origin without artificial coercion. Only when one penetrates Lao Zi’s subtle and wondrous teachings does one realize the Dao’s simplicity and effortless ease—taking and consuming it grants fulfillment of nature and life, instantly ascending to sainthood.

This passage reveals the marvelous application of subduing the gold elixir, the secret essence of Guan Yin’s mission to Chang’an to relieve suffering and save from peril, marking the grand source and culmination of *The Scripture of Liberation from Calamity*. Its placement in the forty-ninth chapter underscores the *Great Correlation*’s number of fifty, with its full use manifesting in forty-nine—here lies its significance.

The immortal’s brush cannot fully convey its depth, so only Guan Yin’s miraculous fish-basket form is depicted to illuminate later generations. Its profound implications are boundless, encompassing all phenomena—only those who master yin-yang and comprehend the workings of creation can glimpse its essence. To say *Journey to the West* lacks ingenuity, relying solely on invoking the Southern Sea Bodhisattva in crises, is as blind as groping for a *zheng* (上“竹”下“龠”) in the dark.

The second disciple devised a plan to descend into the water to seek their master. When Zhu Bajie carried the real and false bodies of the disciple, it signified their shared resolve—urgent need to question a friend and seek their master. How could one not recognize another’s true form when there are forms beyond the body?

*"I’m right here, Old Monkey!"*
But calling to the deaf awakens no fool—*"You’re still carrying me!"*
At the sound of the song, your original form remains.

*Hurry, hurry—no delay!*
Lift your head—this is the Water Turtle’s domain.

Transformed into Shrimp Mother, question Shrimp Grandma—
The Great-Bellied One speaks of vitality;
Encounter Stone Lizi, listen to Stone Xiang—
The Living Tomb’s true master weeps over the path to death.

If the disciples could find their master together, what fear is there that the true scriptures won’t reach home?

The monk wept in grief, recounting the watery disaster—not out of hatred for water, but acknowledging that from birth to return to the source, water’s role is indispensable, never to be overlooked.

The disciple called out: *"Master, do not grieve over the watery calamity. The scriptures say: ‘Earth is the mother of the Five Phases; wood is the source of the Five Phases. Without earth, nothing grows; without water, nothing thrives.’"* This echoes the meaning: *"The Four Symbols and Five Phases rely entirely on earth; the Nine Palaces and Eight Trigrams cannot depart from it."* The point is clear—no need for further annotation.

Having clarified the situation, the disciple ordered Zhu Bajie and Sha Wujing to enter the water to fight separately—why? The monster is the *true gold in water*, a convergence of yin-yang and the Five Phases’ qi, already formed. Yet, obstructed by the talisman’s solar fire, its time has not come, so it cannot return to origin and attain its true fruition. Only Zhu Bajie’s wood-fire refinement and Sha Wujing’s true earth can subdue it.

*"Wielding a nine-pronged red copper mallet"*—a symbol of pure yang, standing alone and unyielding.

Zhu Bajie said: *"You fake being the Spirit King of Illusions, devouring children in Chen’s village! I’m Chen Qing’s one-catty gold—don’t you recognize me?"*
Not to make the king recognize him, but to let those refining the elixir do so.

At this moment, only a female form appears—no mention of boys. Beneath the water, a fierce battle unfolds among the three. Do not mistake this for the initial convergence of the Five Phases forming the embryo—this is the later stage of ten-month fire refinement after the embryo is formed.

The verse reads: *"With fate and affinity, the Dao is complete"*—yin-yang union.
*"Mutual generation and conquest, as countless as grains of sand"*—fire refinement.
*"Earth conquers water; water dries up to the bottom"*—water solidifies with earth.
*"Water generates wood; wood flourishes in blossom"*—wood thrives with water.

In Chan practice, this merges into unity;
In elixir refinement, the three families are distinctly subdued.
*"Earth is the mother, sprouting golden buds—
Golden water births the infant"*—earth generates gold and water.
*"Water is the root, nourishing wooden flowers—
Wood radiates fiery splendor"*—wood and fire refine the gold.
*"The Five Phases converge yet remain distinct—

chunks.translated_text:
The refining is yet incomplete—
Again it is quenched in water.
*"The fire’s power is insufficient; it cannot yet be subdued."*

*"The two return to challenge it"*—
The fire’s power advances once more.

The **Taoist** crone addressed the Great Sage:
*"The Great Sage of Heavenly Contention, born from the primordial unity of the Hunyuan Dao,
Refined in the Eight Trigram Furnace as the Golden Elixir Immortal,
Now submits to the Buddhist teaching.
Oh Great King, henceforth do not battle with him again!"*

She extolled the Great Sage’s origins,
Revealing that his elixir was forged from the **Hunyuan Dao**—
The **Hunyuan Dao** being the unity of **qi**,
Refined in the Eight Trigram Furnace.
When the fire’s power was perfected,
He must retreat and guard himself,
Waiting for the moment of **Dao**’s completion and transcendence.

This is as the **Cui Gong**’s *"Mirror of Entering the Medicine"* says:
*"Receive **qi** auspiciously, guard against perilous omens;
When the fire’s intensity is complete, do not harm the elixir;
Heaven and Earth’s essence refined—transformation is parsimonious."*

Thus the subsequent verses of the demon:
*"My noble sister’s vision is profound—
Tightly bar the gates!"*
*"Let any who call outside remain—
The gates shall never open!"*

The Pilgrim said:
*"You two must patrol the riverbank,
Lest he escape!"*
All were tactics of halting refinement and fortifying defenses,
Guarding against dangers and calamities,
Fearful of the *"midnight storm and thunder"* disaster.

**Danyang** Master spoke:
*"Fire in water rises, yet the mind must not be stirred;
Flowers bloom in snow—let the will extinguish the spring."*
This was when the monster had fortified its ramparts in layers,
Sealing the gates and refusing to emerge.
The **Dao**’s nature returns to its true essence—
A spontaneous, wondrous stillness.
The **Bodhisattva** of **Potalaka** moves with effortless grace—
Not awaiting the Pilgrim’s obeisance,
*"No one is permitted to attend—
She enters the bamboo grove to observe and play."*

Had the **Bodhisattva** known the demon would be subdued,
She would have prepared the instruments of capture beforehand,
To display their marvelous efficacy in **shen guan** [神观, divine observation].
This is not something to be shared with all.

The Great Sage then:
*"Let me sit for a moment,
Awaiting the Bodhisattva’s emergence."*
Since the time was not yet ripe,
He must patiently wait—
No need to agitate his restless mind.

When the **Red Boy** laughed:
*"In those days, your demonic passions clouded your heart,
But today you have attained the fruit of enlightenment—
Only now do you recognize my true goodness."*

This clearly marks the moment when the **Red Boy** revealed his true form.
Today’s demons, like the **Red Boy**,
Cannot achieve enlightenment without the **Bodhisattva**’s **Dao**-power and divine skill.
Though the principle of **Dao** is one—
To transcend the self and attain liberation—
The timing of their subjugation varies.

The Pilgrim’s heart burned with anxiety,
Fearful that delay would endanger his master’s life.
Yet time passed, and the elixir escaped its vessel—
His life was lost.

*"The Bodhisattva instructed,
‘Wait only for his own emergence.’"*
This refers to the elixir’s moment of **tui tai** [脱胎, transformation],
When it must be allowed to rise naturally.

Describing the **Bodhisattva**’s divine play in the bamboo grove—
All was effortless, unforced grace,
No artifice or pretense,
Revealing both male and female in one form,
Distinguishing purity from defilement.
Amidst the haste, she moved with perfect ease—
Within **zuo wang** [坐忘, seated oblivion], all was order.
The instruments of **shen guan** were truly profound,
As the **Ganlu** [甘露, sweet dew] of compassion fell upon the azure void.

Ah! How wondrous!

chunks.translated_text:
The River of Heaven’s demon’s root—
Only the Bodhisattva perceives its source;
In the bamboo grove, she strips the wicker—
What could the celestial hosts ever know?

To restore her household, few things she needs—
A single hand lifts a purple bamboo basket;
To rescue Tang Seng, time must not be lost—
No fetters bind the one who robes and sits.

Unadorned, the Bodhisattva appears,
Yet like a midwife pressed by urgent birth;
The basket tied at the stream’s head,
Plainly the fisherman against the current’s pull.

The Bodhisattva chants:
*"The dead depart, the living abide!
The dead depart, the living abide!"*
Divine! Divine!
The mechanism of life and death lies in her grasp—
Her secret technique, passed only by word of mouth,
Its wondrous inversion beyond speech.
Yet in shallow terms:
*"Abide"*—the essence of humanity,
Where heart-sprout and kidney-qi entwine,
Thus life is formed; entering my *"Gate"* is *"obstruction."*
*"Depart"*—the loss of unity,
Where the Seven Emotions and malevolent intent persist,
Thus death is sealed; when the *"ruin"* comes, it must *"perish."*

The living—this is *shen* [神, spirit],
Qi refined, ascending and abiding,
One’s attainment yields perfection,
Detached from humanity, self-sustaining—
Its abiding is its own, not the Bodhisattva’s.

The dead—this is *wu* [物, matter],
Substance impure, descending and departing,
Touch water, it breaks the law;
Meet the blade, it meets its fate—
Its departure is its own, not the Bodhisattva’s.

The *Sutra* says:
*"The Bodhisattva, in the Dharma, should dwell nowhere."*
Yet now it says *"abide"*—
Life arises from the living,
The living is without abiding, yet abiding arises from the living.
Departure stems from death,
Death is abiding itself—
Thus abiding leads to departure.
The chant’s manifest meaning is clear,
But its hidden marvels cannot be put to paper.

*"A radiant golden fish"*—
Suddenly enters the basket,
Only the Bodhisattva’s divine perception could mark its moment.

What intent does the Bodhisattva hold?
Tracing its origin, born from the lotus, unstained;
Examining her method, from the Nine Transformations, returning to One.

The *"tides surging from the sea"*—
Revealing the cause and conditions of its descent into the world as a spirit;

*"Counting the fingers, tracing the lines"*—
Calculating the time of its return to the origin.

*"Performing divine arts, weaving a bamboo basket, capturing the marvelous manifestation"*—
To show the common folk the vast compassion and great mercy—
For the divine response is such that the King is indeed the embodiment of a Great Sage.

As the *Sutra* states:
*"Guanyin Bodhisattva accomplishes such virtues,
Taking countless forms to traverse the lands,
Rescuing and liberating all beings."*

The Great Sage obtained the Dragon Girl and the Red Boy,
Revealing the true source of inherent nature;
The King obtained the boy and girl,
Manifesting the roots of life itself.

One and two are the same.

The people of Chenjiazhuang who hold faith—
Each household has its own divine-response Great Sage,
And the wondrous forms of the fish basket
Naturally possess the methods to subdue the divine-response King.
Yet why do they not revere and honor them with faith?

When the King is captured in the basket,
Tang Seng’s life is already saved,
The old turtle returns to its original abode and returns to the origin—
This is the completion of the Heavenly Passage and the Universal Salvation Boat.
Why bother with building ships or preparing oars?

From *"knowing enlightenment is inherently divine,"*
*"It is truly real—*
*How dare it be false?"*

Crossing with a steady heart over ice thicker than layers—

Stepping on the lid, standing firm on either side—
Leading the horse upward, it is indeed the *River Diagram*.

Ah!

chunks.translated_text:
The turtle’s back emits a five-colored radiant light;
Within the Heavenly Passage, all mysteries of the formless are spoken.

Returning to the origin, it relies entirely on spontaneity;
Shedding its shell to become true, one must inquire of the Buddha and Ancestors.

Able to board the bottomless ship—
For here lies the root of divine essence planted.
Obtaining the scripture of written truth,
One must still traverse the *River Diagram*’s path.

Solemnly sworn to Heaven, not a word amiss—
I ask, I ask, do not forget.

---
**Fifty-First Chapter**
*Emotions Stirred by Lust, Nature Lost to Desire*
*The Godhead Dimmed, the Heart Bewildered by Demons*

Master Yu-yi of Enlightenment says: *The Journey to the West* expounds the Dao of the Golden Elixir, focusing solely on the two characters **"性" (nature/essence)** and **"命" (life/principle)**, which are in truth the original, true *qi* of the primal heavens.

Those who cultivate nature and life cultivate this single *qi*; when nature and life are both perfected, they return to unity.
Revolving endlessly, transforming in myriad ways, yet never departing from their source.

Various treatises establish doctrines:
Some first clarify nature, then life;
Others first clarify life, then nature.
Some say clarifying nature is the same as clarifying life,
Or that clarifying life is the same as clarifying nature.
Some emphasize nature alone, yet life holds no separate principle;
Others emphasize life alone, yet nature shares the same origin.
Some clarify nature but fail to grasp life’s subtlety,
Or clarify life but miss nature’s essence.
Some first grasp life, then later grasp nature,
Or first grasp nature, then later grasp life.
Some, failing to grasp nature, fall into emptiness and deceit,
Or, failing to grasp life, stray into demonic delusion.
Some, through false paths, fail to grasp life and lose their nature;
Others, through barren stillness, fail to grasp nature and cannot grasp life.
Some, led astray by material desires, fail to grasp nature;
Others, misled by illusions, fail to grasp life.
Some, not fully knowing nature’s beginning, cannot grasp it;
Others, not fully knowing life’s mysteries, cannot grasp it.

Some speak directly, some speak in reverse,
Some convey meaning through metaphor, some through symbols.
Some jest or indulge in idle musings to reveal inherent truth;
Others use cold, subtle words to demonstrate foundational practice.
Some hint at the essential keys,
Others openly reveal the true transmission.

Whether oblique or direct, indirect or allegorical.

chunks.translated_text:
The myriad demons may wield strange arts,
Yet all still revolve around refining **"性命"** (nature and life),
Or cultivating the **先天真乙之氣** (primal Daoist *qi* of the original Yang).

The first seven chapters follow a natural order.
Later ones, either ordered or without sequence,
Are inverted and rearranged—each chapter holds profound meaning.
Like the **造化** (Cosmic Transformation) carving all things,
No repetition exists; all ultimately stem from the **一元** (monarchal unity).

The *Paramartha Contract* says: *"孔窍其門"* (its gate is narrow and secret).
Ziyu Master says: *"引而不發"* (draw but do not release).
Only those who read well can **神觀默察** (divinely perceive and silently observe)
And thereby attain self-realization.

If a chapter’s teaching shifts with circumstance,
Unable to **安身立命** (settle oneself and establish one’s nature),
Then it is the *Yijing*’s *"思出其位"* (thinking beyond one’s station),
And the *Zhongyong*’s *"不能素位而願外"* (unable to abide in one’s inherent station yet craving the external).
All stems from **操守不固** (unstable moral discipline)
And **工夫未到** (unfulfilled practice).

The opening lines of *"Nán Kē Zǐ"* (The Southern Slope’s Child) reveal
A **心地工夫** (heart-mind cultivation) that is continuous and unbroken,
Every word piercing to the core.
Why single out *"南柯"* (Southern Slope)?
Because the world’s treacherous paths are **幻如南柯** (illusions like the Southern Slope).
If one’s heart clings to desires,
Unable to **隨遇而安** (adapt with equanimity),
Flitting from one place to another,
Then it is akin to being caught in a *Nán Kē* dream.

What is hardest for mortals to endure?
Nothing surpasses **饥欲** (hunger and craving),
And what most easily disturbs them?
**饥寒而思衣食** (hunger and cold, pondering food and garments).
In the text, the master and disciple share harmony of heart and unity of intent,
Pursuing truth and returning to the right path—
Thus refining nature and life.

Should hunger or cold arise,
One must **固穷** (embrace poverty with resolve),
Not recklessly act.
The Three Treasures (三藏) see the **楼台** (palatial halls) and desire to take alms,
The practitioner gazes at the **气色** (aura) and urges them not to enter,
Conveying the warning:
*"Do not knock at the gates of the mighty for gain,"*
*"Beware the ice-slick slopes and tread with caution."*
*"Dismount, sit level on the ground,
Do not stir your body.
Grant you a method to settle—
Draw a circle, charge you not to step beyond,
And steadfastly remain within.
This is **素位而行** (to move from one’s inherent station),
Not craving the external.
This is called **有坐性** (having settled nature),
Not merely tracing a circle like the *Yùzhàng Shù* (Jade Canopy Technique).

Having settled nature or lacking it—
Not in the sitting, but in the station.
To move from one’s inherent station is **有坐性** (having settled nature),
Not straying outside the circle.
Once one craves the external,
The settled station is lost—
Though one sits the whole day in stupor,
It is still **無坐性** (lacking settled nature),
Having stepped beyond the circle.

To dwell in wealth as though it were none—**有坐性**.
To endure poverty as though it were fixed—**有坐性**.
To face calamity as though it were trivial—**有坐性**.
To meet circumstances with ease,
Content and unperturbed,
Even without sitting, one sits.
Yet if the mind is restless,
Turned by external influences,
Then one has **性** (nature) and lacks **性** (nature).

To step outside this circle
Is to enter another—
As if trapped in the **罟獲陷阱** (nets and snares),
Yet unaware of how to avoid them.

Master and disciple both sit composed,
The practitioner does not shun a thousand *li* journey,
Serving the master with alms—
This is duty within the circle,
Not craving the external.
*"Until ancient trees rise to the heavens,
A village of dwellings is reached."*

The gate of brushwood creaked as an elder emerged, dragging a staff of *lú* (藜) and gazing upward to the heavens, proclaiming:
**"The northwest wind rises—tomorrow shall be clear!"**

A scruffy hound dashed forth from behind him.

Then he spoke again:
**"You’ve strayed from the path.
The Western Heaven’s way lies straight north ahead."**

But in his heart, fear struck him:
**"This monk is a ghost! A ghost!"**

Then he raised his staff to strike, and the Wayfarer replied:
**"Old one, no matter how you strike,
Just remember the tally of your blows—
One staff for one *shēng* (升) of rice,
Slowly measured out."**

Hearing this, the elder slammed the gate shut,
Shouting only: **"There’s a ghost! A ghost!"**

The Wayfarer said:
**"The Dao transforms the virtuous, and the virtuous release the foolish."**

With a hidden-body technique, he took a bowl of dry rice and returned.

Ah! How wondrous!
The Immortal Master’s parable is profound and veiled—
Unfathomable to the reader.
Common folk might think it merely depicts
A barking village dog and a miserly old man,
But who would know it’s a covert censure
Of those in high station who secretly hoard wealth,
Pretending to discern the *tian shi* (天时) and perceive human affairs,
Relying on their power to gauge the winds of fortune—
Truly, they are men of **shàng kuì fǔ zuò** (仰愧俯怍),
Who have stepped beyond the circle of **tian zuòxìng** (天坐性),
Likely akin to the *Mǎng Dàfū* (莽大夫) of the *Gāng Mù Shū* (纲目书).

How do we see this?
**"Ancient trees reaching to the heavens"**—
Is this not dwelling in the *Mù Tiān* (木天, the realm of wood)?
**"Dragging a staff of *lú* (藜)"**—
Is this not the *Tài Yǐ Zhàng* (太乙杖, the staff of the Supreme Unity), a *lú* staff?
**"Village dwellings and brushwood gates"**—
Is this not wandering in the wilds?
**"Gazing to the heavens and spotting a scruffy hound"**—
Is this not observing the winds while clinging to survival,
And feeling shame before the heavens?

**"You’ve strayed from the path—
The Western Heaven’s way lies straight north ahead."**
Not knowing his own error in facing south,
Yet instructing others of their westward deviation—
His heart is filled with shame,
Hence he cries: **"A ghost! A ghost!"**
If his mind clings to ghosts,
Is this not shame before humanity?

**"The elder raises his staff to strike.
The Wayfarer says: ‘Old one,
Just remember the tally of your blows—
One staff for one *shēng* (升) of rice.’"**
Indeed, he relies only on records to predict promotions,
Knowing nothing beyond his own stolen gains and self-satisfied sustenance—
His heart is filled with shame,
Hence he cries: **"A ghost! A ghost!"**
When he reflects on his deeds,
How could he not shame himself to death?

The Eight Precepts say:
**"I am not like that uncouth man,"**
And thus marks his own kind.

This man is neither virtuous nor foolish—
The Dao cannot transform him,
And the teachings cannot release him.

chunks.original_text: 似此仰愧俯怍之徒，在位而出位，口是心非，言诈行违，分明老贼，诚不如潜形隐面之辈，挜取干饭，事亲供师，反得至恭至敬也。 仙师盖有为而言，所以激励臣节，为千古立有位之防，即《孟子》齐人之喻，贤者自贤，愚者自愚，此有良贵者所以不愿人之膏梁之味也。 唐僧惑于呆子坐牢之说，一齐出了圈外，坐于公侯之门，静悄悄全无人迹，非无人也，即昏夜乞人，如在鬼窟里作生涯也。 呆子入见，黄绫帐幔，象牙床上，白媸媸的一堆骸骨，见位至公侯而不修性命，明眼人视之终是一堆白骨。 呆子洒泪浩叹，“英雄豪杰今安在”一句，深可猛省。 “见帐慢火光一晃”，见石火之易灭。 “见桌上锦绣绵衣”，见朱紫之惑人。 “不管好歹，拿出背心”，见服官之不择。 “四顾无人，谁人知道”，见四知之罔畏。 “立站不稳，扑的一跌”，见荣辱之靡常。 “把两个背剪手贴心捆了”，见刑法之易罹。 唐僧因饥出圈而惊动魔头，呆子因冷贪着而中其机械，皆因爱欲而情乱性从，不清自来，与魔何尤？ 此修天爵者所以不愿人之文绣也。 行者得饭到圈，不见人马，回看楼台，忽成怪石，黄粱未熟，瞬息变迁，沧海桑田，真堪歌哭！ 总由不能稳坐共守性命，妄动出圈，贪图温饱所致，岂不错走了路，闯入妖魔口里去耶？ 老翁指出“金□[左“山”右“兜”]山金□[左“山”右“兜”]洞独角兕大王”，兜鍪为首铠，争战之具。 兕加独角为亢，王加独角为主，出位兜诅不肯宁静，亢主不臣之象，比之古之欢兜然。 故篇首叙师徒正行处，忽遇大山，点缀出石多岭峻，三藏兜住缰绳字样。 早以峻岭衬出崇山，以兜缰映带欢兜。 至此处忽作“□[左“山”右“兜”]字，寓放欢兜于崇山之义也。 欢兜与共工相助为虐，作乱于圣世，不臣之甚，出位之尤者，仙师特引以为圣僧魔头之喻。 老翁现相，称山神土地，收下斋钵，“待救出唐僧，还奉唐僧，以显大圣之至恭至孝”，明山神非越位滥受，见大圣为分内恭敬也。 大圣找寻妖洞索战，魔头闻言欢喜，道：“自离本宫，未试武艺。 ”收其欢喜，兜诅出位，好动之情，非可以动胜也。 行者战不能胜而焦躁，丢起金箍棒，变作千百条，是以动聊动，而益以就其动。 动圈套，老魔取出圈子，把金箍棒收做一条套去，全归于动。 而动者不可收拾，皆由我一念之动自先主张也。 故曰：“道高一尺度高丈，性乱情昏错认家。 可恨法身无坐位，当时行动念头差。 ” 第五十一回　心猿空用千般计　水火无功难炼魔 悟一子曰：兕者，丑土，在人为意，意放而肆无忌惮，则心随意转，无所主持，失其把柄，是昧却定理，而套去金箍棒矣。 “大圣空着手，滴泪叫道：‘岂料如今无主杖。 ’”言没了主意也。 人能主意以格天，天不能强人以主意。 若意被物迷而身遭困厄，不知自反，徒虔心告天，是犹失意罪臣。 没有棒弄，惟事修词饰敬以希君听，虽称“战栗屏营，深躬以闻”，极尽情文，有何裨益？ 适以成其斯昧而已。 大圣上天启奏一段，刻画人臣诈妄之状，为君者亦何能取臣心，而使之主诚悃乎？ 玉帝降旨，可韩司同大圣去查。 《周本记》以何姓为韩后。 韩者，何也，言可作如何而谘询之义。

Such wretched souls—ashamed above, abashed below—
Though they hold office yet step beyond their station,
Their words betray their hearts, their deeds betray their speech,
Clear villains indeed! Better far were those who hide their faces,
Scratching for scraps to feed their parents, serve their masters,
Yet show the utmost reverence and respect.

The Sage’s words are not idle—
He stirs the spirit of loyal ministers,
Sets a warning for all who bear office,
Just as Mencius’ parable of the Qi man:
The wise man knows his own worth,
The fool knows his own folly—
Thus the noble refuse the taste of others’ fat and grain.

Tang Seng, bewildered by the fool’s tale of prison,
All left their circle together,
Sitting at the gates of princes and nobles,
Silent as a ghost’s lair, with no trace of man—
Not that there were none, but only beggars in the dead of night,
Living like ghosts in a tomb.

The fool entered and saw:
Silken curtains, ivory beds—
A heap of white bones, gaunt and shriveled.
To see one of noble rank yet neglect his nature and life—
The clear-eyed see only a pile of bones.

The fool wept and sighed:
*"Where now are the heroes and the bold?"*
A saying to stir the soul to wakefulness.

*"A flicker of lamplight in the tent"*—
The fleeting nature of life, like a spark soon gone.
*"Silken robes on the table"*—
The allure of purple and gold.
*"No matter right or wrong, he takes off his robe"*—
The shamelessness of office.
*"No one around—who could know?"*—
The fearlessness of the four watchful senses.
*"He stands unsteady, then crashes to the ground"*—
The fickleness of honor and disgrace.
*"He binds his own hands behind his back"*—
The ease with which one falls into the law’s snare.

Tang Seng, driven by hunger, left the circle and roused the demon.
The fool, clinging to warmth, fell into its trap—
All because desire clouded their nature, their passions unchecked,
Their ruin self-wrought. What blame to the demon?

Thus those who cultivate the Dao’s natural worth
Refuse the trappings of rank and finery.

The Pilgrim returned to the circle for food,
Found no one, no horses—
Looked back, and the towers had turned to jagged rocks.
The yellow millet still unripe, all changed in an instant—
The sea becomes land, land becomes sea—
Truly worthy of lament and song!

All because they could not steadfastly preserve their nature,
Dared to leave the circle, greedy for warmth and ease—
How could they not stray from the path,
Stumble into the jaws of demons?

The old man pointed to *"The Golden Cangshan Cave, where the One-Horned Rhinoceros King reigns."*
The *cang* is a helmet, armor for battle.
The rhinoceros with a single horn is *kàng*—
The king with a single horn is *zhǔ*—
One who steps beyond his station, restless and defiant,
A rebel lord, like the ancient *Huandou* of old.

Thus the tale begins with the master and disciples on their proper path,
Then suddenly a great mountain appears,
Its peaks towering, its ridges sharp—
San Zang holds the reins tight.

The lofty peaks contrast with the towering mountain,
The *cang* (helmet) echoes *Huandou*’s defiance.
Now the *"Cang"* character appears—
Hiding *Huandou* within the mountain’s grandeur.

*Huandou* aided *Gonggong* in rebellion,
Ravaging the age of sage rule—
The ultimate rebel, the most transgressive.
The Sage likens the demon to this ancient traitor.

The old man revealed himself as mountain god and earth spirit,
Accepted the alms bowl,
*"Wait until I rescue Tang Seng,
Then I will serve Tang Seng—
To show the Great Sage’s utmost reverence and filial piety."*
The mountain god does not overstep, does not accept improperly,
Proving the Great Sage’s respect is his due.

The Great Sage searched for the demon’s lair to battle,
The demon, hearing this, rejoiced:
*"Since leaving my palace,
I have not yet tested my skills."*

His joy was seized—
The *cang* (helmet) of defiance, restless and impulsive—
Not to be overcome by mere movement.

The Pilgrim, unable to win, grew frantic,
Lifted his *Jin’gu* Staff and split it into thousands of strands—
Thus, movement only fuels more movement,
And the more he stirs, the deeper he falls.

The demon’s trap was set by movement itself—
The old demon took the circle and bound the *Jin’gu* Staff,
All reduced to motion.

But motion cannot be contained—
All because the first impulse came from within.

Thus it is said:
*"Dao rises one foot, yet the measure stretches ten—
Nature disordered, passions clouded, home misjudged.
Alas, the Dharma-body has no seat—
At that moment, the moving thought was wrong."*

The Fifth Volume:
*The Monkey King’s Empty Schemes*
*Fire and Water Fail to Forge the Demon*

Master Wu Yi said: The rhinoceros is *chǒu*—
Earth of the ugly trigrams, in man it is *yì* (intent).
When intent runs wild with no restraint,
The heart follows, turning with no master—
Losing its grip, it forgets the principle,
And the *Jin’gu* Staff is bound away.

*"The Great Sage stood empty-handed, weeping:
‘Who would have thought my staff was lost?’"*
Meaning he had lost his resolve.

Man can master intent to overcome Heaven,
But Heaven cannot force intent upon man.
If intent is clouded by things and one falls into misfortune,
Yet knows not to reflect—
Only piously pleading to Heaven,
Like a guilty minister who has lost his way.

Without the staff to wield,
He only polishes his words and feigns respect,
Hoping the ruler will listen—
Though he trembles and grovels, bowing deeply,
Exhausting all artifice—
What good does it do?
It only deepens his delusion.

The Great Sage’s petition to Heaven—
A portrait of the deceitful minister—
How could the ruler take such a heart,
And make it sincere?

The Jade Emperor’s edict:
Let Han Xiang go with the Great Sage to investigate.
*The Zhou Ben Ji* names the Han clan as descendants of He.
*Han* is *He*—
Meaning *"how"*—
As in *"how shall we consult this?"*

Thus, upon close investigation, even the Five Emperors could not intervene, so the Monkey was ordered to select celestial generals. The Celestial Master, Xu Jingyang, merely said, *"Let him choose the generals according to his judgment."* Having selected the Li Heavenly King and his sons, as well as the Thunder Lord, the Jade Emperor granted his request—neither the Heavenly Belt nor the Celestial Master could oppose it.

When the Prince Nezha unleashed his magic, his transformations were boundless; when the Demon King hurled his ring into the sky, it ensnared the Six Divine Weapons. The Deng and Zhang lords dared not strike with thunder, and the Heavenly King exclaimed, *"How can this be resolved?"*—even the heavenly deities could not intervene.

They then summoned the Fire Deity of Vermilion Splendor to unleash flames, only to have the fire dragons themselves ensnared; next, they called upon the Water Deity of Wuhao Palace to flood the battlefield, but the waters surged outward uncontrollably. Even these lifeless yet tangible forces—fire and water—could not subdue him.

Finally, the Monkey transformed his own hairs into tiny monkeys, only to have them trapped as well. Resuming his true form, he realized that distant measures were futile and began to consider the principle of *"near-taking from within."* Yet how could he hope to restrain one so reckless when his efforts were confined to mere skin and hair?

The Demon King is easy to subdue—only the child’s nature is difficult to conquer.
Unless the treasure is obtained, the demon cannot be captured afterward.

For the strategy to subdue the demon, nothing surpasses first seizing what the demon relies upon;
To seize what the demon relies upon, nothing surpasses first mastering what one oneself employs.

Thus, Deng and Zhang the Two Masters said: *"If one must practice the art of stealth, none but the Great Sage can do it."*
Stealth means subtle transformation and silent operation.
To act with virtue is within oneself, not dependent on others;
Only by inwardly reflecting and rigorously self-examining,
Silently transforming within the heart,
Can one suddenly reclaim what was lost—
Not by mere theft of peaches or elixirs,
Nor by superficially grasping it as a skill.

Thus, the Pilgrim stole into the demon’s cave
And suddenly saw the Golden-Hooped Rod—
This was a fleeting enlightenment,
Yet the master of the staff returned to its rightful owner.
But it was not guaranteed he would not lose it again,
For seizing it through theft was but a glimmer in a crack,
Unable to perceive the whole,
And thus ultimately could not escape its bonds.

Earth resides in the central palace,
While Metal, Wood, Water, and Fire encircle it in function;
Distributed to the four corners,
Metal, Wood, Water, and Fire encircle it in form.
Departing from its proper office and achieving one-sided dominance—
If Earth accumulates and buries Metal,
Then the Golden-Hooped Rod is ensnared;
If Earth obstructs and Water is blocked,
Then Water’s force cannot break free from the bonds.

Earth, as the proper principle, is most divine;
Earth, as perverse, is also most divine.
This vile Earth steals its circle to ensnare all things.

Thus, when the spleen fails, danger is near;
When intent is corrupt, affairs fall into chaos.
Those skilled in distinguishing yellow (Earth) must regulate the spleen;
Those skilled in nurturing life must first subdue the intent.
For intent can harm the heart and disrupt the Five Virtues,
Just as Earth can harm nature and disrupt the Five Phases.

To tame the Earthly intent,
No amount of deliberation, strategy, coercion, or force can succeed—
This is why the heavenly deities, Thunder Lord, Fire Deity, and Water God were ineffective.

Thus, the precept states:
*"The mind-monkey, though plotting a thousand schemes,
Finds water and fire useless in refining the demon."*

He who knows the **principal** [主] of intent dwells in the void,

If one relies on the power of transient perceptions and worldly wisdom,

Even if one gains a fleeting glimpse of insight,
Suddenly recalling the old self—
It is but like a thief raiding a camp or plundering a fortress,
A mere skirmish of scattered troops and clever tactics.

The old demon scoffed, *"You waste your contrivances—you know nothing of my true power!"*
Indeed, he did not know the root.

All the gods, thinking themselves triumphant,
Rallied again for battle.
*"The gods remain bare-handed,
The Great Sage still fights empty-handed."*

What use is the brilliance of fire
To pierce the darkness of the boundless sky?
With nothing to grasp or exert,
How could they counter the phantom stirrings of the earth?

Thus the old demon cried, *"My children, move the earth and build!"*
Plotting to *"slay the Tang Monk and his three disciples to repay the earth,
So all may scatter blessings and enjoy their rewards."*
Earth’s movement harms essence and life—
The words made it plain.

*"Fire’s virtue resents its haste,
Thunder’s lord blames his impatience,
The Water Spirit falls silent in frustration."*
All were sharp-witted, yet recalled treacherous schemes,
Their discord and imbalance now evident.

How else could one discern this
Unless the Tathāgata’s wisdom-eye observed?

The Tathāgata—
Neither from nor to anywhere,
The very *"Heaven’s unalterable nature"*—
Is the *"Thus-Come-One"* who neither gains nor loses.

The *"wisdom-eye"*—
The innate luminous clarity of true nature,
Returning to self-illumination,
Transparent within and without,
Not a hair’s breadth obscured,
Neither clinging nor resisting,
Naturally pure and still—
Like a mirror’s calm water.

The Pilgrim arrived at the Sacred Summit,
Surveying the four directions,
When suddenly a voice called out:
*"Sun Wukong, where have you come from?"*

Not truly arriving at the Sacred Summit—
The *"Sacred Platform"* of the heart-mind is the place itself.
Awakening suddenly to the Tathāgata’s realm,
He replied: *"I have just arrived at this noble land."*

The Tathāgata asked: *"How did you come here alone?"*
A place unknown to others,
Yet known only to oneself.

The Tathāgata had long since perceived it through his wisdom-eye,
And already knew—
*"Though I know of that fiend,
I must not reveal it."*

This thing must be self-realized;
Words cannot convey it—
*"That which cannot be spoken is called speech."*

Again, the Tathāgata said:
*"I shall lend you my magical power."*

The Pilgrim asked: *"What power does the Tathāgata lend me?"*
The Tathāgata then commanded the Eighteen Arhats
To open the treasure vault
And take eighteen grains of *jīndānshā* (gold elixir sand).
Each took one grain,
And gave it to Wukong to aid his strength.
Thus trapped, the fiend could not move his body,
Nor lift his feet.

Marvelous!
*"Eighteen"*—the number of *"wood,"*
Which, if taken literally, suggests wood subdues earth as aid—
Yet this is mere empty reasoning.
Where could one exert effort?

Eighteen grains of *jīndānshā*,
Taken by the Eighteen Arhats—
Each took one grain.
*"Eighteen"* plus *"each"* becomes *"gé"* (格),
Meaning *"to restrain"*—
Only by restraining it can one seize it,
As in *"opening the golden treasure vault,
Each takes what they recognize."*

Thus, to cultivate sincerity,
One must first attain knowledge,
And knowledge lies in investigating things.

The character *"wù"* (物) bears the radical *"niú"* (牛).
The *Shuōwén* says:
*"The ox is the great thing.
The cycles of Heaven and Earth begin with the Ox."*
Heaven and Earth rely on the Ox to complete their revolutions;
Humanity relies on sincerity to harmonize the center.

Yet why did the eighteen grains of *jīndānshā* vanish?
*"Jīndān"* called *"shā"* (sand)—
The outer husk of the golden elixir.
The sage deliberately turned the phrase,
Lest scholars mistake *"investigating things"* for mere *"collecting things,"*
And fail to grasp the essence of investigation.
Only when knowledge is complete
Can one truly investigate.

If one merely examines things without true knowing,
Even if they exhaust all books from the age of Xuanyuan onward,
Memorizing every classification,
Or investigate all things within the cosmos—
Encompassing all plants and creatures—
It is still distant, superficial pursuit,
Chasing externals and losing the vital core,
Unrelated to life and essence.

*"Laughing at past delusions,
Seeking branches and leaves beyond."*

How could this be,
When the Arhats stood empty-handed in the clouds?
Names alone filled their minds,
Yet their hands were truly empty—
Where was the restraining?

Only when knowledge is complete
Can one truly investigate.
Selecting the good,
Then investigating thoroughly;
Only when precise,
Can knowledge be complete.

「To select the good and clarify principles,
To refine precision and grasp the central truth,
Only then can one subdue this creature without difficulty.

The Buddha’s command to the two revered beings—**Subduing Dragon** and **Taming Tiger**—who lingered behind:
*"The two revered beings said to the Pilgrim: ‘O **Sun Wukong**, do you know why we two are slow to depart?’*
*The Pilgrim replied: ‘I do not.’"*

Only when one understands the essential subtleties of **Subduing Dragon** and **Taming Tiger**,
Can one fully grasp and know them to their depths.

The **Arhats** explained:
*"The Buddha commanded: ‘Having lost the **Golden Elixir Cinder** (金丹砂),
Let **Sun Wukong** ascend to **Laozi’s** **Highest Primordial Heaven** (離很天太上老君處) to seek its traces.’"*

**Laozi** embodies the **Li** (☉) hexagram’s fifth line—
Five hollows within yet capable of containing all things,
Thus able to **calm the mind** and remain unmoving.

The **Golden Elixir Cinder** (金刚琢) is the **Li** (☉) hexagram’s **yellow ear** (黄耳),
Firm yet yielding, golden yet with jade-like purity,
Unchanging from beginning to end,
Thus able to **encompass all things** without leaving any trace.

In the sixth chapter, this treasure was used
And struck the **Great Sage** (大聖) at that moment—
Its meaning has been fully expounded.

This reveals why **Laozi** lost his **central void** (中),
Not because the **Golden Elixir Cinder** was truly lost from his **hollow core** (虚中),
But due to the **boy’s** ignorance and confusion,
Which stirred the **earthly passions** (意土) into chaos.

It is clear that the **human heart** (人心) possesses an **awakened child** (灵童),
Yet when obscured by ignorance, it fails to recognize,
Thus acting blindly and recklessly,
Creating mischief and havoc,
Endangering one’s **life and essence** (性命).

With a **transformative vessel** (化质之器具) turned against the **sage’s head** (圣魔头),
This is all because of the **unrestrained movement** (纵放出入) of this very thing.

The key to **subduing and returning** lies in
One’s own **secret discernment** (密察),
Not in reliance upon others.

*"The Pilgrim’s eyes did not waver,
Gazing east and west—"*
A **divine observation** (神观).

*"Suddenly seeing the boy dozing,
The ox nowhere in sight,
He cried: ‘Master, the ox is gone!
The ox is gone!’"*
Now tracking the **footprints of the culprit** (脚色),
True knowing and clear vision.

*"The boy awoke with a start,"*
As if emerging from a dream.

*"It has now been seven days,"*
The time of **seven-day return** (七日来复),
When **Heaven’s will** (天心) is restored.

Only upon uncovering the **stolen Golden Elixir Cinder** (偷去金刚琢),
Does one achieve **full mastery of things** and **complete knowing** (物格而知至).

**"Laozi brandished his banana leaf fan,"**
Holding the **pure and empty qi** (清虚之气),
To restore the **central void** (虚中之物),
Thus embodying the principle of **"grasping the center while preserving sincerity"** (执中存诚).

**"He shouted: ‘Ox! Why do you not return home?’"**

That demon instantly recognized the protagonist—
with one wave of the fan, the illusionary circle was cast aside;
with a second, the original form was revealed.
As the saying goes:
*"A single call awakens the enlightened child,
Two breaths restore the true form to the Supreme Clarity."*

*"Laozi mounted the ox and ascended to Heaven,
The assembled deities took up their arms and departed,
Master and disciple prepared their gear to leave the cave."*

The meaning is settled, the heart at peace—
all thanks to the Buddha’s wisdom eye revealing the truth.
Those who seek the Dao each possess the Buddha’s wisdom eye—
yet why do they alone fail to recognize the protagonist within?

The passage where Laozi says,
*"Seven returns of the Fire Elixir—
one grain consumed, seven days of slumber ensue,"*
holds a deeper truth.
*"Seven returns"* is the refined divine fire—
after ingestion, the bones grow numb, the sinews languid,
a natural seven-day repose,
which is in truth a great awakening, not a great sleep.

The thief takes his spoils and barely endures,
the monkey wears silk while sporting a ragged crown—
plainly, they are but kindling for a gate,
a dog barking at the golden **box** (*left "mountain," right "trap"*),
their bones exposed beneath borrowed robes.

All act at whim, defying proper bounds,
utterly lacking the stillness of sitting.

Though luck may spare them, how can they avoid shameful death?

The Tripitaka Master said:
*"Had I known I’d not escape this circle,
I’d never have risked this peril to my life."*

The Pilgrim said:
*"All because you didn’t trust my circle,
yet forced me to endure another’s."*

For man’s circle or my circle—
both are one circle.

Two **"men"** in harmony form **"sitting"** (*土*), but when discord arises and they part from the earth,
then man is man, earth is earth—
no sitting-nature remains, and they step beyond the circle.

The dispute lies in a single thought:
the moment of separation or union,
where truth and falsehood are divided.

To step out or enter—
only self-awareness matters.

The Tathagata points to the root:
the path of insight into the sitting-nature’s separation and union,
the true **dharma** for abiding and establishing life.

Thus it is said:
*"Wash away thoughts and cleanse the heart to return to true awakening,
eat wind and drink dew as you journey westward."*

The above speaks of cultivating the nature’s root—
exhaustive and complete.

Yet the sages say that exhausting nature reaches life,
never speaking only of nature itself.

For when nature is exhausted, life attains its fullness—
life lies within the exhaustion of nature.

This is the sage’s unchanging, immutable **Dao**,
encompassing all under heaven and future generations,
so that the wise, the foolish, the virtuous, and the unworthy
may all bow and accept, or rise and reach it.

Thus, the sage rarely speaks of life,
for its principle is too subtle,
lest it arouse in people the fear of hidden, difficult-to-understand depths.

Only in the *Zhouyi*’s **Dao** of yin and yang’s harmonious exchange,
the subtleties of *Kan* and *Li*’s completion,
the mechanism of all things’ transformation and birth,
does he speak at length without tiring—
never cutting off people from their own ultimate attainment.

In the following three chapters,
the cultivation of life is clarified to perfect the holy embryo,
using the **pre-heaven** true **yi** (*乙*) within the **bing** water (*壬*) to achieve authenticity—
not by clinging to a single aspect to cultivate,
and thus forming the false image of solitary yin or solitary yang.

I have read *Waiji Zazhi*:
*"In the northeastern sea corner lies a land of women,
with no men.
Gazing into a well causes conception,
and they bear daughters."*

The text refers to it as the **"Western Liang"** Women’s Realm (*西梁女国*),*
pointing to that very place,
where it will metaphorically embody the image of a man’s body being pure and untainted by yang.

Zhongli Gong said:
*"Tears, saliva, seminal essence, qi, blood, and bodily fluids—
seven kinds of refined substances, all yin.
If one uses these to forge the elixir,
how can one ascend to the Jade Capital as a spirit?"*

For after a man’s body is broken,
his **pre-heaven** true yang is already lost—
not only is semen obstructed,
but his qi is also yin.

If one clings to cultivating life within a single body
and seeks to restore true yang,
then it is as the *Cansong Qi* says:
*"A hen broods an egg—
its chick will never be whole.
A woman marries a woman,
refining yin with yin.
Why then does she weave and spin?
Why then does she give birth and transform?"*

Cultivators of the elixir, reading the works of immortals and true sages,
encounter phrases like *"a man’s pregnancy is no different from a woman’s,"*
and thus mistakenly think to form an elixir embryo within themselves
by using their own seminal essence and blood,
as if performing the marvel of husband and wife within one’s own body.

Without a true master’s guidance,
misunderstanding the profound intent,
they become like the Tripitaka Master and the foolish monk,
drinking from the **Child-Mother River**,
conceiving a ghost-born babe,
and falling ill as a result.

The **Yellow Nurse** laughed heartily:
*"You’re drinking water from that river over there?
What a prank!"*

「Good joke! Such utter confusion truly deserves to be laughed out of court. The Nurse speaks of the **Child-Mother River**—

*"The Welcoming Yang Inn* and *Illuminating Embryo Spring*!"
She says the **Child-Mother River** flows with pure yin, merging with the Yang, yet never lingering as a station,
and that the *Illuminating Embryo Spring* yields only female offspring, never male—pure yin, no yang at all.

If one cultivates yin to form an embryo,
with a tangible body and distinct shape,
it is clearly a *"clot of blood, lump of flesh."*
*"How can a man’s body, lacking a birth passage,
ever extricate it?"*
Unless it is through the *"flawed side, where the child’s intestine is nurtured,
and the neck is mistaken for the embryonic womb—*
the *"Gentle Hands, Steady Nurse"*—
not knowing where to apply force,
fearing only to *"squeeze and rupture the sac,"*
and then needing medicine to abort the embryo.

Such cold, mocking actions,
everywhere sharp with hidden meaning,
are nothing but a farce—
a grotesque performance of reckless folly,
seeking death in life’s guise—
to ridicule the world’s blind stupidity.
Do not dismiss it as mere jest or idle play!

The Nurse points out:
*"To the true south lies the **Yang-Solving Mountain** and **Child-Splitting Cavern**,
where the Embryo Spring descends."*

Now, the **Child-Mother River**’s yin waters
that the Tripitaka Master and the foolish monk consumed
had not yet reached the *Welcoming Yang Inn*,
untainted by yang qi—
so they could say it *"dissolves yin,"*
but why call it *"Yang-Solving"*?

It is because this water,
which humans fail to grasp as true yang,
earns the name *"Yang-Solving"*—
a mountain that can dissolve the true essence of this yang water,
only then capable of shattering the false formations of yin waters.
It is not to be mistaken for *"breaking a yin embryo"* as *Yang-Solving*.

The true south is the position of the **Li** hexagram,
which clarifies the *Yang-Solving* principle.
The Spring is a well—
a well is the **Kan** hexagram.
Within *Kan* lies the **preheaven true yang**,
the **true yi water** of the **wang** cycle,
the place where *Kan* and *Li* interact in harmony,
where spinning and weaving reach their peak—
the waters surge, and true essence is born.

From the beginning of creation,
all things with form and substance
arise from and transform through this **true yi water** of the three elements and eight trigrams.
