「Thus, the **Sage’s Fire** absorbs this **true yi water** into its belly,
illuminating my **true yin mercury**—
then all the **yin evils** within my body are utterly annihilated,
just as the *Treasure of Enlightenment* says:

*"In the pool’s red dawn, yin demons vanish."*

The meaning of **true yin** and **true yang** is made clear in one verse—
the enlightened shall understand it themselves.

This is called the **"As-You-Wish True Immortal"**—
*"renovating it into the Gathering of Immortals Hall,*
*guarding the Falling Path Well."*
If one attains this **true yi water** and cultivates the body,
nothing shall be unfulfilled.

It is where the **True Immortal’s Water** resides—
the place where **Immortal Qi** converges.
One cannot obtain it lightly—
how could it not be guarded?

Yet if one seeks **true yi water**,
one must spend wealth to acquire it.

If there is no wealth,
one can only endure fate.

The **Old Mother’s** words are each a guiding clue—
she truly has a **compassionate heart for saving the world**!

The **Practitioner**, upon hearing this,
rides the clouds to the mountain,
and sees the **Old Daoist** fully explain its significance.

But why does the **True Immortal** grow angry?
Because **true yi water**, when taken in accordance with the **Dao/Way**,
becomes the **human essence**—
when taken against it,
becomes the **essence of the Immortal**—
taking it in accord is easy,
taking it against is difficult.
Easy brings fulfillment,
difficult brings no fulfillment.

The **anger and conflict** here
symbolize the difficulty of taking it against the **Dao/Way**,
fulfilling one’s wish yet not attaining it.

Unable to fulfill one’s wish,
one cannot bear to abandon the **precious virtue** of the **Sage’s Fire**.

This is why the **Sage’s Fire** and **Precious Virtue** are suddenly raised—
to contrast and debate their merits.

Without the **Yellow Mother’s** mediation,
seeking aid in vain,
the matter would never be resolved.

The **Sand Monk**, of the **earth element**,
is the **Yellow Mother**.

*"The Practitioner directly returns to the village dwelling,*
*summons the Sand Monk to seize the opportunity and take the water.
The Monk retrieves his **precious technique**,
strikes down the Daoist, and takes the water away."*

This makes clear:
without the **Yellow Mother’s** **precious staff**,
one cannot obtain the water.

*"The Practitioner snatches the True Immortal’s As-You-Wish Hook"*
—**true yi** is now in hand.

*"He breaks it into two segments,*
*then splits one of those into four."*

The **Hook** is **yi**—
for **true yi** transforms into the **Two Principles (yin-yang)**,
and the **Two Principles** into the **Four Phases (four symbols)**.

The **True Immortal** is also called **Master**—
what he holds is the **Hook**,
what he guards is the **Water**,
concealing the meaning of **preheaven true yi water** of the **wang cycle**.

*"Laughing heartily, he rides the clouds and returns"*
—seeing that what was not wished for
was taken against the **Dao/Way**,
yet now attains fulfillment.

The verse’s meaning is profound.

If one refines **true yin lead** as **yang**,
one must use this **yang water** of **true yi**.
This **yang water** is the **true yin lead** itself,
hence the saying: *"True yin lead, when refined, requires true yang water."*

Obtaining this **yang water** of **true yi**
and blending it with my **true yin mercury**,
then my **mercury** shall dry naturally—
hence the saying: *"True yang water blends with true yin mercury, making it dry."*

Yet if **true yin mercury** and **true yin lead** do not harmonize,
their **Qi** cannot be attained—
they have **form and substance** yet lack **mother Qi**,
and cannot form the **Elixir**—
hence the saying: *"True yin mercury and true yin lead lack mother Qi."*

One must add **Soul Sand** and **Flying Ascension’s** **precious medicines**—
those with **Qi yet no substance**,
are true **Immortal Elixirs**—
hence the saying: *"Soul Sand and precious medicines are Immortal Elixirs."*

If one only cultivates within the body,
it is no more than **swallowing saliva** and **absorbing Qi**,
**consuming evil** and **feasting on fluids**—
even if a **fetal form** is created,
it is a **pure yin** malady—
hence the saying: *"The child’s fetal form is falsely structured."*

Only when the **Yellow Mother** blends **golden water**
and applies the **refining technique**,
does it become the **true wondrous Dao**—
hence the saying: *"The earthly mother applies the technique—this is no ordinary matter."*

Understanding this,
one shall *"overturn false sects, uphold the orthodox teaching,*
*the mind of the Sage rejoices, returning to delight."*

This water *"requires but a single sip,*
*to dissolve the fetal Qi."*

That is—
when **true yi Qi** enters the **crucible** and illuminates the **mercury**,
it dissolves the **false embryo**,
forming the **natural Immortal fetus**—
a marvel of **one action yielding two results**.

Those who **swallow yin** and **consume substances**,
are they not **self-inflicted sins through the mouth**?

Thus it concludes:
*"Washing away oral sins, the body becomes pure,*
*melting away mortal fetuses, the body transforms naturally."*

In the **fifty-fourth chapter**,
the **Old Mother** speaks of *"slicing flesh to make a fragrant pouch"*—
this warns that when taking the water,
great peril lies ahead,
as if entering a **tiger’s den** to seize its cub,
requiring utmost caution.
Yet she has already foreshadowed the **terrifying nature** of the **Female Realm**.

The **fifty-fourth chapter** states:
*"The Western Liang Female Realm—*
*the mind-monkey devises a plan to escape the illusory world."*

A blind teacher misleads others,
severing the **ultimate Dao**—
such contrivances
not only harm life
but also disrupt **dharma-nature**.

The **Immortal Master** uses the **Western Liang Female Realm** as an allegory.

The verse says:
*"Within the realm, pure yin lacks the least yang"*—
this cuts through the confusion clearly.

For **male and female** copulation,
all things transform and are born.

The **female** attains it as **human seed**,
the **male** attains it as **Immortal seed**.
Their copulation is fundamentally distinct—
**yang** and **yin** differ in direction.

The **Female Realm’s** elderly and young women
all clap joyfully in unison:
*"The human seed has arrived!*

spreading out feasts and arranging women in rows,
displaying the palanquin—
a scene depicting the perilous ease of seduction.

*"The Queen steps forward, seizing the Tripitaka Master,
cooing, 'Brother,'*
taking his unadorned hand,
sitting together in the dragon carriage;
leaning against his fragrant shoulder,
nestling against his peach-blossom cheek;
choosing an auspicious day for the feast,
sealing their union in marriage and enthronement,"*
portraying the most soul-shattering, will-sapping affair.

*"Then came the enchanting music of pipes and drums,
the allure of rouge and powder;
her slender fingers, poised to lift the cup,
arranging the banquet seats;
a single exchange chair, the dragon bed where he was seated—
she giggled, dripping with charm: 'Little Brother, you’re also surnamed Chen.'
Then she said, 'Let me bestow a Buddhist name upon you—how about it?'
To add a man’s name to hers, clearly a sign of affection;
to call him 'Chen' while referring to the Tang, subtly hinting at his eastern journey.
The terms 'Brother, you and I,'—
the manner of asking his surname and given name—
fully captured her boundless tenderness.*

Of all human emotions, none is more easily stirred
than desire for beauty,
and what if that beauty is the queen of a nation’s charms?
What if she alone is the object of that nation’s affection?
What if she is not only the queen of beauty, wealth, and nobility,
but also adorned with every courtesy,
possessing a thousand allures and a hundred graces,
intelligence and tenderness—
side by side, cheek to cheek—
an encounter as rare and fleeting as the dawn of creation,
yet now placed in an irresistible position,
at a moment when resistance is utterly impossible?

The commentator says that among the eighty-one trials of the Three Treasures, this is the greatest of all—how true his words are! Fortunately, the Pilgrim had a scheme of *"pretending marriage to escape the net"* to revive the dead and restore life.

The Pilgrim said, *"Master, you just grant her request—I, Old Monkey, will handle it."* The logic of the world is such that the firm can be subdued by the yielding, but the yielding cannot subdue the firm. The Land of Women is the Way of yielding. When the Queen invites a husband and then abdicates, she yields even more—when yielding reaches its utmost, it becomes the utmost firmness. How then shall I deploy my own firm *qi*?

The Pilgrim said, *"Master, rest assured. In this place, encountering this person, we must turn their own strategy against them."* For she uses her utmost yielding to control me, so I shall use her utmost yielding to counter her. All her yielding is for my use—this is yielding at its peak.

Why? Because the Dao of seeking the Sutras must pass through the Land of Women—there is no way to avoid it. The Land of Women has only people, and people must not be harmed. The goal is to obtain the *tongguan xinxingbao* (pass and credentials) and thus achieve both objectives.

The Master said, *"Disciple, if we indulge in wealth and nobility here, who will go to the Western Heaven to seek the Sutras? Would we not ruin the great Tang Empire?"*

The Pilgrim said, *"If you refuse her by law, she will not exchange the pass documents and will not let us proceed. If she takes a dislike, her cruelty may be extreme—she might order many to cut your flesh to make incense pouches."* This metaphorically speaks of our great nation’s true *yang* being wounded. He added, *"Would we ever willingly harm her?"*

**"Must we fight her?"**

*"This land’s people are not monsters—still, they are people. How could you bear to slaughter countless innocents?"*
This metaphorically speaks of how that small realm’s true *yin* is wounded.

*The Awakening to Reality* states:
*"Great or small, harm none—preserve both nations whole."*
For if she is unharmed, and we are aided, then the Dao’s marvel is complete.

The Pilgrim preemptively cast the *Ding Shen* spell and devised the *"False Kinship to Escape the Net"* stratagem—tricking her into stamping the pass documents and handing them over, so they could proceed westward. *"First, we spare her life; second, we preserve your vital essence."* Is this not mutual non-harm, achieving both goals?

This false kinship, this *Ding Shen* escape—all for securing the *Tongguan Baoyin*. Without the Land of Women’s pass seal, there is no path to the Sutras. Thus, the queen must personally add the name and affix her signature.

The Western Land of Women is the critical waypoint for seeking the Sutras, hence the *Yingyang Station* and *Zhaotai Spring*—its pass documents differ from other realms.

*"The Master leaned on the fragrant shoulder, together ascending the phoenix palanquin to the Western Gate."*
The three disciples *"united in heart, harmonized in purpose, their attire in order."*

The Master bowed to the queen: *"Your Majesty, return—let your humble monk depart to fetch the Sutras."*
Zhu Bajie barked at her: *"What business do we monks have with you, this painted skeleton, as husband and wife?"*
With one shout, know this: beauty is but a skeleton, and false kinship is but the Dao.

Once the pass is secured, liberation follows—three hearts must guard against peril.
*The Knocking on the Diviner’s Song* says:
*"Snatch away the smoke and flowers, severing lustful desire,
Recite the *chan* hymns, singing the rouge-laced verses."*
*The Danjing* says:
*"The non-color is true color; the non-uniting is divine union."*
This law of nature comes from the West—its intent is to escape the painted flowers.

The queen’s pass document uniquely specifies *"Chen"*—clearly marking the journey from east to west.
East is *Zhen* (☳, male), west is *Dui* (☱, female). Ah!
*Zhen* and *Dui* in union—seemingly worldly yet transcending it;
Yin and yang paired—false marriage yet true marriage.
Following yet not following; opposing yet achieving harmony;
Using yet not using; purity yet perfect application.
Neither leaving nor clinging to female beauty—true copulation is not carnal.
*"A woman suddenly appears beside the road,"*
and seizes Tang Sanzang—beware the allure of smoke and flowers!

**Fifty-Fifth Chapter**
*The Lustful Demon’s Trickery*
*Upholding True Nature Preserves the Body*

A Disciple of Awakening says:
This passage reveals how female beauty harms—its venom rivals that of scorpions, hence *"Poison Rivaling the Mountain."*
The *"Lute Cave"* symbolizes the scorpion’s form.
When scorpions become spirits, their *yin* venom is unmatched;
When women indulge in licentiousness, their harm is even greater.
The Pilgrim struck its head, Zhu Bajie its mouth—
The Tathagata could barely endure the pain,
The Bodhisattva dared not approach.
All depict the venom’s overwhelming might—
Not a scorpion-like woman, but a woman shaped like a scorpion.

The earlier queen—maiden, human—was the necessary path for seeking the Sutras.
Without her realm’s sovereign seal, one cannot proceed westward.
To fake marriage and escape through *Ding Shen* was not only to preserve life but to refine nature.

This later woman—lustful, a detour on the path—
If one falls into her snare, the poisoned hook will strike,
And unless one steadfastly upholds true nature while resisting temptation,
One harms not only nature but life itself.

Thus, when encountering the queen’s beauty,
Use life-preserving methods to refine nature—nature thrives through life’s integrity;
When facing the lustful woman,
Use true nature’s purity to safeguard life—life is secured through nature’s virtue.

This is the essence of *"Lustful Demon’s Trickery"* and *"Upholding True Nature."*

The Western Liang women all claimed:
*"We are *White Day Ascension* Arhats,"*
*"Mistaken for Chinese men."*
This points to the Land of Women as the true realm of *Dan* cultivation—where one ascends in daylight—
Not to be confused with Chinese men as mere mortals,
For they possess such transcendence.

Regret and awakening return to the court—harm none, benefit all.

In Tang Sanzang’s first great ordeal,
He fulfilled his greatest purpose:
Securing the queen’s pass seal and adding his name—
A marvelous stroke.

The Immortal Master, fearing worldly misinterpretation—
That one might think he gained through defilement—
Cast himself into the body, even to the point of ruin,
Yet none could save him.
Thus, he offers this parable as a warning.

The green stone screen door is unbreakable;
The bee clings to flowers, reluctant to part.
*"Human flesh filling"*—concealing treachery;
*"Clear sand filling"*—disguised as beauty’s allure.
*"Wealth, honor, glory"*—still worth sharing;
*"Leisure and ease"*—only she craves delight.
*"Just right for chanting scriptures, reciting the Buddha’s words as companions,"*
Yet clear as the Buddha’s mouth, hidden as a scorpion’s heart—
Like a sheep with a tiger.
*"Do not say ‘a hundred years of harmony is true,’*
For know this: the monkey’s head, the Buddha’s hand,
The inverted hook, the pig’s snare."

The queen, though human, moves with propriety—
One may counter her schemes with guile.
This demon, however, harms life through lust—
Only brute force and spiritual resolve suffice.

Splitting the white bread roll nearly revealed a hidden treasure;
The whole roasted meat package concealed a lustful trap—
Yet the Dao-heart remained unshaken, though the human heart was exposed.

Two who converse risk stirring desire—
The two disciples rush to rescue, fearing peril.

Courageously they stand their ground,
Only then revealing the woman’s weapons’ sharp edge—
No matter if you’ve refined her in the Eight Trigrams Furnace,
Or forged her from Heaven-Roaring Golden Cangue Metal,
She’s a wanton, cheap thing—
Calling her husband to lure him in, yet wasting the iron-mouthed blade
Honed at High Old Village to pierce the earth.

Ah, the Master Tripitaka!
A true monk with true precepts—
Cloud-like emotions, rain-like intentions,
Unseen, unheard, untouched by thought—
Forged into my ten thousand pounds of refined gold.

Ah, the demon woman!
Her yin-scheming, yin-poisoned hands—
Coaxing, binding, calling out, *"Good husband, good wife!"*
Almost draining a man’s very marrow.

Ah, the Bodhisattva’s mercy!
Revealing her feet, knowing her tail,
Pointing to her true form’s subjugation—
Unless one attains supreme enlightenment.

Ah, the star Maotai!
Manifesting her form, raising her head,
Her high cries dying on the slope—
Truly, the *"day-see"* snow melts away.

When the Yang Official arrives, the lustful demon is suppressed;
When the sun reddened in the pond, the yin-monster vanishes—
Whoever steadfastly cultivates true nature
Will not let worldly desires disturb them.

Thus it is said:
*"Severing dusty ties, abandoning form’s illusion,
Pushing through the golden sea to awaken the Zen heart."*

Once, reading the Buddhist scriptures,
Mañjuśrī’s disciple Kumārajīva—
A divine monk—
Composed *The Treatise on Reality* in two volumes,
Recited at the Grass Hall Temple.
Emperor Yao Xing and a thousand high-ranking monks and officials
Sat in solemn silence, listening.

Kumārajīva suddenly left his seat and said to Xing:
*"Two boys have climbed my desire-barrier—
They need a woman."* Xing then summoned palace maids,
And after one union, two sons were born.
How could this true monk have broken the precept?
Xing further forced ten courtesans upon him,
Setting up a separate dwelling for him to receive them—
What difference is this from embracing a *pipa*?

At that time, many monks followed Kumārajīva’s example.
He then gathered needles to fill a bowl
And said to the assembly:
*"If any can match this feat, only then may you keep a wife."*
He lifted a spoonful of needles and swallowed them,
No different from eating.

The monks, ashamed, bowed in submission.

Kumārajīva had already cultivated an indestructible golden body—
Thus he could swallow needles and still conceive children,
Dispelling desire’s barrier, not breaking the precept.
Receiving courtesans was but playful *samādhi*—
Not like embracing a *pipa*.

At his passing, the funeral pyre burned his body to ashes,
Yet his tongue did not rot—
Proving his immortality.

Before attaining the elixir, how could one break precepts
And embrace a *pipa*?

The Fifth-Sixth Chapter:
*The Mad God Slays the Grass Bandits*
*The Dao-Confused Monkey Frees His Mind*

The son understood:
*"The Buddha said: ‘All minds are false minds—
This is called mind.
Why?
The past mind cannot be obtained;
The present mind cannot be obtained;
The future mind cannot be obtained.’
For the mind’s essence is empty—
Responding to all things yet not enslaved by them;
Neither within nor without—
Boundless and impartial.
Neither welcoming nor following—
Acting where there is no action.
Like a mirror, like a valley—
Things come and are reflected naturally.

Thus, though myriad changes arise,
This mind remains pure,
Never disturbed by them;
Still, never driven by them—
This is the true mind.

If, before things arrive, one has a mind to welcome them;
If, when things arrive, one is attached to them;
If, after things depart, one chases after them—
This is the Buddha’s teaching:
‘All minds are false minds.’

False minds harm the mind—
Dust accumulates, darkening the mirror;
Filth clogs, blocking the valley.

Thus, having a mind is letting the mind go;
Having no mind is truly gathering the mind.

Yet cultivating the mind in non-existence
Still risks falling back into aimlessness—
Aimlessness leads to obscured nature and trembling life,
Driving one toward death—
The mind’s root of mortality.

Only when the mind dies does nature pierce through;
When nature pierces through, life is fixed—
And returns to its origin.

The secret of eternal life lies in killing the mind;
The secret of no-mind lies in killing the mind;
The secret of killing the mind lies in forgetting the self;
The secret of forgetting the self lies in nurturing *qi*;
The secret of nurturing *qi* lies in tranquility without madness.

These three principles first warn of the harm in intentional mind,
Then of the harm in intentional no-mind,
And finally of the harm in both intentional mind and no-mind.

Only when struck before the Buddha as a six-eared macaque
Does one grasp the wondrous truth of killing the mind.

Alas! Few understand, few bear the weight—
Thus the Immortal Master must deploy his eloquence,
Unfurl the celestial maiden’s subtle tongue,
And expound these three teachings to reveal the truth.

Whether one recognizes or not is beyond calculation.

At the start of the chapter, a single word encompasses all:
*"The Spirit Platform holds nothing—this is called clarity,"*
Speaking of the mind’s original emptiness;
*"Silent, with not a single thought arising,"*
For the mind’s essence holds nothing—
Thus, the mind values no-mind;
*"Monkey and horse firmly restrained, no wildness—
Spirit steadfast, no arrogance,"*
Saying that having a mind is letting it go;
*"Banish the six demons, awaken the three vehicles,"*
Killing the mind to gather it;
*"All threads severed, clearly understood,"*
The mind dies, nature returns;
*"The color-demon forever destroyed, transcending the true realm,
Sitting in enjoyment of the Western Paradise’s bliss,"*
Nature restored, life preserved.

When Tripitaka faced the female demon’s trial,
*"Gnawing nails, chewing iron, with life’s last breath preserving his true form,"*
Like one in stormy seas asking for the rudder,
Or crossing steep mountains holding the reins tightly—
The mind was killed, not let go.

Yet ships capsize when the waters are calm;

The horse’s stumble,
always occurs when the path is level—why?
Because the mind is let go yet cannot be killed.

*"Master and disciples stood on the flat plain,
Eight Rules wielded his cudgel to urge the horse forward,
spurring everyone to move along.
The Pilgrim brandished the Golden Hoop Staff—
a shout, and the horse slipped its reins,
galloping like a bolt of lightning.
The Master could not hold the bridle,
so he let it go, releasing the full length of the reins."*

All depict the mind’s wild impetuosity,
seeing intent and letting the mind go.

Once the mind goes,
the owner loses control,
while the bandits growl like wolves.
Thus, *"Just as he was riding steadily,
he suddenly heard the sound of a cudgel—
unable to sit firm,
he tumbled from his horse."*

This is the harm of letting the mind go
while acting with intent—
as Zhang Zhuo’s *Seeing the Dao Verse* states:
*"Cutting off delusion only breeds more affliction,
Striving toward Suchness is also perverse."*

The bandits cried:
*"Here we raise a ferocious resolve,
blocking the main road,
seeking only wealth and treasure!"*

To block the main road and demand wealth—
raising a ferocious resolve—
are all acts of the mind committing theft,
harming others for self-gain.

Though the tiger seems a hero,
its ferocious resolve is the heart of a beast—
what matter this world or that?
The Master, saying *"In that world, he becomes a beast,"*
was also using the mind to urge goodness,
hoping to turn this world’s heart back—
yet he could not escape the snare of the mind.

The bandits, hearing this,
fell into such great rage
that they beat, bound, and tormented him in every way,
hoping to seize their prize,
unaware that the disaster of their own destruction
had already arrived at their heels.

*"The three disciples saw their Master dangling from a tree,
the Pilgrim bearing a blue cloth bundle on his shoulder,
approaching to call out to their Master,
asking what foul deed had befallen him.
The Master said: ‘These highwaymen demand a toll.
Since I have nothing to offer,
they’ve hung me here,
waiting only for you to settle the matter.’
The Pilgrim said: ‘Why did you speak thus to them?’
The Master said: ‘They beat me so fiercely,
I had no choice but to name you—
it was a desperate plea for help.’
The Pilgrim said: ‘I accept your offering,
and that is precisely how I am offered.’"*

Marvelous!
The Celestial Sage writes of the artful words of surrender,
the false pretenses of abuse,
yet suddenly inserts the word *"offer"*—
*"Helpless, I put you forward,"*
*"I accept your honor, that is exactly how I am offered."*
It plainly points to the greed and deceit
of those who beat and bind—
the greatest thieves among the elite—
while truly portraying the peril in one’s very life-force.

The Pilgrim feigned giving much gold,
bundling the cloth as tribute,
and quoted the ancient text:
*"Virtue is the root;
wealth is the branch."*
saying: *"This is but trifling matters."*
Indeed, he feared the words might be too obscure,
too profound for those who merely chant *"the, he, that, ah"*
or for bandits blocking the road to rob—
lest even common scholars fail to grasp such meaning.
The bandits said: *"Leave your traveling funds behind,
or we’ll resort to violence!"*
The Pilgrim said: *"Agreed—
the funds must be divided three ways."*
Then: *"Let’s secretly keep some for ourselves."*
And again: *"If there’s more,
we’ll share some with you."*

The words ring true as bandits’ threats and pleas—
their twisted tongues of *"Leave your funds behind,
or we’ll strike you down!"*
and *"We’ll secretly keep some for ourselves,
if there’s more, we’ll share it with you!"*—
reveal their malicious intent.

Yet in the *"University"*’s teaching,
*"To grasp the outer limits of punishment
while neglecting the root of fear"*—
the Pilgrim’s righteous wrath was justified,
for he struck down the two robbers without fault.

But the Elder Master, heedless of the Pilgrim,
took a wrong path;
instead, he coddled the grass-bandits,
praising the lone *"Son of the Sun"*—
thus provoking the Pilgrim’s temper:
*"Even if there are Jade Emperor, Heavenly Kings,
and all the gods—
let them come and complain,
I fear nothing!"*

Here, the **Way** is obscured by delusion,
and the heart runs wild with folly.
The tale twists and turns—
readers must discern its meaning.

*"The Elder Master harbors resentment,
while disciples feign agreement, hide dissent"*—
a heart that knows yet strays from truth.

*"The Three Treasures wielded his whip,
shouting: ‘We seek lodging there!’*
For though his heart was set on goodness,
he failed to judge right from wrong—
thus fostering robbers’ audacity,
confusing the **Way** and inviting evil,
unwittingly opening the door to mischief.

*"The Pilgrim roared in fury:
‘Leigong is my grandson,
Yechang is my great-grandson,
Mian is my great-great-grandson!’*
Here, pride swells his tongue,
while madness seizes his spirit.

*"Master and disciples ate their meal in the hut,
when the Elder asked of his lineage—
the Pilgrim replied:
‘Such a worthless son?
Why keep him?
Let me hunt him down
and strike him dead instead!’
A heart that would purge evil
yet wanders beyond restraint.

seeing the white steed,
he questioned its origin,
learning the **Sutra**-taking monk
had sought shelter here—
then burst from the hut,
clapping and laughing:

My enemy is in my home!’"

thus the conclusion:
‘**The heart’s ferocity and madness leave the elixir unripe,
the spirit’s lack of steadfastness makes the Dao unattainable.**’

*The True Pilgrim Complains of His Sufferings at Mount Lava*
*The False Monkey King Copies the Script at the Water Curtain Cave*」

chunks.translated_text:
The **Awakened One** said: *"The Dragon Clan Master spoke: ‘The greatest affliction of humanity lies in having a body; if I had no body, what affliction would remain?’ But I say: The greatest affliction of humanity lies in having a mind; if I had no mind, what affliction would remain?’*

*The *Nanhua Jing* [Zhuangzi] says: ‘I guard my form and forget my body, gaze at turbid water and lose myself in the clear depths.’ But I say: I guard my mind and forget my body, gaze at turbid water and lose myself in the clear depths. Why so?*

*The mind’s presence is the grasping of **dharma**. The mind’s presence as unvirtuous is the grasping of **non-dharma**; the mind’s presence as virtuous is the grasping of **non-non-dharma**. All sages, through **non-doing as dharma**, distinguish subtly—one must abandon **non-dharma**, abandon **non-non-dharma**; if **dharma** is abandoned, what mind remains? Thus, without guarding, without mind, the depths of all phenomena are illuminated.*

*Yet to say ‘no mind’ while letting the mind loose into **emptiness** is more harmful than having a mind. Why? Before **perfect clarity** arises, virtue and vice are confused—this is the **vast and chaotic void**. ‘The Great Sage soared in the void, advancing and retreating in difficulty; seeing the Tang Monk again, he gave no reply, seized the horse, and chanted the **Tight-Fitting Fillet Spell**.’ To let the mind loose into **emptiness** is to fall into the **vast and chaotic void**. How could one know that the **no-mind of no-mind** is both having and not having, releasing yet not releasing—thus able to reach the Western Paradise? If one is merely **vast and chaotic**, how could one go?*

*The Pilgrim said: ‘Only fear that without me, you cannot reach the Western Paradise.’ The Monk replied: ‘I truly do not need you.’ Again chanting the **mantra**, he did not turn back his mind. This was true **vast and chaotic void**. The Great Sage could only rise again into the void—desiring to have no mind while also abandoning the true mind, unable to force others to awaken to this mind.*

*Suddenly enlightened, he said: ‘This monk is faithless; I shall report him to Guanyin Bodhisattva.’ Guanyin is the **pure ocean of divine insight and discernment**. The Pilgrim said: ‘The Master has forgotten his duty and betrayed his gratitude, driving away his disciple and ruining a piece of virtuous destiny, without considering the suffering of black and white.’ His mind was deluded and unperceiving—how great was the harm of **no-mind**!*

*The Bodhisattva said: ‘The Monk’s heart is entirely virtuous; you have slain many bandits. By my judgment, it is your own unvirtue.’ If one says the heart is entirely virtuous, then the unvirtuous mind should be abandoned. The Pilgrim said: ‘Even if I am unvirtuous, my merits should offset my crimes—I should not be driven away like this.’ If one says the mind has merits and crimes, the **anger-mind** is unvirtuous, yet even the virtuous mind is abandoned—how could this be right?*

*This reporting to Guanyin Bodhisattva was not a complaint, but in the place of divine insight and wisdom, the heart’s proper abandonment and non-abandonment were analyzed, and its subtle principle was determined. Only when the **Tight-Fitting Fillet Spell** was recited was the mind truly unbound, returning to its original nature. Yet ‘the **Tight-Fitting Fillet Spell** was transmitted by the Tathagata, but there is no **Loosening Fillet Spell**’—without a spell to transmit, it arises naturally, and without reaching the Tathagata’s realm, liberation is unattainable. Thus he said: ‘I shall go and petition the Tathagata to recite the **Loosening Fillet Spell**.’*

*Marvelous, the Bodhisattva! Neither abandonment nor loosening was possible, so she said: ‘Stay here for now.’ ‘Seated upon the lotus throne, directing the mind through the **Three Realms**, with wisdom-eyes gazing afar, encompassing the universe.’ This is as the *Vajra Sutra* says: ‘One must dwell thus, subduing the mind in this way’—already hinting at the subtle realm of **no-mind**. ‘In an instant, she spoke: “Sun Wukong, your master will soon face bodily harm; he will come to seek you shortly. You must remain here—I will tell the Tang Monk to return with you to fetch the scriptures and fulfill your true destiny.”’ The Great Sage bowed in submission, standing at the foot of the lotus throne.*

*Ah! A mind of pure clarity is the Buddha’s true meaning; **calm-abiding and insight** are inseparable, dwelling in the **Three Refuges** of the mind. To release yet not release is the truth of **no-mind**. Thus the chapter’s theme is declared: ‘The True Pilgrim complains of his sufferings at Mount Lava.’*

*The Monk left the village at the fifth watch, both hungry and thirsty; the Foolish One leapt into the air, carefully observing—yet saw no trace of the village. This was the spirit not guarding its dwelling, having a dwelling yet not seeing it, observing falsely. Desiring to ease hunger but unable to obtain alms; desiring to quench thirst but unable to find water—this was the false realm of **no-mind**. Thus he suddenly saw the False Pilgrim and took him for the True; saw false water and took it for true; heard the False Pilgrim’s words ‘without me, you cannot reach the Western Paradise’ and believed it was the True coming to harass him; saw the False Pilgrim’s changing expression and took it for the True’s; saw the False Pilgrim’s cudgel striking his back and believed it was the True. In his own delusion, how could he avoid being dazed and confused on the ground, losing his satchel and scriptures without knowing? This was the harm of **no-mind**, unable to distinguish virtue, vice, truth, or falsehood.*

*Eight Rules begged for alms to obtain food, and in a moment of **no-mind**, saw a grass hut and begged for rice, changing his appearance; having filled his bowl, he met Sand Monk drawing water, joyfully returning. He thought his mind was pure, free from defilement, as if he had obtained a full bowl. How could he know that ‘the white horse broke free, neighing and galloping beside the road, while the baggage and scriptures had vanished without a trace?’*

chunks.original_text: 心因求静而转纷驰，假之乱真也如是。 八戒道：“还是孙行者赶走的余党，来此打杀师父，抢了行李。 ”沙僧道：“师父还未伤命。 ”长老道：“好泼猴，打杀我也！ ”归罪行者之赶走贼党，而不归咎唐僧之赶走行者； 知师父之未伤命，而不知师父之已失心； 见行者之打杀我，而不见似行者之打杀我； 不见我之赶逐行者，而致来似行者之打杀我； 致来似行者之打杀我，抢去包袱，而以为真行者之打杀我，抢去包袱也。 师徒识昧目迷，总缘无心之故。 八戒要讨包袱，安息师父于化斋之家。 妈妈道：“刚才说是东土往西天去的，怎么又有一起？ ”八戒笑道：“就是我。 ”盖人只一心而真假分，何曾有二？ 真去则假来，假来则所行所见无非假矣。 沙僧曰：“我去，我去。 ”则亦未免走到假处去也。 故曰：“身在神飞不守舍，有炉无火怎烧丹。 五行生克情无顺，只待心猿复进关。 ”言唐僧空具法身，而行者之真神不守，如有空炉而无火煅炼； 虽有药物，而五行各一，其性何能成丹？ 必待行者之真心来复，神运烹炼而后可。 “沙僧直抵花果山水帘洞，见行者高坐石台，朗念牒文，念而又念。 行者抬头，不认得是沙僧，叫：‘拿来！ 拿来！ ’”盖认假为真而真者去，虽念念认真而不见真； 认真为假而假者来，虽抬头遇真而犹见假。 假行者曰：“我打唐僧，抢行李，不因不上西天，亦不因爱居此地。 我今熟读了牒文，自己上西方拜佛求经，送上东土。 我独力成功，叫那南赡部洲人立我为祖，万代传名也。 ”奇哉！ 妙哉！
chunks.translated_text:
The mind, in its pursuit of stillness, only becomes more agitated—just as the False can disrupt the True in this way.

Eight Rules said, *"It must be the True Pilgrim’s remaining bandits, come here to strike and kill my master, and steal the baggage!"*
Sand Monk replied, *"My master’s life has not yet been harmed."*
The Elder exclaimed, *"You damned monkey! You’re the one who killed me!"*

He blamed the True for driving away the bandits, yet never faulted the False for driving away the True.
He knew the master’s life was unharmed, yet failed to see that the master had already lost his mind.
He saw the True striking him, yet did not see the False striking him in his likeness.
He did not see himself driving away the True, yet allowed the False to strike him in the True’s likeness.
This led to the False striking him and stealing his satchel, yet he took it as the True striking him and stealing his satchel.

Master and disciples alike were blind and deluded—all because of **no-mind**.

Eight Rules wished to reclaim his satchel and rest his master in a place of alms.
The woman said, *"Just now you said you were going from the Eastern Lands to the Western Heaven—why is there another now?"*
Eight Rules laughed, *"It is I!"*

For there is but one mind, yet true and false are divided—how could there be two?
If the True departs, the False arrives; if the False arrives, all actions and perceptions are but False.

When Sand Monk said, *"I’ll go, I’ll go,"*
he too was not exempt from wandering into the realm of the False.

Thus it is said:
*"Though the body lingers, the spirit flees without guarding its dwelling,
A furnace stands empty—how can it forge the elixir without fire?
The Five Phases of generation and restraint act without harmony,
Only when the mind-monkey returns to its pass does the Way proceed."*

The False Pilgrim was but an empty vessel of the Law’s form,
yet the True’s spirit did not abide—like an empty furnace without flame to refine.
Though the ingredients were present, the Five Phases each clashed in opposition—
how could their nature ever yield the elixir?
It must await the True’s mind returning to temper the spirit’s course,
only then could the Dao/Way be forged through divine alchemy.

Sand Monk arrived straight at the Peach Blossom Spring’s Water Curtain Cave,
where he saw the True seated high upon a stone platform,
reciting the scriptures again and again.
The True lifted his head and did not recognize Sand Monk,
shouting, *"Seize him! Seize him!"*

He mistook the False for the True, yet the True had departed—
though he recognized the True at every moment, he still did not see him.
He mistook the True for the False, yet the False had arrived—
though he raised his head to meet the True, he still saw the False.

The False Pilgrim declared:
*"I struck the False Pilgrim and stole his baggage—
not because I failed to ascend to the Western Heaven,
nor because I loved this place.
Now that I’ve mastered the scriptures,
I’ll journey alone to the Western Lands to worship the Buddha and seek the sutras,
and deliver them back to the Eastern Lands.
I’ve achieved this alone—
let the people of the Southern Continent [South Jambudvīpa] erect me as their ancestor,
and my name shall endure through the ages!"*

Wonderful! Marvelous!

chunks.original_text: 独力成功者，欲一体孤修以成道，即放心之妄想； 立祖传名者，欲专心自用以传经，非无心之真谛。 沙僧笑道：“自来没个‘孙行者取经’之说”，若说行者可取经，则即心可以悟道，如来何以必令金蝉转东到西，而授以三人护法也？ 岂不是枉费神思，有何实用？ 此处已透起下篇“一体难修真寂灭”之秘旨矣。 故假行者道：“贤弟，你但知其一，不知其二。 ”一心是真，二心是假； 一体是假，二体是真。 岂可知其一而不知其二哉？ 双关妙谛，贯彻前后文，不可忽读！ 又曰； “难道我就没有唐僧？ ”盖不识真心之妙，而弃真从假，则假心自现。 而唐僧假，八戒假，沙僧假，白马假，一假则无不假矣。 西方拜佛求经，亦第文焉而已，何能身抵其域裁？ 故曰：“假猴王水帘洞誊文。 ” “沙僧打死假僧”，显出真土。 “到南海拜菩萨”，诚溯本穷源之意。 “忽见行者站立在旁”，可知真心不离净土，而真意自会真心也。 菩萨道：“悟空到此，今已四日。 我更不曾放他回去，那里有另请唐僧，自去取经之事？ ”“你与悟空同去看看。 是真难灭，是假易除。 ”盖取经必须真僧，真僧必须真心。 真假混淆而无以深识吾心，则无以深识吾真。 乌乎! 第五十八回　二心搅乱大乾坤　一体难修真寂灭 悟一子曰：人只一心，有心者此心，无心者此心。 有心，有有心之真假； 无心，有无心之真假。 其相貌体用无二。 若未能灭假从真，则二心互持混乱不分，是非莫辨，何能攒簇五行而修真寂灭？ 此篇着笔行文，俱写二心扰乱情状，而提纲注意，其实在于“一体难修”句上。 盖“一体难修”之秘，即在“二心扰乱”之内。 故只在于打死猕猴之后，叙明“依旧合意同心”六字； 作四句诗，以结出攒簇五行修丹本旨。 仙师说法传神之妙，可谓凿鬼窍而拔天根矣！ 行者、沙僧“两道样光”，一本良心，一有疑意，已倒射起“合意同心”之义。 “二人洞外细看，果见一个行者，种种一般无二。 ”是三藏放真行者时，一并放来也。 “搅在一处，不分真假”，乃伏于自己幽独之中，非他人可代为认识者。 故即落伽山神观之目，亦所难明。 何也？ 二心俱心，非外观所能见而使之一也。 即暗念紧箍之咒，亦所难剖。 何也？ 二心本一心，非咒语所能强别而使之二也。 虽有诸天之眼力，天正之照妖镜，亦所难辨。 何也？ 二心总一行者，目力有所不能穷，照鉴有所不能及也。 即知己莫如友，而后先变辙，隐显殊情，不可定也； 知弟莫如师，而始合中离，忽来忽往，不可测也。 甚矣，真假二心之难认也！ 以其至幽至冥，而非可以显迹外貌观，是必仍于幽冥中求之。 故入幽冥森罗殿，而索之于猴簿； 而无二心，并无一心，已于大闹时一笔勾之矣！ 说到无心之谛，则知二心俱妄。 住而听之，自有真谛。 故地藏菩萨道：“且住！ 且住！ 等我着谛听与你听个真假。 ”谛听者，人所不知，而己所独知之地。 谛听俯伏在地，须臾知怪。 不曰“视”而曰“听”，不曰“听”而曰“谛听”。 黜聪堕明，而以心谛为听，明之广而聪之至也。 又“不可当面说破，不可助力擒他。 ”何以故？ 盖心有自欺之力，知无缚心之法。 知此心者此心，昧此知者亦此心。
chunks.translated_text:
The one who achieves success alone, desiring to cultivate the Dao in solitary unity, is merely indulging in the delusion of the wandering mind;
the one who seeks to establish an ancestor and transmit a name, fixating on self-centered transmission of the scriptures, fails to grasp the true essence of *wu-xin* [無心].

Sand Monk laughed and said, *"There has never been a saying of 'Sun Wukong seeking the sutras.'"*
If one claims Wukong could obtain the sutras, then enlightenment could come from mere thought—why then did the Tathāgata command the Golden Cicada to journey east to west, and entrust the protection of three disciples?

Was it not a waste of divine thought, with no practical use?
Here lies the hidden meaning of the next section: *"The difficulty of cultivating true stillness in solitary unity."*

Thus, the False Pilgrim declared, *"Worthy brother, you know only one aspect, not the two.*
The single mind is true; the dual mind is false.
The solitary unity is false; the dual unity is true.
How can you know one without knowing the other?"
This profound duality permeates the text before and after—do not read it lightly!

He further said, *"Do I not have a Tang Monk?"*
Those who fail to recognize the subtlety of the true mind, abandoning truth for falsehood, will manifest falsehood in their own hearts.
If Tang Monk is false, Eight Rules is false, Sand Monk is false, the White Horse is false—once falsehood takes root, all is false.

Seeking the Buddha in the Western Lands and obtaining the sutras is but empty words—how could one physically reach that realm?
Thus it is said: *"The False Monkey King copied the scriptures from the Water Curtain Cave."*
*"Sand Monk killed the False Monk"*—this reveals the true soil.
*"To the South Sea to worship the Bodhisattva"*—this is the sincere intent to trace the origin and exhaust the source.
*"Suddenly seeing Wukong standing beside him"*—this shows that the true mind never leaves the Pure Land, and true intent naturally aligns with the true mind.

The Bodhisattva said, *"When Wukong arrived here, four days have already passed.
I never allowed him to return—how could there be another Tang Monk summoned to seek the sutras on his own?"*
*"Go with Wukong to take a look.
What is truly difficult to extinguish is falsehood; what is easily removed is falsehood."*

For seeking the sutras requires a true monk, and a true monk must possess a true mind.
When true and false are confused and one cannot deeply discern the heart, one cannot deeply recognize the true self.

Alas! In the fifty-eighth installment—*"Two Hearts Disrupt the Great Cosmic Order"*—*"The Difficulty of Cultivating True Stillness in Solitary Unity"*—
Master Wujī said: *"Man has but one mind; those with mind possess this mind, those without mind also possess this mind.
With mind, there is true and false within the mind;
without mind, there is true and false within the absence of mind.
Their forms and functions are identical.
If one cannot extinguish falsehood and adhere to truth, the two minds will clash in confusion, unable to distinguish right from wrong—how then can one gather the Five Phases to cultivate true stillness?"*

The brushstrokes of this passage all depict the chaos of the two minds, yet the key focus lies in the phrase *"the difficulty of cultivating in solitary unity."*
For the secret of *"the difficulty of solitary cultivation"* lies within *"the disturbance of the two minds."*
Thus, only after the Monkey is struck down does the text clarify *"once again in harmony, united in heart"*—six words that encapsulate the essence of gathering the Five Phases to refine the elixir.

The Master’s teaching transcends the divine—it pierces through the demonic and uproots the celestial root!

Wukong and Sand Monk’s *"two streams of light"*—one rooted in genuine conscience, the other harboring doubt—already illuminate the meaning of *"harmony in heart and intent."*
*"The two examined outside the cave and saw a pilgrim identical in every way."*
This was when the Triple Gem released the true Wukong, bringing him along as well.
*"Mingled together, indistinguishable as true or false"*—this lies hidden within one’s own solitude, something no outsider can discern for them.

Thus, even the divine vision of the Falling Rock Mountain spirit could not perceive it.
Why?
Because the two minds are one mind, and external observation cannot unify them.

Even reciting the tight-fitting cauldron incantation could not expose it.
Why?
Because the two minds originate from one mind, and no incantation can forcibly separate them.

Even with the divine eyes of the celestial hosts or the Mirror of Demonic Detection, it remains indistinct.
Why?
Because the two minds belong to one Wukong—vision cannot exhaust its depths, nor can the mirror’s reflection reach its limits.

Even *"knowing oneself as a friend does"*—later shifts in stance, hidden and revealed emotions—cannot be fixed;
*"knowing one’s younger brother as a teacher does"*—sudden unity and separation, coming and going unpredictably—cannot be measured.

How profound is the difficulty of distinguishing true and false minds!
For they dwell in the most profound and obscure realms, beyond what can be observed through external appearances.
Thus, one must seek them within the profound and obscure.

Entering the Forest of the Dead’s Hall of Records, one searches for them in the Monkey Ledger—
and if there are no two minds, there is not even one mind, already erased in the chaos of the Great Uproar!

Speaking of the truth of *wu-xin* [無心], one realizes the two minds are both delusion.
To dwell and listen, the true essence will naturally reveal itself.
Thus, Dìzhàng Bodhisattva said, *"Wait! Wait!
Let me listen closely to discern truth from falsehood for you."*

*Dì* [谛] listening—what others cannot know, yet you alone perceive.
*Dì* listening, bowing in silence, soon recognizing the strange.
It is not called *"seeing"* but *"listening,"* nor merely *"listening"* but *"close listening."*
Rejecting sharp hearing and bright sight, using the heart’s profound listening—this is the breadth of insight and the height of perception.

Again, *"Do not expose it directly; do not assist in capturing him."*
Why?
Because the heart has the power of self-deception, and there is no method to bind the heart.
He who knows this heart possesses this heart;
he who is ignorant of this knowing also possesses this heart.

The two hearts contend, the heart refusing to obey the knowing—
instead, it rebels against knowing and disturbs the spirits of the dark depths,
so he cannot be captured.

The *Dì* listening as spoken is truly the *Dì* truth—
it must not be disrespected or neglected in listening.

*"The Buddha-Dharma is boundless,"*
already pointing directly to the marvelous realm of no-heart,
where the two hearts together cause harm.

The verse says:
*"A man with two hearts breeds calamity,
across lands and seas, suspicion and doubt arise.
He dreams of jade steeds in the Three Exalted Offices,
then counts the golden palanquin of the First Rank.
Northward campaigns and southern raids—all futile strife,
eastward and westward fleeting like the serpent’s coils—
left and right, ‘wū’ and ‘guì.’*
The Zen gate must master the secret of no-heart,
cultivating stillness to nourish the infant’s sacred essence.

Carefully ponder the last two lines—
know that no-heart alone is the One,
the true heart not belonging to the heart.

Test listening as the Buddha expounds the Dharma—
with both presence and absence unestablished,
form and emptiness leaning on neither,
only then attaining the marvelous sound.

The two hearts battle fiercely to the realm of thunderous hearing,
where the great assembly listens to their two voices—
yet none can discern.

Guanyin especially came to pay homage—
knowing the heart as heart,
but unaware of the four monkeys stirring the world,
disturbing heaven and earth.

Thus the Buddha smiled and said:
*"Your Dharma-powers are vast,
yet you can only universally survey the affairs of the revolving heavens,
not thoroughly know the things of the revolving heavens,
nor broadly gather the categories of the revolving heavens."*
Meaning you cannot grasp the fullness of things,
but deeply understand the stirring heart of the world.

*"Four monkeys"* refers to the four wisdoms of the heart.
The luminous clarity originates from the primordial heaven,
knowledge arises from the subsequent heaven.
From the presence of subsequent knowledge,
the primordial luminous clarity is disturbed by it,
so the knowledge-heart must be extinguished,
and the luminous clarity-heart will then manifest itself.

The false awakening of emptiness is the six-eared macaque—
the term for *"six consciousnesses."*
The Buddha did not allow this six-consciousness to arise,
covering the bowl and alms-basket with the round emptiness vessel,
revealing its true form—
striking with the luminous clarity-heart,
a single blow to the head, killing the heart.
The marvelous *Dì* of the dead heart is thus.

Yet this kind remains extant to this day,
and those who say *"this kind is utterly extinct today"*—
it is because the Buddha’s bowl and alms-basket,
and the golden cudgel of the false awakening of emptiness,
still exist to extinguish it today.

The *Book of Documents* states:
*"Unknowing and unrecognizing, follow the Dao of the Emperor."*

The *Book of Poems* says:
*"The Supreme Lord watches over you—
do not let your heart be divided."*

chunks.translated_text:
「"Recognizing and knowing are not the marvelous Dao/Way of the transmitted heart—
the single heart is the Supreme Lord’s heavenly heart.

Once the false practitioner is eliminated,
the false Tang Monk and false Eight Rules are struck down together—
then the heart has no divergent inclinations,
and the Dao/Way may be subtly cultivated.

Discard the heart’s semblance of the Dao/Way,
illuminate the Dao/Way’s harmony with the heart,
and elucidate the essential principle of unified mind and intention—
refining the true mechanism of the Five Phases’ convergence;
preparing the chariot and steeds,
the Great Dao/Way is in sight.

Thus it concludes:
*"The Great Dao/Way, midway, departs from chaotic Five Phases,
subduing demons to gather in the unified luminous essence.
Divine returns to the heart, abandoning meditation’s fixed path,
six consciousnesses purged, the elixir naturally forms."*
This is the *"true Nirvana"* of true meditation,
the *"one body, hard to cultivate"* of its profound intent.

**The Fifty-Ninth Chapter: Tang Monk obstructed by the Fire-Flame Mountain**
**Sun Monk adjusts the Banana-Leaf Fan**

The Awakened One said:
*"Dual-heartedness is not merely the mingling of Dao-heart and human heart,
nor just the Dao-heart’s feeble doubt at halfway—
it is also not just one person with two hearts,
but three disciples with three hearts,
and those who fail to align with the Tang Monk.*

*Why?*
*For the three families must unite as one to form the embryo.*
*If only one body cultivates alone,
it is hard to attain true Nirvana.*

Thus:
*"The Three Treasures followed the Bodhisattva’s teaching,
retrieving the Monk and severing the Eight Rules’ and Sha Monk’s dual hearts,
locking away the monkey-steed,
uniting their efforts to press onward toward the Western Heaven."*

*This chapter links the previous meditation on nature’s essence,*
*and sets forth the subsequent marvelous cultivation of life.*

*The Fire-Flame Mountain of this passage*
*is the true Yang’s ascending flame.*
*True Yang must be aided by true Yin to achieve balance,*
*and thus generate all things.*
*If Yang is one-sided without Yin,*
*then the ultimate Dao/Way loses its center,*
*the dharma-nature remains incomplete,*
*though one may possess myriad thoughts and deliberations,*
*they will still result in illusion.*

*Wandering east and west on false paths,*
*how can one gather the golden elixir,*
*and refine it into the Great Dao/Way?*
*The opening line specially declares:*
*"If myriad natures originally share the same essence,
the sea holds boundless capacity."*

*It speaks of the unity of human and self—*
*not separable from humanity alone.*
*"Thousand thoughts and deliberations end in delusion,*
*all colors and forms merge indistinctly."*

*It speaks of the divine mind and all colored forms,*
*all becoming illusion—*
*must be dissolved without trace.*
*"When the day’s labor is complete and the path fulfilled,*
*the round and luminous dharma-nature ascends supreme."*

*It speaks of knowing that human and self share the same nature,*
*and that unified cultivation of body and mind,*
*when labor is complete and the path fulfilled,*
*will bring forth the unsurpassed round dharma-nature.*

*"Do not let differences stray east and west,*
*lock them tightly in the cage.*
*Bring them back to settle within the elixir furnace,*
*refine them into the golden phoenix’s hue—*
*as red as flame."*

*It speaks of this path from east to west,*
*the sole way for seeking the scriptures,*
*do not let differences stray east and west.*
*Diligently cultivate, returning all to your own furnace,*
*then you may refine your own Yin elixir of the golden phoenix,*
*and attain the same hue as the Yang elixir.*

*"Luminous and radiant, delicate and resplendent,*
*let me ride the dragon in and out at will."*

*It speaks of attaining this round and radiant essence,*
*the original source of all—*
*let me ascend to heaven upon the dragon at will.*

The Three Treasures inquired:
*"Why does autumn still have heat?"*

The Eight Rules wondered if it were the country of *Sīhāli* (Shahāli),
where the sun sets;

The Sha Monk suspected it was due to *falling into summer order*.

Seeing the redness of the farmstead by the roadside,
it was merely the color of the Fire-Flame Mountain’s heat—
no deeper meaning.

The old man said:
*"Our land is hot in all four seasons,
it is the necessary path to the Western Realm."*

*He reveals that those who seek the elixir*
*must pass through this true Yang region,*
*refining and tempering it,*
*and abandon all other paths for seeking the scriptures.*

*"Red chariot,"*
*"hot breath of the cake,"*
*again alludes to the fiery hue.*

*The secret of entering the fire and sowing seeds*
*requires true Yin to aid,*
*only then can they be nurtured,*
*hence the saying:*
*"If you wish for cake’s flour and rice,*
*respectfully seek the Iron-Fan Sage."*

*The Banana-Leaf Fan, once waved,*
*stills the fire,*
*twice waved, raises the wind,*
*thrice waved, brings forth the rain—*
*the meaning of the Three Yins arising,*
*and the *Kūn* Dao/Way being fulfilled.*

*The Iron-Fan Sage resides in the southwest,*
*on the Jade-Green Cloud Mountain,*
*within the Banana-Leaf Cave.*
*The southwest is the *Kūn* direction,*
*as the *Yìjīng* says:*
*"The southwest gains companions."*

*"Jade-Green Cloud,"*
*"Banana-Leaf,"*
*borrowed to convey the meaning of a verdant, cool cave,*
*able to dispel the summer’s heat.*

*"Red flowers, inner and outer alike,*
*truly sought, only then obtained,"*
*is the same as:*
*"To seek celestial treasures,*
*one must use worldly wealth."*

*The woodcutter spoke of knowing the Iron-Fan Princess*
*is the *Luo Sā* (Rākṣasī) woman,*
*the wife of the Bull Demon King,*
*and Sun Monk was startled.*

*Borrowing the fan’s difficulty,*
*he recalled the tale of the Red Boy*
*and the Broken Cave at the Sunlit Mountain,*
*seeing that what the Rākṣasī loved was the Treasure of Virtue.*

*Now the Treasure of Virtue is unseen,*
*and there are no red flowers or outer/inner alike,*
*yet he dares to borrow the fan with empty hands—*
*is this not again the same as the Broken Cave at the Sunlit Mountain?*

*"Though the Monkey Girl may show her utmost solicitude,*
*it cannot pacify the Rākṣasī’s rage in her heart.*
*Only because the Treasure of Virtue is not seen,*
*does she push open the Eight Ten Thousand Paths with a single wave."*

*The dialogue between Sun Monk and the Rākṣasī*
*is a segment-by-segment, winding description,*
*all implying that to seek true treasures,*
*one must have wealth—*
*no matter how clever in words or forceful in action,*
*it is all in vain.*

*Sun Monk was blown by the Yin wind to the Xiao Xūmǐ Mountain,*
*and sighed:*
*"What a formidable woman!"*

*Knowing she could not be approached lightly,*
*yet not easily approached either.*

*He remembered the Venerable Lingjì Bodhisattva,*
*who, when inquiring about the path and progress,*
*spoke of the Banana-Leaf Fan as:*
*"The Banana-Leaf Fan was originally*
*a divine treasure of Kunlun Mountain,*
*from the time of Chaos’s primordial opening.*
*It is the essence of the Great Yin,*
*hence its power to extinguish fire."*」

chunks.translated_text:
The essence of Great Yin’s true water
clearly subdues the true fire of fierce flames.
If one employs the treasure of calming winds
with proper method to obtain it,
what need be feared of not achieving great success?
The Lingjì’s aid with the Calming-Wind Pill
is indeed an essential practice for sincere cultivation.

Having obtained the Calming-Wind Pill,
Sun Monk then borrowed the fan,
stacking three together—
unshaken, as a stable foundation brings peace,
a prosperous land and contented people,
seeking battle to gain from others
while suffering no loss to oneself.

*"Clutching the pill in his mouth,
he transformed into a cicada,
entering her belly."*

This speaks of utter sincerity,
placing one’s heart within another’s,
so that no secrets remain—
as if seeing their very lungs and liver—
only then can mutual aid be attained.

This is not achieved through deceitful tricks,
but through genuine sincerity that moves the heart.

Sun Monk said:
*"I, Old Monkey, have never practiced deceitful arts—
only true methods, genuine power,
already playing within your honored wife’s womb,
already seeing her lungs and liver."*

This is the divine interplay of inherent principle and qi,
not the result of contrived techniques.

*—As in the* **Odes***.*

chunks.original_text: 云“式饮庶几”，“式食庶几”，乃是以诚相动。 故曰：“我知道你饥渴了，我送个坐碗儿解渴。 ”又曰：“我再送个点心你充饥。 ”此等恭敬诚求之妙喻，真笔歌墨舞，极文人之乐事矣！ 然我以诚求，而彼以伪应者何？ 罗刹先有言矣，曰； “陷子之仇，尚未报得； 借扇之意，岂得如心？ ”子者，母之息也。 母不见子，则无利以悦其心。 虽用吾恭敬之心，而未用我亲爱之意。 才能得扇，而不能得其真扇。 以其情未尽输，而真宝犹匿也，总由我未能深识耳。 故行者得假扇而不能辨，取而误用之，一扇，二扇，三扇，而火光益炽矣。 夫火为取经必由之路，既不能别转无火之方； 扇为取经济火之宝，又不可假借无用之物。 自必依有力为之，盖“见金夫而不有躬”也。 “头顶偃月冠”之老人，自能深明炉火中之法物。 古仙云：“偃月炉中摘下来”，良有秘旨。 故曰：“若还要借真芭蕉，须是寻求大力王。 ”寻求大力之义，一以结求取真阴，必须善用法财； 一以起下真阴走失，如大力王之难制。 句内包涵要诀，如神龙夭矫，莫测其首尾。 第六十回　牛魔王罢战赴华筵　孙行者二调芭蕉扇 悟一子曰：大力王为真阴之主，欲得真阴，必先寻大力。 牛为阴土而大力，为魔王则更大，谓其易纵而难擒。 《参同契》曰：“太阳流珠，常欲去人。 卒得金华，转而相因。 ”言人身阴精，为太阳之流珠，如铅里之汞，易于走失。 若能得金华之铅气以制之，则可转而济火之炎，以相固结。 此牛王之赴华筵，而转得与罗刹相会，即影借金华铅气之义，而因得会合真明之妙也。 心属火，肾属水。 火为阳，水为阴。 猿以喻阳，牛以喻阴。 其初则同原，而继则相射，终相为用。 “五百年前曾结兄弟”，溯其由来也。 土地道：“这火原是大圣放的，”实为确理。 先天八卦颠倒而入于后天，《离》火所由偏胜。 人见君火之偏胜，而不知由己之颠倒致之，故曰“你也认不得我了”。 曰“五百年前大闹天宫时”，曰“老君八卦炉内煅炼”，曰“开炉时蹬倒落下余火”，曰“我本是守炉的道人。 ”其说井然，非牵合之枝论。 《离》火非得《坎》水，不能济炎而成中道，故必寻求大力，以借真阴。 真阴者，水也，《巽》女主之，非借大力，不能必得，故须从百方家财之处，求大力王也。 然有大力者，必有色欲之外诱。 “现在积雷山摩云洞”，言雷动而云行雨施，恣情纵欲也。 “玉面公主，百万家私”，言财色两齐，而其欲易纵。 “弃了罗刹，久不回顾”，言罔顾真阴，久而不返。 火焰益炽，无可相济。 “寻着牛王，拜求来此，方借得真扇”者，言须戒欲制情，保固弗失，如夫妻相守而不离，然后可得真阴以济炎也。 “积雷山坐落在正南方”，《离》位也，后天真阴之所，乃为外宅次妻，非如铁扇之元配，为先天而有真扇也。 “行者找寻消息，忽见松阴下有一绝色女子，手折了一枝香兰，袅袅娜娜而来。 ”正阴精出现之象。 至假意探问，托词激怒，以及吓走跟随，倒怀撒娇，哭笑温存，诸般情态，写得有声有色，恍然如见其形，如闻其语。 所以明尤物动人，堪爱堪怜； 大力之系恋，销魂夺魄也。
chunks.translated_text:
The lines *"式饮庶几"*, *"式食庶几"*—
this is the art of touching hearts with sincerity.

Thus it is said:
*"I know you are thirsty,
so here’s a bowl to drink—
let it quench your thirst."*

And again:
*"Now here’s a bite to eat—
let it fill your hunger."*

Such delicate, respectful metaphors of true sincerity—
a brushstroke of divine calligraphy,
a dance of immortal ink—
these are the joys of the literati!

Yet when I seek with sincerity,
and they respond with falsehood—
what then?

The Demoness of the Sandstorm had already spoken:
*"Your vengeance against me remains unfulfilled,
and how could I ever lend you my fan
as you wish?"*

*Child* (子) is the breath of the mother (母).
If the mother does not see her child,
then no kindness can please her heart.

Though they use my respectful heart,
they do not employ my true affection.
They may grant me the fan,
but not the *true fan*—
for their emotions are not fully surrendered,
and the precious treasure still hides itself.
All because I have not yet understood them deeply.

Thus, the Pilgrim takes the false fan,
unable to discern its nature,
and misuses it—
first fan, second fan, third fan—
while the flames grow ever fiercer.

For fire is the path to scripture-taking,
and since he cannot find a way without fire,
the fan is the treasure of true yin
to temper the flames of passion.
Yet he cannot borrow what is useless—
he must depend on his own strength,
as in *"seeing the golden husband but not possessing him."*

The old man with the *upside-down moon crown*—
he alone knows the true treasures within the furnace.
The ancient sage said:
*"Plucked from the upside-down moon furnace,"*
and there lies a profound secret.

Thus it is said:
*"If you still wish to borrow the true fan,*
*seek the Great Strength King."*

The meaning of seeking great strength—
first, to bind and take the true yin,
requiring mastery over the *law treasures*;
second, to restrain the wandering true yin,
for the Great Strength King is hard to control.

The verses contain essential keys,
like the divine dragon coiling in flight,
its head and tail beyond measure.

---
**Sixty-First Chapter**
*The Bull Demon King Ceases Battle and Attends the Banquet*
*The Sun Wukong Twice Persuades the Fan*

Thus the Sage said:
*"The Bull Demon King is the master of true yin.*
*To obtain true yin,*
*one must first seek the Bull of Great Strength."*

The Bull is yin-earth and great strength,
but as a Demon King, his might is even greater—
for he is easily unrestrained
and hard to capture.

*The Classic of Correlating Correspondences* says:
*"The Great Sun flows its pearl,*
*always desiring to leave man.*
*Yet when it meets the Golden Phoenix,*
*it turns and binds with it."*

This speaks of the yin-essence (阴精) in man’s body—
the pearl of the Great Sun,
like mercury in lead,
easily lost.

If one can obtain the *Golden Phoenix’s yin-qi* (金华铅气) to restrain it,
then it may turn to temper the fire’s heat,
binding and stabilizing it.

This is the Bull King’s attendance at the Banquet,
and his turn to meet the Demoness—
the shadowed borrowing of the Golden Phoenix’s yin-qi,
and thus the chance to unite with true enlightenment.

The heart belongs to fire,
the kidneys to water.
Fire is yang, water is yin.
The monkey symbolizes yang,
the bull symbolizes yin.

At first, they share the same origin,
then they repel each other,
and finally serve one another.
*"Five hundred years ago, we swore brotherhood,"*
tracing their beginnings.

The Earth Spirit said:
*"This fire was originally set by the Great Sage,"*
a truth confirmed.

The eight trigrams of the Primordial Dao were inverted
and entered into the Postnatal—
the fire of *Li* (離) grew dominant.
Men see the *Li* fire’s excess,
but do not know it comes from their own inversion,
thus saying: *"You no longer recognize me."*

*"Five hundred years ago, when I raided the Celestial Palace,"*
*"when Laozi refined me in his Eight-Trigram Furnace,"*
*"when the furnace was opened and I knocked over the remaining flames,"*
*"I was the Daoist who guarded the furnace."*
His words are clear and well-reasoned,
not a forced argument.

The *Li* fire cannot temper the flames of passion
without the *Kan* water (坎水),
and thus it must seek the Great Strength
to borrow true yin.

True yin is water,
governed by the *Xun* consort (巽女).
Without borrowing the Great Strength,
it cannot be fully obtained—
thus one must seek the Bull Demon King
through all means of wealth and treasure.

Yet those with great strength
must be tempted by external desires.

*"Now residing at Accumulated Thunder Mountain in Cloud-Drift Cave,"*
speaking of thunder stirring the clouds,
of rain falling at will—
of unrestrained lust.

*"The Jade-Faced Princess, with a hundred thousand treasures,"*
speaking of wealth and beauty together,
and desires easily indulged.

*"Abandoning the Demoness, never looking back,"*
speaking of neglecting true yin,
of never returning.

The flames grow fiercer,
with nothing to temper them.

*"Seeking the Bull King, bowing to beg his aid here,*
*only then can I borrow the true fan—*
for one must restrain desire,
control emotions,
guard true yin without losing it,
as husband and wife remain inseparable,
only then can true yin be obtained
to temper the flames."*

*"Accumulated Thunder Mountain lies to the south,"*
the position of *Li*—
the place of postnatal true yin,
a secondary consort in the outer chamber,
not like the Iron Fan’s original mate,
who holds the true fan of the Primordial Dao.

*"The Pilgrim searched for clues,*
*and suddenly saw beneath the pine shade*
*a woman of extraordinary beauty,*
*plucking a fragrant osmanthus branch,*
*gracefully swaying as she approached."*
A true sign of yin-essence manifesting.

When he feigned curiosity to inquire,
used pretexts to provoke anger,
and then frightened away her attendants,
when he embraced her and played coy,
when he wept, laughed, and spoke tenderly—
all her emotions were vividly depicted,
as if one could see her form,
hear her very words.

Thus it is made clear:
how alluring objects move the heart,
worthy of love and pity;
how the Bull’s attachment
melts the soul and steals the breath.

This is not achieved through deceitful tricks,
but through genuine sincerity that moves the heart.

Sun Monk said:

chunks.original_text: 牛王与行者相见，话旧叙温，说明善财极乐之故，已见善财之宜舍矣。 牛王道。 “害子之情，被你说过； 你才欺我爱妾，打上找门，何也？ ”分明道出善财可舍，而美色必争，以见大力殉色之由。 大圣叩求周济，借扇息火，说到“兄长开天地之心，同小弟到大嫂处一行。 ”言《坎》、《离》济舍，为天地之心； 夫唱妇随，乃阴阳之道。 长兄不到大嫂处，则真阴不相见，而真阳不相济矣。 牛王以欺妻灭妾而狠力争持，总状其好色不好德之意。 忽闻“早临安座”之请，而罢战赴筵者，言既迷于色，则必耽于酒，非此则彼。 神情淆乱。 沉沦水窟而横行乱走，能不自失其辅身之脚力？ 然酒者，水金也。 得金华而罢战、有转而相因之机。 故行者卒得金睛兽，而变牛魔王； 魔王卒得散华筵、而来会罗刹也。 “乱石山碧波潭”，浊中还有清； “蟹介士不知礼”，横行岂无直？
chunks.translated_text:
The Bull King met the Pilgrim,
exchanged old greetings and warm words,
and explained the reason for the son’s journey to Bliss—
now the son’s worthiness of renunciation was clear.

The Bull King spoke:
*"The grief of harming my child,
you have already spoken of;
yet you deceived me with my beloved consort,
stormed my gate—why so?"*

He plainly declared that the son could be renounced,
yet beauty must be seized—
thus revealing how the Bull’s devotion to color
led him to perish for its sake.

The Great Sage begged for aid and relief,
asked to borrow the fan to quell the flames,
and spoke of *"brother’s heart of opening heaven and earth,
leading little brother to visit the elder sister."*

He spoke of *Kan* and *Li* aiding and renouncing—
this was the heart of heaven and earth;
husband leading, wife following—
this was the Way of yin and yang.

If the elder brother did not visit the elder sister,
true yin would not be seen,
and true yang would not be aided.

The Bull King, enraged by deceit of wife and destruction of consort,
fiercely contested—
all to show his love of beauty and hatred of virtue.

When he heard the request to *"come quickly to the feast,"*
he abandoned battle for the banquet—
for once lost to color,
he would surely drown in wine,
one obsession replacing another.

His spirit and emotions were in chaos.
Lost in the watery abyss, rampaging wildly—
how could he not lose his own supporting strength?

Yet wine is water-gold.
Obtaining the Golden Flower,
he ceased his battle,
and there was room for change and transformation.

Thus the Pilgrim ultimately gained the Golden-Eyed Beast,
and transformed the Bull Demon King;
the Demon King ultimately gained the Scattered Flower Feast,
and came to meet the Rakshasa.

*"The Green Wave Pool among the chaotic rocks,"*
even in filth, there is purity;
*"The crab and shellfish know no decorum,"*
yet even in recklessness, there is order.

chunks.original_text: 大圣窃兽变形，径到芭蕉洞，读者谓骗借真扇之幻术，不知乃采取真阴之实理。 火眼金睛之大圣，而跨辟水金睛之神兽，水火有相见之象。 心猿以为之心，牛魔以为之体，心肾有交济之形。 夫见旧妻，而亲爱益饶； 妻见金夫，而绸缪愈密。 形虽假合，理有真机，其宝不觉吐露其间，固有天然之妙用也。 极拟夫妻叙阔，姿态横生，或终笑中带妒，或肃雍内含娇； 或假怒里默逗真心，或娇嗔处勾取实话。 携手温腮，跃跃然描画出戏水双鱼； 雨意云情，几几乎洗不清巫山十二。 读者谓深得夫妇闺中比昵之情状，然遗却寓言妙道矣。 其曰：“大王宠幸新婚，抛撇奴家，今日那阵风儿吹你来的？ ”言恋身外之妻而抛身内之妻，一朝返顾，为可幸也。 其曰：“非敢抛撇，只因玉面公主招后，家事冗繁，朋友多顾，是以稽留在外，却也又置得一个家当了。 ”言被财色外诱，迷恋稽留，不能内顾，因致外重而内轻也。 “其故意发怒骂道：‘那泼猴儿时过去了？ ”’又拍胸道：“可惜！ 可惜！ 夫人错了，怎么就把这宝贝与那猴狲？ 抱杀我也！ ”言取经之道，非得真阴，不能前进，岂能舍真扇而过去？ 又岂能舍我而得真扇？ 若夫人就与宝贝，仅是错也。
chunks.translated_text:
The Great Sage stole the beast and transformed its form,
then directly arrived at the Banana Grove.
The reader may think this was a trick—borrowing the true fan’s illusory technique—
but in truth, he seized the very principle of *yin* essence.

The Fire-Eyed Sage, with his Golden-Eyed Beast,
straddling the Water-Splitting Beast—
water and fire now share a meeting in form.

The Monkey-Heart takes it as heart,
the Bull-Demon as body—
heart and *yin* now intermingle in harmony.

When seeing his old wife again,
her affection only deepens;
when the wife sees her golden husband,
their bonds grow ever tighter.

Though their union is borrowed in form,
the principle holds true essence—
how could the treasure not naturally reveal itself?
There lies a natural marvel beyond artifice.

They mimic the joy of reunited spouses,
postures brimming with life—
sometimes laughter hides a trace of jealousy,
sometimes solemnity conceals coquettishness;
sometimes feigned anger betrays true affection,
sometimes playful pique draws out honest words.

Hand in hand, cheeks pressed warm,
they leap like twin fish playing in water;
clouds and rain in their glances—
almost too vivid to wash clean the Twelve Peaks of Wu.

The reader may say they’ve captured the intimate tenderness of married love,
yet they’ve overlooked the profound allegory.

She says: *“Your Majesty favors your new bride,
abandoning me—what wind today blew you here?”*
Speaking of loving an external wife while neglecting the inner one—
a fortunate turn when he finally looks back.

She says: *“I never meant to abandon you—
only that Princess Jade-Face was crowned queen,
household affairs grew burdensome,
and friends demanded my attention,
so I lingered outside—
yet I’ve even set up another household.”*
Speaking of being seduced by wealth and desire,
lingering in distraction,
unable to turn inward,
thus making the outer heavy and the inner light.

Then, feigning anger, she scolds: *“When did that damned monkey pass through?”*
And slaps her chest: *“Alas! Alas!
My lord was wrong—
how could you give this treasure to that monkey?”
“It kills me!”*
Speaking of the Way of the Pilgrimage—
without true *yin*, one cannot advance.
How could one pass without the true fan?
And how could one obtain the true fan without me?
If the wife had given the treasure,
that would be a true mistake.

「Then she says: *“My lord, you are newly married to the Great Sovereign—
do not forget your true bond of *yin* and *yang*,
and drink a cup of this native *yang* water.”*
Speaking of how the true *yin* and *yang* within one’s body are like the bond of marriage,
while the *yin* and *yang* outside are like foreign waters—
one must not indulge in fleeting desires
and forget the source of one’s true essence.

Then she says: *“I, due to my concern for external governance,
have been long separated from my lord,
yet night and day I guard and protect your ancestral domain.”*
Speaking of when *yin* and *yang* lose their proper alignment,
and one must bolster the *yang* essence—
this requires strengthening the *yin* foundation.

Then she says: *“‘Kang’ (康) is harmony (齐).
‘My lord is the *yang* parent that nurtures the body.’”*
Speaking of how *yin* and *yang* in perfect balance
bring forth the flourishing of all things;
true *yin* without *yang* cannot sustain and nourish the ten thousand beings.

When they stand side by side, leaning down to embrace,
and speak in unison to nourish the treasure,
clinging to each other in intimacy,
and reveal the *bao-bei* (宝贝),
the profound interplay of *yang* revering *yin*
and the mutual devouring of opposites
is beyond mere description or analogy.

The Great Sage gains the treasure,
lost in dark musings and divine contemplation,
while the Demon Queen, drunk on wine,
speaks of true sentiment and principle.

For the treasure is originally my family’s heirloom—
yet through reckless indulgence and dissipation,
I lost sight of its true nature,
and now cannot even recognize it.

Thus the Demon Queen says:
*“Great King, you must have been day and night lost in pleasure,
your mind clouded by that Princess Jade-Face,
so how could you forget even your own treasure?”*

For those in the world who live in dreams or drunkenness,
these few words can serve as a sharp awakening.

*“With the left thumb holding seven strands,
chanting ‘□ left “mouth” (口), right “four” (四),
hush, exhale, inhale, laugh, blow, breathe’—
it instantly grows two zhang and two chi in length.
This treasure transforms endlessly—
a fire of eight hundred *li*,
which can be extinguished with a single fan.”*
Speaking of restraining the seven emotions,
while channeling the singular *qi* (气) of the fingers—
true *yang* then flourishes,
and its boundless transformations unfold,
as the nine palaces and eight trigrams
are all but manifestations of this *yang* water’s wondrous effects.
Extinguishing flames and tempering heat—
what could be more difficult?

The Great Sage holds the true treasure in hand,
demonstrating its methods,
yet lacking the incantation,
he clutches it to his shoulder.
This cannot be swallowed whole,
nor transformed at will—
thus he cannot keep it without losing it again.

The Bull Demon King scatters the feast,
the Water-Beast having been stolen,
yet the lead is dispersed and true *mercury* (真汞) loses control.
The cause of the Crab’s reckless rampage is understood,
and the scheme of Monkey’s theft of the beast is revealed—
seeing remorse and regret, there remains a chance for return.

Riding the clouds straight back to the Green Cloud,
the Demon Queen shouts in rage: *“Heaven-damned!”*
Both husband and wife were careless,
thus the true treasure was lost,
and they are now in frantic haste.

The monkey steals the grandmother’s treasure,
the Bull King seizes the grandmother’s weapon—
true and false *yin* and *yang* are both disordered,
and Wood, Metal, Water, Fire all clash at once.

**Chapter 61: Zhu Bajie Lends His Strength to Break the Bull Demon King
Sun Wukong’s Three Attempts to Borrow the Banana Fan**

A scholar once remarked:
Readers compare *“Three Attempts to Borrow the Banana Fan”* (三调芭蕉扇)
with *“Three Visits to the Thatched Hut”* (三顾茅庐)
and *“Three Battles at Zhu’s Village”* (三打祝家庄),
as though these were all sacred *Daoist* talismans (宝箓),
mere set phrases in the novel.
It is like reading *The Strategy of the Rabbit Garden* (《兔园策》)
and *The Dragon-Tiger Scripture* (《龙虎经》)
without discerning their true distinctions.

The Fire-Flame Mountain descends from heaven,
meeting the earth—
this is the union of *Qian* (乾, Heaven) and *Kun* (坤, Earth),
giving rise to the three *yang* (阳) energies,
the Great Sage’s primordial *yang* *qi* (真动之气) transformed,
as explained by the adept who guards the Eight Trigram Elixir Furnace (八卦丹炉之道人).

**The First Attempt (一调):**
The Great Sage, dwelling in *Kun* (Earth),
seeks to borrow from *Qian* (Heaven).
In the first borrowing, *Xun* (巽, Gentle Wind) is born as the eldest daughter—
*Xun* is wind, hence the fan;
obtained from *Qian*’s Metal (金), hence the Iron Fan Princess (铁扇公主).
As the eldest daughter of Earth (土),
she is the first *yin* (阴) to appear.

**The Second Attempt (二调):**
The Great Sage, dwelling in *Kun* (Earth),
borrows again.
In the second borrowing, *Li* (离, Fire) is born as the middle daughter—
*Li* is fire, hence she sits in the south,
the symbol of a sovereign facing south,
thus the Jade-Face Princess (玉面公主) is obtained.
As the middle daughter of Earth,
she is the second *yin* to appear.

**The Third Attempt (三调):**
The Great Sage, dwelling in *Kun* (Earth),
borrows a third time.
In the third borrowing, *Dui* (兑, Joy) is born as the youngest daughter—
*Dui* is the marsh, the union of Water and Metal;
positioned in the west with a white hue,
hence the White Bull (白牛).
The bull belongs to Earth yet bears Metal,
traversing all nine palaces,
its power vast—
thus the Great Power King (大力王),
the *yang* parent that nurtures the Iron Fan Princess’s body,
the true *yin* sovereign—
thus the third *yin* appears,
and the true fan is offered.

Through *Kun*’s three borrowings,
three *yin* energies emerge,
to subdue the fire and nurture all things—
all rooted in the primordial *yin* *qi* (真乙之气).
This is the subtle essence of the Great Sage’s
first, second, and third attempts to borrow the fan.

*“If I were to demand it directly from his face,
he would certainly refuse.
But if he fans me once,
I would be sent eight hundred and forty thousand *li* away!”*
This reveals how *yin* and *yang* have cycles of mutual borrowing,
and how Earth can act as the guiding *qi* (用神).

Above, it can adapt and shift with the flow—
Earth subdues Water in reverse borrowing,
yet Water may also bring harm in its counterattack.
Earth borrows Wood in false alignment,
yet Water naturally brings growth and benefit.

Thus it is said:

The practitioner seeks the true *yin* within *Lǐ*

for Earth resides in the Central Palace and never departs.

*"He recognizes the path while traveling,"*

strive with fierce resolve,
forging harmony between Metal and Wood,
thus manifesting the true *yin*—
hence, the Jade-Faced Princess of Accumulated Thunder Mountain
comes to lend her strength.

*"The Eight Rules, vexed by the difficulty of obtaining the fan,

lest impatience and doubt arise.

The Earth Spirit says:
*"Great Sage, do not grow anxious,
Tianpeng, do not slacken.
To speak of an alternate path
is to enter a side door,
not the way of true cultivation.
Your master sits upon the straight path,
longingly awaiting your success."*
This means only the Great Sage’s Metal
and Tianpeng’s Wood,
when joined and united in purpose,
can exert bold action
to obtain the true *yin* Water
and fulfill the Great Dao.

If one abandons this and seeks an alternate path,
it is to forsake the true Dao for a side door—
Water and Fire cannot be *Jìjí*,
how then could one find the path to the West and retrieve the scriptures?

This is the Dao of *Jìjí* Water and Fire,
precisely to sit and watch
upon the straight path
for the success of Metal and Wood.

The Traveler (*Xíngzhě*) growls in agreement:
*"Indeed, indeed—
you speak with reason."*
He says: *"Well done, the Earthly Constraints transform!"*
He says: *"Shatter the obstinate void
and seek the Buddha’s face!"*
This means to act within the *Kun* [hexagram] Palace,
and through powers and transformations,
to meet the Buddha—
not like the Chan school,
which clings solely to the *xìngzōng* [nature school]
and falls into the void of obstinacy.

The Eight Rules exerts effort and says:
*"What care have I for the Bull King’s coming or not?"
This means to drive the Bull back to Earth,
the action is mine,
while the Bull knows nothing.*

He says: *"Wood in *hài* [the hour of the pig],
its nature paired with the pig,
dragging the Bull’s child back to Earth’s kind."*
This means Wood and Fire are paired,
*yin* within *yang*.
To drag Wood and Mercury (*gōng*) back,
preventing their wildness,
and make them return to Earth,
then the true *yin* is obtained to subdue Fire—
this is the Eight Rules’ exertion.

He says: *"From *shēn* [the hour of the monkey] comes Metal’s birth,
yet without punishment or suppression,
there is much harmony and *qi*."*
This means Metal and Water are paired,
clarifying the central *yang*.

*"With the banana leaf,
as Water’s intention,
the Fire Flame is extinguished—*Jìjí* achieved."*
The meaning is self-evident.

*"Two lead the Earth Spirit and the *yin* soldiers,
advancing together,"*
their actions never stray from Earth.

chunks.original_text: 故三人争战之顷，而土地拦住道：“大力王，那里走？ 吾等在此！ ”老牛、行者，彼此赌斗变化，与前番天宫时与二郎赌斗相对。 彼为先天而顺行天道也，人道也； 此为后天而逆制天道也，仙道也。 总一顺一逆之妙道也。 老牛由地而升，初登于天也。 变为天鹅，天一生水，水生木，顺也； 行者变为海东青，东青，木也，木因水生，而木反克水，逆也。 牛王又变为黄鹰，黄属土，水受克于木而水反生土，故变为黄鹰； 上受克于木而土反克水，土干而木枯也。 故东青不能制黄鹰，而黄鹰能制东青，逆也。 行者又变为乌凤，乌属水，木受制于土而上反生水，故变为乌凤； 水受制于土而水反克上，水决而土陷也。 故黄鹰不能制乌凤，而乌凤能制黄鹰，逆也。 老牛又变为白鹤，白属金，上受克于水而水反生金，故变为白鹤。 行者又变为丹凤，丹属火，火受克于水而水反生火，放变为丹凤。 天一之水，化五行而生万物，不外青、黄、乌、白、丹之五色，此道之一顺一逆，而变化照察于上也。 老牛由天而降，后入于地也。 变为香獐，地二生火。 獐与鹿同类，与马同宫，火也； 由白鹤之金而变，则金反生火。 行者变为饿虎，虎位乎西，金也； 由丹凤之火而变，则火反生金。 论理，金不能克火，而虎有食獐之力，则火反受克于金，逆也； 老牛又变为金钱大豹，金豹为金类，以獐变豹，火变金也，逆也； 行者又变为金睛狻猊，狻猊为火兽，以虎变狻猊，金变火也，逆也； 老牛又变人熊，熊属火，豹变熊，金变火也，逆也； 行者又变为赖象，象力在鼻，土也，狻猊变象，火变土也，顺也。 《剥》之《象》曰：“顺而止之，观象也。 ”地二之火，化五行而生万物，不外金、木、水、火、土之五象。 此道之一逆一顺，而变化昭察于下也。 天一生水，地二成之，水火既济，总归于土，故牛王有原身，而白牛现焉； 土化为白，则木平、水和、火息、金明，而金丹将就，故行者就现原身，而万丈金身之象，巍然毕具矣。 诗曰“奇巧心猿用力降”，言修道全藉心灵而力专。 曰“必须宝扇”，言舍金水不济木火。 曰“黄婆扶元”、“木母同情”，言土木之运用宜勤。 曰“和睦五行归正果”，言五行攒簇而归于一体，不相克害，方证西方也。 此下大圣与牛王争逐，处处俱是八戒、土地努力，金火之煅炼，唯赖土木之运用也。 其诸神将、佛力之护卫拦截，及李天王、哪咤父子之斩头、照像，无非火水土之精神焕发也。 北有神通广大泼法，南有法力无量胜至，东有毗卢沙门大力，西有不坏尊王永住，四面八方都是神兵天将，上有托塔李天王父子神将。 “老牛还变做一只大白牛”，返本还元之象也。 太子变三头六臂，飞身牛背，斩下牛头，《乾》变为《坤》而象阴。 “牛”去其首而象“午”，故钻出一头，口吐黑气而生阴，生生不已，而真阴尽现。 哪咤便吹真火，而真阴真阳相济。 煅炼既成，而以心镜照住本象，不使腾挪。 大力收伏，真宝自昭，此皈依佛法之正路也。 哪咤牵转白牛，罗刹献出真扇，四大金刚道：“圣僧，恭喜了！ 十分功行将完！ ”乃金丹将成之候也。 又道：“汝当竭力修持，勿得须臾怠惰！ 盖指示尚有金丹之火候，不可须臾懈怠也。
