The *sowing of melons yields melons*—the principle of planting roots and cultivating truth. *Maitreya* sows a field of melons and fruits to tempt their thirsty cravings, demonstrating the way to abandon superficiality and embrace reality. The method of action must first restrain and regulate, suppressing their old cunning.

Write the character **"restraint"** (禁) upon the palm, wield it in the hand so that no falsehoods, extravagance, ostentation, or avarice may arise. Attack and retreat in turn. Release restraint and use inducement, gradually drawing them near to truth, then seizing the opportunity to enlighten them; penetrate their core, making them aware of the critical bond between life and *Dao*, thereby subduing them and capturing their hearts. This is the great *pillar to steady the raging waves*’ technique of transforming the melon within, seizing the entrails, and striking at the heart to awaken their minds.

That demon then cries out, *"Master, spare my life!"*—only then does it recognize that life and *Dao* are the most precious of treasures, and the true Master is revealed. Afterward, the *post-heaven sack* and the *striking mallet of the cosmic drum* cannot be wielded in reverse, to harm the world.

Eating the melon’s reality reveals that true learning lies in the *Dao* of life; entering the *sack of Maitreya* reveals that the *sack of the Way* is rooted in one’s own self. Scattered fragments of truth must be gathered into unity; old habits, once abandoned, must be returned to their original source.

The Buddha and the Patriarchs return to *Extreme Bliss* (极乐), the gods each resume their proper stations, the disciples escape calamity and gain freedom, abandoning the *Small Thunder Sound* (小雷音) for the *Great Thunder Sound* (大雷音)—all this is the pursuit of the fundamental truth. Alas! The *yellow-browed* (黄眉) ones borrow the *sack of Maitreya*, which encompasses all phenomena, to become the *abyss of greed* that devours all beings. How tragic! Yet fortunately, the reality of the melon is obtained to reclaim them.

Now, among the *Confucian, Buddhist, and Daoist* schools, many *yellow-browed* ones wield the *cosmic drum* and the *sack* together. How can one expect the *Wanderer* to endure such widespread planting of *Eastern Ling* (东陵) and the burden of repeated action?

**The Sixty-Seventh Chapter: Rescuing the Steadfast *Dharma-nature* of the *Tālā* (驼罗) Hermit, Freeing the Pure *Dao-heart* from Defilement**

The text states: *"This book reveals that great concealment does not prevent dwelling in the marketplace, but one must not be corrupted by market vices; detachment from dust does not prevent entering dust, but one must not be stained by worldly traces."* The false *immortals* of the *Wood Immortal Hermitage* (木仙庵) and the pseudo-*Buddhas* of the *Small Thunder Sound* (小雷音), though they appear to have devised their own methods, seem to avoid the world’s clamor and shun the dust—yet they are not the true essence of great concealment.

At the beginning, the *Three Treasures* (三藏) said, *"Let us seek lodging along that path?"* The Wanderer replied, *"The lodging lies ahead."* These words teach one to accept whatever arises and not to precalculate.

The *Immortal Master* (仙师) thus set forth the analogy of *sparse persimmons* (稀柿) and *extreme filth* (极污). The persimmon, once fallen, has just left the "wood" (木) to become the "market" (市). The *Seven Emotions* (七情) are likened to the seven passions of man. Love and attachment are hard to sever, yet they ultimately lead to poisonous harm. Accumulated over time, they become defilement; deep-rooted obstacles become mountains. The *yin-qi* (阴气) breeds into a *serpent’s den* (蟒穴), and the *Kāngzāng* (康庄) path transforms into the *Swine’s Way* (豕途). This is the origin of the *Tālā* Hermit’s *long serpent* (长蛇) that devours people, and the *Seven Emotions Mountain* (七绝山) that blocks the road like a *walled-off boar* (封豕).

*"Tālā"* (驼罗) is the *Sanskrit* term for *Tāla* (陀罗净土), the *Pure Land*. *"Five hundred or more households"* (共有五百多家) refers to the *Arhats* (罗汉), those who dwell there. The *Buddhist canon* (释典) names them *"Arahat"* (阿罗汉), meaning those who have extinguished all passions, capable of receiving universal offerings, untouched by the three realms, far from all evil, and enjoying pure *Dharma-nature* (禅性稳). Yet now, dwelling beside the *sparse persimmons*, they suffer continuous attacks by serpentine demons, their livestock devoured, their men and women in fear and peril—this is the *Dharma-nature* (性) of a neighbor to a *serpent’s den* (蛇窟), the *Pure Land* (净土) turned into a *field of slander* (舌场). How precarious it is, like one drowning or burning, needing urgent rescue!

Only one with great wisdom and great *pillar to steady the raging waves*’ power, such as the *Wanderer* (孙行者), can easily dispel and drive away such calamities, bringing peace to the world. Could those ordinary monks who rot like *spoiled melons* (烂西瓜) or those ordinary Daoists who are *boiled chickens* (落汤鸡) truly stabilize the *Dharma-nature* (禅性) and purify the *Dao-heart* (道心)?

Only the Wanderer’s supreme methods can be relied upon to shoulder this burden—no other can be summoned. Yet if one does not purify oneself and minimize attachments, or if one lingers over gold, silver, or fields, then it is greed and the pursuit of profit, consorting with the market’s vices. Even if one unites in removing harm, it remains an attack by one demon against another—never to be allowed.

Thus, the Wanderer appears to teach and demonstrates that, though he values gold and silver, he does not indulge in market corruption; though he sees fields, he does not fish with the market’s tricks. All this is but the accumulation of virtue.

The market’s heart is full of deceitful schemes, yet it resembles a serpent. The *Dao* scriptures say, *"The serpent of passions sleeps in your heart"*—this is it. Its accumulated habits are such that it seizes cattle and horses, it seizes chickens and geese, it seizes men and women—regardless of size or status, it is well-practiced in devouring them. Its eyes hang like twin torches, revealing hidden profits in the dark; its tongue dances like double hooks, swiftly blocking and misleading on either side. Only until dawn, when the *heavenly heart* (天心) resets, does it hesitate and conceal itself, yet its head and tail remain exposed, unable to escape the discerning gaze of the wise.

When its *qi* (气) is strong, the *soft-shafted spear* (软柄枪) displays boundless crafty tricks; when its path is exhausted, the *great mouth* (巨口) swiftly swallows all in an instant. Ah! How fearsome it is!

The common man fears it, dreading its fangs and jaws;
The perfected one confronts it, as if seeing its lungs and liver.

The perfected one’s body is firm and pure, untainted by grinding or dyeing.
Thus, though he walks through the marketplace with his mind,
He is not swayed by it;
Though he enters the dens of profit,
He is not harmed by them.

The most wondrous lies in the two meanings of *building a bridge in the serpent’s belly* and *changing the boat*:
To consume fat and blood while growing sluggish flesh—
What compares to an empty stomach harnessing the eastern rainbow,
Accumulating virtue through beneficial deeds?
To hoard wealth and fatten the phantom’s back—
What compares to bankruptcy and building a vessel of compassion,
Accumulating virtue through giving and relief?

Extinguishing the evil karma of cravings,
Binding the universal cause for universal liberation—
Fear and terror vanish,
Each fulfills its nature,
Merit and virtue complete,
All find peace in their essence—
What joy surpasses this?

Henceforth, with sincere heart and empty vessel,
Transforming form and cultivating the Way:
Expanding the heart-mind of ten thousand ages,
Long-blocked alleys now restored to their ancient paths;
Breaking free from the entanglements of a thousand years,
Accumulating filth like the Gourd Ridge,
Yet all attain enlightenment together.

This is as the Inner Canon of the Mysterious Sovereign states:
*"Facing phenomena while forgetting them,
Not sinking into the six demonic magics;
Dwelling in dust yet transcending it,
Not falling into the transformations of myriad entanglements."*

Thus the poem concludes:
*"All desires and dusty emotions are severed,
Peaceful and unobstructed, bowing to the Lotus Platform."*

Ah!

Ah! Marvelous indeed—
Wherever the Lotus Platform is glimpsed, each person’s heart becomes a Pure Land;
Where the Divine Flower Treasury is revealed, every household finds a path to the Western Heaven.

To transcend the Gourd Ridge’s filth and reach the Lotus Platform—
Who is pure, who defiled?
Who is blocked, who unobstructed?
Only the individual may awaken to this.

Yet why does the Camel’s Horn Village fear the serpent and not simply depart?
Why does the Gourd Ridge’s accumulated filth remain, its trees uncut?
Perhaps it is that the land has no harsh governance,
And the roots of karmic affliction are not easily eradicated!

**Sixty-Eighth Chapter**
*The Tang Monk Discusses Past Lives in the Land of Vermilion and Purple*
*The Monkey King’s Three Broken Arms*
*A Disciple Awakens:* This passage, up to the seventy-first, elucidates the cultivation of the Great Dao of Refining the Golden Elixir. Only Zhang Boduan’s *Awakening to Reality* captures its essence—one should follow his teachings with reverence, as the concluding section on *"The True Person’s Rustic Robe"* makes clear.

The heading explicitly declares *"Land of Vermilion and Purple,"*
Connoting the nobility of vermilion and purple,
Yet inverting to suggest that none surpasses the authenticity of Boduan.

The Lacquered Sage speaks of *"The Ox Adorned in Brocade,"*
The Master Confucius views *"Wealth and Honor as Fleeting Clouds,"*
Zilu values *"The Noble’s Rank Above Silk-Beams,"*
And Jin Ping warns of *"High Chariots and Four Horses Bringing Ruin."*
Chen the Recluse writes:
*"Though Purple Avenues teem with vain display,
Vermilion robes, though noble, pale beside poverty."*

From antiquity, sages have given profound counsel—
Yet how is it that people read ten thousand volumes and a thousand scriptures
And still fail to recognize the letters?

The Monkey King immediately roars in awakening:
*"Master, you do not recognize the three great characters—'Land of Vermilion and Purple'!"*

For vermilion and purple dust and glory are but illusions, dream-bubbles;
Imperial capitals and royal domains are but transient echoes of Zen.

「To know what comes next, one must observe the past;
The past, viewing the future, is like the future viewing the past.

Thus, the Tripitaka traces back to the Three Sovereigns and reaches the Five Emperors,
From yielding to others to waging conquests;
Contending for succession, merging and struggling for dominance;
Alternating between governance and chaos, life’s span stretched yet unequal,
Only to finally converge in the dream of the Tang King.

Alas! Within the winding, circuitous discourse,
Lies an infinite lament of sorrowful, profound truths.

Just as the yellow apricot flags atop the city walls,
Flutter wildly in the wind—
If not for old Sun Wukong’s clear vision,
Even if you master celestial lore, know geography, and debate *yin-yang*,
Or if you govern the realm and found states,
Send books to the *Yin Du* underworld,
Extend lives through alchemical arts,
All these efforts are but the work of *"Weizheng the Omen."*

Far better is to worship the Buddha,
Take the *Mahayana Sutras* of the Three Baskets,
And ascend to heaven by transcending the sufferings of karma!

*The Fa Yuan Zhu Lin* states:
*"Though the peacock boasts a splendid form,
It cannot fly as far as the wild crane;
Though vermilion robes carry wealth and honor,
They cannot match the virtue of renouncing the world."*

The kings of vermilion and purple,
Though adorned with splendor, face peril in their bodies;
Though their robes hold wealth and honor, their hearts ache with suffering—
Lamenting that no one comes to save them,
Yet they do not suffer the same fate as the Tang King,
Who dreamt his way into hell?

Those who gather at the *"Hui Tong Hall"*—
Meet without appointment, align without plan;
Ancient and modern worlds differ not,
Yet their boundaries share the same rules.

A king wears vermilion and purple while feasting on *guanglu* honors,
While common folk chase after food and fame, seeking profit and name.
Both share the same cravings of mouth and body,
Yet both fall ill unto the marrow of life’s vitality.

Thus, when the Eighth Rule hears of wine, rice, silk, and brocade,
Or fragrant foods, he cannot help but drool and enter the market.

When the Pilgrim sees the royal edict calling for worthy men,
And lands of vermilion and purple,
He cannot help but joyfully rush to serve as a royal physician.

In truth, wandering east to west, pursuing worldly gains is but a fleeting illusion;
One must know that bowing to lift the royal edict,
And accepting fate to heal the realm, is also of utmost importance.

The Eighth Rule seeks food and gains renown,
Yet unexpectedly, he ponders the royal physician’s edict—
Grandfathers, fathers, sons, and grandsons,
Nurses and elders—
All vie for the empty title in unison.

The Pilgrim, though jesting, acts with earnestness,
As if he truly holds the king’s position—
Revered and honored, obeyed and worshipped,
With ranks arrayed and bowing in procession—
In moments, he becomes a puppet.

For any true hero,
Their words are sharp and striking beyond measure—
Thus, if the vulgar do not flinch, it is not the mark of a hero;
For one with genuine wisdom,
Their actions are swift yet deliberate, not reckless—
Thus, if the first move is not refused, it is not true wisdom.

This is how the Pilgrim steps forward with a stern voice,
And how the king is startled into submission—
*"Dismiss him!"*

What truly startles the listener,
Is not *"stepping forward with a stern voice,"*
But *"a thousand years without relief."*

If one does not cultivate the Dao,
Even if their schemes for wealth and honor succeed,
It is but a ghostly, fleeting existence—
A life bound to death.

Born with sickness, dying from sickness;
Living as a sickly mortal, dying as a suffering ghost;
Through countless kalpas of rebirth,
When will this suffering end?
A thousand years without relief—
If spoken of in terms of *wànjié* rebirth,
Does it not startle the ignorant?

The depths of wisdom lie not in *"hanging threads to diagnose pulses,"*
But in *"each of the three fine hairs measuring twenty-four feet."*

*The Yellow Emperor’s Inner Canon*, *The Classic of Difficulties*, *The Fundamentals of Herbal Medicine*, and *Pulse Decisions*
Serve only to cure momentary ailments,
And prolong a single life.

If medical skill is commonplace,
Then the three fine hairs are likened to the Three Passes—
*Tian Guan* at the hand, *Di Zhu* in the heart—
And the five movements correspond to *jing*, *qi*, and *shen*.

To align the three fine hairs with the twenty-four *qi* of the seasons,
And to harmonize the three conditions with the seventy-two *hou* of fate—
This is to treat diseases spanning thousands of years;
A grand masterpiece of medical wisdom—
Yet the world struggles to grasp its profundity!

Thus, the Daoist sage concludes with this instruction:
*"The heart holds secret prescriptions to heal the realm,
Within it lies the wondrous formula for eternal life."*

I once visited Jingyang,
And inscribed this couplet at the Temple of the Medicine King:
*"How many commoners’ afflictions exist?
Drink it, eat it—
Better seek the Daoist’s elixirs for true cures;
The world’s incurable maladies in countless forms—
Names and profits—
What compares to the white clouds atop the mountain?"*

Yet how is it that people read ten thousand volumes and a thousand scriptures
And still fail to recognize the letters?

The Monkey King immediately roars in awakening:
*"Master, you do not recognize the three great characters—'Land of Vermilion and Purple'!"*

The compiler, it seems, must recognize the phrase *"Zhūzǐ Guó"* (Jade-Purple Realm) and be willing to shatter the butterfly dream of the mortal world—then proceed to read this book together.

**Chapter Sixty-Ninth**
*The Heart’s Nighttime Alchemy*
*The King’s Feast on Demonic Heresies*

A sage once said:
*"Floating glory and vain pursuits—
A dream steeped in yellow millet;
Worldly tastes and dusty bonds—
Swift as sparks on stone."*

Men call this the common talk of old monks,
Saying that within ritual teachings lies a place of joy.
Yet in truth, one’s life is but restless toil—
Clutching wind, embracing shadows—
And in an instant, eternal slumber descends.
From ancient times to now, how many have truly awakened?

Lu Zong said:
*"Seeking fame and fortune births hell’s torment,
Ritual propriety kills in the prison of the heavens."*
Truly, this awakens the dream and shatters delusion!

The Daoist sage’s work here
Specially highlights the pure night’s sincere heart,
Pointing to the path of awakening for self-recognition.
For to cultivate the Dao, one must first purify the heart;
To purify the heart, one must first dispel illness;
To dispel illness, one must first know its roots.

The ancient divine physicians,
Gazing at the lofty walls, their skill astounding the two young men.
Hanging threads to diagnose pulses—
Not absurd, but rather describing
Deep contemplation leading to penetration,
Silent cultivation reaching divine insight.

As birds have fixed mates, so too their cries when separated;
As humans cannot have one polarity dominate, so too illness arises from imbalance.
The marvelous prescriptions of medicine—
The blind and foolish cannot grasp them.

The Medical Officer said:
*"The eight hundred and eighty flavors—
Not all are used,"*
Seeing that their use cannot be exhaustive.

The Wanderer said:
*"Medicine does not cling to formulas,
Thus it fully conquers,"*
Seeing that the formula’s essence lies in its application.

*"Eight hundred and eighty flavors,"*
Clarifying the number two-eight.
Two-eight refers to what *The Parametric Concordance* calls
Nine Returns, Seven Circulations, Eight Reunions, Six Residences.
Nine and seven are yang numbers, combining into sixteen—
The full essence of a man’s true *jing*.
Eight and six are yin numbers, combining into fourteen—
The arrival of a woman’s *tian gui*.
Taking the moon’s waxing and waning as symbols,
Thus it is also said:
*"The waxing phase—eight of *Dui*,
The waning phase—eight of *Gen*—
Their combined essence forms the *Kan* and *Kun* bodies."*
*"Two-eight corresponds to one *jin*,
The *Yijing*’s unshaken truth."*

*The Awakening to Reality* says:
*"When the moon first hangs half-lit in the sky,
Already the dragon’s roar and tiger’s growl resound.
Now is the time to refine the two-eight,
Within a single hour, the elixir is complete."*
Speaking of yin-yang union,
The opportune moment for alchemical refinement.

Thus the Wanderer says:
*"When night is still, we best prepare the medicine."*
*"By midnight, the streets lie empty, all sounds hushed,
Eight Rules said, ‘Brother, hurry—let’s act early.’"*
All pointing to the urgency of the two-eight’s timing.

Taking *dàhuáng* (great yellow), the utmost yin;
And *bādòu* (croton seed), the utmost yang.
*"Dà"*—one, *rén* (person);
*"Bā"*—one, *jǐ* (self).
Person and self unite, essence complete—
Yin and yang harmonized, the medicine is ready.

Thus Eight Rules said:
*"Eight hundred and eighty flavors—
Just these two suffice,
Truly capable of reviving the dead, defying heaven’s will,
And becoming the complete elixir."*

Earlier, the Three Treasures answered the king:
*"Three stubborn brutes—none know the nature of the medicine."*
Now, the Sand Monk is well-acquainted with *dàhuáng*’s cold nature,
Eight Rules deeply versed in *bādòu*’s heat—
Yet if one clings only to the properties of the herbs,
Even knowing them, how can one heal the realm?
Still, they remain unenlightened.

The Wanderer said:
*"My brother, you do not know."*

The Wanderer said:
*"You too do not know."*

He spoke of these two flavors repeatedly as *"unknown"* to urge careful study of their subtleties—one must not grasp at superficial traces alone.

In the text, *"spun fine"*—when spoken of medicine, yet not just of medicine.

*"Bai cao shuang"* (Hundred Herbs’ Frost) takes the harmonizing of the earthen tripod;
*"Long ma niao"* (Dragon-Horse Urine) draws from the treasures of the Water Palace.

*"Guo hui"* (Kettle Ash) and *"jin zhi"* (Golden Juice)—their meaning is clear.

When stirred together as *"San Jiu"* (Three Nines), it gathers the Five Phases and divides the Three Realms.

Named *"Wu Jin Dan"* (Black Gold Pill), to reveal the essence of the Golden Elixir—the sovereign’s secret remedy lies here.

Ah! How wondrous!

The Immortal Master feared the world might remain ignorant, so within the medicine’s ingredients, he embedded six hidden marvels, each laden with meaning.

*"Laoya"* (Old Crow) is the yin of the *Lǐ* (Trigrams: *Lǐ* 离), taking its *qi*;
*"Lǐ yú"* (Carp) is the yang of the *Kǎn* (坎), drawing its essence.

*"Wangmu fen"* (Queen Mother’s Powder) is the yin-earth *jǐ* (己);
*"Laojun hui"* (Laozi’s Ash) is the yang-earth *wù* (戊).
*"Toujin san kuài"* (Three Headcloths) gathers the three blossoms of the crown;
*"Long xu wu gen"* (Five Dragon Whiskers) encircles the five radiant yangs.

Taking the body’s *qi* and essence, combining *wù* and *jǐ* to form the *gui* (圭), this is the marvelous Dao of Three-Five.

These are formless substances, arising from the void—beyond the ken of ignorant physicians. Hence it is said:
*"This is something the world cannot possess."*

The vulgar claim this remedy excels in curing false illnesses, unaware that common speech conceals profound principles, not deceit.

Even ordinary medicine uses rootless water, yet it too descends from heaven;
If the Dragon King sneezes and spits his essence, it is no ordinary rainwater.

As the Mud Pill Master said:
*"Saliva and spittle, precious fluids—
Only they can serve as the ladder to ascent."*

When the essence transforms into ambrosial dew,
Three cups descend the Three Nines,
Like the unceasing sound of a waterwheel,
Piercing the Three Passes—
And the root of illness vanishes.

This remedy heals the realm like a god—
Why not record it on bamboo and silk,
So all under heaven, in future ages, may take and nourish themselves?
Yet it is kept secret—why?

The Practitioner spoke: *"The king is indeed a great sage of virtue and power,"*
*"I shall assist you and stand by him."*

This wisdom is not lightly given—
Only to those of true virtue and power may it be entrusted.

The Ancestor said:
*"Gain a worthy disciple yet fail to pass on the Heavenly Treasure,
And pass it to the unworthy, the Seventh Patriarch suffers."*

Examine the past: the Purple Yang True Person thrice passed it to the unworthy,
And thrice met Heaven’s retribution—
A lesson to be heeded!

How could it be openly inscribed on bamboo and silk?
Thus, the Eighth Precept spoke of *"horse in the medicine"*,
Yet ceased to reveal it afterward;
The Practitioner, in anger at his concealment,
Suddenly invoked *"the Horsehoe Herb"* as a cover—
All to show that such secrets must not be recklessly divulged,
Lest calamity be invited.

The later text foreshadows the **Tài Suì**’s resolution of the Golden Bell,
The welcome of the Golden Saint,
And the true method for refining the Golden Elixir.
Yet without knowing the cause of its dispersion,
Or recognizing the marvel of its return,
One cannot grasp the king’s words at the feast,
Which reveal the root of the *"lost and scattered"* affliction.

The **Black** is the essence of the *Lì* hexagram—
It has its primordial mate,
But when separated, it does not return.
The **Black** alone, without pair,
Though it can internally nourish the Five Spirits,
Cannot externally harmonize with the One Qi.
It dispels only later-acquired diseases within the body,
Yet fails to retreat the original external afflictions.

Thus, even the *"Black-Gold Elixir"* is not yet the pure Yang,
The true crimson-gold Elixir.

The king said:
*"At the very time of the Duan’yáng festival,
In the Sea-Pomegranate Pavilion, I watched the Dragon Boat races.
Suddenly, a gust of wind arose,
And a demon appeared—
It called itself the **‘Rival Tài Suì’**,
Dwelling in the **Qílín Mountain’s Xiè Zhì Cave**,
And had seized the Golden Saint Palace to take it away."*

The **Duanwǔ** festival marks the throat of Heaven—
A sudden wind rising,
The Six Yangs first encounter One Yin, forming the *Gòu* hexagram.
The *Gòu*—Heaven’s wind—
(□ hexagram diagram omitted);
The gradual onset of *Bō*—
The root of *Fù*.

In a man’s body,
It is like first taking a woman and craving her child,
Or racing dragon boats and delighting in frivolity—
Hence the saying: *"Riding in the Flower Garden Sea-Pomegranate Pavilion,
Engaging in Dragon Boat races."*

At this moment,
The true gold of the Six Yangs of the *Qián* body is broken,
And sinks into the *Kūn* earth.
Then the Six Yins of the *Kūn* earth,
In turn, obtain the true gold and become *Fù*—
Earth’s thunder.
(□ hexagram diagram omitted),
The reverse of *Bō*—
The end of *Gòu*.

When thunder erupts from the earth,
The spirit of **Gōu Máng** manifests.
*"It calls itself the **‘Rival Tài Suì’**"*—
As if offering true gold and praying to it,
Is it not a **"Rival"**?

The **Qílín** is the beast of benevolence,
Its nature is to love all things;
The **Xiè Zhì** is the divine sheep,
Its wisdom discerns deceit—
It embodies the heart of love and hatred.

The **Tài Suì** lurks within,
And seizes the Golden Saint Palace—
Then I lose what I love,
And exchange it for what I do not love, breeding sorrow;
I gain what I hate,
And exchange it for what I do not hate, breeding doubt.
The maladies of sorrow and doubt arise from this—
Not the essence of the benevolent who do not sorrow,
Or the wise who are not confused.

Yet after years of sorrow and doubt,
After three years of stagnant accumulation,
A single dose of the **Líng Dān Elixir** can clear the passage;
If the **Tài Suì** is subdued and the Golden Saint welcomed back,
The method requires threefold folding—
It cannot be easily attained.

Avoiding the Maze Tower cannot keep evil at bay,
For one who flees the true south
Cannot ensure the evil’s departure.

Instead, one must recognize it—
Only when recognizing its nature
Does one know the disease’s root,
And can refine the medicine to cure the illness
And bring peace to the realm.

Hence it is said:
*"To pacify the realm, first know the king’s affliction;
To uphold the Dao, remove the heart of love and hatred."*

The *"king"* refers to the **Heart Sovereign**;
The *"heart of love and hatred"* is the **Sovereign’s Heart**.

chunks.original_text: 第七十回　妖魔宝放烟沙火　悟空计盗紫金铃 悟一子曰：金丹之道，《易》道也。 《乾》、《坤》其门户，《坎》、《离》其妙用，《姤》、《复》其化机。 《姤》终必至于《否》，《否》则必至于《剥》，《剥》极则必归之于《复》，《复》则必归于《泰》。 阴阳消长，循环无端。 即篇中所谓“有来有去”者。 是大修行人，先具一双慧眼，亟须狠力一棒打杀，不使他再到剥皮亭。 潜通消息，方能消息由我，相机下手，盗转紫金铃，迎还金圣官，完全《乾》体，而超凡出世也。 “金铃”者，先天真乙之宝，混而为一气，分而为三元，人人具足。 只因交《姤》之候，忽然失去。 如治国者，不能内安而召取外乱，举国忧疑者然。 若非良谋善策，大展雄才，以图恢复，仅作避妖地穴，终避不得。 三番四覆索取宫娥，能无日促国百里乎？ 国王筵上一论，说出病根； 行者酒中灭火，讲明丹决。 乃因病立方，大展经纶之妙手也。 这般法力，正是打开生死路，明师传授的大道。 诗中“为鼎炉”，“团乌兔”，“采阴阳”，“悟玄关”，“运天罡”，“移斗柄”； “退炉进火”，“抽铅添汞”“攒簇五行”，“和合四象”； “归二气”，“会三家”等句，字字金丹药物火候之的髓也，同一金铃也。 太岁本《坤》土，而得其《乾》金，既《复》矣。 然挟女后而图交姤，是《复》而复《姤》也。 故太岁摇动金铃，＿放烟火而为害，放飞沙而为害，虽曰计，而实为妖魔。 国王失《乾》金而陷于《坤》土，既《姤》矣。 然不忘金圣而志图迎复，是《姤》而复《复》也。 故行者动静不拘，变人物而为盗，变有来有去而为盗，虽曰计，而实为悟空。 “有来有去”，本是天理之流行。 学道之人，当于天理流行中，讨问出“一个神仙，送一件五色仙衣与金圣宫妆新”的妙道，开“有去无来”的正法眼，方能入道从真。 故行者一变火鹞子而上极乎天，二变蜢虫儿而下入乎地，三变道童而中位乎人。 勘破上下今古，而能将有来有去一棒打杀也。 “战书揣在三藏怀里，莫与国王看见。 ”书中何语？ 盖有难以形诸笔墨者，终秘而不言，正打杀“有来有去”之妙也。 然天理之流行，如何打杀，得非诳世？ 不知打杀正是打活。 打杀者，“有来有去”； 不曾打杀，“无去无来”。 故无去无来，仍不离有来有去的模样。 行者打杀而为无，仍一变为有，所谓“着有真成幻，去无不入中。 有无俱不立，内外悉皆空”也。 咦！ 妙哉！
chunks.translated_text:
**Chapter Seventy: The Demon’s Jewel Sets Off Smoke and Sand Fires; Tripitaka’s Disciple Steals the Purple Gold Bell**

Tripitaka’s son said: The Dao of the Golden Elixir is the *Yijing*’s Way.
*Qian* and *Kun* are its gateways,
*Kan* and *Li* its wondrous applications,
*Guà* and *Fù* its transformative mechanisms.

*Guà* must inevitably reach *Pǐ*,
*Pǐ* must inevitably reach *Bó*,
*Bó* at its extreme must return to *Fù*,
*Fù* must return to *Tài*.

Yin and yang wax and wane, cycling endlessly—
This is the "having come, having gone" spoken of in the text.

For those of great cultivation, first possessing a pair of enlightened eyes,
They must strike with fierce resolve—
Lest he return to the Flayed-Skin Pavilion.

Only by secretly penetrating the currents
Can one make the currents follow me,
Acting at the opportune moment,
Stealing the Purple Gold Bell in reverse,
Welcoming back the Golden Saint,
Perfecting the *Qian* essence,
And transcending the mundane.

The "Purple Bell" is the primordial true-yi treasure,
Mingled as one *qi*,
Divided into the Three Primordials—
Every person possesses it fully.

Yet at the moment of *Guà*,
It suddenly vanishes.

Like a ruler unable to secure internal peace,
Summoning external chaos,
Causing the nation to sink into doubt—
If not for wise strategies and grand talent,
Plotting recovery,
Merely hiding in a demon-avoiding cave
Will never truly repel the evil.

Seeking the palace maidens three times over—
How could this not hasten the nation’s ruin?

At the royal banquet, one speech reveals the disease’s root;
In the drink, the practitioner extinguishes the fire,
Clarifying the elixir’s principles.
This is to diagnose the illness and prescribe the remedy—
A display of masterful governance.

Such power is the key to unlocking the path of life and death,
A great Dao passed down by the enlightened master.

In the verses:
*"For the tripod’s furnace,"*
*"Gathering the tortoise and hare,"*
*"Harvesting yin and yang,"*
*"Awakening the Mystic Pass,"*
*"Moving the Heavenly Ganges,"*
*"Shifting the Dipper’s handle,"*
*"Retreating the furnace, advancing the fire,"*
*"Drawing lead, adding mercury,"*
*"Concentrating the Five Phases,"*
*"Harmonizing the Four Symbols,"*
*"Returning the Two *Qi*,"*
*"Uniting the Three Families"*—
Each word is the quintessence of the elixir’s alchemical fire and timing,
All pointing to the same Purple Bell.

The *Tài Suì* is fundamentally *Kun* earth,
Yet obtains *Qian* gold—
Already *Fù*.
But clinging to the female consort to seek *Guà*,
This is *Fù* returning to *Guà*.

Thus, the *Tài Suì* shakes the Purple Bell,
Releasing smoke and fire as harm,
Releasing flying sand as harm—
Though called a "strategy," it is truly demonic.

The king loses *Qian* gold and sinks into *Kun* earth—
Already *Guà*.
Yet, not forgetting the Golden Saint,
He resolves to welcome him back—
This is *Guà* returning to *Fù*.

Thus, the practitioner acts freely, shifting form to steal,
Changing "having come, having gone" into theft—
Though called a "strategy," it is truly Tripitaka’s disciple.

"Having come, having gone" is the natural flow of Heaven’s principle.
Those who study the Dao must, within this flow,
Seek out the marvelous method:
*"One immortal sends a five-colored celestial robe
To adorn the Golden Saint’s palace."*

Only by opening the "Dharma-eye of having gone without coming"
Can one enter the Dao and attain truth.

Thus, the practitioner:
First transforms into a fire-hawk soaring to the heavens,
Second into a grasshopper descending to the earth,
Third into a Daoist acolyte dwelling among mortals—
Piercing through past and present, above and below,
And striking down "having come, having gone" with a single blow.

*"The battle scroll is hidden in the Three Treasures’ bosom—
Do not let the king see it."*
What words are written within?
Some truths cannot be put into words,
And must remain secret—
This is the marvel of striking down "having come, having gone."

Yet how can one strike down the natural flow of Heaven’s principle?
Is this not deceiving the world?
No—striking down is striking to life.
Striking down means "having come, having gone";
Not striking down means "neither coming nor going."

Thus, neither coming nor going
Still does not depart from the form of having come and gone.

The practitioner strikes down to achieve the void,
Yet transforms again into existence—
*"When existence is true, it becomes illusion;
When nothingness departs, it enters the middle.
Existence and nothingness neither stand,
Inside and outside are all emptiness."*

Ah! Marvelous!

chunks.original_text: 一双黄金宝串，分明两个夫妻，匹配团围，连环相顾。 若能于此物打通消息，便是降魔复圣的机关。 行者径入剥皮亭，不答妖王问，展施于胳膊之上，玩弄于礼法之中，乃去来无碍，微妙圆通之作用也。 行者虽变有来有去，实是无去无来； 虽是大王心腹小校，实是金圣心腹小校，总是国王之心腹小校。 盗取金铃，迎复金圣之下手秘诀也。 三个金铃，火为神，烟为气，沙为精。 动而摇晃，则烟、火、沙散而为魔； 静而涵虚，则金火同宫凝聚而为丹。 此般至宝家家自有，只因女后之姤，而入于魔手，原非妖魔己物。 复得之道，仍须从魔手盗来。 故失铃出于姤，得铃亦必由于姤。 若非叙夫妻之情，彼此喜悦，把铃与她收贮，终难下手，所谓“外作夫妻心盗贼”是也。 金圣宫说出“共枕同衾，前世之缘”，即骗出金铃，付其收藏。 又说“我与大王交欢会喜”，“做出妖烧之态，哄着精灵。 行者在旁取事，把三个金铃轻轻拿过”，俱是实法。 最妙是“在旁取事”，“跟在我身边，乘机盗我宝贝”二语。 盖金铃系夫妻欢会付托收藏之物，盗之者，盗其夫妻之所有而为我有，窃天地之道化，非乘机不可得也。 然又必深知奥妙，从容静悟而取，非粗率疏躁而得。 特演叙“不知利害，就扯棉花，进出烟、火、黄沙，惊动妖王”一段，以明难得易失之故。 仙师又借妖王之口，频说“仔细搜寻”之语，以叮咛提醒之。 国王与金圣宫，真夫妻也，真者一姤而忽遭魔难，顷刻分离，“弄巧反成拙”也； 太岁与金圣宫，假夫妻也，假者一姤而即成宝藏，还返有机，“作耍却为真”也。 结出二语，学者仔细搜寻。 第七十一回　行者假名降怪犼　观音现像伏妖王 悟一子曰：《敲爻歌》曰，“纵横逆顺没遮拦，静则无为动是色。 ”常人不解其妙，谓“静则无为”，是道； 而“动是色”，非道也。 不知静无动，动无静，物也； 静而动，动而静，神也。 又曰：“酒是良朋花是伴，花街柳巷觅真人，真人只在花间现。 ”又曰：“只因花酒悟长生，饮酒带花神鬼哭。 ”“神鬼哭”者，六贼三尸之鬼，不能猖狂也。 古佛云：“汝知得老婆禅否？ 汝明得皮壳子禅否？ ”又云：“袈裟下大事不明最苦，裙钗下大事不明更苦。 ”皆言“动是色”之妙谛也。 篇首“色即空兮，空是色，人能悟彻色空禅，何用丹砂炮炼？ ”即是此义。 学人不仔细搜寻，而反视为痴愚，不知痴愚中之妙用，有非智者所能及。 行者变痴苍蝇，而妖王不能窥其踪迹，所谓“微妙圆通，深不可识，大智若愚”者是也。 此金铃妙道，非得真师附耳低言，终难解识。 行者到娘娘耳根后悄悄的叫道：“你可再以夫妻之礼哄他进来安寝，我好脱身行事，别作区处救你。 ”此即附耳密传之要诀。 先次作夫妻，金铃得而未识； 再作夫妻，金铃解而可得。 分明两次夫妻，而有颠倒反覆之妙用。 娘娘闻言，惊疑不信，如下土闻道而见疑，以为鬼话也。 行者曰：“我也不是人，我也不是鬼，如今变做个痴苍蝇儿在此。 ”噫！ 妙哉！ 他篇行者会变苍蝇，乃其常技之变相； 此处变蝇儿，则系变体之正谛。 非神非鬼是蝇儿，明金丹入手，全在结婴儿。 变蝇儿而嘤嘤呼应，金丹灵悟之象也。

---

A pair of golden bells, bright and clear—
two souls bound as husband and wife,
matched and entwined, gazing like rings in a chain.
If one can pierce through this thing with the Dao’s insight,
it is the key to subduing demons and reclaiming the Sage.

The practitioner boldly enters the *Bōpí Tíng* (Shedding-Skin Pavilion),
ignoring the demon king’s questions,
displaying them upon his arm,
playing with them within the rites of propriety—
thus arises the marvel of effortless coming and going,
the subtle, perfect penetration of the Dao’s workings.

Though the practitioner appears to manifest "having come, having gone,"
in truth, he is "neither coming nor going."
Though he seems a trusted general of the Great King,
in truth, he is a trusted general of the Golden Sage—
yet he remains the Great King’s trusted general.
Stealing the golden bells is the secret technique
of the Sage’s subordinate to restore them.

Three golden bells:
Fire is the *shén* (spirit),
Smoke is the *qi*,
Sand is the *jīng* (essence).
When moved and shaken,
smoke, fire, and sand disperse as demons.
When still and embracing the void,
golden fire merges in the palace and congeals as the elixir.

This treasure is found in every home,
yet it fell into the demon’s grasp through the *gǔ* (fortuitous encounter) of the queen,
not originally belonging to the fiend.
The way to reclaim it
must still pass through stealing from the demon’s hand.
Thus, the loss of the bells stems from the *gǔ*,
and their recovery must also arise from the *gǔ*.

If not for the bond of husband and wife,
their mutual joy and delight—
if he did not take and hide the bells with her,
he could never act.
This is why it is said:
*"The thief in disguise steals as a husband."*

The Golden Sage’s palace declares:
*"‘Shared pillow, entwined bed—
the fate of past lives.’*
And thus the golden bells are tricked out,
entrusted to her keeping.
Again it says:
*"‘I have rejoiced with the Great King,
shared his pleasures.’"*
It feigns the demon’s burning rage,
to deceive the *jīnglíng* (spirits and essences).
The practitioner seizes the opportunity,
lightly snatching the three golden bells—
all done with true method.

Most wondrous is *"seizing the opportunity"*—
*"‘Stay beside me, and when the chance arises,
steal my treasure.’"*
The golden bells were entrusted as tokens of a husband’s joy,
and to steal them is to take what belongs to the husband-wife union
as one’s own—
to grasp the transformation of Heaven and Earth’s Dao.
Without seizing the opportunity, it cannot be obtained.
Yet one must deeply know the subtleties,
calmly and patiently perceive them,
not through crude haste or recklessness.

There follows the tale of *"one who does not know the peril,
who tugs at cotton—
pulling forth smoke, fire, and yellow sand,
disturbing the demon king"*—
to show why such treasures are hard to gain yet easy to lose.
The Immortal Master further uses the demon’s mouth
to repeat *"‘Search carefully’"*—
a reminder to the scholar.

The Great King and the Golden Sage’s palace,
are truly husband and wife—
truly, for in one *gǔ* (encounter),
they suddenly fall into calamity,
separated in an instant,
*"turning cleverness into folly."*
The *Tàisuì* (Great Age) and the Golden Sage’s palace,
are falsely husband and wife—
falsely, yet in one *gǔ*,
they become treasure, returning to the realm of possibility,
*"playful deception turns to truth."*

These closing words are profound.
Scholars, search carefully.

**The 71st Episode: The Practitioner Feigns a Name to Subdue the Monster-Tiger, Guanyin Manifests to Suppress the Demon King**

A disciple said: The *"Qiāo Yáo Gē"* (Song of the Divine Stems) states,
*"‘Crosswise and upright, no obstruction—
stillness is non-action, movement is form.’"*
Common folk do not grasp its meaning,
saying *"‘stillness is non-action’"* is the Dao,
while *"‘movement is form’"* is not.
Yet they do not know:
stillness without movement, movement without stillness—these are mere things;
stillness within movement, movement within stillness—this is the spirit.

Again it says:
*"‘Wine is a fine friend, flowers a companion;
in the flower streets and willow lanes, seek the True Person—
the True Person appears only among the flowers.’"*
And again:
*"‘Only through wine and flowers does one awaken to eternal life—
drink wine, wear flowers, and the spirits and demons weep.’"*
*"The spirits and demons weep"*—
the six bandits and three corpses of the ghostly realm,
no longer able to rage.

The ancient Buddhas asked:
*"‘Do you know the *lǎopó* (Old Wife) Dharma?
Do you know the *píkēzi* (Skin-Shell) Dharma?’"*
Again it is said:
*"‘The great matter beneath the *jiāshā* (robe) is unclear—most bitter!
The great matter beneath the *qúnchāi* (woman’s ornaments) is unclear—even more bitter!’"*
All speak of the profound truth of *"movement is form."*

The opening lines of this chapter:
*"‘Form is emptiness, emptiness is form—
if one truly penetrates the Dharma of form and emptiness,
why bother refining cinnabar and sulfur?’"*
This is the same meaning.

Scholars who do not carefully search
instead see it as foolishness,
not knowing the wondrous workings within foolishness—
beyond the grasp of mere cleverness.

The practitioner transforms as a foolish fly,
yet the demon cannot discern his traces—
*"‘Subtle and perfect penetration,
deeply unrecognizable—
great wisdom as foolishness.’"*

This marvel of the golden bells
cannot be understood without a true master’s whispered instruction.
The practitioner, standing by the queen’s ear,
softly calls:
*"‘Again feign the rites of husband and wife to lure him in,
so I may slip away and act.
Do not fear—I will find another way to save you.’"*
This is the key to secret transmission by ear.

First, as husband and wife,
the golden bells are gained but not recognized.
Second, as husband and wife,
the golden bells are understood and may be seized.
Two clear instances of husband and wife,
yet with the marvel of reversed and repeated transformations.

The queen hears this,
startled and doubtful—
like one who hears the Dao from the earth
and is met with skepticism,
thinking it mere ghost talk.
The practitioner says:
*"‘I am neither human nor ghost—
now I have transformed into a foolish little fly.’"*
Ah!
Marvelous!

In other chapters, the practitioner feigns the form of a fly—
his usual technique.
Here, the transformation into a fly
is the very truth of the *biànxìng* (shape-shifting).
Neither spirit nor ghost—just a fly.
The golden elixir’s enlightenment is shown
when the fly hums in response.

chunks.translated_text:
The queen said, *"Do not bewitch me with your sorcery!"*
Only when she was held in the queen’s grasp did she begin to understand and no longer doubt—
this was the very essence of *jiéyīng* (embryonic coalescence) taking root.

Master Sanfeng declared:
*"Open the door, I’ll tell you—
without wine or flowers, the Dao cannot be spoken."*

Master Qiu Chuji said:
*"Drink wine, eat meat,
yet guard against the allure of smoke and flowers to curb lust."*

For wine dissolves all obstacles—
the Dao does not forbid it,
so the practitioner said:
*"Drinking wine is the highest path."*

*Chūnjiāo*—this is the flower.
Spring is the Flower Festival,
*jiāo* is the flower’s grace—
all mere illusion.

*"The practitioner transforms into her likeness,
serving beside her—
now the moment arrives to strike."*

This is the hidden principle within flowers,
the true secret of seizing the celestial opportunity.

*"The false Chūnjiāo stands beside her, holding the cup,
saying: ‘Great King and Queen, tonight you must exchange cups—
a double-happiness goblet!’"*

The queen and the demon king spoke only of conjugal matters,
their words thick with passion—
the king’s bones softened, his limbs weakened,
yet he could not touch her.

All this was real—
the very purpose of *"guarding against smoke and flowers to curb lust."*

When husband and wife unite,
the primordial treasure naturally manifests within them.

But how could the treasure in his waist reach my hands?
It must be seized when he is lost in ecstasy,
unable to resist—
only then can the opportunity be seized.

Thus the practitioner transformed into three monstrous forms
to assault his body,
while the demon lord, unaware, exposed his shame—
the golden bells were freed.

The false Chūnjiāo, waiting beside them,
observed carefully—
thus the moment was seized.

This was a method with precise timing,
most wondrous and divine,
a secret transmission from master to disciple—
as *Wù Zhēn* says:
*"With *Gù* and *Gòu*, the transformations unfold—
who says the Golden Elixir cannot succeed?"*

Once the golden bells were seized,
the false was abandoned for the true—
the Golden Saint Queen would naturally reunite,
and the method of returning the External Elixir was thus demonstrated.

If one seeks the treasure in the body alone,
it fails to grasp the ultimate truth of *yīn-yáng* reversal and harmony.

Thus the practitioner again called himself *"External Grandfather,"*
demanding, *"Return my Golden Saint Queen!"*—
this was to illustrate the principle.

This Dao is originally a transmission beyond scripture,
so the queen’s words *"external instruction"* clarify its meaning—
do not dismiss it as vulgar jest,
but recognize its profound intent.

After obtaining it, nourishment and protection were essential,
for danger and risk must be guarded against—
thus war was invoked as a metaphor.

War is perilous, a matter of life and death.
Only by maintaining *femininity* without *masculinity*
can one preserve it without loss.

The practitioner said:
*"Two and three cycle as six—
my femininity, your masculinity."*

For *masculinity* leads to loss;
*femininity* leads to gain.

The demon king relied on his shaking bells to assert dominance,
unaware that he had been outmaneuvered by one who guarded *femininity*—
his presence flickered between existence and nonexistence;
*masculinity* was impossible to grasp.

The practitioner, guarding *femininity* while shaking the bells,
unwittingly violated the precepts of the self-sovereign—
his essence flickered between presence and absence,
*femininity* was no easier to maintain.

To transcend the names of existence and nonexistence,
to erase the traces of *yīn* and *yáng*,
this is the sacred form of Guanyin’s boundless freedom.

*"Only the cry rang through the void:
‘Sun Wukong, I have arrived!’"*
Was this not the empty void of the *Lingbeng*’s purity,
where smoke and fire instantly vanished?

The Golden-Haired Mastiff returned to its origin,
the purple golden bells restored to their source;
the arrow shot at the sparrow was self-inflicted,
the wind torn apart was the destruction of its own young.

Disaster arises from oneself and is self-remedied—
the Mastiff bore no blame.

Just as the ultimate Dao of the Golden Elixir:
loss comes from oneself, gain comes from oneself—
thus it is said:
*"Who can free the golden bells from the Mastiff’s neck?
Ask the one who tied them."*

This is the true transmission of Master Zhuyou,
revealed at the time of the Golden Saint’s return to the palace,
to demonstrate its essence and clarify the doctrine.

The character *"宗"* (ancestral lineage) with *"木"* (wood) added,
piercing through the Golden Saint’s body—
when wood and metal unite in *Gòu*,
five-colored light emerges—
this is the true ancestral lineage.

All under heaven, in future generations,
should inherit and uphold it.

Wearing it for three years,
removing it for one day—
only then could husband and wife reunite,
*femininity* and *masculinity* remain in harmony,
*yin* and *yang* preserve their proper order,
and the complete meaning of the Golden Elixir be fulfilled—
thus the great man’s purpose is accomplished.

What use are fleeting red and purple glories?
Hence it is said:
*"With fate fulfilled, doubts and ailments washed away,
with thoughts extinguished, the heart naturally at peace."*

**Chapter 72: The Spider Silk Cave—Seven Emotions Obscuring the True Nature**
**The Filth-Rinsing Spring—Eight Precepts Losing Form**

Master Wù Yīzǐ said:
The earlier lines *"washed away"* and *"thoughts extinguished"*
seem to introduce the themes of *"Spider Silk"* and *"Filth-Rinsing."*
Readers may mistakenly take the Seven Emotions as joy, anger, sorrow, fear, love, hate, and desire,
thus losing sight of their true origin.

Eight Precepts losing form means failing to wash away filth entirely—
one must strive for absolute nakedness,
emptiness of all concerns,
and purity beyond all stains,
only then achieving self-perfection—
this seems correct but is not.

*The Cāntóng Zhì* states:
*"Discernment through the viscera’s laws,
inner vision clouded by thought.
The Dark Path rejects the Nine-One,
turbulence corrupts the primordial embryo.
Countless arts abound—
thousands upon thousands."*

Master Zhōnglí Wēng said:
*"Tears, saliva, semen, breath, blood, and sweat—
seven kinds of essence, all yin.
If these are used as elixir materials,
how can one ascend to the Jade Capital?"*

chunks.original_text: “缘世人从业识中来，却又因业识中而去。 一阳奔失，形虽男子，而身中皆阴，非惟真精七物属阴，五脏六腑，俱阴无阳。 若独修此阳里阴精之物，孤阴无偶，如牝鸡抱卵，欲抱成子，万不可得。 其所抱成者，亦是螟蛉异种，如此篇中之蜜蜂、蚂、蠦等之阴毒，非本性之嫡子，岂不迷失其本源耶？ 更有稍识阴阳之义，而不识阴阳得类之的，乃妄猜为御女采战，以阴炼阴，抛身灭身者，尤可怜悯！ 此提纲“迷本”、“忘形”之所由着也。 首叙“三藏别了朱紫国王，正行处，望见是个人家，欲自去化斋。 ”寓言学道者辞别富贵，向往修行，错认人家，执已独求之意。 “原来那人家没个男子。 ”乃纯阴寡阳之处，如诗中所云“游蜂错认真”者是也。 “静悄悄，鸡犬无声”，二物属阳而全无，阴寂可知。 “见女子踢气球”，阴气交互之象。 石洞、石门、石桌、凳，内外俱阴质也。 故总拟之曰：“冷气阴阴。 ” “长老心惊，、暗忖多凶少吉”，身心阅历而始惊疑也。 然虽惊疑，“没奈何，只得坐了”，以舍此之外，别无寻讨处也。 那知此内安排的东西，不过是人油、人肉、人脑，尽人身之阴质，绝无阳气，故曰：“若是这等东西，我和尚吃了啊，莫想见得世尊，取得经卷！ ”即“若将此物为丹质，怎得飞神上玉京”之义。 迷人不识真本，误认门户，转转纠缠，莫可解脱，如绳捆高吊一般。 即欲寻思出路，脱去外层，还有里层； 解了上截，还有下截； 思愈多则门愈闭，与丝绳漫了庄门何异？ 旁观者见其千百层穿道经纬，而不知实是盘丝岭盘丝洞七个女怪而已。 噫！ 一盘迷局无头绪，七扇灵扉总障缘。

「The worldly folk arise from the realm of *business* and *perception*,
yet also depart through the same.
When the one *yang* flees, though the form be that of a man,
the body is entirely *yin*—
not merely are the seven true essences all *yin*,
the five *zàng* and six *fǔ* are also *yin* without *yang*.

If one seeks to cultivate only these *yin* essences within the *yang*,
it is *yin* without its counterpart—
like a hen brooding an egg,
hoping to hatch a child,
yet achieving nothing.
What is hatched instead
are moths and caterpillars of strange kind—
such as the *yin*-toxic creatures in this tale:
the bees, ants, and clams,
not the true offspring of one’s original nature—
how could one not lose sight of their true source?

Even worse are those who grasp but a trifle of *yin-yang* principles,
yet fail to comprehend the true *yin-yang* correspondence—
they recklessly assume that consorting with women and gathering *yin* essence
to refine *yin* further,
leaving their bodies or even their lives behind,
is most pitiable!

This is the root of the errors in the "misguided origin" and "losing form."

The opening verse reads:
*"The Three Treasures parted from the Red and Purple King,
just as they were practicing,
they saw a household,
and wished to go and take refuge in a vegetarian hall."*

The allegory speaks of those who seek the Dao:
they renounce wealth and nobility,
yet mistakenly believe they alone can attain it.
*"It turned out that household had no men."*
This is a place of pure *yin* and scarce *yang*—
just as the poem says,
*"the wandering bee mistook the true path."*

*"Silent and still, no roosters or dogs in sound,"*
these two creatures being *yang* are entirely absent—
the stillness of *yin* is evident.
*"They saw a woman kicking a rubber ball,"*
a symbol of *yin* and *yang* energies intertwining.
The stone cave, stone door, stone table, and stool—
all are of *yin* essence within and without.
Thus, they summed it up as:
*"A chill *yin* atmosphere."*

*"The elder’s heart was alarmed,
and in secret, he pondered many ills and few blessings,"*
his body and mind, through experience, now doubted.
Yet though alarmed,
*"there was no alternative—
he had no choice but to sit down."*
For beyond this, there was no other path to seek.

Little did he know that within this household,
the arranged provisions were merely
human oil, human flesh, and human brains—
all the *yin* essence of the human body,
utterly devoid of *yang* energy.
Thus he declared:
*"If such things were to be consumed,
this monk would never hope to behold the World-Honored One,
nor obtain the sacred scriptures!"*
This is the same meaning as:
*"If one were to use these *yin* essences as elixir materials,
how could one ascend to the Jade Capital?"*

Lost in delusion, they fail to recognize the true source,
mistake the entrance,
and are entangled endlessly,
unable to escape—
like a rope binding a high-hanging corpse.
Even if they seek to escape the outer layers,
there are still inner layers;
if they break free from the upper section,
there remains the lower.
The more they ponder,
the more the doors close—
what difference is there
between this and the silkworm spinning endless threads
at the entrance of a village?

An outside observer sees them weave through countless layers of Daoist teachings,
yet knows not that they are merely trapped in the Seven Female Demons of the Silkworm Ridge:
the silkworm, the silkworm moth, and the other six.

Alas!
A single tangled maze with no threads to follow,
seven enchanted gates forever blocking the path.»

chunks.translated_text:
If one seeks true liberation,
one must first bathe in the natural order of Heaven.
A spring of primordial filth—born of Heaven—must be raised,
to be found in the very center of the southern *cùn* (inch),
where the old is cast off and the new is born.

This place is where celestial immortals dwell,
yet also where demons tread.
Should one mistake demons for immortals,
and then devise new schemes,
even if the silkworm threads are all consumed,
one will only stray into false and perverse paths.

Thus, the practitioner, once transformed,
becomes a carrion fly,
nailed to the roadside—
and in an instant,
though all silkworm flies are gone,
he hears the creak of a wooden gate—
this is the man who alters his path and falls into another heresy.

To practice the art of seducing women
is to hasten one’s own death.

The practitioner says:
*"These seven beauties—
if they were to keep my master,
they would not even fill a single meal;
if they were to use him,
they would not last two days.
A single touch, and he would be dead."*

「Careful calculation reveals that the few who escape being boiled and devoured by the myriad demons are indeed rare.

Speaking of the hot springs’ origin, it traces back to Hou Yi’s shooting down the sun—nine arrows struck, one remained—symbolizing the *"yin-path’s aversion to the nine-one"* [i.e., the excess of yin]. Speaking of the women stripping and bathing, it vividly depicts the alluring beauty that melts the soul.

Those starved for lust, like hungry vultures, will spread their wings and claws, snatch away clothing, and pay no heed to modesty. Those obsessed with seduction, like loach spirits, will slither and probe, their legs and groins writhing, while abandoning their own forms.

The practitioner and Eight Rules [Eight Precepts]—both demonstrate this in person, revealing their true appearances. Snatching clothing and probing groins are all symbols of seduction and plunder.

When qi is strong, *"they are crude and heavy, unaware of cherishing jade or loving fragrance."* When disaster strikes, their entire body is injured, yet they stumble left and right like one struck by blows. *"Numb limbs, weak legs, dizzying head, blurred vision—even crawling is impossible, only groaning on the ground"*—these are real consequences. How could such things not end in death? *"The seven women laugh as they return to their old chamber, while Eight Rules keeps tumbling"*—they gain nothing from others but harm themselves.

The *Yin-Shu Jing* [Classic of the Mysterious Pivot] states: *"Fire is born from wood; when disaster arises, it will surely overcome."* This is exactly what is meant.

Moreover, yin manifestations are manifold—some cling to you like a shadow, yet are not of your true kind. Not only can they not nourish the body to form the elixir, but they will turn the entire body into poison. Their offspring—*dry children, ants, clams, spotted creatures, grasshoppers, wax moths, and dragonflies*—will swarm over the limbs, shifting and transforming endlessly, beyond all cure.

Even with medicines like *huang* [yellow], *ma* [hemp], *□* [a missing character, possibly *wu* 鸟戎, "martial bird"], *bai* [white], *diao* [falcon], *yu* [fish], and *yao* [hawk], it is already too late—this serves as a profound warning.

*Zhuangzi* says: *"I guard my form and forget my body, appearing in murky waters while lost in clear depths."* I say: *"If one forgets form while seducing women, lost in clear depths while gazing into murky waters."* Such heretical practices must be burned away with fire.

**Chapter 73: Resentment from the Past Brings Poisonous Disaster; The Heart-Master’s Misfortune Luckily Breaks the Light**

Master Wu Yi said: The earlier text spoke of solitary cultivation gone wrong, leading to schemes of seduction. Now, it shifts from seduction’s folly to the delusion of alchemical refining. All are the work of mistaken speculation by the recognizing mind.

Though they claim to see with ten thousand eyes, believing they’ve spread the Heavenly Net and Earthly Web, their vision extends no further than an inch—blindly practicing, blindly refining. How could they know the subtlety of true yin and yang? It is supremely simple, effortlessly pure, and effortlessly one—boundless in its greatness, yet without internal limits. It is found in daily life, naturally at ease, effortlessly grasped, and unfathomably subtle.

To refine cinnabar, mercury, and black lead—substances of foreign essence—is to brew poison and invite death. There is no possibility of longevity or transcendence.

Pure Yang Master said:
*"Alas for Zhang the Prefect of Jiangzhou,
who took medicine and lost his sight—his spirit withered.
He did not know the True Elixir has no substance—
to swallow gold and stone is sheer folly!"*

Zi Yang Master said:
*"Do not refine the Three Yellows or Four Spirits,
for seeking herbs is not the True Way.
If one seeks the true lead and mercury,
they are not common sand or quicksilver."*

Bai Juyi said:
*"Before Dongyue’s tomb, new graves rise,
At Beimang’s mound, the dead lie.
I’ve heard of those who erred in their elixirs,
obsessed with the art of eternal life."*

The *Biography of Wei Fu* states:
*"Once, one who twice drank the elixir of immortality was found dead in his coffin.
Another, after taking a single dose of the knife-elixir, rotted in his grave.
Lu Pi Gong swallowed the Jade Flower, yet worms crawled from his mouth.
Jia Ji swallowed the Golden Elixir, and the stench reached a hundred li.
Huangdi melted nine tripods on Jing Mountain, yet his tomb remains on Qiao Ridge.
Li Yu took Cloud-Dispersing Pills to ascend in secret, yet his head and feet were found apart.
Mo Di drank the Rainbow Elixir and drowned himself in water.
Ning Sheng swallowed the Stone Marrow and threw himself into fire.
Wu Guang chopped chives to enter a cold spring;
Xiang Cheng inhaled qi, yet his stomach and intestines rotted away."*

All these prove that alchemical refining and ingestion are not noble pursuits—they are not the Great Dao of natural transformation. These are the golden needles of this very text.

The *Daozang Song* [Song of the Daoist Canon] says:
*"Seeing those who learn Daoism along the streams,
their paths billow with fiery smoke.
They no longer await the sun’s light,
nor do they preserve the essence of yin."*

It laments the deceptive paths of alchemy,
blocking the natural source of life.
It is like seeking to form a fetus from external substances,
or hoping to bear fruit by gathering flowers—
such attempts are doomed to fail.

The Daoist master of Huanghua Guan refined mercury and lead.
On the gate of his observatory hung a plaque proclaiming *"Yellow Sprouts"* and *"Qixia Flowers"*—
sitting and concocting pills, these are the very marks of a practitioner,
yet they hide their malevolent intentions.

The Daoist said: *"This medicine must not be given to yin-people."*
They know that humans belong to yin,
yet they fail to see that they themselves are the poison within yin.

These charlatans, under the guise of secret arts,
deaf, blind, and ignorant, covet wealth and seduce the greedy.
They will not rest until flesh and marrow are exhausted—
only then will their insatiable hunger be sated.

The seven demons’ complaints—first stealing clothes, then committing deceit—
are the everyday grievances of their sect.
Those who harm others now turn to accuse them,
still clinging to the flesh of others while claiming others harm themselves.

*"Fetching the ladder to climb the rafters,
bringing down the medicine."*
The medicine has been stored for a long time,
intended solely to poison others.
They scrape the light and pure substance from the cauldron—
this is what alchemists call *"plucking feathers to ascend as a treasure."*

The Daoist said: *"My treasure, if given to a commoner,
would kill them with just a grain—
once swallowed, death is certain."*

Only after they had eaten did he intervene to settle the matter.

The Daoist said: *"You’ve brought this calamity upon yourself—
don’t you realize?"*
For in the Spider Silk Cave, he had taken his alms,
and disaster struck from deep contemplation without enlightenment;
in the Filth-Washing Spring, he had bathed,
and disaster arose from licentiousness beyond restraint.

He willingly invited the plagues of *xiaoke* (consumption), *laozhui* (wasting sickness), and *taizhe* (emaciation),
willing to squander his fortune and sacrifice his life for the death-drug—
his resolve was beyond mortal obstruction.
Thus, the evil master could poison him with impunity;
he trusted blindly, and though he died, he bore no grudge—
*"Self-made misfortune cannot be undone."*

At this end, the seven demonesses’ true nature—
their clinging, pus-and-blood essence—was revealed.
How could they ascend?

The Daoist’s ruthless desire for flesh
merely exposed his shortsightedness—
how could he transcend?

Though the silk cords gleamed with intricate weavings,
at the limits of thought, the *"spider"* still knew its doom;
though the golden flanks blazed with a thousand flames,
ten *li* away, the *"centipede"* could never match *"Wukong’s"* enlightenment.

The Old Mother of Li Mountain mastered the *Yinfu* (Obscure Symbols),
speaking of the Hundred-Eyed Demon King’s monstrous sight—
the pure *yin* recognition, harboring poisoned flames.
The *Pilao* (Pilao) nun governed *yang* energy,
resembling the purple clouds of Thousand-Flower Cave atop *Ziyun Mountain*,
manifesting supreme *yang* brilliance, piercing luminous clarity.

The embroidered needle—
neither steel, nor iron, nor gold—
forged in the eye of *Mao* (the star).
Illuminating natural wisdom,
abandoning the muddled crossroads of perception.
*"A sound breaks the golden light,"*
countless cleverness is but illusion;

when the sun rises, fire loses its glow.

The centipede’s *yang* poison revealed its true form—
where then is the Daoist’s *"yellow sprout"* and *"qi flower"*?

Wisdom shatters illusion;
*yang* subdues *yin*;
subtlety conceals profundity;
virtue eradicates evil;
one principle encompasses myriad truths;
the elixir dissolves poison—

A cultivator who, at the *Mother Hen’s* abode,
removes the *wuqi* (centipede) from the robe,
deeply grasps true and false,
and subdues the roots—
then all peripheral obstacles will be reduced to ashes,
and one may attain life while perfecting nature.

Treasure One said: *"Austerities and refining bring no benefit to longevity—
they only hasten death; this is demonic, not Dao!"*
Beyond this, where else might one seek truth?
One must empty oneself to serve others,
seeking a true master’s guidance.

If one boasts arrogantly or hesitates with doubt,
a monstrous obstacle will surely arise,
blocking the path to the West.

The opening states: *"Practicing merit, advancing in error,"*
warning disciples to proceed with caution in seeking instruction,
finding a genuine place to go.

*"The Three Saints broke free from desire’s net,
leaping from emotional bonds—
as they walked forward, they saw a towering mountain,
its peaks piercing the blue sky, truly obstructing heaven and sun.
An old man shouted: ‘Master of the West, halt for now!
On this mountain lurks a band of demons,
who have devoured countless mortals—
do not proceed!’"*

This arose from his own arrogance,
blindly rushing forward without seeking guidance,
raising a treacherous peak to block the path—
a demon born of his own hubris.

It foreshadows the later revelations of *yin-yang* mysteries,
for without humility and self-abnegation,
one cannot penetrate deeply and instead becomes a demon.

The *Laozi* says:
*"Not asserting oneself, one becomes eminent;
not praising oneself, one achieves merit;
not boasting, one endures."*
The *Zuozhuan* says:
*"When seeking something, one must first humble oneself."*
Confucius says:
*"Consider others below you."*
The *Dao Decalogue Stele* says:
*"Gentleness and weakness are the path’s crossing."*
All urge the practitioner to cultivate a yielding nature,
a humble heart seeking benefit to enter the Dao.

*"The Master said: ‘Your appearance is grotesque,
your speech vulgar—
I fear you’ll offend him,
and we’ll gain no truth.’"*
This is the passage’s core lesson.

The Disciple laughed: *"Let me change into a more refined form to ask."*
He transformed into a young novice—
truly able to alter his demeanor.

Yet phrases like *"degrading oneself to rise"* were still excessive.

The old man said: *"This novice spoke too boldly—
he’ll never grow again."*
Seeing his reckless words, he gave no reply—
arrogant speech earns no trust.

Eight Rules then bowed to ask,
begging for guidance once more.
Only with humility could true trust be earned.

Pointing to *"Lion-Tiger Ridge, Lion-Tiger Cave,"*
it symbolizes obstinate, unruly *qi*—
if the heart lacks mastery and restraint spreads unchecked,
south, north, east, and west—
all directions become demonic mouths,
and the body becomes mere meat.

Thus the Disciple said: *"I have my own plan."*
The Golden Star said: *"Only your transformative schemes
will allow passage.
If you delay even slightly,
the path will prove difficult."*

The road does not bend left to turn,
but points toward the Western Sea as its goal."*

It laments the world’s tangled paths, where the straight way is unpassable.
To turn aside seems like a stratagem, yet abandoning the true path to speak of turning
is like abandoning the scripture to speak of expedients,
or abandoning the balance to speak of the hammer.
To reverse the scripture and distort the measure
is not the subtle art of weighing and balancing to judge lightness and heaviness—
thus it cannot be called an expedient.
Hence, *"You cannot turn aside."*

Since the Han dynasty, none have deeply understood this meaning.
The Immortal Master, along the journey to obtain the scriptures,
always pointed out the phrase *"You cannot turn aside,"*
profoundly illustrating that the true path—abandoning the yin-yang mysteries—
does not allow westward passage.
This can be said to be one who deeply grasps both scripture and expedient.

This is the power of transformative action,
and thus it is uniquely attributed to the Disciple.

For turning means:
the demon lords over me, and I flee the demon—
yet the demon remains, and the demons in the path of turning are even more numerous.
If the demon remains, how can I rely on turning?

The turning that does not turn:
I lord over the demon, and the demon submits to me—
the demon is already subdued, and the demons in the path of turning are already vanquished.
When the demon is subdued, that is the use of turning,
yet I do not lose the true path.

Thus, the great practitioner knows
that all external demons arise from internal demons—
not questioning the external, only the internal;
not fearing demons, only fearing myself.

The Disciple said: *"As long as we remain mindful."*

chunks.original_text: “变做苍蝇儿”者，化大为小，变粗就细，为婴儿善柔之状，而不失其赤子之心也。 婴儿之心，天然良知，毫无私意，魔所不能窥。 入于魔之耳，出于魔之口，即此会变婴儿一念，已足钻透魔腹矣。 心主火，而虚灵不昧，故称为“烧火的”； 火得风，而乘势益燃，故称为“总站风”。 最妙在“查勘真假”一段：统大小于一体，混真假为一家，此纵神造鬼幻之笔，描心口商量之词，非可泥为实相也。 真心原是真钻风，在魔则为假； 真钻风原是假心，在魔则为真。 以假勘真，假可为真； 以真从假，真亦是假。 故曰：“合着我，便是真； 差了些，便是假。 ”此知小钻风之实话，即总钻风之大话矣。
chunks.translated_text:
「“Transforming into a gnat” means:
to reduce the great to the small,
to refine the coarse into the subtle,
to embody the gentle and tender state of an infant—
yet never losing the pure, innocent heart.

The infant’s heart,
by nature, is true knowing (*liángzhī*),
free from all private intent—
demons cannot penetrate it.

Entering through the demon’s ear,
exiting from the demon’s mouth—
this very act of transforming into a gnat in a single thought
is already enough to pierce through the demon’s belly.

The heart commands fire (*xīnhuǒ*),
yet its emptiness and luminosity remain unobscured—
thus it is called *“the one who stokes the fire”* (*shāohuǒ de*).
Fire needs wind to spread,
and when it rides the wind, it burns even more fiercely—
thus it is called *“the master of the wind”* (*zǒngzhàn fēng*).

The most wondrous part lies in the *“Investigating the true and false”* section:
unifying great and small into one,
blending true and false into a single household—
this is the stroke of the divine creating ghostly illusions,
painting words of the heart’s inner deliberation,
not to be taken as literal reality (*shíxiàng*).

The true heart is originally the true master of the wind (*zhēnzhuānfēng*),
yet in the demon’s realm, it becomes false;
The true master of the wind is originally false heart (*jiǎxīn*),
yet in the demon’s realm, it becomes true.

Using false to investigate the true,
the false can become true;
Using true to follow the false,
the true also becomes false.

Thus it is said:
“When it aligns with me, it is true;
When it strays even slightly, it is false.”

This is the genuine speech of the small master of the wind (*xiǎo zhuānfēng*),
which is also the profound discourse of the great master of the wind (*dà zhuānfēng*).」

chunks.original_text: 盖矢口之魔，出好兴戎，原属自造，小妖所告“吞天兵”、“欲争天”、“蟠桃会”诸语，适与行者五百年前所为吻合。 魔之所为，即行者之所为，行者所以道：“若是讲口头话，老孙也曾干过。 ”然“一口曾吞十万天兵”之语，虽似诞妄，不过形容豪迈夸大之概耳。 如宋玉云”弯弓挂扶桑，长剑须天倚”； 又“饮如长鲸吸百川”； 杨大年云“手可摘星辰”； 王右军云“笔阵独扫千人军”； 文天祥云“南人志欲扶昆仑，北人志欲河带吞”，皆是也。 唯言大而夸，狂荡失中，实为入道之魔。 行者始而“暗笑”，继而“暗想”，终而“暗惊”，乃三思自反，检束着里也。 “阴阳二气瓶”，变化莫测，精微融浑之妙理。 以粗豪遇之，鲜不葬埋其中； 以浮夸处之，罔不汩没其内。 其窍至虚而至坚，苟不细心研究，深入其际，终难出窍。 行者道：“只是仔细防他瓶儿。 ” 防之之法，务先平气慎言为要。
chunks.translated_text:
The demon of reckless speech stirs up martial ambition—
its origins lie in self-forged delusion.
The minor demon’s warnings—
*"swallowing the Heavenly Host,"*
*"contending with Heaven,"*
*"the Peach Blossom Feast"*—
mirror the Journeyer’s deeds from five hundred years past.

What the demon does, the Journeyer has done;
thus the Journeyer says:
*"If it’s mere boastful talk, I’ve done worse myself."*

Yet the claim—
*"once swallowed ten million Heavenly Soldiers"*—
though seemingly absurd,
merely captures the bold, exaggerated spirit.

As in Song Yu’s words:
*"Bent bow hung on the Fu Sang,*
*long sword leaned against Heaven’s pillar";*
or *"drinking like a great whale absorbing the hundred rivers";*
or Yang Da’s *"hand plucking stars from the sky";*
or Wang Xizhi’s *"brush strokes sweeping a thousand-man army";*
or Wen Tianxiang’s *"southern will to prop up Kunlun,*
*northern will to swallow the Yellow River whole"*—
all such speech is grand yet empty,
wild yet ungrounded—
the very demon of the Dao.

The Journeyer first *"darkly laughs,"*
then *"darkly ponders,"*
finally *"darkly startles,"*
threefold reflection to curb himself.

The *"Yin-Yang Qi Bottle"*—
its transformations boundless,
its subtleties fused in profound unity.
Encountered with crude boldness, few escape its grasp;
met with empty boasting, none avoid its depths.
Its aperture is both utterly void and utterly firm—
unless one studies it with meticulous care,
penetrating to its core,
one will never pass through.

The Journeyer says:
*"Only beware the bottle itself."*
To guard against it,
one must first cultivate evenness of breath and caution in speech.

chunks.original_text: 然多口尤为心害，故要拿洞里妖，必先除门前怪，吹散小妖，去多口也。 妙在唐僧肉“不多几片”一语，言道味淡泊，简要无多，众口嗷嗷，万不得一，亦空费垂涎而已，多口果何用哉？ 然则说大话骗人，只可吹散小妖，何能免大魔之吞噬乎？ 第七十五回　心猿钻透阴阳窍　魔主还归大道真 悟一子曰：此明炼精化气之妙用，施为变化之初乘也。 昔老聃语孔子曰：“去子之骄气。 ”盖“骄”之一字，道之魔也。 人能以柔用，以弱进，则无刚不柔，无强不弱。 我善养锐锋，而魔自失其完垒，魔还归我之真矣。 非逊志善下，洞晓阴阳，深明造化，终莫窥其底里。 老子云：“吾无欲以观其妙，有欲以观其徼[微]。 ”紫阳云：“不会钻研莫强攻。 ”切指阴阳二气之徼、妙不易钻研也。 后人不知大道之的，谓即心是道，以心钻心，尽失其徼、妙。 张子曰：“由气化有道之名。 ”则已明指道属二气而不属于心，特心为钻透徼妙之主耳。 “大圣变小钻风，进了狮驼洞”，正变化柔弱而虚心寻讨也。 “变苍蝇”，柔弱之至。 惊动老魔，不觉一笑，戏渝疏忽，自露圭角，焉得不被魔所缚，拘于宝瓶乎？ 宝瓶合阴阳二气，水火浑沌，涵罗精神，无物不化。 就人身而言，即脐内中黄呼吸之根蒂，修炼家认为玄牝，凝神结路之处，所谓“白玉连环”也； 位居中央，而七宝、八卦、二十四气，无所不包。 人身有天地，而此穴象太极，原无二理。 然此为顺则成人之徼、妙，而非逆则成丹之徼、妙。 学道者说到此处，茫然不识，无可钻研，惟有缩手待毙而已。 唯能于此内打通消息，则知丹道法象亦只如此，特有内外顺逆之差别耳。 奈何世人谬执此宝瓶，谓精能生气，气能生神，凝神此穴，用意封固，以自取速化耶！ 老魔曰：“猴儿今番入我宝瓶之中，再莫想那西天之路。 ”仙师设此二语，提醒春梦多矣。 “装入瓶中”，凝神气穴，炼精化气之象。 “闭息忘言”，寂然不动也，不动者，静也，静属水； “失声发笑”，感而遂通也，感通者，动也，动属火。 故闻人言而火来，动静感应之理。 “四十条蛇揪做八十段”，四象分为八卦也； “三条火龙上下盘旋”，君火、相火、民火互为运用也。 又三四为七，二四为八，三八为二十四，四八为三十二，循环计之，仍合宝瓶中“七宝、八卦、二十四气”、“三十六人”之义。 “身长则长，身小则小”，总明随身动静，不能知微妙而解脱也。 盖执此中而欲超凡证果，是执有名之体而冀无名之始，岂不自误？ 行者道：“何期今日误入此中，倾了性命。 想是我昔日名儿，故有今朝之难。 ”想到菩萨心传三根救命毫毛，方归真谛。 变化钻研，透彻天机，开菩萨之法眼，泄阴阳之秘妙，打破疑团，脱离火阱，真造化出身之大道也！ “变蟭蟟，暂借一枝栖，姑且魔顶游衍； “放下杯”，忽讶瓶之罄，能不失声破釜！ “空者，控也”，空劳水火煮空铛； “搜者，走也”，搜寻虚窟难搜着。 噫！ 瓶子钻破，装不得人”，犹人身真阳已泄，还不得丹，古人比之“破叉袋”，即此义也。 钻研至此，道心自现，魔胆自惊。 真精化气，真气化身，悟彻真空，头头是道。 魔刀下处即成我，我者，魔之分身，劈做两半，还做两身，虽千万亿身，无非我也；
chunks.translated_text:
The many-mouthed are the greatest harm to the heart—
thus to seize the cave’s demon,
one must first dispel the gate’s specter,
scattering minor demons,
removing the many-mouthed.

The marvel lies in the phrase *"Tang Seng’s flesh—no more than a few scraps"*—
speaking of flavor so sparse and simple,
so few and far between,
that all their clamoring is but wasted drooling.
What use are the many-mouthed then?

Yet if one speaks grand lies to deceive,
scattering minor demons may work—
how can it escape the Great Demon’s devouring?

In the seventy-fifth installment—
*"The Monkey’s Spirit Pierces Yin-Yang’s Aperture,"*
*"The Demon Lord Returns to the True Dao"*—
Master Wu Yi says:
This is the wondrous application of refining essence into qi,
the initial stage of transformation and change.

Of old, Lao Dan spoke to Confucius:
*"Banish your arrogant qi."*
For *"arrogant"* is the Dao’s demon.

If one uses softness and advances with weakness,
then nothing rigid remains unyielding,
nothing strong remains unweakened.

I cultivate my sharp edge well—
the demon loses its perfect defenses,
and the demon returns to my true self.

Unless one humbles the will,
penetrates Yin-Yang’s secrets,
and deeply grasps the workings of creation,
one will never fathom its depths.

Laozi said:
*"Without desire, I observe its marvel;
with desire, I observe its subtleties."*
Zhu Xi said:
*"Without study, do not force attack."*
Both point to the subtleties and marvels of Yin-Yang qi—
difficult to penetrate.

Later scholars, unaware of the Dao’s essence,
claim *"the heart is the Dao,"*
and by probing the heart with the heart,
lose all trace of subtlety and marvel.

Zhang Zai said:
*"From qi’s transformation comes the name Dao."*
Thus, it is already clear that the Dao belongs to Yin-Yang,
not to the heart—
though the heart is the master of piercing its subtleties and marvels.

*"The Great Sage transforms into a tiny wind-drilling insect,
entering the Lion’s Mane Cave"*—
this is the transformation of softness and weakness,
seeking with an empty heart.

*"Transforming into a fly"*—
the ultimate of softness and weakness.

Startling the old demon,
unaware it laughs,
its careless jest reveals its flaw—
how else could it be bound by the treasure bottle?

The treasure bottle unites Yin-Yang qi,
water and fire in primal chaos,
encompassing spirit and vitality—
nothing escapes its transformation.

In the human body, it is the root of the navel’s central yellow breath,
the alchemical *"play of the mysterious female,"*
where spirit is condensed and the path is sealed—
the so-called *"white jade linked rings."*

Central in position,
it contains the seven treasures, eight trigrams, and twenty-four qi—
nothing is excluded.

The body mirrors heaven and earth,
and this orifice symbolizes the Supreme Ultimate—
no duality exists.

Yet this, when followed correctly, becomes the marvel of human perfection;
when reversed, it becomes the marvel of elixir cultivation.

Students of the Dao reach this point,
bewildered and unable to probe—
only to retreat in despair.

Only by penetrating its inner workings
does one realize that the alchemical method is but this—
with only internal and external, correct and inverted, distinctions.

Yet how foolish to cling to this treasure bottle,
claiming *"essence begets qi, qi begets spirit,"*
condensing spirit here, fixing intent to seal it—
only to hasten one’s own transformation!

The old demon says:
*"Monkey, this time you enter my treasure bottle—
no more thoughts of the Western Path."*

The immortal sage’s words here awaken many spring dreams.
*"Sealed within the bottle"*—
condensing spirit at the qi-orifice,
the symbol of refining essence into qi.
*"Closing breath, forgetting speech"*—
silent and unmoving—
stillness belongs to water;
*"losing voice, breaking into laughter"*—
stirred and responsive—
responsiveness belongs to fire.

Thus, hearing words ignites fire—
the principle of dynamic response in stillness.

*"Forty snakes twisted into eighty"*—
the four symbols divided into eight trigrams;
*"three fire dragons spiraling above and below"*—
the interplay of sovereign fire, ministerial fire, and common fire.

Again, three and four make seven,
two and four make eight,
three and eight make twenty-four,
four and eight make thirty-two—
counting in cycles,
they still align with the bottle’s *"seven treasures, eight trigrams, twenty-four qi,"*
and *"thirty-six persons."*

*"Long body, short body"*—
all reveal that movement and stillness adapt to the body,
yet one cannot perceive its subtleties to escape.

To cling here and seek transcendence—
this is to grasp a named form
while hoping for the origin of the nameless—
is it not self-deception?

The Journeyer says:
*"Who would have thought today I’d fall into this,
losing my very life?
It must be my past name
that brings this present calamity."*

Recalling the Bodhisattva’s transmission of the three-hair saving thread,
he returns to true truth.

Through transformation and study,
he pierces the heavens’ secrets,
opens the Bodhisattva’s law-eye,
reveals Yin-Yang’s hidden marvels,
shatters doubt,
escapes the fire-pit—
the true Dao of transcending birth and death!

*"Transforming into a cicada,
temporarily perching on a branch,
wandering atop the demon’s head;
setting down the cup,*
suddenly astonished to find the bottle empty—
how could one not cry out in shattering the pot!"

*"Empty"*—also *"control"*—
laboring in vain, boiling an empty pot with water and fire;
*"searching"*—also *"fleeing"*—
seeking a hollow cave in vain.

Alas!
*"The bottle is pierced—
no one can be sealed within."*
Like the body’s true yang already dissipated,
no elixir remains—
ancients likened it to *"breaking the forked sack."*
This is the meaning.

Studying to this point,
the Dao-heart manifests itself,
the demon’s audacity falters.

True essence refines into true qi,
true qi transforms into the body—
enlightenment dawns on true emptiness,
everywhere is the Dao.

Where the demon’s blade falls,
I become—
I, the demon’s manifestation,
split into two, yet still two selves—
though countless billions of bodies,
they are all still me;

chunks.translated_text:
I head meets—it becomes true,
True—*the original body of the demon*,
clasped to my form—
still, one and the same.
Though countless billions of demons,
they are all still true.

One becomes two, two becomes one—
thus the demon reveals its original form to devour the true self,
I am the true demon;
I enter the demon’s belly, subduing its head,
I am demon of the demon.

*"Stay through winter, reach Qingming"*—
symbolizing the ebb and flow of yin-yang *qi*;
*"Practice inhalation-exhalation, sneeze"*—
illustrating the false actions of mouth and nose.
*"Take the medicine elixir, trumpet-mouth"*—
soon the peach-blossom face glows red;
*"Scatter the wine-qi, somersault"*—
only then is the treasure hidden in the *utpala* belly revealed.

Ah!
*Transform qi!* *Transform qi!*
How shall it emerge?
This must have a method.

*"When Old Monkey thrusts his *jin-gu* staff into his crown—
a hole is pierced:
first as a sky-light,
second as a smoke-chute."*
Is this not the supreme method for *qi* to exit?

Those who expound the Dao reveal the heavens’ secrets to this point—
truly, they know deeply and speak exhaustively.

Divine!
Wondrous!
