「Yet this is but the *true* understanding of the *Way*’s core, but the practitioner has not yet attained its *true* subtlety—thus it is the *"initial vehicle"* (初乘).

**Chapter 76: *Heart-Mind Dwells, Demon Returns to Its True Nature* (心神居舍魔归性)**
*Wood-Mother’s* descent betrays the demon’s true form (木母同降怪体真).
*The Awakened One* said: This reveals the profound art of refining *qi* and transforming *spirit*—the *"middle vehicle"* (中乘) of Daoist practice and change.

*The Zhuangzi* teaches: *"When the mind’s intent is undivided, it coalesces into *spirit*."* (用志不分，乃凝于神。)
*The Master* said: *"The heart is the sovereign of *qi*; *qi* is the root of *spirit*; *spirit* is the very *nature* itself. The form is the dwelling of *qi*; *spirit* is the essence of the form; *qi* is the vital *command*."* (心者气之主，气者神之根，神即性也；形者气之舍，神者形之精，气即命也。)
Indeed, refining the *form* (形) allows the *essence* (精) to transform *qi*; when *qi* gathers, it transmutes into *spirit*; when *spirit* is concentrated at the *qi*’s aperture (气穴), *qi* grows ever more potent, and *spirit* becomes ever more luminous (灵).
Yet this *essence* is not the *yin* essence of copulation (交感精), this *qi* is not the breath of respiration (呼吸气), this *spirit* is not the restless mind of deliberation (思虑神).
As *Duzijian* (督子) says: *"From the void it arises, not in heart or kidney, but in the *Xuanmen* aperture alone."* (从虚无中来，不在心肾，而在于玄关一窍。)
Scholars who fail to grasp *yin-yang* merely grope at their own bodies, mistaking the *manifest* and *luminous* cognition (昭昭灵灵之识神) for true attainment—thus they wander far astray.

In the text: *"The Old Demon roars, ‘Great Compassionate, Great Merciful Sage of Equal Heavenly Rank!’"* (老魔叫一声：‘大慈大悲齐天大圣菩萨！ ’)
Calling *"Great"* (大) repeatedly, he seeks *command* (命) through the *one* (人) within.
*The Pilgrim* replies: *"Shorten it by a few characters—just call ‘Old Monkey’s grandfather, Sun Wukong.’"* (行者道：‘省几个字儿，只叫孙外公果。 ’)
The Old Demon, thus addressed, truly calls out: *"Grandfather! Grandfather!"*
This shows that recognizing the *external* and *internal* dualities (外来二八厶厶) is the true way to borrow *command*.

Why send him out with a *single-vehicle* bamboo litter (一乘香藤轿)?
It signifies that only this *single-vehicle* method is genuine—all others are false.

*"The Pilgrim acts within the Demon’s belly"*—
his *heart-mind* (心神) dwells and refines, calming the *internal* to secure the *external*.
*"He binds his heart-liver with a single thread"*—
placing it in one fixed point, holding the *commercial* (商) to govern the *excessive* (多).
*"Then he shrinks his body, facing the Demon’s steel fangs and sharp blades"*—
controlling his *form* (形) and *spirit* (魄), using the *small* to subdue the *great*, the *yielding* to overcome the *unyielding*.
*"With a sneeze, the Pilgrim bursts forth—seeing the wind, he grows three zhang tall"*—
refining *qi* (气) reveals the *original spirit* (元神).
*"Severing the outer, the inner feels distress"*—
*internal* and *external* are one; *emotion* (情) does not part from *nature* (性)—this is not a clear-cut severance.

*"The Three Demons fall together, bowing their heads; the host of demons retreat, all returning to their caves"*—
this is the refining of *qi* and transforming of *spirit*, where the demon submits to its true *nature*.

Yet even at this stage, though the *yang spirit* (阳神) appears, the *yin qi* (阴气) has not yet integrated with *my* (我) *qi* as one—so the demon remains, like a traveler still midway.

In the text: *"The Master and Disciple pack their belongings and horses, waiting along the road"*—
and at its end: *"The Demon and monsters, united in heart and intent, march west for another four hundred li"*—
merely illustrating the midpoint of their journey.

The practitioner must now diligently apply *fire cultivation* (火功), proceed with utmost caution, lest he falter—
for if *yin qi* is not subdued, it will encroach upon the *original spirit*, when will he transcend?

*"The False Descents of the Two Demons"*—
*yin qi* not yet mastered.
*"The Three Demons’ ‘Separate the Tiger from the Mountain’"*—
*yin qi* not yet mastered.
*"The Thirty Monsters, arranging tea and meals, hosting the Tang Monk"*—
the lingering of *yin qi*.
*"The Sixteen Ghosts, in turn shouting orders, replacing the litter-bearers"*—
the harassment of *yin qi*.

*"Beholding the city’s malevolent *qi*"*—
the obstruction of *yin qi*.
*"Each harbors wrathful *qi*—thunderous clashes erupt; the Three Monks and Three Demons battle to the death"*—
*yin qi* and *yang spirit* intermingle, locked in struggle.
*"They bear the Tang Monk aloft, silence their banners and drums; the monsters swirl around him, the Elder sinks into a stupor"*—
*yin qi* overwhelms in its vast, desolate power, and the true *yang* is once more submerged.

Tracing the root of this failure:
*Wood-Mother* indulged in private schemes, while *fire cultivation* was weak.
*"At the slightest provocation, he scatters *fire*"*—
*fire cultivation* is weak.
*"He hoards his private stores"*—
*Wood-Mother* indulges in private schemes.
Only because of this weakness, he suffered defeat in battle—*fire* was exhausted by *earth*.
Only because of this indulgence, he was terrified into feigning submission—*wood* was overwhelmed by *water*.

Thus, the translation concludes.

only then is the treasure hidden in the *utpala* belly revealed.

Ah!
*Transform qi!* *Transform qi!*
How shall it emerge?
This must have a method.

*"When Old Monkey thrusts his *jin-gu* staff into his crown—
a hole is pierced:
first as a sky-light,
second as a smoke-chute."*
Is this not the supreme method for *qi* to exit?

Those who expound the Dao reveal the heavens’ secrets to this point—
truly, they know deeply and speak exhaustively.

Divine!
Wondrous!

The Dao of seeking the scriptures forbids complacency and sloth, demanding instead steadfast and arduous effort. The Pilgrim says: *"Let him endure some hardship, that he may know the difficulty of seeking the scriptures."*

Knowing that the quest cannot do without the *Wood-Mother*, yet that the monstrous forms must be subdued through mutual descent—when *metal* and *wood* harmonize, the male leads while the female follows, as brothers in affection, the elder and younger in accord. *"The Pilgrim obeys Eight Rules and strikes through the elephant’s trunk, while Eight Rules obeys the Pilgrim and beats the elephant’s hide. Two elephant powers, together subduing the monsters."* Is this not the true spirits uniting their strength, the true monsters manifesting their forms?

Thus, the guiding principle states:
*"The mind-spirit dwells in the demon’s nature, the Wood-Mother descends with the monster’s true form."*

In the seventy-seventh chapter—*Group Demons Mock True Nature, One Body Pays Homage to True Suchness*—Master Yu says: This is the wondrous application of refining the spirit back to emptiness, the supreme technique of transformation and action. Subduing the Lion’s heart earned the first stage; subduing the Elephant’s nature earned the middle stage; subduing the Peng’s *qi* earned the highest stage. When the Great Suchness Dao arrives, though it is said the mind-spirit dwells in the demon’s nature, the spirit and *qi* have not yet merged into undivided oneness, returning to the Great Void—then this mind-nature remains entangled in existence and cannot transcend the mundane. Thus, the Great Peng was not subdued in *qi*, and the Lion and Elephant followed suit—*"the group demons mock the true nature."*

The Master said: *"Subduing qi does not serve qi; serving qi requires subduing qi. Serving qi does not bring longevity; longevity requires subduing qi."* The Peng does not yield to *qi*, for it follows the true *yin* *qi*, roaming freely through heaven and earth without submission, making the demon’s influence vast. *"Lion"* symbolizes the mind, belonging to *fire*, prone to suspicion, hence its green hue. Fire not yet ignited but smoke arising—*fire* combined with *wood*—it is the leader of cultivation, the foundation of the Dao’s practice, hence called the Old Demon. Its domain is named *"Lion’s Ridge, Lion’s Cave."*

*"Elephant"* symbolizes nature, belonging to *earth*, generating *metal*, hence its white hue. It rests upon the body and resides in the west, *earth* combined with *metal*—it is the mighty strength bearing the Dao, the luminous essence embodying the Dao, hence called the Second Demon. To subdue these two demons is to attain the Two Vehicles, the wondrous application of cultivating nature.

The Great Peng is the *kun* of the Northern Sea in *Zhuangzi*, transforming into the Peng, soaring ninety thousand *li* southward. The Northern Sea is water—*"uttermost yin, solemn and austere, yet within it lies yang."* The *kun* in water is *yang*; transforming into the Peng, soaring ninety thousand *li* southward, it reaches the extreme of *yang* in its ninefold power. Thus, *"uttermost yang, blazing beneath the Great Brightness above."* The Peng belongs to the Phoenix, the Vermilion Bird of the South. The *Shi Han Ji* says: *"The Vermilion Bird blazes through the void descending,"* akin to the *Dan Jing*’s *"Crimson Phoenix,"* both referring to true *yang qi* and the wondrous application of nurturing life.

The Sun-Wukong of old, in his boastful defiance, declares:
*"My mighty lord can swallow ten ten-thousands of celestial soldiers in one gulp."*
*"My lord desires to challenge Heaven."*
*"Five hundred years ago, he devoured the Lion-Elephant Kingdom and seized its realm."*
This already foreshadows the meaning above.

*"The Old Fiend praised his strength and cunning, ordering the minor demons to fetch water, stir the pot, and haul out the iron cage to steam the monk and scatter them each to their own fate."*

The lesser demons took turns stoking the fire, awaiting the moment when the monk’s vital essence would be consumed.

*"The Elder cried to the Pilgrim, ‘How shall we save our lives?’ The two monks wept in unison."*
This laments that all are unaware of the *Dao* of escape.

*"The Pilgrim laughed, ‘Master, fear not. Brothers, cease your tears. Whatever he may do, I shall suffer no harm.’ He then gathered his spirit, leapt into the air, and vanished from sight."*

chunks.translated_text:
The words speak of spirit and enlightenment, for it lies within the person. If one seeks to escape the cycle of life and death, there exists a method of leaping beyond the body.

Human existence within the *Wu Xing* is like being trapped in an iron cage, subjected to steaming—when the fire reaches its peak, none escape unscathed, their flesh rotting and bones dissolving. Thus, death is as inevitable as night follows day, with none spared.

The *Dao* of escape begins with subduing desires through *fùlóng* (伏龙, "Suppressed Dragon")—quelling passions as one draws fuel from beneath the cauldron, preventing the flames from surging. The Great Sage dispatched the Northern Sea Dragon to guard beneath the pot, drawing fuel as *fùlóng* does.

Next, it lies in cultivating virtue through precepts to soothe the mind, opening a boundless and uninhibited spirit, so that *qi* does not stagnate. The Eight Rules [Precepts] spoke of "stifled *qi*" and "releasing *qi*," for when the Pilgrim sealed the pot, the Eight Rules declared, *"Tonight, death is certain."*

The Elder wept bitterly, revealing how stifled *qi* becomes a demon—most pitiable of afflictions. The Eight Rules exclaimed:
*"Hark! O fire-tender, why add more fuel? You’ve sealed your own fate!"*
Truly wondrous!

chunks.original_text: 天蓬身遭铁笼之惨遇，当危急之地，而潇洒玩弄如无事戏耍，然知其俯视一切，不足为魔，其胸怀为何如也？ 宜乎烧火小妖瞌睡寝息矣。 “行者现身来救，八戒道：‘救要脱根救，莫又要笼蒸。 ’”谓能逃五行蒸气之外为脱根，不能逃五行蒸气之外为复笼。 倘修行之人不能超凡出世，虽德行无亏，仍在轮回之内，终是凡体生根，难免入笼复蒸之患。 故行者道：“若不为师父是个凡体，我三人不管怎的也走了。 ”但此脱根出世之道，乃劈破鸿蒙、凿开混沌之大超脱，非不顾行检、算计爬墙之小法门。 师徒爬墙，而魔头忽起，纷纷拿住，势必复蒸，不省已错报怨于人，果有何益？ 然何以不复蒸，把唐僧抱住不放，入于锦香铁柜之中，设为生吃谣传之计？ 盖明世间一切旁门小术，俱是爬墙，必至入柜而后已。 若欲借此逃命，反自促其死，不必俟五行之气极而肉烂，即已自罹戾气而生就魔口矣。
chunks.translated_text:
The **Tianpeng** found himself trapped in the iron cage’s cruel fate, yet at the moment of dire peril, he lounged about with carefree ease, as though playing at leisure. Knowing he looked down upon all things, insufficient to be a demon, what was the breadth of his heart?

Thus, the fire-tending minor demon dozed and slept soundly.

When the Pilgrim revealed himself to save, the Eight Rules said:
*"Escape must mean breaking free from the cage’s roots—
do not again let it steam you!"*

He meant that to evade the Five Elements’ [五行] suffocating *qi* was to break free from the cage’s roots,
while to be unable to evade the Five Elements’ suffocating *qi* was to be trapped again within its steam.

If a cultivator cannot transcend the mundane and escape the cycle of existence,
though his virtue and conduct may be flawless,
he remains bound within rebirth,
his ordinary essence still rooted—
how could he avoid the fate of being recaptured and steamed once more?

Therefore, the Pilgrim declared:
*"If my master is no more than an ordinary being,
we three will leave anyway, no matter what."*

Yet this path of breaking free from the cage’s roots and escaping the world
is the grand liberation—
splitting apart the primordial chaos and piercing through the formless void,
not the petty tricks of ignoring discipline,
or scheming to climb walls.

When master and disciple climbed the wall,
the demon suddenly awoke,
seizing them all—
they were bound to be recaptured and steamed again.
Even if they did not wrong others,
how could they benefit themselves?

But how did they not face recapture and steaming?
How did the demon cling to the Tang Monk, refusing to let him go,
and thrust him into the **Jinxin Iron Chest** [锦香铁柜],
planning to devour him alive?

It was because he knew that all worldly shortcuts and minor arts
are but schemes to climb walls—
they inevitably lead to being locked in the chest.

chunks.original_text: 伤哉； 世人多犯魔口之夹生活嚼，三藏犹然，大圣闻之，能不心如刀搅，泪如泉涌而放声大哭？ 曰：“努力修行共炼魔”，“气散心伤可奈何”，此大哭也！ 乃大哭世人当于此时困心衡虑，砥砺增益之时，故现身设法，急急回头，扫荡狮驼洞而猛省，见如来念《松箍咒》，以图超脱也。 你看“径上灵山”，“哮吼如雷”，抑何勇往精进耶？ 如来指示老魔二怪之主，说出大鹏系凤凰所生，与孔雀一母同气，是亦佛母也。 所言孔雀出世之时，一口吸四十五里之人，如来亦被吸去，即“一口能吞十万天兵”之意。 但如来已修成丈六金身，故能入魔口而剖魔脊。 三藏未成金身，未免为魔口所吞而不能超脱。 故必收伏此魔，而后能成丈六金身也。 然则凡魔之捆我、蒸我、吞我、柜我，皆魔之所以爱惜我、生育我、陶铸我、造化我，非唯有大仇，而有大恩也。 孔雀、大鹏，皆大慈大悲而真为怫母，夫复何疑？ 后人见孔雀封佛母，以佛法冤亲无等为痛，殆未深得孟氏“动心忍性，生于忧患”之义； 亦未深识大鹏喻真乙之气，实为生仙、佛、圣人之母耳。 夫美珠沉于海底，坚金炼于烈火，至真出于大魔，极贯之物，未有不从难险而获。 学道若不遭大鹏而勇猛收伏，终不能成仙作佛，不易之定理也。 “如来引文殊、普贤至狮驼国，命行者与怪交战，诱至佛前。 那怪见过去、未来、现在三尊佛像及罗汉、揭谛，认得主人公。 ”非认得心为主人公也，所以者何？ “过去心，不可得； 未来心，不可得； 现在心，不可得。 ”狮、象两怪，乃心性之魔，认得非心性，乃得真心胜。 归正现相，泯耳皈依，心性之归于一气也。 “只有三魔不伏，扶摇直上，如来用手往上一指，那怪飞不去，只在佛顶上，现了本相，乃是一个大鹏金翅鹊。 ”此一个，即一粒金丹真乙之气，如来已明明指示收伏之法矣。 “对如来叫道：‘你怎么使大法力捆住我？ ’”大法力，乃佛门正法眼。 教外别传，言不能显。 “欲脱难脱，只得皈依。 ”“佛祖不敢松放，只叫在光焰上做护法。 ”所谓“得其一，万事毕。 ”炼神还虚，脱根救度之无上乘也。 然必发大勇猛、大刚断，方能制伏此魔。 大鹏云：“猴头！ 寻这等狠入困我！ ”狠处正是慈处，即是能施真法之人。 不能施真法，则为狮魔、象魔、鹏魔而成群魔； 能施真法，则为狮真、象真、鹏真而合一体。 行者悟到如来施法伏魔，沙僧一棒打开铁柜，救僧上路，仅是狠人狠法，百折不回之真人。 故曰：“真经必得真人取，魔怪千般总是虚。 ” 第七十八回　比丘怜子遣阴神　金殿识魔谈道德 悟一子曰：《道德》五千言，要在“得一毕万”。 “一”者，先天真己之气，生天地人物之理也。 如先天既生果实而为后天，果实中又有仁而为先天，后天之仁，即先天之气所在，人人具足，至近至切。 人能得仁，则生机存而枝叶自茂，长生之事毕矣。 “仁”，象“二、人”，有阴阳合德之妙，非一人孤修所能全。 《易》云：“一阴一阳之谓道。 ”《孟子》云：“仁也者，人也。 合而言之道也。 ”后世学人不识《道德》真诠，《坎》《离》妙用，谬解妄谈，甚以采阴补阳邪说治身惑人，以盲引盲，譬犹救饥服砒，恶寒负冰，必至于伤生害命而后已，是舍至仁而行大不仁。
chunks.translated_text:
Alas! Most mortals fall prey to the demon’s cruel jaws of life’s torment,
yet even the Tang Monk is no exception.
When the Great Sage hears this, how could his heart not be torn like a knife,
his tears not surge like a spring, and his voice not burst in great lamentation?
He says:
*"Strive to practice and refine the demon together,"*
*"Yet when the qi scatters and the heart is wounded, what can be done?"*
This is the great weeping!

Thus, he weeps for all beings now in this moment of distressed reflection,
of diligent cultivation and growth.
He manifests his form and devises a method,
urgently turning back to sweep away the Lion-Demons’ Den
and awaken with fierce resolve,
seeing the Tathāgata recite the *Songgu Caṣṭra*,
to achieve transcendence.

Look—
*"Directly ascending the Spirit Mountain,"*
*"Roaring like thunder!"*
How bold and diligent is his progress!

The Tathāgata points to the old demon’s two monstrous disciples,
declaring that the Great Phoenix is born from the Azure Dapeng,
and shares the same mother—孔雀—as the Peacock,
both being the very *Dharma-mothers* of compassion and mercy.
When the Peacock first emerged,
it swallowed a man in a single breath—
even the Tathāgata was swallowed whole,
meaning *"one mouth can devour ten million heavenly warriors."*
Yet the Tathāgata had already cultivated his *Jianliu Jīnshēn*—*
a golden body of six feet.
Thus, he could enter the demon’s mouth and split its back.

The Tang Monk had not yet attained the golden body,
and risked being swallowed by the demon’s jaws,
unable to transcend.
Therefore, he must subdue this demon
before he can achieve the *Jianliu Jīnshēn*—
a golden body of six feet.

So, all demons that bind me, steam me, swallow me, or lock me in their chests,
do so out of their love, their nurturing, their molding, and their creation—
not only do they harbor great grudges,
but they also bestow great kindness.

孔雀 and 大鹏,
both embodying boundless compassion and mercy,
are truly *Dharma-mothers*—
what more could one doubt?

Later generations, seeing the Peacock enshrined as a *Dharma-mother*,
take offense at the Buddha’s teachings on impartiality toward kin,
yet they fail to grasp Mencius’ words:
*"To cultivate one’s heart and endure with steadfastness,
one must first experience hardship and suffering."*

Nor do they recognize that the Great Phoenix symbolizes the *Zhenyi*—
the primordial *qi* of true essence,
which is indeed the mother of all who become immortals, Buddhas, or sages.

*"Fine pearls sink to the ocean’s depths,
hard gold is refined in raging flames—*
the most genuine truths emerge from great demons,
and those who penetrate to their core
are never won without peril and risk.*

If one seeks the Dao without first facing the Great Phoenix
and subduing it with bold resolve,
they will never become an immortal or a Buddha—
an unalterable truth.

*"The Tathāgata summoned Manjushri and Samantabhadra to the Lion-Demons’ country,
commanding the Pilgrim to battle the monsters,
luring them before the Buddha’s presence.
The monsters, seeing the past, future, and present Triple World-honored images,
as well as the Arhat and *Keshin*,
recognized the protagonist."*

Not recognizing the protagonist as the heart—
why so?
*"The past heart cannot be obtained;
the future heart cannot be obtained;
the present heart cannot be obtained."*
The Lion and Elephant demons,
being demons of heart-nature,
fail to recognize the true heart-nature—
this is the victory of the true heart.

Returning to the authentic form,
the ears vanish and the reliance is extinguished—
the heart-nature merges with the primordial *qi*.

*"Only the three demons refused to submit,
rising straight into the heavens.
The Tathāgata raised his hand and pointed upward—
the monsters could not fly away,
remaining only on the Buddha’s crown,
where they revealed their true forms:
a Great Phoenix with golden wings."*

This one,
the very essence of a single grain of golden elixir—
the *Zhenyi qi*,
which the Tathāgata has plainly shown how to subdue.

*"To the Tathāgata, they cried:
‘How dare you use the Great Dao’s power to bind me!’"*
The Great Dao’s power,
the Buddha’s true and direct teaching,
cannot be openly revealed—
it is transmitted outside the scriptures.

*"To escape difficulty, one must only take refuge."*
*"The Buddha’s ancestors dare not loosen their grip,
only commanding me to serve as a guardian in the radiant flames."*
This is *"obtaining one, all things are complete."*
Refining the spirit and returning to emptiness,
the supreme path of severing roots and salvation.

Yet one must first awaken great courage and firm resolve
to subdue this demon.

The Great Phoenix declares:
*"Monkey! You’ve gone too far in tormenting me!"*
His cruelty is the very seat of compassion—
the one who can apply the true Dao.

Unable to apply the true Dao,
one becomes a demon of the Lion, Elephant, or Phoenix—
a host of demons.
Able to apply the true Dao,
one becomes the Lion’s truth, the Elephant’s truth, the Phoenix’s truth—
a unified whole.

The Pilgrim realizes the Tathāgata’s method of subduing demons,
the *Shāmen* strikes the iron chest with a single rod,
saving the monk and setting them on their way—
this is the resolve of a true practitioner,
unyielding even in a hundred setbacks.

Thus it is said:
*"The true scripture must be taken by the true person,
while demons, though myriad in form, are all but illusions."*

**Chapter 78**
The *Bīqú* [比丘] pities his son and dispatches a shadow spirit,
The *Jīndiàn* [金殿] recognizes the demon and discusses Daoist morality.

The *Wùyīzǐ* [悟一子] says:
The *Dàodé* [道德]’s Five Thousand Words
center on *"obtaining one, all things are complete."*

*"One"* refers to the primordial *Zhenyi qi*—
the essence that generates heaven, earth, and all beings.
As the primordial *qi* gives birth to the fruit of *Hòutiān*—
the post-heavenly realm,
so too does the fruit contain *rén*—
the virtue of primordial harmony.
The post-heavenly *rén*,
the very presence of the primordial *qi*,
is possessed by all—
near and intimate.

If one attains *rén*,
then the life-force remains and branches flourish naturally—
the matter of longevity is already accomplished.

*"Rén"* mirrors *"two"* and *"person"* [人],
embodying the marvel of yin and yang merging in virtue—
not something a single person can fully achieve through solitary cultivation.

The *Yì* [易] says:
*"One yin and one yang constitute the Dao."*
Mencius says:
*"Rén is the very nature of being human.
Together, they form the Dao."*

Later scholars fail to grasp the true meaning of *Dàodé*,
misunderstanding the profound uses of *Kǎn* [坎] and *Lí* [离].
They err and fabricate false theories,
even claiming that *"harnessing yin to supplement yang"* is a cure for bodily ailments,
leading the blind to guide the blind—
like feeding arsenic to the hungry,
or carrying ice to ward off the cold—
inevitably harming life and shortening years.
This is to abandon the utmost *rén* and practice the greatest *bùrén*—
unrighteousness.

chunks.original_text: 大错！ 大错！ 仙师特垂怜悯，借鹅笼赤子为喻。 “鹅”者，讹也，言讹至于此，如将无知之赤子而加以牢笼刀俎之惨也。 揆厥所由，皆因心君昏昧，惑于邪妄所致。 故篇中屡提“昏君，昏君”，以示其义。 夫人人有赤子之心，本广大慈悲，今讹笼锢蔽，临死无知，分明原唤“比丘国”，今改作“小子城”。 师徒见鹅笼而惊疑审视，到金亭驿馆问驿丞，请教鹅笼不明之事，疑其不知养育之法。 丞云：“‘天无二日，人无二理。 ’养育孩儿，怀胎十月而生。 生下乳哺三年，渐成体相，岂有不知之理？ ”明知生育之道出于天理人心之自然，而强制造作，残忍伤生，至于此极者，以为此中有道，吾不知其道于何有？ 故曰“无道之事”。 说出“道人献女，国王宠幸美后，不分昼夜贪欢，弄得身体尪羸，命在须臾； 采药完备，单用着一千一百一十一个小儿的心肝为药引，服后有干年不老之功，谣言叫做小子城”等语，讹哉！ 惨哉！ 较之麻叔谋、赵思绾其人而更甚！
chunks.translated_text:
Ah, the great error! The great error!
The Immortal Master, in His boundless compassion,
used the metaphor of the *"goose-cage"* for the innocent—
*"Goose"* is a mispronunciation—
to show how the ignorant are ensnared in cruel bondage,
as though one were to place a helpless infant upon the slaughter’s block.

Examine its origin:
All stems from the *heart-sovereign’s* [心君] delusion,
bewitched by false and perverse teachings.
Thus, the text repeatedly speaks of *"the dim-witted ruler"* [昏君],
to reveal its meaning.

Every person possesses the *innocent’s heart* [赤子之心],
rooted in boundless compassion and mercy—
yet now, misled and confined,
they perish in ignorance.
What was once plainly called *"Bhikṣu’s Realm"* [比丘国]
has now been twisted into *"City of the Little Ones"* [小子城].

When the disciples see the goose-cage and pause in doubt,
they inquire at the *Golden Pavilion Inn* of the *drystation officer* [驿丞],
asking why such a cage exists—
suspecting he may lack the ways of nurturing life.

The officer replies:
*"Heaven tolerates no second sun, nor does humanity two principles.
To rear a child—
nine months in the womb, then born—
three years of milk and care,
gradually forming body and form—
how could one not know this truth?"*

Yet they *know* the way of birth arises from the natural *Dao* of Heaven and humanity,
yet forcefully contrive and brutalize life to such extremes,
claiming this holds some *Dao*—
I know not what *Dao* they speak of!
Thus it is called *"the affair of no-Dao"* [无道之事].

They speak of:
*"Daoists offering maidens,
kings indulging in favored consorts,
night and day lost in lust,
until their bodies wither and their lives hang by a thread;
gathering herbs complete,
using the hearts and livers of one thousand one hundred and eleven children as medicine,
so that, upon ingestion, one gains the power of eternal youth—
a rumor called *City of the Little Ones*" [小子城].*

How erroneous! How tragic!
Worse even than the deeds of *Ma Shu* [麻叔谋] and *Zhao Si* [赵思绾]!

chunks.original_text: 世岂果有此采心为药之邪妄哉？ 特以借喻邪人外道，无知被害之烈祸己耳！ 然言千百十个心，不过一个心而已。 人心皆同，言多以示其惨也，看一个“一”字自明。 行者道：“只恐他走了旁门，不知正道，徒以采药为真，待老孙将先天之要旨，化他皈正。 ”盖御女采药，丧身灭命之术，后天渣滓之物，安可为真？ 若先天要旨，绝无形质，出于自然。 唯能神明默运，潜施阴德，摄脱讹笼，使被陷之赤子转杀为生，无复以采取为事，当下即是救生药师佛，而得先天度世之要旨矣。 三人齐念药师佛，大圣施为发令，众种各使神通，阴风惨雾，摄去鹅笼，而昏君之迷惑有开悟之机。 故三藏一见，国王即喜道：“远来之僧，必有道行。 ”此金殿之论禅谈道，自不能已已。 三藏论禅，皆主心言而辨其采取之非。 曰：“坚诚知觉，须当识心。 心净则孤明独照，心存则万境皆清。 ”又曰：“一心不动，万行自全。 若云采阴补阳，诚为谬语； 服饵长寿，实乃虚词。 ”缘国王安用其心，而入于邪道，因病以下药也。 至国丈道：“寂灭门中，须云识性。 你不知性从何灭，枯坐参禅，尽是盲修瞎炼。 ”又曰：“夺天地之秀气，采日月之华精。 运阴阳而丹结，按水火而胎凝。 ”又曰：“应四时采取药物，养九转修炼丹成。 ”又曰； “你那静禅释教，寂灭阴神。 涅盘遗臭壳，又不脱凡尘。 ”句句都是《道德》真言，与木仙庵拂云叟所谈无异。 但彼以空言而成荆棘，此行谬行而成邪妄。 行者明眼识破，知其口是心非，叫道：“师父，这国丈是个妖邪。 ” 国丈道：“才见入朝来，见一个绝妙的药引，强似那一千一百一十一个小儿之心。 ”盖先因昧心而误认采取，自灭其良心，继因失心而转以人心为道心，皆邪妄也。 昏君不察，求僧取心，是犹御女而欲取其身中之物以为药也，其可得乎？ 不知采取先天真一之气，有大小颠倒，改换头面，变化腾挪，鬼神莫测之妙用，而不专属于心。 故行者道：“若要好，大做小。 ”“八戒撒泡尿，一团臊； 行者泥作片，像猴脸； 吹口仙气，长老变； 摇身变作僧脸。
chunks.translated_text:
「Is the world truly filled with such perverse practices as taking hearts as medicine? It is merely a metaphor to warn of the wickedness of those who stray from the true *Dao* and the dire consequences they bring upon themselves through ignorance!

Yet when they speak of a thousand one hundred and ten hearts,
they mean but one heart in truth.
All human hearts are the same—
the repetition only serves to emphasize their cruelty.
See the meaning in the single word *"one"* [一].

The *Daoist* practitioner says:
*"I fear they have wandered into false paths,
unaware of the true *Dao*,
merely taking external alchemy as genuine,
until I reveal the essence of *Xiantian* [先天],
and turn them back to the right path."*

For such practices as consorting with women and gathering herbs,
which destroy the body and extinguish life,
are but post-heaven dross [后天渣滓].
How could they be true?

If the essence of *Xiantian* [先天],
it is formless and void,
arising naturally.
Only through silent illumination [神明默运],
hidden cultivation of *yin virtue* [阴德],
and escaping the snare of delusion [摄脱讹笼],
can one rescue the ensnared and transform destruction into life—
no longer taking as medicine,
this very moment is the *Saviour of Living Beings Buddha* [救生药师佛],
and one attains the *Xiantian* method of transcending the world [先天度世之要旨].

The Three Treasures [三藏] chanted the *Dharma* of the *Yushifu* [药师佛],
the Great Sage [大圣] acted and issued his decree,
each creature employed their spiritual powers [神通],
as the cold winds and mournful mists [阴风惨雾]
carried away the *Ego-Cage* [鹅笼],
and the bewildered king began to awaken.

Thus, upon seeing the Three Treasures [三藏],
the king rejoiced and said:
*"These distant monks must surely possess the *Dao* and its practice [道行]."*
This was the golden hall’s discourse on *Chan* and the *Dao*—
it could not be suppressed.

The Three Treasures spoke of *Chan*,
all emphasizing the mind’s true nature and refuting the taking of external things.
They said:
*"Firm sincerity and awareness,
must first recognize the mind.
A pure mind shines alone,
a mind with attachments sees all phenomena clearly."*

They also said:
*"If the mind remains undisturbed,
all actions will be complete.
To speak of taking *yin* to supplement *yang* [采阴补阳],
is sheer falsehood;
to claim that ingesting elixirs grants longevity [服饵长寿],
is mere empty talk."*

Since the king had already misused his mind,
and fallen into false *Dao*,
the illness was the medicine of his own making.

The king’s attendant said:
*"Within the *Jie mie* [寂灭] school of *Dao*,
one must speak of recognizing *xing* [性].
You do not know from where *xing* is extinguished—
sitting in vain and blindly practicing *Chan*,
it is all futile striving and delusion."*

He also said:
*"You plunder the *f秀气* [f秀气] of Heaven and Earth,
and gather the *hua精* [华精] of the sun and moon.
You manipulate *yin* and *yang* to form the elixir,
and press *water* and *fire* to solidify the embryo.
You follow the seasons in collecting medicines,
and nurture the nine transformations to refine the elixir into completion."*

He further said:
*"Your quiet *Chan* teachings and *Shijie* [释教] doctrines,
which extinguish the *yin spirit* [阴神],
leave behind only the foul shell of the *Nirvana* [涅盘],
and do not escape the dust of the mundane.
Each word is a true saying from the *Daode Jing* [《道德》],
yet differs not from what the *Muxian An* [木仙庵] and *Fuyun Sou* [拂云叟] spoke of.
But he spoke of it in vain,
while you act falsely—
both are perverse delusions."*

The *Daoist* practitioner saw through their hypocrisy,
knowing their words were false,
and cried out:
*"Master, this attendant is a demonic heretic!"*

The attendant said:
*"Just now, upon entering the court,
I saw a marvelous elixir—
far superior to the hearts of a thousand one hundred and eleven children!"*

He had first lost his true heart through ignorance,
then extinguished his own innate virtue [良心],
and finally, through madness,
mistook human hearts for the true heart of the *Dao*—
all perverse delusions.

The king, blind to truth,
ordered the monks to take his heart as medicine—
as if he could extract its essence like one taking a woman’s body as medicine!
Could such a thing be attained?

He did not know that the *Dao* of *Xiantian* [先天]
has the wondrous, unfathomable transformations—
great and small inversions, head and face reversals,
shifting and changing beyond measure—
which are not confined solely to the heart.

Thus the *Daoist* practitioner said:
*"If you wish to succeed,
greatly do the small."*
*"Eight Precepts urinates a puddle—
a foul clump;
The *Daoist* practitioner molds mud into a piece—
like a monkey’s face;
A breath of *Xianqi* [仙气] is blown—
the Elder changes;
Shaking his body, he transforms into a monk’s face."*

They speak of:
*"Daoists offering maidens,
kings indulging in favored consorts,
night and day lost in lust,
until their bodies wither and their lives hang by a thread;
gathering herbs complete,

chunks.original_text: ”忽倏之间，内外互济，转移造化，妙道天机，默不能隐，语不能显，徒谈《道德》而昧心错认、妄希取用者，乌足以知之？ 惜哉！ 比丘上不能乞真法，下不能乞真食，空有释家乞土之号，不与尼山丹丘同实，竟误用而成小子，悲夫！ 第七十九回　寻洞擒妖逢老寿　当朝正主救婴儿 悟一子曰：羁縻小子无知之心而求道，则锢蔽其心而无道； 强执成人有知之心而求道，则空费其心而无道。 盖小子无知，心虽多，只一个； 成人有知，心虽一个，实多般，总见其昏也。 心君一昏，或惑于采取而无知，或惑于人心而有知，去道益远。 此大圣所以现身说法，开心见诚，尽剖其心中之所有，“咕噜噜滚出一堆”，“一个个捡与大众观看”，以示此心之中色样多般，俱是假像，并无可为药引之处。 如止盗者锢钥而守御之，不如发箧而示之以无也。 故曰：“都是红心、白心、黄心、悭贪心、利名心、嫉妒心、计较心、好胜心、望高心、侮慢心、杀害心、狠毒心、恐怖心、谨慎心、邪妄心、无名隐睛之心，种种不善之心，更无一个黑心。 ”若云此即黑心，此等心之外更无黑心也！ 夫仁、义、礼、智根于心，道心也。 此心本诸天性、良知良能，无用再求，特放以上诸人心，则道心自见。 然则孟子所谓“收放心”者，非收也，放亦是收。 如比丘王所言：“收了去！ 收了去！ ”不知收此等心在内何用，故圣人知无心之为要，而息虑忘机，廓然无我。 若取人心以为道，而钩索远致，虽呕尽心血，作用千般，吾知其所希得者，只是一个黑心而已。 “国丈指定道； ‘要你的黑心。
chunks.translated_text:
The fleeting instant—
when inner and outer mutually aid,
shifting and transforming creation—
the wondrous Dao of Heaven’s mechanism,
silent yet cannot be concealed,
spoken yet cannot be revealed—
merely prattling of the *Dàodé Jīng* [《道德经》] while lost in delusion,
mistakenly hoping to extract or employ it—
how could they ever grasp it? Alas!

The *Bīqiú* [比丘] cannot beg for the true *dharma* [法] above,
nor for true sustenance below—
mere hollow title of the *Shìjiā* [释家] to beg for scraps,
not sharing the substance of *Níshān* [尼山]’s elixir fields—
yet they err in application and become petty disciples.
Pitiful!

The *Dàshèng* [大圣] thus manifested in person to teach,
unveiling the true nature of the heart,
laying bare all its contents—
*"Gulu gulu, tumbling out a heap,"*
*"one by one, picking them up for all to see,"*
to show that within this heart are myriad colored forms,
all illusory, none suitable as a medicinal guide.

Like the *zhǐdào* [止盗者] who locks the key and guards it—
better to open the chest and reveal its emptiness.

Thus it is said:
*"All red-hearted, white-hearted, yellow-hearted,
stingy, greedy, fame-seeking, jealous, calculating,
boastful, arrogant, murderous, cruel,
fearful, cautious, deluded—
and myriad other unwholesome hearts,
there is not one black heart among them."*

If you claim this *is* the black heart,
then outside these hearts, there is no black heart at all!

For *rén* [仁], *yì* [义], *lǐ* [礼], and *zhì* [智] arise from the heart—
the Dao-heart.
This heart is the innate nature of all heavens,
the pure knowing of pure ability—
no need to seek further,
only release from the myriad human hearts,
and the Dao-heart reveals itself.

Yet then, what *Mèngzǐ* [孟子] called *"shōufàng xīn"* [收放心],
was not to collect—
to release *is* to collect.

As *Bīqiú Wáng* [比丘王] spoke:
*"Collect it away! Collect it away!"*
Not knowing what use such collection holds within,
thus the Sage knows the essentiality of *wúxīn* [无心],
to cease thought and forget artifice—
unbounded, selfless.

If you take human hearts as the Dao,
and dig for distant traces,
though you expend every drop of vitality,
employ every means—
I know what you truly seek
is merely the black heart.

*"The Prime Minister demands the Dao;
‘I want your black heart.'"*

chunks.original_text: ’假僧道：‘我和尚都是好心，这国丈是个黑心，好做药引。 ’”非真谓其心可为药引，言如心可为药，人人同心，人所自有，何必采阴以为药？ 又何必执心以为采？ 又何必舍自己之心而采取他人？ 非其本心黑洞洞而昏惑之甚者哉？ 心也者，火脏也，卦气属《离》，外阳而内阴，外明而内暗。 若谓即心即道，纵操至入定出神，终是后天阴神，非先天阳神，未成正果，仍堕轮回。 何况认假为真，以阴采阴，而妄行邪说以为道乎？ “国丈认得大圣，迎敌不住。 将身化作一道寒光，进宫带去妖后，并化寒光而去。 ”见乘风御女而行阴邪之道，自此而真假可辨，昏君之主公亦可寻觅而相见。 三藏道； “我这个臊脸，怎么见得人？ ”只此一语，已骂尽世间邪妄之徒千般害人的丑态。 《参同契》曰：“阴道厌九一，浊乱弄胞元。 诸术甚众多，千条有万余。 ”彭真人曰：“世人不达大道之宗元，而趋旁门曲径，此属多般，皆为左道乖讹，天理愦乱，生真本期永寿，反尔伤生。 ”“大圣与八戒找寻妖处，但见千万株的杨柳，更不知清华庄在于何处。 正是：万顷野田观不尽，千堤杨柳隐无踪。 ”即“千条万余”、“此属多般”之义也。 土地说出“一颗九叉杨柳下，左转三转，右转三转，连叫三声‘开门’，即现清华洞府”，即“九一”、“浊乱”、“曲径”、“左道”之义也。 大圣依言叫门，“霎时间，一声响亮，呼啦啦的两扇门开，不见树的踪迹”，即“趋旁门曲径”，“乖讹”、“愦乱”之义也。 “见石屏上有‘清华仙府’四字”。 “府”即腑，清似烟，华本花，盖烟花自迷而不知为“浊乱胞元”也。 “见老妖怀中搂着个美女，齐道‘好机会’，行者掣棒叫道； ‘毛团！ 什么好机会！
chunks.translated_text:
「The Daoist monk protests, *“I am a monk of pure heart—
this Prime Minister is the black-hearted one,
the perfect alchemical ingredient.”*»
Yet it is not that his heart can truly serve as an ingredient,
for if one takes the heart as medicine,
all people share the same heart—
what need to extract *yin* as the drug?
And why grasp the heart as the thing to extract?
Why abandon one’s own heart
and seek another’s?

It is not his true heart that is black and murky,
lost in profound confusion.

The heart, you see,
is the *fire* organ—
its *coagulation* belongs to the *Li* hexagram,
external *yang* yet internal *yin*,
external brightness yet internal darkness.

If one claims the heart itself is the Dao,
even if he practices to the point of *meditative absorption* or *transcendence*,
it remains but a *post-heaven yin* spirit—
not the *pre-heaven yang* spirit.
The fruit is not yet ripe,
and he still falls into the *wheel of rebirth*.

How much worse to mistake falsehood for truth,
to extract *yin* from *yin*,
and to peddle perverse teachings as the Dao?

*"The Great Sage meets the Prime Minister;
the enemy cannot be withstood.
He transforms his body into a streak of cold light,
invades the palace to seize the demoness,
then vanishes as cold light."*

Seeing her ride the wind like a phantom,
pursuing the *yin* path of deceit,
from this moment truth and falsehood can be discerned,
and the deluded ruler’s true nature revealed.

The Tripitaka Master says,
*“How can this shameful face be seen by others?”*
With just this one phrase,
he curses the myriad wicked deeds of all false pretenders in the world.

*The Canon of Supreme Unity* states:
*“The Dao of *yin* abhors the nine-one,
and the turbid chaos disturbs the *bāoyuán* [embryonic essence].
The myriad arts are countless—
ten thousand paths, ten times ten thousand.”*

Peng Zhenren says:
*“Men do not grasp the Dao’s fundamental principle,
but chase after side paths and crooked ways—
these are the myriad arts,
all belonging to *leftist* perversions,
chaos of Heaven’s order.
Those who seek longevity in the True
instead harm their own life.”*

*"The Great Sage and the Eight Rules seek the demon’s lair,
but only see countless willows—
the location of Qinghua [Pure Splendor] Manor remains unknown.
Just as it is said:
‘A thousand leagues of wild fields cannot be fully surveyed,
countless rows of willows vanish without trace.’*

This is the meaning of *“ten thousand paths, ten times ten thousand,”*
*“these belong to the myriad arts.”*

The earth spirit instructs:
*“Under a nine-pronged willow,
turn left three times,
turn right three times,
and call three times, ‘Open the door!’—
then the Qinghua Cave will appear.”*
This is the meaning of *“nine-one,”*
*“turbid chaos,”*
*“crooked paths,”*
*“leftist perversions.”*

The Great Sage follows the words and calls out,
*“In an instant, a resounding crack—
the two doors swing open,
no trace of the trees remains.”*
This is the meaning of *“chasing after side paths,”*
*“perversions,”*
*“chaos of Heaven’s order.”*

*"He sees on the stone screen the words:
‘Qinghua [Pure Splendor] Immortal Manor.’*
The *府* (Manor) is the *fǔ* [viscera],
*qing* like smoke,
*huá* like flowers—
for smoke and flowers blind one,
unaware that it is *“turbid chaos, embryonic essence.”***

*"He sees the old demon clutching a beauty in his arms,
and exclaims, ‘What a fine opportunity!’
The Sage leaps forward, brandishing his staff:
‘Hairy beast! What fine opportunity?’"*

chunks.translated_text:
The Great Sage shouts to incite the demon to battle,
while the Eight Rules [Guài] knocks down the willow tree,
causing fresh blood to spurt forth.
This is the *正見御女邪術* (right-seeing to subdue women, perverse Dao/Way), a beastly act of slaughterous intent,
which cannot bring eternal life—
instead, it is *“反傷生”* (backwardly harming life).

Only by penetrating to its root cause,
and eliminating this demonic evil,
can one attain true longevity.
Thus, at the very moment of the battle cry,
the **Southern Pole Old Man Star** (Southern Celestial Longevity Star) unexpectedly arrives.
The Longevity Star smiles and says,
*“Spare this creature’s life, O Two Gentlemen—
it is my match in vitality.”*
This refers to the vitality that grants eternal life—
how could one rashly act to end such a life?

The White Deer reveals its true form,
and pounces to slay the White Fox Demoness.
*“Together, we return to the Bhikṣu [monk], manifesting our forms and transforming into mortals,”*
signifying the Sage’s intent:
to split open the belly, gouge out the heart,
and deliver a sermon in person.
The Great Sage then addresses the king with a smile:
*“This is your Prime Minister,
and this is your Queen.”*
His words strike home with piercing clarity—
how could one not be moved to sweat and shiver in dread!

The king, ashamed and grateful,
with the heart of an ignorant child,
suddenly awakens to remorse and confession,
thus declaring:
*“You have saved a king’s son—
this is true Heaven’s mercy!”*

The Longevity Star explains:
*“I was playing chess with the Eastern Peak Emperor—
the game was not yet finished
when I went to find him.”*

The Longevity Star says:
*“If you return late,
this beast will be no more.”*
And again:
*“I wish to teach you the way of cultivation,
but you are already weak in sinew and spirit,
unable to refine the elixir.
Only these three dates remain—
they were gifts to the Eastern Peak Emperor for tea,
now I give them to you.”*
This passage, which readers might see as mere concluding words,
is in fact the immortal’s urgent admonition at parting,
urging one to hasten cultivation.

Life’s time is fleeting,
worldly affairs like a chess game—
one must cultivate with haste,
never delay.
Do not wait until your sinews weaken and your spirit fails,
for then you cannot refine the elixir.

The “three dates” symbolize:
one, restraining early desires;
two, seeking guidance from a teacher early;
three, beginning practice early.
The Master of Upper Yang declared:
*“Common mortals from seventy to a hundred and twenty years old
can all refine the elixir,”*
encouraging those who are frail in old age.
But here it says:
*“Weak in sinew and spirit,
unable to refine the elixir,”*
warning those who do not exert themselves in youth.
This is also the meaning of Confucius’ words:
*“At forty or fifty, one is still not to be feared,”*
not truly implying that a weak body cannot attain the elixir.

The king pleads for instruction,
and the Sage replies:
*“From now on, curb your lust for desire,
accumulate your hidden merit—
all worldly matters will then lengthen your deficiencies,
sufficient to dispel illness and prolong life.”*
Though the elixir’s method may not be spoken of,
the teaching of lengthening deficiencies is never abandoned.

*“As they leave the city,
suddenly they hear a gust of wind from midair,
and on both sides descend a thousand, one hundred, and ten-one egg baskets—
each household comes forward,
recognizing their children inside,
joyous and delighted,
leaping and laughing,
without distinction of age or gender,
male or female alike,
crowding the master and disciple back into the city.”*

Seeing the compassionate heart of the Sage,
all beings are united as one—
no distinction between great and small.
Once lost in delusion for long,
now awakened in a single day,
they return as if descending from the sky—
each reclaims their child,
no longer ensnared by harm.
What joy like this!

This is the verse:
*“Hidden merit saves a thousand lives,
the child’s city remains—
the Bhikṣu [monk] still prevails.”*

Yet, if the heart holds no medicine,
and one practices the Way of the World,
where should they seek the roots and sprouts?
Thus, the immortal teacher urgently reveals the next section’s teachings.

**The 80th Episode:**
*The Fair Maiden Nurtures Yang to Seek a Mate,*
*The Monkey-King Guards His Master and Discerns Demons.*

The Sage of Awakening says:
*“This chapter, up to the 82nd,
clearly states that cultivators must step by step guard their original nature,
returning to their innate purity.
Even a single misstep
will plunge them into bottomless emptiness,
making liberation difficult.*

At the chapter’s beginning,
the Sage cites an ancient saying:
*“If you seek temporal wealth and honor,
you must exert the effort of transcending death.”*
The Sand Monk says:
*“If you persist in the effort,
there will surely come a day of attainment.”*
Meaning: one must never slacken for a moment.

In the previous chapter,
desire was led astray by external allurements,
but if one can fiercely reflect and return,
it is still easier to restrain.
Now, it is made clear:
desire arises from the heavens,
thoughts spring from within—
these are the hardest to suppress.

The term *“fair maiden”* (姹女)
refers to the utmost essence of the *Kān* [Water] trigram;
*“nurturing yang”* (育阳)
is the yang cultivated within the *Kān* trigram.
*Kān* represents male,
so why is it called female?
Because its outer form is yin-like.
Post-heaven yang is nurtured within the center.”

remain ever still and unmoved;

its utmost subtlety lies at the juncture of *Kūn* [Earth] and *Fù* [Return],

The black pines’ shade, the black resting **qi**—
this is the **Dao**-manifestation of motion reaching its peak and seeking stillness.

At the moment of stillness, when one sits with closed eyes,

In the text, *"suddenly see"* and *"suddenly hear"*—

*"Only then did I see a beautiful woman bound to a great tree,

her lower half buried in the earth below."*

This woman is the **yang** essence of the *Kan* hexagram,

*Hai* belongs to **Wood**, hence her upper half is bound to the tree.
*Hai* passes to *Zi*, the hour of **Mouse** essence—
*Zi* belongs to **Metal**, hence she is the **Mouse** essence.
*Zi* ends and gives way to *Chou*, which belongs to **Earth**,

countering and restraining it—

The immortal master then pointed directly and said, *"Ah! This fellow is clearly a demon—how strange! The venerable elder, with his ordinary mortal eyes, does not recognize it."*

Upon seeing it, one could not help but feel stirred, *"unable to restrain oneself."* The moment a thought of suppression arises, another thought of desire sprouts—pitying and cherishing, lingering along the path. Alas! Alas! *"The practitioner from the side coldly laughs,"* piercing through the demonic deceit, admonishing and restraining, relying entirely on this steadfast and tranquil mind.

*"Suddenly, they arrived at the Zenhai Temple, and once again heard a bell toll."* From the stirring of desire, another thought emerges—like a bronze bell struck, one awakens abruptly, realizing the boundless ocean of craving. Then, suddenly, the unyielding strength of true gold arises, severing and subduing it with resolve.

But why does the bell, though struck on earth, have its upper half like snow and its lower half like indigo? It is said: *"Bronze does not change its sound from external assaults; a man must not lose his resolve from the ungovernable desires of the world."* The Tripitaka Master stroked the bell and sighed, while the Dao cultivator picked up a stone and struck it—both employing the same principle.

Upon entering the temple, they saw *"the front in disarray, the rear in perfect order."* The *"Zen"* here refers to true gold. This steadfast mind, like true gold unchanging, though the front may be in disarray, the rear remains in perfect order—what is there to fear?

Yet this *"nurturing"* is but the cultivation of **yang qi**; this *"seeking"* is but the search for a partner; this *"protecting"* is but the safeguarding of the self. All lead to the profound and wondrous words of the next section.

Yet once **Yang** is ensnared in **Kan**, it is as if one has fallen into the **Bottomless Pit**—how then can one emerge?

For centuries, those who profane this **sacred text** have failed to grasp what the **Bottomless Pit** truly is—**sin**! **Sin**!

The **Kan** hexagram is void above and void below—clearly, a mountain hollowed with no bottom.

*"Male and female copulate, all things transform and generate."* The **Daoist** path is complete.

The **bewildered**, reading this, mistakenly assume it refers to **sexual alchemy**—the farther they stray, the harder it is to find salvation.

When the **practitioner** leaps in, he plunges into *"a fine place indeed—this is a **Tian** realm of bliss!"*

Yet within, one must grasp it firmly—never *"lose true Yang, fall into the wheel of rebirth, and never rise again."* Swiftly seek an exit; do not forget, for it plainly teaches that **birth** comes from **life**, urging **respect** and **truth-preservation**, and to urgently find the **transcendent** union—never abandoning the original path.

This reminds all to seek the **ultimate cause** of escape from the very path they entered.

The **practitioner** says: *"Do not speak of forgetting the way—this cave is strange, not meant for easy entry or exit. You came by diving headfirst and descending; now to save you, you must dive from below and ascend."*

chunks.original_text: 上篇是陷于洞之根苗，此篇是出于洞之因果。 第八十三回　心猿识得丹头　姹女还归本性 悟一子曰：出世之道，在于制伏金精。 倘知制伏之法，而工夫不到，未得其真，则不能返本还元。 理欲交战，仍与性体为二，势必飞飏奔越，纵肆猖狂，使我站脚不定，所谓“工夫不到不方圆”也。 三藏之既出而复陷，由知之未尽，而得之未真。 故求丹之要，须精心根究，识得丹头。 仙师恐世人认假为真，又发此段，令人察识精妙。 若看做水穷云起，绝处逢生，不过为文家之波澜，便埋没作者婆心矣。 经云：“金来归性初，乃得称还丹。 ”当行者化桃入腹，强其负僧而出，原非心悦诚服，自然超脱者。 故出来而重整旗鼓，争战乱打，置唐僧于独坐无援之地，非和合攒簇之理．由金不归性，而水火土木相持，是金为假象，而先错于左者，今又错于右，故右脚上花鞋，又脱变而莫定也。 子精为《坎》中之物，出之于地，又名地涌夫人。 不闻地涌金莲乎？ 金莲为夫人之纤趾，饰以花鞋。 鞋附《坤》土而行，为归性； 脱下凭空而起，是飞飏奔越，金不归性矣。 左属阳，右属阴，前以偏阳左旋，而左非真； 此以偏阴右旋，而右非真。 “鞋”者，谐也。 左右分飞，何谐之有？ 故不能脚踏实地，站立不定。

The preceding chapter laid the roots of those who fall into the cave;

**Chapter 83: The Mind-Monkey Recognizes the Elixir’s Core**
**The Vermilion Maiden Returns to Her True Nature**

The Master of Awakening said:
The **Dao of transcending the world** lies in subduing the **golden essence**.
If one knows the method of subjugation yet lacks cultivation,
and fails to grasp its truth,
then one cannot return to the origin and restore the fundamental.

When **principle and desire** wage war,
they remain separate from **True Nature**,
inevitably **soaring and unrestrained**—
wild and rampant—
leaving one ungrounded.
This is what is meant by:
*"Cultivation insufficient, no square nor round."*

The **Tang Monk’s** repeated fall after escape
arises from incomplete understanding
and untrue attainment.

Thus, the essence of seeking the **elixir**
demands meticulous inquiry into the roots,
to recognize the **core of the elixir**.

The **Celestial Master** feared the world would mistake falsehood for truth,
so he revealed this passage
to discern its subtle profundity.
If one views it merely as *"water’s end and clouds’ ascent,"*
a sudden turn after exhaustion—
merely a literary flourish—
then the author’s **benevolent intent** is buried.

The **Sutra** states:
*"Gold returns to its original nature—
only then may it be called the **Returning Elixir**."*

When the practitioner forces the **peach** into his belly,
compelling the **monkey** to carry the monk out,
it is not from **voluntary harmony** or **natural liberation**.
Thus, upon emerging, he **reassembles his forces**,
engages in chaotic battle,
leaving the **Tang Monk** alone and unsupported—
this violates the **principle of harmonious integration**.

while **departing from True Nature** becomes the **Démonic Essence (妖精)**.
**Returning to True Nature** makes me **whole in truth**,
while **departing from True Nature** turns me into a **démon’s essence**,
and I fall into its snare.

*"The Tang Monk was seized and held in one embrace,
his reins severed—both man and horse were dragged away."*
All because he could not subdue the **True Gold (真金)**,
his roots were not firm, and his reins were broken.

The **Tang Monk’s steed’s** strength in its hooves
was never greater than the **Démonic Essence’s flowered shoes**,
so it must be tamed and made its foundation.

The **Great Sage** saw the half-severed reins,
and felt helpless sorrow welling up—
tears streamed from his eyes.
He turned swiftly, with fierce resolve,
seeking the origin’s root,
only then could he find true remedy.

Seeing the **Golden Character Tablet (金字牌)**,
he recognized his father’s and elder brother’s names,
and thus knew the **Dan (丹, cinnabar)**—
was he not filled with joy?

If his father **returned to True Nature**,
where could his son go?
He **clutched the Tablet** and ascended to the **Heavenly Palace (天堂)**,
to **report to the Jade Emperor (玉帝)**,
and thus his kin could be saved.

This is the **strategy of capturing the thief by seizing the king’s hand**,
the **key to tracing origins and uncovering roots**.

When the **Jade Emperor** commanded **Tai Bai (太白, the Great White Star)** to summon **Li Tianwang (李天王, the Heavenly King of the Li clan)** to the **court of judgment (对簿)**,
the Heavenly King failed to recognize her as a **female**,
and **Ne Zha (哪吒)** revealed her lineage—
*"The thief from the Sacred Mountain stole the Buddha’s fragrant flowers and lamps."*
Only then did he realize she was his **sworn sister (结拜)** by fate.

Yet how could she be a **sworn sister**,
if she was born of his clan?
The Heavenly King bears the **Li (李) surname**,
which belongs to **wood (木)**.
By the **wood’s children (木之子)**, **fire (火)** is meant,
so how could his daughter be of **gold (金)**,
with a **golden nose and white fur (金鼻白毛)**?

A **golden form throughout her body**?
He did not know that **gold in water (水中之金)** can subdue wood,
yet **gold** also **engenders water (生水)** to nourish wood;
that **fire in wood (木中之火)** can restrain gold,
yet **fire** also **engenders earth (生土)** to give rise to gold.

A disciple of enlightenment says:
This passage speaks only of **all dharmas being empty**,
with no attachment—
thus the great meaning is fulfilled.

Humanity’s nature is **originally round and awakened**,
with no division between self and others.
When **self and dharma** arise, division appears.
If **self has no dharma**, others extinguish my nothingness;
if **others possess dharma**, I extinguish their dharma with my own.
Only when **self and others both lack dharma**,
and the **heavenly body** is perfectly round,
does **Great Awakening** emerge.

In the **Dao**,
**insight** is the **gateway to marvel**,
**stillness** the **true essence**,
**wise thought** the **armor and shield**,
**discriminating wisdom** the **sword and spear**.
Breaking the **inner demon’s high ramparts**,
crushing the **outer foe’s fortified ranks**,
pacifying the chaotic and explaining the ensnared.

Deeply knowing that **form and substance** cannot long endure,
yet the **true spirit** persists through countless eons.
Understanding **transformation’s impermanence**,
the **abiding** lies only within myself.

Not originally **dharma**, it cannot be spoken of as dharma;
not originally **teaching**, it cannot be transmitted as teaching.
As it is said:
*"Round and red, not a thread nor a hair."*

Yet within it lies a **foundation of firm footing**—
if one drifts like a rudderless boat,
lost in empty vagueness,
the Buddha calls it **"vague and empty"**—
still, it is the plight of falling into the **bottomless abyss of emptiness**.

Confucius said:
*"One may stand with him, but not yet be entrusted with authority."*
Only when one can **stand firm** may one speak of **authority**.

but rather, to weigh the **light and heavy** along the **true path**,
to bend one’s heart without abruptness—
thus must one **seek the Dao** until the journey’s end.

Since the **Han dynasty** onward, none have truly understood its meaning,
and so they abandon the **middle path** to take **devious side paths**—
how could they align with **reason**?

Those who cannot uphold the **Way** invariably enter **erroneous paths**,
and cloak their **skillful means** in pretense to justify their **deviance**;
while those who practice **skillful means** in truth
must follow the **right path**, transforming the **Way** to serve the **orthodox**.

This is the **true skillful gate** of the **middle path**—
the **skillful means** of **sages, immortals, and Buddhas**.

Past readers of *Journey to the West* have seen the **Great Sage’s** appearance
as mere literary exhaustion, unable to grasp these **cool, idle words**—
all profound in meaning.

**Dao** is that which **does nothing yet nothing remains undone**.
Its **substance** is **emptiness and non-being**,
its **function** is **following and adapting**.
Without fixed form, without enduring shape,
it thus explores the **emotions of all things**;
neither preceding nor following things,
it thus becomes the **master of all things**.

With **dharma** or without **dharma**, it acts according to the **time**;
with **precepts** or without **precepts**, it harmonizes with **sentient beings**.
Thus it is said:
*"The sage is imperishable, for he guards with the times."*
And again:
*"Change and move without abiding, shifting with the flow of the age."*
This is the **true intent** of the **Great Sage’s** westward journey to guide the world.

The instruction having been made clear,
he turned straight back to the **Southern Seas**.

The **Pilgrim** then concealed his name to avoid danger,
transforming into a **moth-lantern** to advance by the **light**,

when the **Way** was clear, he changed his attire,
imitating the **disguise of a humble servant** in the **Song dynasty**—
truly blending with the mundane, not clinging to his own form.

Ah! Without worldly law, there is no Buddhist law—realizing that no-mind is the Dao-mind. The most subtle part is the *"Entering the Counter to Stir Ghosts"* passage.

Laozi says: *"A skilled merchant hides his goods as if empty."* If one has no worldly possessions, why not feign emptiness while revealing substance? Boldly brandishing the law like a torch, one knows the peril of being caught in darkness by light; robbing the horse merchant reveals the danger of arrogance inviting theft.

The law’s net is dense—everywhere, one must beware. All are the Wayfarer’s embodied teachings.

At this stage, the Great Sage displays boundless, transcendent transformations—left arm, right arm, left as right, nothing unsuited. Manipulated on the palm, left and right flow effortlessly. Thus, a single shake of the Golden Hoop scatters across the six directions; gathering into truth, it retreats into the hidden.

*"Form and spirit both perfect, harmonizing with the Dao’s truth—thus able to multiply the body into countless transformations, pluck a hair to forge countless weapons."* From the highest palaces and ministries to the lowest officials and commoners, noble or lowly, great or small—spontaneous divine power shifts forms and moves emotions.

This is the Wayfarer’s body transforming into a blade, shaving every hair clean, making self and others one, all rounded into perfection, unrestricted movement, natural as heaven—is this not like one suddenly awakening from a dream?

Ah! Destroying law through law, revering law to attain law—law has no fixed form. Such is its nature.

The Eighty-Fifth Chapter: The Heart-Monkey Envious of the Wood Mother, the Demon King’s Scheme to Devour Zen

The Sage said: This chapter—readers may say that the earlier demons were beyond comparison, but this one is merely ordinary, as if hastily written. Yet what seems unremarkable is truly wondrous: what can be thought of is not what should be thought at all.

The previous section exposed the emptiness of human nature and worldly affairs, revealing all dharmas as void. One must blend with the world, adapting to circumstances—whether square or round—though outwardly responding to events, yet rooted in the boundless luminosity of the heart’s essence. Fearful that others might not perceive this from the heart, the Immortal Master forcefully turns outward to inward, emphasizing the profound intent of *"The Heart Sutra is not to be sought far away,"* urging one to recognize this heart and never harbor the slightest obstruction, lest one fall into demonic snares.

For the Holy Heart is like a mirror-still pool—ever luminous, ever tranquil, ever responsive yet ever still. All uses arise from its singular essence, and its essence never strays from all uses. Thus it is said: *"The body of wisdom is silent and still, its function radiant and suchness."*

Yet if even a speck of obstruction arises, the heart’s essence grows murky and clogged, and its outer functions become deceitful—like mist veiling the soul’s faculties, where Zen is swallowed whole, as though dense fog concealed within the transparent layers of the *Lianhuan Cave*, shattering the sky-piercing pillars!

Thus the next section is titled: *"Hidden Mist Mountain, the Broken Peak, the Linked-Ring Cave."* The Five Peaks are the celestial pillars; the One Heart is the master of the body. When the peaks collapse, the sky lacks support; when the heart is obscured, the body loses its root. Actions unrooted in the heart become nothing but afflictions—what Zen remains?

Zen seeks to dissolve demons; the staff is wielded to subdue them. Yet how does the demon wield the staff and devour Zen? Zen stills but one mind, while the demon traverses the Six Realms. To bind Zen and extinguish dharma is for the demon to govern demons—how can it avoid becoming a gluttonous maw, greedily consuming living Zen?

Why? Because following desire is not Zen-mind. It splits into precepts, concentration, and wisdom—expanding into the Six Perfections, dispersing into myriad practices. Zen is but one of the Six Perfections—how can it encompass all dharmas? Few escape becoming demonic.

Moreover, Zen-mind is hard to purify, and the golden and wooden essences remain unmelted. How could one then reject all existence and eliminate all dharmas without falling into calculation? If all dharmas are void, it is not that there are no dharmas. The heart gives rise to all dharmas yet does not belong to them. Those who attain it find dharma at their command, verified from the heart, arising as desired—neither identical nor different, neither different nor identical; neither dharma nor non-dharma, neither non-dharma nor non-non-dharma. How could one seek it by clinging to traces?

Dharma is like a tuft of hair. External dharmas are like the body’s bearing—without dharma, it is a loss of decorum. The opening lines, spoken by the ministers, plainly state *"loss of decorum."* Yet the subtlety of dharma’s empty nature is beyond those who cling to worldly dharmas. The minister says, *"I do not know,"* the king replies, *"Indeed, you do not know,"*—each weeping profusely, truly pitiful.

When the king repents of killing and the entire kingdom takes refuge, changing *"destroying dharma"* to *"revering dharma,"* it embodies the principle *"The Buddha has no fixed form; no abiding birth-mind."* For clinging to dharma is to destroy dharma; not clinging to dharma is to revere dharma. Thus sitting in Zen is sitting as Buddha; sitting as Buddha is killing Buddha. Clinging to dharma is fixing the mind; a fixed mind is demonic mind.

The Elder on horseback joyfully declared, *"Wukong, this principle is excellent, of great merit."* Already, all dharmas return to One—every aspect radiates the Dao’s essence. Sha Wujing immediately continued, *"Brother..."*

「Where could one find so many artisans of such craft?」
In the secular world, this is called *"losing decorum"* (失仪); in the Buddhist law, it is called *"crafting appearances"* (整容).
Though seemingly opposed, they mutually complement each other—such is the law’s refusal to be rigidly fixed.
This is the principle that *dharma has no fixed form*, its transformations boundless, its wondrous play unfolding through roots and mind.

The Pilgrim recited this once, then swiftly chanted the four lines of the *Heart Sutra’s Preface* (《多心经》四句《颂子》):
*"The Buddha is not sought afar on Spirit Mountain—
Spirit Mountain stands within your own mind.
Each person has a Spirit Mountain stupa—
Practice beneath it, and you shall find."*

The Tang Monk said, *"All scriptures and teachings boil down to cultivating the mind."*
*"When the mind is pure, clarity shines alone;
When the mind harbors dharma, all worlds grow clear.
A moment’s negligence breeds slackness—
No success in ten thousand years, no matter how long.
But with a single thread of true sincerity,
The Voice of Thunder resounds right before your eyes."*

This *"mind"* is the very focus of the two preceding passages.

The Monkey was of the *Jin-Water Hour* (金水), the Pig of the *Hai-Wood-Fire Hour* (亥木火)—
Though they clash, they also complete each other.
The Monkey, laboring yet weary, harbors resentment from exhaustion;
The Pig, slack from idleness, deceives through comparison.
Below, it was precisely this negligence and lack of sincerity that caused the error—
Thus the sudden rise of wind and mist.

*"Eight Rules [of Conduct] shirks duty,
The Pilgrim deceives him, calling demons ‘good’ and mist ‘qi.’
Steamed rice, flatbread, vegetables—
Little eaten, but the mouth complains.
The horse must be fed first—
Fresh grass sought before its meal.
Fine food for the handsome, coarse for the ugly;
Mumbling ‘Great Sage!’ from his lips."*

Their words ring hollow, deceit between them—
Greedy, lazy, mouth and heart misaligned—
Is this not falling into the *Circle of Demonic Illusions*?

Had the Pilgrim not turned his mind inward and secretly intervened,
Their hidden deceit and broken precepts would have sealed their fate.
Thus, when the heart’s sincerity is absolute, demons retreat;
When the mind wanders, demons manifest.
Demons are not external—they are shadows summoned by one’s own heart.

Observe how the Pilgrim and Eight Rules were deceived by the clear wind and mist—
The demon, to deceive them, gathered the wind and dispersed the mist.
When the Pilgrim and Eight Rules sought to eat the offering,
The demon demanded the monk instead;
When the Pilgrim spoke of steamer’s vapor,
The demon scraped the pot to steam the monk.
Eight Rules and the Pilgrim disguised themselves as a short monk and false Pilgrim—
The demon became a false demon in return.
The Pilgrim employed the *Divided Body Technique*—
The demon countered with the *Sliced Plum Blossom Scheme*.
When the Pilgrim saw the demon defeated and turned back,
The demon retreated to its cave, silent and still.
The Pilgrim called Eight Rules *"Vanguard General"*—
The demon anointed a minor demon as *"Scout."*

Sincerity makes *Chan* the master, swallowing demons;
Negligence makes demons the master, devouring *Chan*.
Like the pole’s shadow or echo in the valley—
Blurred, indistinguishable.
*Chan* or *demon*?
One or two?

The demon bound the Tang Monk to a tree,
And the woodcutter likewise bound to the tree,
Each speaking of loyalty to lord and filial piety—
Their deepest, most sincere words.

The tree, with roots and branches,
Is the foundation of all things.
A just ruler and filial parent are the great Dao of heaven and earth,
While loyalty and filial virtue are the roots of human nature—
Both spring from the true nature of the heart,
Adorned with no false pretense or artifice.

To bow in devotion, serving with utmost loyalty,
And to nurture life while honoring death—
Not betraying the lord’s grace—
This is the true attainment of the sacred scripture.

To exhaust one’s strength in filial duty,
Nurturing life and honoring death—
Repaying the debt of parental kindness—
This is the true reverence for the living Buddha.

If one does not act from the root of true nature,
But instead feigns loyalty and filial piety in outward show,
Then it is like the hidden leopard of Aiyue Mountain,
Wielding the staff of demon-subduing in reverse—
Devouring *Chan* while disguised as virtue.

Lost in the root, cloaked in false filiality as demon—
How easily one may be lamented and defeated!

Oh, Three Treasures and woodcutter—
How could they not be moved to sorrow and grief?

The profound meaning leaps beyond the text,
Beyond the strokes of the brush.

Is it plain?
Or wondrous?
Can it be contemplated and imitated?
Or is it beyond contemplation and imitation?

chunks.original_text: 第八十六回　木母助威征怪物　金公施法灭妖邪 悟一子曰：此承上篇，言禅心被障。 由于怠欺，须精勤振摄，不可使一毫假借，然后能表里洞彻，通透连环也。 “隐雾折岳连环洞”，前解已明。 自称“南山大王”者，南者，《离》也，属心。 “数百年放荡于此”者，言由久放其心而成，故特提出李老君、佛如来、孔夫子三教大圣人，以证其自尊自大之妄。 五祖云：“身是菩提树，心如明镜台。 时时勤拂拭，不使惹尘埃。 ”进而言之：“菩提本无树，明镜亦无台。 本来无一物，何处惹尘埃。 ”虽有安勉之殊，总明心体之宜明净也。 猪属亥，亥为木； 猴属申，申为金。 不合则金能克木，而成妒，合则金能生水以生木，木中之火亦能生土以生金，故能助。 金木有相制之义，亦有相成之理，金得水火而成真金，木得金水而滋生息。 原作夫妻配偶，终不相离也。 夫妻和而家道成，金水调而身命理，是水固和宁内安外攘之道，此邪魔所以从此收伏也。 然则魔若外至，而实自心生。 故心之所为，魔知之； 魔之所为，心知之。 行者知是“分瓣梅花计”，又知“此间妖精住处，师父必在他家”，俱是自心察识。 而特不可认假以为真，如妖精以绝不相似之柳树，做假人头，此假易辨； 而特恐似真者为难辨也，如妖精以鲜人头做真师父，似是而非，最难察识。 此行者兄弟所以不觉一齐大哭矣。 明真假之分甚微，而是非之端易淆也。 然则此一哭也，岂行者果信为实然，而率众大哭耶？ 悲素丝可青而可黄，歧路可东而可西。 一齐大哭，寓意深矣！ 夫惟大哭，而后可即假以为真，亦可寻真以弃假。 何也？ 哭者，心之痛也，有声有泪，皆认真中流出，能发真心。 魔以假乱我，我以真自主，则邪不胜正，而魔自潜形。 所以“努力向前，把石门打开”，而坚垒可破。 昔之偷安怠欺者，一旦奋勇争先，而志趣精明，南山大王放荡之形状，不可尽识哉？ 行者前以假分身而起魔，今以真分身而除魔，“从外边往里打，从阵里往外杀”，合力同心，内外夹击，打倒用计之苍狼，堵住久放之老怪，然后静气存心，细察其门户，洞晓其源流，潜身直入其洞中，而真假毕露，大怪小怪，纷纷鹿鹿。 设计布害，果何惧之有？ 知其为魔，炼成真窍，诸怪自倒，顿皆寝息，即现出本相，而打破旁门矣。 夫而后真者显，假者灭，断其根，现其形。 艾叶花皮之浮障已除，而在我之真心无损。 此即樵子用心尽孝，感动高天厚地，死里逃生，得见亲娘一理也。 樵子曰：“如今山上太平，孩儿彻夜可行。 ”又曰：“这条大路向西不满千里。 ”噫！

The Eighty-Sixth Episode: *Mu* Mother Aids in Subduing the Fiend
*Jin* Father Applies the Dao to Exterminate the Demon

*Wu Yi Zi* said: This continues from the previous section, speaking of the Dao/Way being obscured by *Chan* (meditation).

Due to negligence and deceit, one must diligently awaken and discipline oneself—never allowing the slightest falsehood or pretense—then can one penetrate the inner and outer, and comprehend the interconnected cycles of cause and effect.

*"Hidden Mist Mountain, the Aiyue Leopard’s Linked and Pierced Illusion"*—its meaning was clarified earlier.

The one who calls himself *"Nan Shan Da Wang"* (Southern Mountain King), *Nan* (south) being the *Li* (trigram of wood) and belonging to the heart—
*"For hundreds of years, I have roamed here"*—speaks of his demonic form arising from long indulgence of the heart, hence he is singled out to refute his arrogance by invoking Laozi, the Buddha, and Confucius, the three great sages of the teachings.

The Fifth Patriarch said:
*"The body is the Bodhi tree, the mind the mirror platform.
Ever diligently wipe and polish it,
Lest dust gather upon it."*

Further still:
*"Bodhi has no tree, the mirror no platform.
Originally, there is no single thing—
Where could dust gather upon it?"*

Though their exhortations differ in tone,
both illuminate the mind’s proper clarity and purity.

The boar belongs to *Hai* (the eleventh earthly branch), *Hai* being wood;
the monkey belongs to *Shen* (the ninth earthly branch), *Shen* being metal.
When out of harmony, metal subdues wood, creating jealousy;
when in harmony, metal generates water to nourish wood,
and the fire within wood generates earth to foster metal—
thus it aids.

Metal and wood have both restraining and fostering relationships.
Metal becomes true gold when refined by water and fire;
wood thrives when nourished by metal and water.
The original pairing of husband and wife
never truly departs.

When husband and wife live in harmony, the household prospers;
when metal and water are balanced, the body and life align—
this is the Dao/Way of water’s inherent tranquility,
which calms inner and outer, repelling chaos.
Thus, the demon is subdued from this very source.

Yet though the demon comes from without,
its true origin lies within the mind.
So whatever the mind creates,
the demon knows;
whatever the demon creates,
the mind knows.

The practitioner recognizes this as *"the Plum Blossom’s Divided Petal Strategy"*,
and also knows *"the demon’s dwelling is here—my master must be in this very place"*,
both insights arising from the mind’s own discernment.

Yet the most perilous deception is when the false resembles the true—
like the demon crafting a human head from a willow tree,
which is easily discerned as false;
but far more treacherous is when it mimics the true,
such as the demon fashioning a fresh human head as the master,
seemingly real yet not—
most difficult to recognize.
Thus the practitioner brothers failed to perceive and wept together in lament.

The distinction between true and false is subtle,
yet the root of right and wrong is easily confused.

But why did they weep as one?
Was it because the practitioner truly believed in the illusion
and led the crowd in grief?

Sorrow can turn black silk to green or yellow,
and diverging paths can lead east or west.
Their unified weeping holds profound meaning!

Only through great lamentation
can one either mistake the false for the true,
or seek the true while abandoning the false.
How so?

Weeping is the mind’s pain—
with sound and tears, both arise from genuine sincerity,
able to awaken true awareness.
The demon confuses me with falsehood,
but I master it with truth—
then evil cannot overcome righteousness,
and the demon vanishes.

Thus, *"Strive forward, shatter the Stone Gate!"*
and the fortress collapses.

Those who once sought ease and slacked in discipline,
now suddenly rouse courage and sharpen their resolve—
the Southern Mountain King’s reckless form
can no longer be fully comprehended!

Before, the practitioner raised a false doppelgänger to summon the demon;
now, he employs a true doppelgänger to dispel it—
*"Strike from without, slay from within the ranks,"*
united force and will, inner and outer assault—
overthrowing the scheming *Cang Lang* (blue wolf),
blocking the long-indulgent old fiend,
then calming the *qi* and preserving the mind,
examining its gateways,
penetrating its origins and currents,
slipping unseen into its lair—
true and false now fully revealed,
great demons and small, all trembling in confusion.
What fear could there be of its plots and harm?

Recognizing it as demonic,
refining its essence to true insight,
all fiends fall, instantly silenced—
its original form exposed,
and the false paths shattered.

Only then does the true manifest,
the false perish,
its roots severed, its form laid bare.
The Aiyue Leopard’s superficial illusions are removed,
and my true mind remains unharmed.
This is how the woodcutter’s filial devotion,
moving heaven and earth,
escaped death and glimpsed his mother’s true nature.

The woodcutter said:
*"Now the mountain is at peace,
and I may travel through the night."*
And again:
*"This path leads west for less than a thousand *li*."*

Ah!
chunks.overlap_context:

Wielding the staff of demon-subduing in reverse—

chunks.original_text: 内外一体，表里洞彻，近在极乐之乡，道其庶几乎！ 第八十七回　凤仙郡冒天致旱　孙大圣劝善施霖 悟一子曰：此篇明修真者，必先积阴德，阴德未充，名虽美而无用，功垂成而忽隳，鬼神不能默佑，事业总属虚文，急须返躬内省，发大慈悲，戒谨精进，广施阴德。 何谓阴德？ 修己之天，以敬人之天，阴德也； 暗中行方便，阴德也； 施与不图报，阴德也； 积善无人知，阴德也； 不迫人于险，阴德也； 隐人之丑恶，阴德也。 经云：“彼以祸来，我以福往； 彼以怨来，我以德往。 ”皆阴德之事，解灾消孽，广大无边。 《悟真》曰“大乐修之有易知”也，知由我，亦由天。 若非积行修阴德，动有群魔作孽障。 盖我命不由天，是造化之妙存乎我； 由我亦由天，默想之功存乎天。 行者道：“但论积功累德，老孙送你一场大雨，”是此篇的旨。 称“凤仙郡”者，跨凤登仙之美郡，今不能阴积功德而阳卜虚名，虽阳为爱民，实阴以害民，民命倒悬，守实主之，天怒其可回乎？ 然郡侯上官“十分清正”，“爱民心重”，求雨济民，乃万善之事，即此一节，善念无穷，何以不能回天？ 曰：此阳德，非阴德也。 盖十分清正，则过于明，偏于义，如阳刚之烈，故曰“不仁”。 《洪范传》云：“若明则旱。 ”明为阳刚，使无阴道以济之，膏泽不能下究，人事失于下，天道应于上，旱其征也。 故为上者惟存仁施济，广行阴德为要，不尚乎察察为明。 先贤有曰：“明而不恕，不如不明。 ”尧之三宥，禹之下车，汤之解网，皆明而恕也。 臣子食禄天朝，奉命守土，体国爱民，职分宜然，何德之有？ 明德者，非人所知，而天独知之。 至于“三年前十二月二十五日，上官氏将斋天素供推倒喂狗，口出秽言，冒犯上天”，乃阴恶也，亦人不及知，而天独知之。 夫民者，天之所生，天无不爱其所生，君子能体天之心以爱民，必受天之阴报，一定之理也。 爱民必自敬天始，故曰“敬天勤民”。 今上官氏不能敬天而反亵天，罪莫大焉！ 夫民以食为天，斋供者，民所仰食之天，天所养民之本也。 推倒喂狗，欺灭天、民，其为不仁，孰甚于此？ 故阳善万端，不能胜阴恶之一事。 是以圣人兢宥密，君子严幽独也。 夫阴者，独知之地； 德者，有得于心。 非沽名，非钓誉。 屋漏为康衢，梦寐同白昼； 精神呼吸，默通帝座，感应之速，有不捷于桴鼓哉！ 但获罪于天者，郡守也，何以降灾于兆民？ 守为风，而民为草：守不仁，则民不义。 上行下效，气类相感。 夙夜之负疚，酿成黎庶之隐忧； 一念之敬肆，播为苍生之休咎。 守造之而民爱之，理势之自然也。 故地方灾变之非常，必由有位之失德，其冒天致旱也固宜。 然天心至仁，每缓于罚恶，以容人之省悔； 亟于贪善，以诱人之进修。 又有阴阳缓急之各宜，如阴德每缓之，以俟积累而大其报； 阴恶则必速之，以彰显应而信其诛。 盖阳为人所共知，而阴为天所独知也。 虽有缓急之不同，绝无丝毫之舛错。 志之极明，加之相称，非天也，人自召也。

The inner and outer as one,
penetrating through surface and depth—
how near we stand to the Land of Ultimate Bliss!
This is the Dao’s true measure.

**Chapter Eighty-Seventh: The Phoenix Immortal County—Defying Heaven’s Drought, the Great Sage Sun Wukong Urges Benevolence to Bring Rain**

The Awakened One said:
*"This passage reveals that those who cultivate the True Way must first amass hidden virtue.
Before hidden virtue is complete,
even a beautiful name is useless,
and a half-finished deed collapses.
Ghosts and spirits cannot silently aid,
and all deeds remain hollow pretense.
One must urgently turn inward and reflect,
awaken boundless compassion,
observe strict discipline with diligent progress,
and widely cultivate hidden virtue.*

*What is hidden virtue?*
Cultivating one’s own *heaven* to honor others’ *heaven*—this is hidden virtue;
acting secretly with skillful means—this is hidden virtue;
giving without expecting repayment—this is hidden virtue;
accumulating goodness unknown to others—this is hidden virtue;
not forcing others into peril—this is hidden virtue;
concealing others’ flaws—this is hidden virtue.

The *sutra* says:
*'When they bring calamity, I bring fortune;
When they bring enmity, I bring virtue.'*
All these are deeds of hidden virtue,
boundless in dispelling disasters and karmic retribution.

*The Awakening of the True* says:
*'Great joy lies in what is easy to know,'*
for knowledge comes from both self and *heaven*.

If one does not accumulate deeds and hidden virtue,
demons and fiends will obstruct at every turn.
For though one’s fate is not entirely by *heaven*,
it lies in the marvel of creation within oneself;
and though it is also by *heaven*,
the silent power of reflection rests with *heaven*.

The practitioner says:
*'Only by amassing merit and virtue can I grant you this great rain,'*
—this is the essence of this passage.

The name *'Phoenix Immortal County'* signifies a land of transcendent virtue,
yet now it fails to accumulate hidden merit while boasting hollow fame.
Though it claims to love the people outwardly,
it secretly harms them.
With the people’s lives hanging in peril,
how can the true ruler appease *heaven’s* wrath?

Yet the county magistrate, *Shangguan*,
is *'tenfold in his uprightness'* and *'deep in his love for the people.'*
His plea for rain to save the people is a deed of boundless goodness—
how then does he fail to move *heaven*?

It is said:
*'This is outward virtue, not hidden virtue.'*

For though he is *'tenfold in his uprightness,'*
he is too bright, too rigid in righteousness—
like the fierce *yang* force,
and thus *'unbenevolent.'*
The *Hongfan Transmission* says:
*'If bright, then drought.'*
Brightness is *yang* force unbalanced by *yin* to harmonize it.
Without *yin*’s nourishing flow,
the land’s vitality cannot penetrate deep,
human efforts falter below,
and *heaven’s* response manifests above—
drought is its sign.

Thus, rulers must embody benevolence and relief,
widely practice hidden virtue,
and not prize mere clarity as wisdom.

The sages have said:
*'Brightness without compassion is worse than ignorance.'*
Yao’s three pardons,
Yu’s descent from his chariot,
Tang’s release of the fishnets—
all were brightness tempered by compassion.

Officials who receive *heaven’s* bounty,
holding their posts by imperial command,
must cherish the land and its people—
this is their duty.
What virtue do they possess?

True virtue is known only to *heaven*,
not to mortals.
Yet when *'three years ago, on the twenty-fifth day of the twelfth month,
Shangguan’s household overturned the vegetarian offerings for the gods to feed dogs,
and spoke blasphemous words, defying *heaven,’*
this was hidden evil—
known only to *heaven*, not to men.

The people are *heaven’s* creation;
*heaven* loves all it creates.
If a ruler embodies *heaven’s* heart in loving the people,
he will surely receive *heaven’s* hidden reward—
this is an unchanging principle.

To love the people must begin with revering *heaven*,
hence the saying: *'Revere *heaven* and diligently tend the people.'*
Now Shangguan cannot revere *heaven* but instead profanes it—
no greater crime exists!

For the people, food is *heaven*.
The offerings are what the people rely on for sustenance,
the foundation *heaven* uses to nourish them.
To overturn them for dogs is to deceive and extinguish both *heaven* and the people—
what greater lack of benevolence could there be?

Thus, a thousand outward good deeds
cannot outweigh one hidden evil act.

Hence the Sage is cautious in public and vigilant in solitude,
while the virtuous man guards his private conduct.

For *yin* is the realm of solitary knowledge,
and *virtue* is what one attains in the heart.
It is neither name-seeking nor reputation-chasing.

When the roof leaks, the streets become thoroughfares;
in dreams, night merges with day.
Spirit and breath silently commune with the imperial throne—
the speed of response surpasses even drumbeats!

Yet the one who has incurred *heaven’s* wrath is the magistrate—
how then does disaster descend upon the common folk?

The magistrate is the wind, the people the grass:
if the magistrate is unbenevolent, the people become unrighteous.
Above and below follow in kind—
*qi* and kindred natures resonate.
Day and night, his guilt festers into the people’s hidden anxieties;
a single moment of irreverence spreads as fate’s blessing or ruin for all.

If the magistrate creates it, the people will love him—
this is the natural order of cause and effect.

Thus, extraordinary local calamities
must stem from those in power losing virtue—
and this drought, defying *heaven*, is entirely deserved.

Yet *heaven’s* heart is supremely benevolent,
slow to punish evil to allow repentance,
and swift to reward goodness to encourage virtue.

There are also the appropriate urgencies of *yin* and *yang*:
hidden virtue is delayed to await accumulation and magnify its reward,
while hidden evil is swiftly met to demonstrate *heaven’s* response and confirm its retribution.

For *yang* is known to all,
while *yin* is known only to *heaven*.
Though there are differences in urgency,
there is not the slightest error.

When intent is absolute and aligned,
it is not *heaven* that calls—
but the person who summons their own fate."*
